description: The CCENT show is built around the exam objectives for the Cisco certification bearing the same name.  The episodes are meant for the entry level technician working in a small branch environment where he is expected to install, configure, operate and troubleshoot Cisco routers and switches.  Each episode will focus on the technology, why we use it and how to configure and or operate them for a small enterprise environment.

name: CCENT (2018)
subtitle: Cisco Certified Entry Networking Technician

episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

2

which we're about to get started in.

3

We wanna make sure that you understood

5

So let's take a look at my desktop
here that will help us to see.

6
00:00:21.800 --> 00:00:25.420
When we start off and we start taking a
look at the idea of doing the Cisco CCENT

show, we wanna make sure that you

8

When you take a look at that, the exam

ICND1 is the actual exam name.

10

And our show is gonna be named,
of course, Cisco CCENT,

11

in the idea of making sure that
they're all aligned together.

12
00:00:47.810 --> 00:00:49.200
Now this exam though,

13

14

Have you worked that out?

15

It's a little bit over an minute

16

So, you want to make sure you
take requirement a bit seriously

17

because Cisco exams are notorious.

Where the idea of not only of course do
you need to get the answers right but

19
00:01:09.280 --> 00:01:12.920
of course you need to get them
right very quickly as well.

20
00:01:12.920 --> 00:01:16.880
So make sure you understand that

21
00:01:16.880 --> 00:01:22.090
Now as we start to get ready for that
exam day and you're ready to go ahead and

22

take this, you're gonna sign
up at a Pearson VUE Center.

23

And you wanna make sure that you go

Cisco ID, make sure that you get

25
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:34.925
And this is where you'll need that
exam number that you'll be able to do,

26
00:01:34.925 --> 00:01:36.640
then you follow the instructions.

27
00:01:36.640 --> 00:01:41.370
Find your nearest Pearson VUE
testing center to help you out.

28
00:01:41.370 --> 00:01:46.230
Now as far as the exam costs go, I'm gonna

29

As of March 2017, so a little bit over a

30

we'll end up seeing that the exam

31

And when we start looking at it, it's a

of course the 200 series here and when you

00:02:09.244 --> 00:02:13.838
Now if you happen to be in other places

the easiest way to check the cost of this

website to make sure that you get all

36

Also, make sure you show up for

37

Bring the form of ID that you need to,
as they ask you to do so and

38
00:02:33.150 --> 00:02:36.180
then get ready to test for
the exam as well.

39

So what are some of the topics we'll

It's gonna be based officially off of

41

And if you're saying, well, where are the

it will probably lead

44

And on this web page,
you'll end up seeing that there is a link

down here where it says

46
00:03:02.660 --> 00:03:06.800
When you click on that link, then it will

48
00:03:12.510 --> 00:03:16.240
When you do that, here's what

49

It will, of course,
bring you to a breakdown of the exam

00:03:18.970 --> 00:03:22.850
by the percentages here and

51
00:03:22.850 --> 00:03:25.014
Now you'll actually see

52

that's gonna be 45 to 55 questions,

53

And you wanna make sure that you pay

54
00:03:32.130 --> 00:03:36.230
So during our show, we'll make sure that

55

56
00:03:40.540 --> 00:03:44.860
Which of course begins with the OSI and

57
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:49.654
We of course will break down and make sure

58
00:03:49.654 --> 00:03:53.620
as much as we can, to get you prepared for

59
00:03:53.620 --> 00:03:57.054
Also, we'll be heading

60

which of course includes understanding

61
00:04:02.096 --> 00:04:04.300
the Ethernet frame format as well.

62
00:04:04.300 --> 00:04:07.851
Of course even some cabling

63
00:04:07.851 --> 00:04:12.900
basic VLAN configuration, as well as

64
00:04:12.900 --> 00:04:15.920
And you'll see that there's a lot of
different information in here that will be

65
00:04:15.920 --> 00:04:18.430
covering as we go on through the show.

66
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:21.930
Once we get through that, of course
there will be routing fundamentals.

67
00:04:21.930 --> 00:04:26.450
We'll be using RIP primarily to help us
understand the concept of routing but

68
00:04:26.450 --> 00:04:31.200
also, as our initial dynamic routing
protocol configurations too,

69
00:04:31.200 --> 00:04:34.210
as well as we'll be handling

70

We'll also be doing some inter-VLAN

71

even IPv6 routing,
we'll talk about that briefly too.

72
00:04:41.370 --> 00:04:44.381
So you'll see a lot of other

73
00:04:44.381 --> 00:04:48.915
Once we're done with the concept of
routing and switching, as far as the basic

74
00:04:48.915 --> 00:04:53.588
topic, we'll talk about of course
infrastructure services that also exists,

75
00:04:53.588 --> 00:04:56.767
DNS and DHCP are kind of

76
00:04:56.767 --> 00:04:59.292
And we've course what she set that up for
us,

77
00:04:59.292 --> 00:05:03.320
as well as the labs as we walk through
all these different concepts too.

78
00:05:03.320 --> 00:05:08.010
We'll configure NTP, our network
time protocol, as well as NAT for

79
00:05:08.010 --> 00:05:11.680
network address translation, that will
be a big part of what we'll be covering.

80
00:05:11.680 --> 00:05:14.377
And then lastly, we'll talk about
some infrastructure maintenance.

81
00:05:14.377 --> 00:05:17.810
Throughout in the entire series, we'll
probably be using some of the different

82
00:05:17.810 --> 00:05:21.750
technologies that we'll be covering
here in this bit domain objective.

83
00:05:21.750 --> 00:05:24.130
To make sure and
then we'll review them at the end,

84
00:05:24.130 --> 00:05:27.930
where there's actually a lot of different
protocols and some of the different device

85
00:05:27.930 --> 00:05:30.080

need to know about.

86
00:05:30.080 --> 00:05:34.267
In terms of securing the device and making
sure that you know how to maintain them,

87
00:05:34.267 --> 00:05:37.189
as well as do things like backups and
password recovery.

88
00:05:37.189 --> 00:05:42.000
So all these are actually
a part of the CCENT exam.

89
00:05:42.000 --> 00:05:46.535
Now remember for this exam, it doesn't

90
00:05:46.535 --> 00:05:49.084
certification knowledge
as you go into this.

91
00:05:49.084 --> 00:05:51.684
So there's no prerequisite or
requirement but

92
00:05:51.684 --> 00:05:56.560
it does require you to have a strong
formation in basic networking right away.

93
00:05:56.560 --> 00:06:00.480
So if you do not have that, it is
recommended of course that you go ahead

94
00:06:00.480 --> 00:06:05.180
and that you take a look at getting some
of that knowledge set before you start.

95
00:06:05.180 --> 00:06:09.181
But we'll be covering a lot of it
as a review at the very beginning,

96
00:06:09.181 --> 00:06:12.116
as it does cover a big
portion of the exam as well.

97
00:06:12.116 --> 00:06:15.764
Or another basic topic, right, that we
definitely need to discuss in which

98
00:06:15.764 --> 00:06:17.954
we will discuss in depth
will be subnetting.

99
00:06:17.954 --> 00:06:21.020
So we'll make sure that you
understand how to subnet,

100
00:06:21.020 --> 00:06:25.110
as well as how to actually get
faster at doing subnetting as well.

101
00:06:25.110 --> 00:06:27.460
Which is probably one of the main and

102
00:06:27.460 --> 00:06:30.760
probably one of the hardest concepts
that you'll have to be able to do

103
00:06:30.760 --> 00:06:35.480
at a proficient level on
the CCENT exam too, okay?

104
00:06:35.480 --> 00:06:39.890
So, if you are getting prepared for
your Cisco CCENT exam,

105
00:06:39.890 --> 00:06:43.630
make sure you watch this episode and that
you review the concepts that are here.

106
00:06:43.630 --> 00:06:45.420
And if you are ready to get started,

107
00:06:45.420 --> 00:06:47.990
all you have to do is click
on the next video link.

108
00:06:47.990 --> 00:06:49.828
Thank you for joining us.

109
00:06:49.828 --> 00:06:54.986
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: The CCENT show is built around the exam objectives for the Cisco certification bearing the same name.  The episodes are meant for the entry level technician working in a small branch environment where he is expected to install, configure, operatate and troubleshoot Cisco routers and switches.  Each episode will focus on the technology, why we use it and how to configure and or operate them for a small enterprise environment.
episodes.title: What is Networking?
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.350 --> 00:00:03.503
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.503 --> 00:00:07.000
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.000 --> 00:00:08.490
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.490 --> 00:00:10.992
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.992 --> 00:00:13.550
>> Hello to all our viewers out there.

6
00:00:13.550 --> 00:00:15.930
Welcome Back to another great
episode here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.930 --> 00:00:17.600
I'm your show host, Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:17.600 --> 00:00:22.760
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our series in the CCENT.

9
00:00:22.760 --> 00:00:26.150
And joining us back in the studios is
our networking guru, Mr Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:26.150 --> 00:00:27.720
Ronnie, how we doing today, sir?

11
00:00:27.720 --> 00:00:29.310
>> We're doing fine, Wes.

12
00:00:29.310 --> 00:00:32.560
Thank you for having me back on
the show as we take a look now at

13
00:00:32.560 --> 00:00:37.610
the idea of what networking really is
about and why we also want to learn it.

14
00:00:37.610 --> 00:00:40.210
So, as we are beginning
in the series here and

15
00:00:40.210 --> 00:00:42.930
we wanna make sure that we
understand a few things.

16
00:00:42.930 --> 00:00:46.790
Most of the times when somebody gets
led into saying that certification

17
00:00:46.790 --> 00:00:50.550
track of some sort and saying,
hey, I want to earn the CCent, or

18
00:00:50.550 --> 00:00:55.180
the CCNT usually the question
of course brings it up like why?

19
00:00:55.180 --> 00:00:58.790
Why do I really care,
what is this really about?

20
00:00:58.790 --> 00:01:04.670
So, this particular episode really
focuses in on the where we begin, okay?

21
00:01:04.670 --> 00:01:07.570
The reason why we do
the things that we do.

22
00:01:07.570 --> 00:01:11.710
So, what we're gonna do, or what Wes and I
are gonna do is just talk about the basic

23
00:01:11.710 --> 00:01:15.490
communication process to at least
get us set on the right track.

24
00:01:15.490 --> 00:01:18.320
And then, as you start to get into

25
00:01:18.320 --> 00:01:21.460
the actual studies that not
only cover the exam objective.

26
00:01:21.460 --> 00:01:25.180
But also, you are learning
about networking as well, and

27
00:01:25.180 --> 00:01:29.130
learning it better, you can actually
see where all the stuff falls in place.

28
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:31.650
So, we wanna, of course,
start off with this idea, so

29
00:01:31.650 --> 00:01:34.910
that you have a great understanding
of what the communication process is.

30
00:01:34.910 --> 00:01:37.590
And then, we were transferred
over into the computer world and

31
00:01:37.590 --> 00:01:38.780
to networking world.

32
00:01:38.780 --> 00:01:41.600
And then, of course,
we'll actually talk out why in the world

33
00:01:41.600 --> 00:01:45.510
we really want to begin to learn
this especially for the future, for

34
00:01:45.510 --> 00:01:47.780
those either heading to the IT career.

35
00:01:47.780 --> 00:01:49.646
This is a great place to begin here.

36
00:01:49.646 --> 00:01:54.430
All right, so, Wes, as we start to
take a look at these concepts and

37
00:01:54.430 --> 00:01:57.100
the idea of networking when I first began,

38
00:01:57.100 --> 00:02:01.920
Wes, I really didn't understand like
why does it really matter, okay.

39
00:02:01.920 --> 00:02:05.140
What is the point,
what is it that we really want to get to.

40
00:02:05.140 --> 00:02:09.090
But it really took a little
bit of time before I realize

41
00:02:09.090 --> 00:02:12.680
that learning on a computer
by itself it works.

42
00:02:12.680 --> 00:02:17.330
But with out me as she also being able
to communicate with another computer and

43
00:02:17.330 --> 00:02:19.880
being able to connect to another computer.

44
00:02:19.880 --> 00:02:22.270
It really is kinda very lonely venture,
and

45
00:02:22.270 --> 00:02:24.730
the very fact that I'm not
getting much work done.

46
00:02:24.730 --> 00:02:26.650
I'm getting a little bit of work done, but

47
00:02:26.650 --> 00:02:30.609
a standalone computer by itself it really
only accomplishes what you need it to do.

48
00:02:30.609 --> 00:02:32.850
But it may not help out anything else and

49
00:02:32.850 --> 00:02:35.630
in the society that we live in
computers aren't connected,

50
00:02:35.630 --> 00:02:39.690
because it's together that they really
do form a little bit more powerful.

51
00:02:39.690 --> 00:02:42.970
So, that's why we're actually
starting her at this point,

52
00:02:42.970 --> 00:02:43.890
which is what we want to do.

53
00:02:43.890 --> 00:02:45.960
>> You know, Ronnie,
one of the things I was thinking of,

54
00:02:45.960 --> 00:02:48.110
right there in the name is
networking technician, right.

55
00:02:48.110 --> 00:02:52.144
And networking is about communication, but
when it comes to communication, what is

56
00:02:52.144 --> 00:02:55.851
it, Ronnie, that it takes for essentially
a couple of nodes to communicate?

57
00:02:55.851 --> 00:02:58.640
>> Right, so
let's start with just you and me first.

58
00:02:58.640 --> 00:03:01.630
Okay, and instead of going
directly into the computer node

59
00:03:01.630 --> 00:03:04.970
most of the time we don't think
about the process of communication.

60
00:03:04.970 --> 00:03:06.940
And that's, because you and

61
00:03:06.940 --> 00:03:12.110
I have learned to do this from the time
that our parents started to talk to us.

62
00:03:12.110 --> 00:03:16.638
We made faces, we kinda made some gurgling
sounds, our parents would communicate with

63
00:03:16.638 --> 00:03:19.770
us, we'd respond back stuff
like that would end up happen.

64
00:03:19.770 --> 00:03:23.902
But as we continued to grow, and
started to learn a little bit more,

65
00:03:23.902 --> 00:03:28.618
we started to realize something,
that there is a process to communication,

66
00:03:28.618 --> 00:03:31.870
because it's not just
enough that I say things.

67
00:03:31.870 --> 00:03:36.370
Okay, what has to happen in the entire
communication process at least between two

68
00:03:36.370 --> 00:03:41.320
individuals, is not only is there a source
in other words somebody saying something.

69
00:03:41.320 --> 00:03:44.280
But there is also going to be
the idea of a destination, or

70
00:03:44.280 --> 00:03:49.700
a receiver, in which somebody is also
listening to what's actually being said.

71
00:03:49.700 --> 00:03:53.590
So, in that sense communication
process at least involves, well,

72
00:03:53.590 --> 00:03:58.460
those two concepts, right?, you have
a source and you have a destination.

73
00:03:58.460 --> 00:04:02.810
And when you have both, then you can
begin that process of communication.

74
00:04:02.810 --> 00:04:06.990
Being able to get a message that you
want to actually have as a source, and

75
00:04:06.990 --> 00:04:12.860
then relay that to someone else that you
want to also know that same information.

76
00:04:12.860 --> 00:04:15.130
So, that's where the process begins.

77
00:04:15.130 --> 00:04:20.000
Now, Wes, when you and I think about
it it's not difficult in human terms,

78
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:22.840
because like I said,
we've been doing it our entire lives.

79
00:04:22.840 --> 00:04:25.710
But overall, Wes, if we were to break it
down, we're not gonna break it down to

80
00:04:25.710 --> 00:04:31.160
the smallest components, but if you and
I were just to break down that process,

81
00:04:31.160 --> 00:04:35.790
it actually is a little bit more
complex than what we think, right?

82
00:04:35.790 --> 00:04:39.570
So, let's begin to try and
understand the breakdown at the beginning.

83
00:04:39.570 --> 00:04:40.740
So, Wes, here we are.

84
00:04:40.740 --> 00:04:45.210
We're on the show, and we're talking about
the basic idea of communication, okay?

85
00:04:45.210 --> 00:04:48.710
And I want to relay the stuff that we're
gonna be talking about, of course, to our

86
00:04:48.710 --> 00:04:53.020
audience, as well as to you and to whoever
else is actually watching this, too.

87
00:04:53.020 --> 00:04:55.480
So, what needs to happen is
I need to formulate that.

88
00:04:55.480 --> 00:05:00.340
So, I think in terms of words and once I
have the words, now, Wes, that's in my

89
00:05:00.340 --> 00:05:05.810
mind, and Wes, you don't know what words
gonna come out of my mouth next, okay.

90
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:09.360
Because if you did,
you'd be telepathic, okay.

91
00:05:09.360 --> 00:05:12.070
So, Wes, are you telepathic by any chance.

92
00:05:12.070 --> 00:05:14.720
>> No, not yet, because if I
do I'd have the lotto numbers.

93
00:05:14.720 --> 00:05:19.010
>> Okay, so if you're not telepathic,
okay, that means somehow for

94
00:05:19.010 --> 00:05:23.910
me to actually be able to tell Wes
what message I want to give him,

95
00:05:23.910 --> 00:05:25.460
this is where it has to begin.

96
00:05:25.460 --> 00:05:30.080
I need to take whatever's in my mind, and

it means that we'll not actually

things that can happen along the way and

>> Yeah, we have multiple points
of failures that can happen and

But if I don't know

On my own computer, that I'm going to go,

Wes, I might not have done anything wrong,

The very notion is,
I might be doing everything fine, and

00:17:54.440 --> 00:17:56.620
somewhere along the line,
something broke down.

344
00:17:56.620 --> 00:17:59.230
A connector along the path is broken.

00:17:59.230 --> 00:18:02.890
A wire got somehow crimped the wrong way.

346
00:18:02.890 --> 00:18:07.010
A particular router is kind of
going nuts a little bit and

00:18:07.010 --> 00:18:08.640
it's just not allowing it through.

348
00:18:08.640 --> 00:18:11.450
Or it's actually having to take a long

349
00:18:11.450 --> 00:18:15.310
Whatever it might be,
it may actually be any of those problems.

350
00:18:15.310 --> 00:18:16.740
But if I don't know
anything about networking,

351
00:18:16.740 --> 00:18:21.520
Wes, someone that's actually really
saying, I'm troubleshooting this computer.

352
00:18:21.520 --> 00:18:24.460
I really have to begin and
end pretty much with,

00:18:24.460 --> 00:18:27.360
it's gotta be my fault

00:18:27.360 --> 00:18:32.030
A networking is actually what allows

00:18:32.030 --> 00:18:36.320
not only where things can go wrong but
what has to be established so

356
00:18:36.320 --> 00:18:38.560
that everything goes right, okay?

357
00:18:38.560 --> 00:18:41.390
So that's the cool a thing

358
00:18:41.390 --> 00:18:43.220
And Wes I've said it for years and years.

00:18:43.220 --> 00:18:46.770
Okay, the very fact is that
networking is pretty much the heart

360
00:18:46.770 --> 00:18:48.620
of anything that you do in IT.

361
00:18:48.620 --> 00:18:52.510
Okay, in any information
technology field that's out there.

00:18:52.510 --> 00:18:56.570
If you don't understand the networking
process, well, you're really kinda kicking

363
00:18:56.570 --> 00:19:01.510
out a foundational part of what
actually can go wrong, and

364
00:19:01.510 --> 00:19:04.740
then you don't actually have clue

So, we wanna spend some time, then,

the fundamentals of networking but

Now, Wes, when we talk about

it's only gonna help you as you get

398

So, Wes, when we start talking about this,

what we're really to do at

But this is something else I want

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie discuss and describe the OSI model used to describe how data originates from a source, accesses the media, traverses networking devices to forward data to the destination device. They also reveal that networking troubleshooting can also be based on this descriptive model
episodes.title: Understand and Apply the OSI Model
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

2

>> [CROSSTALK]

3

>> Hello to all our viewers out there,

5

welcome to another great episode here
at ITProTV, I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:17.465 --> 00:00:22.075
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our series in the Cisco CCENT.

7

And joining me back in the studios
again is Mr Ronnie Wong.

8

Ronnie, how we're doing today, sir?

9
00:00:27.235 --> 00:00:30.485
Thank you once again for
having me back on the show as we

continue our journey in
learning more about networking.

11
00:00:33.470 --> 00:00:37.972
And our basic fundamentals of networking,
right?

12

We wanna begin exactly
where we should begin, Wes.

13
00:00:41.324 --> 00:00:45.732
And today, we are talking,
of course, about understanding and

00:00:45.732 --> 00:00:47.426
applying the OSi model.

15
00:00:47.426 --> 00:00:48.080
Okay?

16
00:00:48.080 --> 00:00:52.630
So Wes, let's kind of rewind
our history a little bit here.

17
00:00:52.630 --> 00:00:53.131
And Wes,

18
00:00:53.131 --> 00:00:57.910
we're gonna kind of playback kind of that
little snippet of This is Your Life, Wes.

19
00:00:57.910 --> 00:01:03.170
So Wes, when you first heard about the OSi
model and you first started to see it,

20
00:01:03.170 --> 00:01:06.230
what did you think was going on here?
>> Boy boy,

21
00:01:06.230 --> 00:01:08.451
why didn't I just take the blue pill?
>> [LAUGH]

22
00:01:08.451 --> 00:01:11.049
>> That's for sure, a lot of terminology,

23
00:01:11.049 --> 00:01:15.960
and I remember when I first see the OSI
model saying what have I got myself into.

24
00:01:17.580 --> 00:01:21.860
At first, you think a lot of theory but
apparently this OSI model,

25
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:26.640
it has a lot of benefits in
your learning networks as well

26
00:01:26.640 --> 00:01:30.930
as your continued network administration.
>> Yeah, so Wes,

27
00:01:30.930 --> 00:01:34.680
once we start talking about this idea and
you're gonna hear about it over and

28
00:01:34.680 --> 00:01:38.640
over again, throughout the entire series,
we're gonna be referring to the model that

29
00:01:38.640 --> 00:01:41.780
we'll be discussing right here and

30
00:01:41.780 --> 00:01:44.264
It really depends on how much I talk,
Wes, and

31
00:01:44.264 --> 00:01:46.892
how much you talk on this

32

But we want to, of course, make sure

33
00:01:50.374 --> 00:01:54.386
we also want to guide you through a little
bit about the history of it because it's

34
00:01:54.386 --> 00:01:57.178
actually very interesting
a little bit of the history.

35
00:01:57.178 --> 00:02:00.543
And then of course why do we
want to really learn it and

36
00:02:00.543 --> 00:02:03.860
then how does it help us in networking,
okay?

37
00:02:03.860 --> 00:02:08.050
So I wanna make sure that we cover
all of that and get down to it so

38
00:02:08.050 --> 00:02:11.840
that we understand the way that
things actually ended up developing.

39
00:02:11.840 --> 00:02:16.700
Now Wes, networking that,
as it exists today in the 21st century,

40
00:02:16.700 --> 00:02:20.780
is not how it always worked in the past.

41
00:02:20.780 --> 00:02:23.045
So if we go back historically, okay?

42
00:02:23.045 --> 00:02:27.590
Even before Wes's day which is now so
long ago that Wes doesn't remember.

43
00:02:27.590 --> 00:02:29.820
So as we go back in history,

44
00:02:29.820 --> 00:02:34.310
even before that point in time, what you
and I actually have to understand is

45
00:02:34.310 --> 00:02:39.750
that networking is not really
the unified way that it is done today.

46
00:02:39.750 --> 00:02:44.400
And what I mean by that is that it
was actually a very diverse landscape

47
00:02:44.400 --> 00:02:47.690
of different networking
models that were out there.

48
00:02:47.690 --> 00:02:50.860
So let me show you what I'm talking
about right here on my screen and

49
00:02:50.860 --> 00:02:52.910
this will help us out a little bit more.

50
00:02:52.910 --> 00:02:56.467
Okay?
So before the days of the OSI model, okay?

51
00:02:56.467 --> 00:03:00.850
We ended up having what we call
different proprietary networking models.

52
00:03:00.850 --> 00:03:04.400
Now let's make sure that we understand
the term and the idea here.

53
00:03:04.400 --> 00:03:06.480
Okay?
When we talk about proprietary,

54
00:03:06.480 --> 00:03:08.640
that means somebody else owned it.

55
00:03:08.640 --> 00:03:11.350
And that normally, for
at least networking,

56
00:03:11.350 --> 00:03:16.170
usually meant some hardware vendor or some
software vendor ended up owning, okay?

57
00:03:16.170 --> 00:03:19.300
The way that they did networking.

58
00:03:19.300 --> 00:03:20.600
Okay?
So that's what you have.

59
00:03:20.600 --> 00:03:24.710
So you might see, if you continue to read
blogs about the legacy networking models

60
00:03:24.710 --> 00:03:28.710
that are out there, you might
hear the term vendor proprietary,

61
00:03:28.710 --> 00:03:31.040
networking models, whatever it might be.

62
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:32.420
Okay?
So what you would end up

63
00:03:32.420 --> 00:03:33.432
having then, okay?

64
00:03:33.432 --> 00:03:35.110
At some point, right?

65
00:03:35.110 --> 00:03:36.990
Is that someone would
choose a networking model?

66
00:03:36.990 --> 00:03:39.450
So I'll just pick on this on
this one on the left-hand side,

67
00:03:39.450 --> 00:03:41.930
DEC, Digital Equipment Corporation.

68
00:03:41.930 --> 00:03:44.252
They came up with their
own networking model,

69
00:03:44.252 --> 00:03:47.056
the way that their computers
should be able to network.

70
00:03:47.056 --> 00:03:52.227
And so that meant that when computers
communicated, so it just has the beginning

71
00:03:52.227 --> 00:03:57.333
opening salvo of communication, as long
as those computers spoke DEC, okay?

72
00:03:57.333 --> 00:04:01.401
As their networking protocol, in other
words, you had two computers as long as

73
00:04:01.401 --> 00:04:05.530
they were using the DEC communication
model, well, one would say hello.

74
00:04:05.530 --> 00:04:06.860
Right?
The source.

75
00:04:06.860 --> 00:04:08.970
And then the other person
on the other side or

76
00:04:08.970 --> 00:04:11.660
the other computer on the other
side would understand and go, hey.

77
00:04:11.660 --> 00:04:13.480
We're speaking the same language.

78
00:04:13.480 --> 00:04:15.500
We're using the same protocols.

79
00:04:15.500 --> 00:04:17.820
I understand what it is
you're communicating.

80
00:04:17.820 --> 00:04:18.500
Okay?

81
00:04:18.500 --> 00:04:21.227
So that actually did end up working.

82
00:04:21.227 --> 00:04:23.138
Now the problem that we have, okay?

83
00:04:23.138 --> 00:04:28.162
That ends up happening as well is that
when you start to actually take a look

84
00:04:28.162 --> 00:04:32.863
around, some networks then adopted DEC,
which is perfectly fine,

85
00:04:32.863 --> 00:04:37.746
others might have ended up adopting SNA,
or AppleTalk, or IPX/SPX.

86
00:04:37.746 --> 00:04:38.560
Okay?

87
00:04:38.560 --> 00:04:43.405
Or even this guys down here, XNS and
DSA, as you start doing all of these.

88
00:04:43.405 --> 00:04:43.970
Okay?

89
00:04:43.970 --> 00:04:46.630
All these were actually
different companies, right?

90
00:04:46.630 --> 00:04:49.300
So DEC was actually DEC.

onto our network, okay?

477
00:29:43.130 --> 00:29:45.930
But to ensure that it
doesn't get lost either,

478
00:29:45.930 --> 00:29:48.850
we're gonna put sequencing
information on it.

479
00:29:48.850 --> 00:29:52.160
The other thing that we're gonna do
is because of sequencing information,

480
00:29:52.160 --> 00:29:55.130
we're going to be able to establish
error recovery on the other end, too.

481
00:29:55.130 --> 00:29:59.420
So it adds in a ton of information because
it knows it's going across network and

482
00:29:59.420 --> 00:30:01.160
it doesn't wanna lose anything.

483
00:30:01.160 --> 00:30:06.440
So the transport layer can, optionally,
give us that benefit to do this.

484
00:30:06.440 --> 00:30:08.050
Now once we do that,
that's called a layer 4 PDU.

485
00:30:08.050 --> 00:30:11.950
Now the other term that I want
you to associate at this layer,

486
00:30:11.950 --> 00:30:14.120
though, is right here, okay?

487
00:30:14.120 --> 00:30:15.590
Which is the segment.

488
00:30:16.690 --> 00:30:21.250
Now this particular term segment, it is
all about that chunking of the data, okay?

489
00:30:21.250 --> 00:30:24.910
But that's what we also call it,
we call it a segment of data at

490
00:30:24.910 --> 00:30:27.880
layer 4 on the OSI model.
>> So

491
00:30:27.880 --> 00:30:31.310
if your computer goes to put that
box out there on that network and

492
00:30:31.310 --> 00:30:34.140
that box is too big, it's going to say,
well, wait a second here,

493
00:30:34.140 --> 00:30:38.750
I can't handle that box but what I can
handle is a lot of small individual boxes.

494
00:30:38.750 --> 00:30:42.280
And then I'll go ahead and mark each
one of those boxes so that we know

495
00:30:42.280 --> 00:30:44.570
what we should expect on the other end.
>> Right, so

496
00:30:44.570 --> 00:30:47.170
there's plenty of stuff that
we're actually seeing it.

497
00:30:47.170 --> 00:30:52.230
So now I'm notice that at layer 4, as we
move from the data getting prepared for

498
00:30:52.230 --> 00:30:54.700
the receiving computer on the other end.

499
00:30:54.700 --> 00:30:59.520
Now we're starting to prepare the data to
be put out on network, we now have exactly

500
00:30:59.520 --> 00:31:03.930
what we need to make sure that it goes and
that it actually arrives properly here.

501
00:31:03.930 --> 00:31:06.710
But when you hear the term segment,
technically, that's what we're

502
00:31:06.710 --> 00:31:11.000
referring to is layer 4 data.
>> So we got all these boxes, Ronnie.

503
00:31:11.000 --> 00:31:12.180
And we've got them numbered.

504
00:31:12.180 --> 00:31:14.990
But how do we tell where they're going?
>> Yeah, and

505
00:31:14.990 --> 00:31:17.140
that's what we need to
actually be able to do.

506
00:31:17.140 --> 00:31:21.400
So the rest of our process,
in terms of what we call encapsulation.

507
00:31:21.400 --> 00:31:23.720
And notice we're calling it encapsulation,
because we continue to do what?

508
00:31:23.720 --> 00:31:28.240
Add in more and more layers at each of
these layers here, is what's happening.

509
00:31:28.240 --> 00:31:30.810
Now, Wes, we still have these
three layers to go, and

510
00:31:30.810 --> 00:31:33.220
we haven't even talked
about the receiving side.

511
00:31:33.220 --> 00:31:38.860
But I'm also noticing that I have come
up on the end of time for our segment.

512
00:31:38.860 --> 00:31:41.250
So it looks like that we need
to hang on a little bit, and

513
00:31:41.250 --> 00:31:42.930
we'll discuss the rest of this.

514
00:31:42.930 --> 00:31:46.990
And then pickup on how the receiving
computer handles this information as well.

515
00:31:46.990 --> 00:31:47.510
>> Ronnie,

516
00:31:47.510 --> 00:31:51.170
we have that capability the way you're
thoroughly just giving us the information

517
00:31:51.170 --> 00:31:54.870
that we need to know, a lot of moving
components when it comes to the OSI model.

518
00:31:54.870 --> 00:31:58.020
I look forward to seeing part
three here because, well,

519
00:31:58.020 --> 00:31:59.580
we have a lot more to talk about.

520
00:31:59.580 --> 00:32:02.920
Remember, this is the foundational
information that is not gonna just benefit

521
00:32:02.920 --> 00:32:03.830
you on the exam.

522
00:32:03.830 --> 00:32:06.880
But like Ronnie and I have been talking
about in the beginning of this episode,

523
00:32:06.880 --> 00:32:09.870
we've been using it for
years now even though it is foundational.

524
00:32:09.870 --> 00:32:13.230
So it is crucial that you guys
stick around for a part three.

525
00:32:13.230 --> 00:32:16.310
Ronnie, as always we do appreciate
having you here in the studios and

526
00:32:16.310 --> 00:32:18.580
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

527
00:32:18.580 --> 00:32:21.440
Keep in mind, we've got a part three
coming up on the OSI model, but

528
00:32:21.440 --> 00:32:22.590
you're gonna have to stay tuned.

529
00:32:22.590 --> 00:32:24.990
Signing out for
ITProTV I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

530
00:32:24.990 --> 00:32:25.790
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

531
00:32:25.790 --> 00:32:26.850
>> And we'll see you next time.

532
00:32:26.850 --> 00:32:30.097
[MUSIC]

533
00:32:30.097 --> 00:32:35.850
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie complete the encapsulation process. They associate other terminology like "segment," "packet," and "frame." They also describe how L2 PDU is the data that is converted to signal, impulses or bits that is put on the wire as a complete set of data that is ready for the network.  They also show the destination device uses the headers to process the data.
episodes.title: Understand and Apply the OSI Model Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:03.480
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:03.480 --> 00:00:08.468
I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.468 --> 00:00:10.891
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.220 --> 00:00:13.620
Hello to our TV viewers out there.

5
00:00:13.620 --> 00:00:15.940
Welcome back to another great
episode here at ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.940 --> 00:00:17.660
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:17.660 --> 00:00:22.230
And in today's episode we are continuing
through our series in the Cisco CCENT.

8
00:00:22.230 --> 00:00:22.950
And that's right,

9
00:00:22.950 --> 00:00:26.600
we're coming back with the Open Systems
Interconnection Model, the trilogy.

10
00:00:26.600 --> 00:00:30.290
That's right, and to help us up with
our Part 3 there is Mr. Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:30.290 --> 00:00:32.370
Ronnie, how we doing, sir?
>> We're doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:32.370 --> 00:00:35.510
Thank you for having me back on
the show as we continue our process in

13
00:00:35.510 --> 00:00:39.180
understanding more about
the way that the OSI model

14
00:00:39.180 --> 00:00:44.140
helps us out in getting data delivered
from the source to the destination.

15
00:00:44.140 --> 00:00:49.230
So in the last segment, we did pick up
on completing a table of information.

16
00:00:49.230 --> 00:00:51.910
Let's take a look at this
monstrosity again here.

17
00:00:51.910 --> 00:00:55.880
Just briefly, yes, we did actually
take a look at all that information.

18
00:00:55.880 --> 00:01:01.750
We talked about them briefly and your
goal as you prepare for your CCENT exam,

19
00:01:01.750 --> 00:01:07.190
of course, is to, I hate to say it,
memorize more than anything else.

20
00:01:07.190 --> 00:01:11.591
I'll put a link in there if I can remember
in our show notes to the official

21
00:01:11.591 --> 00:01:12.320
Cisco one.

22
00:01:12.320 --> 00:01:14.220
This is kinda the Ronnie Wong version.

23
00:01:14.220 --> 00:01:18.970
Take the official Cisco one, this is
me trying to remember everything here,

24
00:01:18.970 --> 00:01:19.700
is what we're seeing.

25
00:01:19.700 --> 00:01:24.290
And we are in the process of taking
a look at the encapsulation model.

26
00:01:24.290 --> 00:01:29.450
Now we had just gotten through
talking about the transport layer and

27
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:32.120
Layer 4 and the idea of the word segment.

28
00:01:32.120 --> 00:01:36.810
And I described at the end of the previous
episode that you wanna make sure that you

29
00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:41.310
associate the term segment with
transport layer data, okay.

30
00:01:41.310 --> 00:01:43.550
Or Layer 4 PDU.

31
00:01:43.550 --> 00:01:44.500
It is the same.

32
00:01:44.500 --> 00:01:46.800
It is equal at this point.

33
00:01:46.800 --> 00:01:51.610
So the idea of the PDU is
a very sophisticated way of,

34
00:01:51.610 --> 00:01:54.280
another way of saying segment,
is what it actually comes out to be.

35
00:01:54.280 --> 00:01:58.680
The OSI model prefers this
terminology right here.

36
00:01:58.680 --> 00:02:02.120
In reality,
Cisco uses the term segment as well.

37
00:02:02.120 --> 00:02:03.940
So you'll see both of them, but

38
00:02:03.940 --> 00:02:08.530
you need to make sure that you understand
that as we continue on, right?

39
00:02:08.530 --> 00:02:12.240
So now that we've gotten
a little bit of understanding,

40
00:02:12.240 --> 00:02:16.290
right, that the transport layer will
essentially break the data up, give us

41
00:02:16.290 --> 00:02:21.450
some error recovery that we need to have,
give us some sequencing information.

42
00:02:21.450 --> 00:02:24.140
We understand that that
means that now the data

43
00:02:24.140 --> 00:02:27.460
has to be able to get to its ultimate
destination, and Wes brought out.

44
00:02:27.460 --> 00:02:29.320
So now that we have it, what does it mean?

45
00:02:29.320 --> 00:02:32.610
Well, now it means that all
those chunks of data, okay?

46
00:02:32.610 --> 00:02:36.344
We need to put a dressing on each
one of those chunks of data, and

47
00:02:36.344 --> 00:02:39.171
that the network layer,
that's what it does.

48
00:02:39.171 --> 00:02:43.587
So whatever data,
whatever Layer 4 information that we have,

49
00:02:43.587 --> 00:02:49.145
it now also applies to each chunk that was
chopped up or to one chunk, the ultimate

50
00:02:49.145 --> 00:02:55.040
addressing, in other words, of
the destination of where it's going to go.

51
00:02:55.040 --> 00:02:58.320
So this is where it will put in
what we call the source IP and

52
00:02:58.320 --> 00:03:02.450
the destination IP,
meaning that this is where the data is

53
00:03:02.450 --> 00:03:06.530
ultimately going to end up
using this Layer 3 information.

54
00:03:06.530 --> 00:03:11.140
And we'll describe this process a little
bit better as we get into that on

55
00:03:11.140 --> 00:03:14.660
the other side when we see it on
the receiving side of the computer.

56
00:03:14.660 --> 00:03:15.810
So now, notice once again,

57
00:03:15.810 --> 00:03:22.210
encapsulating all the Layer 4
PDU inside of a Layer 3 header.

58
00:03:22.210 --> 00:03:24.320
We now get of course a Layer 3 PDU and

59
00:03:24.320 --> 00:03:28.500
the terminology has changed
once again to the term packet.

60
00:03:28.500 --> 00:03:33.060
So when you hear the term packet, there's
two things that go on here, especially in

61
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:36.280
reading about it on the blogs, and
hearing about people talk about it.

62
00:03:36.280 --> 00:03:38.820
You never know which one
people are going to mean.

63
00:03:38.820 --> 00:03:40.668
There is a generic term packet,

64
00:03:40.668 --> 00:03:43.686
which means anything that's
set across a network.

65
00:03:43.686 --> 00:03:47.477
People use that term all the time and
when you read about it in networking,

66
00:03:47.477 --> 00:03:49.923
you also hear people referring to packets,
and

67
00:03:49.923 --> 00:03:53.910
what they mean is really data
that's just being sent across.

68
00:03:53.910 --> 00:03:57.570
But when it comes down to some of
the things that you'll have to deal with,

69
00:03:57.570 --> 00:04:01.050
especially for exam focus, though, okay?

70
00:04:01.050 --> 00:04:04.430
Packet actually means that Layer 3 PDU.

71
00:04:04.430 --> 00:04:07.090
I know there's some specific stuff,
but yeah,

72
00:04:07.090 --> 00:04:10.540
this is the term that,
if you wanna go technical, right, Wes?

73
00:04:10.540 --> 00:04:13.510
This is the term that's been
abused probably more often.

74
00:04:13.510 --> 00:04:17.450
Because when people use it, you don't know
if they're referring to Layer 4 data, or

75
00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:21.990
Layer 3 data, or Layer 2 data a lot of
times, they're just packets being sent,

76
00:04:21.990 --> 00:04:24.160
is what they're doing.
>> Absolutely, I use that,

77
00:04:24.160 --> 00:04:27.010
I am as guilty as anybody
saying everything's a packet,

78
00:04:27.010 --> 00:04:27.580
right?
>> Who doesn't?

79
00:04:27.580 --> 00:04:29.120
>> But like you said, specifically for

80
00:04:29.120 --> 00:04:33.670
the exam, you're gonna have to be aware of
which layers these PDUs operate at, right?

81
00:04:33.670 --> 00:04:34.460
>> Right, so

82
00:04:34.460 --> 00:04:37.900
just make sure that when it
comes down to your exam prep,

83
00:04:37.900 --> 00:04:42.850
use the term packet when you think that
there're referring to Layer 3 PDUs.

84
00:04:42.850 --> 00:04:48.730
But in generic terms, people will use it
in any way, shape, form that they want to.

85
00:04:48.730 --> 00:04:51.340
So that's just a hint and
a warning to you.

86
00:04:51.340 --> 00:04:56.440
Layer 2 is the most interesting one that
we have here, because now that we have

87
00:04:56.440 --> 00:05:01.692
the ultimate destination, in other words,
where it's actually going to end up.

88
00:05:01.692 --> 00:05:05.300
Remember that the data might
actually reside on the same network,

89
00:05:05.300 --> 00:05:06.252
it's very possible.

90
00:05:06.252 --> 00:05:11.910
But there's also a possibility that the
destination computer may reside somewhere

91
00:05:11.910 --> 00:05:17.300
else, on a different network, and you
may have to actually go across multiple

92
00:05:17.300 --> 00:05:24.242
different devices before you ever get
to that network destination, okay.

93
00:05:24.242 --> 00:05:27.900
So it's very possible that
that ends up happening.

94
00:05:27.900 --> 00:05:32.210
And when something like that ends up
happening, okay, what does it mean?

95
00:05:32.210 --> 00:05:36.850
It means that not only do we know where
it's ultimately going, we also need to

96
00:05:36.850 --> 00:05:43.180
have the information that allows us to
put the data on its forwarding path.

97
00:05:43.180 --> 00:05:47.180
In other words, I may not know the whole
thing, but I know how to get it started

98
00:05:47.180 --> 00:05:52.030
toward the destination and
the data link layer helps us out there.

99
00:05:52.030 --> 00:05:57.490
It adds in a Layer 2 addressing,
okay, and this actually is

100
00:05:57.490 --> 00:06:03.310
what we call the source MAC and
the destination MAC address,

101
00:06:03.310 --> 00:06:06.850
that is actually a device
address at this point, okay.

102
00:06:06.850 --> 00:06:10.470
And this means that it can actually move
to the next device where the Layer 2

103
00:06:10.470 --> 00:06:12.230
information is going.

104
00:06:12.230 --> 00:06:15.390
And then it can actually be forwarded
to that device as well, and

105
00:06:15.390 --> 00:06:21.290
then move it along the path towards
that Layer 3 addressing that it sees.

106
00:06:21.290 --> 00:06:25.190
Now the other thing that Layer 2 does,
and you'll see it here at the end,

107
00:06:25.190 --> 00:06:27.250
I marked it so
that we could see it very clearly here.

108
00:06:27.250 --> 00:06:29.010
I have FCS.

109
00:06:29.010 --> 00:06:33.150
Now, Wes,
does that acronym mean anything to you?

110
00:06:33.150 --> 00:06:34.300
>> It certainly does.

111
00:06:34.300 --> 00:06:36.190
That's frame check sequence.
>> Yeah.

112
00:06:36.190 --> 00:06:38.371
The frame check sequence
is actually very important.

113
00:06:38.371 --> 00:06:41.790
Now, Wes, what's the purpose
of this frame check sequence?

114
00:06:41.790 --> 00:06:43.170
>> I think it's an integrity check.

115
00:06:43.170 --> 00:06:47.280
I need to make sure that the frame itself
there, when it's received by the switch,

116
00:06:47.280 --> 00:06:50.080
that it has maintained its integrity and
it hasn't been, and

117
00:06:50.080 --> 00:06:53.550
when I say compromised,
I mean whether network transmissions or

118
00:06:53.550 --> 00:06:55.160
some malicious transmission.
>> Yeah.

119
00:06:55.160 --> 00:06:58.310
The whole goal behind the frame check
sequence is to ensure that the data

120
00:06:58.310 --> 00:07:02.240
that's been moved along the path
hasn't changed since it left, okay.

121
00:07:02.240 --> 00:07:05.912
So when a device receives this data, okay,

122
00:07:05.912 --> 00:07:10.100
it's gonna actually do
a mathematical problem.

123
00:07:10.100 --> 00:07:14.656
And what should end up happening is that
the answer to that mathematical problem

124
00:07:14.656 --> 00:07:18.040
matches what's also in
this frame check sequence.

125
00:07:18.040 --> 00:07:22.070
Because the very first time when we
send that data, it's gonna put in that

126
00:07:22.070 --> 00:07:27.120
addressing information, then it's gonna
run through its entire thing here,

127
00:07:27.120 --> 00:07:29.060
and also put in a check sequence.

128
00:07:29.060 --> 00:07:31.760
In other words, it's gonna run through and
do the same mathematical problem,

129
00:07:31.760 --> 00:07:35.490
and then put the answer right
here in the frame check sequence.

130
00:07:35.490 --> 00:07:36.530
>> And when it does that,

131
00:07:36.530 --> 00:07:39.900
it will add it in here at the end,
so that the receiving computer

132
00:07:39.900 --> 00:07:43.890
can do the same mathematical problem and
get the same answer.

133
00:07:43.890 --> 00:07:48.890
If it doesn't get the same answer,
that means that somewhere along this path,

134
00:07:48.890 --> 00:07:53.100
okay, the data is no longer the same
as what was originally sent.

135
00:07:53.100 --> 00:07:56.227
Which means it needs to actually
be resent at some point too.

136
00:07:56.227 --> 00:07:59.711
So you name it, it actually has that
ability to check that too, okay?

137
00:07:59.711 --> 00:08:03.248
So now here you have a Layer 2 PD or
the term is frame.

138
00:08:03.248 --> 00:08:08.911
The frame is essentially what gets put
out onto the wire in terms of data, okay?

139
00:08:08.911 --> 00:08:15.040
So that is the last real step in the
encapsulation process, at least formally,

140
00:08:15.040 --> 00:08:20.537
of saying, here's all the data that's
gonna be put out onto the wire.

141
00:08:20.537 --> 00:08:24.421
Now we're not done yet, because once we
start talking about putting it out on

142
00:08:24.421 --> 00:08:29.410
the wire, we don't just put a frame, which
is a logical containment for you and me.

143
00:08:29.410 --> 00:08:35.610
All of that is actually transmitted as,
well, really, 1s and 0s, okay?

144
00:08:35.610 --> 00:08:38.022
Bits of data is what it's
actually transmitting.

145
00:08:38.022 --> 00:08:41.426
Now I added in bits here,
because it doesn't seem to make sense, but

146
00:08:41.426 --> 00:08:45.361
when you actually see it on oscilloscopes
and stuff, it just looks like waves,

147
00:08:45.361 --> 00:08:46.202
is what it does.

148
00:08:46.202 --> 00:08:49.394
But when the receiving computer and
the sending computer send out,

149
00:08:49.394 --> 00:08:51.357
it sends out as either an on or off, okay?

150
00:08:51.357 --> 00:08:54.503
Or a 1 or a 0,
if you were to actually see this, and

151
00:08:54.503 --> 00:08:57.300
that is what they generally count on,
okay?

152
00:08:57.300 --> 00:09:02.172
And now we take 1s and 0s, or
electrical signals, light signals,

153
00:09:02.172 --> 00:09:06.372
whatever you want to call it,
radio frequency signal, and

154
00:09:06.372 --> 00:09:10.749
we put it out on to the media to
then be sent across the network.

155
00:09:10.749 --> 00:09:15.030
Of course, then it actually needs
to get to the destination computer.

156
00:09:15.030 --> 00:09:19.005
Now, in that particular idea then,
we're not counting routing,

157
00:09:19.005 --> 00:09:22.785
which we'll explain the process
of routing a little bit later.

158
00:09:22.785 --> 00:09:27.544
But let's jump to the receiving side,
and so now it's hit its ultimate

159
00:09:27.544 --> 00:09:31.847
destination at this point,
at least it believes it has, okay?

160
00:09:31.847 --> 00:09:34.690
So now what will end up happening here?

161
00:09:34.690 --> 00:09:37.580
Well, on the receiving computer side,

162
00:09:37.580 --> 00:09:41.751
at the NIC itself,
it will start sensing the signal okay?

163
00:09:41.751 --> 00:09:45.440
That can be voltage differentiation or
whatever you want to call it.

164
00:09:45.440 --> 00:09:50.608
It starts to sense this, and
once it begins to take that data in,

165
00:09:50.608 --> 00:09:55.888
the data on the NIC, will start
seeing that it's a frame of data.

166
00:09:55.888 --> 00:10:00.420
It will have of course, a frame header
as well as a frame trailer here.

167
00:10:00.420 --> 00:10:05.911
And when it does that, it takes a look
at Layer 2 and the information here.

168
00:10:05.911 --> 00:10:08.634
And it says hey,
the destination map address,

169
00:10:08.634 --> 00:10:12.170
here's what the destination
MAC address is.

170
00:10:12.170 --> 00:10:15.256
The receiving computer takes
a look at it's own MAC address.

171
00:10:15.256 --> 00:10:19.560
At this point it says hey,
that's my MAC address.

172
00:10:19.560 --> 00:10:24.967
So it processes the layer two frame and
it gets rid of the layer

173
00:10:24.967 --> 00:10:29.853
two frame and
it begins to also process at layer three.

174
00:10:29.853 --> 00:10:33.867
Once it goes to layer 3, now that
has processed the layer 2 header and

175
00:10:33.867 --> 00:10:37.898
footer, because it matched up and
the frame check sequence was good.

176
00:10:37.898 --> 00:10:41.397
It now also looks at
the receiving computer and

177
00:10:41.397 --> 00:10:45.975
says the destination IP address
on the packet of information

178
00:10:45.975 --> 00:10:50.340
matches my own IP address,
that means that what?

179
00:10:50.340 --> 00:10:53.920
This packet of information was
definitely destined for me.

180
00:10:55.560 --> 00:10:59.800
Why, because it matched on the destination
IP address on layer three, and

181
00:10:59.800 --> 00:11:02.510
it also matched on it's
own machine here too.

182
00:11:03.590 --> 00:11:06.318
Then it continue to process on and
as it does it,

183
00:11:06.318 --> 00:11:10.362
notice that what’s happening at each
of these layers heer was right.

184
00:11:10.362 --> 00:11:15.230
We are removing the headers
as we move up the stack.

185
00:11:15.230 --> 00:11:19.450
Now, when we do that, that process
is called decapsulation, okay.

186
00:11:19.450 --> 00:11:23.130
And that is because each one is taking
a look at the header information.

187
00:11:23.130 --> 00:11:28.335
So now on that computer it's also taking
a look at the sequence information,

188
00:11:28.335 --> 00:11:31.538
any error recovery
information that it has to,

189
00:11:31.538 --> 00:11:35.380
any type of other information
that needs that later for,

190
00:11:35.380 --> 00:11:39.888
in terms of putting everything back
together as far as sizes goes.

191
00:11:39.888 --> 00:11:44.022
And it goes all right, so
I know that I've received this pack,

192
00:11:44.022 --> 00:11:49.327
everything is good, it processes layer 4,
and then on that machine it says

193
00:11:49.327 --> 00:11:53.557
I know exactly who this belongs to,
and I know where it's from.

194
00:11:53.557 --> 00:11:55.879
I know everything about
this particular packet and

195
00:11:55.879 --> 00:11:57.990
everything else that it needs here.

196
00:11:57.990 --> 00:12:01.050
So it establishes that and
it synchronizes and says,

197
00:12:01.050 --> 00:12:05.220
all right, I know where this is actually
from and everything's going to be good.

198
00:12:05.220 --> 00:12:07.063
Then at the session layer,

199
00:12:07.063 --> 00:12:11.159
it begins to once again process
through the layer 5 header.

200
00:12:11.159 --> 00:12:15.443
At layer 6, it says,
this is this file type.

201
00:12:15.443 --> 00:12:17.860
And does my machine
recognize that file type?

202
00:12:17.860 --> 00:12:21.260
It does, well,
then it processes the layer 6 header.

203
00:12:21.260 --> 00:12:25.380
And then it knows exactly what
application to pass that up into.

204
00:12:25.380 --> 00:12:29.300
And when it does that, that email program
on the other end, it opens it up and

205
00:12:29.300 --> 00:12:31.827
it goes,
that's the email program that I need.

206
00:12:31.827 --> 00:12:34.110
There's the email program that opens up.

207
00:12:34.110 --> 00:12:37.221
Wes now actually clicks on that,
and when he does that, or

208
00:12:37.221 --> 00:12:38.947
whoever it is on the other side.

209
00:12:38.947 --> 00:12:40.660
I think I used Wes as the sending guy.

210
00:12:40.660 --> 00:12:42.837
So whoever it is on the other side there,
okay?

211
00:12:42.837 --> 00:12:47.735
That Wes has sent that email to,
now opens up his email application and

212
00:12:47.735 --> 00:12:52.130
he can read and
understand the data, itself okay?

213
00:12:52.130 --> 00:12:56.335
All this happens with data as
it goes across the network okay?

214
00:12:56.335 --> 00:12:59.000
So, this is actually why it's important.

215
00:12:59.000 --> 00:13:03.373
You begin to see where things
can go wrong very easily right?

216
00:13:03.373 --> 00:13:08.840
So, for example, if it arrives on
the nick, itself, right here, right Wes?

217
00:13:08.840 --> 00:13:11.427
And let's say that it says, look,

218
00:13:11.427 --> 00:13:15.239
the destination Mac address
is not the same as mine.

219
00:13:15.239 --> 00:13:17.340
Well, what does it do at that point?

220
00:13:17.340 --> 00:13:18.983
That's what we have to ask, right?

221
00:13:18.983 --> 00:13:22.881
So if it doesn't match at that
particular point in time,

222
00:13:22.881 --> 00:13:26.750
it says that packet doesn't belong to me.

223
00:13:26.750 --> 00:13:30.797
If it doesn't belong tome I'm just gonna
get rid of it cuz there's no need for

224
00:13:30.797 --> 00:13:34.797
me to have a pack that I don't really,
doesn't really belong to me, okay?

225
00:13:34.797 --> 00:13:36.614
Let say it does match.

226
00:13:36.614 --> 00:13:41.910
Okay that is actually one of the places
along the path to the destination.

227
00:13:41.910 --> 00:13:45.811
It matches on the Mac address so
process layer 2.

228
00:13:45.811 --> 00:13:52.170
But then, it goes to layer 3,
the destination IP address though, okay?

229
00:13:52.170 --> 00:13:55.478
It doesn't match
the destination over here.

230
00:13:55.478 --> 00:13:58.980
And then it goes, wait a minute,
it matched on the Mac address, but

231
00:13:58.980 --> 00:14:01.410
I don't have an IP address for this.

232
00:14:01.410 --> 00:14:06.760
So I need to just go ahead and just put
this back out cuz I don't need it anymore.

233
00:14:06.760 --> 00:14:10.850
So in other words it says I'm
refusing this at this point in time.

234
00:14:10.850 --> 00:14:13.503
So it actually doesn't get past that.

235
00:14:13.503 --> 00:14:18.068
And even if it gets past that, let's say
that it's a partial part of the data.

236
00:14:18.068 --> 00:14:19.860
It's missing some information.

237
00:14:19.860 --> 00:14:25.112
Layer 4 checks it and goes,
I'm missing sequence 300, okay?

238
00:14:25.112 --> 00:14:29.601
I've got 100, 200, 400, but
I'm missing sequence 300.

239
00:14:29.601 --> 00:14:33.860
It knows it can go, all right, so I need
to resend a message and ask for what|?

240
00:14:33.860 --> 00:14:35.471
Sequence 300, okay?

241
00:14:35.471 --> 00:14:38.130
So I can get the entire message back in.

242
00:14:38.130 --> 00:14:41.054
So anytime that we have that,
that's what can happen.

243
00:14:41.054 --> 00:14:45.410
If it can't synchronize, if the wrong
presentation is not actually, and

244
00:14:45.410 --> 00:14:48.522
it doesn't recognize
the actual format of the data,

245
00:14:48.522 --> 00:14:53.330
then it doesn't matter, cuz the end
user will never get the data itself.

246
00:14:53.330 --> 00:14:57.478
So you can see why the OSI model,
in terms of its encapsulation and

247
00:14:57.478 --> 00:15:01.329
decapsulation of the messages
is really an important part of

248
00:15:01.329 --> 00:15:03.917
everything that we do.
>> Now I'm glad you clarified

249
00:15:03.917 --> 00:15:04.570
that, Ronnie.

250
00:15:04.570 --> 00:15:08.607
Because maybe somebody out there is
thinking it just goes from layer 7,

251
00:15:08.607 --> 00:15:12.988
sending from layer 1 back up to layer
seven when it comes to the receiving end.

252
00:15:12.988 --> 00:15:16.244
So what you're saying is in the process
of getting that information across

253
00:15:16.244 --> 00:15:19.500
the various networks, it doesn't
necessarily mean that it's going to go

254
00:15:19.500 --> 00:15:22.880
layer 7 to 1 and then layer 1 to 7.
>> Yup.

255
00:15:22.880 --> 00:15:24.160
>> We could see some,

256
00:15:24.160 --> 00:15:27.930
hey we're going back and forth between
these layers before we ever make it back

257
00:15:27.930 --> 00:15:31.210
up to layer 7 on that recipient end.
>> Right, so that's one of

258
00:15:31.210 --> 00:15:34.800
those things that's a little bit hard
to understand at the very beginning.

259
00:15:34.800 --> 00:15:36.112
Just exactly what Wes said.

260
00:15:36.112 --> 00:15:40.244
There’s sometimes it's not going to make
it all the way through and needs to get

261
00:15:40.244 --> 00:15:44.840
data resent and that is part of what the
OSI model helps us to understand and do.

262
00:15:44.840 --> 00:15:49.786
But it actually is helpful because if you
can understand this part of the process,

263
00:15:49.786 --> 00:15:51.947
troubleshooting becomes easier.

264
00:15:51.947 --> 00:15:56.718
Understanding where things break down and
on what devices that we have to check.

265
00:15:56.718 --> 00:15:58.262
>> So if we know that, hey,

266
00:15:58.262 --> 00:16:03.047
the router's not forwarding it, okay,
or whatever it might be or something

267
00:16:03.047 --> 00:16:07.628
like that, then we know that something
is wrong somewhere down the line.

268
00:16:07.628 --> 00:16:11.118
More than likely, it means that this L3
packet of the information was meant for

269
00:16:11.118 --> 00:16:14.260
the router, if it's not actually
getting past that router.

270
00:16:14.260 --> 00:16:17.570
So there is a lot of different
ways that this can come in handy.

271
00:16:17.570 --> 00:16:19.890
But for us,
it is about troubleshooting, and

272
00:16:19.890 --> 00:16:23.200
a lot of times, depending on how you work.

273
00:16:23.200 --> 00:16:28.180
I always like working from layer 1 all the
way through layer 7, so I know that when

274
00:16:28.180 --> 00:16:32.770
somebody says, I'm not sure if I'm
getting basic data or connectivity.

275
00:16:32.770 --> 00:16:36.140
I always check in the physical layer,
is this working?

276
00:16:36.140 --> 00:16:38.310
And that means,
are the connectors actually good?

277
00:16:38.310 --> 00:16:39.610
Is the cabling good?

278
00:16:40.830 --> 00:16:44.270
Do I know that another device can
actually do some of that, okay?

279
00:16:44.270 --> 00:16:48.400
Then you move up and verify that
layer 2 is working, then layer 3.

280
00:16:48.400 --> 00:16:51.960
Do I have all of these things
in the process of doing that?

281
00:16:51.960 --> 00:16:57.760
But for us, especially in Cisco, we really
do focus in on these first four layers.

282
00:16:57.760 --> 00:17:01.030
It's not that the last ones
are not important, they are,

283
00:17:01.030 --> 00:17:03.490
cuz that's ultimately what
we want to have happen.

284
00:17:03.490 --> 00:17:08.250
But since we're really focused in on
delivery itself, it really is these lower

285
00:17:08.250 --> 00:17:13.575
three or four layers that we tend to
focus in on in the realm of Cisco, okay?

286
00:17:13.575 --> 00:17:18.010
So it's one of those
things where if you go,

287
00:17:18.010 --> 00:17:20.540
I can get by without doing this,
you're not, okay?

288
00:17:20.540 --> 00:17:22.250
It's just not going to happen.

289
00:17:22.250 --> 00:17:26.346
The OSI model is that important,
you're not going to bypass this.

290
00:17:26.346 --> 00:17:30.270
But the issue though, Wes,
where it comes down to this, right?

291
00:17:30.270 --> 00:17:35.993
Is that we use this in teaching,
we use it as a reference all the time,

292
00:17:35.993 --> 00:17:40.480
but, Wes,
it was never really implemented, okay?

293
00:17:40.480 --> 00:17:47.960
And so it was never really implemented,
when we go back to this right here, right?

294
00:17:47.960 --> 00:17:54.710
I told you that there is another model
that is out there, which is called TCP/IP,

295
00:17:54.710 --> 00:18:00.020
which is a competing model
that we have out here.

296
00:18:00.020 --> 00:18:04.978
And when we start to take a look at that,
we are gonna actually find out something

297
00:18:04.978 --> 00:18:09.566
in the future a we jump into this one,
is that you're actually gonna end up

298
00:18:09.566 --> 00:18:14.228
seeing something that even though
the OSI model never really got popular,

299
00:18:14.228 --> 00:18:18.678
the TCP model did, it became very
widely adopted as a competing model.

300
00:18:18.678 --> 00:18:20.880
But even as a competing model,

301
00:18:20.880 --> 00:18:25.808
it still uses the OSI model to really
describe a lot of its processes.

302
00:18:25.808 --> 00:18:29.443
So we'll actually see another competing
model here that we'll see that was

303
00:18:29.443 --> 00:18:30.647
actually implemented.

304
00:18:30.647 --> 00:18:33.529
And do that and then we'll of course
compare and contrast them, so

305
00:18:33.529 --> 00:18:36.875
that we understand why it's actually
important that we know this.

306
00:18:36.875 --> 00:18:41.140
But this is a big chunk of data, a good
chunk of data for you to spend time in

307
00:18:41.140 --> 00:18:47.040
learning and memorizing, because this will
be much easier points on the exam for you.

308
00:18:47.040 --> 00:18:50.015
That's some of the things we will be
going over later on once we get more

309
00:18:50.015 --> 00:18:51.610
Cisco-specific.
>> Ronnie,

310
00:18:51.610 --> 00:18:54.470
you had mentioned in the very
first part of the OSI model here,

311
00:18:54.470 --> 00:18:57.430
you had mentioned some other certification
exams that are out there, right?

312
00:18:57.430 --> 00:18:59.720
I know I come over from
the CompTIA side of things and

313
00:18:59.720 --> 00:19:02.780
things tend to be very vendor-
>> Neutral.

314
00:19:02.780 --> 00:19:04.840
>> Or they attempt vendor neutrality and

315
00:19:04.840 --> 00:19:08.470
when you have such a large corner of
the market to specific vendors, sometimes,

316
00:19:08.470 --> 00:19:09.630
you do get vendors specific.

317
00:19:09.630 --> 00:19:12.700
But would you say that,
definitely for a CISCO exam,

318
00:19:12.700 --> 00:19:14.810
that we're steering away
from that vendor neutrality?

319
00:19:14.810 --> 00:19:18.640
And we really have to understand this
from the Cisco's mindset because,

320
00:19:18.640 --> 00:19:21.260
while there might be other people
that reference this model,

321
00:19:21.260 --> 00:19:24.010
ultimately at the end of the day
with a CCENT it's gonna be how

322
00:19:24.010 --> 00:19:26.530
Cisco references it.
>> That's pretty much the key

323
00:19:26.530 --> 00:19:28.860
as far as understanding
the differences here.

324
00:19:28.860 --> 00:19:32.055
The great thing is if you already have
that knowledge such as the CompTIA

325
00:19:32.055 --> 00:19:36.230
network+ underneath your belt and you're
ready to go forward, it's nothing but

326
00:19:36.230 --> 00:19:37.370
helpful for you.

327
00:19:37.370 --> 00:19:41.440
I guarantee that it has a big help and
what you'll be facing here, too.

328
00:19:41.440 --> 00:19:45.970
So even if you're seeing a bit of
redundancy on what you're learning here,

329
00:19:45.970 --> 00:19:50.190
it is going to become more Cisco
specific as we move forward as well, but

330
00:19:50.190 --> 00:19:52.820
it still means that
fundamentals are important.

331
00:19:52.820 --> 00:19:54.880
If you don't learn this process here,

332
00:19:54.880 --> 00:19:58.620
it's going to be much more difficult
later on as we get into other things.

333
00:19:58.620 --> 00:20:01.770
Especially in Cisco specific
types of terminology,

334
00:20:01.770 --> 00:20:05.000
that's gonna be hard to describe if
you don't understand the OSI model.

335
00:20:05.000 --> 00:20:07.700
So take a look at it if
you actually need to.

336
00:20:07.700 --> 00:20:10.190
Make sure you understand it as well and

337
00:20:10.190 --> 00:20:12.360
review this episode if
you need to as well.

338
00:20:12.360 --> 00:20:15.750
That will help out make sure that you
have a solid understanding before

339
00:20:15.750 --> 00:20:16.390
you to an exam.

340
00:20:16.390 --> 00:20:19.830
And you will see it's a good chunk of what
you will learn, what you will actually

341
00:20:19.830 --> 00:20:23.052
be tested on the exam as well.
>> Words of wisdom from Ronnie Wong.

342
00:20:23.052 --> 00:20:23.745
Now Ronnie,

343
00:20:23.745 --> 00:20:27.589
it does look like we are coming to
the end of a another great episode here.

344
00:20:27.589 --> 00:20:30.700
And we have been talking
pretty specifically about OSI.

345
00:20:30.700 --> 00:20:31.660
Before we wrap it up,

346
00:20:31.660 --> 00:20:33.850
do you have any final words that
maybe you'd like to impart?

347
00:20:33.850 --> 00:20:35.190
Maybe some new viewers,

348
00:20:35.190 --> 00:20:37.980
maybe this is the first time they're
going into networking when it comes to

349
00:20:37.980 --> 00:20:42.510
that Open Systems Interconnection model.
>> Yeah, you just have to be willing to at

350
00:20:42.510 --> 00:20:46.640
least memorize it for
this point as much as anything.

351
00:20:46.640 --> 00:20:49.660
I'd love to tell you that there's
a shortcut way to do this.

352
00:20:49.660 --> 00:20:51.110
I do not know of any way.

353
00:20:51.110 --> 00:20:55.930
So, you make sure you memorize this OSI
model and the layers that are there.

354
00:20:55.930 --> 00:20:59.090
And take a look at the information
that's available to you.

355
00:20:59.090 --> 00:21:02.960
Ask for help if you need to, especially in
different study groups that are out there.

356
00:21:02.960 --> 00:21:08.150
Cisco has a well-rounded community that
really is trying to help people learn and

357
00:21:08.150 --> 00:21:09.390
get certified.

358
00:21:09.390 --> 00:21:13.890
So don't be hesitant to actually look
in those places that are there too.

359
00:21:13.890 --> 00:21:18.770
So don't avail yourself of thinking that
you have to memorize this on your own.

360
00:21:18.770 --> 00:21:22.907
There are people that might have actually
figured out different ways to make it

361
00:21:22.907 --> 00:21:26.993
easier for you to understand, to veer
yourself of the community knowledge.

362
00:21:26.993 --> 00:21:27.852
>> All right, Ronnie,

363
00:21:27.852 --> 00:21:29.962
always great to have you
here in the studios with us.

364
00:21:29.962 --> 00:21:32.154
And always great to have
you the viewer watching.

365
00:21:32.154 --> 00:21:35.481
Take Ronnie's advice and make sure,
practice, practice, practice, and

366
00:21:35.481 --> 00:21:36.460
memorize this stuff.

367
00:21:36.460 --> 00:21:37.175
Get it under your belt.

368
00:21:37.175 --> 00:21:40.820
We're gonna go ahead and sign out here for
ITProTV, I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

00:21:40.820 --> 00:21:41.440
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss and describe the TCP/IP networking model used in the majority of LAN networks and on the internet. They use multiple examples to describe how the TCP/IP layers work. process. Lastly, they compare and contrast the OSI and TCP/IP model.

461
00:25:38.350 --> 00:25:42.233
So in TCP/IP, that's essentially
what ends up happening for us.

462
00:25:42.233 --> 00:25:45.350
So it does it in four layers today and
five layers overall.

463
00:25:45.350 --> 00:25:48.336
Because they broke out the difference
between the media and,

464
00:25:48.336 --> 00:25:51.450
of course something like our
Layer 2 addressing that they did.

465
00:25:51.450 --> 00:25:56.652
But you do see where this kind of comes
out for us in what we actually need here.

466
00:25:56.652 --> 00:25:59.927
So it's essential that we
understand those differences.

00:25:59.927 --> 00:26:03.821
Now when you take a look at
it compared to the OSI model,

00:26:03.821 --> 00:26:06.031
it does the same thing, okay?

00:26:06.031 --> 00:26:07.459
The OSI model, though,

00:26:07.459 --> 00:26:11.001

understand the end to end process.

00:26:11.001 --> 00:26:14.616
The encapsulation and
the decapsulation of everything.

472
00:26:14.616 --> 00:26:18.193
The TCP/IP model is really
more about the idea,

00:26:18.193 --> 00:26:22.100
how do I get it from one place to another,
okay?

474
00:26:22.100 --> 00:26:26.310
So it's not that it doesn't
do applications, it doesn't.

00:26:26.310 --> 00:26:30.500
So the equivalent that we tend to see,
let me make sure I can get this.

00:26:30.500 --> 00:26:31.880
Where did I put that?

00:26:31.880 --> 00:26:32.832

00:26:34.584 --> 00:26:37.124
So let's go ahead and
take a look at this full screen, so

00:26:37.124 --> 00:26:39.190
that we understand what we have here,

00:26:39.190 --> 00:26:42.936
When you line this up and

00:26:42.936 --> 00:26:45.395
make sure that you can understand this.

00:26:45.395 --> 00:26:49.041
I wish I could tell you don't worry about

00:26:56.260 --> 00:26:58.150
But make sure you can do this and

line these things up,
because it really matters.

00:27:00.838 --> 00:27:07.760
But for example, from layer five, all the

00:27:07.760 --> 00:27:13.827
make sure you can distinguish to

00:27:13.827 --> 00:27:18.461
And then of course,

00:27:27.537 --> 00:27:31.798

00:27:31.798 --> 00:27:33.110

So now that we have a comparison,

And then, in reality, right, it's because

OSI Model said,
we're developing a reference model and

00:28:08.585 --> 00:28:11.275

00:28:11.275 --> 00:28:14.736
TCP said, let's find the protocols first.

Let's find the protocols

00:28:20.282 --> 00:28:24.054
So that's really kinda the difference, and
that's why you see the difference here.

00:28:24.054 --> 00:28:27.478
But in reality, though,

00:28:27.478 --> 00:28:30.247
So today, even though we're using TCP/IP,

It's because it's easier to describe

00:28:43.907 --> 00:28:47.250

00:28:47.250 --> 00:28:49.090
So you're not gonna get away from it.

That's what it comes down to, and you'll

Now as far as I know, I'm trying to think.

00:28:54.890 --> 00:28:58.980
Just make sure that you also

we really did talk about

00:30:19.840 --> 00:30:20.750

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe and discuss the two foundational Transport Layer Protocols: TCP and UDP.  They compare and contrast and explain their basic breakdown, function and give examples of when they are used in networking.
episodes.title: Compare and Contrast TCP and UDP

The transport layer, it essentially

Whatever is happening here,

00:15:16.700 --> 00:15:19.880

they have to be synchronized before

00:15:44.270 --> 00:15:46.780

00:15:46.780 --> 00:15:49.450

00:17:26.950 --> 00:17:31.960

00:17:31.960 --> 00:17:34.880
It's because now,
this machine that was receiving it,

00:17:39.240 --> 00:17:42.170

00:17:46.320 --> 00:17:51.310

the left-hand side then goes ahead and

00:17:51.310 --> 00:17:53.950
says, hey, I acknowledge that

00:17:55.490 --> 00:18:01.090

acknowledge your synchronization.

00:18:01.090 --> 00:18:03.940

any other delays or anything else.

588
00:29:26.790 --> 00:29:30.310
It will kind of, you know,
make that happen as much as possible.

589
00:29:30.310 --> 00:29:34.059
Now, surrounding all this, to deal
with things like delay and gender and

590
00:29:34.059 --> 00:29:34.973
stuff like that.

591
00:29:34.973 --> 00:29:38.150
There's a bunch of other
things that can happen.

592
00:29:38.150 --> 00:29:41.324
But at least at the basic level here,
when we start to take a look here.

593
00:29:41.324 --> 00:29:48.055
It is really all about the ideas of what
UDP offers and why we'd choose to do that.

594
00:29:48.055 --> 00:29:51.900
And make sure as you get ready for
the exam, understand, of course,

595
00:29:51.900 --> 00:29:55.620
not only the differences between them but
also that connection.

596
00:29:55.620 --> 00:30:01.120
That layer four of the OSI model,
make sure that you get that down, too.

597
00:30:01.120 --> 00:30:04.570
But don't overlook this if you
have any doubts about this,

598
00:30:04.570 --> 00:30:06.290
make sure you review the concepts.

599
00:30:06.290 --> 00:30:09.400
Do a bit more reading on it okay.

600
00:30:09.400 --> 00:30:14.290
So my mind is kind of taking me back and
I'm going to figure it out probably later.

601
00:30:14.290 --> 00:30:17.410
But the sequence number I don't know
why that kind of confused me for

602
00:30:17.410 --> 00:30:18.800
a moment as I was reading through it.

603
00:30:18.800 --> 00:30:20.620
But I think I got it right at that point.

604
00:30:20.620 --> 00:30:23.780
But if I didn't,
you'll kind of be able to research and go,

605
00:30:23.780 --> 00:30:24.660
Ronnie got that one wrong.

606
00:30:24.660 --> 00:30:29.688
So just kind of realize but remember,
hey this is as important as anything.

607
00:30:29.688 --> 00:30:31.324
Because it counts toward the exam and

608
00:30:31.324 --> 00:30:32.870
that's the key.
>> Well Ronnie you

609
00:30:32.870 --> 00:30:35.910
got a whole lot more right than you got
wrong in my estimation, that's for sure.

610
00:30:35.910 --> 00:30:37.530
A lot of good information here,

611
00:30:37.530 --> 00:30:41.130
this is foundational networking
knowledge that you must know.

612
00:30:41.130 --> 00:30:45.200
Regardless of whether or not you're
getting ready for an exam for Cisco.

613
00:30:45.200 --> 00:30:49.100
This is the stuff that you
have to have locked down tight

614
00:30:49.100 --> 00:30:51.830
inside of your brain when it comes
to working in a networking field.

615
00:30:51.830 --> 00:30:54.675
So just get prepared for that,
this is gonna be your bread and butter.

616
00:30:54.675 --> 00:30:58.475
Ronnie you did a fantastic job in
my estimation of disseminating that

617
00:30:58.475 --> 00:30:59.597
information to us.

618
00:30:59.597 --> 00:31:01.300
So we could understand it,
It was very understandable.

619
00:31:01.300 --> 00:31:02.790
I appreciate your time on that.

620
00:31:02.790 --> 00:31:05.750
Appreciate your time out there as well,
but I'm looking at our clock.

621
00:31:05.750 --> 00:31:08.120
And I think it's ticked it's last time for
this episode anyway.

622
00:31:08.120 --> 00:31:10.070
Don't worry,
we got more on this series to come.

623
00:31:10.070 --> 00:31:12.930
But as far as this one goes, we're gonna
go ahead and sign off for ITProTV,

624
00:31:12.930 --> 00:31:15.430
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

625
00:31:15.430 --> 00:31:16.390
>> We'll see you next time.

626
00:31:16.390 --> 00:31:23.230
[MUSIC]

627
00:31:23.230 --> 00:31:24.630
>> Thank you for watching.

628

>> ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe some of the different networking components usually found within an enterprise network.  They discuss briefly the purpose of each device and where they are normally connected in the network path.  They describe the connection path from internet connection through to the end user devices.
episodes.title: Describe Enterprise Infrastructure Components
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

2

3

4

5
00:00:11.970 --> 00:00:13.883
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

6

welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.642 --> 00:00:19.974
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

8

we're continuing on with

9

Joining us in the studio today, the master
blaster himself, my good friend,

10
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:27.480
one Mr Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:27.480 --> 00:00:29.081
Ronnie, welcome back, man, how's it going?

12
