>> It is going great,
Daniel, thank you for

13
00:00:30.936 --> 00:00:34.070
having me back on the show as we
continue on in our journey here.

14
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:37.410
Learning a little bit more about
the networking fundamentals for,

15
00:00:37.410 --> 00:00:43.120
of course, the Cisco CCENT
exam as we start to do this.

16
00:00:43.120 --> 00:00:45.950
And also of course hopefully
giving you a little bit

17
00:00:45.950 --> 00:00:50.550
more knowledge as you prepare for
your next journey into networking.

18
00:00:50.550 --> 00:00:54.150
Remember that as we start,
especially on this episode, we're

19
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:58.630
taking a look at different enterprise
components that we tend to find.

20
00:00:58.630 --> 00:01:03.300
In other words, the security components,
the different devices, that you and

21
00:01:03.300 --> 00:01:06.060
I are gonna run into in networking.

22
00:01:06.060 --> 00:01:09.270
That we wanna make sure that
we understand what they do and

23
00:01:09.270 --> 00:01:11.050
where they're normally placed.

24
00:01:11.050 --> 00:01:15.450
Most of us that don't have much
experience at all in networking,

25
00:01:15.450 --> 00:01:17.740
we're used to working with
our own computer, and

26
00:01:17.740 --> 00:01:21.750
maybe with a wireless access point,
a couple of monitors.

27
00:01:21.750 --> 00:01:22.902
But overall, though,

28
00:01:22.902 --> 00:01:26.940
that doesn't describe anywhere near the
number of devices that we can talk about.

29
00:01:26.940 --> 00:01:30.353
And some of the functions that
those devices have in networking.

30
00:01:30.353 --> 00:01:34.385
And today we're gonna expose you to
a little bit more of that, show you what

31
00:01:34.385 --> 00:01:38.691
the impact of these things are, and even
talk about topology just a little bit.

32
00:01:38.691 --> 00:01:40.921
Because everybody does things
a little bit differently,

33
00:01:40.921 --> 00:01:42.730
so it depends on what you're doing.

34
00:01:42.730 --> 00:01:46.934
But the focus of what we're taking a look
at of course has to do with connectivity

35
00:01:46.934 --> 00:01:48.081
as well as security.

36
00:01:48.081 --> 00:01:51.172
So that's what we want to
make sure that we understand.

37
00:01:51.172 --> 00:01:53.573
There's really jut a few
different components,

38
00:01:53.573 --> 00:01:55.924
everybody will have
different flavors of this.

39
00:01:55.924 --> 00:01:59.792
Cisco, of course, has their brand of
stuff, which, since we're talking

40
00:01:59.792 --> 00:02:03.430
about Cisco certification,
that's what we're gonna be leaning on.

41
00:02:03.430 --> 00:02:05.080
>> Probably gonna put
the emphasis on that one.

42
00:02:05.080 --> 00:02:09.480
>> We are pretty much gonna put
the emphasis on the Cisco brand of things.

43
00:02:09.480 --> 00:02:12.850
So go figure, I wonder why,
but that's what it's gonna be.

44
00:02:12.850 --> 00:02:16.600
So let's take a look at my screen here,
that will help us to get set up and

45
00:02:16.600 --> 00:02:19.380
to take a look at as we get started.

46
00:02:19.380 --> 00:02:23.440
So different enterprise networking
components, well, depending on

47
00:02:23.440 --> 00:02:26.950
the size of your network, I've kind
of blown this out a little bit more.

48
00:02:26.950 --> 00:02:29.702
Not every network will have
every one of these components,

49
00:02:29.702 --> 00:02:31.582
but some networks will and some won't.

50
00:02:31.582 --> 00:02:35.430
Right, smaller networks may not
have anything but one of these.

51
00:02:35.430 --> 00:02:40.150
Networks may not have anything that's
actually on my screen except for

52
00:02:40.150 --> 00:02:43.190
a wireless access point of some sort,
or a wireless router.

53
00:02:43.190 --> 00:02:46.555
But for us, we're gonna take a look
at it from the enterprise side,

54
00:02:46.555 --> 00:02:49.997
which normally means better
infrastructure, different devices.

55
00:02:49.997 --> 00:02:52.938
As well as redundancies at times
that we have to know about, so

56
00:02:52.938 --> 00:02:55.441
we're gonna discuss these
different components.

57
00:02:55.441 --> 00:03:00.797
So today, in our episodes, we're gonna
take a look at the idea of firewalls,

58
00:03:00.797 --> 00:03:05.279
we're gonna talk about switches and
routers and access points.

59
00:03:05.279 --> 00:03:09.597
And some of the different terminology that
you're also gonna hear from Cisco as well.

60
00:03:09.597 --> 00:03:14.225
And make sure that we understand what they
do, just a basic overview of what they do.

61
00:03:14.225 --> 00:03:18.577
And then describe of course where they
normally end up functioning for us and

62
00:03:18.577 --> 00:03:20.730
what we want to take a look at.

63
00:03:20.730 --> 00:03:23.172
So when we start to build up a network and

64
00:03:23.172 --> 00:03:26.729
some of the components that we
may end up taking a look at.

65
00:03:26.729 --> 00:03:29.413
Notice that from right to left here, okay,

66
00:03:29.413 --> 00:03:32.546
I have the Internet over
here on the left hand side.

67
00:03:32.546 --> 00:03:37.567
And over on the right hand side,
really going towards our LAN environment,

68
00:03:37.567 --> 00:03:41.187
our local area network, and
trying to keep it linear.

69
00:03:41.187 --> 00:03:47.224
So that we kind of see that side as we
kind of go deeper into our network here.

70
00:03:47.224 --> 00:03:50.893
So not everything's gonna normally be
exactly this way, but at least linear,

71
00:03:50.893 --> 00:03:54.870
we can actually describe its
progression in this sense, right?

72
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:57.130
Now, when we take a look
at this diagram and

73
00:03:57.130 --> 00:03:58.800
some of the enterprise
networking components.

74
00:03:58.800 --> 00:04:03.770
Remember that in our network itself,
in what people work with every day, and

75
00:04:03.770 --> 00:04:08.063
the data and the machines that they're on,
and everything else.

76
00:04:08.063 --> 00:04:11.103
Those are components
that we want to protect.

77
00:04:11.103 --> 00:04:15.240
We also want those components to be
able to communicate with each other.

78
00:04:15.240 --> 00:04:17.670
And we want users, of course,
to be able to use them.

79
00:04:17.670 --> 00:04:22.550
As we move towards the left hand side
of the screen, ultimately, what we have

80
00:04:22.550 --> 00:04:28.250
out here of course is the Internet itself,
which we have no control over at all.

81
00:04:28.250 --> 00:04:33.360
So there are several components that we
may run across as we start to do this.

82
00:04:33.360 --> 00:04:39.210
Let's kind of start with the simple
ones that we tend to think about.

83
00:04:39.210 --> 00:04:44.850
On the edge of our networks, normally
in today's day and age, it can actually

84
00:04:44.850 --> 00:04:48.410
be a couple of different ways, but
let's talk about the idea of a firewall.

85
00:04:48.410 --> 00:04:52.060
Now, a firewall is,
actually I do have a little diagram here,

86
00:04:52.060 --> 00:04:55.000
of a little brick wall that is here.

87
00:04:55.000 --> 00:04:58.157
In the Cisco world they call this an ASA,
right,

88
00:04:58.157 --> 00:05:02.868
adaptive security appliance is what
this one's actually called here.

89
00:05:02.868 --> 00:05:07.941
And a firewall's basic function, okay,
really divides our network, okay,

90
00:05:07.941 --> 00:05:12.651
into a couple of different things,
or what we're actually trying to do.

91
00:05:12.651 --> 00:05:13.341
One side,

92
00:05:13.341 --> 00:05:19.270
usually there's a single port that we have
that essentially is an untrusted side.

93
00:05:19.270 --> 00:05:22.750
And that is what we
are protecting against, so

94
00:05:22.750 --> 00:05:24.970
that's what a firewall can do for us.

95
00:05:24.970 --> 00:05:28.120
And it actually says, hey,
here's what we're protecting against here.

96
00:05:28.120 --> 00:05:30.937
So the untrusted side means,
we don't know how much control or

97
00:05:30.937 --> 00:05:32.966
we don't know who's actually on this side.

98
00:05:32.966 --> 00:05:36.445
But we have that on one
side of the firewall,

99
00:05:36.445 --> 00:05:40.970
on the other side of the firewall
is the trusted network.

100
00:05:40.970 --> 00:05:44.487
Usually the components that you and
I have put together and

101
00:05:44.487 --> 00:05:47.520
the network itself that
we are trying to protect.

102
00:05:48.580 --> 00:05:53.290
The way that these ASAs end up
working by default is simple.

103
00:05:53.290 --> 00:05:56.980
On the untrusted side, nobody gets
in without your permission, okay,

104
00:05:56.980 --> 00:05:57.650
it's locked up.

105
00:05:57.650 --> 00:06:01.367
It just says, nope, you can connect me and
I can give you connectivity.

106
00:06:01.367 --> 00:06:06.046
But you're not actually sending traffic
that you don't know anything about over

107
00:06:06.046 --> 00:06:08.300
here on the right-hand side.

108
00:06:08.300 --> 00:06:12.977
So traffic coming in from the Internet
just trying to make an initial connection,

109
00:06:12.977 --> 00:06:17.203
the firewall says, you're connecting
to an untrusted port initially.

110
00:06:17.203 --> 00:06:21.690
No, I'm not allowing you to come in,
now, can that change?

111
00:06:21.690 --> 00:06:27.410
Yes, you can open it up by poking holes in
your firewall temporarily, as you need to.

112
00:06:27.410 --> 00:06:30.270
But by default, it is locked up, so

113
00:06:30.270 --> 00:06:34.880
no outside traffic, initiating traffic,
coming into my network is gonna work.

114
00:06:34.880 --> 00:06:39.456
Now, on the trusted side,
though, usually, by default,

115
00:06:39.456 --> 00:06:44.303
all these devices can reach out and
go through to the Internet and

116
00:06:44.303 --> 00:06:47.560
return traffic is allowed to come back in.

117
00:06:47.560 --> 00:06:52.436
But overall though, it actually says,
yes, you going out is perfectly fine, but

118
00:06:52.436 --> 00:06:56.279
on the outside coming back in,
it's gonna end up being blocked.

119
00:06:57.460 --> 00:07:02.030
Firewalls are normally one of the things
that we can do that really do help provide

120
00:07:02.030 --> 00:07:05.260
initial, we'll call perimeter security.

121
00:07:05.260 --> 00:07:08.030
Now, we're gonna talk about this
router a little bit later on.

122
00:07:08.030 --> 00:07:10.180
Cuz we're gonna spend, essentially,

123
00:07:10.180 --> 00:07:14.540
a good portion of this entire series
on routers as well as the switches.

124
00:07:14.540 --> 00:07:17.960
So we're talking about just a few
of the other components too.

125
00:07:17.960 --> 00:07:22.190
Now the other thing that we also have
that you can have inside a network is,

126
00:07:22.190 --> 00:07:25.800
not only do you have a firewall,
which is normally good.

127
00:07:25.800 --> 00:07:29.970
In this firewall, these things have
advanced over the years, okay.

128
00:07:29.970 --> 00:07:33.929
Where it used to just do simple packet
inspection as far as filtering,

129
00:07:33.929 --> 00:07:37.094
I should say packet filtering
is what it actually does.

130
00:07:37.094 --> 00:07:41.766
Which says, hey, we're dropping packets
based on whatever filter that we want,

131
00:07:41.766 --> 00:07:42.778
perfectly fine.

132
00:07:42.778 --> 00:07:45.414
Today, though, they've advanced this, so

133
00:07:45.414 --> 00:07:49.063
when you hear the term like
next-generation firewall, okay,

134
00:07:49.063 --> 00:07:52.929
that's actually been a pretty
popular term for several years now.

135
00:07:52.929 --> 00:07:58.560
Or NGIPS,
which is the next generation IPS here.

136
00:07:58.560 --> 00:08:02.740
All that can be wrapped up in these
firewall components as dedicated

137
00:08:02.740 --> 00:08:06.995
components today, and
that's because Cisco, several years ago,

138
00:08:06.995 --> 00:08:09.990
bought a company called Sourcefire.

139
00:08:09.990 --> 00:08:12.940
And when they first bought that company
called Sourcefire, it was because of what

140
00:08:12.940 --> 00:08:18.060
they could do, which was just more than
what the standard packet filtering did.

141
00:08:18.060 --> 00:08:21.930
Did deeper packet inspection,
did a lot more different things.

142
00:08:21.930 --> 00:08:25.570
And at the beginning, they called it
Sourcefire ASAs or something, but

143
00:08:25.570 --> 00:08:29.364
today it's all underneath
a general moniker of Firepower.

144
00:08:29.364 --> 00:08:32.520
So whenever you hear somebody
referring to Firepower,

145
00:08:32.520 --> 00:08:37.460
it usually is an ASA of some type
that has special components,

146
00:08:37.460 --> 00:08:42.090
hardware components in it that does
the Firepower or the Sourcefire

147
00:08:42.090 --> 00:08:47.330
software of what it does to do everything
that it needs to, and it is massive.

148
00:08:47.330 --> 00:08:49.340
There's no other way to describe this.

149
00:08:49.340 --> 00:08:50.136
You wanna learn more about it.

150
00:08:50.136 --> 00:08:53.495
Make sure you check out some
of our other Cisco shows,

151
00:08:53.495 --> 00:08:57.265
especially on the cybersecurity
shows that we have there.

152
00:08:57.265 --> 00:09:01.670
Cuz we dive right into the idea of
a Firepower Management Center, and

153
00:09:01.670 --> 00:09:03.460
we show you some of the stuff it can do.

154
00:09:03.460 --> 00:09:07.760
It's amazing about how much information
it can actually track, okay?

155
00:09:07.760 --> 00:09:11.930
So when you hear ASA, it could be just
a plain-Jane ASA, but today, most of

156
00:09:11.930 --> 00:09:17.180
the time, it's gonna be some Firepower
device, is what it's gonna turn out to be.

157
00:09:18.240 --> 00:09:21.840
Now, along the path here,
I also put an IPS, which stands for

158
00:09:21.840 --> 00:09:24.850
intrusion prevention system, okay?

159
00:09:24.850 --> 00:09:27.390
Now, an IPS can work in
a couple of different ways.

160
00:09:27.390 --> 00:09:29.490
It can be an intrusion detection system,
or

161
00:09:29.490 --> 00:09:32.480
an intrusion prevention system here, okay?

162
00:09:32.480 --> 00:09:34.970
An intrusion prevention system
is exactly what you see.

163
00:09:34.970 --> 00:09:40.380
It's inline, from traffic coming from
the outside going to the inside.

164
00:09:40.380 --> 00:09:44.420
Notice that no other device is directly
connected to the firewall here.

165
00:09:44.420 --> 00:09:46.620
It's all going through this IPS.

166
00:09:46.620 --> 00:09:51.020
So the IPS gives us the ability to
add in signatures that will say,

167
00:09:51.020 --> 00:09:54.020
hey, this is what I believe
an intrusion looks like, and

168
00:09:54.020 --> 00:09:56.485
it will start to filter out,
based on those signatures.

169
00:09:56.485 --> 00:09:59.417
IPSs are picky devices.

170
00:09:59.417 --> 00:10:01.240
I don't know how else to describe them.

171
00:10:01.240 --> 00:10:05.390
You can't just go, all right, I'm turning
on the IPS, and then expect it to work.

172
00:10:05.390 --> 00:10:08.720
You have to train this thing, so you have
to actually go, here's what's allowed,

173
00:10:08.720 --> 00:10:09.630
here's what's not allowed.

174
00:10:09.630 --> 00:10:12.560
And it takes a little bit of time for
it to get up to speed

175
00:10:12.560 --> 00:10:15.798
before you've got it tweaked or
tuned the way that you want to so

176
00:10:15.798 --> 00:10:18.435
that it actually only allows
the traffic that you want to come in.

177
00:10:18.435 --> 00:10:22.829
An IPS is good because it's prevention
here, an intrusion prevention.

178
00:10:22.829 --> 00:10:24.970
It will stop intrusions.

179
00:10:24.970 --> 00:10:28.600
So after the firewall pretty much
rejects all the traffic that we go,

180
00:10:28.600 --> 00:10:31.000
you're originating from the outside,

181
00:10:31.000 --> 00:10:35.580
if somehow there is an intrusion that
comes back in, the IPS can then say,

182
00:10:35.580 --> 00:10:39.160
no, I'm filtering you out at this point,
if you choose to, okay?

183
00:10:39.160 --> 00:10:40.640
So that is another one.

184
00:10:40.640 --> 00:10:45.920
Now, once again, Cisco has their own
Cisco IPS system that's out there.

185
00:10:45.920 --> 00:10:51.720
But because of the popularity and
the incredible versatility of Firepower,

186
00:10:51.720 --> 00:10:56.770
even their IPS systems have kind of
taken a backseat to the Firepower stuff.

187
00:10:56.770 --> 00:10:58.130
So you might even see that.

188
00:10:58.130 --> 00:10:59.860
Now, these devices are expensive.

189
00:10:59.860 --> 00:11:02.689
Whether you're talking about Firepower or
whether you're talking about IPSs,

190
00:11:02.689 --> 00:11:03.762
they are insanely expensive.

191
00:11:03.762 --> 00:11:06.625
>> You have to come up with the wallet
when it comes to these guys, but

192
00:11:06.625 --> 00:11:09.170
they are extremely effective devices.

193
00:11:09.170 --> 00:11:14.038
The fact that you can even upload or
put into these devices your private key so

194
00:11:14.038 --> 00:11:17.080
that it can even decrypt
traffic to make sure and

195
00:11:17.080 --> 00:11:19.840
verify that no malfeasance is happening.

196
00:11:19.840 --> 00:11:21.730
>> Right.
>> And then re-encrypt the traffic and

197
00:11:21.730 --> 00:11:23.070
send it on its way.

198
00:11:23.070 --> 00:11:25.910
It's that deep level of
inspection that's going on there.

199
00:11:25.910 --> 00:11:27.850
They are no joke, and they do a great job.

200
00:11:27.850 --> 00:11:31.760
>> They do, they're very effective,
they really help you out, and

201
00:11:31.760 --> 00:11:35.470
the great thing is it's not that
you're detecting an intrusion.

202
00:11:35.470 --> 00:11:38.700
[LAUGH] It reminds me of
a commercial that's happening.

203
00:11:38.700 --> 00:11:40.980
There's a bank guard that's
standing there like, yeah, no,

204
00:11:40.980 --> 00:11:42.200
there's a bank robbery going on.

205
00:11:42.200 --> 00:11:43.900
>> They're robbing that
bank right now [LAUGH].

206
00:11:43.900 --> 00:11:46.130
>> They say, well, do something,
and the guard's saying, no,

207
00:11:46.130 --> 00:11:47.400
I'm just a detection system.

208
00:11:47.400 --> 00:11:49.860
>> Yeah, you just hired me to tell
you when you're getting robbed.

209
00:11:49.860 --> 00:11:50.925
[LAUGH]
>> But

210
00:11:50.925 --> 00:11:52.762
intrusion detection systems do work,

211
00:11:52.762 --> 00:11:56.446
and the very fact that they do alert us
to the different things that can happen.

212
00:11:56.446 --> 00:12:00.064
But they don't really do anything about
it, but their key is to log it, right,

213
00:12:00.064 --> 00:12:03.630
is to make sure that they understand
what has happened at this point.

214
00:12:03.630 --> 00:12:08.400
Now, a lot of times, the IPS and the IDS,
they're kind of similar devices.

215
00:12:08.400 --> 00:12:11.060
It just depends on their
placement in the network.

216
00:12:11.060 --> 00:12:13.230
So you have it inline in your network,

217
00:12:13.230 --> 00:12:16.880
like what I have it,
it's an intrusion prevention system.

218
00:12:16.880 --> 00:12:20.550
If I have it just as another device
off of this switch 1 over here,

219
00:12:20.550 --> 00:12:23.280
it becomes an intrusion detection system.

220
00:12:23.280 --> 00:12:27.690
Cuz what I'm doing is I'm telling
the switch, hey, any copy that comes in on

221
00:12:27.690 --> 00:12:31.550
this one port, send a copy of it over
to the intrusion detection system.

222
00:12:31.550 --> 00:12:33.640
And that means it can get
to its destination, and

223
00:12:33.640 --> 00:12:35.870
if an intrusion happens,
it will detect it.

224
00:12:35.870 --> 00:12:38.470
Okay, but here we're using it as an IPS.

225
00:12:38.470 --> 00:12:42.334
So the same thing that we were talking
about, whereas essentially what happens,

226
00:12:42.334 --> 00:12:46.039
right, with Firepower is you take the
power of the ASA, in terms of hardware.

227
00:12:46.039 --> 00:12:50.110
And then you take the power of an IPS
system and the hardware behind that,

228
00:12:50.110 --> 00:12:53.760
as well as the software behind it,
you combine them together.

229
00:12:53.760 --> 00:12:58.080
That's essentially what Firepower does for
us, so it gives us a next-generation

230
00:12:58.080 --> 00:13:03.790
firewall, or not firewall, as well as
a next-generation IPS to help us out.

231
00:13:03.790 --> 00:13:07.750
Now, we also have a switch, which we'll
talk about a little bit more in detail in

232
00:13:07.750 --> 00:13:13.398
another series, but here, notice the idea
of AP1, which is access point one.

233
00:13:13.398 --> 00:13:17.599
Access point 1 helps to extend
our broadcast domain by

234
00:13:17.599 --> 00:13:22.220
allowing us to no longer be bounded
by the media that we're tied to.

235
00:13:22.220 --> 00:13:26.920
We can now extend our broadcast domain
using radio frequency waves, instead, and

236
00:13:26.920 --> 00:13:31.640
simple access points, by themselves,
okay, do help us out.

237
00:13:31.640 --> 00:13:34.100
Now, there is one device that
I did forget to put in here.

238
00:13:34.100 --> 00:13:36.335
As I looked, I was like,
I'm missing one of these.

239
00:13:36.335 --> 00:13:39.076
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so let me make a copy of this one,

240
00:13:39.076 --> 00:13:42.084
and then I'll just add it in between here,

241
00:13:42.084 --> 00:13:45.609
is what we'll do, and
we'll call this one a WLC.

242
00:13:47.679 --> 00:13:53.941
Okay, now, WLC stands for wireless LAN
controller, is what that one stands for,

243
00:13:53.941 --> 00:14:00.340
if I can actually make that work, and
a wireless LAN controller is great.

244
00:14:00.340 --> 00:14:04.810
Because what it can do for our networks
that we have right here is that

245
00:14:04.810 --> 00:14:08.010
if we have multiple
wireless access points,

246
00:14:08.010 --> 00:14:11.910
I can just make a configuration
on the wireless LAN controller.

247
00:14:11.910 --> 00:14:16.270
And then push out those configurations
to the access points themselves, and

248
00:14:16.270 --> 00:14:19.250
now I have less administrative overhead,
okay?

249
00:14:19.250 --> 00:14:23.460
That less administrative overhead
means that I can spend more time

250
00:14:23.460 --> 00:14:25.190
making sure that other
things are actually good.

251
00:14:25.190 --> 00:14:26.891
But I can control, essentially,

252
00:14:26.891 --> 00:14:30.186
the entire wireless network using
that wireless LAN controller.

253
00:14:30.186 --> 00:14:34.300
I can control the frequency that
we're actually on, a lot of times.

254
00:14:34.300 --> 00:14:38.950
I can control the,
I can't say it, antenna.

255
00:14:38.950 --> 00:14:41.100
I don't know why I was missing the N.

256
00:14:41.100 --> 00:14:42.090
I was saying atenna.

257
00:14:42.090 --> 00:14:43.398
I was like, that's not right.

258
00:14:43.398 --> 00:14:44.566
>> Atenna.
>> Yeah, antenna strength.

259
00:14:44.566 --> 00:14:45.081
>> It's lacking atenna.

260
00:14:45.081 --> 00:14:48.363
>> Yeah, that's right, yeah,
he's lacking atenna, which means he needs-

261
00:14:48.363 --> 00:14:49.067
>> Sans tenna.

262
00:14:49.067 --> 00:14:49.822
>> Yeah.

263
00:14:49.822 --> 00:14:52.739
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, he needs a baritone, [LAUGH] no,

264
00:14:52.739 --> 00:14:53.280
sorry.

265
00:14:53.280 --> 00:14:53.910
Let's make it stop, Ronnie.

266
00:14:53.910 --> 00:14:54.454
>> I know, we need to.

267
00:14:54.454 --> 00:14:55.044
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

268
00:14:55.044 --> 00:14:58.172
that's what the access point does for
us, okay?

269
00:14:58.172 --> 00:15:02.890
Now, it's actually very key here,
right, these wireless LAN controllers.

270
00:15:02.890 --> 00:15:05.722
Most of the time, in our own homes,
we run what was called a wireless router.

271
00:15:05.722 --> 00:15:07.770
It's essentially a multilayer device.

272
00:15:07.770 --> 00:15:11.320
It functions as a router, a switch,
as well as a wireless access point, but

273
00:15:11.320 --> 00:15:16.110
in large enterprise networks, you may just
have access points that only do that.

274
00:15:16.110 --> 00:15:22.063
So now, with this wireless LAN controller
being connected into this switch here,

275
00:15:22.063 --> 00:15:25.719
okay, as well,
once we connect that, we can now,

276
00:15:25.719 --> 00:15:30.672
of course, control those access
points that help us to manage that.

277
00:15:30.672 --> 00:15:33.560
And usually, that's because you
have multiple ones to do so.

278
00:15:33.560 --> 00:15:38.420
One of the systems that I ended
up help set up is that there were

279
00:15:38.420 --> 00:15:39.570
25 access points.

280
00:15:39.570 --> 00:15:43.470
And we wanted to make sure that users
could actually use certificates for

281
00:15:43.470 --> 00:15:49.670
authentication, instead of actually having
to type in the password every time.

282
00:15:49.670 --> 00:15:54.498
Well, how do you do that on
25 access points to do that?

283
00:15:54.498 --> 00:15:57.970
You could individually do that, but what
we did is we set up a certificate server.

284
00:15:57.970 --> 00:16:01.460
We connected a wireless LAN controller and
then we pushed out the certificates.

285
00:16:01.460 --> 00:16:05.181
That's easy enough, it was a little
bit more challenging than that, but

286
00:16:05.181 --> 00:16:05.850
it did work.

287
00:16:05.850 --> 00:16:11.000
I didn't have to walk around to
all 25 access points to do so, so

288
00:16:11.000 --> 00:16:14.710
you do have things like that
that really do help us out.

289
00:16:14.710 --> 00:16:18.130
So wireless LAN controllers are kind
of the ones that are called out to,

290
00:16:18.130 --> 00:16:19.430
it's on the exam, right.

291
00:16:19.430 --> 00:16:24.460
Make sure you pay attention to ASA,
the idea of the next generation IPS and

292
00:16:24.460 --> 00:16:29.240
next generation firewall, wireless LAN
controllers, as well as access points.

293
00:16:29.240 --> 00:16:33.535
Now, the other devices that we
are gonna spend a ton of time on, and

294
00:16:33.535 --> 00:16:38.369
we'll talk about this part down here
at the bottom in a moment here, okay,

295
00:16:38.369 --> 00:16:40.386
switches and routers, okay?

296
00:16:40.386 --> 00:16:44.275
Remember that a switch is, for
us, a connectivity device, and

297
00:16:44.275 --> 00:16:47.595
it also allows us to do much
more inside of our network.

298
00:16:47.595 --> 00:16:51.166
Such as separate out broadcast
domain if we need to,

299
00:16:51.166 --> 00:16:54.450
by using something called VLANs.

300
00:16:54.450 --> 00:16:56.720
Just about on any network
that you'll come across,

301
00:16:56.720 --> 00:17:00.170
you'll end up seeing that if nothing else,
you'll have at least a switch

302
00:17:00.170 --> 00:17:03.870
on the network to connect
all those devices together.

303
00:17:03.870 --> 00:17:08.320
The other one is the idea of a router,
now, believe it or not,

304
00:17:08.320 --> 00:17:13.580
a router and a basic firewall can
do pretty much the same thing.

305
00:17:13.580 --> 00:17:17.910
We can turn on access control list and
do basic filtering if we need to.

306
00:17:17.910 --> 00:17:20.100
But an ASA by itself or

307
00:17:20.100 --> 00:17:23.010
a firewall by itself is probably
much better at doing it.

308
00:17:23.010 --> 00:17:26.396
Whereas routers also have to route
the traffic at the same time.

309
00:17:26.396 --> 00:17:30.220
Puts a little bit more strain on
the hardware that we have available to us.

310
00:17:30.220 --> 00:17:33.560
So it just depends on what
you need to set up here.

311
00:17:33.560 --> 00:17:38.481
Traditionally, the model that you
tend to see in enterprise networks is

312
00:17:38.481 --> 00:17:43.090
the one that I have up here on this
top branch that kind of goes along.

313
00:17:43.090 --> 00:17:47.394
It’s not every time, but it’s typical
in terms of the way that the data or

314
00:17:47.394 --> 00:17:49.870
the devices are in line, right.

315
00:17:49.870 --> 00:17:53.360
You have a router that really
separates you from the Internet.

316
00:17:53.360 --> 00:17:55.500
But then it routes
the traffic to the firewall,

317
00:17:55.500 --> 00:17:58.653
this is the first place where
it begins the filtering.

318
00:17:58.653 --> 00:18:02.140
Then the IPS inspects the traffic
that's left over, and

319
00:18:02.140 --> 00:18:03.210
then it gets on to your network.

320
00:18:04.210 --> 00:18:08.640
There are people out there that swear that
this is the way you should do it instead,

321
00:18:08.640 --> 00:18:15.070
which is down here at the bottom,
that you put the IPS before the firewall.

322
00:18:15.070 --> 00:18:20.200
Now if you do that, you can filter
out a ton of traffic right away, but

323
00:18:20.200 --> 00:18:22.850
there is a cost that's
actually involved here.

324
00:18:22.850 --> 00:18:26.540
Remember that this is based
off of signatures, right.

325
00:18:26.540 --> 00:18:30.311
That means that every single packet
of data sent to that interface,

326
00:18:30.311 --> 00:18:35.160
it has to match it against some signature,
or not match it against some signature.

327
00:18:35.160 --> 00:18:38.960
That slows down everything, okay,
and I mean slows down everything,

328
00:18:38.960 --> 00:18:41.570
I mean to a crawl,
it can slow down everything.

329
00:18:41.570 --> 00:18:44.153
And it also means that if you
don't have updated signatures,

330
00:18:44.153 --> 00:18:46.520
things are gonna slip through very easily.

331
00:18:46.520 --> 00:18:49.678
Whereas this one by default says,
well, blocked, yeah.

332
00:18:49.678 --> 00:18:53.740
I just look at the IP address, you're
not from the inside, you're blocked,

333
00:18:53.740 --> 00:18:56.820
you're not coming in,
it's just not gonna happen.

334
00:18:56.820 --> 00:19:00.040
So I like following this
traditional model more, but

335
00:19:00.040 --> 00:19:03.610
there are people out there that swear
that this is the way to go instead, okay?

336
00:19:03.610 --> 00:19:07.040
>> It seems like your way would
be better just because you've

337
00:19:07.040 --> 00:19:11.468
dropped the amount of traffic that the IPS
has to deal with right out of the gate.

338
00:19:11.468 --> 00:19:15.700
Which increases the speed of
the way that it's gonna work, and

339
00:19:15.700 --> 00:19:17.210
just cuz it has less to process.

340
00:19:17.210 --> 00:19:20.150
>> Right, and that's what I think too,
but once again, every time I

341
00:19:20.150 --> 00:19:23.430
think something like that, somebody always
kinda goes, no, that's not how it works.

342
00:19:23.430 --> 00:19:27.160
And you're like okay, well, I just wanted
to show you both because you never know.

343
00:19:27.160 --> 00:19:30.370
So what am I saying, is there a right
way and a wrong way, probably,

344
00:19:30.370 --> 00:19:31.690
but I don't know which one it is.

345
00:19:31.690 --> 00:19:32.870
But what I'm telling you is,

346
00:19:32.870 --> 00:19:37.490
you may end up getting hired at a company,
and here it is.

347
00:19:37.490 --> 00:19:39.960
You go, hey, Ronnie said that this
is how you're supposed to do it.

348
00:19:39.960 --> 00:19:43.930
And then they go, that Ronnie is nuts,
he's not supposed to do that.

349
00:19:43.930 --> 00:19:47.700
So I wanted to show you both, okay,
I believe that this is the right way,

350
00:19:47.700 --> 00:19:51.200
which is the top way to
actually do this right here.

351
00:19:51.200 --> 00:19:54.380
And to me, it does make sense, but

352
00:19:54.380 --> 00:19:59.160
there are people that argue that
the IPS should actually be first.

353
00:19:59.160 --> 00:20:02.268
You do a get a lot more blocking
right here over the IPS, but

354
00:20:02.268 --> 00:20:06.603
a that's a lot of traffic to have to block
against every signature that you have.

355
00:20:06.603 --> 00:20:10.320
Yeah, you're gonna be updating like
crazy to try and do stuff like that.

356
00:20:10.320 --> 00:20:14.520
I'd rather actually block it after the
device is actually designed for, right.

357
00:20:14.520 --> 00:20:18.573
The firewall is designed to eat up traffic
that you don't want to come in just by

358
00:20:18.573 --> 00:20:22.550
default, so
that's my particular conclusion.

359
00:20:22.550 --> 00:20:25.840
But do make sure that you pay
attention to each one of these.

360
00:20:25.840 --> 00:20:29.440
That doesn't mean you have to know
every single detail about every single

361
00:20:29.440 --> 00:20:30.400
one of these.

362
00:20:30.400 --> 00:20:32.744
But for
those of you that want to go on and

363
00:20:32.744 --> 00:20:35.740
learn more about some of these devices,
you are.

364
00:20:35.740 --> 00:20:40.113
You're gonna learn more about the routers
and switches not only in this series, but

365
00:20:40.113 --> 00:20:42.850
also in the CCNA show
that will be coming up.

366
00:20:42.850 --> 00:20:47.770
You also learn more about the ASAs,
as well as what the routers do in terms of

367
00:20:47.770 --> 00:20:52.240
security, if you go on toward
the CCNA security show as well.

368
00:20:52.240 --> 00:20:53.740
So there's actually chances and

369
00:20:53.740 --> 00:20:58.330
opportunities for you to learn about
how these devices really do function.

370
00:20:58.330 --> 00:21:01.110
But at least from this standpoint here,

371
00:21:01.110 --> 00:21:04.940
don't be surprised as you run across

372
00:21:04.940 --> 00:21:08.990
Now Cisco, has a complete market on
whatever company you work for right now,

373
00:21:08.990 --> 00:21:12.950
or you end up working for them in the
future, this lines up exactly with them.

374
00:21:12.950 --> 00:21:16.956
But you may find that they'll be different
brands wherever the company that you

00:21:16.956 --> 00:21:17.503

376
00:21:17.503 --> 00:21:21.432
So for example, I'm right here at ITProTV,
we have, I hate to say it,

00:21:21.432 --> 00:21:22.882
we have Juniper routers.

378
00:21:22.882 --> 00:21:23.522
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

00:21:23.522 --> 00:21:27.537
then our firewall is actually a PSS
firewall, our switch is an HP switch.

00:21:27.537 --> 00:21:31.503
>> Cisco people are going, no [LAUGH].

00:21:31.503 --> 00:21:37.328
>> But it's the reality, right,
not every shop's gonna be 100% Cisco.

00:21:37.328 --> 00:21:40.950
Now the ones that are, don't get me wrong,

383
00:21:40.950 --> 00:21:42.092
But the very fact is,

384
00:21:42.092 --> 00:21:45.780
you kind of at least understand

00:21:45.780 --> 00:21:47.876
In an enterprise business, that's the key,

386
00:21:47.876 --> 00:21:50.790
is understanding where these
things end up lining up.

387
00:21:50.790 --> 00:21:55.220
So don't be surprised on the exam,
if they ask you about the functionality or

388
00:21:55.220 --> 00:21:58.850
where do you tend to
place these devices here?

389
00:21:58.850 --> 00:22:01.430
Now I do have to warn, cuz I mentioned
that we're talking about enterprise.

390
00:22:01.430 --> 00:22:06.090
But in small businesses,
I know that at one point, okay,

00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:11.590
in a smaller company that I did some

00:22:11.590 --> 00:22:15.410
an ASA that directly connected

00:22:15.410 --> 00:22:20.770
So in other words, because the ASA can

So they didn't even have

they just had an ASA

00:22:26.060 --> 00:22:29.280
So that's fine too, but

If you have a big shop where
there's actually gonna be

And then an ASA at each one

episodes.description: n this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at basic networking topologies called out the CCENT exams.  They talk about the problems that can happen with a bad design and compare that with better network topology.  The team explains the purpose and contrasts the difference and provide the use case for them too.
episodes.title: Compare and Contrast Network Topologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the networking architectures.  They review the concepts of the 3-Tier Architecture and the Collapsed Architechture.  They also state the goals of this design is for capacity and capability of your network.

00:10:34.440 --> 00:10:38.340

00:10:41.790 --> 00:10:44.130

00:10:46.920 --> 00:10:51.590

00:11:02.270 --> 00:11:05.750
So in Cisco, they call this

00:11:05.750 --> 00:11:09.660
And you have a core, you have

00:11:09.660 --> 00:11:14.010

00:11:14.010 --> 00:11:18.170
Now for most of our company,

00:11:18.170 --> 00:11:22.750

they are going to be at this access layer.

00:11:22.750 --> 00:11:27.710
So here you see the desktops, and they're

00:11:27.710 --> 00:11:30.520
In other words, these are probably

00:11:30.520 --> 00:11:33.640

00:11:33.640 --> 00:11:38.050

00:11:38.050 --> 00:11:41.480
They're gonna connect to one of these

00:11:41.480 --> 00:11:44.290
And it's here at this layer

00:11:44.290 --> 00:11:49.350

00:11:49.350 --> 00:11:52.990

So if you know that you need

00:12:09.058 --> 00:12:12.844

00:12:12.844 --> 00:12:16.620
All of this is actually done at this

00:12:16.620 --> 00:12:17.900
So this helps us.

00:12:17.900 --> 00:12:21.790
Notice the number of switches, it's

00:12:26.020 --> 00:12:28.870

00:12:32.791 --> 00:12:37.027

00:12:37.027 --> 00:12:40.100

00:12:40.100 --> 00:12:43.250
And then you actually have

00:12:43.250 --> 00:12:47.660
So at this layer, okay, this is probably

00:12:47.660 --> 00:12:52.590
that means a single workstation goes down,

00:12:52.590 --> 00:12:56.390

00:12:56.390 --> 00:12:58.170

00:12:58.170 --> 00:13:02.080
And so when you do this,

00:13:02.080 --> 00:13:06.290
Now once we get to that point,

00:13:06.290 --> 00:13:10.490
also end up doing is having what

00:13:10.490 --> 00:13:15.421
A distribution layer allows us to be able

00:13:15.421 --> 00:13:19.430
over here wants to talk to this guy or

00:13:19.430 --> 00:13:24.850
Well, in theory, this is where you can

00:13:24.850 --> 00:13:27.560
So you can prevent the left
side over here from

271
00:13:27.560 --> 00:13:30.720

the right side if you want to, okay?

00:13:30.720 --> 00:13:34.980
That's not about controlling

00:13:34.980 --> 00:13:37.450
I'm just gonna stop it when

00:13:37.450 --> 00:13:39.170

00:13:39.170 --> 00:13:40.380
It's not gonna allow it to go over.

00:13:40.380 --> 00:13:43.010
So you can actually put in filtering and

00:13:43.010 --> 00:13:46.045

at this layer as well.

278
00:13:46.045 --> 00:13:50.130
So you might see a combination of
different types of devices up here.

00:13:50.130 --> 00:13:54.597
Down here on the access layer,
let's go back to the model for a moment,

280
00:13:54.597 --> 00:13:59.130
because it really does kind of help
us to think about these things too.

281
00:13:59.130 --> 00:14:04.020
Access layer, you're probably looking at

282
00:14:04.020 --> 00:14:07.890
You're controlling it by the individual
computer, if you need to, okay?

283
00:14:07.890 --> 00:14:12.740
And so, in this sense, these are probably
gonna be what we call layer two switches

284
00:14:12.740 --> 00:14:17.140
that really provide just that
accessibility that we need to for

285
00:14:17.140 --> 00:14:18.490

00:14:18.490 --> 00:14:22.590
Then in the distribution layer,
you may have layer two switches but

00:14:22.590 --> 00:14:27.330
normally, here's a term that we're gonna
also end up using in our episodes a little

288
00:14:27.330 --> 00:14:32.940
bit later on, what we call a layer three

00:14:32.940 --> 00:14:37.290
This particular switch normally also
has not only switching capabilities but

00:14:37.290 --> 00:14:40.880

00:14:40.880 --> 00:14:44.800
the ability to have filtering
possibilities in terms of routes.

292
00:14:44.800 --> 00:14:47.740
So it's here at the distribution layer,

293
00:14:47.740 --> 00:14:51.090
Notice that we don't need a lot of

00:14:51.090 --> 00:14:54.100
than these particular layer
two switches down here.

295
00:14:54.100 --> 00:14:57.340
They can handle a lot more traffic,
they can do a lot more in terms of

00:14:57.340 --> 00:15:01.150
the capabilities that they
also have as well, okay?

297
00:15:01.150 --> 00:15:04.210
So that's where you have
the distribution layer of things and

298
00:15:04.210 --> 00:15:05.580
when you start seeing it.

299
00:15:05.580 --> 00:15:09.349
The other ones that Cisco of course
recommends if you have this type

00:15:09.349 --> 00:15:11.370
of network and you're planning for

00:15:11.370 --> 00:15:14.218
scalability is to have
a core networking device.

the cable.

452
00:23:35.630 --> 00:23:38.522
And if you do it right,
if you do it right,

453
00:23:38.522 --> 00:23:43.482
what you should see is you is follow
one standard on one end and you follow

454
00:23:43.482 --> 00:23:49.210
the other standard on the other end, and
that gives you a proper crossover cable.

455
00:23:49.210 --> 00:23:52.803
And that is because these devices and
the way that they're pinned down on their

456
00:23:52.803 --> 00:23:55.158
network interface cards,
it makes a difference.

457
00:23:55.158 --> 00:23:58.711
If they're actually designed
to send out on one and two.

458
00:23:58.711 --> 00:24:02.252
That means they're gonna actually
receive on three and six.

459
00:24:02.252 --> 00:24:05.924
Well if I connect to another PC,
and I use a straight through cable,

460
00:24:05.924 --> 00:24:09.250
that means I'm actually trying
to transmit into, what?

461
00:24:09.250 --> 00:24:12.972
A transmitting pin pair, okay.

462
00:24:12.972 --> 00:24:16.730
So we don't wanna do that,
what we wanna do is if I connect for

463
00:24:16.730 --> 00:24:22.370
a PC to a PC directly, I want to send to
the receiving pins over on the other side.

464
00:24:22.370 --> 00:24:26.320
So that's gonna be very important
that we understand that, too, okay.

465
00:24:26.320 --> 00:24:27.110
The great thing is,

466
00:24:27.110 --> 00:24:31.310
I believe if you do check out the Comptia
network plus, or A plus show.

00:24:31.310 --> 00:24:34.869
I think Wes Brian actually breaks it down
and actually creates one of these cables

468
00:24:34.869 --> 00:24:37.130
for you, so
that you can see how it actually works.

469
00:24:37.130 --> 00:24:39.220
So make sure you check that out.

470
00:24:39.220 --> 00:24:43.080
Now the other one that you
definitely need to pay attention to

471
00:24:43.080 --> 00:24:45.550
is going to be this one.

472
00:24:45.550 --> 00:24:50.320
This one looks like it's all
in a complete 100% mess here.

473
00:24:50.320 --> 00:24:54.180
Now on a crossover cable,
this one will work and

474
00:24:54.180 --> 00:24:57.900
the straight through cable
will work on gigabit.

475
00:24:57.900 --> 00:25:03.040
But in a crossover cable, you need
to also remember this, is that we've

476
00:25:03.040 --> 00:25:08.790
also changed pairs four and five because
it uses all eight wires in gigabit here.

477
00:25:08.790 --> 00:25:13.290
So in this instance here,
you'll also take pins four and

478
00:25:13.290 --> 00:25:17.570
five, and directly connect them to
seven and eight on the other side.

479
00:25:19.520 --> 00:25:21.830
So let me add that back in here.

480
00:25:21.830 --> 00:25:24.989
Oops, let me try and
add that back in here.

481
00:25:27.720 --> 00:25:31.515
So now we also have
transmissions on four and five.

482
00:25:33.280 --> 00:25:37.085
And then, we would actually connect
them over here to the receiving side.

483
00:25:39.280 --> 00:25:45.509
Which would be seven and eight, which I
can't remember, I don't know why, okay.

484
00:25:48.390 --> 00:25:52.500
So on the gigabit it is going
to be different to do this.

485
00:25:54.100 --> 00:25:58.180
So you wanna make sure that you understand
that connection as well when you're

486
00:25:58.180 --> 00:26:02.300
actually told that you need to choose
what devices that these things go in to.

487
00:26:02.300 --> 00:26:05.380
So understanding those particular

00:26:05.380 --> 00:26:06.330
here, okay.

489
00:26:06.330 --> 00:26:10.000
So make sure you understand where you
would end up using a cross over cable.

490
00:26:10.000 --> 00:26:12.962
We've already said when it's
the same device to the same device,

491
00:26:12.962 --> 00:26:14.860
you can use a cross over cable.

492
00:26:14.860 --> 00:26:17.400
If you're actually connecting
to a different device,

493
00:26:17.400 --> 00:26:19.230
a router to a switch, okay.

494
00:26:19.230 --> 00:26:21.815
And you might go how
the heck does that work?

495
00:26:21.815 --> 00:26:24.650
Remember that a router will
work at layer three, and

496
00:26:24.650 --> 00:26:26.350
a switch will work at layer two.

497
00:26:27.400 --> 00:26:30.960
When you have something like that,
you're gonna use a straight through cable.

498
00:26:30.960 --> 00:26:35.430
But a switch to switch, that's layer two,
you're gonna use a crossover cable.

499
00:26:35.430 --> 00:26:38.360
Router to router,
you're gonna use a crossover cable.

500
00:26:38.360 --> 00:26:40.660
A router essentially is
just a basic computer.

501
00:26:40.660 --> 00:26:42.920
So if you actually connect a PC
to a router, which you can,

502
00:26:42.920 --> 00:26:45.850
you're gonna need a cross over cable for
the exam.

503
00:26:45.850 --> 00:26:50.220
So those are kind of the key elements
there in getting prepared and ready for

504
00:26:50.220 --> 00:26:51.800
the exam as well.

505
00:26:51.800 --> 00:26:56.300
There is one other cable that
we really want to stress and

506
00:26:56.300 --> 00:26:58.790
show you, which is right here, okay?

507
00:26:58.790 --> 00:27:02.930
There is one other cable that we're gonna
end up using when we start talking about

00:27:02.930 --> 00:27:10.510
Cisco configuration explicitly here, which

00:27:10.510 --> 00:27:16.640
A rollover cable is exactly like it

00:27:16.640 --> 00:27:21.950
they actually start a pens 8 all the way

00:27:21.950 --> 00:27:26.400
Usually this is called a console cable,
and then that console cable,

let me see if I can just show you

00:27:29.620 --> 00:27:31.080
So on my screen here,

00:27:33.880 --> 00:27:38.270
It's light blue,
there's a RJ45 connector on this side.

There is also, of course,

00:27:41.933 --> 00:27:44.310
A problem that I have, Daniel, is simple.

some of the newer Cisco devices

00:27:58.493 --> 00:28:00.677

00:28:00.677 --> 00:28:02.815
So you just kind of have to pay attention.

Usually for Cisco, it's this color right

00:28:07.065 --> 00:28:10.735
I have an older one, cuz this is the one

00:28:10.735 --> 00:28:14.410

00:28:14.410 --> 00:28:16.070

00:28:23.340 --> 00:28:27.010

Because if you ever need to,

So, that's kind of the big

Now, there are a few different standards

It's not so much about Cat 3

you're gonna see Cat 5e and

Cat 6 cable today.

If you're using copper, remember that

328 feet here.

The regular outside jack ending this

00:29:31.263 --> 00:29:34.543

00:29:39.135 --> 00:29:44.350
inside of walls when there's a fire

00:29:44.350 --> 00:29:47.054
So yeah, it's very bad.

00:29:47.054 --> 00:29:50.080
>> t's really bad, so, pay attention here.

So remember, I just put this for

episodes.description: n this episode, Cherokee and Ronnie discuss different types of IP addresses and their use.  They also begin the talk about why addressing is important for communication.  Using the MAC address as the initial example, they talk about the pool size of addresses and why it doesn't work on the internet.

understand what the network boundary is.

466
00:26:06.215 --> 00:26:10.582
>> Now Ronnie I know I just kind of jumped
in mid-stream here during your show, but

467
00:26:10.582 --> 00:26:13.726
I saw you talking and
going over some previous episodes.

468
00:26:13.726 --> 00:26:16.008
I saw your really cool
diagrams of the OSI model,

00:26:16.008 --> 00:26:18.692
looked like you guys were
talking about encapsulation.

470
00:26:18.692 --> 00:26:23.210
So I'm assuming that you already
know about the different OSI layers.

471
00:26:23.210 --> 00:26:27.474
So when in terms of OSI here at the MAC
address, what are we looking at?

472
00:26:27.474 --> 00:26:29.930
>> Yeah, once you start taking
a look at the OSI model, right?

473
00:26:29.930 --> 00:26:36.214
So that's where this works on Layer 2,
okay, of the OSI model.

474
00:26:39.474 --> 00:26:44.560
And it also works on the Network Layer,
Or the Network Access.

475
00:26:44.560 --> 00:26:50.328
Works on the, Network Access Layer

476
00:26:50.328 --> 00:26:54.560
of the TCP/IP model as well, okay?

477
00:26:54.560 --> 00:26:57.350
So both of those will actually
help us out here when we start

478
00:26:57.350 --> 00:26:58.650
thinking about this, okay?

479
00:26:58.650 --> 00:27:01.492
So this is, for us here, right?

480
00:27:01.492 --> 00:27:05.430
It is the beginning of understanding
the purpose of the address.

481
00:27:05.430 --> 00:27:11.510
When we dive into now trying to say, well,
how do we cross those network boundaries?

482
00:27:11.510 --> 00:27:16.251
It means that we have to have a mechanism
or an identifier that allows us to be

483
00:27:16.251 --> 00:27:20.768
able to distinguish those networks,
and then be able to get that data,

484
00:27:20.768 --> 00:27:24.716
not only in that one big network,
but now to another network.

485
00:27:24.716 --> 00:27:31.017
And that is where we begin with,
of course then, IP addresses, okay?

486
00:27:31.017 --> 00:27:37.082
And this is actually gonna
be our Layer 3 address,

487
00:27:37.082 --> 00:27:42.852
okay, or
the Internet Layer of the OSI model.

488
00:27:42.852 --> 00:27:44.276
It's not OSI, TCP/IP.

489
00:27:44.276 --> 00:27:44.829
>> TCP/IP.

490
00:27:44.829 --> 00:27:47.190
>> Yeah, I'm gonna get all that confused.

491
00:27:47.190 --> 00:27:51.960
Okay, so those are the addresses that
we are going to really focus in on so

492
00:27:51.960 --> 00:27:56.500
that we have a good understanding of
how this ends up happening, okay?

493
00:27:56.500 --> 00:28:00.113
So we started off by just talking about
the different address types here.

494
00:28:00.113 --> 00:28:03.307
And we then tried to show you that
addressing can be done at any layer that

495
00:28:03.307 --> 00:28:03.849
we want to.

496
00:28:03.849 --> 00:28:06.369
But limitations of just
using the MAC address,

497
00:28:06.369 --> 00:28:10.346
is because they really aren't designed
to go across network boundaries.

498
00:28:10.346 --> 00:28:13.901
And now it means we are ready to
start diving into the idea here

499
00:28:13.901 --> 00:28:17.038
of IP version for addresses and
understanding them,

500
00:28:17.038 --> 00:28:19.912
and then showing you where
to apply them as well.

501
00:28:19.912 --> 00:28:20.978
But Cherokee,
I think I've run out of time.

502
00:28:20.978 --> 00:28:24.140
>> I know it, we're looking at
the clock here and I know you

503
00:28:24.140 --> 00:28:28.100
have a lot of great information that you
wanna share looking at IP addresses.

504
00:28:28.100 --> 00:28:29.614
So I think we should table
that until the next episode.

505
00:28:29.614 --> 00:28:31.570
>> Sounds great.
>> So thank you for your time.

506
00:28:31.570 --> 00:28:33.941
Thank you for your time, but
we're gonna go ahead and sign out.

507
00:28:33.941 --> 00:28:35.380
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

508
00:28:35.380 --> 00:28:36.209
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

509
00:28:36.209 --> 00:28:39.409
>> See you next here at ITProTV.

510
00:28:39.409 --> 00:28:45.388
[MUSIC]

511
00:28:45.388 --> 00:28:48.924
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Cherokee and Ronnie continue with addressing.  This time, they focus on the IP address breakdown to help understand the 2 parts of an IP address.  The review the structure of IP Addresses in classes A,B, and C.

doing that, but let's do talk about

So in our previous episode,

Is really direct communication.

44

So whether we're talking about unicast,
multicast,

45

broadcast, it all works based

46
00:02:16.640 --> 00:02:20.270
Then we showed you the initial addressing

47
00:02:20.270 --> 00:02:24.370
the MAC address, and is an integral

48
00:02:24.370 --> 00:02:25.900
But at the same time,

49
00:02:25.900 --> 00:02:31.490
we also showed you the limitations of
using a MAC address just for transmission.

50
00:02:31.490 --> 00:02:35.080
The very fact is, as long as all
the devices on the same network,

51
00:02:35.080 --> 00:02:37.420
Mac addresses works perfectly fine.

52
00:02:37.420 --> 00:02:40.310
But once we start to

53
00:02:40.310 --> 00:02:44.270
to connect two devices that
are across networks though.

54
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:45.960
We can't use Mac any more.

55

Because they assume that

56
00:02:48.810 --> 00:02:52.390
even on the Internet, there's

57
00:02:52.390 --> 00:02:56.070
in which the Mac addresses cannot

58
00:02:56.070 --> 00:02:59.770
So that's what we have to understand
as we continue to see and

59
00:02:59.770 --> 00:03:01.760
move the way that we want to.

60
00:03:01.760 --> 00:03:06.010
So we're picking up at this point, where
we've moved on from the MAC addresses and

61
00:03:06.010 --> 00:03:09.630
we're now starting to talk about
the IP addressing as well.

62
00:03:09.630 --> 00:03:12.090
Let's take a look at the notes
that I've been making here.

63
00:03:12.090 --> 00:03:15.195
And I've just kinda cleared off
the screen to start a little bit again.

64
00:03:15.195 --> 00:03:20.565
So remember that this actually
occurs at layer three of the OSI.

65
00:03:20.565 --> 00:03:23.951
And then also at the Internet.

66
00:03:27.289 --> 00:03:33.165
Layer of the TCP/IP model as well.

67
00:03:33.165 --> 00:03:36.550
So make sure you actually match both
of those up as you get ready for

68

the exam as well.

69
00:03:38.250 --> 00:03:43.250
Now, on the addressing itself when
we actually take the look at.

70
00:03:44.370 --> 00:03:47.812
Most of the time,
when we start talking about IP address,

71
00:03:47.812 --> 00:03:52.962
the reality of an IP address is that it's
what we would call a 32-bit binary number.

72
00:03:54.895 --> 00:03:58.640
Let's call it a binary identifier,
number's actually easier.

73
00:03:58.640 --> 00:03:59.690
Number or identifier.

74
00:04:00.860 --> 00:04:01.720
And that is actually,

75
00:04:01.720 --> 00:04:05.640
because it does identify that
machine on that network for us.

76
00:04:05.640 --> 00:04:08.000
So, when we actually
understand the idea of binary,

77
00:04:08.000 --> 00:04:10.220
it's actually a string of 32 one's and
zero's.

78
00:04:10.220 --> 00:04:12.350
That's what it comes down to.
>> Pretty straight forward.

79
00:04:12.350 --> 00:04:14.360
>> Seems to be straight forward, but

80
00:04:14.360 --> 00:04:19.450
the great thing is since you and
I didn't probably grow up knowing binary,

81
00:04:19.450 --> 00:04:22.670
learning binary or
understanding it too much.

82
00:04:22.670 --> 00:04:27.480
It normally is reported though in what
we call, well, Dotted Decimal Notation.

83
00:04:30.892 --> 00:04:34.770
And decimal system though,
is something that we did learn.

84
00:04:34.770 --> 00:04:36.180
So Dotted Decimal Notation.

85
00:04:39.168 --> 00:04:46.338
So for example here,
192.168.10.100 is actually an example.

86
00:04:46.338 --> 00:04:49.160
So that translates into 32 ones and

87
00:04:49.160 --> 00:04:54.110
zeroes at some point is what
it ends up translating into.

88
00:04:54.110 --> 00:04:58.730
Now, notice the dots in the middle
here as you start to see in between.

89
00:04:58.730 --> 00:05:02.530
And that's because trying to
translate this number in reality and

90
00:05:02.530 --> 00:05:06.250
what it comes out to be,
it's a horrendously long number.

91
00:05:06.250 --> 00:05:09.400
And it doesn't match up exactly
like the numbers that we have here.

92
00:05:09.400 --> 00:05:13.073
So they separate it out into
smaller sections to make it easier.

93
00:05:13.073 --> 00:05:15.248
>> Good, more manageable sections here.

94
00:05:15.248 --> 00:05:16.008
>> Yep, so

95
00:05:16.008 --> 00:05:20.260
they actually separate
it out into 4 octets.

96
00:05:20.260 --> 00:05:22.773
And that is four sets
of eight binary bits.

97
00:05:28.452 --> 00:05:32.021
So each one of those in
between the actual dot set.

98
00:05:32.021 --> 00:05:36.099
Is essentially a representation of
8 bits of binary as what we have.

99
00:05:36.099 --> 00:05:40.734
And that makes it easier,
because the highest number that

100
00:05:40.734 --> 00:05:45.471
we can get in one of those 8
bits section is gonna be 255.

101
00:05:45.471 --> 00:05:47.324
So that's the highest
number that we can get.

102
00:05:47.324 --> 00:05:50.909
So you should never see in
terms of an IP address,

103
00:05:50.909 --> 00:05:55.729
when there's a number larger
than 255 in that set of numbers.

104
00:05:55.729 --> 00:06:00.229
Now, if you're like me and you watch some
TV shows, when they start doing this kind

105
00:06:00.229 --> 00:06:04.366
of cyber tracking thing, this is where
TV shows just kinda go off and board.

106
00:06:04.366 --> 00:06:05.030
>> Gets silly?

107
00:06:05.030 --> 00:06:05.918
>> Yeah, and

108
00:06:05.918 --> 00:06:10.074
then you start seeing them like 523.924.

109
00:06:10.074 --> 00:06:12.940
And you start going, man,
that's kind of the weirdest addressing.

110
00:06:12.940 --> 00:06:15.890
But more than likely, it's because
they really can't use real numbers

111
00:06:15.890 --> 00:06:19.180
that might affect somebody's network,
is what it turns out to be.

112
00:06:19.180 --> 00:06:22.140
So just realize that you will
have something like that.

113
00:06:22.140 --> 00:06:24.760
So this is normally the way that you and
I encounter that.

114
00:06:24.760 --> 00:06:26.550
So let me show you what
I'm talking about here,

115
00:06:26.550 --> 00:06:30.250
when we start seeing
the idea of addressing.

116
00:06:30.250 --> 00:06:32.580
So every machine that's connected
to a network of course,

117
00:06:32.580 --> 00:06:35.660
then will have an IP
address connected to it.

118
00:06:35.660 --> 00:06:39.500
So for example,
my machine right here has an IP address.

119
00:06:39.500 --> 00:06:43.170
If I want to show you that,
I can do it in a couple of different ways.

120
00:06:43.170 --> 00:06:47.674
I'm just gonna just come down here to
the Cortana search bar on my Windows 10

121
00:06:47.674 --> 00:06:50.604
machine, and type in cmd for
the command prompt.

122
00:06:52.534 --> 00:06:58.120
And on this command prompt, I'm just gonna
do an ipconfig to bring out that command.

123
00:06:58.120 --> 00:07:03.370
And you'll see right away, it actually
shows me well, this number right here.

124
00:07:03.370 --> 00:07:07.390
And that is my IP version 4 address.

125
00:07:07.390 --> 00:07:10.660
Every machine will have one,
whether you're on Windows or

126
00:07:10.660 --> 00:07:14.990
whether you're on a MacBook or
Mac, whatever you want to call it.

127
00:07:14.990 --> 00:07:18.410
Whether you're on a Linux machine,
you'll actually have an IP address

128
00:07:18.410 --> 00:07:21.830
that you'll be able to
actually have on your machine.

129
00:07:21.830 --> 00:07:26.182
Now, each one of these addresses
if you're in the same network,

130
00:07:26.182 --> 00:07:31.566
you actually see that some of these bits
you'll share will be in common with other

131
00:07:31.566 --> 00:07:37.050
people on their machines, and some of them
will not be in common with that as well.

132
00:07:37.050 --> 00:07:39.429
Now Cherokee and
I are actually on a different network.

133
00:07:39.429 --> 00:07:42.409
I'm actually on a 172.16 network.

134
00:07:42.409 --> 00:07:45.072
And Cherokee, if you'll do the IP
config for me on your machine?

135
00:07:45.072 --> 00:07:46.128
>> Sure.

136
00:07:46.128 --> 00:07:48.810
>> We'll kind of make a comparison here.

137
00:07:48.810 --> 00:07:52.127
And we'll see that the bits don't even
match, cuz I think she is on the ten dot

138
00:07:52.127 --> 00:07:56.202
something network, if I remember right.
>> 192.968.22.1 Weird,

139
00:07:56.202 --> 00:08:00.266
I wonder where you're getting that
particular network from cuz that's not

140
00:08:00.266 --> 00:08:02.245
actually anywhere in our building.

141
00:08:02.245 --> 00:08:04.452
Maybe unless you're,
no you are using wireless so

142
00:08:04.452 --> 00:08:06.876
you could actually be on some
bodies wireless network.

143
00:08:06.876 --> 00:08:11.170
That's about perfectly fine, so
she's on a 192168, what dot 1?

144
00:08:11.170 --> 00:08:14.244
>> Dot, 168.222.1

145
00:08:14.244 --> 00:08:14.916
>> Yeah so,

146
00:08:14.916 --> 00:08:17.355
wow that's a pretty neat number.

147
00:08:17.355 --> 00:08:20.447
So you actually see that when those
addresses don't even match then that's

148
00:08:20.447 --> 00:08:22.632
actually an indication
that they're on different-

149
00:08:22.632 --> 00:08:23.619
>> I'm looking at my VMware machine

150
00:08:23.619 --> 00:08:24.153
there, Ronnie.

151
00:08:24.153 --> 00:08:25.552
Sorry, I've got a couple machines running.

152
00:08:25.552 --> 00:08:26.889
[CROSSTALK]
>> Okay, no, that makes more sense now.

153
00:08:26.889 --> 00:08:27.928
>> Yeah, that's my bridged adapter.

154
00:08:27.928 --> 00:08:28.849
>> That you're actually

155
00:08:28.849 --> 00:08:29.820
on the VMware machine.

156
00:08:29.820 --> 00:08:32.245
Yeah, so you'll actually end
up seeing something like that.

157
00:08:32.245 --> 00:08:35.967
So every machine on the same node,
some these bits will actually be the same,

158
00:08:35.967 --> 00:08:37.067
some of them will not.

159
00:08:37.067 --> 00:08:41.345
The separation with the dots here are
actually just to help you and I be able

160
00:08:41.345 --> 00:08:46.106
to manage these IP addresses, instead
of actually looking at a 32-bit address

161
00:08:46.106 --> 00:08:50.931
string, is what it actually does for us.
>> You're right, my real Ethernet

162
00:08:50.931 --> 00:08:55.849
adapter is gonna be in the ten-dot range.
>> All right, so cool, okay?

163
00:08:55.849 --> 00:09:00.531
Now the great thing about this address,
okay, so even though it's just

164
00:09:00.531 --> 00:09:05.541
a single 32-bit number it's actually
divided into two portions, okay.

165
00:09:05.541 --> 00:09:09.846
So that 32 bit number represents
two portions of the address.

166
00:09:09.846 --> 00:09:14.862
And those two portions,
usually this one is called the network ID,

167
00:09:14.862 --> 00:09:19.097
okay, and that is the grouping,
the logical grouping.

168
00:09:23.782 --> 00:09:26.243
Okay, that we are a part of.

169
00:09:26.243 --> 00:09:30.180
And then the other portion is
also known as the HostID or

170
00:09:30.180 --> 00:09:33.271
node ID sometimes you'll hear it saying.

171
00:09:33.271 --> 00:09:39.766
And this is the unique
identifier within that group.

172
00:09:39.766 --> 00:09:44.417
Okay, so those are the actually two
portions of that 32 bit address.

173
00:09:44.417 --> 00:09:45.658
So what does that mean?

174
00:09:45.658 --> 00:09:49.139
That means of those 32 bits, okay.

175
00:09:49.139 --> 00:09:54.010
Some of those, let's say the first
24 bits, just as an example,

176
00:09:54.010 --> 00:09:55.469
are the network ID.

177
00:09:55.469 --> 00:09:57.383
Well that means the rest of the bits.

episodes.description: Daniel and Ronnie continue with addressing.  They show how to convert binary to decimal and decimal to binary numbers.  These conversions are key to help identify different address regardless of whether they are reported in decimal or binary.

episodes.description: Daniel and Ronnie discuss how the binary can help reveal some additional information to prepare for the exam: It reveals the NetworkID and the BroadcastID.  They also discuss briefly limitation of classing addressing which lead to classful routing.  The classful routing works based on the 1st Octet only.  They also describe some of the methods used to deal with the limitation of the IPv4 address pool: NAT, VLSM and IPv6.  Lastly, they show how IPv4 addresses are applied to routers and switches.
episodes.title: Understand and Apply IPv4 Addressing Part 4

437
00:23:24.060 --> 00:23:26.440
This will get me into what's
called global configuration mode.

438
00:23:26.440 --> 00:23:28.260
We still have to get to that part here.

439
00:23:28.260 --> 00:23:29.910
But then we have to find an interface.

440
00:23:29.910 --> 00:23:33.620
So at this point,
let's see what interfaces that there are.

441
00:23:35.110 --> 00:23:42.330
So let me do a show ip interface brief,
just as an example here.

442
00:23:42.330 --> 00:23:46.890
So we're gonna just take this gigabit 0/0
here, this is what we're going to do.

443
00:23:46.890 --> 00:23:51.392
I go back to configure, terminal and

444
00:23:51.392 --> 00:23:54.594
then I type in interface,

445
00:23:59.143 --> 00:24:04.409
Gigabit Ethernet 0/0.

446
00:24:04.409 --> 00:24:07.520
And it's not case sensitive.

447
00:24:07.520 --> 00:24:08.472
It should find it.

448
00:24:08.472 --> 00:24:10.044
And it's right here,

449
00:24:10.044 --> 00:24:15.100
I can type in IP address then 192
168 0.1 and it's subnet mask.

450
00:24:16.630 --> 00:24:22.880
And once I do that, I type in a no
shut down to turn the interface on.

451
00:24:24.660 --> 00:24:28.060
Then I'm gonna type in exit, so
I'm gonna try and type in exit.

452
00:24:28.060 --> 00:24:33.181
Then I do a show IP interface brief.

453
00:24:35.608 --> 00:24:39.830
And there you can see, I actually
assigned an IP address to it, okay.

454
00:24:39.830 --> 00:24:43.560
So you'll end up assigning this on
a router, usually a per interface basis.

455
00:24:43.560 --> 00:24:45.450
The limitation on the router is simple.

456
00:24:45.450 --> 00:24:48.210
Notice that there are other
interfaces here also Daniel.

457
00:24:48.210 --> 00:24:52.820
They cannot be in the same
network as this one.

458
00:24:52.820 --> 00:24:53.790
The way that the router works,

459
00:24:53.790 --> 00:24:56.230
each interface essentially
represents a different network.

460
00:24:56.230 --> 00:24:59.270
If you type in one in the same network,
it's gonna say nah, you can't do it.

461
00:24:59.270 --> 00:25:00.640
It's not gonna allow you to do so.

462
00:25:00.640 --> 00:25:02.520
So that's what it will actually do for
you.

463
00:25:02.520 --> 00:25:04.850
And there's even other
interfaces down here as well,

464
00:25:04.850 --> 00:25:09.730
but you can assign IP addresses
to these interfaces very easily.

465
00:25:09.730 --> 00:25:13.890
Now on a switch thought and
this is another way here, okay?

466
00:25:13.890 --> 00:25:15.500
A switch is different.

467
00:25:15.500 --> 00:25:22.150
A switch doesn't actually allow you to
assign IP addresses to an interface.

468
00:25:22.150 --> 00:25:23.640
Let me show you what I mean.

469
00:25:23.640 --> 00:25:26.524
Let me go to configure terminal and

470
00:25:26.524 --> 00:25:31.600
then let's do an interface,
I see that I actually have one.

471
00:25:31.600 --> 00:25:33.640
Let's see there's probably 0.1.

472
00:25:33.640 --> 00:25:38.466
So interface, gig,

473
00:25:38.466 --> 00:25:41.414
you got bit,

474
00:25:41.414 --> 00:25:46.250
ethernet, 0/1.

475
00:25:46.250 --> 00:25:47.519
There we go.

476
00:25:47.519 --> 00:25:48.960
So that interface.

477
00:25:48.960 --> 00:25:53.125
Now I am going to type
in an IP address here.

478
00:25:53.125 --> 00:25:55.781
IP address 192 168 10.1.

479
00:25:55.781 --> 00:26:02.140
Oops, I forgot the subnet mask,
so we can do it complete here.

480
00:26:02.140 --> 00:26:04.913
192.168.0.1.

481
00:26:07.379 --> 00:26:09.560
Notice it says, hey,
you're having an error, right?

482
00:26:09.560 --> 00:26:10.660
It says invalid input.

483
00:26:10.660 --> 00:26:13.070
And that's because you can't do this.

484
00:26:13.070 --> 00:26:16.930
Normally switches do not allow
you to put an IP address on them.

485
00:26:16.930 --> 00:26:18.350
There's ways you can do that,

486
00:26:18.350 --> 00:26:21.620
but for us, it's not normally
going to be where you do this.

487
00:26:21.620 --> 00:26:25.056
So it's different because in a router,
the IP address are set there so

488
00:26:25.056 --> 00:26:27.170
that you can route information.

489
00:26:27.170 --> 00:26:29.260
On switches,
you aren't routing information.

490
00:26:29.260 --> 00:26:33.200
So IP addresses on switches
are actually for identification and

491
00:26:33.200 --> 00:26:36.850
this is where you have to put
it on a virtual interface.

492
00:26:36.850 --> 00:26:39.205
On this one, let me exit here.

493
00:26:39.205 --> 00:26:42.210
And then let me do interface, VLAN 1.

494
00:26:42.210 --> 00:26:46.170
That's the default virtual interface.

495
00:26:46.170 --> 00:26:48.480
That's on the switch by default.

496
00:26:48.480 --> 00:26:55.904
This will help you out, because this
is where I can now assign, 1921680.2.

497
00:26:57.170 --> 00:26:58.624
I forgot the IP address, see?

498
00:26:58.624 --> 00:27:07.840
So, 0.2, And now notice it accepted it?

499
00:27:07.840 --> 00:27:12.820
And you don't necessarily have to do
a no shutdown command to turn it on,

500
00:27:12.820 --> 00:27:14.950
that switch is,
the interfaces are always on.

501
00:27:14.950 --> 00:27:17.750
But this is where you would do this and
this is for identification.

502
00:27:17.750 --> 00:27:22.090
It now has an IP address, looks just like
a regular computer has an IP address.

503
00:27:22.090 --> 00:27:25.140
Now, on the switch and on a router, okay,

504
00:27:25.140 --> 00:27:29.740
usually on a router, can be assigned
by using other services like DHCP.

505
00:27:29.740 --> 00:27:32.460
In other words,
a server that can assign IP addresses.

506
00:27:32.460 --> 00:27:34.490
Yes you can, you can set it to do that.

507
00:27:34.490 --> 00:27:38.030
On a switch, not so much so,
but on a regular router,

508
00:27:38.030 --> 00:27:39.680
you definitely can do that.

509
00:27:39.680 --> 00:27:43.290
But for us, we statically showed you
where you'll generally apply this.

510
00:27:43.290 --> 00:27:45.810
Inside of a regular PC that you have,

511
00:27:45.810 --> 00:27:50.340
remember you'll actually be able

512
00:27:50.340 --> 00:27:52.080
And when you do this,
you're actually looking.

So if you're like me on this

You can actually look for

So see this is changed

00:28:09.330 --> 00:28:09.830
Let me see.

Network adapter options.

00:28:14.540 --> 00:28:15.490
Let's try that one.

00:28:15.490 --> 00:28:16.220
There we go.

521
00:28:16.220 --> 00:28:17.330
Adapter options.

00:28:19.240 --> 00:28:21.610
Then I go to the properties

00:28:23.290 --> 00:28:27.290
So like internet protocol version four and
properties.

524
00:28:27.290 --> 00:28:30.790
And it's right here that I

00:28:30.790 --> 00:28:33.850
So both of those, at least this way,

00:28:33.850 --> 00:28:37.100

00:28:37.100 --> 00:28:40.750

528
00:28:40.750 --> 00:28:42.150
But, overall though,

00:28:42.150 --> 00:28:45.230
those are usually the applications you'll
end up seeing whether on a router or

00:28:45.230 --> 00:28:49.240
a switch IP addresses can be assigned or

531

But that's kind of the basics

Now, there's still a bit

But, at this point though,

Daniel, this kind of really does end our

how to actually do that successfully.
>> Well, it sounds like a lot of fun but

cuz most people when they get

These foundational truths that

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie begin taking a look at subnetting.  They discuss the uses of subnetting. The team subnets a single class c network and sub divides it into 4 subnets.
episodes.title: Understand and Apply Subnetting

If you have the foundations to it,

Remember when we talked about

You and

Base ten mathematics.

And for

At this point, you and

25.

00:03:39.970 --> 00:03:41.990

00:03:41.990 --> 00:03:42.810
Now-

00:03:42.810 --> 00:03:44.850
>> Yeah whew,
yeah that whew very difficult.

00:03:44.850 --> 00:03:46.200

And the reason why I wanted to

So everybody that kind of has this

00:04:11.350 --> 00:04:13.900
Just like what Daniel

00:04:13.900 --> 00:04:17.654
When I said 100 divided by 4, he said, 25.

00:04:19.420 --> 00:04:22.430
But, no, I'm joking,

00:04:24.460 --> 00:04:25.800

00:04:25.800 --> 00:04:30.270
>> I was hoping you would

00:04:30.270 --> 00:04:33.008
But overall though,

00:04:33.008 --> 00:04:35.647
So if you can remember that okay,

00:04:35.647 --> 00:04:41.430
it really is just basic division okay,

00:04:41.430 --> 00:04:44.860
The hard part then is actually going,

00:04:44.860 --> 00:04:51.700
like that 100 divided by 4, and make that

00:04:51.700 --> 00:04:53.330
So that's what we're actually heading to,

102
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:56.342
that's what it is that we

00:04:56.342 --> 00:04:58.330
So we're gonna start off by using,

And that is what's usually

00:05:05.580 --> 00:05:08.630
Okay, so we're gonna start off with

Now, when I was working with

given whatever your scenario is, okay?

That you want to actually create well,

smaller networks from that

So remember that, for us,

Possibility of 254 hosts, okay?

So, the reason why I'm emphasizing that

that's actually a great number, okay?

In these,

Given four networks,

That amount of networks,

00:20:58.084 --> 00:21:02.557
So I know that I'm essentially

Now once I borrow those 2 bits,
and let me get rid of this so

that it's not blocking what I need here,

00:21:09.712 --> 00:21:13.686
I wanna go ahead and

So the way that I do that,
right, if I were to do binary

ending is that I would

And add that in.

And that would be 255.255.255 and then

00:21:35.110 --> 00:21:38.533
That's 128 plus 64, that's gonna be 192.

401
00:21:38.533 --> 00:21:40.920
And the rest are 0s.

402
00:21:42.790 --> 00:21:51.710
And now for my smaller networks,
Okay, now I have a new subnet mask.

403
00:21:55.934 --> 00:21:58.670
Oops, let me change that once

404
00:21:58.670 --> 00:22:02.748
[LAUGH] I still didn't change it though.

405
00:22:02.748 --> 00:22:03.790
No, that did, okay.

406
00:22:16.619 --> 00:22:19.640
Let me just leave that blank.

407
00:22:19.640 --> 00:22:21.667
I was trying to do this so

408
00:22:21.667 --> 00:22:23.299
But there we go, okay.

So now I've got anew subnet mask
that will be assigned to each

00:22:28.015 --> 00:22:31.994
of my new networks,
which is gonna be here, okay?

So how do we determine the network step,

Well, now I can change these two

00:22:41.620 --> 00:22:42.749
But let's go ahead and do that.

00:22:42.749 --> 00:22:46.647
Now, we're not paying attention to

Let me copy this one.

00:22:49.493 --> 00:22:55.492
On my first network then It's

actually this one right here,

That's gonna be 168.10.0

00:23:10.247 --> 00:23:17.475
And now let's determine

Paste this one down here.

00:23:22.848 --> 00:23:27.481
So this is gonna be first,

00:23:27.481 --> 00:23:30.858

Our second one, we'll start with the

And now I wanna take a look

It's gonna be 192.168.10 because

The 64, so

Which is gonna be the second-

And now, I'll flip those two bits again.

00:24:17.208 --> 00:24:20.100
And now I have to change this,

64.

00:24:22.120 --> 00:24:26.932
So now this one becomes a 10, like that.

And so now if we take a look at

128.

And why would it actually line

00:25:30.727 --> 00:25:38.717

We started off with this one

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the results of class c subnetting.  They demonstrate how the NetworkID, Range and BroadcastID determined and not just a random thought.  The guys discuss preparations for the exam will include not only the ability to subnet but subnet quickly.

In a previous episode,

If all of the binary host bits,
