do I really have to do that?

513
00:27:56.740 --> 00:28:00.520
At the beginning, yes, you need to
go through and do that conversion.

514
00:28:00.520 --> 00:28:01.400
>> This needs to be just

515
00:28:01.400 --> 00:28:02.080
second nature for you.

516
00:28:02.080 --> 00:28:06.059
You look at it and see it and it's-
>> But once you start to actually do a lot

517
00:28:06.059 --> 00:28:12.341
of these you go, wait a minute, that bit
right there is 32, I know that's 32.

518
00:28:12.341 --> 00:28:17.090
And right below that then, if all the bits
are turned on, that's gotta equal to 31.

519
00:28:17.090 --> 00:28:21.532
Cuz then if I go to 32 and I turn on this
bit, all these other ones go to zero.

520
00:28:21.532 --> 00:28:22.710
>> They go to zero.

521
00:28:22.710 --> 00:28:24.030
>> So now you're starting to see,

522
00:28:24.030 --> 00:28:28.020
hopefully, a little pattern, where you're
like, wait a minute, that's what it is.

523
00:28:28.020 --> 00:28:30.057
Yeah, so I know at least
that network portion is 31.

524
00:28:30.057 --> 00:28:36.110
And then this right here is all 8s,
which is 255.

525
00:28:36.110 --> 00:28:42.056
So my BroadcastID is essentially
going to be right there.

526
00:28:42.056 --> 00:28:45.610
All network bits as being all 1s, right?

527
00:28:45.610 --> 00:28:47.450
And that's what we have, okay?

528
00:28:47.450 --> 00:28:50.955
So that is the, oops, I didn't have
to change it, I already typed it in.

529
00:28:50.955 --> 00:28:53.522
I was gonna say, darn.
>> I was wondering why you were doing it

530
00:28:53.522 --> 00:28:55.257
[LAUGH].
>> It was just because I keep

531
00:28:55.257 --> 00:28:59.042
forgetting everything,
that's what happens here.

532
00:28:59.042 --> 00:29:01.755
All right, so it's down here, okay?

533
00:29:01.755 --> 00:29:06.226
So 31.255, now Daniel,
this is were people get confused like,

534
00:29:06.226 --> 00:29:09.578
how is that actually one network?
>> Hold on Ronnie,

535
00:29:09.578 --> 00:29:11.772
that last one can't be right.

536
00:29:11.772 --> 00:29:14.153
Because if it's 32 was the next one,

537
00:29:14.153 --> 00:29:15.082
right?
>> Right.

538
00:29:15.082 --> 00:29:16.496
>> Then it can't be 31,

539
00:29:16.496 --> 00:29:18.555
it's gotta be 30 or something.

540
00:29:18.555 --> 00:29:22.542
But it's class B, that's the key.
>> That is the key, so

541
00:29:22.542 --> 00:29:26.640
you've gotta be careful here as you
start to take a look here, okay?

542
00:29:26.640 --> 00:29:31.550
So now you just continue
to move that third octet.

543
00:29:31.550 --> 00:29:34.341
And now remember,
we don't care what the first two are.

544
00:29:34.341 --> 00:29:40.266
We changed that number, so it actually
incremented one up from 00 to 01.

545
00:29:40.266 --> 00:29:44.269
And once we do that,
now you begin to go, hey,

546
00:29:44.269 --> 00:29:48.010
look at that, that's gonna be 32.0.

547
00:29:48.010 --> 00:29:52.930
And then your network range is one above

548
00:29:52.930 --> 00:29:58.600
the NetworkID and one down from
the BroadcastID and here's the broadcast.

549
00:29:58.600 --> 00:30:01.400
And if you talk about one down,
that's what it would normally be there.

550
00:30:01.400 --> 00:30:05.630
You just change that least significant
bit to a zero, and you're ready to go.

551
00:30:05.630 --> 00:30:07.780
So there's the second one, okay?

552
00:30:07.780 --> 00:30:10.460
Now we're not gonna go through the rest
of these, because you've already

553
00:30:10.460 --> 00:30:12.630
done this at this point here.
>> It's lather, rinse,

554
00:30:12.630 --> 00:30:14.531
repeat at this point.
>> It is pretty much that,

555
00:30:14.531 --> 00:30:17.690
and the only thing that you
have to do is verify, right?

556
00:30:17.690 --> 00:30:22.770
And the easiest way slowly that you verify
is by doing this right here, right?

557
00:30:22.770 --> 00:30:27.250
Verifying your bits,
once you get those fundamentals down and

558
00:30:27.250 --> 00:30:31.490
it begins to make sense there,
then we can work on increasing in speed.

559
00:30:31.490 --> 00:30:35.956
But until you start to see this, and
now where you can go sixth, seventh, and

560
00:30:35.956 --> 00:30:37.555
eighth, all the way down.

561
00:30:37.555 --> 00:30:39.810
Now we have one last step.

562
00:30:39.810 --> 00:30:44.172
Which is we wanted to make sure that we
could determine the number of hosts per

563
00:30:44.172 --> 00:30:44.793
network.

564
00:30:44.793 --> 00:30:48.790
So for us, if the network bits is 19,
then you just take 32 and

565
00:30:48.790 --> 00:30:50.620
you subtract 19 from 32.

566
00:30:50.620 --> 00:30:54.200
That leaves you with 13 bits, and

567
00:30:54.200 --> 00:30:59.200
then 2 to the 13th power,
that should give you 8,192.

568
00:30:59.200 --> 00:31:05.545
But we subtract out two numbers for
the NetworkID and for the BroadcastID,

569
00:31:05.545 --> 00:31:10.400
and now you can actually
get 8,090 per host, okay?

570
00:31:10.400 --> 00:31:15.098
Now if we compare that to what we
actually already did up here, so

571
00:31:15.098 --> 00:31:18.409
we were looking for eight networks, right?

572
00:31:18.409 --> 00:31:21.334
This time I kind of fudged
a little bit more here.

573
00:31:24.225 --> 00:31:28.251
And you can see that I actually picked
another network just as a representative

574
00:31:28.251 --> 00:31:29.350
example in this one.

575
00:31:29.350 --> 00:31:31.989
And there you go,
eight networks, 8,090 bits here.

576
00:31:31.989 --> 00:31:32.910
>> 8,190.

577
00:31:32.910 --> 00:31:34.670
>> 190, excuse me, god,

578
00:31:34.670 --> 00:31:37.130
see I can't even know.

579
00:31:37.130 --> 00:31:39.340
And notice that the NetworkID changed.

580
00:31:39.340 --> 00:31:43.090
So is this one of my networks
that's in what I just showed you?

581
00:31:43.090 --> 00:31:45.986
If I scroll down here to the bottom-
>> You're right in the middle of it.

582
00:31:45.986 --> 00:31:46.620
>> In my seventh network.

583
00:31:46.620 --> 00:31:50.850
Yep, I just chose one at random to
report so that we could see this.

584
00:31:50.850 --> 00:31:53.950
Cuz I wanted you to see that they
could be all different numbers here.

585
00:31:53.950 --> 00:31:56.990
And that's another thing in the realm
of Cisco that you want to start paying

586
00:31:56.990 --> 00:31:58.100
attention to.

587
00:31:58.100 --> 00:32:00.671
Which will help us to get
a little bit faster is this, and

588
00:32:00.671 --> 00:32:02.221
we'll end with this note, too.

589
00:32:02.221 --> 00:32:05.723
Cisco, as much as we like, and
especially in teaching, right?

590
00:32:05.723 --> 00:32:09.580
We want simple numbers, cuz binary
conversion of 1 is a lot easier than

591
00:32:09.580 --> 00:32:16.011
binary conversion of 177 and 185 and 187.
>> You see, cuz you gotta do that math

592
00:32:16.011 --> 00:32:20.480
thing that everyone is such a big fan of.
>> And so

593
00:32:20.480 --> 00:32:23.326
you're probably saying, so
what Ronnie, what's the big deal?

594
00:32:23.326 --> 00:32:26.313
Well, this is just a hint Daniel,

595
00:32:26.313 --> 00:32:31.884
Cisco is probably not gonna
test us on the 0.1 and the 8.1.

596
00:32:31.884 --> 00:32:36.660
It's gonna be something like 191.277-
>> They like to throw you the hard to

597
00:32:36.660 --> 00:32:38.674
find ones, right?
>> Not 277, 256 or 255,

598
00:32:38.674 --> 00:32:40.206
something like that.
>> 183.223.57.

599
00:32:40.206 --> 00:32:43.873
>> Yeah, not in the range that I gave you,

600
00:32:43.873 --> 00:32:46.993
cuz those are actually invalid.

601
00:32:46.993 --> 00:32:51.800
But just kind of realize
that they're always gonna

602
00:32:51.800 --> 00:32:55.020
be those kind of higher numbers.

603
00:32:55.020 --> 00:32:57.210
So we need to learn how
to work with those,

604
00:32:57.210 --> 00:33:00.140
but start practicing
something like this here.

605
00:33:00.140 --> 00:33:01.670
And once you get that done,

606
00:33:01.670 --> 00:33:05.860
then we can start working a little
bit faster at what we have to do.

607
00:33:05.860 --> 00:33:08.170
Now Daniel,
one of the keys that we have to do this,

608
00:33:08.170 --> 00:33:10.180
is that we have to go on
a little bit further.

609
00:33:10.180 --> 00:33:13.541
We still need to talk about some of
the other concepts here with class B,

610
00:33:13.541 --> 00:33:14.784
such as getting quicker.

611
00:33:14.784 --> 00:33:18.216
And we still have to talk about CIDR
notation just a little bit as well.

612
00:33:18.216 --> 00:33:23.419
And then we'll get into some practice
that should kind of be challenging and

613
00:33:23.419 --> 00:33:24.895
fun at the same time.

614
00:33:24.895 --> 00:33:28.780
So Daniel that is the basics
of class B subnetting.

615
00:33:28.780 --> 00:33:32.204
Remember that the key here is that
the networks get really large

616
00:33:32.204 --> 00:33:35.122
as the number of hosts start
shrinking at this point.

617
00:33:35.122 --> 00:33:39.027
And so you can actually have thousands
of networks with the class B,

618
00:33:39.027 --> 00:33:42.191
instead of just 100 and
then, well, 50 or 60.

619
00:33:42.191 --> 00:33:46.029
It's 60 from that point and less.
>> Gotcha, well Ronnie,

620
00:33:46.029 --> 00:33:47.700
it's been good stuff so far.

621
00:33:47.700 --> 00:33:49.304
It's all coming back to me now.

622
00:33:49.304 --> 00:33:51.920
It's been a while since I've
had to mess with this stuff.

623
00:33:51.920 --> 00:33:54.290
So it's a lot of fun,
it can be challenging.

624
00:33:54.290 --> 00:33:57.525
And if you thought you were gonna roll up
in here thinking that Ronnie's gonna do

625
00:33:57.525 --> 00:33:58.890
a class B subnetting in one show.

626
00:33:58.890 --> 00:34:00.931
Well, we hate to pull the rug
out from underneath you.

627
00:34:00.931 --> 00:34:03.680
But we're going into a part two,
so come back for that.

628
00:34:03.680 --> 00:34:07.140
Ronnie, we appreciate your time as always,
looking forward to seeing you in part two.

629
00:34:07.140 --> 00:34:10.099
But let's do it everyone,
signing off for ITPro.TV,

630
00:34:10.099 --> 00:34:13.715
[LAUGH] I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.
>> [LAUGH] And I'm Ronnie Wong.

631
00:34:13.715 --> 00:34:14.810
>> We'll see you next time.

632
00:34:14.810 --> 00:34:22.035
[MUSIC]

633
00:34:22.035 --> 00:34:27.071
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the use of CIDR.  The team describe CIDR's function.  They contrast this notation as being easier way to report the network bits no longer by arbitrary classes.  They emphasize the importance understanding these notations for the exam.
episodes.title: Understand Class B Subnetting Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.480
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.480 --> 00:00:06.613
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.613 --> 00:00:08.277
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.277 --> 00:00:13.805
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.
>> All right, greetings, everyone,

5
00:00:13.805 --> 00:00:17.833
and welcome back to another great episode
of ITPRO.TV, I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:17.833 --> 00:00:21.346
And in today's episode,
we're back with more of our CCENT series.

7
00:00:21.346 --> 00:00:25.126
And of course, joining us yet again in
the studio for some more subnetting.

8
00:00:25.126 --> 00:00:27.993
Class B subnetting specifically,
our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong,

9
00:00:27.993 --> 00:00:30.694
Ronnie, welcome back, how's it going?
>> It is going well, Daniel.

10
00:00:30.694 --> 00:00:34.237
Thank you for having me on the show as
we continue on taking a look at some

11
00:00:34.237 --> 00:00:36.899
of the other features inside
of Class B subnetting.

12
00:00:36.899 --> 00:00:41.636
Now the one we're about to talk about here
is not really specific to Class B, but

13
00:00:41.636 --> 00:00:44.553
we see it more often applied
in Class B networks.

14
00:00:44.553 --> 00:00:49.415
The majority of the time because writing
out a subnet mask, Daniel, when it comes

15
00:00:49.415 --> 00:00:53.300
down to it, is kind of redundant, right?
>> [LAUGH]

16
00:00:53.300 --> 00:00:57.664
>> 255.255.255.128.192,

17
00:00:57.664 --> 00:01:01.915
it becomes insanely
redundant after a while,

18
00:01:01.915 --> 00:01:06.937
reporting on those things
becomes redundant as well.

19
00:01:06.937 --> 00:01:11.407
And then trying to get the information
passed on from one particular person to

20
00:01:11.407 --> 00:01:14.457
another one,
it really gets to be very long winded.

21
00:01:14.457 --> 00:01:18.459
Even in reporting and writing when we
have to say that every single time.

22
00:01:18.459 --> 00:01:21.927
So one of the things
that started to happen,

23
00:01:21.927 --> 00:01:25.219
if we kind of back up
in time just a moment.

24
00:01:25.219 --> 00:01:28.530
Let's kind of remind ourselves
of a few different things that

25
00:01:28.530 --> 00:01:30.836
happened on the Internet as it came along.

26
00:01:30.836 --> 00:01:35.061
As we started depleting addresses, we've
done this earlier on another episode.

27
00:01:35.061 --> 00:01:40.019
Remember that three or four technologies
really did come along to help us

28
00:01:40.019 --> 00:01:43.283
to slow down the depletion
of those addresses.

29
00:01:43.283 --> 00:01:46.828
We've talked about this idea of NAT,
Network Address Translation.

30
00:01:46.828 --> 00:01:50.525
Where we now have those private
IP addresses that aren't valid on

31
00:01:50.525 --> 00:01:54.037
the Internet, that get converted
into public IP addresses.

32
00:01:54.037 --> 00:01:58.117
And there's different methods in how that
also works, but the simple one is this,

33
00:01:58.117 --> 00:02:00.055
and so one to one translation, right?

34
00:02:00.055 --> 00:02:04.124
You have public IP addresses and
you have private IP addresses and

35
00:02:04.124 --> 00:02:08.053
your router can convert one over
to another one, if we need to.

36
00:02:08.053 --> 00:02:12.101
Now that's usually not just the only
way that it happens today, but for us,

37
00:02:12.101 --> 00:02:14.832
that's at least the simple
basics of what we have.

38
00:02:14.832 --> 00:02:19.160
The other one that we also can do,
of course, is like we talked about here,

39
00:02:19.160 --> 00:02:21.790
use of private IP
addresses behind a router.

40
00:02:21.790 --> 00:02:26.895
And then, of course, the solution to that
is the use of IP version 6 addresses,

41
00:02:26.895 --> 00:02:30.067
which is really starting
to come on strongly now.

42
00:02:30.067 --> 00:02:34.719
A lot of ISPs are now ready for it, most
companies haven't switched over yet, but

43
00:02:34.719 --> 00:02:36.890
they're probably ready at any time.

44
00:02:36.890 --> 00:02:41.809
I think even our ISP said that any time we
want to convert over, they are ready for

45
00:02:41.809 --> 00:02:45.276
us to convert over, so
they've got everything set up.

46
00:02:45.276 --> 00:02:47.652
But let's go back to this one.

47
00:02:47.652 --> 00:02:50.530
Which is really what
became super helpful for

48
00:02:50.530 --> 00:02:54.477
us to slow down the depletion
of IP addresses on the Internet.

49
00:02:54.477 --> 00:02:57.512
Which is variable length subnet masking.

50
00:02:57.512 --> 00:03:01.772
Now once we started actually implementing
variable length subnet masking.

51
00:03:01.772 --> 00:03:06.445
What this actually ends up meaning for
a single company is simple.

52
00:03:06.445 --> 00:03:10.503
Let's say, for an example,
we have this 192.168.1.0 network,

53
00:03:10.503 --> 00:03:12.600
we can use a Class B
address if we need to.

54
00:03:12.600 --> 00:03:16.693
And if we do that, we have one
network with so many hosts on it.

55
00:03:16.693 --> 00:03:21.328
Well, we can now subdivide,
which we've been doing subnetting now for

56
00:03:21.328 --> 00:03:24.219
quite a bit of time,
in taking a look at that.

57
00:03:24.219 --> 00:03:27.852
And the problem with the subnetting and
the way that we've done it,

58
00:03:27.852 --> 00:03:30.159
whether it's Class C or Class B is simple.

59
00:03:30.159 --> 00:03:31.400
When we created eight networks.

60
00:03:31.400 --> 00:03:35.957
We understood that each one of those eight
networks were going to give us essentially

61
00:03:35.957 --> 00:03:38.406
what the same range of IP addresses,
right?

62
00:03:38.406 --> 00:03:42.848
So the last one that we did,
with the eight networks that we did,

63
00:03:42.848 --> 00:03:44.875
I think I had 8,190-
>> Correct.

64
00:03:44.875 --> 00:03:46.829
>> Possible hosts, right?

65
00:03:46.829 --> 00:03:53.378
So each one of those eight subnets gave
us equal number of hosts per network.

66
00:03:53.378 --> 00:03:58.316
Well, Daniel, in reality, in a business,
even if it is a large business, okay,

67
00:03:58.316 --> 00:04:02.075
we may find out that there is
one network that's large, okay?

68
00:04:02.075 --> 00:04:06.848
But then we might find out that we have
branch offices that have maybe a handful,

69
00:04:06.848 --> 00:04:09.927
15 or maybe less than that,
10, out of there.

70
00:04:09.927 --> 00:04:13.623
Some may have 30 or 25 employees,

71
00:04:13.623 --> 00:04:18.486
some may have 50, but not 120, not 254.

72
00:04:18.486 --> 00:04:24.275
So if we have something like that,
now that becomes more challenging.

73
00:04:24.275 --> 00:04:28.742
Because what we want to do is we want
to conserve address spaces, okay?

74
00:04:28.742 --> 00:04:30.895
So on the Internet,
that is much more important.

75
00:04:30.895 --> 00:04:35.024
So what your ISPs did is they took
the addresses they they were given,

76
00:04:35.024 --> 00:04:36.667
such as Class C addresses.

77
00:04:36.667 --> 00:04:40.181
And then they were actually able to
chop them off, Daniel calls them,

78
00:04:40.181 --> 00:04:42.161
he goes, I need two IP addresses.

79
00:04:42.161 --> 00:04:46.102
I don't need six,
I don't need eight, I need two.

80
00:04:46.102 --> 00:04:49.566
Well, we have a Class C, Daniel says,
no, no, no, you're not understanding me.

81
00:04:49.566 --> 00:04:50.477
>> That's too much, [LAUGH].

82
00:04:50.477 --> 00:04:52.646
>> Two, I just two.

83
00:04:52.646 --> 00:04:56.703
Well, with variable length subnet masking,
that can be done.

84
00:04:56.703 --> 00:05:01.669
So ISPs can do that, they can chop
off a portion of what they can do,

85
00:05:01.669 --> 00:05:05.861
now, can they give Daniel
exactly three if he needs it?

86
00:05:05.861 --> 00:05:08.270
No.
>> There's limitations.

87
00:05:08.270 --> 00:05:09.631
>> Yeah, there is limitations and

88
00:05:09.631 --> 00:05:13.324
limitation comes back down to what we've
learned about, which is the binary, okay?

89
00:05:13.324 --> 00:05:15.573
So if we remember that
those binary place values,

90
00:05:15.573 --> 00:05:17.402
those are the limitations that we have.

91
00:05:17.402 --> 00:05:20.815
I can give Daniel one, because I know
that the binary value, the place value,

92
00:05:20.815 --> 00:05:21.446
gives me one.

93
00:05:21.446 --> 00:05:26.578
We could do two, we know that there's
that, we could do four, but three?

94
00:05:26.578 --> 00:05:28.011
Daniel would have to go with four.
>> Right.

95
00:05:28.011 --> 00:05:28.708
>> Okay?

96
00:05:28.708 --> 00:05:33.863
So that's what we have, too, so there
are certain limitations to this as well.

97
00:05:33.863 --> 00:05:36.887
And when you start dealing
with something like this,

98
00:05:36.887 --> 00:05:40.797

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the basics of IPv6 addressing.  The team describe it's history and why it is needed for networking today.  They also describe the IPv6 address as 128 bits and it is reported in hexadecimal format.  IPv6 address works the same as the IPv4 address having 2 parts:  Network ID and Interface ID. formatting of what it actually does, okay?

475
00:24:54.460 --> 00:24:59.690
Now, this particular address is also
actually a special type of address,

476
00:24:59.690 --> 00:25:00.670
as well.

477
00:25:00.670 --> 00:25:04.420
And that's what we need to jump into,
Daniel, is now, we need to, of course,

478
00:25:04.420 --> 00:25:08.790
talk about some of the different types of
addresses that we are likely to encounter.

479
00:25:08.790 --> 00:25:13.090
You're likely to see as you start
doing IP version 6 networking, okay.

480
00:25:13.090 --> 00:25:17.820
But Daniel, there's only like three,
four minutes left on our [CROSSTALK] so

481
00:25:17.820 --> 00:25:22.545
it's not enough time for us to get into it
cuz if I start I'm not gonna be able to

482
00:25:22.545 --> 00:25:24.690
finish.
>> Yeah, yeah that's right.

483
00:25:24.690 --> 00:25:25.260
It's how he is,

484
00:25:25.260 --> 00:25:29.540
he's like an old some sort of housing he
just keeps going until he gets there.

485
00:25:29.540 --> 00:25:31.820
Or through yeah, or
through yeah that's right.

486
00:25:31.820 --> 00:25:34.950
So Ronnie, we will do that,
we will and we'll wind you down,

487
00:25:34.950 --> 00:25:37.080
let you take some pixie dust here and
settle down.

488
00:25:37.080 --> 00:25:39.790
I know he's chomping at the bit
to get at those addresses.

489
00:25:39.790 --> 00:25:41.370
But we're not gonna let
him do it just yet.

490
00:25:41.370 --> 00:25:43.220
So come back for part two on this.

491
00:25:43.220 --> 00:25:46.510
Ronnie, we'll see you there, we do thank
you good folks out there for watching.

492
00:25:46.510 --> 00:25:49.850
We're gonna call this one a show signing
off for ITProTV, I've been your host,

493
00:25:49.850 --> 00:25:51.260
Daniel Lowrie.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

494
00:25:51.260 --> 00:25:53.579
>> And we'll see you next time.

495
00:25:53.579 --> 00:25:59.471
[MUSIC]

496
00:25:59.471 --> 00:26:04.945
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss some of the different IPv6 address types.  The guys discuss the different types of unicast addresses: Unspecified, Loopback, ULA and Global Unicast.  These unicast types of addresses are used for testing, for reaching nodes within the same local networks and routing.
episodes.title: Identify IPv6 Addressing Scheme Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:00.906
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:00.906 --> 00:00:06.293
I am your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.293 --> 00:00:08.527
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.527 --> 00:00:12.577
>> You are watching ITPro.TV.
>> All right,

5
00:00:12.577 --> 00:00:15.970
greetings, everyone, and welcome back
to another great episode of IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:15.970 --> 00:00:17.790
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

7
00:00:17.790 --> 00:00:21.670
in today's episode we're back with more
of our CCENT series, and joining us for

8
00:00:21.670 --> 00:00:25.220
a part two in IPv6 addressing,
our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:25.220 --> 00:00:27.750
Ronnie, welcome back, how's it going?
>> It is going great, Daniel.

10
00:00:27.750 --> 00:00:30.820
Thank you for having me back on the show
as we continue taking a look at this

11
00:00:30.820 --> 00:00:33.410
little series here on IP Version 6.

12
00:00:33.410 --> 00:00:35.762
It is a transitional at least for us,

13
00:00:35.762 --> 00:00:39.990
right, moving from IP version four to IP
version six, it's gonna be a little bit of

14
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:43.611
transition that we have to get used to,
that we have to understand.

15
00:00:43.611 --> 00:00:47.698
It begins of course with a basic
understanding of what the formatting of IP

16
00:00:47.698 --> 00:00:48.960
version six looks like.

17
00:00:48.960 --> 00:00:52.900
And then also, some of the different
addresses that we're going to encounter

18
00:00:52.900 --> 00:00:54.830
as we start to see this.

19
00:00:54.830 --> 00:00:58.110
So let's go ahead and start here,
and we'll start taking

20
00:00:58.110 --> 00:01:02.180
a look at some of the different types of
addresses and see how far we get, right?

21
00:01:02.180 --> 00:01:06.610
So here on my screen I've tried to divide
this up to help us out a little bit more.

22
00:01:06.610 --> 00:01:10.600
And we're just gonna spend some time
in identifying some of the formats and

23
00:01:10.600 --> 00:01:14.350
making sure that we can see
what we need to, right?

24
00:01:14.350 --> 00:01:16.050
Just remember the key here, okay?

25
00:01:16.050 --> 00:01:18.890
So at the very beginning of everything,

26
00:01:18.890 --> 00:01:21.390
when they first started coming
out with it, they did this.

27
00:01:21.390 --> 00:01:23.230
They took the 128 bits,

28
00:01:23.230 --> 00:01:26.540
they said the first part is really
going to be your network ID.

29
00:01:26.540 --> 00:01:30.220
And technically, they call it the unicast
prefix because we are now talking about

30
00:01:30.220 --> 00:01:32.180
unicast types of addressing.

31
00:01:32.180 --> 00:01:35.845
Just like what we had talked about in
IP version 4 where there is unicast,

32
00:01:35.845 --> 00:01:41.822
there's broadcast, and there is multicast,
well, IP version 6 there are unicast.

33
00:01:41.822 --> 00:01:45.190
Broadcasts they have completely gone away,
okay?

34
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:49.330
And now, we have multicast and
that's pretty much it.

35
00:01:49.330 --> 00:01:54.920
Essentially, multicast replaces or
supersedes what broadcasts do, okay?

36
00:01:54.920 --> 00:01:58.730
So that's what you'll end up
seeing is what happens there.

37
00:01:58.730 --> 00:02:04.640
So broadcast addresses are pretty much
just disappeared by IP version 6.

38
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:10.930
Over on the left-hand side, there's
gonna be some different types of unicast

39
00:02:10.930 --> 00:02:15.680
addresses that you need to be
very familiar with as you go and

40
00:02:15.680 --> 00:02:18.260
start to see this on the exam as well.

41
00:02:18.260 --> 00:02:19.629
And also, of course,

42
00:02:19.629 --> 00:02:23.820
some of them will be utilities just
like what we have an IP version 4.

43
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:26.410
Some them will, of course,
represent different things, and

44
00:02:26.410 --> 00:02:28.250
then I will show you some of the other,

45
00:02:28.250 --> 00:02:31.870
like this last one here in IP version 4
format, we'll talk about that one, too.

46
00:02:31.870 --> 00:02:35.340
So at the very beginning here,
I just wanted to try and

47
00:02:35.340 --> 00:02:40.620
set up the stage of what you actually
end up seeing a lot of times too, okay?

48
00:02:40.620 --> 00:02:43.830
The first type of unicast address
that we're gonna talk about, and

49
00:02:43.830 --> 00:02:47.080
we've actually left off the big one
which I have on another slide here,

50
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:50.280
we're gonna talk about the global
unicast address as well, okay?

51
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:50.960
But at the beginning,

52
00:02:50.960 --> 00:02:54.420
some of the ones that you might end up
seeing as kind of a little bit strange.

53
00:02:54.420 --> 00:02:59.090
If you have where it's actually
all zeros that are reported, okay?

54
00:02:59.090 --> 00:03:04.200
So if you see eight sections and they're
all zeros, okay, and then this ends with

55
00:03:04.200 --> 00:03:08.850
a /128 here, they're essentially
telling you this is the network ID.

56
00:03:10.240 --> 00:03:16.380
All 128 of them, it's all zeros,
it is called an unspecified address.

57
00:03:16.380 --> 00:03:23.840
Now the unspecified address, it can be
the source of an IP version 6 traffic.

58
00:03:23.840 --> 00:03:26.380
But what it normally actually means for

59
00:03:26.380 --> 00:03:31.058
us is that the traffic source has yet
to be identified.

60
00:03:31.058 --> 00:03:32.020
In other words,

61
00:03:32.020 --> 00:03:36.704
they don't really have an address assigned
to whatever interface it came from.

62
00:03:36.704 --> 00:03:40.342
So instead of actually just
leaving it blank at that point,

63
00:03:40.342 --> 00:03:46.340
they're gonna put one that begins with
all zero's instead, and the whole thing.

64
00:03:46.340 --> 00:03:51.901
So when you see it, you actually see that
contiguous string of all those zeros,

65
00:03:51.901 --> 00:03:56.230
okay, and
then at the end you'll see a slash 128.

66
00:03:56.230 --> 00:04:00.864
Now, if you shorten it up, okay, what it
actually ends up looking like is this

67
00:04:00.864 --> 00:04:03.762
portion right here that is highlighted,
okay?

68
00:04:03.762 --> 00:04:09.251
Which is a ::0 /128.

69
00:04:09.251 --> 00:04:13.192
Now, that address, if you go and
you think about the idea of routing, so

70
00:04:13.192 --> 00:04:17.263
those of you that are familiar with
the routing table inside, let's say,

71
00:04:17.263 --> 00:04:19.350
of a Windows machine, right?

72
00:04:19.350 --> 00:04:23.700
If you take a look at something like that,
let's see if I can point that out here.

73
00:04:23.700 --> 00:04:29.950
Let me go to my command prompt,
and then we'll do the route print,

74
00:04:29.950 --> 00:04:35.050
okay, you'll notice that I have one
of those addresses right here, okay?

75
00:04:35.050 --> 00:04:40.070
And when you see where it's actually all
zeroes, okay, this is now saying in this

76
00:04:40.070 --> 00:04:46.510
IP version 6 route table is that, look,
here's where it's actually going.

77
00:04:46.510 --> 00:04:47.762
Now, what does that actually mean?

78
00:04:47.762 --> 00:04:49.490
It means it can go anywhere.

79
00:04:49.490 --> 00:04:51.290
Notice it's unspecified.

80
00:04:51.290 --> 00:04:54.710
It's saying, look,
I don't have a particular destination.

81
00:04:54.710 --> 00:04:57.768
But normally, what we're actually doing
is when we do something like that,

82
00:04:57.768 --> 00:04:59.568
we're telling it to
send it somewhere else.

83
00:04:59.568 --> 00:05:03.275
And this one says send it out on that
same link, which is perfectly fine.

84
00:05:03.275 --> 00:05:07.160
But in Cisco land, okay,
you'll probably see this as possibly being

85
00:05:07.160 --> 00:05:11.890
a source address, rarely
a destination address a lot of times.

86
00:05:11.890 --> 00:05:13.810
But in the world of Microsoft,

87
00:05:13.810 --> 00:05:17.270
you actually do see where it's actually
that destination address as well, okay?

88
00:05:17.270 --> 00:05:20.709
So that one is actually gonna
be something that we can use.

89
00:05:20.709 --> 00:05:22.035
And in our routing table,

90
00:05:22.035 --> 00:05:26.132
if we actually just see it because we've
done some type of show command in Cisco,

91
00:05:26.132 --> 00:05:30.292
it's probably because we do not know what
the actual source is, so they're still

92
00:05:30.292 --> 00:05:34.300
saying traffic from source that we don't
know, it can still come out, okay?

93
00:05:34.300 --> 00:05:35.270
So that's where you have it.

94
00:05:35.270 --> 00:05:39.656
So make sure you can
actually identify that.

95
00:05:39.656 --> 00:05:43.080
Now, the other one that we
also have is the same thing as

96
00:05:43.080 --> 00:05:48.060
what we have inside of IP version 4,
which is the loop-back address.

97
00:05:48.060 --> 00:05:50.983
So most of us have learned
the idea of the home address or

98
00:05:50.983 --> 00:05:52.837
the loop-back address, right?

99
00:05:52.837 --> 00:05:58.400
127.0.0.1, usually that's
what it's going to be.

100
00:05:58.400 --> 00:06:02.450
But remember that in all reality
it's that entire network range.

101
00:06:02.450 --> 00:06:07.225
So, Daniel,
have you actually ever pinged anything for

102
00:06:07.225 --> 00:06:12.097
your loop-back besides 127.0.0.1?
>> Yes.

103
00:06:12.097 --> 00:06:13.522
>> Okay, and what did you get?

104
00:06:13.522 --> 00:06:15.620
Did you get a reply?
>> I did.

105
00:06:15.620 --> 00:06:17.030
>> Yeah, you actually ended up getting

106
00:06:17.030 --> 00:06:17.980
a reply here, okay?

107
00:06:17.980 --> 00:06:19.900
So here's the one that we normally do.

108
00:06:19.900 --> 00:06:21.990
And the loop-back address
really is tied back to what?

109
00:06:21.990 --> 00:06:23.600
My own interace, right?
>> Correct.

110
00:06:23.600 --> 00:06:31.637
>> So if I go and ping 127.254.139.245,

111
00:06:31.637 --> 00:06:38.985
okay, Daniel,
who's actually replying here?

112
00:06:38.985 --> 00:06:42.060
Who do you think is replying
to that address at all?

113
00:06:43.800 --> 00:06:46.100
>> I'm assuming it's also the loop-back.

114
00:06:46.100 --> 00:06:47.070
>> It is also the loop-back.

115
00:06:47.070 --> 00:06:48.064
And see, that's the weird thing.

116
00:06:48.064 --> 00:06:51.569
Most of us, because we've only
been trained like 127.0.0.1,

117
00:06:51.569 --> 00:06:53.660
that's the only address you ping.

118
00:06:53.660 --> 00:06:57.888
You can ping anything in 127 and
it's actually your own loop-back, okay?

119
00:06:57.888 --> 00:07:00.670
It's your own machine answering here.

120
00:07:00.670 --> 00:07:02.925
So, anything in the 127 range.

121
00:07:02.925 --> 00:07:07.020
That's not exactly mind blowing,
but you kinda look and go,

122
00:07:07.020 --> 00:07:11.106
wait a minute, I'm 0.0.1.
>> So, funny thing.

123
00:07:11.106 --> 00:07:18.028
I actually use that to exploit
a system that was blocking 127.0.0.1,

124
00:07:18.028 --> 00:07:24.650
wasn't blocking 127.0.0.2 or 127.200.0.1.

125
00:07:24.650 --> 00:07:29.385
And I was able to get it to respond.
>> And that does lead you to actually

126
00:07:29.385 --> 00:07:33.670
realize how narrow we've
gotten in our focus sometimes,

127
00:07:33.670 --> 00:07:36.450
that someone might have actually done
this, if you did this through a firewall,

128
00:07:36.450 --> 00:07:40.300
said I just need to block that loop-back
address, that one loop-back address, and

129
00:07:40.300 --> 00:07:44.550
not thinking about that entire range,
what are called Bogon ranges, too.

130
00:07:44.550 --> 00:07:45.160
>> And just saying, look,

131
00:07:45.160 --> 00:07:46.460
the whole range here.

132
00:07:46.460 --> 00:07:47.840
So you can get tripped up.

133
00:07:47.840 --> 00:07:51.416
And thank you for that example, cuz I
didn't even think about that as exploiting

134
00:07:51.416 --> 00:07:54.558
that particular device.
>> [CROSSTALK] cross-site scripting, and

135
00:07:54.558 --> 00:07:57.690
I wanted to do it against that local host,
so I was doing 127,

136
00:07:57.690 --> 00:08:00.546
then they got smart and
closed down 127.0.0.1.

137
00:08:00.546 --> 00:08:01.820
Then I used localhost.
>> Yeah.

138
00:08:01.820 --> 00:08:03.009
>> [LAUGH] Just because that-

139
00:08:03.009 --> 00:08:03.630
>> Yeah, that works, too.

140
00:08:03.630 --> 00:08:04.602
>> That translates.

141
00:08:04.602 --> 00:08:06.300
[LAUGH] They shut that down.

142
00:08:06.300 --> 00:08:08.235
Then I was like, well,
we'll try something else.

143
00:08:08.235 --> 00:08:11.760
IPv6 is localhost as well.
>> It is, yeah, so

144
00:08:11.760 --> 00:08:16.495
when we start doing that with IPv6,
okay, they really only have one though.

145
00:08:16.495 --> 00:08:17.200
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah.

146
00:08:17.200 --> 00:08:17.791
>> So, for

147
00:08:17.791 --> 00:08:22.696
us it's all zeros, and then in
the interface ID it's gonna be a one.

148
00:08:22.696 --> 00:08:27.610
So now notice that I still get
replies that are coming through,

149
00:08:27.610 --> 00:08:32.150
and this allows us to see that
it is also working as well.

150
00:08:32.150 --> 00:08:34.610
Replying to what we see,
which is the protocol, and

151
00:08:34.610 --> 00:08:36.850
everything is actually working too, okay.

152
00:08:36.850 --> 00:08:40.012
Now, remember that all of these,
right, at least these first two here,

153
00:08:40.012 --> 00:08:42.984
it's still the same thing,
it's still the first 128 bits here.

154
00:08:42.984 --> 00:08:45.634
They're actually gonna
be designated this way.

155
00:08:45.634 --> 00:08:48.880
You should not see any
other numbers in front.

156
00:08:48.880 --> 00:08:52.990
They should really, in this network
portion, always be zeroes, and

157
00:08:52.990 --> 00:08:54.560
then the same thing here.

158
00:08:54.560 --> 00:08:55.990
Make sure you know those two.

159
00:08:55.990 --> 00:08:59.270
As simple as it is, and you go,
okay Ronnie, that's easy enough.

160
00:08:59.270 --> 00:09:04.240
It's really difficult on an exam when
they give you both of them, and you can't

161
00:09:04.240 --> 00:09:07.680
remember which one's the loop back, and
which one's the unspecified address.

162
00:09:07.680 --> 00:09:09.890
Make sure you actually
pay attention there,

163
00:09:09.890 --> 00:09:12.210
to make sure you can distinguish them.

164
00:09:12.210 --> 00:09:15.940
So you'll see these right
there to help you out.

165
00:09:15.940 --> 00:09:20.660
Now, the other one here, and this is one
that also can get confused with another

166
00:09:20.660 --> 00:09:25.540
type of address, in the way that's
actually listed here, okay.

167
00:09:25.540 --> 00:09:28.922
So, there is what we call
a unique local address,

168
00:09:28.922 --> 00:09:32.069
sometimes you also see
it abbreviated as ULA.

169
00:09:32.069 --> 00:09:38.128
Let me type that out just in case somebody
actually does read that that way.

170
00:09:38.128 --> 00:09:41.591
ULA, the unique local address.

171
00:09:41.591 --> 00:09:45.634
This type of address here is very

172
00:09:45.634 --> 00:09:51.090
similar to your APIPA address, okay.

173
00:09:51.090 --> 00:09:53.850
Now, if you've already been
reading about this, and

174
00:09:53.850 --> 00:09:57.870
a lot of people get this confused with
what they call the link local address, and

175
00:09:57.870 --> 00:10:01.297
they go, yeah, that functions
exactly like APIPA does, okay.

176
00:10:01.297 --> 00:10:06.470
Well, both of them function
like what APIPA does, okay, but

177
00:10:06.470 --> 00:10:13.220
inside of the unique local, okay,
you have a different range here, okay.

178
00:10:13.220 --> 00:10:14.180
So the unique local,

179
00:10:14.180 --> 00:10:18.550
make sure you equate that to something
that's very similar to the APIPA address.

180
00:10:18.550 --> 00:10:22.540
If you take a look at
the very first portions in

181
00:10:22.540 --> 00:10:27.484
the unicast prefix here,
okay, the first seven bits.

182
00:10:27.484 --> 00:10:32.503
So if we were to convert this FC,
and the first seven bits here,

183
00:10:32.503 --> 00:10:37.645
and I'll just use this space right here,
F would be all ones.

184
00:10:37.645 --> 00:10:43.205
That gives us 15, which is the equivalent
of what we see as F, and then C would be,

185
00:10:43.205 --> 00:10:50.212
A is 10, B is 11, C is 12,
that would be 1 1 0 0, okay, like that.

186
00:10:50.212 --> 00:10:53.542
And now they're saying
it's the first seven bits.

187
00:10:53.542 --> 00:10:59.532
So, according to the prefix notation
that we see right here, the prefix link,

188
00:10:59.532 --> 00:11:05.182
what they're telling us is that
that portion of the very beginning

189
00:11:05.182 --> 00:11:11.370
of the address, the first seven bits,
are the ones that will not change, okay?

190
00:11:11.370 --> 00:11:12.620
Now, technically,

191
00:11:12.620 --> 00:11:16.490
there's actually even another one
that we can actually convert there.

192
00:11:16.490 --> 00:11:17.590
Did I do that right?

193
00:11:17.590 --> 00:11:18.790
Yeah, okay.
>> [LAUGH]

194
00:11:18.790 --> 00:11:19.923
>> I start looking at a series of ones

195
00:11:19.923 --> 00:11:21.346
like, how many ones did I put down there?

196
00:11:21.346 --> 00:11:24.220
So I needed to count again,
that's right, okay.

197

That's why we would use
something like DHP, right?

424
00:24:05.760 --> 00:24:09.740
So that can be done, but now we don't
have to do this statically, Daniel.

425
00:24:09.740 --> 00:24:11.229
64 bits?

426
00:24:11.229 --> 00:24:13.830
That's a lot of numbers to have to
type in just on two or three machines.

427
00:24:13.830 --> 00:24:14.950
>> I'm going to number that truck master

428
00:24:14.950 --> 00:24:16.792
school you were working at?
>> Yeah, truck master,

429
00:24:16.792 --> 00:24:18.757
do you still have that number?
>> Yeah, we need that.

430
00:24:18.757 --> 00:24:20.550
>> So here we go.

431
00:24:20.550 --> 00:24:25.420
Now on the 64 bit, how do people
end up dealing with this portion.

432
00:24:25.420 --> 00:24:27.090
Well it's easy, okay?

433
00:24:27.090 --> 00:24:29.760
For those that remember back
when we reviewed a little bit of

434
00:24:29.760 --> 00:24:32.652
some hardware that we've been talking
about such as the network interface card,

435
00:24:32.652 --> 00:24:35.020
the NIC that we have available.

436
00:24:35.020 --> 00:24:36.870
There's a hardware address on, okay?

437
00:24:36.870 --> 00:24:40.845
So you heard the term hardware address,
burned in address, MAC address,

438
00:24:40.845 --> 00:24:41.549
you name it.

439
00:24:41.549 --> 00:24:45.331
We've heard all of these
different type of addresses and

440
00:24:45.331 --> 00:24:48.020
that number is a 48 bit number, okay?

441
00:24:48.020 --> 00:24:54.981
So when you do something like that, that's
what happens is that out of those 64 bits,

442
00:24:54.981 --> 00:24:59.970
a lot of companies just allow for
the network interface cards to

443
00:24:59.970 --> 00:25:05.790
assign 48 bits of this to that
portion of the interface ID, okay?

444
00:25:05.790 --> 00:25:07.810
So that's what will also end up happening.

445
00:25:07.810 --> 00:25:12.635
Now if your company has also
ended up doing this, right?

446
00:25:12.635 --> 00:25:16.260
Let's say that they bought all the NICs
for all the machines that they have in

447
00:25:16.260 --> 00:25:19.215
their company, all from Intel,
just as an example.

448
00:25:19.215 --> 00:25:22.510
Well, what that does

449
00:25:22.510 --> 00:25:27.390
is it actually leaves everything as
being almost identical except for

450
00:25:27.390 --> 00:25:32.520
the last 24 bits of this interface
identifier and that is because on each and

451
00:25:32.520 --> 00:25:36.790
every one of those NICs is stamped,
essentially, a serial number from

452
00:25:36.790 --> 00:25:41.990
the company or the vendor ID,
also known as a unique ID that we have.

453
00:25:41.990 --> 00:25:47.270
So it really is kind of
a gigantic mass way that

454
00:25:47.270 --> 00:25:53.030
we can easily have IP addresses
on these machines as well.

455
00:25:53.030 --> 00:25:56.510
So this is probably the most important one
because when we talk about the idea of

456
00:25:56.510 --> 00:26:02.210
global unicast here, it means that
this particular address is routable.

457
00:26:02.210 --> 00:26:07.310
So with this address, remember that the
benefit behind us is we don't need private

458
00:26:07.310 --> 00:26:11.250
IP addresses anymore because private IP
addresses aren't allowed on the Internet.

459
00:26:11.250 --> 00:26:15.530
It means that my own machine can
actually have an address like this.

460
00:26:15.530 --> 00:26:18.910
And be routed out on the Internet and
don't have to worry, again,

461
00:26:18.910 --> 00:26:22.060
about setting up so
many structures in between, okay?

462
00:26:22.060 --> 00:26:25.774
So in that unicast idea that
we've actually talked about here,

463
00:26:25.774 --> 00:26:29.714
there are a lot of different ones
that we have to think about, okay?

464
00:26:29.714 --> 00:26:35.494
So do remember, pay attention to what
a specified address is loop back address,

465
00:26:35.494 --> 00:26:37.286
the unique local or ULA.

466
00:26:37.286 --> 00:26:41.275
Make sure you pay attention to
that abbreviation sometimes.

467
00:26:41.275 --> 00:26:44.499
Don't worry about the IP version format,
I just put that in there for

468
00:26:44.499 --> 00:26:47.260
the sake of completeness cuz
you'll see that sometimes.

469
00:26:47.260 --> 00:26:51.280
And then the Global Unicast, this is by
far the most important one that we'll

470
00:26:51.280 --> 00:26:55.540
kind of see at least for the purpose
of the exam, know the breakdown here.

471
00:26:55.540 --> 00:26:59.390
Yeah, I can't tell you anything
different at this point.

472
00:26:59.390 --> 00:27:02.580
You don't have to know everything but
you have to know at least the breakdown.

473
00:27:02.580 --> 00:27:05.260
Remember that this is the type of
address that we normally do end up

474
00:27:05.260 --> 00:27:08.135
assigning to an interface on a router.

475
00:27:08.135 --> 00:27:12.970
And a lot of times, and of course even on
individual host machines that will have.

476
00:27:12.970 --> 00:27:15.780
We still need to talk about
assignment of these addresses too but

477
00:27:15.780 --> 00:27:18.460
there's a few more different types
of addresses we need to get to.

478
00:27:18.460 --> 00:27:23.230
But Daniel, it looks like again that if I
start I'm not gonna be able to stop, so

479
00:27:23.230 --> 00:27:27.030
there's still a few more for us to cover
and then we'll get into the configuration

480
00:27:27.030 --> 00:27:29.350
of these things as well.
>> All right Ronnie, well not a problem.

481
00:27:29.350 --> 00:27:33.360
I'll look forward to the,
getting a trilogy going on.

482
00:27:33.360 --> 00:27:34.740
Good things comes in threes, right?

483
00:27:34.740 --> 00:27:37.520
Star Wars, Lord of the Rings,
you name it, all comes in threes.

484
00:27:37.520 --> 00:27:40.870
Ronnie's IPv6, it's gonna go right
there on the heap with those guys.

485
00:27:40.870 --> 00:27:44.550
Ronnie, thanks for joining us today and
we'll see you in part three and

486
00:27:44.550 --> 00:27:46.120
hopefully we'll see you there as well.

487
00:27:46.120 --> 00:27:48.750
As for this episode,
then we're gonna call it quits.

488
00:27:48.750 --> 00:27:51.230
For IT ProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

489
00:27:51.230 --> 00:27:52.030
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

490
00:27:52.030 --> 00:27:53.909
>> We'll see you next time.

491
00:27:53.909 --> 00:27:59.947
[MUSIC]

492
00:27:59.947 --> 00:28:03.080
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the use of multicast IPv6 addresses.  They describe the format and that multicasts supercede broadcasts in IPv6.
episodes.title: Identify IPv6 Addressing Scheme Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.216
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.216 --> 00:00:11.812
>> You are watching ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:11.812 --> 00:00:13.817
>> All right, and greetings everyone.

4
00:00:13.817 --> 00:00:16.765
Welcome back to another
great episode of ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:16.765 --> 00:00:19.924
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

6
00:00:19.924 --> 00:00:21.569
we continue with our C-Senses.

7
00:00:21.569 --> 00:00:23.600
We're actually at part three.

8
00:00:23.600 --> 00:00:27.942
IPv6 addressing, and if you thought it was
good in the last two parts, just wait for

9
00:00:27.942 --> 00:00:32.192
this one, cuz are good man, Mr. Ronnie
Wong is back for the conclusion of IPv6?

10
00:00:32.192 --> 00:00:34.586
[LAUGH]
>> It is very possible that this should be

11
00:00:34.586 --> 00:00:37.231
the conclusion,
it depends on how much I talk, of course.

12
00:00:37.231 --> 00:00:39.706
And that's where the problems lie.

13
00:00:39.706 --> 00:00:44.388
I'm not gonna say it's not,
cuz I do talk a lot.

14
00:00:44.388 --> 00:00:46.826
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]
>> But I will try my best here to make

15
00:00:46.826 --> 00:00:49.670
this not a a four parter button.

16
00:00:49.670 --> 00:00:51.270
I can't guarantee that.

17
00:00:51.270 --> 00:00:55.670
But just as we start here,
I started looking down at my notes as we

18
00:00:55.670 --> 00:01:00.280
began this show for today, Daniel,
and I started to realize something.

19
00:01:00.280 --> 00:01:04.690
That in my mind, I was saying it
correctly, but there was something that

20
00:01:04.690 --> 00:01:08.860
I did say that was not exactly correct,
and I want to make that correction here.

21
00:01:08.860 --> 00:01:11.330
And I'll make sure that it also
appears in the show notes.

22
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:13.627
But just in case you kind
of ran over like I did and

23
00:01:13.627 --> 00:01:18.100
you're now at the middle of part three and
you're a little bit confused by something.

24
00:01:18.100 --> 00:01:19.550
Well, I wanna make
the correction right now so

25
00:01:19.550 --> 00:01:20.700
that you know what I'm talking about.

26
00:01:20.700 --> 00:01:23.430
So let's take a look at
my screen as we begin.

27
00:01:23.430 --> 00:01:24.750
This will help us out.

28
00:01:24.750 --> 00:01:29.005
In previous episodes when we
covered the Unicast address,

29
00:01:29.005 --> 00:01:33.530
I said that a unique local is
similar to an APIPA address.

30
00:01:33.530 --> 00:01:36.690
And in my mind,
that was absolutely 100% right.

31
00:01:36.690 --> 00:01:39.700
But I was like, no,
one of them is a private IP address and

32
00:01:39.700 --> 00:01:40.260
the other one is APIPA,

33
00:01:40.260 --> 00:01:44.870
and since we're talking about the other
one, which is a linked local address.

34
00:01:44.870 --> 00:01:47.910
And then I started looking over and
I was like, I said that backwards.

35
00:01:47.910 --> 00:01:49.370
So let me correct it now.

36
00:01:49.370 --> 00:01:52.795
The unique local are like the private
IP addresses that we have today.

37
00:01:52.795 --> 00:01:55.600
Okay, that's pretty much
the correction that we need.

38
00:01:55.600 --> 00:01:57.920
And then, we'll talk about the other
one which is a linked local,

39
00:01:57.920 --> 00:02:00.960
which is more like the APIPA
address in just a moment.

40
00:02:00.960 --> 00:02:02.670
But today, we've got a few more addresses.

41
00:02:02.670 --> 00:02:04.680
So we've covered Unicast.

42
00:02:04.680 --> 00:02:07.780
We of course have talked about
the Global Unicast here.

43
00:02:07.780 --> 00:02:11.980
And now,
we are moving into Multicast addresses,

44
00:02:11.980 --> 00:02:14.490
is what we're actually taking a look at,
okay?

45
00:02:14.490 --> 00:02:17.490
When we back to different
address types in IPv4,

46
00:02:17.490 --> 00:02:21.940
we of course discussed what a Unicast
address was really about, okay?

47
00:02:21.940 --> 00:02:27.630
It allows to make sure that the data can
get from the source to the destination,

48
00:02:27.630 --> 00:02:31.160
a direct path there, nothing else is
really interfering in terms of the data

49
00:02:31.160 --> 00:02:33.440
pathway or the address, okay?

50
00:02:33.440 --> 00:02:38.970
In a broadcast,
it's also of course one to everyone, okay?

51
00:02:38.970 --> 00:02:43.480
So Unicast, one to one type of addressing
and one to one type of transmission.

52
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:46.510
And then, of course,
in a broadcast it's a one to all or

53
00:02:46.510 --> 00:02:50.210
every device on that subnet that we have.

54
00:02:50.210 --> 00:02:55.190
And then we also mentioned Multicast,
which essentially is a one to some, or

55
00:02:55.190 --> 00:02:59.370
one to many,
a subset of the broadcast instead.

56
00:02:59.370 --> 00:03:02.420
In IP version four, you have all
three of those traffic types and

57
00:03:02.420 --> 00:03:04.980
you have all three of those
address types as well.

58
00:03:04.980 --> 00:03:09.260
But in IP version six you only have of
course Unicast types of addresses, and

59
00:03:09.260 --> 00:03:11.760
you have multicast types of addresses.

60
00:03:11.760 --> 00:03:15.970
And now, I want you to make sure that you
understand that there is no broadcast,

61
00:03:15.970 --> 00:03:20.038
multicast supersedes broadcast
in IP version six, okay?

62
00:03:20.038 --> 00:03:23.470
So if somebody says is there
broadcast in IP version six?

63
00:03:23.470 --> 00:03:25.085
Technically, no.

64
00:03:25.085 --> 00:03:28.145
But multicast function in its place,
is what I'd guess.

65
00:03:28.145 --> 00:03:31.815
>> So you can multicast to everyone,
which is like a broadcast, but

66
00:03:31.815 --> 00:03:33.635
it's not technically a broadcast.

67
00:03:33.635 --> 00:03:37.115
>> Right, so yeah, that's where
it gets a little bit confusing.

68
00:03:37.115 --> 00:03:38.555
But the whole goal of course,

69
00:03:38.555 --> 00:03:43.015
right, is to understand and make sure that
we understand the type of traffic and

70
00:03:43.015 --> 00:03:47.110
the way that it's transmitted and goes out
is kinda the key difference here when we

71
00:03:47.110 --> 00:03:50.550
talk about broadcast versus the multicast,
right?

72
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:53.140
Broadcast, once you
broadcast it out right,

73
00:03:53.140 --> 00:03:57.160
everybody should be able to pick up on
that broadcast and be able to have that.

74
00:03:57.160 --> 00:04:01.050
Whereas the multicast allows you to join
or not join depending on, of course,

75
00:04:01.050 --> 00:04:05.010
bits that are set in your address, whether
or not you are a part of that group, okay?

76
00:04:05.010 --> 00:04:07.510
But that's pretty much the key idea.

77
00:04:07.510 --> 00:04:10.510
Now, it's still the same
type of address type, right?

78
00:04:10.510 --> 00:04:15.020
So it's not actually taking any less bits
out, it's still a 128-bit address, and

79
00:04:15.020 --> 00:04:18.940
if you and I were to look at it
we'd still see all 128-bits.

80
00:04:18.940 --> 00:04:22.934
But I do want you to note something in
both of these types of multicast addresses

81
00:04:22.934 --> 00:04:23.669
here, okay?

82
00:04:23.669 --> 00:04:28.037
They both begin with FF02, okay?

83
00:04:28.037 --> 00:04:29.954
FF02.

84
00:04:29.954 --> 00:04:33.241
Now here,
I forgot to actually put this in here, but

85
00:04:33.241 --> 00:04:36.170
I need to because it does
matter at this point.

86
00:04:36.170 --> 00:04:37.818
Let me make sure I'm telling you right,
here.

87
00:04:37.818 --> 00:04:40.140
Yeah, it is a /8.

88
00:04:40.140 --> 00:04:45.240
So I always get this one and the link
local a little bit confused here, okay?

89
00:04:45.240 --> 00:04:47.600
But I told you that this was one
of the most important parts, and

90
00:04:47.600 --> 00:04:52.910
of course I left it right off
the diagram that I created here, okay?

91
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:56.698
Both of these are /8s,
which means we're really only paying, or

92
00:04:56.698 --> 00:05:01.350
the networking portion, right, is really
only paying attention to the beginning

93
00:05:01.350 --> 00:05:03.419
here where it actually is FF, okay?

94
00:05:03.419 --> 00:05:07.110
So the first 8-bits is what's
paying attention to it.

95
00:05:07.110 --> 00:05:11.320
So with multicast,
that's what you end up having, okay?

96
00:05:11.320 --> 00:05:13.310
Notice the 02 and the 02 here.

97
00:05:13.310 --> 00:05:18.203
Those are clear distinguishing
marks of what multicast address in

98
00:05:18.203 --> 00:05:20.221
IPv6 will look at, okay?

99
00:05:20.221 --> 00:05:21.923
The difference, though,

100
00:05:21.923 --> 00:05:25.924
will be in the lowest order bit
of the 128-bits here, okay?

101
00:05:25.924 --> 00:05:29.360
One is gonna be a 1,
it's gonna always end in a 1.

102
00:05:29.360 --> 00:05:32.160
And the other one is gonna end in a 2.

103
00:05:32.160 --> 00:05:34.320
Traditionally, when you
do something like this,

104
00:05:34.320 --> 00:05:38.500
of course, you can have a whole string of
zeroes in between if you want to, okay?

105
00:05:38.500 --> 00:05:41.460
But notice the difference
over here in the description.

106
00:05:41.460 --> 00:05:46.370
If you need to communicate with
all the nodes on that particular

107
00:05:46.370 --> 00:05:51.060
network segment, then you're going to use
FF02, and it's going to end in the 1.

108
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:56.680
If you're only communicating
with all the routers,

109
00:05:56.680 --> 00:06:01.880
then you're going to do FF02, and
then it's also going to end in this 2.

110
00:06:01.880 --> 00:06:03.320
So when do we use these?

111
00:06:03.320 --> 00:06:06.710
The majority of times with the routers,
if we're doing this, is for

112
00:06:06.710 --> 00:06:09.848
things like routing protocols in IPv6.

113
00:06:09.848 --> 00:06:14.220
Everything in IPv6, right, on the routing
protocols is gonna be in multicast.

114
00:06:14.220 --> 00:06:18.900
And even IPv4, most of it's actually
done in multicast today, okay?

115
00:06:18.900 --> 00:06:21.180
So it's still gonna be the same way there.

116
00:06:21.180 --> 00:06:24.760
So routing protocols 10 update,
and doing things like,

117
00:06:24.760 --> 00:06:27.290
of course, multicast addressing as well.

118
00:06:27.290 --> 00:06:31.730
So that's actually a key part of
the different types of addresses here

119
00:06:31.730 --> 00:06:35.740
when we start to multicast
is a big part of what we do

120
00:06:35.740 --> 00:06:39.840
to help us to get that data
to where we need to go, okay?

121
00:06:39.840 --> 00:06:42.410
So that is pretty much in,
and there is not a lot.

122
00:06:42.410 --> 00:06:43.820
Now, just when I said that, right.

123
00:06:43.820 --> 00:06:46.230
So far, in just our three episodes.

124
00:06:46.230 --> 00:06:49.870
Let's take a look at the different
types of the addresses.

125
00:06:49.870 --> 00:06:52.660
So there is one, two, three, four.

126
00:06:52.660 --> 00:06:58.530
And of course, then we also took at
the global unicast, five, at this point.

127
00:06:58.530 --> 00:07:02.840
And now, start adding in six and seven.

128
00:07:02.840 --> 00:07:06.450
Seven addresses so far, and
we have at least one more to go.

129
00:07:06.450 --> 00:07:08.887
And this is the last one we
gonna really focus in on.

130
00:07:08.887 --> 00:07:11.734
Are there more different
addresses types out there?

131
00:07:11.734 --> 00:07:13.700
Yes, okay?

132
00:07:13.700 --> 00:07:17.832
But the great thing is, the majority
of those, even though they exist,

133
00:07:17.832 --> 00:07:22.102
have been superseded, or they've been
kind of deprecated at this point,

134
00:07:22.102 --> 00:07:24.505
depending on what's happened, right?

135
00:07:24.505 --> 00:07:28.133
So different address types that
they were trying to segment off and

136
00:07:28.133 --> 00:07:31.852
make specific types for
different traffic and stuff.

137
00:07:31.852 --> 00:07:33.660
I said, look, you're now getting it so

138
00:07:33.660 --> 00:07:38.530
overly complex nobody is going to
actually know what's happening here.

139
00:07:38.530 --> 00:07:39.580
So instead,

140
00:07:39.580 --> 00:07:44.400
you'll see what they used to call site
local addresses have kind of disappeared.

141
00:07:44.400 --> 00:07:46.280
Why?
Because multicast addresses essentially

142
00:07:46.280 --> 00:07:47.120
serve the same thing.

143
00:07:47.120 --> 00:07:49.660
The only thing that we were
really doing was just saying

144
00:07:49.660 --> 00:07:52.250
we want to segment this down even further.

145
00:07:52.250 --> 00:07:54.240
You're doing a multicast of a multicast.

146
00:07:54.240 --> 00:07:55.814
Why would you do that?

147
00:07:55.814 --> 00:07:57.929
Why would you-
>> It doesn't seem to make a lot of

148
00:07:57.929 --> 00:07:58.613
sense, right?

149
00:07:58.613 --> 00:07:59.472
>> It doesn't.

150
00:07:59.472 --> 00:08:02.561
So in other words, if it functions
well in a small environment, and

151
00:08:02.561 --> 00:08:06.143
it functions the same way in the big Why
would you actually separate that out and

152
00:08:06.143 --> 00:08:07.678
try and make some subset of that?

153
00:08:07.678 --> 00:08:11.606
So that's why you are actually starting
to see some of those more specific ones,

154
00:08:11.606 --> 00:08:15.980
as you did see some of them also
disappear at some point in time, okay?

155
00:08:15.980 --> 00:08:20.510
Now, this is one of the more important
addresses to that we have to think of,

156
00:08:20.510 --> 00:08:22.620
which is the link local address, okay?

157
00:08:22.620 --> 00:08:26.740
So this is the one I did get confused in
the beginning cuz I was not looking at

158
00:08:26.740 --> 00:08:30.180
my notes here and
not paying attention as I said it.

159
00:08:30.180 --> 00:08:35.185
This link local address is very similar
to the APIPA address, but this time

160
00:08:35.185 --> 00:08:39.170
whereas APIPA, at least in this day and
age, it really is just an indicator,

161
00:08:39.170 --> 00:08:42.540
right, that, hey,
something in your network is not working.

162
00:08:42.540 --> 00:08:46.790
So it's either your machine is not
talking to the DHCP server, or

163
00:08:46.790 --> 00:08:49.820
your DHCP server isn't functioning.

164
00:08:49.820 --> 00:08:56.740
And your own machine in IP version 6
gives you a 169.254 address, okay?

165
00:08:56.740 --> 00:09:00.700
So that's usually what you see there
when you start talking about this idea

166
00:09:00.700 --> 00:09:01.880
of APIPA.

167
00:09:01.880 --> 00:09:05.590
And once we see that 169.254,
it's not routable, okay?

168
00:09:05.590 --> 00:09:08.130
So that address is not gonna
be forwarded by the router.

169
00:09:08.130 --> 00:09:12.640
You actually end up getting this without
you actually having to do anything.

170
00:09:12.640 --> 00:09:16.450
Your machine actually assigns itself
this address if it can't communicate.

171
00:09:16.450 --> 00:09:19.550
So in the realm of Windows,
that's what they call it.

172
00:09:19.550 --> 00:09:23.910
The self assigned address is what
it's also called as well, okay?

173
00:09:23.910 --> 00:09:29.350
So notice here as I wrote down
some of the characteristics for

174
00:09:29.350 --> 00:09:33.401
us, in a link local
address in IP version 6,

175
00:09:33.401 --> 00:09:39.180
instead of doing 169.254,
it begins with FE8, okay.

176
00:09:39.180 --> 00:09:43.976
I've put the zero there to fill out
the actual last bit of that section, but

177
00:09:43.976 --> 00:09:47.900
it's a /10, and
anything can follow after that, okay?

178
00:09:47.900 --> 00:09:52.880
Now here, when you break that down,
here's what it looks like in the binary.

179
00:09:52.880 --> 00:09:58.570
The first four in this section here under
F actually turned out to be all ones.

180
00:09:58.570 --> 00:10:02.440
And then E turns out to
be this right here, okay?

181
00:10:02.440 --> 00:10:05.874
So remember that F is 15, and
then that means that E is 14.

182
00:10:05.874 --> 00:10:09.150
So that's 8, 4, and 2, that's 14.

183
00:10:09.150 --> 00:10:15.570
And then 8 here, and that goes all the way
to those 10 bits is what it does, right?

184
00:10:15.570 --> 00:10:20.530
So for us, it actually is the first bit
and then the second one is a zero, okay?

185
00:10:20.530 --> 00:10:22.830
That's why it actually
goes out to ten bits,

186
00:10:22.830 --> 00:10:27.750
because the zero is significant here for
what we want it to be.

187
00:10:27.750 --> 00:10:31.030
The rest of this address really
does not matter what it is.

188
00:10:31.030 --> 00:10:34.180
If we are actually using FE80 here,

189
00:10:34.180 --> 00:10:37.460
more than likely you're
using a link local address.

190
00:10:37.460 --> 00:10:39.290
Now, remember I said this is usable.

191
00:10:39.290 --> 00:10:43.303
And the reason why we actually want
to notice is that this is kinda of

192
00:10:43.303 --> 00:10:47.677
the majority of where all the
communications happen between routers and

193
00:10:47.677 --> 00:10:50.390
between machines on my network.

194
00:10:50.390 --> 00:10:55.498
They don't always have to use
a unicast local address, okay?

195
00:10:55.498 --> 00:11:00.850
Not everything actually has to be
able to use a global routing prefix.

196
00:11:00.850 --> 00:11:04.670
But things that are happening just between
the devices, if they are talking, if they

197
00:11:04.670 --> 00:11:08.910
are communicating, this is the address
that they're using, which is a link local.

198
00:11:08.910 --> 00:11:11.520
If I bring up my machine again, here, and

199
00:11:11.520 --> 00:11:16.710
let me run the ipconfig/all, and let's
take a look at a couple of things here.

200
00:11:16.710 --> 00:11:20.680
We'll go to the ethernet adaptor,
Ethernet0, which is the first one.

201
00:11:20.680 --> 00:11:25.780
You'll notice that when I take
a look at the IP version 6 address,

202
00:11:25.780 --> 00:11:31.360
the first one that it gives
me begins with fe80, okay?

203
00:11:31.360 --> 00:11:33.850
That is the address
that's actually on this.

204
00:11:33.850 --> 00:11:38.340
And that's because I'm not really
routing this particular computer itself.

205
00:11:38.340 --> 00:11:40.870
But if I do a route print,

206
00:11:42.380 --> 00:11:46.200
you'll now notice that there
are some unicast addresses here too.

207
00:11:46.200 --> 00:11:50.584
So for example, on this one on
the fifth line in this table,

208
00:11:50.584 --> 00:11:56.111
notice that there is an actual unicast
address right here with a /128,

209
00:11:56.111 --> 00:12:01.060
and then you also have,
of course, link local addresses.

210
00:12:01.060 --> 00:12:06.446
And you can see there is first
64 bits here, and then 128.

211
00:12:06.446 --> 00:12:09.801
And now you actually see like
the ones that we were talking about,

212
00:12:09.801 --> 00:12:12.810
which is just the /8s
here on the link as well.

213
00:12:12.810 --> 00:12:15.440
Those are also there and available to you.

214
00:12:15.440 --> 00:12:20.052
So now notice that this machine alone,
Daniel, just on my virtual machine, right,

215
00:12:20.052 --> 00:12:26.070
I have, let' see, one,
two, possible three,

216
00:12:26.070 --> 00:12:31.350
four different addresses that it's
actually on the link that we can actually

217
00:12:31.350 --> 00:12:34.530
use here or find in the destination
of what needs to happen.

218
00:12:34.530 --> 00:12:37.350
So it's kind of amazing that
we'll actually see multiple IP

219
00:12:37.350 --> 00:12:40.610
version 6 addresses for
the different types of traffic and

220
00:12:40.610 --> 00:12:42.780
different things that will be used here,
okay?

221
00:12:42.780 --> 00:12:47.572
So I'll also put down on this one,
just as a reminder throughout the show,

222
00:12:47.572 --> 00:12:52.821
if I forgot to say it again, remember that
ULA is more like the private IP address,

223
00:12:52.821 --> 00:12:56.650
whereas the link local is more
like the APIPA address here.

224
00:12:56.650 --> 00:12:59.294
That's what I wanted to make
sure that we emphasized.

225
00:12:59.294 --> 00:13:04.271
All right, Daniel,
those are kind of the major IP version 6

226
00:13:04.271 --> 00:13:08.670
addresses that you and
I will pretty much encounter.

227
00:13:08.670 --> 00:13:12.972
And nothing else at this point,
as far as identifying those addresses,

228
00:13:12.972 --> 00:13:15.580
you really can matter above this thing.

00:13:15.580 --> 00:13:17.372
You've got to know them.

00:13:17.372 --> 00:13:19.300
You've gotta memorize them.

That's the easy way to get

I know that memory work,

00:13:24.730 --> 00:13:30.450
it's really you taking note cards or

00:13:30.450 --> 00:13:35.570
as easy points on the Cisco exam that

00:13:35.570 --> 00:13:39.100
It's amazing of all the things

00:13:39.100 --> 00:13:40.935
That's the easiest ones that we can do.

00:13:40.935 --> 00:13:45.030
But these eight different ones,
you've gotta be able to spot them and

238
00:13:45.030 --> 00:13:48.060
know what they actually identify with,
and be able to go,

239
00:13:48.060 --> 00:13:53.620
I know that that's a multicast address or
that's a link local address as well, okay?

240
00:13:53.620 --> 00:13:56.830
Now, we've been dealing with
just really the prefix, right?

241
00:13:56.830 --> 00:14:00.470
The unicast prefix or
the network ID all this time.

242
00:14:00.470 --> 00:14:04.380
We do need to talk about the other
portion just briefly, okay?

243
00:14:04.380 --> 00:14:07.425
The last 64 bits here I've
kind of ignored totally.

244
00:14:07.425 --> 00:14:08.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> At this point, except for

245
00:14:08.750 --> 00:14:10.310
every once in a while having a one or two.

246
00:14:10.310 --> 00:14:10.990
>> To reference it?

247
00:14:10.990 --> 00:14:12.940
>> Yeah,
every once in a while having a one or two.

248
00:14:12.940 --> 00:14:17.119
And then I explained to you that there is
a chance that you can also use your MAC

249
00:14:17.119 --> 00:14:20.350
address in that portion
of the address as well.

250
00:14:20.350 --> 00:14:25.077
But it doesn't work just by itself
because out of those 64 bits, right,

251
00:14:25.077 --> 00:14:27.790
a MAC address is only 48 of those.

252
00:14:27.790 --> 00:14:30.450
So how do you actually
fill up the rest of that?

253
00:14:30.450 --> 00:14:35.544
Well, the way that you do that is
through what is called EUI-64.

254
00:14:35.544 --> 00:14:41.710
So if you are actually going to allow your
machine to identify its own interface ID,

255
00:14:41.710 --> 00:14:48.200
okay, that means that it has to come up
with 64 bits to be able to essentially

256
00:14:48.200 --> 00:14:54.490
be unique inside of whatever network you
are actually given in your unicast prefix.

257
00:14:54.490 --> 00:14:58.450
So if we were to break this down,
okay, here is what I actually did.

258
00:14:58.450 --> 00:15:03.590
I took the MAC address on my virtual
machine, which is this one right here.

259
00:15:03.590 --> 00:15:07.820
I went ahead and
converted it into the binary so that you

260
00:15:07.820 --> 00:15:12.680
could actually see what it would actually
look like in terms of the MAC address.

261
00:15:12.680 --> 00:15:16.200
But here it is, it's 48 bits on
the MAC address at this point.

262
00:15:17.610 --> 00:15:23.260
Once you do that, what IP version 6 and
the protocol, what it does and says and

263
00:15:23.260 --> 00:15:28.523
gives us the ability to do, is that now
I'm gonna take that entire 64 bits,

264
00:15:28.523 --> 00:15:33.650
and then we are gonna add
in 16 bits of this, okay?

265
00:15:33.650 --> 00:15:36.670
And those 16 bits are gonna be FFFE.

266
00:15:36.670 --> 00:15:38.140
And once you do that,

267
00:15:38.140 --> 00:15:43.540
that turns it into that extended
unique identifier, is what it does.

268
00:15:43.540 --> 00:15:47.010
Now, of course it doesn't just add
it at the end or at the beginning.

269
00:15:47.010 --> 00:15:52.377
It says, right smack dab in the middle
of your 48 bit address, we're

270
00:15:52.377 --> 00:15:58.295
gonna add 16 bits in it, and I've coded
those in red so that you could see it.

271
00:15:58.295 --> 00:16:01.271
So you go ahead and you add that in, and

272
00:16:01.271 --> 00:16:07.316
now notice that your MAC address now
turns into a 64 Bit Mac address as well,

273
00:16:07.316 --> 00:16:11.810
in theory,
with the addition of these 16 bits.

274
00:16:11.810 --> 00:16:14.180
Now in the earliest stages of this,

275
00:16:14.180 --> 00:16:19.040
what they were afraid of, is that even
with this at somewhere down the line

276
00:16:19.040 --> 00:16:23.410
of 64 bits that they would end
up with a duplicate number.

277
00:16:23.410 --> 00:16:26.560
So what they decided, and
I don't know how they decided this, but

278
00:16:26.560 --> 00:16:28.350
somebody decided this.

279
00:16:28.350 --> 00:16:33.700
The seventh bit of that first section

280
00:16:33.700 --> 00:16:38.480
of the first bits here,
the seventh bit in that first

281
00:16:38.480 --> 00:16:42.740
octet that we see that would
actually become significant.

282
00:16:43.780 --> 00:16:47.620
So I marked this one in green, so
that's actually significant for us.

283
00:16:47.620 --> 00:16:51.399
To ensure the uniqueness of the EUID,

284
00:16:51.399 --> 00:16:57.315
if it happened to be a 0,
they would go ahead and turn it on.

285
00:16:57.315 --> 00:17:03.208
Well, if you did that, notice that
it changes your 48 bit MAC address,

286
00:17:03.208 --> 00:17:06.250
even though it changes it to 64 bit,

287
00:17:06.250 --> 00:17:12.170
it also flips that second number to
a 2 because notice that would be what?

288
00:17:12.170 --> 00:17:17.530
In binary that would be a 1 and
that would be a 2 to flip it to a 2.

289
00:17:17.530 --> 00:17:19.590
Now Daniel, what happens out?

290
00:17:19.590 --> 00:17:22.400
What if that number is something else,
okay?

291
00:17:22.400 --> 00:17:25.500
So what if we actually have like a 1,
1 there, okay?

292
00:17:25.500 --> 00:17:26.866
>> Yeah.
>> Or a 1,1,1,1, okay?

293
00:17:26.866 --> 00:17:29.770
What if we have something like that?

294
00:17:29.770 --> 00:17:34.680
Well, later on they said yeah,
we can't just flip that.

295
00:17:34.680 --> 00:17:36.870
So what they said is if it's
actually any other number,

296
00:17:36.870 --> 00:17:40.320
in other words if it's a 1,
they're actually gonna turn it off.

297
00:17:41.960 --> 00:17:47.000
So they flip that either way, so
now notice that if it actually did have,

298
00:17:47.000 --> 00:17:49.930
let's just pretend that
this was a 2 anyways.

299
00:17:49.930 --> 00:17:54.000
And then, it actually came across and that
was a 1 well they just turned it off and

300
00:17:54.000 --> 00:17:55.780
they made it a 0.

301
00:17:55.780 --> 00:17:58.718
So that's why you will get some weird,
where people look at and

302
00:17:58.718 --> 00:18:00.771
go, it's just a MAC address with FF-
>> Yeah.

303
00:18:00.771 --> 00:18:02.590
>> Not exactly, okay?

304
00:18:02.590 --> 00:18:03.570
They added that in there and

305
00:18:03.570 --> 00:18:09.210
that is what is used currently today
which is called the Modified EUI-64.

306
00:18:09.210 --> 00:18:13.837
And this is version that they specifically
call out which is the one that can

307
00:18:13.837 --> 00:18:14.429
do both.

308
00:18:14.429 --> 00:18:19.119
If it's a 0, it won't go in and flip it,
if it's a 1 it will go ahead, and

309
00:18:19.119 --> 00:18:20.246
flip it that way.

310
00:18:20.246 --> 00:18:24.630
The original one, just look just take
the seventh bit and make sure it's on.

311
00:18:24.630 --> 00:18:26.028
So that's the way that it happens.

312
00:18:26.028 --> 00:18:27.604
>> It's like a very truncated,

313
00:18:27.604 --> 00:18:30.639
trucked down version of like
random number generating.

314
00:18:30.639 --> 00:18:31.480
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

315
00:18:31.480 --> 00:18:35.710
>> It really is, and so
this is key for us understanding this.

316
00:18:35.710 --> 00:18:38.850
I don't wanna type in
64 bits on a static IP.

317
00:18:38.850 --> 00:18:39.920
What I would rather do,

318
00:18:39.920 --> 00:18:43.060
at the end when I do the addressing you'll
see when we get into configuration.

319
00:18:43.060 --> 00:18:47.595
If I don't wanna do that, I type out
the first portion of what I want.

320
00:18:47.595 --> 00:18:52.940
So whether I want a multicast address,
or a unicast address like 200.

321
00:18:52.940 --> 00:18:58.620
I can do a double colon at the end
of that, I can do a slash and

322
00:18:58.620 --> 00:19:02.860
then put EUI-64, and
this is what it will do.

323
00:19:02.860 --> 00:19:05.190
It will take the MAC address and

324
00:19:05.190 --> 00:19:09.640
convert it into binary,
add 16 bits here in the middle.

325
00:19:09.640 --> 00:19:14.200
Go to the seventh bit and either flip it
on or off depending on what it finds.

326
00:19:14.200 --> 00:19:17.120
And then,
this is what you'll get in the end result.

327
00:19:17.120 --> 00:19:19.900
And when you do that,
that's what will make that

328
00:19:19.900 --> 00:19:25.310
unique identifier,100% unique is the way
that they actually describe it here.

329
00:19:25.310 --> 00:19:27.420
So it is more of an extensive process,

330
00:19:27.420 --> 00:19:31.390
than just what people say, just add
the Mac address and there just fine.

331
00:19:31.390 --> 00:19:33.970
You could see there are essentially
relatively complex, but

332
00:19:33.970 --> 00:19:38.320
the great thing Daniel, you and I will
never have to figure this out, okay?

333
00:19:38.320 --> 00:19:40.270
Now, you've got, so Ronnie,
what do you explain?

334
00:19:40.270 --> 00:19:44.170
Because people always acts like,
all right, so what does it do it that way.

335
00:19:44.170 --> 00:19:45.856
>> Yeah.
>> Cuz that's the way they chose,

336
00:19:45.856 --> 00:19:49.557
they wanted to fill that out to make sure
that the only thing that was in these 64

337
00:19:49.557 --> 00:19:50.728
bits is the Mac address.

338
00:19:50.728 --> 00:19:54.027
That was something that they knew that
they could identify easily, okay?

339
00:19:54.027 --> 00:19:57.313
So you can always spot
that by looking here and

340
00:19:57.313 --> 00:20:03.369
realizing that it's it's an EUI-64, and
when you see in those last 64 bits,

341
00:20:03.369 --> 00:20:07.560
FF-FE, right in the middle
of those 64 bits.

342
00:20:07.560 --> 00:20:11.380
Every single time, that'll help

343
00:20:11.380 --> 00:20:14.958
>> Right, it's like a big
blinking neon sign going, hello,

344
00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:17.117
you should know what I am right now.

00:20:17.117 --> 00:20:21.745
>> And hopefully, me emphasizing it three

00:20:21.745 --> 00:20:23.097

>> One more time, Ronnie, for

00:20:23.097 --> 00:20:23.639
good measure.

348
00:20:23.639 --> 00:20:27.592
>> Remember, you're looking for FF-FE
essentially is what you're looking for

349
00:20:27.592 --> 00:20:31.120
that will tell you, hey,
this is how it actually came about.

350
00:20:31.120 --> 00:20:33.380
So don't always think that
it's just randomly generated.

351
00:20:33.380 --> 00:20:33.907
Is that a possible entry?

Your Mac address plus those 16

They're probably not gonna get

I wouldn't know-
