00:21:34.690 --> 00:21:39.251
So when we get in, we're gonna actually
kind of stop this series, and we're going

373
00:21:39.251 --> 00:21:43.630
to go into configuring IP addresses in
the next little mini-series that we do.

374
00:21:43.630 --> 00:21:46.897
And show you how to actually put all
these addresses on interfaces, and

375
00:21:46.897 --> 00:21:49.200
on the machines, and what we want to do.

376
00:21:49.200 --> 00:21:53.794
But you also have to realize that there's
different ways to configure this, okay?

377
00:21:53.794 --> 00:21:57.878
One of course, is fairly simple,
you can actually say,

378
00:21:57.878 --> 00:22:03.000
look here's what we're gonna do,
and it can do a Auto Configuration.

379
00:22:04.380 --> 00:22:06.400
Now in Auto Configuration,

380
00:22:06.400 --> 00:22:12.150
what normally happens is that on your
router you assign an IPv6 address to it.

381
00:22:12.150 --> 00:22:15.230
Once you do that and
you make that configuration happen,

382
00:22:15.230 --> 00:22:19.670
it will begin to do what's called
Router Advertisement, okay?

383
00:22:19.670 --> 00:22:23.470
Router Advertisement essentially say,
I'm the router go figure.

384
00:22:23.470 --> 00:22:25.200
It makes sense right?

385
00:22:25.200 --> 00:22:26.990
I'm the actual router.

386
00:22:26.990 --> 00:22:30.280
Now at the same time that's happening,

387
00:22:30.280 --> 00:22:35.010
your machine that's prepared with IPv6 and
ready to go with it.

388
00:22:35.010 --> 00:22:39.590
It is also sending out router
solicitation messages too, okay?

389
00:22:39.590 --> 00:22:41.200
It's saying, where's the router?

390
00:22:41.200 --> 00:22:42.980
This guy's saying, I'm the router.

391
00:22:42.980 --> 00:22:47.830
This guy's asking for where is the router,
so those two were meant to communicate.

392
00:22:47.830 --> 00:22:51.450
And usually, the main communication
that happens at the beginning of course

393
00:22:51.450 --> 00:22:54.350
is what we call Auto Configuration.

394
00:22:54.350 --> 00:22:55.020
Which that's alright.

395
00:22:55.020 --> 00:22:56.070
I'm the router.

396
00:22:56.070 --> 00:23:01.274
Why don't you go ahead and
assign yourself an IPv6 address, and

397
00:23:01.274 --> 00:23:06.204
the way it will do it,
is that it will give the network prefix.

398
00:23:06.204 --> 00:23:10.282
The prefix from the router and
say, give yourself,

399
00:23:10.282 --> 00:23:15.530
a unique identifier on this
particular prefix number.

400
00:23:15.530 --> 00:23:18.750
And then,
the machine itself can configure it

401
00:23:18.750 --> 00:23:21.660
to do that without anything
else that we need.

402
00:23:21.660 --> 00:23:23.590
That is awesome, okay?

403
00:23:23.590 --> 00:23:28.330
Essentially, the router and
actually your own machine accesses its own

404
00:23:28.330 --> 00:23:33.158
little DHCP server, where you and
I ever having to bring up a DHCP server.

405
00:23:33.158 --> 00:23:35.602
That's pretty down and cool, okay?

406
00:23:35.602 --> 00:23:37.560
Don't ever have to do that.

407
00:23:37.560 --> 00:23:41.380
And when you do something like that
that's also known as Stateless Auto

408
00:23:41.380 --> 00:23:46.320
Configuration, or SLAAC, S-L-A-A-C.

409
00:23:46.320 --> 00:23:48.750
Stateless, I don't know why they
put the l there, stateless,

410
00:23:48.750 --> 00:23:51.258
S-L-
>> Because then it's SLAAC instead

411
00:23:51.258 --> 00:23:51.980
of SAAC.

412
00:23:51.980 --> 00:23:53.213
>> Auto, yeah-
>> [LAUGH]

413
00:23:53.213 --> 00:23:56.085
>> True, yeah, auto address configuration.

414
00:23:56.085 --> 00:23:59.050
When you do something like that,
that's what's happening.

415
00:23:59.050 --> 00:24:04.450
But the other way you can do this,
you can run a DHCPv6.

416
00:24:04.450 --> 00:24:07.050
And you can assign those addresses.

417
00:24:07.050 --> 00:24:10.965
That is that control of that address
space that we were talking about.

418
00:24:10.965 --> 00:24:12.460
Are there some companies
that will do that?

419
00:24:12.460 --> 00:24:13.260
You better believe it.

420
00:24:13.260 --> 00:24:17.800
Some companies go, I want to know that all
the addresses are something that we have

421
00:24:17.800 --> 00:24:22.550
issued not generated itself, not
anything like that, we want to do some.

422
00:24:22.550 --> 00:24:26.700
So if you need the control you're
gonna do what's called stateful,

423
00:24:26.700 --> 00:24:32.270
which means you've brought up your own
DHCP server, and then you can do that.

424
00:24:32.270 --> 00:24:37.340
But if you just put the IPv6
address on that interface and

425
00:24:37.340 --> 00:24:41.340
it is connected in,
it will begin that communication process.

426
00:24:41.340 --> 00:24:44.260
It will have a link local address on it,

427
00:24:44.260 --> 00:24:47.620
as well as whatever global unicast
address you put on this thing.

428
00:24:47.620 --> 00:24:49.910
And then it will begin routing
that advertisement number, and

429
00:24:49.910 --> 00:24:51.020
go, here's my link local.

430
00:24:51.020 --> 00:24:52.440
Let's communicate over this.

431
00:24:52.440 --> 00:24:54.100
And here's my global prefix.

432
00:24:54.100 --> 00:24:55.170
Assign yourself that.

433
00:24:55.170 --> 00:24:57.540
Okay, let's do this, and it works.

434
00:24:57.540 --> 00:24:59.530
That's exactly what starts to happen.

435
00:24:59.530 --> 00:25:03.860
And it gets inside of that
multicast group that it needs to.

436
00:25:03.860 --> 00:25:07.340
It begins to listen for something
else that we called anycast as well.

437
00:25:07.340 --> 00:25:10.390
Which you can't distinguish from
the regular unicast addresses.

438
00:25:10.390 --> 00:25:14.077
Anycast for us is actually where
the router actually says, all right,

439
00:25:14.077 --> 00:25:17.963
where's the nearest other router that
I need to be able to communicate to.

440
00:25:17.963 --> 00:25:21.480
And that's going across networks
when we start doing that.

441

So at this point, we've got a lot
to actually talk about in terms of

the configuration, but Daniel, I think
that's enough for what we have at this

443

particular point that we need to talk

it's a bit of a mystery and

Yeah, you're right it can be that way,

I think Ronnie, you've done a great

450

all the key elements of IPv6.

So we are, a successful on exam, and b,

Very cool stuff, Ronnie, we appreciate

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show access into the initial device.  The team reviews the boot process for cisco devices.  The boot the cisco switch and show the initial information at boot.  Lastly, the begin with the initial switch configuration.

So, when you think about this,

Right when we put the power to the switch

What we call boot strap at that point,

Now, once the boot strap is running

it's also gonna end up looking at

47

48
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:46.000
The configuration register
is something that you and

49
00:02:46.000 --> 00:02:50.850
I can actually set to tell it whether or
not everything is actually

So, you can actually tell it

that's what the configuration
register does.

54

If everything is good and it finds the

55
00:03:09.730 --> 00:03:14.660

get redirected to look for

56
00:03:14.660 --> 00:03:19.640

57
00:03:19.640 --> 00:03:25.060
Normally on a Cisco router, okay,
the IOS and on a Cisco switch,

58
00:03:25.060 --> 00:03:31.070
it's gonna be found in the area

59
00:03:31.070 --> 00:03:32.170
Now, Flash works and

00:03:32.170 --> 00:03:36.540

61
00:03:36.540 --> 00:03:41.770

62
00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:47.240
When it finds that, and it is actually
going to be the operating system that

00:03:47.240 --> 00:03:52.820

64
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:57.950
when it does that it will decompress
it loading it in the RAM at this point.

65
00:03:57.950 --> 00:04:00.622
Once it actually is inside of RAM,

66
00:04:00.622 --> 00:04:05.424
then it will have to locate what

67
00:04:06.580 --> 00:04:09.624
Usually there's another file that
is stored in what we call NVRAM,

68
00:04:09.624 --> 00:04:13.630
non-volatile ram,
that of course allows you to actually have

69
00:04:13.630 --> 00:04:17.670
a file that can persist through
boot ups and power off and

70
00:04:17.670 --> 00:04:22.680
everything else and
that file is called the startup-.config.

71
00:04:22.680 --> 00:04:24.070
So just call it start up config,

72
00:04:24.070 --> 00:04:28.470
nobody cares about the extension at
this point but the startup-config here.

73
00:04:28.470 --> 00:04:33.060
If it finds a startup-config
it will then load that on top

74
00:04:33.060 --> 00:04:38.440
of the operating system integrating it in
and you'll have all of your configuration

75
00:04:38.440 --> 00:04:42.050
that you have to ensure that
everything is the way that it needs to.

76
00:04:42.050 --> 00:04:43.310
Now what if it doesn't?

77
00:04:43.310 --> 00:04:47.970
Well initially you haven't configured
anything on the switch, so what it

00:04:47.970 --> 00:04:52.650
will do instead of doing this part, which
says load up, start up, config into RAM,

79
00:04:52.650 --> 00:04:57.410
it will lead you to what we call the
set-up screen is what it will do, okay.

80
00:04:57.410 --> 00:05:02.079
So, pay attention to this process in
particular because you do need to

81
00:05:02.079 --> 00:05:06.670
understand that it goes from
post from that point into Flash.

82
00:05:06.670 --> 00:05:11.060
Inside of Flash, it loads the OS
into RAM and then you go and

83
00:05:11.060 --> 00:05:15.320
check the NVRAM and make sure that
everything is actually good and

84
00:05:15.320 --> 00:05:18.010
then everything, of course,
runs inside of RAM.

85
00:05:18.010 --> 00:05:22.200
So, verify and
understand that part of the process.

86

Now what does it look like though,
when you and

I are actually going to see

So here it is, I am in practice

You want the one that says 100-105 and

the initial device configuration.

So what we're gonna take a look

So it's gonna take just a little bit

But at the very beginning, we'll start

This is during this time and
process that we will start seeing or

00:17:47.456 --> 00:17:49.069

00:18:31.235 --> 00:18:34.277

00:18:34.277 --> 00:18:40.349

00:19:03.120 --> 00:19:05.910

00:19:05.910 --> 00:19:07.450
So you could see where the show command.

00:19:07.450 --> 00:19:10.230
It does show you quite

00:19:10.230 --> 00:19:13.400

00:19:13.400 --> 00:19:19.143

00:19:19.143 --> 00:19:23.348

00:19:23.348 --> 00:19:27.100

00:19:28.110 --> 00:19:31.030
When we type in enable,
notice the change here.

00:19:31.030 --> 00:19:34.930
We went from of course switch

00:19:34.930 --> 00:19:38.560

symbol at this point.

338
00:19:38.560 --> 00:19:42.540
So this is what is called
privileged exit mode.

339
00:19:42.540 --> 00:19:46.440
So now if I do a question mark here and
I press Enter,

340
00:19:46.440 --> 00:19:51.540
I may still see some of the very same

00:19:51.540 --> 00:19:56.300

00:19:56.300 --> 00:19:59.365
I get access to more things

00:19:59.365 --> 00:20:03.440
Whereas in Show or in the User mode,

00:20:03.440 --> 00:20:07.760

not also supposed to see.

345
00:20:07.760 --> 00:20:14.000
So in the Show they give me a limited
amount of data that I can see whereas

346
00:20:14.000 --> 00:20:18.760
in the privileged exact mode, I can
pretty much see anything that I want to.

347
00:20:18.760 --> 00:20:21.440
There are some things that
are configurable here, but

348
00:20:21.440 --> 00:20:23.510
not everything, okay?

349
00:20:23.510 --> 00:20:28.019
There are some commands that allow you to
clear old process, that allow you to do

350
00:20:28.019 --> 00:20:31.733
something but overall, though,
this is kind of that mode here.

351
00:20:31.733 --> 00:20:33.954
Most of the time,
I have really used it for

352
00:20:33.954 --> 00:20:36.625
the show command more than anything else,
okay?

353
00:20:36.625 --> 00:20:40.661
But the next mode is probably the one

354
00:20:40.661 --> 00:20:45.990
which is going to be the one for what we
call global configuration mode, okay?

355
00:20:45.990 --> 00:20:48.860

00:02:28.540 --> 00:02:34.550

00:02:34.550 --> 00:02:37.510

00:02:37.510 --> 00:02:43.180

00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:48.500

00:02:59.740 --> 00:03:02.140

That means that they've added in some

00:03:12.970 --> 00:03:14.390

00:03:44.570 --> 00:03:48.290

00:04:49.280 --> 00:04:54.200

00:04:54.200 --> 00:04:57.720

Configuration Register, look for

00:04:57.720 --> 00:05:00.880

00:05:00.880 --> 00:05:03.830

00:05:03.830 --> 00:05:05.920

00:05:05.920 --> 00:05:09.360
And what happens at that point is,

00:05:12.610 --> 00:05:16.970

00:05:20.860 --> 00:05:24.310

So those are the fundamental differences,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue with the lab this time verifying the remote connection is possible from another machine on the network.  Also , they do the basic router configuration as well.

00:10:37.120 --> 00:10:39.730

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the use of IPv4 addresses.  They begin with subnetting 192.168.16.0/24 network into 3 networks: One that supports 110 hosts, another that supports 55 hosts and a third that supports 25 hosts. They apply the ip addresses in each subnet to the available interfaces to create network connectivity.
episodes.title: Configure IPv4 Addressing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie configure the other interfaces in the lab for connectivity too.  These include adding IP addresses to the specified interfaces as well as configuring SVIs on switches with IP addresses.  Lastly, they begin to verify connectivity and run into an issue when subnetting, they discuss and explain what can happen if you overlap the IP subnets.
episodes.title: Configure IPv4 Addressing Part 2

So in this point here, I'm going to

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie begin verifying network connectivity and basic troubleshooting.  They show some of the most common errors and mistakes caused by configuration and can be fixed by them too!

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and onnie discuss the use of IPv6 addresses. They create 3 smaller networks from 2001:a::/48.  With the created networks, they show how to enable IPv6 routing on each router using ipv6 unicast-routing. They assign the ipv6 addresses on the router interfaces for connectivity.  Using show ipv6 interface brief, the team shows each interface with the global-unicast address assigned and also a self-assigned link-local address.
episodes.title: Configure IPv6 Addressing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss basic ipv6 issues when assigning addresses. They describe the possibility of manually assigning IPv6 Link Local addresses.  Lastly, they reveal that statically assigning the addresses are not our only option.  We also have SLAAC, Stateless Address Auto Configuration.  They also configure an interface to use the RS and RA to get an IPv6 address on it's interface.
episodes.title: Configure IPv6 Addressing Part 2

00:11:05.010 --> 00:11:08.550

211
00:11:08.550 --> 00:11:10.640
When you programmed it

00:11:10.640 --> 00:11:13.020

00:11:28.730 --> 00:11:33.050

219
00:11:34.220 --> 00:11:37.350

00:11:41.980 --> 00:11:44.360

00:24:50.910 --> 00:24:51.860
>> Now let's do this.

453
00:24:51.860 --> 00:24:52.810
Let me do something here.

454
00:24:52.810 --> 00:24:56.779
Let me do a show running-config.

455
00:24:58.181 --> 00:25:01.822
Wait, I'm inside the interface right now.

456
00:25:01.822 --> 00:25:06.380
I was actually where I need
to be finally [LAUGH] funny,

457
00:25:06.380 --> 00:25:12.209
here show running-config.
>> They should put a little map,

458
00:25:12.209 --> 00:25:13.174
says you are here.

459
00:25:13.174 --> 00:25:16.587
[LAUGH]
>> Now look here,

460
00:25:16.587 --> 00:25:21.283
Daniel, and look at the interfaces right
here, the ones that we just configured on

461
00:25:21.283 --> 00:25:22.750
this router.
>> Yeah.

462
00:25:22.750 --> 00:25:25.160
>> Notice it has both IP version 4 and

463
00:25:25.160 --> 00:25:29.245
IP version 6s on them, okay?
>> So now I can use either one Whatever

464
00:25:29.245 --> 00:25:33.805
network I attach to, if it's IPv4 and so
we're on that, cool, I'm connected but if

465
00:25:33.805 --> 00:25:37.640
it's IPv6, I'm connected to that as well.
>> Right, and the only place, in theory,

466
00:25:37.640 --> 00:25:38.642
right,
>> In theory.

467
00:25:38.642 --> 00:25:40.044
[LAUGH]
>> Which we should note.

468
00:25:40.044 --> 00:25:42.292
We should see this for
a period of time but

469
00:25:42.292 --> 00:25:46.460
we shouldn't see it as a permanent
solution because the goal of what we're

470
00:25:46.460 --> 00:25:50.210
seeing right here is called
a transitional technology.

471
00:25:50.210 --> 00:25:52.538
It's called six to, not six to four,
it's called dual stack.

472
00:25:52.538 --> 00:25:54.081
That's what it's called.
>> Dual stack.

473
00:25:54.081 --> 00:25:54.911
>> Dual stack, okay?

474
00:25:54.911 --> 00:25:59.997
So this allows us to say if my network
is transitioning from IP version 4 to IP

475
00:25:59.997 --> 00:26:05.170
version 6, let me go ahead and configure
the router to work on IP version 4.

476
00:26:05.170 --> 00:26:10.030
Then let me put the IP version
6 router's information on it.

477
00:26:10.030 --> 00:26:12.022
Test it, verify that it works and

478
00:26:12.022 --> 00:26:15.863
once everything is working the way
that I think it should be, and

479
00:26:15.863 --> 00:26:20.366
I start getting machines on it, yup,
then you just turn off IP version 4.

480
00:26:20.366 --> 00:26:21.400
And you are ready to go.
>> Ready to work.

481
00:26:21.400 --> 00:26:21.920
>> Yeah, and

482
00:26:21.920 --> 00:26:23.750
hopefully everything does work.
>> [LAUGH] Right.

483
00:26:23.750 --> 00:26:25.560
>> So but that's the goal, okay?

484
00:26:25.560 --> 00:26:27.550
But we shouldn't see it
on there permanently.

485
00:26:27.550 --> 00:26:28.890
Now will people leave it permanent?

486
00:26:28.890 --> 00:26:29.940
Probably.
>> Of course.

487
00:26:29.940 --> 00:26:31.080
>> You better believe it.

488
00:26:31.080 --> 00:26:32.060
>> When people say,

489
00:26:32.060 --> 00:26:33.410
well it's not permanent.

490
00:26:33.410 --> 00:26:35.020
It's only been on there for
the last ten years.

491
00:26:35.020 --> 00:26:37.940
We will eventually be IPv6 only.

492
00:26:37.940 --> 00:26:39.073
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

493
00:26:39.073 --> 00:26:42.210
but just remember if you see that
term dual stacked, it really is.

494
00:26:42.210 --> 00:26:44.450
It's what's called
a transitional technology.

495
00:26:44.450 --> 00:26:45.915
So even though it can work and

496
00:26:45.915 --> 00:26:49.058
you're seeing it work right here,
it's not supposed to be something that is

497
00:26:49.058 --> 00:26:49.830
permanent.
>> Yeah.

498
00:26:49.830 --> 00:26:50.507
>> So Daniel, for

499
00:26:50.507 --> 00:26:53.788
us we have a lot of different ways to
kinda really get out of some of the issues

500
00:26:53.788 --> 00:26:55.523
that IP version 6 is going to cause us.

501
00:26:55.523 --> 00:26:59.010
The great thing is it doesn't have
anything that really breaks, right?

502
00:26:59.010 --> 00:27:03.410
For us, it's really about configuring
it correctly is kind of the key.

503
00:27:03.410 --> 00:27:06.770
Turning on and off the interfaces to make
sure that we get them ready to go and

504
00:27:06.770 --> 00:27:10.580
if they're matching or if they're
actually exactly what they need to be,

505
00:27:10.580 --> 00:27:12.300
it works perfectly fine.

506
00:27:12.300 --> 00:27:15.768
So that's why we only spent very little
time in the troubleshooting cuz there's

507
00:27:15.768 --> 00:27:18.726
really not a lot, except for
the stuff that we would have showed you,

508
00:27:18.726 --> 00:27:20.873
even an IP version 4 that
you can translate over.

509
00:27:20.873 --> 00:27:23.884
The key word to remember here,
and the difference, right,

510
00:27:23.884 --> 00:27:26.970
is when you start typing in commands,
make sure it's IPv6.

511
00:27:26.970 --> 00:27:28.990
Look at that, get it memorized.

512
00:27:28.990 --> 00:27:33.740
If you see where it shows you when you get
into the interface and you get a command

513
00:27:33.740 --> 00:27:38.910
there, and
you see an answer that says IP address,

514
00:27:38.910 --> 00:27:43.030
and shows you an IP version 6 address,
that is gonna be wrong, okay?

515
00:27:43.030 --> 00:27:47.000
So even if it looks 100% right,
read it and make sure.

516
00:27:47.000 --> 00:27:49.180
Then if the next one says, IPv6 and

517
00:27:49.180 --> 00:27:54.030
then the right IPv6 address there,
then that's the right one.

518
00:27:54.030 --> 00:27:55.740
It's tricky, okay?

519
00:27:55.740 --> 00:27:58.820
Don't just go,
I don't care which one it is.

520
00:27:58.820 --> 00:27:59.920
It matters, okay?

521
00:27:59.920 --> 00:28:04.130
And don't forget that Unicast AS route,
IPv6 Unicast AS routing.

522
00:28:04.130 --> 00:28:08.280
Pay attention, make sure you get those
show commands that we just showed you.

523
00:28:08.280 --> 00:28:12.185
Don't depend on the show
run as much as you can.

524
00:28:12.185 --> 00:28:14.325
You are gonna see it, but
don't depend on that.

525
00:28:14.325 --> 00:28:17.235
That is kind of the easy way
to get through everything.

526
00:28:17.235 --> 00:28:20.179
And I guarantee, on Cisco,
when you're trying to do it quickly,

527
00:28:20.179 --> 00:28:23.648
that is the least way that they want you
to go because that takes the most time for

528
00:28:23.648 --> 00:28:26.455
you to filter through all of
the stuff that you see right there.

529
00:28:26.455 --> 00:28:30.136
So right now,
that should actually end for us here,

530
00:28:30.136 --> 00:28:34.052
the IP version 6 lab that we have.
>> All right, well, great stuff Ronnie.

531
00:28:34.052 --> 00:28:37.342
Thank you so much for explaining IPV 6,
how to get it configured,

532
00:28:37.342 --> 00:28:39.972
how to get it working, and
all of the pitfalls and

533
00:28:39.972 --> 00:28:43.382
caveats that we might have to look out for
as we do that very thing.

534
00:28:43.382 --> 00:28:45.160
So thank you for
joining us again, Ronnie, and

535
00:28:45.160 --> 00:28:46.592
we do thank you as well for joining us.

536
00:28:46.592 --> 00:28:48.520
Hopefully you've enjoyed this episode.

537
00:28:48.520 --> 00:28:49.680
There will be more to come.

538
00:28:49.680 --> 00:28:51.310
As for this one though,
we're gonna call it a day.

539
00:28:51.310 --> 00:28:53.850
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

540
00:28:53.850 --> 00:28:54.700
>> And I’m Ronnie Wong.

541
00:28:54.700 --> 00:28:55.666
>> We'll see you next time.

542
00:28:55.666 --> 00:29:02.490
[MUSIC]

543
00:29:02.490 --> 00:29:05.422
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss how to apply troubleshooting methodologies.  They discuss that though many methods are available they can be reduced to a few different approaches. They begin with emphasizing problem isolation.  The methods are descriptive: bottom-up, top-down and divide-and-conquer using the OSI model as a guide.
episodes.title: Apply Troubleshooting Methodologies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.413
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.413 --> 00:00:06.545
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.545 --> 00:00:08.308
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.308 --> 00:00:12.577
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> All right,

5
00:00:12.577 --> 00:00:17.080
greetings everyone, welcome back to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:17.080 --> 00:00:20.033
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

7
00:00:20.033 --> 00:00:23.152
we're continuing on with more of
that good old CCENT that you love so

8
00:00:23.152 --> 00:00:23.840
much.
>> [LAUGH]

9
00:00:23.840 --> 00:00:25.282
>> Joining us back in the studio, yet

10
00:00:25.282 --> 00:00:28.290
again lending his expertise for us,
our good friend Mr. Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:28.290 --> 00:00:30.143
Ronnie, glad to have you back,
how's it going today?

12
00:00:30.143 --> 00:00:32.182
>> It is going well Daniel, thank you for

13
00:00:32.182 --> 00:00:36.197
having me back on the show as we continue
on with learning more, of course,

14
00:00:36.197 --> 00:00:38.830
getting ready for that Cisco CCENT exam.

15
00:00:38.830 --> 00:00:42.610
And today we're gonna take a look at just
some troubleshooting methodologies, and

16
00:00:42.610 --> 00:00:44.960
show you how they can be applied as well.

17
00:00:44.960 --> 00:00:47.419
So we have to, of course,
talk about some of the basics, and

18
00:00:47.419 --> 00:00:48.931
the foundational theory behind it.

19
00:00:48.931 --> 00:00:52.510
But then we're going to show you just
a brief lab that we also have inside of

20
00:00:52.510 --> 00:00:55.352
Practice Labs that you'll be
able to follow right along.

21
00:00:55.352 --> 00:00:59.630
And I may kind of not do every single step
cuz sometimes I forget what the steps are,

22
00:00:59.630 --> 00:01:03.488
even though I have right here, what
ends up happening is I kind of forget.

23
00:01:03.488 --> 00:01:04.066
>> [LAUGH]

24
00:01:04.066 --> 00:01:05.344
>> But you'll be able to follow

25
00:01:05.344 --> 00:01:08.227
every single step exactly the way
that they've planned it out.

26
00:01:08.227 --> 00:01:11.766
So just pay attention as we go
through that part as well as this.

27
00:01:11.766 --> 00:01:14.469
Because there's gonna be
questions on whether or

28
00:01:14.469 --> 00:01:19.040
not you actually have the idea of
understanding troubleshooting now, okay?

29
00:01:19.040 --> 00:01:23.165
So Daniel, let's just talk
basically about troubleshooting at

30
00:01:23.165 --> 00:01:26.093
the beginning of our IT
careers just a moment.

31
00:01:26.093 --> 00:01:29.830
So Daniel, I remember when I first
really started getting at that.

32
00:01:29.830 --> 00:01:32.302
I'd take a look at a machine,
it would stop working, I'd go-

33
00:01:32.302 --> 00:01:33.157
>> Check the oil and

34
00:01:33.157 --> 00:01:36.801
the gas to make sure that [LAUGH].
>> Well, you would think, right, yeah, but

35
00:01:36.801 --> 00:01:39.137
I'd just go, well,
let's just try this, right.

36
00:01:39.137 --> 00:01:40.863
It was essentially a shotgun approach,

37
00:01:40.863 --> 00:01:42.480
what about you?
>> Yeah,

38
00:01:42.480 --> 00:01:46.690
because you had no real way
to figure out where to begin.

39
00:01:46.690 --> 00:01:49.090
So you just began with the first
thing you could think of.

40
00:01:49.090 --> 00:01:51.960
Okay, maybe it's that, and you would
attempt and see if that would fix it.

41
00:01:51.960 --> 00:01:54.450
If not, chuck it and try something else.
>> Yeah

42
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:58.508
the shotgun approach seems to kind of
be where most beginners kind of start.

43
00:01:58.508 --> 00:02:02.360
It's like, here's the body of
knowledge that I have right now, and

44
00:02:02.360 --> 00:02:03.698
let's just see what sticks.

45
00:02:03.698 --> 00:02:07.387
So you tried something and then you're
like, that didn't really do anything,

46
00:02:07.387 --> 00:02:09.296
and then you keep trying something else.

47
00:02:09.296 --> 00:02:12.029
And maybe, if you're lucky,
a lot of times, or

48
00:02:12.029 --> 00:02:16.631
if you've actually just kind of hit very
close, not super far off the target, but

49
00:02:16.631 --> 00:02:19.550
close enough where you're like, okay.

50
00:02:19.550 --> 00:02:23.790
That gives me a result I was expecting,
and now you can begin to troubleshoot.

51
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:28.460
Well Daniel, even though that is
a practical approach at the beginning,

52
00:02:28.460 --> 00:02:31.760
the problem is, it's a time
wasting approach as well, right.

53
00:02:31.760 --> 00:02:35.350
If I have to try out let's
say ten solutions before I

54
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:37.180
get to the right solution.

55
00:02:37.180 --> 00:02:41.063
And then the other problem behind it,
right, because it takes that long is,

56
00:02:41.063 --> 00:02:42.031
is it consistent?

57
00:02:42.031 --> 00:02:45.140
So let's say that here's what
happened week after week, okay?

58
00:02:45.140 --> 00:02:49.270
One computer has a problem and
I try it, and bam, it worked, okay?

59
00:02:49.270 --> 00:02:52.510
Second week comes along, Daniel,
you tell me if you've experienced this.

60
00:02:52.510 --> 00:02:54.400
You try the same thing and
you're like, no.

61
00:02:54.400 --> 00:02:55.435
>> It didn't work.

62
00:02:55.435 --> 00:02:56.140
>> It didn't work, so

63
00:02:56.140 --> 00:02:58.969
Daniel, have you had that experience too?
>> Yeah, of course,

64
00:02:58.969 --> 00:03:03.162
like you said, everybody that starts
off just starts using whatever bits and

65
00:03:03.162 --> 00:03:06.663
pieces of knowledge they have
to try to troubleshoot problems.

66
00:03:06.663 --> 00:03:11.169
And since we're not super familiar at
that point with what causes what and

67
00:03:11.169 --> 00:03:13.575
having all the conceptual knowledge.

68
00:03:13.575 --> 00:03:16.824
And of course that practical knowledge,
to be able to put it together and

69
00:03:16.824 --> 00:03:19.408
go, I should be seeing this,
because of x, y and z.

70
00:03:19.408 --> 00:03:23.274
That'd be the the only reasons that
would happen, and helping us focus

71
00:03:23.274 --> 00:03:27.088
on [LAUGH] a specific area, we just
try everything in the kitchen sink.

72
00:03:27.088 --> 00:03:28.843
>> Yeah, and so we're getting two things,

73
00:03:28.843 --> 00:03:30.870
right, from that shotgun approach.

74
00:03:30.870 --> 00:03:34.580
One, it can waste a lot of time, and
in a critical environment, right,

75
00:03:34.580 --> 00:03:39.180
where you need to be up and fast, and
quick as possible to get everything up and

76
00:03:39.180 --> 00:03:43.520
functioning so that other people can do
work, well, that's what you can't waste.

77
00:03:43.520 --> 00:03:48.020
And this is part of the realm of
the way that Cisco tests whether or

78
00:03:48.020 --> 00:03:50.776
not you've internalized that knowledge,
and you have it.

79
00:03:50.776 --> 00:03:55.480
They don't really get you by asking
questions, at least on certification,

80
00:03:55.480 --> 00:03:57.770
right, applying your knowledge and
everything.

81
00:03:57.770 --> 00:04:01.060
They don't get you by asking very long and
complex questions.

82
00:04:01.060 --> 00:04:02.909
They get you by just saying,

83
00:04:02.909 --> 00:04:06.699
you need to know what to do when
you see this type of result.

84
00:04:06.699 --> 00:04:09.726
Or you need to know what
the next step should be so

85
00:04:09.726 --> 00:04:13.260
that you can get the proper
result that you want.

86
00:04:13.260 --> 00:04:17.435
So in that sense, that's what the shotgun
approach really doesn't help.

87
00:04:17.435 --> 00:04:19.640
And secondly, what Daniel and

88
00:04:19.640 --> 00:04:24.970
I just described as well Is the idea
of consistency and results.

89
00:04:24.970 --> 00:04:28.567
If I apply something one week and
I go, all right, that fixed it, and

90
00:04:28.567 --> 00:04:31.000
I think that it's come
close to the solution.

91
00:04:31.000 --> 00:04:35.265
I try the same thing the next week and it
doesn't work, that's inconsistent results.

92
00:04:35.265 --> 00:04:39.489
And Daniel, that probably might even
become more of a waste of time because I

93
00:04:39.489 --> 00:04:41.145
think it should have worked.

94
00:04:41.145 --> 00:04:44.394
And now I'm almost, I'm thinking,
look, it worked last week.

95
00:04:44.394 --> 00:04:50.523
So I hate to say this,
it's that weird idiom, right, insanity,

96
00:04:50.523 --> 00:04:54.726
doing the same thing over and over again-
>> Expecting different results-

97
00:04:54.726 --> 00:04:56.766
>> Expecting different results, yeah,

98
00:04:56.766 --> 00:04:57.730
we do that.

99
00:04:57.730 --> 00:05:01.980
We keep going, no, it worked last time,
let me just reboot the computer and

100
00:05:01.980 --> 00:05:04.920
I'll try that same thing again,
and it still doesn't work.

101
00:05:04.920 --> 00:05:06.610
And then you go, okay, well let me try and

102
00:05:06.610 --> 00:05:08.780
turn this off and
I'll try the same thing again.

103
00:05:08.780 --> 00:05:11.975
Now wait a minute, you're doing
something just slightly different, but

104
00:05:11.975 --> 00:05:15.690
you're still getting the same result, but
you're really only doing the same thing.

105
00:05:15.690 --> 00:05:19.990
So that's where the problem lies, okay,
so shot gun approach, can it work?

106
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:21.850
I'm not gonna say it can't, okay,

107
00:05:21.850 --> 00:05:24.437
there are times when
Ronnie Wong has gotten lucky.

108
00:05:24.437 --> 00:05:27.487
And once that's done,
here's the third issue.

109
00:05:27.487 --> 00:05:30.770
Do I have a clue what actually fixed it?

110
00:05:30.770 --> 00:05:34.030
Daniel, have you run across that,
where you're like, okay it's working.

111
00:05:34.030 --> 00:05:35.949
And you just walk away and
go, glad it's working.

112
00:05:35.949 --> 00:05:41.013
And then somebody says, hey Daniel, what
did that fix do, you're like, [SOUND].

113
00:05:41.013 --> 00:05:43.551
>> Which one of those ten things you

114
00:05:43.551 --> 00:05:48.348
did actually fixed the problem,
hey, is that Elvis [LAUGH]?

115
00:05:48.348 --> 00:05:50.766
>> That's a frustrating thing too, right,

116
00:05:50.766 --> 00:05:55.345
because you can't go back and reuse that
knowledge that you almost came up with.

117
00:05:55.345 --> 00:05:59.962
You're counting at that point on the very
fact that you're gonna trend toward what's

118
00:05:59.962 --> 00:06:00.858
gonna be right.

119
00:06:00.858 --> 00:06:02.963
But you don't have a clue
what made that trend.

120
00:06:02.963 --> 00:06:05.145
>> We need to be more scientific when it

121
00:06:05.145 --> 00:06:10.315
comes to coming up with our methodology
and our actual troubleshooting solutions,

122
00:06:10.315 --> 00:06:13.560
that's the word I'm looking for,
solutions.

123
00:06:13.560 --> 00:06:19.160
I want to be able to say yes, I did this,
that was the answer to this problem.

124
00:06:19.160 --> 00:06:21.600
I can repeat this, anybody else
calls me with the same problem,

125
00:06:21.600 --> 00:06:24.000
I can apply said solution and
it will work.

126
00:06:25.310 --> 00:06:27.700
Understanding that all
the variables were the same.

127
00:06:27.700 --> 00:06:28.304
>> Right, so

128
00:06:28.304 --> 00:06:31.665
when we start to take a look at
the idea of troubleshooting,

129
00:06:31.665 --> 00:06:35.784
what we want you to do is be able to
apply an approach to troubleshooting.

130
00:06:35.784 --> 00:06:40.555
That should help you to effectively
approach just about every problem in

131
00:06:40.555 --> 00:06:44.775

That is really just a layer two issue at

Let's talk about this idea of top-down.

00:17:50.260 --> 00:17:53.730
Now, top-down, I've got these

Well, everybody has been able to

355
00:18:43.080 --> 00:18:47.400
They're getting information that comes
back and goes forward, sessions are good.

356
00:18:47.400 --> 00:18:52.880
They're actually able to read the web
page, the application seems to be working,

357
00:18:52.880 --> 00:18:56.480
all except for one website.

358
00:18:56.480 --> 00:18:58.448
So this is when you actually go,
all right, so

359
00:18:58.448 --> 00:19:00.290
let's take a look at that browser.

360
00:19:00.290 --> 00:19:03.370
And then I'm gonna take a look at
the information that it's giving me.

361
00:19:03.370 --> 00:19:07.180
And I may even go to another machine and
go, are you able to connect?

362
00:19:07.180 --> 00:19:10.280
And all of a sudden, that one is
actually not able to connect either.

363
00:19:10.280 --> 00:19:13.590
Well, now I'm no longer dealing
with these upper three layers.

364
00:19:13.590 --> 00:19:18.350
Now I have two or three machines saying,
hey, I can't connect to there either.

365
00:19:18.350 --> 00:19:21.690
That means I can begin here
at the transport layer.

366
00:19:21.690 --> 00:19:23.740
But when I take a look at the browser,
and it opens up and

367
00:19:23.740 --> 00:19:26.440
it doesn't show me anything,
I'm not receiving traffic.

368
00:19:26.440 --> 00:19:29.140
I'm not getting any chunks
of data coming through.

369
00:19:29.140 --> 00:19:31.840
So that probably means that I need
to begin troubleshooting here.

370
00:19:31.840 --> 00:19:37.140
So you can use that to help you to isolate
and then come down to the network layer.

371
00:19:37.140 --> 00:19:40.320
If the network layer is it, you go and
start troubleshooting the equipment that

372
00:19:40.320 --> 00:19:44.930
you need to, to see where along this
path are we not getting connected.

373
00:19:44.930 --> 00:19:47.406
It could be at the server room,
server might not just be responding.

374
00:19:47.406 --> 00:19:48.663
>> And that's a really interesting point.

375
00:19:48.663 --> 00:19:52.224
Because a lot of times, just going into
the practicality of troubleshooting, which

376
00:19:52.224 --> 00:19:54.000
Ronnie and I have both have had to do-
>> [LAUGH]

377
00:19:54.000 --> 00:19:56.031
>> On multiple, multiple occasions,

378
00:19:56.031 --> 00:20:00.810
is sometimes it's not anything that
is wrong with any of your equipment.

379
00:20:00.810 --> 00:20:04.120
Which I can connect to Google,
I can connect to Microsoft.

380
00:20:04.120 --> 00:20:07.080
But when I try to get Amazon,
things aren't working.

381
00:20:07.080 --> 00:20:08.930
Doesn't necessarily mean
something's wrong on my end.

382
00:20:08.930 --> 00:20:11.100
It might actually be that
Amazon's site is down,

383
00:20:11.100 --> 00:20:13.150
or at least the one that
I'm trying to connect to.

384
00:20:13.150 --> 00:20:18.360
So that is always a possibility,
everything is technically working,

385
00:20:18.360 --> 00:20:21.320
except on the other end, right?
>> So there are issues

386
00:20:21.320 --> 00:20:24.924
that you have to face like this, but
notice how we approached it, right?

387
00:20:24.924 --> 00:20:29.410
We took one or the other,
whether it's from the bottom-up or not.

388
00:20:29.410 --> 00:20:32.740
And this all actually comes down
to experience a lot of times,

389
00:20:32.740 --> 00:20:34.240
if you choose to do this.

390
00:20:34.240 --> 00:20:36.640
We'll also talk about these two
a little bit more in-depth in a moment.

391
00:20:36.640 --> 00:20:39.430
But let me go through the idea
of divide and conquer, and

392
00:20:39.430 --> 00:20:41.560
that one will help us out too, okay?

393
00:20:41.560 --> 00:20:46.050
Now, when you talk about dividing and
conquer, this is where you go, all right,

394
00:20:46.050 --> 00:20:48.400
so I already know some of the stuff.

395
00:20:48.400 --> 00:20:52.500
So you assume like I did here, okay,
you go, hey, look, physical and

396
00:20:52.500 --> 00:20:54.610
data link there, that's working.

397
00:20:54.610 --> 00:20:58.980
So you might just go ahead and
jump onto the network, okay?

398
00:20:58.980 --> 00:21:01.287
So when I go to an end user workstation,
I told you,

399
00:21:01.287 --> 00:21:03.045
I always start at the physical layer.

400
00:21:03.045 --> 00:21:05.830
Cuz I don't know if they're
actually connected to the wall,

401
00:21:05.830 --> 00:21:08.400
or if the wireless is actually working.

402
00:21:08.400 --> 00:21:10.840
Then if that's working,
I know the data link is working.

403
00:21:10.840 --> 00:21:14.940
Are they able to connect to whatever
resource they want to using IP address or

404
00:21:14.940 --> 00:21:16.640
DNS to make that work?

405
00:21:16.640 --> 00:21:18.320
Then that's perfectly fine,

406
00:21:18.320 --> 00:21:22.560
then I know that I can begin
troubleshooting at that point as well.

407
00:21:22.560 --> 00:21:24.310
Now once you do the divide and

408
00:21:24.310 --> 00:21:28.030
conquer, okay, here is the question
that you want to have.

409
00:21:28.030 --> 00:21:31.859
And that's actually represented by this
two-headed green arrow right here, okay,

410
00:21:31.859 --> 00:21:33.070
now, what does this mean?

411
00:21:33.070 --> 00:21:37.540
Let's say that I get to the network layer,
and

412
00:21:37.540 --> 00:21:42.380
when I do that and
now I can, I can't connect.

413
00:21:42.380 --> 00:21:45.090
Well, what does that actually mean?

414
00:21:45.090 --> 00:21:50.230
Well, if it's actually an IP issue,
then I know something that,

415
00:21:50.230 --> 00:21:53.070
hey I've got to actually stay
right here and troubleshoot.

416
00:21:53.070 --> 00:21:55.819
But what if everything
actually does seem fine,

417
00:21:55.819 --> 00:21:59.719
in other words the IP address is
responding, let's say, to pings.

418
00:21:59.719 --> 00:22:02.829
If we're actually able
to ping the other side,

419
00:22:02.829 --> 00:22:06.080
then I know that network is not the issue.

420
00:22:06.080 --> 00:22:10.801
And that means I have to actually be
able to move up in that protocol stack.

421
00:22:10.801 --> 00:22:12.688
Which means for us at the transport layer,

422
00:22:12.688 --> 00:22:16.232
then we would begin troubleshooting
at the transport layer as well.

423
00:22:16.232 --> 00:22:20.110
But let's say that at the network layer,
oops,

424
00:22:20.110 --> 00:22:23.510
I'm starting to change that,
which I didn't want to do.

425
00:22:23.510 --> 00:22:26.310
See if I can grab this thing again,
there we go.

426
00:22:26.310 --> 00:22:30.290
If I move down to the data link layer
here, now, why would I do this?

427
00:22:30.290 --> 00:22:33.710
What if I'm actually not getting
any response at all, okay?

428
00:22:33.710 --> 00:22:37.170
Well, then I might check out
the data link later then, so

429
00:22:37.170 --> 00:22:38.770
how do you do this, all right?

430
00:22:38.770 --> 00:22:41.460
So here is the way that it works for
each one of these.

431
00:22:41.460 --> 00:22:44.745
But the divide and conquer is kind of
the easiest one to use an example of.

432
00:22:44.745 --> 00:22:49.037
Okay, regardless of where you start,
whether it's top or down, okay, the bottom

433
00:22:49.037 --> 00:22:52.920
is the only one that this doesn't apply
to, that's why [INAUDIBLE], okay?

434
00:22:54.070 --> 00:22:57.255
So let's do this,
with the divide and conquer, Daniel,

435
00:22:57.255 --> 00:22:59.275
here's the way that we answer this.

436
00:22:59.275 --> 00:23:03.124
If I go to the data link layer and
I see, not only the link light,

437
00:23:03.124 --> 00:23:07.499
I see the activity light, so
I know I'm sending and receiving, okay.

438
00:23:07.499 --> 00:23:12.891
I've gotten an answer which says, NIC
is good, okay, so that means I move up.

439
00:23:15.509 --> 00:23:17.287
If I can grab that ever again.

440
00:23:17.287 --> 00:23:22.390
Okay, I move up the actual stack here,
but what if I don't get anything?

441
00:23:22.390 --> 00:23:23.130
I look, and

442
00:23:23.130 --> 00:23:27.500
all of a sudden I realize something,
that the activity light is not blinking.

443
00:23:27.500 --> 00:23:32.940
Or that there's no light at all,
that means I move down the stack instead.

444
00:23:32.940 --> 00:23:37.405
So this is how you do that, right,
if you get an answer at one layer,

445
00:23:37.405 --> 00:23:42.350
ping's working,
it means I move up to the transport layer.

446
00:23:42.350 --> 00:23:48.860
Can I actually see the port numbers coming
uncrossed, the way that it needs to.

447
00:23:48.860 --> 00:23:52.430
And then I can begin to move up
to the application at that point

448
00:23:52.430 --> 00:23:54.570
if that starts to happen, okay?

449
00:23:54.570 --> 00:23:58.730
But if I don't get an answer at
whatever layer I choose to start with,

450
00:23:58.730 --> 00:24:01.040
then that's what happens from there, okay?

451
00:24:01.040 --> 00:24:03.260
So when we start to see this,

452
00:24:03.260 --> 00:24:07.950
start to see something like this, that
is what we're also doing as well, okay?

453
00:24:07.950 --> 00:24:12.920
So that is kind of a key to us beginning
to isolate where the problem is gonna be.

454
00:24:12.920 --> 00:24:16.618
So take a look at these different
approaches that are out there.

455
00:24:16.618 --> 00:24:17.323
And in our lab,

456
00:24:17.323 --> 00:24:21.040
they actually have a nice little guide
that kind of describes it as well.

457
00:24:21.040 --> 00:24:24.850
You're, again, getting my approach in
the way that they're talking about here.

458
00:24:24.850 --> 00:24:27.370
But this is the beginning
of problem isolation.

459
00:24:27.370 --> 00:24:30.940
Daniel, we still need to talk
about implementing corrections and

460
00:24:30.940 --> 00:24:34.060
then verifying outcomes, and
then we'll get into our lab here.

461
00:24:34.060 --> 00:24:36.708
But overall, though,
that's probably enough for this episode,

462
00:24:36.708 --> 00:24:39.275
cuz I realize we're running out
of time again cuz I keep talking.

463
00:24:39.275 --> 00:24:40.059
>> [LAUGH]

464
00:24:40.059 --> 00:24:42.078
>> But we'll actually do another one here

465
00:24:42.078 --> 00:24:46.340
and finish up our at least basic models
here, and then we'll move into our lab.

466
00:24:46.340 --> 00:24:47.559
>> All right, excellent, Ronnie,

467
00:24:47.559 --> 00:24:49.458
sounds like a plan,
we all have our marching orders.

468
00:24:49.458 --> 00:24:52.217
Go out there and start troubleshooting
everything you can find cuz it's so

469
00:24:52.217 --> 00:24:52.800
much fun to do.

470
00:24:52.800 --> 00:24:55.220
And then we'll figure out what we
can do with those results later.

471
00:24:55.220 --> 00:24:58.920
Ronnie, thanks for joining us,
looking forward to seeing you in part two.

472
00:24:58.920 --> 00:25:00.410
Hopefully you good folks will join us,
as well.

473
00:25:00.410 --> 00:25:02.880
As for this, we're gonna call it a day,
thanks for watching, everyone.

474
00:25:02.880 --> 00:25:05.780
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

475
00:25:05.780 --> 00:25:06.609
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

476
00:25:06.609 --> 00:25:07.523
>> And we'll see you next time.

477
00:25:07.523 --> 00:25:14.740
[MUSIC]

478
00:25:14.740 --> 00:25:17.872
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss how to apply troubleshooting methodologies.  They use practice-labs.com lab to show the way to isolate, apply a problem and verify the action is correct.
episodes.title: Apply Troubleshooting Methodologies Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:03.191
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.191 --> 00:00:05.576
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,
California.

3
00:00:05.576 --> 00:00:12.186
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.186 --> 00:00:12.722
>> All right,

5
00:00:12.722 --> 00:00:16.595
greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.595 --> 00:00:19.979
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and today's episode, well,

7
00:00:19.979 --> 00:00:22.460
we are gonna spin gold out of,
well, straw.

8
00:00:22.460 --> 00:00:23.965
Ronnie's gonna do it for
us today, it's gonna be awesome.

9
00:00:23.965 --> 00:00:25.665
No, no, no, no,
I'm just having a little fun.

10
00:00:25.665 --> 00:00:27.455
We're back for more CCENT.

11
00:00:27.455 --> 00:00:30.050
And as I let the cat out of the bag,
Ronnie is back with us.

12
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:31.599
Ronnie, we're glad to have you yet
again today.

13
00:00:31.599 --> 00:00:32.393
How is it going, man?

14
00:00:32.393 --> 00:00:35.726
>> It's going very well except that
you referred to be as Rumpelstiltskin,

15
00:00:35.726 --> 00:00:36.972
and now, I'm wondering.

16
00:00:36.972 --> 00:00:38.065
>> He's cool, man.

17
00:00:38.065 --> 00:00:41.938
>> [LAUGH] All right, Daniel, thank you
for having me on this show as we continue

18
00:00:41.938 --> 00:00:46.470
on learning more, of course, about our
CCENT, and getting ready for that exam.

19
00:00:46.470 --> 00:00:48.944
We're in the middle of taking a look at,
of course,

20
00:00:48.944 --> 00:00:51.546
applying troubleshooting models or
methodologies.

21
00:00:51.546 --> 00:00:53.680
And we are now ready to proceed on.

22
00:00:53.680 --> 00:00:57.210
So let's go ahead and pick up here, and
we'll also show you the concept and

23
00:00:57.210 --> 00:00:59.610
lab that we have ready for
you as well, okay?

24
00:00:59.610 --> 00:01:03.190
So we've just talked about the different
problem isolation stuff, right?

25
00:01:03.190 --> 00:01:05.030
And we went through those to try and

26
00:01:05.030 --> 00:01:08.660
help you out to start off with
a consistent methodology, right?

27
00:01:08.660 --> 00:01:13.660
A step by step approach that as you
end up seeing a networking issue or

28
00:01:13.660 --> 00:01:17.310
problem, you shouldn't just try and
do a shotgun approach.

29
00:01:17.310 --> 00:01:21.030
This should help you to isolate what
you actually want to be able to do.

30
00:01:21.030 --> 00:01:22.791
>> Now, Ronnie,
you gave us three great approaches.

31
00:01:22.791 --> 00:01:28.510
You gave us, what was it, the top, down,
bottom, up, and the divide and conquer.

32
00:01:28.510 --> 00:01:29.010
>> Divide and conquer.

33
00:01:29.010 --> 00:01:30.600
>> All fantastic, all have their place.

34
00:01:30.600 --> 00:01:31.187
>> Right.
>> But

35
00:01:31.187 --> 00:01:34.717
then we kind of left off from there,
once we employ a methodology,

36
00:01:34.717 --> 00:01:37.316
we have to kinda continue on from there,
right?

37
00:01:37.316 --> 00:01:39.105
>> Yeah, so that-
>> It's at the end of the show.

38
00:01:39.105 --> 00:01:40.620
>> Yeah,
this is not the end of the show yet.

39
00:01:40.620 --> 00:01:42.310
So yeah, don't get me wrong.

40
00:01:42.310 --> 00:01:45.440
Memorizing those are going to
help you on the exam as well.

41
00:01:45.440 --> 00:01:49.360
But understanding that this is part of
that general troubleshooting nature and

42
00:01:49.360 --> 00:01:52.180
approach that pretty much
every method comes along.

43
00:01:52.180 --> 00:01:55.360
Isolating a problem is key when it begins.

44
00:01:55.360 --> 00:01:58.559
Now, once you do figure out
what problem that you're at,

45
00:01:58.559 --> 00:02:02.822
more than likely you're gonna end up
isolating down to usually two or three.

46
00:02:02.822 --> 00:02:06.304
At that point, you kind of pick
which one you believe is gonna be

47
00:02:06.304 --> 00:02:09.139
the one that's gonna lead
you to the right answer.

48
00:02:09.139 --> 00:02:12.135
The reason why you don't always wanna
isolate down to one immediately.

49
00:02:12.135 --> 00:02:15.985
I know this sounds strange unless
you really can do this great, okay?

50
00:02:15.985 --> 00:02:21.178
Is that more than likely, if you just do
that, you give yourself tunnel vision and

51
00:02:21.178 --> 00:02:26.260
you absolutely expect that that's gonna
be the only issue that could be wrong.

52
00:02:26.260 --> 00:02:29.396
Sometimes you might find yourself
where it's actually a couple of

53
00:02:29.396 --> 00:02:30.353
different issues.

54
00:02:30.353 --> 00:02:34.874
So that's why you want to at least kind of
narrow it down to do what you want to be

55
00:02:34.874 --> 00:02:36.050
able to do.

56
00:02:36.050 --> 00:02:37.990
So that's what we have here, okay?

57
00:02:37.990 --> 00:02:42.199
Now, once the problem isolation is there,
the next step is simple, right?

58
00:02:42.199 --> 00:02:45.026
And everything else is try something.

59
00:02:45.026 --> 00:02:48.320
And that is some type of corrective
action, is what you want to try next.

60
00:02:49.710 --> 00:02:53.050
Now, there are a couple of different
approaches to doing this, okay?

61
00:02:53.050 --> 00:02:56.640
The OSI model approach
really helps us once again,

62
00:02:56.640 --> 00:02:59.260
depending on what we need to do, okay?

63
00:02:59.260 --> 00:03:03.480
It can help us, and we're looking at the
bottom half of the screen right now, okay?

64
00:03:03.480 --> 00:03:08.060
At the Physical layer, I already told you
some of the things that we ended up doing.

65
00:03:08.060 --> 00:03:12.520
We of course, can just try and
take a look at cabling if we need to.

66
00:03:12.520 --> 00:03:15.310
We can verify at the lights here, okay?

67
00:03:15.310 --> 00:03:18.719
Are they actually working,
are connectors good, okay?

68
00:03:18.719 --> 00:03:21.392
So if they're bad on the connectors,
right,

69
00:03:21.392 --> 00:03:24.440
we need to either get a new cable or
we need to do what?

70
00:03:24.440 --> 00:03:28.586
We need to re-crimp the new end on it,
and that helps us out too, okay?

71
00:03:28.586 --> 00:03:30.860
The same thing if
the lights are not working.

72
00:03:30.860 --> 00:03:34.147
There is no way that you're verifying
that the light is actually working.

73
00:03:34.147 --> 00:03:38.305
So you may want to either replace that so
that you can easily verify that, or

74
00:03:38.305 --> 00:03:42.400
just make sure that everything
is actually the way it needs to.

75
00:03:42.400 --> 00:03:46.160
Now, at the Data Link layer you're gonna
be checking NICs, of course, okay?

76
00:03:46.160 --> 00:03:49.880
You want to make sure that this is
also sending and receiving traffic.

77
00:03:49.880 --> 00:03:52.990
Switches are generally where
you'll be working at as well.

78
00:03:52.990 --> 00:03:57.410
And then of course, for us, where our main
issue in troubleshooting is gonna be,

79
00:03:57.410 --> 00:04:01.060
is this actually going to the right NIC,
the right MAC address?

80
00:04:01.060 --> 00:04:04.338
Or is it actually from the right
MAC address as well, so

81
00:04:04.338 --> 00:04:06.918
you'll also be checking out there, too.

82
00:04:06.918 --> 00:04:09.820
And then at the Network layer,
you're normally dealing with routers.

83
00:04:09.820 --> 00:04:12.910
Is it gonna be IP addressing and
then filtering, right?

84
00:04:12.910 --> 00:04:16.839
Straight up what we call access lists
a lot of times where it might be

85
00:04:16.839 --> 00:04:19.447
blocking just certain IP addresses or not.

86
00:04:19.447 --> 00:04:20.972
And then you can get to, well,

87
00:04:20.972 --> 00:04:23.810
even more advanced filtering
once you start doing that.

88
00:04:23.810 --> 00:04:27.460
Where you say, hey, not only to this
address, but even to this protocol.

89
00:04:27.460 --> 00:04:30.140
So you might continue to move up and
work from there.

90
00:04:30.140 --> 00:04:33.530
Now, I didn't fill out the rest of this
because we're dealing with network

91
00:04:33.530 --> 00:04:34.790
troubleshooting.

92
00:04:34.790 --> 00:04:38.180
So we're not really concerned about
whether or not, I shouldn't say that.

93
00:04:38.180 --> 00:04:40.028
We're not really, in the end here,

94
00:04:40.028 --> 00:04:42.954
right, when we talk about
troubleshooting networking.

95
00:04:42.954 --> 00:04:44.710
The data is what it is, okay?

96
00:04:44.710 --> 00:04:47.500
If it's corrupted,
that's not our issue at this point,

97
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:50.750
unless we realize that one of
these devices is causing that.

98
00:04:50.750 --> 00:04:54.649
But for us, right, it's really about,
are these things working so

99
00:04:54.649 --> 00:04:57.888
that I can deliver it from
the source to the destination?

100
00:04:57.888 --> 00:04:59.830
And that's what I'm
really concerned about.

101
00:04:59.830 --> 00:05:02.310
So at this point,
it's whatever application from there,

102
00:05:02.310 --> 00:05:03.970
you can troubleshoot the application.

103
00:05:03.970 --> 00:05:07.880
Or you turn it over to someone who can
troubleshoot the application if you go,

104
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:11.290
hey, these networking layers,
every device along that path,

105
00:05:11.290 --> 00:05:14.120
every configuration along
that path is working, okay?

106
00:05:14.120 --> 00:05:16.040
And then you don't worry
about it at that point.

107
00:05:16.040 --> 00:05:17.920
You escalate that if you need to.

108
00:05:17.920 --> 00:05:21.500
But the other thing which has
always served me well, Daniel,

109
00:05:21.500 --> 00:05:23.490
especially in Ciscoland, okay?

110
00:05:23.490 --> 00:05:27.970
Is this idea of once I get the basic
skills that I need to in configuring

111
00:05:27.970 --> 00:05:32.840
routers and switches,
I always want to start with what I know

112
00:05:32.840 --> 00:05:37.920
should be on that switch, or
should be on that router.

113
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:42.200
All the other extraneous
configuration that might be there,

114
00:05:42.200 --> 00:05:43.950
it could be part of the problem.

115
00:05:43.950 --> 00:05:46.222
But I want to start by verifying,

116
00:05:46.222 --> 00:05:49.884
did I configure those
interfaces correctly, okay?

117
00:05:49.884 --> 00:05:52.730
So I always wanna start
with that as the base.

118
00:05:52.730 --> 00:05:57.120
Do not go, well, that's possibly right.

119
00:05:57.120 --> 00:06:00.302
You've got to know,
you have to know, excuse me,

120
00:06:00.302 --> 00:06:02.900
whether or not it is right when you start.

121
00:06:02.900 --> 00:06:07.221
So when there is troubleshooting, a lot of
times what I might end up doing, right,

122
00:06:07.221 --> 00:06:10.121
is that I might go ahead and
just for the sake of testing,

123
00:06:10.121 --> 00:06:13.200
back up everything on that router,
that switch.

124
00:06:13.200 --> 00:06:15.168
And I might just go ahead and startle it.

125
00:06:15.168 --> 00:06:17.336
Let me make sure I can do
basic connectivity and

126
00:06:17.336 --> 00:06:21.154
reconfigure those interfaces just
to verify I can get connectivity.

127
00:06:21.154 --> 00:06:24.930
And then I can add that back in
on those different configurations

128
00:06:24.930 --> 00:06:27.250
to see what breaks it at that point.

129
00:06:27.250 --> 00:06:30.730
But I always want to begin
with what I know is right, and

130
00:06:30.730 --> 00:06:34.540
then I can begin to spot what
isn't right as well, okay?

131
00:06:34.540 --> 00:06:38.940
So implementing those types of
corrections that we need are key.

132
00:06:38.940 --> 00:06:42.200
This is the part that
comes with experience,

133
00:06:42.200 --> 00:06:45.800
more than any type of methodology
that we can show you.

134
00:06:45.800 --> 00:06:50.070
But the only methodology that I can
actually kind of share with you through

135
00:06:50.070 --> 00:06:53.700
experience is begin with what
you know has to be there for

136
00:06:53.700 --> 00:06:55.670
those devices to communicate.

137
00:06:55.670 --> 00:06:58.475
And then from that point,
everything else that's extra.

138
00:06:58.475 --> 00:07:01.816
Well, then you can start isolating them,
turning them off,

139
00:07:01.816 --> 00:07:04.780
or just making sure that
that's not part of the issue.

140
00:07:04.780 --> 00:07:08.000
So you can isolate that down and
say, here's my correction here,

141
00:07:08.000 --> 00:07:12.360
is I'm gonna remove this item on this
interface, and see if that fixes anything.

142
00:07:12.360 --> 00:07:15.502
If it doesn't, put it back,
is kind of the key.

143
00:07:15.502 --> 00:07:17.696
Cuz, okay, so
that didn't actually fix anything.

144
00:07:17.696 --> 00:07:19.196
So let me put it back in place.

145
00:07:19.196 --> 00:07:22.110
So I'm troubleshooting the original
problem as well, okay?

146
00:07:22.110 --> 00:07:24.536
So that's a hard part to actually learn.

147
00:07:24.536 --> 00:07:27.362
Because it's easy, one of the things
we don't want to do, Daniel,

148
00:07:27.362 --> 00:07:29.920
is something that you had
mentioned before, right?

149
00:07:29.920 --> 00:07:32.960
Is that in the part one that
we were talking about here,

150
00:07:32.960 --> 00:07:37.340
right, is that we might try 15 different
things, 10 or 15 different things.

151
00:07:37.340 --> 00:07:43.240
And now, when it's working and somebody
says, which one is the right answer?

152
00:07:43.240 --> 00:07:46.020
You're going, it's one of those ten.

153
00:07:46.020 --> 00:07:47.738
Well, that's kind of
a hard situation to be in.

154
00:07:47.738 --> 00:07:52.128
>> Yeah, I mean, you could redo all of
the ten steps that you did and then-

155
00:07:52.128 --> 00:07:53.030
>> Every time.

156
00:07:53.030 --> 00:07:56.257
>> Every time, that seems like a lot
of wasted time and effort, though.

157
00:07:56.257 --> 00:07:58.070
So narrowing it down
to the actual problem,

158
00:07:58.070 --> 00:08:01.402
plus it kinda Proves to your employer and
the other people working around you that

159
00:08:01.402 --> 00:08:04.261
you can actually figure out what
the hell you're doing and not just.

160
00:08:04.261 --> 00:08:05.688
>> Right, [LAUGH].

161
00:08:05.688 --> 00:08:07.779
>> Anybody can shock and
[INAUDIBLE] things, right?

162
00:08:07.779 --> 00:08:09.522
>> Right, and that's no what we want.

163
00:08:09.522 --> 00:08:13.343
In a true production environment
speed is kinda the key.

164
00:08:13.343 --> 00:08:16.069
Getting things that
are critical to work back and

165
00:08:16.069 --> 00:08:18.073
the nature that need to is also key.

166
00:08:18.073 --> 00:08:20.383
That's why we often emphasize backups.

167
00:08:20.383 --> 00:08:23.379
And that's another thing that I should
have emphasized right from the beginning,

168
00:08:23.379 --> 00:08:24.335
Daniel, that I didn't.

169
00:08:24.335 --> 00:08:27.000
Before you implement any correction,
Daniel,

170
00:08:27.000 --> 00:08:30.706
how important do you think a backup
of your configuration would be?

171
00:08:30.706 --> 00:08:33.343
>> As important as anything, if not more.

172
00:08:33.343 --> 00:08:36.454
>> Right, because if I
implement a correction, Daniel.

173
00:08:36.454 --> 00:08:38.623
Let's say I do the thing
that you're talking about.

174
00:08:38.623 --> 00:08:39.238
12 corrections.

175
00:08:39.238 --> 00:08:39.838
>> Yeah.

176
00:08:39.838 --> 00:08:44.254
>> And all of a sudden, not only doesn't
it work, it actually has broken it more.

177
00:08:44.254 --> 00:08:45.096
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, right,

178
00:08:45.096 --> 00:08:46.278
that's always the fear, right?

179
00:08:46.278 --> 00:08:49.691
Like, yeah, you may have even actually
fixed the issue that you had.

180
00:08:49.691 --> 00:08:50.931
But you created three more issues.

181
00:08:50.931 --> 00:08:52.365
>> Right.
>> So the person's gonna go,

182
00:08:52.365 --> 00:08:55.804
now my computer's doing this, or now we're
having trouble with connectivity to that.

183
00:08:55.804 --> 00:08:56.476
>> Yeah.

184
00:08:56.476 --> 00:08:57.219
>> What did you do?

185
00:08:57.219 --> 00:08:59.202
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's a great question.

186
00:08:59.202 --> 00:09:00.012
Hey, is that Elvis?

187
00:09:00.012 --> 00:09:01.124
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

188
00:09:01.124 --> 00:09:01.960
>> Yeah, once again,

189
00:09:01.960 --> 00:09:03.637
let's find if Elvis is in the building.

190
00:09:03.637 --> 00:09:05.963
So here, we have this idea, right?

191
00:09:05.963 --> 00:09:08.852
So before implementing any
of these corrective steps,

192
00:09:08.852 --> 00:09:12.482
get a good backup of your configurations
and whatever you're doing.

193
00:09:12.482 --> 00:09:14.867
And this is true, whether you're
on an end user work station or

194
00:09:14.867 --> 00:09:16.853
whether you're dealing with router and
switches.

195
00:09:16.853 --> 00:09:18.867
Router and
switch is a lot easier to back up.

196
00:09:18.867 --> 00:09:21.464
But then use a workstation
even if it takes longer.

197
00:09:21.464 --> 00:09:26.211
You want to ask any files that you're
working on, go ahead and save those.

198
00:09:26.211 --> 00:09:31.198
Do you already have this backed up in
a business to your centralized chair,

199
00:09:31.198 --> 00:09:34.770
your location of the files
that you absolutely need?

200
00:09:34.770 --> 00:09:38.016
If not, by me fixing a particular problem,

201
00:09:38.016 --> 00:09:42.688
like what Daniel said,
I could end up really breaking it hard.

202
00:09:42.688 --> 00:09:46.723
So Daniel, you're more familiar with
the Linux operating system that I am.

203
00:09:46.723 --> 00:09:49.127
There's actually a command that can
wipe the hard drive very easily.

204
00:09:49.127 --> 00:09:50.464
Just a few different letters, right?

205
00:09:50.464 --> 00:09:52.134
>> Yep.
>> And you go, yes,

206
00:09:52.134 --> 00:09:54.795
Ronnie said I should do that and
press Enter.

207
00:09:54.795 --> 00:09:55.496
Go ahead.

208
00:09:55.496 --> 00:09:56.411
What rm something?

209
00:09:56.411 --> 00:09:57.835
>> Yeah, rm-rf.

210
00:09:57.835 --> 00:09:59.648
>> Yeah, rm-rf slash.

211
00:09:59.648 --> 00:10:01.123
And once you do, bye bye.

212
00:10:01.123 --> 00:10:03.455
>> I mean that's just five letters.

213
00:10:03.455 --> 00:10:07.967
And so I wouldn't ever want to do that,
but if I happen to go,

214
00:10:07.967 --> 00:10:13.114
I'm reading this forum post or
a blog out there, and I'm gonna try.

215
00:10:15.798 --> 00:10:19.439
Backup though, if I have a backup I go,
good thing there's a backup of this,

216
00:10:19.439 --> 00:10:20.572
and we're ready to go.

217
00:10:20.572 --> 00:10:23.643
>> I always say, backups are one of those
things that you would rather have and

218
00:10:23.643 --> 00:10:24.973
not need than need and not have.

219
00:10:24.973 --> 00:10:28.017
>> That's a great idiom
to actually think about.

220
00:10:28.017 --> 00:10:31.935
So make sure you do that before you
implement any of these correction steps.

221
00:10:31.935 --> 00:10:36.912
I know that, especially with speed, you
don't tend to write a lot of things down.

222
00:10:36.912 --> 00:10:40.455
But make sure that even
immediately after doing it,

223
00:10:40.455 --> 00:10:45.202
jot down as much as you can, or
as little as you can, that reminds you,

224
00:10:45.202 --> 00:10:48.196
I did try this,
I did do that, I did do that.

225
00:10:48.196 --> 00:10:51.046
It's a lot easier to go back
right then if it's only three or

226
00:10:51.046 --> 00:10:52.648
four commands that you typed in.

227
00:10:52.648 --> 00:10:54.352
To kind of put those back in,

228
00:10:54.352 --> 00:10:58.115
rather than go,
I gotta restore the backup a lot of times.

229
00:10:58.115 --> 00:10:59.431
Now on routers and switches,

230
00:10:59.431 --> 00:11:01.912
the backup config really
doesn't take too long to run.

231
00:11:01.912 --> 00:11:05.591
But a lot of times it also takes you
to reboot it for it to happen too.

232
00:11:05.591 --> 00:11:07.454
That could cause some outage as well.

233
00:11:07.454 --> 00:11:10.412
But implementing corrections,
you have to try this.

234
00:11:10.412 --> 00:11:14.722
And it's only gonna become better with
experience is what you'll actually

235
00:11:14.722 --> 00:11:15.338
find out.

236
00:11:15.338 --> 00:11:19.698
You won't actually do this, you won't get
any better at if if you don't try it.

237
00:11:19.698 --> 00:11:23.171
If you don't try and actually fix stuff,
it's not gonna happen.

238
00:11:23.171 --> 00:11:27.202
So in a lab setting,
you should try and break it.

239
00:11:27.202 --> 00:11:28.609
I'm not saying go in there and

240
00:11:28.609 --> 00:11:31.857
take a screwdriver to your Cisco
equipment that you just bought.

241
00:11:31.857 --> 00:11:33.934
>> It's broke.
>> It's broke, yeah, and

242
00:11:33.934 --> 00:11:35.513
use a hammer to do that.

243
00:11:35.513 --> 00:11:38.458
But what I'm saying it go in,
take the configuration,

244
00:11:38.458 --> 00:11:41.788
type in something that you know
is obviously not going to work.

245
00:11:41.788 --> 00:11:45.485
And then walk through this troubleshooting
and that way it will help you out and

246
00:11:45.485 --> 00:11:47.342
you get something like that to happen.

247
00:11:47.342 --> 00:11:52.749
Okay, all right, let's move on to
the idea of verifying the outcome.

248
00:11:52.749 --> 00:11:56.898
Now Daniel, you'll notice right at
the top here, look at what I say.

249
00:11:56.898 --> 00:11:58.382
Start with what you know is right.

250
00:11:58.382 --> 00:12:00.431
That is also part of this step too.

251
00:12:00.431 --> 00:12:01.409
>> Could be a mantra.

252
00:12:01.409 --> 00:12:02.655
>> Yeah, it should be.

253
00:12:02.655 --> 00:12:06.645
Because this is how you verify, hey,
here's what I know to be right.

254
00:12:06.645 --> 00:12:10.144
Cuz if I can actually say
everything else is right here,

255
00:12:10.144 --> 00:12:12.755
then I know I can isolate down once again.

256
00:12:12.755 --> 00:12:16.576
But as I move stuff around that
I didn't want to move around.

257
00:12:16.576 --> 00:12:20.264
So always start, verify the outcome.

258
00:12:20.264 --> 00:12:22.579
Here's what I'm expecting to see.

259
00:12:22.579 --> 00:12:25.316
If I don't see that then
I know it's not right.

260
00:12:25.316 --> 00:12:25.939
>> Right.

261
00:12:25.939 --> 00:12:27.677
>> That's what's happened.

262
00:12:27.677 --> 00:12:29.767
So this is where you go and
you talk to somebody.

263
00:12:29.767 --> 00:12:33.034
You go,
is this what you were expecting to see?

264
00:12:33.034 --> 00:12:35.167
They go, well sort of.

265
00:12:35.167 --> 00:12:37.684
You need to clarify that and
go, all right,

266
00:12:37.684 --> 00:12:41.848
tell me what you were expecting to see
here or what should have happened.

267
00:12:41.848 --> 00:12:43.224
What should be happening.

268
00:12:43.224 --> 00:12:45.181
Sometimes it's easy to actually know.

269
00:12:45.181 --> 00:12:47.679
A web page doesn't come up
that they're expecting.

270
00:12:47.679 --> 00:12:48.658
The web page shows up.

271
00:12:48.658 --> 00:12:51.097
Or at least the connection
to the web page shows up.

272
00:12:51.097 --> 00:12:51.994
We're good.

273
00:12:51.994 --> 00:12:55.245
But if you don't even know
what the outcome's gonna be,

274
00:12:55.245 --> 00:12:59.459
you can't verify what you know is
supposed to be the right result of this.

275
00:12:59.459 --> 00:13:02.252
Now let's go ahead and
take a look as well.

276
00:13:02.252 --> 00:13:06.891
The other things that you also do is,
let's say, did you solve it?

277
00:13:06.891 --> 00:13:10.059
If you did solve the issue and
it's working fine,

278
00:13:10.059 --> 00:13:13.920
you'll need to monitor this,
of course, for days to come.

279
00:13:13.920 --> 00:13:18.508
And you want to make sure that everybody
has this question in their mind.

280
00:13:18.508 --> 00:13:21.009
Or that you put the question out.

281
00:13:21.009 --> 00:13:23.107
I shouldn't say question, the statement.

282
00:13:23.107 --> 00:13:26.714
You should say something
like this to the people.

283
00:13:26.714 --> 00:13:30.562
If you're experiencing any difficulties or
you're seeing something that

284
00:13:30.562 --> 00:13:34.358
seems strange that you haven't
experienced before, please let me know.

285
00:13:34.358 --> 00:13:37.709
That way you can know whether or
not you actually solved it.

286
00:13:37.709 --> 00:13:41.708
Go back and start making your document.

287
00:13:41.708 --> 00:13:46.024
Make sure that you documented your steps
at solving it and then your backup.

288
00:13:46.024 --> 00:13:50.029
You're essentially creating
a database that makes it easier for

289
00:13:50.029 --> 00:13:53.688
you next time if you run into
an issue that is similar or not.

290
00:13:53.688 --> 00:13:55.624
Now what if you don't solve?

291
00:13:55.624 --> 00:13:57.083
If you do not solve this,

292
00:13:57.083 --> 00:14:01.117
remember that you want to be
troubleshooting the original problem,

293
00:14:01.117 --> 00:14:05.932
not the problem that Ronnie might have
created by troubleshooting 15 steps in.

294
00:14:05.932 --> 00:14:08.048
And then when you go, okay,
Ronnie, what did you do?

295
00:14:08.048 --> 00:14:10.280
I go, I can't remember.

296
00:14:10.280 --> 00:14:13.117
I don't know,
I tried everything underneath the sun.

297
00:14:13.117 --> 00:14:16.187
And now Daniel's going,
what do you mean by that?

298
00:14:16.187 --> 00:14:20.325
I might have been at the keyboard for 25,
30 minutes trying different commands.

299
00:14:20.325 --> 00:14:23.227
Now Daniel's just kind of scratching,
he's like, are you joking?

300
00:14:23.227 --> 00:14:25.027
Why would you do that?

301
00:14:25.027 --> 00:14:28.452
Well, this is where it
really does help us.

302
00:14:28.452 --> 00:14:33.245
During that implementation process, as
we're starting to implement corrections,

303
00:14:33.245 --> 00:14:34.434
only do one at a time.

304
00:14:34.434 --> 00:14:36.316
And test and verify.

305
00:14:36.316 --> 00:14:40.932
If it's not solved, remove that fix and
then come back and see if it's solved.

306
00:14:40.932 --> 00:14:44.472
If it is, then you document and
go all right, that's the right answer.

307
00:14:44.472 --> 00:14:47.624
But if it's not,
remove the fix, that's the key.

308
00:14:47.624 --> 00:14:51.097
You're also gonna need to realize
something that most of us don't want to

309
00:14:51.097 --> 00:14:51.609
admit to.

310
00:14:51.609 --> 00:14:53.810
You may have to escalate this issue.

311
00:14:53.810 --> 00:14:57.127
That means for some people,
it's like, all right,

312
00:14:57.127 --> 00:14:59.937
who do I need to call that
can help me out here?

313
00:14:59.937 --> 00:15:02.529
Daniel's, that's the international symbol,
Cisco Tech, that's who you call.

314
00:15:02.529 --> 00:15:03.150
>> That's right.

315
00:15:03.150 --> 00:15:05.578
>> [LAUGH]
>> Listen, you pay them good money, and

316
00:15:05.578 --> 00:15:06.914
guess what they will do for you?

317
00:15:06.914 --> 00:15:08.015
They will fix your problem.

318
00:15:08.015 --> 00:15:09.539
>> They will fix your problem.

319
00:15:09.539 --> 00:15:10.703
And that is not a bad answer.

320
00:15:10.703 --> 00:15:11.592
>> No it is not.

321
00:15:11.592 --> 00:15:12.936
[CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah,

322
00:15:12.936 --> 00:15:14.850
practically it's not a bad answer.

323
00:15:14.850 --> 00:15:16.331
On the exam, though,
follow this step right here.

324
00:15:16.331 --> 00:15:19.243
>> Yeah, Cisco Tech is not gonna
be one of the A, B, C or Ds.

325
00:15:19.243 --> 00:15:21.143
[LAUGH]
>> Well if it is,

326
00:15:21.143 --> 00:15:22.026
it would be neat, but it's not.

327
00:15:22.026 --> 00:15:22.626
