553
00:26:53.081 --> 00:26:55.254
which is kind of a neat one there.

554
00:26:55.254 --> 00:27:02.317
But now it went from that to up, okay, so
I know now this interface is responding.

555
00:27:02.317 --> 00:27:06.660
And then,
by typing in the show ip interface brief,

556
00:27:06.660 --> 00:27:10.080
I can now see that the status is up up.

557
00:27:10.080 --> 00:27:14.496
Remember for us, status at this level
means the link light is up on a NIC.

558
00:27:14.496 --> 00:27:18.323
And then the protocol means activity,
so the boinking light on a NIC.

559
00:27:18.323 --> 00:27:23.610
That's how I always see it now because
it just makes it easy for me to do this.

560
00:27:23.610 --> 00:27:26.272
So did I solve the issue,
well, let's check.

561
00:27:26.272 --> 00:27:30.279
>> Well, I'm gonna actually be super
impressed if an Internet site comes

562
00:27:30.279 --> 00:27:33.015
up, because the IP address
is on the interface of

563
00:27:33.015 --> 00:27:35.620
a router
>> Unless the router is serving up a web

564
00:27:35.620 --> 00:27:39.135
page, which I'm guessing it's doing,
do Cisco routers actually do that?

565
00:27:39.135 --> 00:27:43.470
>> Yeah, they can actually serve
up a web page, they sure can.

566
00:27:43.470 --> 00:27:47.626
Yeah, now the web page is not for you to
kind of design and put something up there.

567
00:27:47.626 --> 00:27:51.707
Usually the web page is designed for
you to connect to it, so

568
00:27:51.707 --> 00:27:55.554
that you can manually
administrate the router itself.

569
00:27:55.554 --> 00:27:56.102
>> Very cool.
>> So

570
00:27:56.102 --> 00:27:59.730
let's check it out and
see what happens as we do this.

571
00:27:59.730 --> 00:28:04.450
I need to go back to the lab
machine that I was on and

572
00:28:04.450 --> 00:28:08.390
also, gonna see if I can
bring up the browser again.

573
00:28:08.390 --> 00:28:11.060
So we already know that we can connect
to this one they've named Internet.

574
00:28:11.060 --> 00:28:13.650
And this is actually from Practice Labs,

575
00:28:13.650 --> 00:28:15.840
so you can get access
to some of the files.

576
00:28:15.840 --> 00:28:18.219
We'll be using that in the future
in other episodes, here.

577
00:28:18.219 --> 00:28:23.724
Then http, oops, so much for

578
00:28:23.724 --> 00:28:28.618
that, Now Daniel,

579
00:28:28.618 --> 00:28:34.645
the other method, right, that I should
be thinking about even before I do this,

580
00:28:34.645 --> 00:28:39.630
because I'm going to do this thing
backward if I don't, is this.

581
00:28:39.630 --> 00:28:44.553
Okay now, I should just bring this up,
verify first, right?

582
00:28:44.553 --> 00:28:48.816
>> This is giving you verification that
those lower layers are working fine.

583
00:28:48.816 --> 00:28:52.704
>> Right, yeah, see, I just jumped right
into the layer seven [CROSSTALK] because I

584
00:28:52.704 --> 00:28:54.090
was like, no big deal.

585
00:28:54.090 --> 00:28:55.635
But now that I have everything working,

586
00:28:55.635 --> 00:28:57.686
I wanna verify that that's
actually working first.

587
00:28:57.686 --> 00:29:00.491
>> Now that would be a shortcut,
you could do that and see,

588
00:29:00.491 --> 00:29:04.140
cuz if you do get a web page,
then everything below that is working.

589
00:29:04.140 --> 00:29:06.760
>> Yes, and
that is the absolute truth, and

590
00:29:06.760 --> 00:29:10.960
most of us would just do that anyways,
just to go ahead and check here.

591
00:29:10.960 --> 00:29:13.430
Let's see if this actually
does end up working.

592
00:29:13.430 --> 00:29:18.120
I've opened up so many tabs now, I've
forgot, and everything is smaller now too.

593
00:29:18.120 --> 00:29:21.821
So let me close all that out, and
then we'll use this one that's open here.

594
00:29:21.821 --> 00:29:27.063
Let's see, no, I've gotta,
we'll just check here,

595
00:29:27.063 --> 00:29:30.820
and then I'll zoom in in just a moment.

596
00:29:30.820 --> 00:29:34.949
Let me type it in, 192.168.16.1.

597
00:29:36.899 --> 00:29:41.790
All right, now let me zoom back in,
I can't do it on that page.

598
00:29:41.790 --> 00:29:46.100
I gotta come back over here for
just a moment, and then I can zoom in and

599
00:29:46.100 --> 00:29:47.049
show you the results.

600
00:29:48.750 --> 00:29:51.357
Now, Daniel it doesn't look
like the web page came up, but

601
00:29:51.357 --> 00:29:52.725
I am now certain of something.

602
00:29:52.725 --> 00:29:54.443
>> That's because it's asking you for

603
00:29:54.443 --> 00:29:57.350
security credentials before it
allows you go to the web page.

604
00:29:57.350 --> 00:30:03.230
>> Right, so now I know something, right,
from this IP, this server is asking.

605
00:30:03.230 --> 00:30:08.030
So that now means what, that this
address and this web server, it's there.

606
00:30:08.030 --> 00:30:09.430
It is replying,

607
00:30:09.430 --> 00:30:13.550
it is doing what it needs to do here,
okay, so that's what it's doing.

608
00:30:13.550 --> 00:30:17.744
It says, server reports that it
is from level 15 access as well.

609
00:30:17.744 --> 00:30:21.232
So it gives a little bit more in like,
hey, this is what's happening,

610
00:30:21.232 --> 00:30:21.999
that's fine.

611
00:30:21.999 --> 00:30:26.140
If I click Cancel, just for a moment,
cuz I don't really need it right now.

612
00:30:26.140 --> 00:30:33.050
Notice what else it says, unauthorized,
so I know that the website is up.

613
00:30:33.050 --> 00:30:36.570
But right now, the only thing it's telling
me is that I'm not allowed to see it,

614
00:30:36.570 --> 00:30:38.730
I am not authorized to
be able to see this.

615
00:30:38.730 --> 00:30:42.460
So that is kinda one of the methods
that we can actually take a look at.

616
00:30:42.460 --> 00:30:45.670
Now Daniel, we do need to go
through just a couple of more.

617
00:30:45.670 --> 00:30:48.570
We need to go through the bottom up and

618
00:30:48.570 --> 00:30:52.320
then we'll talk about the divide and
conquer just briefly.

619
00:30:52.320 --> 00:30:54.336
But Daniel,
it looks like I've run out of time and

620
00:30:54.336 --> 00:30:56.075
probably even a little bit over that time.

621
00:30:56.075 --> 00:30:59.560
So let's go ahead and end this episode
here and we'll pick up from this point.

622
00:30:59.560 --> 00:31:01.932
>> All right, Ronnie, not a problem,
we look forward to seeing you there,

623
00:31:01.932 --> 00:31:03.286
look forward to seeing you there as well.

624
00:31:03.286 --> 00:31:07.012
But as the man said, we are out of time,
so join us back for part three, and

625
00:31:07.012 --> 00:31:10.305
see how Ronniestiltskin over here
continues to spin that gold.

626
00:31:10.305 --> 00:31:11.387
>> [LAUGH]
>> Signing off for

627
00:31:11.387 --> 00:31:14.050
ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

628
00:31:14.050 --> 00:31:18.932
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.
>> And we'll see you next time.

629
00:31:18.932 --> 00:31:22.204
[MUSIC]

630
00:31:22.204 --> 00:31:24.462
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss how to apply troubleshooting methodologies.  They use practice-labs.com lab to show the way to isolate, apply a problem and verify the action is correct.
episodes.title: Apply Troubleshooting Methodologies Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.011
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.011 --> 00:00:05.056
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,
California.

3
00:00:05.056 --> 00:00:06.518
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.518 --> 00:00:08.014
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.014 --> 00:00:12.060
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.060 --> 00:00:13.590
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:13.590 --> 00:00:16.940
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.940 --> 00:00:18.180
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

9
00:00:18.180 --> 00:00:23.770
in today's episode we are continuing
on with more in our CCENT series.

10
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:25.980
Joining us in the studio the man,
the myth, the legend,

11
00:00:25.980 --> 00:00:28.760
the master blaster himself,
one Mr. Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:28.760 --> 00:00:30.480
Ronnie, welcome back, how's it going?

13
00:00:30.480 --> 00:00:32.550
>> It's going well Daniel, thank you for
having me back on the show.

14
00:00:32.550 --> 00:00:35.502
As we continue on in our little
troubleshooting lab here,

15
00:00:35.502 --> 00:00:40.140
trying to make sure we cover the bases
of some of the most identifiable

16
00:00:40.140 --> 00:00:43.090
types of approaches in
troubleshooting methodology.

17
00:00:43.090 --> 00:00:46.160
We've just went through,
of course, the top-down method and

18
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:49.110
now we're gonna approach it
a little bit differently as well.

19
00:00:49.110 --> 00:00:51.310
Which is, of course,
going back through and

20
00:00:51.310 --> 00:00:54.866
now taking it from
the bottom-up method as well.

21
00:00:54.866 --> 00:00:57.650
So being able to actually
kind of pace ourselves and

22
00:00:57.650 --> 00:01:00.670
understand what we're actually
doing is kind of the key.

23
00:01:00.670 --> 00:01:01.930
So the initial one right,

24
00:01:01.930 --> 00:01:05.560
we found out that we couldn't get
access to an intranet website.

25
00:01:05.560 --> 00:01:08.840
We found where that is, and
then once we corrected the issue,

26
00:01:08.840 --> 00:01:11.566
everything was good and
now we are ready to move on.

27
00:01:11.566 --> 00:01:14.920
So in our second task here, okay.

28
00:01:14.920 --> 00:01:18.390
We have a scenario that says users have
been complaining that they're unable to

29
00:01:18.390 --> 00:01:19.787
connect to the Internet at all,

30
00:01:19.787 --> 00:01:23.530
okay, and all other internal network
resources are still available.

31
00:01:23.530 --> 00:01:26.490
However, we actually need
to troubleshoot that.

32
00:01:26.490 --> 00:01:29.742
So everybody is essentially saying,
the Internet is broken, okay?

33
00:01:29.742 --> 00:01:34.100
That is pretty much what we have to
actually be able to see, and do, and

34
00:01:34.100 --> 00:01:34.760
just verify.

35
00:01:34.760 --> 00:01:39.770
Because if not, we're gonna be in big
trouble here as we start with the idea

36
00:01:39.770 --> 00:01:42.340
of the issues that we have, okay?

37
00:01:42.340 --> 00:01:45.010
So the bottom-up approach for us, okay?

38
00:01:45.010 --> 00:01:48.770
If we were to talk about trying
to do this at the physical layer.

39
00:01:48.770 --> 00:01:52.310
This would kind of lead us to back to
what we were saying a little bit earlier,

40
00:01:52.310 --> 00:01:54.370
are we checking cables at this point?

41
00:01:54.370 --> 00:01:58.070
Are we checking the actual
lights on the NIC?

42
00:01:58.070 --> 00:02:02.290
Verifying that everything is good, or even
on the router or whatever it might be,

43
00:02:02.290 --> 00:02:03.800
whatever device that we're on,

44
00:02:03.800 --> 00:02:06.740
we're just trying to verify that
those connections are good.

45
00:02:06.740 --> 00:02:08.990
That's always a great place to begin.

46
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:12.080
And since I told you where I normally
begin when users start telling me

47
00:02:12.080 --> 00:02:16.380
the issues, I always start with the
physical layer as much as possible, and

48
00:02:16.380 --> 00:02:18.420
try and troubleshoot at that point.

49
00:02:18.420 --> 00:02:22.020
If I determine that it's more than one
individual that's facing that issue and

50
00:02:22.020 --> 00:02:24.890
here we're given the scenario that
it's all users that are complaining

51
00:02:24.890 --> 00:02:26.670
that they can't get to the Internet.

52
00:02:26.670 --> 00:02:31.470
Well then, I have to actually start to try
and find out, what is common between all

53
00:02:31.470 --> 00:02:35.690
those users that we might think about
here and we might begin to troubleshoot?

54
00:02:35.690 --> 00:02:39.000
So I know that maybe the physical
layer is probably not gonna be

55
00:02:39.000 --> 00:02:40.140
the issue at this point.

56
00:02:40.140 --> 00:02:43.230
They can get access to intranet sites.

57
00:02:43.230 --> 00:02:46.720
But now it's also, essentially,
the Internet, right?

58
00:02:46.720 --> 00:02:51.180
So for us, we really know that
that's not gonna be layer one.

59
00:02:51.180 --> 00:02:53.570
It's not gonna be layer two,
internally, right?

60
00:02:53.570 --> 00:02:55.960
If we start having issues getting access,

61
00:02:55.960 --> 00:02:59.020
we know that most of the devices
communicate using MAC addresses.

62
00:02:59.020 --> 00:03:03.360
So that's layer two,
they're saying internal things, it works.

63
00:03:03.360 --> 00:03:06.296
But now we're starting to deal with
layer three issues, once again,

64
00:03:06.296 --> 00:03:07.799
is where we begin to troubleshoot.

65
00:03:07.799 --> 00:03:10.759
Now, before we do that,
okay, let's start with

66
00:03:10.759 --> 00:03:15.422
that idea that we think that it's
something that's happening on the router.

67
00:03:15.422 --> 00:03:19.023
So how do we troubleshoot on the router,
okay, if we need to?

68
00:03:19.023 --> 00:03:20.873
Well, we know we can look at the lights,
but

69
00:03:20.873 --> 00:03:24.150
is there some place that gives us
a little bit more information?

70
00:03:24.150 --> 00:03:26.670
Yes there is, and
you do need to know about it, so

71
00:03:26.670 --> 00:03:28.270
we'll show you that command right now.

72
00:03:28.270 --> 00:03:31.166
Okay, let's take a look at my
diagram before we get started here.

73
00:03:31.166 --> 00:03:38.784
I've added in an IP address on NYEDGE
over here, okay, and this is 172.14.0.1.

74
00:03:38.784 --> 00:03:40.920
Now I say that, I've added it in.

75
00:03:40.920 --> 00:03:45.530
This has been preconfigured in the lab and
practice labs so I didn't add it in.

76
00:03:45.530 --> 00:03:48.020
They went ahead and
preconfigured it for us, and

77
00:03:48.020 --> 00:03:52.700
that's what's gonna be
representing our connection out to

78
00:03:52.700 --> 00:03:55.340
the Internet is what that
one's gonna be connecting to.

79
00:03:55.340 --> 00:03:57.400
So we're fine there.

80
00:03:57.400 --> 00:04:00.370
We still have essentially
the same topology here.

81
00:04:00.370 --> 00:04:03.180
So let's talk about this for
a moment, Daniel.

82
00:04:03.180 --> 00:04:07.220
I'm gonna troubleshoot from right here and
I wanna verify that all layer one and

83
00:04:07.220 --> 00:04:10.930
layer two issues are not
gonna be present at all.

84
00:04:10.930 --> 00:04:16.550
So let's switch over to, if I can
actually switch over, there we go.

85
00:04:16.550 --> 00:04:21.754
To my NYEDGE here, and
now, I didn't change it.

86
00:04:21.754 --> 00:04:23.290
No, that's actually changed and
that's correct.

87
00:04:25.318 --> 00:04:31.290
Here on NYEDGE, let's begin a little bit
of troubleshooting now that we're here.

88
00:04:31.290 --> 00:04:34.515
What I want to do is I know I
can get to the default gateway.

89
00:04:34.515 --> 00:04:39.800
We've already pinged that before
in our previous lab that we did.

90
00:04:39.800 --> 00:04:42.164
Now we're actually going ahead and

91
00:04:42.164 --> 00:04:46.745
now I want to get to the interface
that's connected to the Internet.

92
00:04:46.745 --> 00:04:50.312
What I wanna do is,
I wanna issue a show interface,

93
00:04:52.928 --> 00:04:57.868
Gigabit Ethernet 0/1.

94
00:04:57.868 --> 00:05:01.855
These particular types of show commands,
especially interface commands,

95
00:05:01.855 --> 00:05:06.280
they give you so much information,
and it's good, valuable information.

96
00:05:06.280 --> 00:05:09.621
Especially when you're
beginning to troubleshoot, and

97
00:05:09.621 --> 00:05:12.629
you need information to be
shown very quickly here.

98
00:05:12.629 --> 00:05:17.431
You can pretty much begin to troubleshoot
almost all the way through layer three

99
00:05:17.431 --> 00:05:18.369
all together.

100
00:05:18.369 --> 00:05:20.210
So let's show you what
we're talking about.

101
00:05:20.210 --> 00:05:24.480
Right away, Daniel, without me even
being in the same room as the router,

102
00:05:24.480 --> 00:05:28.352
I see this top line of
information right here, okay?

103
00:05:28.352 --> 00:05:30.970
And it's exactly like I
described to you right?

104
00:05:30.970 --> 00:05:32.670
It says it's up and up.

105
00:05:32.670 --> 00:05:35.150
Line protocol is up, the interface is up.

106
00:05:35.150 --> 00:05:37.910
This is the same as the link
light being on, and

107
00:05:37.910 --> 00:05:40.650
the activity light blinking on you're net.

108
00:05:40.650 --> 00:05:45.257
So, I get good confirmation,
at least at layer one at this point,

109
00:05:45.257 --> 00:05:47.497
everything looks good, okay?

110
00:05:47.497 --> 00:05:53.683
Layer two, well, it's reporting back to me
it's particular BIA, or burned in address.

111
00:05:53.683 --> 00:05:58.770
Now, I didn't spend any time talk
about the formatting of Mac addresses.

112
00:05:58.770 --> 00:06:02.162
In Cisco land, you may see them formatted
a little bit differently than what

113
00:06:02.162 --> 00:06:05.350
you're used to seeing if you come
from the desktop support arena.

114
00:06:05.350 --> 00:06:09.040
So normally what we see is two digits,
either a dash or

115
00:06:09.040 --> 00:06:12.650
a colon, and then two digits and
you go all the way down.

116
00:06:12.650 --> 00:06:15.185
Cisco, they like dividing it up into well,
here.

117
00:06:15.185 --> 00:06:18.876
Okay so each one of these is
actually a dot, and then of course,

118
00:06:18.876 --> 00:06:21.394
you have hexidecimal formats in between.

119
00:06:21.394 --> 00:06:26.009
And, once again, each section
represents 16 bits here, okay, so

120
00:06:26.009 --> 00:06:28.190
that is a 48 bit address.

121
00:06:28.190 --> 00:06:32.620
Notice the term BIA, which is the other
way that it was used to being know a lot

122
00:06:32.620 --> 00:06:34.260
of times, burned in address,

123
00:06:34.260 --> 00:06:38.520
that's still there from the very beginning
when bridges were coming around.

124
00:06:38.520 --> 00:06:41.702
It's still reporting it in the same
manner and fashion as well.

125
00:06:41.702 --> 00:06:45.150
Notic, Daniel,
I also have the layer three information.

126
00:06:45.150 --> 00:06:47.510
Now, it's fairly simple, right?

127
00:06:47.510 --> 00:06:50.000
What if I don't have
this configured correctly

128
00:06:50.000 --> 00:06:52.590
the way that my ISP said
that I should configure?

129
00:06:52.590 --> 00:06:55.770
Well, that might be something I
need to troubleshoot at that point.

130
00:06:55.770 --> 00:06:59.827
So if I'm not sure, what if the ISP said,
you have to have it in this range, and

131
00:06:59.827 --> 00:07:01.404
that's not the actual range.

132
00:07:01.404 --> 00:07:05.134
That might be something for
me to consider when I start taking a look.

133
00:07:05.134 --> 00:07:08.463
But right here it's just what,
layer one, layer two, and

134
00:07:08.463 --> 00:07:11.720
layer three information
all from one command.

135
00:07:11.720 --> 00:07:14.720
And this is a quick way to
verify all of it very quickly if

136
00:07:14.720 --> 00:07:16.560
everything is actually good.

137
00:07:16.560 --> 00:07:18.822
Now from that particular point though.

138
00:07:18.822 --> 00:07:23.286
Once we start seeing it,
we also have to see some other things that

139
00:07:23.286 --> 00:07:28.169
are also layer two issues that can
help us, too, and layer one issues.

140
00:07:28.169 --> 00:07:31.330
So let's take a look at this line here.

141
00:07:31.330 --> 00:07:33.990
Notice I also get more
layer one information.

142
00:07:33.990 --> 00:07:40.500
Media type, RJ-45 is a connector,

Let me see if I can spell

00:21:56.789 --> 00:21:59.970
All right, so Daniel,

The difference between this is the top

00:22:19.658 --> 00:22:21.294

00:22:21.294 --> 00:22:26.096
>> So this leads me to that conclusion

So we started off by just

layer three, and

It just says it was refused, so at this

00:22:52.915 --> 00:22:56.135
So what do I need to do if I want

00:22:56.135 --> 00:22:58.035

Now we want to, inside of NYWAN1 here,

Now if you're doing this for

00:23:33.630 --> 00:23:37.420
Now this is kind of the neat thing here,

Doing it with HTTP secure server

Where it goes out and

you with a standard 1,024 bit key that's

Now let's also show you

Even though it's currently enabled,

here's the name of it

00:24:14.890 --> 00:24:20.750
Configuration has been modified, issue

By default, a router comes with its

The problem is it's usually the same

00:24:29.298 --> 00:24:30.350

So always, if you're going to do this,
issue yourself a new certificate.

00:24:33.960 --> 00:24:37.110
And then, you go ahead and
issue the right memory.

415
00:24:37.110 --> 00:24:41.116
I'm going to do the shortcut,
which is do write.

416
00:24:41.116 --> 00:24:44.400
Now, I'm here.

417
00:24:44.400 --> 00:24:47.970
And let it go ahead and
save that certificate as we actually put

00:24:47.970 --> 00:24:51.040
an issue to it to be able to
use in the way that we want to.

419
00:24:52.140 --> 00:24:55.245
So that's actually gonna

00:24:55.245 --> 00:24:57.780
All right, now,

Now that I know that

Is what we're actually

that's always the key at the very end.

435

So if we were that junior administrator

>> Who cares?

00:26:30.460 --> 00:26:32.660
So this means that we

00:26:32.660 --> 00:26:34.830

Nobody else can verify that except for

Now I have an option right do I want

I'm going to select continue

Meaning that we can now connect in and

00:26:52.440 --> 00:26:55.860

00:26:55.860 --> 00:26:57.250
Now at this point, right?

You're able to see some

This, by far is one of

00:27:08.800 --> 00:27:10.690
The only way for

Trait, and make sure that you implement

But Daniel that's actually for us here,

I explained to you what

00:27:55.850 --> 00:27:57.370

478

We are now done with that, and that means

00:28:00.590 --> 00:28:02.420

Well, Ronnie, we shot some trouble, and

00:28:06.770 --> 00:28:08.090
Thank you so much Ronnie for dropping by,

That being said,

00:28:21.220 --> 00:28:24.080
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

00:28:24.080 --> 00:28:24.690

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at the component parts of a cisco switch.  They show the ports and identification of them.  Also, the team looks at the internal components showing that there are no real upgradable parts.
episodes.title: Interact with Cisco Devices

00:27:35.617 --> 00:27:39.979
>> Yep.

551
00:27:39.979 --> 00:27:41.504
>> Not normally, but on the outer cover,

552
00:27:41.504 --> 00:27:42.250
you'd have that.

553
00:27:42.250 --> 00:27:44.610
But then on the back side here,

554
00:27:44.610 --> 00:27:46.406
I have a power plug.
>> Yep.

555
00:27:46.406 --> 00:27:47.212
>> Okay.

556
00:27:47.212 --> 00:27:52.080
I have a port for a redundant power
supply or a remote power supply.

557
00:27:52.080 --> 00:27:53.130
Have a console port.

558
00:27:54.250 --> 00:27:59.490
There's something that
might kind of be missing.

559
00:27:59.490 --> 00:28:02.140
What do you think might be missing here?
>> Well, one might be wondering where

560
00:28:02.140 --> 00:28:04.742
the heck the power button is.
>> That's exactly right.

561
00:28:04.742 --> 00:28:06.430
So yeah, all the sudden, you're like,

562
00:28:06.430 --> 00:28:08.570
hey wait a minute,
how do we turn these things off?

563
00:28:09.620 --> 00:28:11.740
You just unplug the power.
>> Yeah.

564
00:28:11.740 --> 00:28:12.410
>> When you turn them off,

565
00:28:12.410 --> 00:28:14.210
you plug it back in.

566
00:28:14.210 --> 00:28:18.910
That is pretty much it when it comes
down to the hardware on a CISCO switch.

567
00:28:18.910 --> 00:28:21.780
There is no external on, off button.

568
00:28:21.780 --> 00:28:25.693
So if you need to reset one you kind
of unplug it, wait a few seconds.

569
00:28:25.693 --> 00:28:28.819
I usually count to 10 or
15, heck, even 30.

570
00:28:28.819 --> 00:28:30.634
Or go and get a cup of coffee and
plug it back in, but

571
00:28:30.634 --> 00:28:33.540
it depends on what you need.
>> I make a poor man's power button called

572
00:28:33.540 --> 00:28:35.147
a power strip and
it has a button on there.

573
00:28:35.147 --> 00:28:37.423
[LAUGH]
>> And you turn it off, yeah.

574
00:28:37.423 --> 00:28:39.300
That's what you end up doing, right?

575
00:28:39.300 --> 00:28:41.162
So that's exactly what happens here.

576
00:28:41.162 --> 00:28:42.681
So there's no power.

577
00:28:42.681 --> 00:28:45.836
Once you turn it on, it is on, okay?

578
00:28:45.836 --> 00:28:47.573
And that's pretty much it, okay?

579
00:28:47.573 --> 00:28:51.683
So the other thing that also is kind of
neat about the way that switches work or

580
00:28:51.683 --> 00:28:54.845
maybe not so
neat depending on your perspective, right?

581
00:28:54.845 --> 00:29:01.160
Is it means that every single port by
default when you turn it on is on, okay.

582
00:29:01.160 --> 00:29:05.660
So this means that as soon as you plug
it in and once the power cycles idle

583
00:29:05.660 --> 00:29:09.130
down like you expect, just like your
computer once you get it ready to go.

584
00:29:09.130 --> 00:29:10.940
You plug in a network cable and

585
00:29:10.940 --> 00:29:14.630
there's a device on the other end that
goes, sure let's network, lets do it.

586
00:29:14.630 --> 00:29:17.180
So there's nothing that
stops it from doing that.

587
00:29:17.180 --> 00:29:20.430
From a security standpoint,
that may be a bad thing as well.

588
00:29:20.430 --> 00:29:23.390
So we'll talk about some of that as we go
through some of the other configuration

589
00:29:23.390 --> 00:29:24.700
that we have to do.

590
00:29:24.700 --> 00:29:27.170
But overall, Daniel when we
start talking about a switch,

591
00:29:27.170 --> 00:29:30.990
we're at least taking a look and
seeing just kind of the basic nature, so

592
00:29:30.990 --> 00:29:34.620
we've taken a look at the hardware inside
as well as discussed the outside here.

593
00:29:34.620 --> 00:29:37.480
And these are usually the components
that we'll have to handle.

594
00:29:37.480 --> 00:29:38.230
So at least one down.

595
00:29:38.230 --> 00:29:41.710
But we still have to talk about something
like the ASA just briefly we're not gonna

596
00:29:41.710 --> 00:29:43.220
spend a lot of time in there.

597
00:29:43.220 --> 00:29:45.760
But we're also gonna take
a look at a router and

598
00:29:45.760 --> 00:29:48.890
see some of the different ways
that we can configure a router.

599
00:29:48.890 --> 00:29:49.890
Sometimes you can open them up,

600
00:29:49.890 --> 00:29:53.540
sometimes you can't, unless we show you
a big one is what I'm gonna show you.

601
00:29:53.540 --> 00:29:57.680
So, Daniel that's enough for at least this
particular episode, but we still have

602
00:29:57.680 --> 00:29:59.620
a couple hardware devices to get.
>> All right.

603
00:29:59.620 --> 00:30:01.580
Well, it's always cool to
get our hands dirty and

604
00:30:01.580 --> 00:30:05.500
actually handle some of the hardware
that we're so used to hearing about, but

605
00:30:05.500 --> 00:30:08.430
maybe have never seen or
have the privy to be around.

606
00:30:08.430 --> 00:30:10.070
And now we get a little
more familiar with it so

607
00:30:10.070 --> 00:30:11.900
we can understand,
I know what the ports look like.

608
00:30:11.900 --> 00:30:13.030
I know there's lights on it.

609
00:30:13.030 --> 00:30:17.640
I know some of the ideas that
go into the design of the case,

610
00:30:17.640 --> 00:30:19.820
like the yellow rings that
Ronnie was talking about.

611
00:30:19.820 --> 00:30:22.880
That's gonna help you actually start
to design networks and whether or not

612
00:30:22.880 --> 00:30:26.830
a piece of equipment is gonna be right for
that network when you do that designation.

613
00:30:26.830 --> 00:30:28.130
Ronnie, thank you so much for joining us.

614
00:30:28.130 --> 00:30:30.390
We look forward to seeing
you in the next episode, so

615
00:30:30.390 --> 00:30:32.620
we continue this walk down hardware lane.

616
00:30:32.620 --> 00:30:35.450
But as you've said, we're out of time for
this one, so we're gonna call it a day.

617
00:30:35.450 --> 00:30:38.160
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

618
00:30:38.160 --> 00:30:38.836
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

619
00:30:38.836 --> 00:30:40.823
>> And we'll see you next time.

620
00:30:40.823 --> 00:30:46.997
[MUSIC]

621
00:30:46.997 --> 00:30:50.217
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the physical components of a Cisco ASA 5505 and Cisco 3845 router.  They discuss the physical presentation of the device, power supply and possible modifications to add additional functionality.
episodes.title: Interact with Cisco Devices Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:04.958
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.958 --> 00:00:06.539
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.539 --> 00:00:07.489
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.489 --> 00:00:10.610
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.150 --> 00:00:13.460
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.460 --> 00:00:15.690
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.690 --> 00:00:17.821
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

8
00:00:17.821 --> 00:00:21.721
in today's episode we continue
with more on our CCEMT series.

9
00:00:21.721 --> 00:00:24.509
And of course joining us back in the
studio, yet again, lending his expertise,

10
00:00:24.509 --> 00:00:26.080
our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:26.080 --> 00:00:27.560
Ronnie, welcome back man, how's it going?

12
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:30.770
>> It's going great, Daniel,
thank you for having me back on the show.

13
00:00:30.770 --> 00:00:34.300
As we continue to interact with
some of the Cisco devices, and

14
00:00:34.300 --> 00:00:38.300
we're kind of, I kind of changed
the order of a few things here.

15
00:00:38.300 --> 00:00:41.000
Remember to add the CCENT
level as you get hired.

16
00:00:41.000 --> 00:00:45.360
You're more than likely to encounter
switches, routers and ASAs.

17
00:00:45.360 --> 00:00:48.840
And today, we're gonna take
a look at ASAs and routers so

18
00:00:48.840 --> 00:00:54.400
that we can finish out the trio of
devices that we're more than likely see.

19
00:00:54.400 --> 00:00:55.680
Now, is that all that there is?

20
00:00:55.680 --> 00:00:58.090
No, there's plenty of other devices,
but at least for

21
00:00:58.090 --> 00:00:59.920
us these are meat and potatoes.

22
00:00:59.920 --> 00:01:04.260
These are the basic devices that we
are more than likely to encounter.

23
00:01:04.260 --> 00:01:08.110
And we are now going to take a look
at the idea of the Cisco ASA.

24
00:01:09.140 --> 00:01:12.360
So in our last episode when we
talked about the switch and

25
00:01:12.360 --> 00:01:14.390
we took a look at that,
we're doing the same thing.

26
00:01:14.390 --> 00:01:16.339
We're going to look at everything but
the inside.

27
00:01:16.339 --> 00:01:21.850
The inside is actually plainer than
what we saw inside of the switch.

28
00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:24.770
It really is a small circuit board, and
the only thing that's really different is

29
00:01:24.770 --> 00:01:28.520
that some of them you
can upgrade the RAM to.

30
00:01:28.520 --> 00:01:33.780
But even then, it can be a relatively
expensive venture to upgrade the RAM.

31
00:01:33.780 --> 00:01:37.200
Because of the way that Cisco
has designed their boards and

32
00:01:37.200 --> 00:01:40.710
everything else, it likes some RAM sticks,
and some of them it doesn't.

33
00:01:40.710 --> 00:01:45.400
So it can be an expensive venture if you
don't know exactly what brand to get, and

34
00:01:45.400 --> 00:01:46.940
exactly how that works.

35
00:01:46.940 --> 00:01:48.610
So let's go ahead and
jump right into it, and

36
00:01:48.610 --> 00:01:53.480
on my desk here as we start to do this
we have what we call a Cisco ASA.

37
00:01:53.480 --> 00:01:58.300
Now most of the Cisco ASAs today have, I
don't want to say gone by the way side but

38
00:01:58.300 --> 00:02:01.800
they've been replaced with something
that has more features, okay?

39
00:02:01.800 --> 00:02:07.190
More feature rich here,
which is going to be the Cisco firepower.

40
00:02:07.190 --> 00:02:11.470
So instead, on this one,
let's start off with the very front and

41
00:02:11.470 --> 00:02:16.240
what we end up seeing here
which is pretty simple by far.

42
00:02:16.240 --> 00:02:20.509
So here is, of course, the front cover and
you see the model of this device,

43
00:02:20.509 --> 00:02:22.330
the Cisco ASA 5505 series.

44
00:02:22.330 --> 00:02:24.518
This is their smallest model and

45
00:02:24.518 --> 00:02:28.490
this is great inside of
things like branch offices.

46
00:02:28.490 --> 00:02:32.180
And you're likely to see
something like this as well, okay?

47
00:02:32.180 --> 00:02:35.776
So a lot of times in small branch
offices here this is the device.

48
00:02:35.776 --> 00:02:39.323
Or somebody that's actually
got a home environment and

49
00:02:39.323 --> 00:02:44.164
you need to make sure that you have
a secure VPN that's always up in between.

50
00:02:44.164 --> 00:02:47.000
This is the rock solid device to go with.

51
00:02:47.000 --> 00:02:52.630
But today you'll actually see the ones
that they call 5506 come out,

52
00:02:52.630 --> 00:02:55.980
or 550 something, or 5515.

53
00:02:55.980 --> 00:02:58.443
When you start seeing those
with the letter X and stuff,

54
00:02:58.443 --> 00:03:01.880
they are more advanced features,
so you'll see that.

55
00:03:01.880 --> 00:03:05.244
But this series,
the 5505 is the smallest, and

56
00:03:05.244 --> 00:03:09.536
there is a 5510, a 20 and
I think there's a 40 after that.

57
00:03:09.536 --> 00:03:14.179
And then there's an 80 which is enterprise
that's as big as a regular switch and

58
00:03:14.179 --> 00:03:18.370
those things get incredible
expensive as you go through.

59
00:03:18.370 --> 00:03:23.160
Now with this one, this is kind
of limited in what you see here.

60
00:03:23.160 --> 00:03:26.580
So notice that actually does tell us.

61
00:03:26.580 --> 00:03:30.570
I don't know, Aubrey, if we can
zoom in on that a little bit more.

62
00:03:30.570 --> 00:03:33.615
I'll try to move my hand so
it can focus and what needs to.

63
00:03:33.615 --> 00:03:39.270
Cuz it's hard for me to point it out on
the bottom where you see the yellow there,

64
00:03:39.270 --> 00:03:42.820
that actually says 100 megabit.

65
00:03:42.820 --> 00:03:45.350
So this particular switch here,

66
00:03:45.350 --> 00:03:50.060
and the port's on the back,
all 100 megabit switches.

67
00:03:50.060 --> 00:03:52.680
As you start getting more advanced
features you'll see of course gigabit

68
00:03:52.680 --> 00:03:54.870
ports is what you're likely to see.

69
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:58.010
And then you have your link and
activity light as well.

70
00:03:58.010 --> 00:03:59.170
You plug a device in,

71
00:03:59.170 --> 00:04:03.290
it automatically shows you the link which
means it does recognize the device.

72
00:04:03.290 --> 00:04:06.157
The top one, or I can't remember,
usually the top one there,

73
00:04:06.157 --> 00:04:09.585
if it blinks it tends to actually show
you that there's activity going on.

74
00:04:09.585 --> 00:04:13.712
In other words you are sending, you of
course also have power and status, and

75
00:04:13.712 --> 00:04:15.248
whether or not you have VPN.

76
00:04:15.248 --> 00:04:17.976
And then of course some other
things that you have up here,

77
00:04:17.976 --> 00:04:19.430
that's pretty much about it.

78
00:04:20.450 --> 00:04:25.580
Now there is a strange port over on
the lower left-hand corner of this device

79
00:04:25.580 --> 00:04:27.630
which is a USB Port.

80
00:04:27.630 --> 00:04:30.030
And notice they've actually
labeled it as zero.

81
00:04:30.030 --> 00:04:33.620
In theory this can be a USB
management port over here,

82
00:04:33.620 --> 00:04:35.860
I've never seen anybody use it okay?

83
00:04:35.860 --> 00:04:40.200
So this is kinda the device that you again
will end up putting up as your firewall

84
00:04:40.200 --> 00:04:41.400
as what you'll see.

85
00:04:41.400 --> 00:04:45.700
It's not exactly rack-mounted,
it's actually meant to actually sit

86
00:04:45.700 --> 00:04:48.770
on a device and you see where
they planted these feet on here.

87
00:04:48.770 --> 00:04:50.970
And you're probably wondering like,
wow, shameless advertising.

88
00:04:50.970 --> 00:04:54.514
Well, to a point hey, but
the serial number's right behind here.

89
00:04:54.514 --> 00:04:59.447
And Daniel, I wanted to make sure that
I covered that up right now in the lan

90
00:04:59.447 --> 00:05:03.110
that Cisco has of the recording of this,
right?

91
00:05:03.110 --> 00:05:05.442
They found some vulnerabilities
with the original VPN, right?

92
00:05:05.442 --> 00:05:07.050
>> That's right.

93
00:05:07.050 --> 00:05:09.540
>> So one of the ways that
you can fix that is that

94
00:05:09.540 --> 00:05:13.240
if you don't have a current
service contract with Cisco.

95
00:05:13.240 --> 00:05:16.609
Is that all you have to do is call them
and you say, hey I read about this and

96
00:05:16.609 --> 00:05:18.940
this link,
you could them the link of the router.

97
00:05:18.940 --> 00:05:25.940
And then you can give them serial number
so in theory I'm trying to obscure this.

98
00:05:25.940 --> 00:05:27.910
>> Yes.
>> Because we still need to do it to this

99
00:05:27.910 --> 00:05:29.040
device right here.

100
00:05:29.040 --> 00:05:32.096
So yeah, I don't want somebody
to get this and go and

101
00:05:32.096 --> 00:05:36.650
use his serial number no somebody's
already called that and I'm done.

102
00:05:36.650 --> 00:05:39.510
So we've obscured where serial number is.

103
00:05:39.510 --> 00:05:43.230
But there's nothing really on the bottom
side of this that we have to worry about.

104
00:05:43.230 --> 00:05:44.430
Can you get a rack mount of this?

105
00:05:44.430 --> 00:05:49.350
Yes, they do sell n extra rack mount
which has panels on both sides.

106
00:05:49.350 --> 00:05:52.930
It's just the metal shelf is what it
allows you to do and it just sits there.

107
00:05:52.930 --> 00:05:55.780
It allows you to unscrew something here.

108
00:05:55.780 --> 00:05:58.870
I don't exactly remember where that actual
allows you to mount it directly on to that

109
00:05:58.870 --> 00:06:00.370
part, okay?

110
00:06:00.370 --> 00:06:03.540
So then the other part of this, okay?

111
00:06:03.540 --> 00:06:05.850
Depending on how much money
you're willing to spend,

112
00:06:05.850 --> 00:06:09.240
this is that security services card slot.

113
00:06:09.240 --> 00:06:13.230
And on the front where I
kind of went over that SSC,

114
00:06:13.230 --> 00:06:17.440
if you have one of those, that's where
you'll actually be plugging that thing in.

115
00:06:17.440 --> 00:06:23.550
That expands the capabilities of your
ASA is this particular slot here.

116
00:06:23.550 --> 00:06:26.240
Now, when you start adding
in module like this,

117
00:06:26.240 --> 00:06:30.660
this already by itself was
an expensive device, okay?

118
00:06:30.660 --> 00:06:31.860
By itself, but

119
00:06:31.860 --> 00:06:36.550
when you start adding that in that makes
it a really, really expensive device.

120
00:06:36.550 --> 00:06:40.065
These types of add-in modules that
are hardware set and everything else,

121
00:06:40.065 --> 00:06:41.811
especially for security features.

122
00:06:41.811 --> 00:06:46.690
And what it does, it nearly doubles
the price of some of these things.

123
00:06:46.690 --> 00:06:50.837
So, yeah, you don't tend to see a lot of
them, but you know, if you do have that,

124
00:06:50.837 --> 00:06:53.325
that's a very fancy ASA,
too, though, okay?

125
00:06:53.325 --> 00:06:57.044
You'll also end up seeing
that here's these ports.

126
00:06:57.044 --> 00:07:00.961
They're labeled from zero which,
unusually from the right hand side,

127
00:07:00.961 --> 00:07:03.550
all the way through port number seven.

128
00:07:03.550 --> 00:07:06.550
So zero through seven,
that gives you eight different ports.

129
00:07:06.550 --> 00:07:10.092
And you can use them in whatever
configuration that you want to, okay?

130
00:07:10.092 --> 00:07:11.901
But normally on these right?

131
00:07:11.901 --> 00:07:14.460
You actually have where
one side is actually,

132
00:07:14.460 --> 00:07:17.850
gonna be of course representing
the untrusted side of your network.

133
00:07:17.850 --> 00:07:22.720
And then the other ports are representing
whatever you want to DMZ,

134
00:07:22.720 --> 00:07:24.820
your own LAN, whatever you want to do.

135
00:07:24.820 --> 00:07:29.108
So, when you actually start configuring
it, you normally start with the first

136
00:07:29.108 --> 00:07:31.994
inside port,
which is usually this port number one.

137
00:07:31.994 --> 00:07:34.980
And not this one,
which might represent your outside.

138
00:07:34.980 --> 00:07:38.020
Sometimes they change these
around by default, and

139
00:07:38.020 --> 00:07:39.670
you have to look at the actual

140
00:07:40.980 --> 00:07:45.160
console when you pull it up which one
they consider outside and inside first.

141
00:07:45.160 --> 00:07:48.930
But if I remember right,
this is your first outside port and

142
00:07:48.930 --> 00:07:50.410
then this is your first inside port.

143
00:07:50.410 --> 00:07:52.767
And you start using those from that point.

144
00:07:52.767 --> 00:07:55.742
These last two are special,
they have these little black bar and

145
00:07:55.742 --> 00:07:58.674
we can't zoom in enough so
that you can read what that one says.

146
00:07:58.674 --> 00:08:01.266
But that one says power over ethernet.

147
00:08:01.266 --> 00:08:04.912
Okay, so these two ports have POE in them.

148
00:08:04.912 --> 00:08:07.611
So if you do have a device
that will support POE,

149
00:08:07.611 --> 00:08:11.840
you plug in those two devices, and
then you're up and ready to go.

150
00:08:11.840 --> 00:08:16.980
And I did this with an actual
outside wireless access point for

151
00:08:16.980 --> 00:08:19.420
a customer as well, okay?

152
00:08:19.420 --> 00:08:25.430
So they had a Cisco lightweight access

Card and then of course,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie introduce the basic switching functions. The review basic fundamental concepts of broadcast domains and collision domains.  They also describe the basic difference betweena hub and a switch.

course getting prepared or taking that

And today we're beginning a new topic.

We've been on networking fundamentals for

quite a bit of time, we've been

this is actually the part where we finally

20

You need to actually understand not only

00:01:00.220 --> 00:01:05.110
the network fundamentals,
as far as the physical switch itself but

22

now also, of course the configuration side

23

So we need to have a solid foundation

because that's the way that when we

if you don't have the fundamentals down,

you won't be able to understand
why it's operating the way it is.

27
00:01:22.290 --> 00:01:24.220
So that's what we're going
to start off with today.

28
00:01:24.220 --> 00:01:26.710
So we're gonna take a look at
different switching concepts,

29
00:01:26.710 --> 00:01:28.920
make sure that we get started correctly.

30
00:01:28.920 --> 00:01:32.240
All right, so Daniel, let's start off
with understanding the way that you and

31
00:01:32.240 --> 00:01:33.650
I started here.
>> Okay.

32
00:01:33.650 --> 00:01:35.160
>> And which is not really with switching.

33
00:01:35.160 --> 00:01:35.920
Okay?
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

34
00:01:35.920 --> 00:01:36.990
>> When it came down to it,

35
00:01:36.990 --> 00:01:41.600
when we first started connecting devices
together, multiple devices together,

36
00:01:41.600 --> 00:01:44.120
we probably came along in the day and
ages of what we call hubs.

37
00:01:44.120 --> 00:01:45.000
>> Yes we did and

38
00:01:45.000 --> 00:01:46.860
that was the de facto standard man.

39
00:01:46.860 --> 00:01:49.475
Every room had a hub up in it and
that's how everything connected and

40
00:01:49.475 --> 00:01:51.835
it was easy, it was nice, splits.

41
00:01:51.835 --> 00:01:55.615
There were some downfalls to that and as
things got faster we had to move away from

42
00:01:55.615 --> 00:01:56.175
it, right?
>> Right, yeah.

43
00:01:56.175 --> 00:01:59.145
So when you started that she started
looking at the idea of the hub

44
00:01:59.145 --> 00:02:00.465
and what it did.

45
00:02:00.465 --> 00:02:03.355
It was really just a point
of connectivity device.

46
00:02:03.355 --> 00:02:07.635
Everybody connected in but it was like
us still not really getting away from

47
00:02:07.635 --> 00:02:10.810
the old way of doing it which was just
running a single wire down the hall and

48
00:02:10.810 --> 00:02:12.350
tapping in that wire.

49
00:02:12.350 --> 00:02:15.620
When you started doing stuff like that,
that's when you started having more and

50
00:02:15.620 --> 00:02:16.850
more collisions.

51
00:02:16.850 --> 00:02:21.710
The hub allowed us to hardwire it in
to a central hardwire device now.

52
00:02:21.710 --> 00:02:26.570
And then it could actually say, look,
we're reducing the overall length and

53
00:02:26.570 --> 00:02:28.600
distance that we had to go.

54
00:02:28.600 --> 00:02:32.380
And the reason why that was important is
because the longer that old kind of that

55
00:02:32.380 --> 00:02:34.200
cable went, right?

56
00:02:34.200 --> 00:02:37.210
If you took a regular cable and
you ran it down the hallway,

57
00:02:37.210 --> 00:02:40.540
the longer that got,
the slower the network became, okay?

58
00:02:40.540 --> 00:02:42.590
So now, a hub would reduce that limit and

59
00:02:42.590 --> 00:02:45.360
then everybody was just tied into
one central connectivity device.

60
00:02:45.360 --> 00:02:48.150
The problem though,
is you still experienced collisions.

61
00:02:48.150 --> 00:02:50.760
You still had a single broadcast domain,

62
00:02:50.760 --> 00:02:54.330
you still have what we call
a single collision domain, as well.

63
00:02:54.330 --> 00:02:56.830
So that's what we want to talk
about right at the beginning.

64
00:02:56.830 --> 00:02:59.030
So let's take a look at my machine here.

65
00:02:59.030 --> 00:03:02.230
And I've went ahead and
I've created a simple diagram for us, so

66
00:03:02.230 --> 00:03:06.315
that we can understand what the difference
is between the two of these and

67
00:03:06.315 --> 00:03:08.925
make sure that we have
a solid understanding, okay?

68
00:03:08.925 --> 00:03:12.475
So when we started connecting
devices together, okay?

69
00:03:12.475 --> 00:03:16.124
So I have here just a simple, in the old
days, we didn't call it, of course,

70
00:03:16.124 --> 00:03:17.035
like an ethernet.

71
00:03:17.035 --> 00:03:19.565
We called it a bus in the very beginning.

72
00:03:19.565 --> 00:03:21.185
That's what it was is a bus.

73
00:03:21.185 --> 00:03:23.815
An electrical bus,
essentially a wire, okay?

74
00:03:23.815 --> 00:03:30.140
When we tied devices together to
that one bus or that one wire.

75
00:03:30.140 --> 00:03:35.040
That meant any time that a single source
would want to transmit, let's say,

76
00:03:35.040 --> 00:03:37.070
to a single destination.

77
00:03:37.070 --> 00:03:39.760
Because everybody was
tied to a single wire,

78
00:03:39.760 --> 00:03:45.110
it meant every single device also ended
up getting that transmission as well.

79
00:03:45.110 --> 00:03:48.330
Now it doesn't mean that all those
other devices in which they weren't

80
00:03:48.330 --> 00:03:52.990
the destination of that packet or that
frame, that it was actually done that way,

81
00:03:52.990 --> 00:03:56.020
it means these other two
devices would simply ignore it.

82
00:03:56.020 --> 00:03:57.400
But they would still get it.

83
00:03:57.400 --> 00:03:58.900
So it still had to kinda go okay,

84
00:03:58.900 --> 00:04:02.840
I hear it, I don't wanna listen to it but
there it is, it's there.

85
00:04:02.840 --> 00:04:07.058
And finally the destination also
end up getting that device as well.

86
00:04:07.058 --> 00:04:09.610
But there did comment issue with this too,

87
00:04:09.610 --> 00:04:11.760
which we really didn't get
away from very easily.

88
00:04:11.760 --> 00:04:14.460
And to tell you the truth even today,
if we would still do this,

89
00:04:14.460 --> 00:04:16.210
we'd still have these problems here.

90
00:04:16.210 --> 00:04:18.850
Is that we ended up having
what we called collisions.

91
00:04:18.850 --> 00:04:21.340
When do collisions tend to happen?

92

a collision domain with only two devices.

326
00:15:21.332 --> 00:15:24.911
Or one device, right?
>> Yeah, when it comes down to a switch,

327
00:15:24.911 --> 00:15:28.076
but at the beginning we have
bridges that separate out into,

328
00:15:28.076 --> 00:15:30.652
well, let's say-
>> That’s where that separation you were

329
00:15:30.652 --> 00:15:33.492
talking about, like instead of doing 48,
what if I just did half that?

330
00:15:33.492 --> 00:15:36.602
And now I've reduced the amount of
collisions I can have per domain,

331
00:15:36.602 --> 00:15:39.217
even though more than one collision
can be happening on one platform.

332
00:15:39.217 --> 00:15:40.652
>> Yeah, all right, so

333
00:15:40.652 --> 00:15:43.920
now let's take a look at this diagram.

334
00:15:43.920 --> 00:15:48.636
And I brought this up specifically because
it is a diagram like something you

335
00:15:48.636 --> 00:15:51.192
might see on the exam here, okay?

336
00:15:51.192 --> 00:15:54.020
And usually,
when you actually see something like this,

337
00:15:54.020 --> 00:15:57.970
they are trying to get you to understand
what it is that you're looking at.

338
00:15:57.970 --> 00:16:03.210
So, if, Daniel, if I were to ask you,
okay, how many collision domains and

339
00:16:03.210 --> 00:16:07.630
how many broadcast domains are here, okay?

340
00:16:07.630 --> 00:16:10.200
Well, you wouldn't be able to
tell until I actually removed-

341
00:16:10.200 --> 00:16:11.180
>> The little bang.

342
00:16:11.180 --> 00:16:15.440
Okay and this is where you have to
pay attention sometimes to that

343
00:16:15.440 --> 00:16:18.200
wierd symbol.
>> Cisco has it's own little symbology

344
00:16:18.200 --> 00:16:19.010
thing going on there.

345
00:16:19.010 --> 00:16:21.520
It's a little crazy but if you don't get
initiated to it you're gonna get a hard

346
00:16:21.520 --> 00:16:25.050
time looking at their diagram.
>> Right, and so make sure you take a look

347
00:16:25.050 --> 00:16:29.585
like if you go online you'll see
there are official symbols for

348
00:16:29.585 --> 00:16:34.580
Cisco that they use for certain devices.

349
00:16:34.580 --> 00:16:37.810
Cuz the hub and a switch on the outside,
on a physical hub and

350
00:16:37.810 --> 00:16:41.840
switch, they look identical cuz
you won't know the difference.

351
00:16:41.840 --> 00:16:44.770
But in a diagram,
the way that they tend to draw a hub,

352
00:16:44.770 --> 00:16:49.840
you see a single two headed arrow is
what you normally end up seeing here.

353
00:16:49.840 --> 00:16:53.860
So it's very easy for
you to actually kind of look at this and

354
00:16:53.860 --> 00:16:57.920
go, that's just a switch,
that would actually be what of this?

355
00:16:57.920 --> 00:17:01.530
So, you might see where they might ask
you something like this on a diagram, and

356
00:17:01.530 --> 00:17:03.100
say explain the following.

357
00:17:03.100 --> 00:17:04.550
Is this a collision domain?

358
00:17:04.550 --> 00:17:06.420
Is this a broadcast domain?

359
00:17:06.420 --> 00:17:07.410
Is it a combination?

360
00:17:07.410 --> 00:17:08.950
Whatever it is here.

361
00:17:08.950 --> 00:17:11.944
Or they might just ask you
what this device actually is.

362
00:17:11.944 --> 00:17:16.810
Or which, something like this 192.168.101

363
00:17:16.810 --> 00:17:21.780
has the possibility of colliding
with which of the following devices?

364
00:17:21.780 --> 00:17:25.050
So you may also see something like this.

365
00:17:25.050 --> 00:17:26.457
So don't make mistake this,

366
00:17:26.457 --> 00:17:29.760
it's just [INAUDIBLE] just
showing us another diagram here.

367
00:17:29.760 --> 00:17:33.820
It's because there's actually a meaning
to the diagrams that they may show you,

368
00:17:33.820 --> 00:17:36.120
just trying to make you
encounter different things.

369
00:17:36.120 --> 00:17:40.130
So this is not exactly one,
because it's not.

370
00:17:40.130 --> 00:17:43.600
You get this idea that somehow
they're expecting you to know this.

371
00:17:43.600 --> 00:17:47.050
And the way that they expect you to know
this is by dealing with the conceptual

372
00:17:47.050 --> 00:17:51.150
knowledge between what a collision
domain is and what hubs do, and

373
00:17:51.150 --> 00:17:53.065
what switches will end up doing for us.

374
00:17:53.065 --> 00:17:55.920
Provided we've got a good
solid foundation now, and

375
00:17:55.920 --> 00:18:01.670
that means that we can actually move
on to the area and nature of switches.

376
00:18:01.670 --> 00:18:03.070
So in between hubs and

377
00:18:03.070 --> 00:18:07.470
switches, we actually did end up having
a device that we called a bridge.

378
00:18:07.470 --> 00:18:12.370
Now a bridge was like a switch in
the function and manner that it did.

379
00:18:12.370 --> 00:18:16.910
But it did it very slow by comparison to
the way that switches function today.

380
00:18:17.980 --> 00:18:20.170
And it was just kind of
the very basics here.

381
00:18:20.170 --> 00:18:24.090
It was like we need to reduce the number
of collisions that are happening and

382
00:18:24.090 --> 00:18:28.320
they figured out how to do that by
creating more collision domains instead.

383
00:18:28.320 --> 00:18:30.070
But now we'll move to
the realm of switches.

384
00:18:31.300 --> 00:18:36.580
Note now, Daniel,
the difference in the symbol here instead.

385
00:18:36.580 --> 00:18:40.890
It's actually two single headed arrows
pointing in a different direction.

386
00:18:40.890 --> 00:18:47.150
Now on this one, when you start
taking a look at what a switch does,

387
00:18:47.150 --> 00:18:52.480
unlike with the hub, as soon as a hub gets
the information in, it goes ahead and

388
00:18:52.480 --> 00:18:57.850
sends it out every other port but
the one it comes in on.

389
00:18:57.850 --> 00:19:00.850
Automatically and
simultaneously that's what it does.

390
00:19:00.850 --> 00:19:05.780
A switch though, the data that's
entering in that particular port,

391
00:19:05.780 --> 00:19:10.650
it will only go out to the port that’s
destined to go out, leave imports 2,

392
00:19:10.650 --> 00:19:14.600
4, and
5 alone is what we want to understand.

393
00:19:14.600 --> 00:19:19.660
So in this one, we don’t really have
a lot of times here, the idea of

394
00:19:19.660 --> 00:19:25.430
possibilities of collisions between
those other ports that are out there.

395
00:19:25.430 --> 00:19:27.930
We have a source,
which is going in port 1.

396
00:19:27.930 --> 00:19:31.660
We have a destination which
is coming out port number 3.

397
00:19:31.660 --> 00:19:33.645
And that's what a switch,

398
00:19:33.645 --> 00:19:38.488
at least in the physical manner
that handles it, does it this way.

399
00:19:38.488 --> 00:19:43.928
Now the other thing here that it does,
which is unlike the hub, is that it has

400
00:19:43.928 --> 00:19:50.560
to make a decision and how it knows to go
from port number one to port number three.

401
00:19:50.560 --> 00:19:54.130
A hub does not have any
logic inside of it.

402
00:19:54.130 --> 00:19:58.060
It is essentially just a device
that is hardwired that says,

403
00:19:58.060 --> 00:20:02.240
when something is gone into one part,
send it out every other part except for

404
00:20:02.240 --> 00:20:03.800
the one it came in on.

405
00:20:03.800 --> 00:20:08.160
Inside of the switch though, when you
send something into port number one,

406
00:20:08.160 --> 00:20:13.880
it has to make a decision on what port
it actually is supposed to go out of,

407
00:20:13.880 --> 00:20:17.330
before it sends the information
out of that port.

408
00:20:17.330 --> 00:20:21.300
So this particular device
is at least one step above.

409
00:20:21.300 --> 00:20:25.200
And not even a couple of steps above
the way that a hub would actually or

410
00:20:25.200 --> 00:20:28.580
a switch would end up functioning for
what we actually want it to do.

411
00:20:31.150 --> 00:20:35.950
So let's make sure that we understand
what a switch will do for us.

412
00:20:35.950 --> 00:20:40.662
Now here, Daniel, I've tried to reproduce
what we saw when took a look at

413
00:20:40.662 --> 00:20:44.241
the Cisco device interacting
with Cisco devices here.

414
00:20:44.241 --> 00:20:45.130
>> The physical devices.

415
00:20:45.130 --> 00:20:47.105
>> The physical devices itself.

416
00:20:47.105 --> 00:20:48.187
>> That's a lovely yellow border

417
00:20:48.187 --> 00:20:49.997
which you have reproduced.
>> Right and

418
00:20:49.997 --> 00:20:54.470
here I've created a 16-port switch for us.

419
00:20:54.470 --> 00:20:57.980
Remember that this yellow one
represents the idea that it's sharing

420
00:20:57.980 --> 00:21:01.100
a gigabit kind of back plane.

421
00:21:01.100 --> 00:21:04.380
Or the idea that they're sharing
one gig on all these ports.

422
00:21:04.380 --> 00:21:09.330
And this other one here is also sharing
a gig in the background as well.

423
00:21:09.330 --> 00:21:14.140
So this one when we start taking
look at what a switch does.

424
00:21:14.140 --> 00:21:18.500
A switch really does
three basic functions.

425
00:21:18.500 --> 00:21:23.060
When we start to kind of reduce
it down to a basic function.

426
00:21:23.060 --> 00:21:25.200
We're not talking about
how it does it yet.

427
00:21:25.200 --> 00:21:28.320
We're talking about it's
three basic functions here.

428
00:21:28.320 --> 00:21:31.030
So what are it's three basic functions?

429
00:21:31.030 --> 00:21:36.294
A switch will forward data
to its destination port.

430
00:21:36.294 --> 00:21:41.305
So if data comes into this initial port
it will automatically be able to make

431
00:21:41.305 --> 00:21:46.080
a decision based on some information
that we're about to talk about and

432
00:21:46.080 --> 00:21:49.750
forward it directly to
its destination port.

433
00:21:49.750 --> 00:21:51.680
So it has that ability to do so.

434
00:21:53.180 --> 00:21:57.470
The other thing that it can, and
it's not in any one particular order here.

435
00:21:57.470 --> 00:22:00.220
But forwarding is kind of
the main thing that it does.

436
00:22:00.220 --> 00:22:02.250
And that's why I had it forward.

437
00:22:02.250 --> 00:22:05.680
Flooding and filtering,
it just depends on what happens.

438
00:22:05.680 --> 00:22:07.620
Filtering data.

439
00:22:07.620 --> 00:22:13.290
The key is here is understanding
when data actually leaves a port.

440
00:22:13.290 --> 00:22:18.690
It can forward it to every other port,
except for the one that it came in on.

441
00:22:20.090 --> 00:22:27.140
So if we forward data and we sent it into
this port number one, and let's say for

442
00:22:27.140 --> 00:22:32.180
one reason or another the destination
of that is supposed to also come

443
00:22:32.180 --> 00:22:37.590
out of that port as well, well, the switch
says, I can send it out to any other port.

444
00:22:38.760 --> 00:22:41.900
I can't send it out the port
that it came in on.

445
00:22:41.900 --> 00:22:45.380
The switch says I can't send it back
to the port that it came in on, so

446
00:22:45.380 --> 00:22:47.840
instead it will also filter it too.

447
00:22:49.020 --> 00:22:53.660
There is another possibility here though,
which is flooding.

448
00:22:53.660 --> 00:22:57.740
Flooding is actually part of the way
the switch learns how to do what it needs

449
00:22:57.740 --> 00:23:00.870
to do, which is for
the data as well as filter the data.

450
00:23:00.870 --> 00:23:04.240
But it also helps us in a couple
of different ways as well.

451
00:23:05.260 --> 00:23:10.150
It helps us to learn what device
is also on what port as well.

452
00:23:10.150 --> 00:23:13.450
And it also helps us to address
something that we didn't talk about,

453
00:23:13.450 --> 00:23:15.670
which we'll have to talk
about a little bit later too.

454
00:23:15.670 --> 00:23:22.080
But here flooding means that if I send
data into this particular port itself.

455
00:23:23.880 --> 00:23:26.640
It can also act like a hub and

456
00:23:26.640 --> 00:23:31.370
send it out to every other port except for
the one the data came in on.

457
00:23:32.480 --> 00:23:36.697
So that is also a possibility
when we do that.

458
00:23:36.697 --> 00:23:39.460
Now when we actually do all that how does

459
00:23:39.460 --> 00:23:44.251
that make these three basic functional
decisions that it needs to?

460
00:23:44.251 --> 00:23:48.550
Well, I already emphasized this idea
of not sending data on the same port it

461
00:23:48.550 --> 00:23:49.740
came in on.

462
00:23:49.740 --> 00:23:54.740
But now notice it makes it based on
what we call the MAC Address Table.

463
00:23:54.740 --> 00:23:59.810
So inside of the switch, unlike a hub,
there's actually a table that's in there

464
00:23:59.810 --> 00:24:06.400
that begins to allow us to map or
to link that particular interface number

465
00:24:08.070 --> 00:24:14.400
to a MAC address of a device that
is connected to that switch.

466
00:24:15.450 --> 00:24:20.450
Now on the way that it begins to build
this data is what we also need to

467
00:24:20.450 --> 00:24:23.040
at least begin to take a look at here.

468
00:24:23.040 --> 00:24:28.100
So on making that decision, we need
to learn about how in the world does

469
00:24:28.100 --> 00:24:32.470
this particular switch begin to
populate that MAC address table.

470
00:24:32.470 --> 00:24:38.810
And how it actually uses it to be able
to Forward, Filter, and Flood Data.

471
00:24:38.810 --> 00:24:40.740
Now Daniel,
I just looked over at the clock

472
00:24:40.740 --> 00:24:42.180
here just briefly.
>> Hm.

473
00:24:42.180 --> 00:24:43.882
>> And if I get started, this is gonna

474
00:24:43.882 --> 00:24:46.330
actually be a very long, long episode.
>> [LAUGH]

475
00:24:46.330 --> 00:24:47.710
>> So, Daniel, this is actually a good

476
00:24:47.710 --> 00:24:50.100
point for us to go ahead and
make a break and

477
00:24:50.100 --> 00:24:55.780
then we'll start with this process of how
that MAC address table will be built and

478
00:24:55.780 --> 00:24:58.900
how it uses it to do its decision making.
>> Sounds awesome, Ronnie.

479
00:24:58.900 --> 00:25:03.370
Obviously, switching is a very vital and
important function of anybody's network,

480
00:25:03.370 --> 00:25:06.790
and understanding that for our exam
is also a vital important function.

481
00:25:06.790 --> 00:25:11.090
So we will allow you all the time
necessary to fully explain that to

482
00:25:11.090 --> 00:25:11.900
our viewing audience.

483
00:25:11.900 --> 00:25:14.700
So we thank you for dropping by,
we thank you good folks for joining us.

484
00:25:14.700 --> 00:25:17.360
Definitely come back for that part two,
learn a little more about switching.

485
00:25:17.360 --> 00:25:19.290
As for this episode,
signing off for ITPRO.TV,

486
00:25:19.290 --> 00:25:21.800
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

487
00:25:21.800 --> 00:25:23.560
>> We'll see you next time.

488
00:25:23.560 --> 00:25:29.516
[MUSIC]

489
00:25:29.516 --> 00:25:32.315
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie introduce the basic switching functions. Here they discuss the building of the mac address table.  They also review the concepts of the decision to flood, forward, or filter data moving through a switch and how the mac address table is populated.
episodes.title: Describe and Verify Switching Concepts Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.007
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.007 --> 00:00:02.625
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.625 --> 00:00:06.040
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.040 --> 00:00:07.969
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.969 --> 00:00:12.077
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:12.077 --> 00:00:14.061
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:14.061 --> 00:00:17.070
welcome back to another
great episode of ITPro.TV.

8
00:00:17.070 --> 00:00:18.607
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

9
00:00:18.607 --> 00:00:21.932
in today's episode, we're moving on,
moving forward and trying to make some

10
00:00:21.932 --> 00:00:24.727
headway into this lovely little
thing we've been calling CCENT.

11
00:00:24.727 --> 00:00:27.771
And joining us back in the studio to help
us with that is our good friend, Mr.

12
00:00:27.771 --> 00:00:28.360
Ronnie Wong.

13
00:00:28.360 --> 00:00:29.777
Ronnie, welcome back sir,
and how is it going?

14
00:00:29.777 --> 00:00:30.880
>> It's going well Daniel.

15
00:00:30.880 --> 00:00:32.732
Thank you agin for
having me back on the show.

16
00:00:32.732 --> 00:00:35.955
As we continue now of course
on our CCENT journey.

17
00:00:35.955 --> 00:00:39.651
Specifically learning more about
how switches functions and

18
00:00:39.651 --> 00:00:42.090
the way that they operate.

19
00:00:42.090 --> 00:00:46.793
So Daniel, we've already talked about
their three basic functionalities,

20
00:00:46.793 --> 00:00:51.367
their differences between, of course,
the idea here of a hub and a switch.

21
00:00:51.367 --> 00:00:55.337
So we've covered quite a bit of ground in
our initial episode trying to make sure

22
00:00:55.337 --> 00:00:58.300
that we lay the foundation
down that we need to.

23
00:00:58.300 --> 00:01:02.482
Now were really focusing in on how the
switch does the job that it needs to do

24
00:01:02.482 --> 00:01:05.180
and whether it's forwarding, filtering, or

25
00:01:05.180 --> 00:01:08.634
flooding the actual switch itself and
what needs to happen.

26
00:01:08.634 --> 00:01:10.184
Now at the same time,

27
00:01:10.184 --> 00:01:15.542
let's also remind you that what you'll
also end up seeing here, right?

28
00:01:15.542 --> 00:01:19.692
Is switches, they'll still be
one big broadcast domain, but

29
00:01:19.692 --> 00:01:24.548
in the end now, what ended saying where
the end up creating those multiple

30
00:01:24.548 --> 00:01:29.343
collision domains that will help us
to reduce the number of collisions.

31
00:01:29.343 --> 00:01:32.412
And that we tend to end up by
dealing with this well, okay?

32
00:01:32.412 --> 00:01:35.964
So we've really taken look at a lot of,
so let's go ahead and

33
00:01:35.964 --> 00:01:37.787
take a look on my screen again.

34
00:01:37.787 --> 00:01:42.189
And just the basic idea and foundation,
remember that this is what we do,

35
00:01:42.189 --> 00:01:45.100
we forward, filter, or flood data.

36
00:01:45.100 --> 00:01:47.508
A switch will always forward data, okay?

37
00:01:47.508 --> 00:01:52.177
Or send that data out of that port,
but it will not actually end up

38
00:01:52.177 --> 00:01:56.764
sending it back into that port,
the one that it also came in on.

39
00:01:56.764 --> 00:01:59.210
And this is what we left off with, right?

40
00:01:59.210 --> 00:02:03.132
It makes a decision based on
the MAC address table, okay?

41
00:02:03.132 --> 00:02:08.020
So a switch internally
has some logic to it.

42
00:02:08.020 --> 00:02:12.701
And it builds what it calls a MAC address
table that links up a MAC address of

43
00:02:12.701 --> 00:02:17.097
a device that's directly attached
to one of these interfaces here.

44
00:02:17.097 --> 00:02:21.650
And also of course,
to the port number that it's on.

45
00:02:21.650 --> 00:02:25.573
And the way that it does it,
is actually quite interesting here, okay?

46
00:02:25.573 --> 00:02:29.765
And there are some key terms that you
want to make sure that you remember,

47
00:02:29.765 --> 00:02:32.070
as you start to do this.

48
00:02:32.070 --> 00:02:34.530
When a switch first turns on, okay?

49
00:02:34.530 --> 00:02:38.084
And everything is ready to go,
you start plugging cables into it.

50
00:02:38.084 --> 00:02:42.450
And on the end of those cables,
are devices that are up and operating.

51
00:02:42.450 --> 00:02:46.821
When you plug those in, what ends up
happening on that one switch board and

52
00:02:46.821 --> 00:02:49.090
on every other switch board, right?

53
00:02:49.090 --> 00:02:53.420
Is that it will begin to try and
learn the MAC address.

54
00:02:53.420 --> 00:02:56.138
Now inside of a Ethernet frame though,
okay?

55
00:02:56.138 --> 00:02:58.720
There are usually two MAC addresses.

56
00:02:58.720 --> 00:03:00.357
One, of course is the source MAC address.

57
00:03:00.357 --> 00:03:03.646
Now I've simplified these MAC
addresses here for us, so

58
00:03:03.646 --> 00:03:06.240
that I'm not trying to actually-
>> [LAUGH]

59
00:03:06.240 --> 00:03:08.032
>> Remember the weird MAC addresses that

Okay, so now let's go back and let's

Okay, so Daniel, if I were to actually

Now, Daniel what if

port number five though-

Cuz we went over that concept that

Whoever sent this-

you know what you're talking about.

The very fact is you have two

The second one is technically

So, it could be where that device is

It thinks it's there it's not actually

now then Daniel brings his own machine

Now if he does that MEZ

They'll never actually be

And now that means Daniel

Pretty darn hefty.

And that's a one of those things that can

All right Daniel lets go to

And what if I send between,

What if the source if this one 100.106 and

00:19:34.280 --> 00:19:38.587
>> So it's trying to, it just trying to

It will just connect to the hub,

00:19:45.160 --> 00:19:47.220
>> Yeah.
>> Yes okay it will end up doing that but

00:19:47.220 --> 00:19:48.420
it won't connect to the switch.

00:19:48.420 --> 00:19:52.560

00:19:52.560 --> 00:19:53.430
>> Yep.
>> Out of everybody yeah.

yes the hub's default nature.

We'll hit the switch but remember

I came in on this port I can't

00:20:01.410 --> 00:20:02.320
>> Right.
So when it sees and

00:20:02.320 --> 00:20:06.190

So it says,
I'm not gonna send out anywhere.

00:20:08.880 --> 00:20:10.870
I'm just gonna filter it out.

372
00:20:10.870 --> 00:20:16.860
So it is a very real possibility that any

00:20:16.860 --> 00:20:20.870
are things that you're actually going to

00:20:20.870 --> 00:20:23.680

00:20:23.680 --> 00:20:27.790
So understanding the layout and

Daniel and I just showed you about three,

questions types that you might

And this is to get you to learn more

00:20:40.500 --> 00:20:41.260

Now Daniel added in an extra

So, now we have layer two as well as layer

three addressing that happens here too,

So, Daniel we have something like that.

There is a possibility specially when we

That what can happen is, I might

I don't know how to get it there okay?

And when something like that happens,

00:21:26.320 --> 00:21:28.530
So here Daniel,

So I know that this is going from one

When we do this even through a switch,

00:21:43.620 --> 00:21:46.680
So it is very possible Daniel,
in the upper left hand corner.

00:21:46.680 --> 00:21:50.660
I get a frame or

That has all the layer three information.

There's the source 172

I have the destination IP address,

How do I find the mac

00:22:15.800 --> 00:22:18.862
And the way that we do that is through

00:22:26.895 --> 00:22:27.985

00:22:28.945 --> 00:22:32.745
So this is why it's important because

00:22:32.745 --> 00:22:36.385
because you have to discover what

00:22:36.385 --> 00:22:41.170
So at this point when you do this,

00:22:41.170 --> 00:22:42.380

00:22:42.380 --> 00:22:47.010
So now Daniel,
if I send an ARP broadcast into a switch,

00:22:51.246 --> 00:22:54.144

00:22:54.144 --> 00:22:59.570

So now that means that the file

also this router interface

Well the file server says,

It says why don't you go head and

now PC one Can in theory,

00:23:41.608 --> 00:23:45.740
Put the map address.

00:23:47.160 --> 00:23:48.665
It's Qs not As.

00:23:48.665 --> 00:23:52.530
[LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK]

00:23:52.530 --> 00:23:53.510
>> Maybe.

00:23:53.510 --> 00:23:54.158
A.

00:23:54.158 --> 00:23:58.252
[LAUGH] So all as here.

00:23:58.252 --> 00:24:02.944
So when this works, right,
it will now send this on and

00:24:02.944 --> 00:24:07.690

00:24:07.690 --> 00:24:12.410
Now once it's on the router,

I've got this one down

So when it goes to the router,

The file server hears it,

And then, paste that right in there and

I thought that routers broke

00:25:08.630 --> 00:25:11.010

00:25:11.010 --> 00:25:11.910

00:25:14.465 --> 00:25:17.485
>> Well, it's not actually making it

00:25:17.485 --> 00:25:21.490

00:25:21.490 --> 00:25:23.490
>> Gotcha, so
the router is making the request.

00:25:23.490 --> 00:25:25.640
>> Right.

00:25:25.640 --> 00:25:27.220
not allowing broadcaster

00:25:34.183 --> 00:25:36.575

At each place along the way

that will actually change cuz it's

00:25:55.250 --> 00:26:00.310
So even that will change but

00:26:00.310 --> 00:26:04.530
So now when it replies back, it knows to

00:26:09.390 --> 00:26:13.120

00:26:13.120 --> 00:26:17.870
So, part of the ARP traffic that

Makes sure it gets fitted in there but

00:26:26.940 --> 00:26:31.668

00:27:03.580 --> 00:27:07.280

Now, Daniel, when we start to take

00:22:34.370 --> 00:22:36.920

394
00:22:36.920 --> 00:22:41.883
exercise here which is frame switching
methods and of course frame flooding.

395
00:22:41.883 --> 00:22:44.659
We wanna take a look at this idea too,
okay?

396
00:22:44.659 --> 00:22:49.061
When it comes down to frame switching
the exercise itself also subdivides

397
00:22:49.061 --> 00:22:53.090
something that I didn't talk
about during our time in theory.

398
00:22:53.090 --> 00:22:57.644
Which is that there's two different
methods to actually forwarding data as it

399
00:22:57.644 --> 00:22:59.852
comes through a switch board, okay?

400
00:22:59.852 --> 00:23:04.572
On a switch board there's two methods
that really are kind of what's left and

401
00:23:04.572 --> 00:23:05.850
available.

402
00:23:05.850 --> 00:23:10.092
There's one called store and forward, and
the other one's called cutthroat, okay?

403
00:23:10.092 --> 00:23:14.876
Store and forward, what it says is bring
the entire frame into that switchboard.

404
00:23:14.876 --> 00:23:18.464
Put in its buffer, and
then once it's there,

405
00:23:18.464 --> 00:23:21.504
forward it on to the destination port.

406
00:23:21.504 --> 00:23:26.199
Okay, so it takes everything and it
puts it into the buffer on that port and

407
00:23:26.199 --> 00:23:27.577
then forwards it on.

408
00:23:27.577 --> 00:23:30.953
That's probably what
you'll see most often, but

409
00:23:30.953 --> 00:23:34.573
it is slower when it comes down to it,
but you see that.

410
00:23:34.573 --> 00:23:36.968
And it's also the way to guarantee,

411
00:23:36.968 --> 00:23:40.532
sometimes faster transmission
speeds in this sense.

412
00:23:40.532 --> 00:23:46.704
If it can actually intake the entire frame
into the buffer that's means the CRC and

413
00:23:46.704 --> 00:23:50.655
everything has been checked,
everything is good.

414
00:23:50.655 --> 00:23:54.526
That means then it knows that when it's
transmitting it's transmitting everything

415
00:23:54.526 --> 00:23:55.385
that it needs to and

416
00:23:55.385 --> 00:23:59.160
there's no need to actually worry about
it kind of needing to be re-transmitted.

417
00:23:59.160 --> 00:24:01.450
But there's also something
called cut through.

418
00:24:01.450 --> 00:24:04.799
Cut through says, just get me to
that point where I see source and

419
00:24:04.799 --> 00:24:08.210
destination MAC address
in the frame header.

420
00:24:08.210 --> 00:24:10.880
Once I get that much,
let me just send it on through.

421
00:24:10.880 --> 00:24:14.990
And the reason why is that, for
however they figured this out, now Daniel,

422
00:24:14.990 --> 00:24:15.510
I don't know how.

423
00:24:15.510 --> 00:24:17.600
But they look at billions of packets, and

424
00:24:17.600 --> 00:24:21.220
what they realized is that if
fragmentation happens with the frames,

425
00:24:21.220 --> 00:24:26.450
it's within the first 48 bytes or
something like that, or 64 bytes.

426
00:24:26.450 --> 00:24:30.615
That if it doesn't happen in that time,
it's probably not gonna happen.

427
00:24:30.615 --> 00:24:35.159
So they're counting on statistical
probability that if we can get that much

428
00:24:35.159 --> 00:24:39.350
in there, okay, then more than likely,
it is not going to fragment.

429
00:24:39.350 --> 00:24:42.970
It's not gonna actually be any different,
you're not gonna have to retransmit.

430
00:24:42.970 --> 00:24:47.300
But there is always that theoretical
possibility that it can happen.

431
00:24:47.300 --> 00:24:51.819
So cut through has, of course, been making
its way through these switches because it

432
00:24:51.819 --> 00:24:53.906
is much faster in what it does instead.

433
00:24:53.906 --> 00:24:58.122
So those are two different methods
that you can also end up seeing too.

434
00:24:58.122 --> 00:24:59.114
Most of the time,

435
00:24:59.114 --> 00:25:04.130
you'll have to take a look at your switch
because it is dependent upon the switch.

436
00:25:04.130 --> 00:25:07.280
Whether or not it's actually cut
through or whether it's store and fort.

437
00:25:07.280 --> 00:25:09.330
It's not a setting that you and
I get to choose,

438
00:25:09.330 --> 00:25:11.699
it's not a configuration that you and
I get to choose.

439
00:25:11.699 --> 00:25:14.375
It's gonna be based on the device itself,
and

440
00:25:14.375 --> 00:25:18.912
what we tend to need there at that point
in time for what's gonna be happening.

441
00:25:20.170 --> 00:25:21.480
So let's go ahead and

442
00:25:21.480 --> 00:25:24.630
take a look at some of the information

The other thing that we're also

451
00:26:08.680 --> 00:26:13.990
right here in the queuing is what

452
00:26:13.990 --> 00:26:15.900
When you start taking a look
at something like this,

453
00:26:15.900 --> 00:26:21.850
notice it tells you the size of the queue
and the maximum size that you'll see.

454
00:26:21.850 --> 00:26:22.460
So in other words,

00:26:22.460 --> 00:26:26.210
this thing has queued up to about
75 at one point if it needed to.

And then the total output drops, anything
that it dropped, it will also show up here

457
00:26:30.360 --> 00:26:35.160
as well, that is a possibility
when stuff happens, you see that.

458
00:26:35.160 --> 00:26:37.609
Also notice this queueing strategy,
Daniel, FIFO,

459
00:26:37.609 --> 00:26:40.278
you remember what FIFO stands for?
>> First in, first out.

460
00:26:40.278 --> 00:26:41.528
>> First in, first out, so

461
00:26:41.528 --> 00:26:45.098
it's not just trying to, it's not

So even if we were to put this out onto a

two information, that means all of those

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie use Wireshark to capture the frame information.  They point out how to examine the header information.  Capturing `https` and `ssh` traffic, they demonstrate not only the encrypted data but the frame information remains readable.
episodes.title: Interpret Ethernet Frame Format Part 2

The red and

So here is the negotiation of things.
