>> And the reason why is because it's

00:15:04.020 --> 00:15:04.567

00:15:04.567 --> 00:15:05.337

00:15:07.207 --> 00:15:08.156

00:15:10.212 --> 00:15:10.980

But yes, Daniel,

you are absolutely correct-

>> Yeah, that's actually even better

All right, so
I was trying to pull this up.

And then beings.

Now technically it's the TCPIP model,

The very fact is, when you talk

Here's the bits or

278

Here of course is the data length.

279

This would be the internet layer.

280

And that would be the transport.

Ultimately, there would be an application

up there to look at it.

But when we talk about just

we don't tend to open the application

00:16:22.140 --> 00:16:24.230
So you will see all this information,

theoretically, here's what it looks

So when you get those replies and

00:16:33.710 --> 00:16:36.850
you're talking about where it is,

And that's why it's so valuable and

As you get into whatever specialty you get

294

And say, hey, here's the clue you're

But for us it's just enough to at least

And it is actually there.

297
00:16:57.920 --> 00:17:00.992
We're not just not-
>> [LAUGH] It's not just a made up thing

that we pretend exists and

299
00:17:03.505 --> 00:17:06.750
>> Yeah, it really is, when it comes

really, no, that's the way you

>> But make sure you pay attention to that

Ethernet and that layer 2 header

That's gonna be key,

making sure that you can identify

Because we're in kind of

that's really the component that

the rest of what we're gonna be taking

So understanding that layer 2

How does this work itself out into

And this was a great look at away that

Let me fire up WireShark and

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at issues dealing with interfaces and cabling.  They demonstrate how to use cisco switches and routers to get information and to configure them for duplex.  The also discuss hard setting the duplex for troubleshooting and use of auto.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Interfaces and Cables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.158 --> 00:00:00.905
You're watching ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:00.905 --> 00:00:01.911
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:01.911 --> 00:00:03.621

4

5
00:00:07.743 --> 00:00:11.888
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.
>> All right,

6
00:00:11.888 --> 00:00:15.688

7

>> It's going well Daniel.

13
00:00:31.340 --> 00:00:32.887
Thank you for having me on the show.

14
00:00:32.887 --> 00:00:36.612
We are continuing on of course in our
Cisco CCENT series making sure you're

15
00:00:36.612 --> 00:00:38.041

As well as helping you if you haven't

anything configuring of course with Cisco,

And for us, we're part way through

And it seems strange here,

00:01:00.840 --> 00:01:04.980
but right smack dab in one of those
objectives that they call out for,

this particular topic is gonna be

Now if we kind of backtracked a little bit

And so we have a good understanding

We also have talked about

So that is what we're

We'll see some of the errors or some of

So you might be wondering,

00:02:19.923 --> 00:02:23.714

[LAUGH] This is where it gets a little

67
00:03:21.040 --> 00:03:24.038
It may be a little bit harder to actually

68
00:03:24.038 --> 00:03:27.688
And that means troubleshooting

00:03:27.688 --> 00:03:31.500

70

72
00:03:37.460 --> 00:03:38.978
So that's what at today,

74

76
00:03:48.450 --> 00:03:51.849
So Daniel, today we're gonna be
talking about that idea of duplex and

77

speed like I said.

78
00:03:52.780 --> 00:03:57.068
And then in the end here, we're also of
course, gonna end up covering this idea

79
00:03:57.068 --> 00:04:01.100
of what we call auto-MDIX or
MDIX auto, however you want to say it.

80

I learned it as auto-MDIX,
it's always in my mind that way.

81
00:04:04.000 --> 00:04:07.290
And that is of course,
choosing what cable actually goes where.

82
00:04:07.290 --> 00:04:09.220
We've already done that
in a previous episode,

83
00:04:09.220 --> 00:04:11.490
but we'll kind of review the concept.

84
00:04:11.490 --> 00:04:13.279
We'll also show you how you can set it and

86
00:04:15.657 --> 00:04:18.090
And your routers too.

87
00:04:18.090 --> 00:04:20.960
So let's go ahead and

88
00:04:20.960 --> 00:04:25.971
So right here on my screen, I've gone
ahead and I've launched up practice labs.

89
00:04:25.971 --> 00:04:27.916
There's a complete lab for this,

90
00:04:27.916 --> 00:04:31.200
make sure you follow along
in the guide as you do this.

91
00:04:31.200 --> 00:04:35.845
Let me show you the name of this guide
is gonna be Iinterface Configuration and

92
00:04:35.845 --> 00:04:36.495
Cabling.

93
00:04:36.495 --> 00:04:40.790
And it does have all the steps for
you too, to allow you to do something.

94
00:04:40.790 --> 00:04:45.562
Now Daniel, I also wanna point out kind
of a practice labs kind of a secret

95
00:04:45.562 --> 00:04:48.306
trick that happens sometimes.
>> I like secret tricks.

96
00:04:48.306 --> 00:04:50.420
>> Yeah, it does help.

97
00:04:50.420 --> 00:04:54.017
I don't know why, every once in

98
00:04:54.017 --> 00:04:57.190

here that's available for you.

You go and then you click on that lab and

100

But sometimes it seemed like

Well one of the things I discovered

109
00:05:25.795 --> 00:05:26.600
>> Interesting.

110
00:05:26.600 --> 00:05:27.568

114
00:05:36.070 --> 00:05:38.264
But that's just kind of a practice labs,

126
00:06:12.390 --> 00:06:15.754
There's half duplex and
there's full duplex, okay?

127
00:06:15.754 --> 00:06:20.310
So this is about the transmission that

128
00:06:20.310 --> 00:06:23.349

00:06:29.140 --> 00:06:29.955

133
00:06:33.171 --> 00:06:38.073
When you start talking about the idea
of half duplex, it means that,

134
00:06:38.073 --> 00:06:44.890
that interface can send or it can receive
data, but it can't do both simultaneously.

135
00:06:44.890 --> 00:06:49.183

duplex, that means it can send and

136
00:06:49.183 --> 00:06:50.900

00:06:50.900 --> 00:06:54.720

00:06:54.720 --> 00:06:57.180

00:06:57.180 --> 00:07:01.200

00:07:01.200 --> 00:07:04.285

is what ends up happening.

141
00:07:04.285 --> 00:07:09.180
So in a half duplex, you normally
end up getting one pair of wires.

142
00:07:09.180 --> 00:07:11.115
And that way you can transmit or

143
00:07:11.115 --> 00:07:14.627

144
00:07:14.627 --> 00:07:18.930
But you cannot do both of them
on that wire at the same time.

145
00:07:18.930 --> 00:07:22.802
When we go to full duplex, we normally
end up using at least two pairs of wires.

146
00:07:22.802 --> 00:07:27.380
And so we can actually send on one pair,
and receive on the other.

147
00:07:27.380 --> 00:07:30.713
So it allows us to be able to do that and
that's the idea of full duplex.

00:29:43.730 --> 00:29:46.920
If you absolutely are trouble shooting and

580
00:29:46.920 --> 00:29:51.030
you're 100% trouble shooting,
set both sides to full, hard set up.

581
00:29:51.030 --> 00:29:54.740
Okay but
if you have tis notion at some point.

582
00:29:54.740 --> 00:29:56.250
You're going to be taking
this interface and

583
00:29:56.250 --> 00:29:59.040
multiple devices are going
to be plugged into it.

584
00:29:59.040 --> 00:30:02.110
You don't know what the speed is,
you don't know what it could be.

585
00:30:02.110 --> 00:30:03.670
Then set it back to auto.

586
00:30:03.670 --> 00:30:07.670
But if you're troubleshooting,
hard set both sides, okay?

587
00:30:07.670 --> 00:30:11.290
So that's not a, it's not a CISCO rule but
it's a good rule of thumb-.

588
00:30:11.290 --> 00:30:13.000
>> Just a good rule to and

589
00:30:13.000 --> 00:30:13.900
practicuum, right.

590
00:30:13.900 --> 00:30:15.920
We don't like to give you
just the book knowledge that

591
00:30:15.920 --> 00:30:16.800
you can, just to-
>> Right.

592
00:30:16.800 --> 00:30:18.340
>> Pass, pass the test.

593
00:30:18.340 --> 00:30:22.370
This will help you out in the real world
scenario, which very well might happen.

594
00:30:22.370 --> 00:30:23.490
>> Yeah cuz if you think,

595
00:30:23.490 --> 00:30:26.730
even in most devices should
be 100% full duplexing.

596
00:30:26.730 --> 00:30:30.390
There's no guarantee that if,
I know that this isn't a switch but

597
00:30:30.390 --> 00:30:33.040
let's say it was a switch and
you hard set it to full.

598
00:30:33.040 --> 00:30:35.010
And then you bring in another device,
though.

599
00:30:35.010 --> 00:30:37.500
And that other device only
communicates half duplex.

600
00:30:37.500 --> 00:30:39.660
It's gonna tell you that there's
a duplex missing [INAUDIBLE].

601
00:30:39.660 --> 00:30:41.580
Why did I set this thing to full?

602
00:30:41.580 --> 00:30:43.080
Why did I hard set it?
>> Of course, then,

603
00:30:43.080 --> 00:30:45.590
you hard set it to half duplex or
whatever that device is.

604
00:30:45.590 --> 00:30:48.496
And then you plug something else in and
it's duplex mismatch.

605
00:30:48.496 --> 00:30:49.570
>> So, in production, right,

606
00:30:49.570 --> 00:30:55.360
if you know I'm not troubleshooting here
and it was hard set, set it back to auto.

607
00:30:55.360 --> 00:30:56.770
And then you're ready to go but

608
00:30:56.770 --> 00:31:00.230
if you ever suspect there's
an interface issue of any type and

609
00:31:00.230 --> 00:31:04.160
you're saying, it could be a duplex
mismatch, set both sides to what you need.

610
00:31:04.160 --> 00:31:06.530
And that's what we want
to also be able to do.

611
00:31:06.530 --> 00:31:08.980
All right Daniel, so
in this particular segment,

612
00:31:08.980 --> 00:31:13.290
we did get to the idea of actually seeing
the duplex settings and how that works.

613
00:31:13.290 --> 00:31:14.910
We now need to move on to speed.

614
00:31:14.910 --> 00:31:17.760
But Daniel, I've run out of time for
this segment.

615
00:31:17.760 --> 00:31:19.450
So that means we are ready to move on.

616
00:31:19.450 --> 00:31:22.980
But we will do it in another episode.
>> That clock is a fickle friend everyone.

617
00:31:22.980 --> 00:31:24.390
It goes so fast.

618
00:31:24.390 --> 00:31:25.670
But not to worry we can just make

619
00:31:25.670 --> 00:31:26.330
another episode.
>> Right.

620
00:31:26.330 --> 00:31:27.120
>> That's what we do here.

621
00:31:27.120 --> 00:31:28.170
Ronnie I look forward to seeing you then.

622
00:31:28.170 --> 00:31:30.610
And I'm looking forward to seeing
you good folks there as well.

623
00:31:30.610 --> 00:31:32.210
But it is that time for
us to call it a day.

624
00:31:32.210 --> 00:31:35.380
Signing off for IT Pro TV I've
been your host Daniel Lowrie.

625
00:31:35.380 --> 00:31:36.110
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

626
00:31:36.110 --> 00:31:38.167
>> We will see you next time.

627
00:31:38.167 --> 00:31:44.134
[MUSIC]

628
00:31:44.134 --> 00:31:47.503
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at issues dealing with interfaces and cabling.  They demonstrate how to use cisco switches and routers to get information and to configure them for speed and mdix. They show speed settings on routers and switches and talk about the issues with cabling choices and how mdix works.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Interfaces and Cables Part 2

Both 10 and

If both sides are set to auto on

Okay, so at this point when we take a look

172
00:10:05.130 --> 00:10:07.040
At this time, if I typed in speed.

173

Then you wait a certain period of time
that you think is gonna give you that

408
00:22:11.060 --> 00:22:12.420
as you're transmitting.

409
00:22:12.420 --> 00:22:15.310
And then you take a look at
the initial command again.

410
00:22:15.310 --> 00:22:16.640
And if now they're happening,

411
00:22:16.640 --> 00:22:19.860
it let's you know right then and
ther, tThat something is going wrong.

412
00:22:19.860 --> 00:22:23.995
Now ours, there's nothing connected that
we're actually gonna cause collisions on.

413
00:22:23.995 --> 00:22:31.238
So we shouldn't see anything,
I say we shouldn't but

414
00:22:31.238 --> 00:22:37.705
let's do interface fastethernet 1/0/2.

415
00:22:37.705 --> 00:22:41.898
So now that we've cleared the counters
once again, no runs, no collisions,

416
00:22:41.898 --> 00:22:46.190
no late collisions you name it,
they're all just not there anymore.

417
00:22:46.190 --> 00:22:50.610
So for us, it didn't do anything but
if you really did have a busy switch and

418
00:22:50.610 --> 00:22:52.460
you started looking at this and
you started to see that.

419
00:22:52.460 --> 00:22:55.870
You wanna verify that it's still
happening, that's the way you do it.

420
00:22:55.870 --> 00:22:57.150
And they start showing up.

421
00:22:57.150 --> 00:23:00.450
It lets you know that that's what's
happening at that point, okay?

422
00:23:00.450 --> 00:23:02.490
All right, so Daniel,
that kind of leads it for

423
00:23:02.490 --> 00:23:05.346
us when we start dealing with the idea
of speed and duplex issues and

424
00:23:05.346 --> 00:23:07.800
helping us to troubleshoot
a little bit more.

425
00:23:07.800 --> 00:23:10.100
I've only got one other thing left for
us to do,

426
00:23:10.100 --> 00:23:14.380
which is the thing that should not
affect us at all anymore, okay?

427
00:23:14.380 --> 00:23:15.790
And it's always a should not.

428
00:23:15.790 --> 00:23:18.530
But when it comes down to Cisco exams,

429
00:23:18.530 --> 00:23:22.490
it's not a matter of whether it should
not or whether it could not, okay?

430
00:23:22.490 --> 00:23:26.720
The idea here is, do you really
know what should be there, okay?

431
00:23:26.720 --> 00:23:30.150
Cisco has made many strides
at trying to make it almost,

432
00:23:31.150 --> 00:23:33.560
I don't wanna be insulting but
dummy proof.

433
00:23:33.560 --> 00:23:35.940
>> Gotcha.
>> In terms of cabling, right?

434
00:23:35.940 --> 00:23:39.200
Cabling can be a bit of a hassle.

435
00:23:39.200 --> 00:23:40.280
You pick up a cable,

436
00:23:40.280 --> 00:23:43.190
you go to plug in two devices and
you're like, why isn't this working?

437
00:23:43.190 --> 00:23:46.730
And you trouble shoot everything you can
at layer three and then somebody goes,

438
00:23:46.730 --> 00:23:47.630
did you check the cable?

439
00:23:47.630 --> 00:23:49.130
And then you go, no.

440
00:23:49.130 --> 00:23:50.920
I didn't check the cable.

441
00:23:50.920 --> 00:23:52.026
>> And then, you shut up.

442
00:23:52.026 --> 00:23:52.853
>> Yeah.

443
00:23:52.853 --> 00:23:54.233
And then that's what happens, yeah.

444
00:23:54.233 --> 00:23:56.241
You start losing that track.

445
00:23:56.241 --> 00:23:59.534
And all of a sudden you realize,
it was a cable, but

446
00:23:59.534 --> 00:24:02.770
it doesn't even look like
it's pinned in correctly.

447
00:24:02.770 --> 00:24:04.940
And that's even harder, you go,
no, the cable looks good.

448
00:24:04.940 --> 00:24:08.400
>> Well, and in troubleshooting theory
you always start with the simple things

449
00:24:08.400 --> 00:24:09.330
first, right?

450
00:24:09.330 --> 00:24:10.180
Does it have power?

451
00:24:10.180 --> 00:24:10.920
Is it plugged in?

452
00:24:10.920 --> 00:24:11.830
Is it plugged in correctly?

453
00:24:11.830 --> 00:24:13.110
Is it making contact?

454
00:24:13.110 --> 00:24:16.566
If you get through that physical layer,
everything's up and

455
00:24:16.566 --> 00:24:18.899
running, then you know it's not there.

456
00:24:18.899 --> 00:24:20.430
If everything's on the up and up.

457
00:24:20.430 --> 00:24:24.832
>> Yeah, one of the easiest things, right,
that people can and it shouldn't be,

458
00:24:24.832 --> 00:24:26.277
but if people are hiring.

459
00:24:26.277 --> 00:24:28.570
They're like, all right, so here it is.

460
00:24:28.570 --> 00:24:31.560
Take this cable, plug it in,
make this device work.

461
00:24:31.560 --> 00:24:33.200
And if it doesn't work, do you know.

462
00:24:33.200 --> 00:24:35.930
They handed you what the answer is, okay.

463
00:24:35.930 --> 00:24:38.390
But they're expecting you
to examine the cable and

464
00:24:38.390 --> 00:24:43.110
verify it's the type of cable that you
need when you're plugging in that device.

465
00:24:43.110 --> 00:24:46.600
But Cisco says look,
let's not deal with that.

466
00:24:46.600 --> 00:24:50.540
Let's build it into the interface,
to the port itself, okay, so

467
00:24:50.540 --> 00:24:52.560
that we never have to deal with it.

468
00:24:52.560 --> 00:24:55.790
So regardless of whether you
pick up a crossover cable,

469
00:24:55.790 --> 00:24:59.470
regardless of whether you pick up
a straight-through cable, it will work.

470
00:24:59.470 --> 00:25:01.260
So if you put two switches on top, and

471
00:25:01.260 --> 00:25:05.960
you go crud I have to make a crossover
cable and you don't know how to do that.

472
00:25:05.960 --> 00:25:08.480
Well Cisco says don't worry about it,

473
00:25:08.480 --> 00:25:09.480
I'll help you out
>> Yeah.

474
00:25:09.480 --> 00:25:11.030
>> It will do it, okay?

475
00:25:11.030 --> 00:25:13.910
So today, cabling should not be an issue.

476
00:25:13.910 --> 00:25:17.730
That doesn't mean Cisco doesn't
expect you to know whether or

477
00:25:17.730 --> 00:25:19.920
not it can do that, okay?

478
00:25:19.920 --> 00:25:23.350
So this is also gonna be
age-dependant on the switch and

479
00:25:23.350 --> 00:25:25.790
the platform itself as well.

480
00:25:25.790 --> 00:25:30.790
Some of the really older switches that
are out there, Pry will not do this,

481
00:25:30.790 --> 00:25:34.870
and that's a feature that is called MDIX,
that's out there.

482
00:25:34.870 --> 00:25:38.220
Where it automatically detects the cable
and what it needs to do on the other end.

483
00:25:38.220 --> 00:25:41.080
Whether it needs to send or
receive and it will switch it around.

484
00:25:41.080 --> 00:25:43.830
So whether you use a crossover cable,
whether you actually use a straight

485
00:25:43.830 --> 00:25:48.560
through cable, it says I am
smart enough to figure this out.

486
00:25:48.560 --> 00:25:50.860
Okay, that's what it will actually do for
us.

487
00:25:50.860 --> 00:25:55.260
So that's one of those things that we want
to make sure that we understand it, okay?

488
00:25:55.260 --> 00:25:57.180
So what do we need to determine that?

489
00:25:57.180 --> 00:26:01.620
Well, the great thing is usually every
port today or every switch today, right.

490
00:26:01.620 --> 00:26:07.920
Just about every device today it has
it set to auto to do the MDIX, right?

491
00:26:07.920 --> 00:26:09.890
So what if we wanted
to manually configure?

492
00:26:09.890 --> 00:26:12.940
So on NYCORE1, let's go ahead and do this.

493
00:26:12.940 --> 00:26:14.660
I'm gonna go into our global config.

494
00:26:16.620 --> 00:26:22.800
Nope, I have to spell terminal right,
configure terminal.

495
00:26:24.510 --> 00:26:26.130
And then let's get into that interface.

496
00:26:26.130 --> 00:26:31.197
So interface Fastethernet 1/0/2,

497
00:26:31.197 --> 00:26:34.520
this one says do it on port 22.

498
00:26:34.520 --> 00:26:40.104
We'll do this on port 22 here, and
I have to spell interface right.

499
00:26:50.941 --> 00:26:53.345
Here underlined in red, so
I'm actually trying to be careful.

500
00:26:53.345 --> 00:26:54.137
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right,

501
00:26:54.137 --> 00:26:57.496
now that's actually kind of pointing
out something I wouldn't expect here.

502
00:26:57.496 --> 00:27:02.648
So now if I wanted to make sure auto MDIX

503
00:27:02.648 --> 00:27:08.127
is actually off, I just do no MDIX auto.

504
00:27:08.127 --> 00:27:11.280
And that will automatically
just turn that off.

505
00:27:11.280 --> 00:27:15.700
So if this is turned off it
means you will have to decide

506
00:27:15.700 --> 00:27:19.400
what cable that you have
to actually put in there.

507
00:27:19.400 --> 00:27:23.220
So I can see, Daniel, on this just
in the last few minutes that we have

508
00:27:23.220 --> 00:27:27.610
together here right,
as far as exam this is a great one, right?

509
00:27:27.610 --> 00:27:29.895
>> Yeah.
>> That the very fact that it's like look

510
00:27:29.895 --> 00:27:33.325
jey, you need to select the proper cable.

511
00:27:33.325 --> 00:27:36.377
Or, you believe that MDIX is turned on,
but

512
00:27:36.377 --> 00:27:40.759
when you plug in a straight through cable,
it's not working.

513
00:27:40.759 --> 00:27:41.821
>> One of those little gotcha questions.

514
00:27:41.821 --> 00:27:45.459
>> Yes, one of those little gotcha
questions, which is simple,

515
00:27:45.459 --> 00:27:48.699
that means MDIX was turned
off at some point or somehow.

516
00:27:48.699 --> 00:27:51.100
And all you have to do is enable it again.

517
00:27:51.100 --> 00:27:52.930
But that's what you have
to be able to determine.

518
00:27:52.930 --> 00:27:54.860
So it's not exactly
the hardest thing in the world,

519
00:27:54.860 --> 00:27:58.930
but it's one of those where it
just kinda slipped in, right?

520
00:27:58.930 --> 00:28:04.690
And this is an easy points for
the exam type of question where it's like,

521
00:28:04.690 --> 00:28:08.930
this is not something I should miss
just because I chose not to know it.

522
00:28:08.930 --> 00:28:09.440
>> Yeah.

523
00:28:09.440 --> 00:28:11.200
>> There's so much stuff out there, but

524
00:28:11.200 --> 00:28:15.960
this is one just like man, that's
an easy question marked off and do that.

525
00:28:15.960 --> 00:28:19.070
And so you can get a lot of
just stuff just by doing this.

526
00:28:19.070 --> 00:28:22.500
So that's it, because cabling today
should not be an issue, period.

527
00:28:22.500 --> 00:28:24.260
>> Yeah.
>> It should not be, okay.

528
00:28:24.260 --> 00:28:28.320
Unless you get like,
a Ronnie Wong special cable Which means,

529
00:28:28.320 --> 00:28:31.608
he didn't try to follow any
particular standard at all.

530
00:28:31.608 --> 00:28:36.090
He just kinda randomly made
an RJ45 connector, and

531
00:28:36.090 --> 00:28:42.040
just scrambled up all the wires and
shoved them in there.

532
00:28:42.040 --> 00:28:44.632
Even Cisco is gonna have
a hard time with that cable.

533
00:28:44.632 --> 00:28:47.310
>> They're like whoa buddy,
what are you doing?

534
00:28:47.310 --> 00:28:49.570
What are you doing?

535
00:28:49.570 --> 00:28:50.320
>> Can that happen?

536
00:28:50.320 --> 00:28:52.910
Yes, okay, it can happen.

537
00:28:52.910 --> 00:28:54.720
>> I've seen stranger things, Daniel.

538
00:28:54.720 --> 00:28:56.080
>> It's a great show.

539
00:28:56.080 --> 00:28:57.808
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

540
00:28:57.808 --> 00:28:58.636
>> Yeah, it is a great show.

541
00:28:58.636 --> 00:29:00.238
>> [LAUGH]
>> But at some point,

542
00:29:00.238 --> 00:29:02.037
I've seen where people are like,

543
00:29:02.037 --> 00:29:06.010
well it only needs two pairs of wire and
they literally just put four wires.

544
00:29:06.010 --> 00:29:11.110
I’m like there's eight slots, just fill in
the rest of this thing, are you joking?

545
00:29:11.110 --> 00:29:16.300
>> That sounds a lot like work and
I'm not really into that.

546
00:29:16.300 --> 00:29:18.090
>> Like I said,
I've seen a lot of strange things,

547
00:29:18.090 --> 00:29:19.920
I'm not pointing out
anybody in particular.

548
00:29:19.920 --> 00:29:22.290
But when you start seeing stuff like that.

549
00:29:22.290 --> 00:29:26.670
This is in a production,
it's not even a testing environment.

550
00:29:26.670 --> 00:29:30.141
You're using this to allow for
your data and your business to run.

551
00:29:30.141 --> 00:29:33.800
>> Right you would think that
you'd want that work properly.

552
00:29:33.800 --> 00:29:35.989
>> Yeah but so.

553
00:29:35.989 --> 00:29:37.412
>> A little time and care.

554
00:29:37.412 --> 00:29:40.690
>> But that's what they're told,
that's somehow some people learn that way.

555
00:29:40.690 --> 00:29:44.640
Yeah you only need four of the eight
wires, so why deal with the other four?

556
00:29:44.640 --> 00:29:47.730
But those are some of the other things
that kind of scare you a little bit.

557
00:29:47.730 --> 00:29:50.810
>> Yeah.
>> But like I said Cisco says look

558
00:29:50.810 --> 00:29:55.770
as long as they are fairly standard
straight through or they are crossover.

559
00:29:55.770 --> 00:29:57.980
You shouldn't have to deal with that mess.

560
00:29:57.980 --> 00:30:02.540
But if you have to there is a reason
why when you put in the right cable and

561
00:30:02.540 --> 00:30:03.470
it's still not working.

562
00:30:03.470 --> 00:30:04.770
The wrong cable I should say.

563
00:30:04.770 --> 00:30:08.050
And it's still not working for
you, I would check this on

564
00:30:08.050 --> 00:30:12.530
each interface that they're tell you to
connect to, verify which side is off.

565
00:30:12.530 --> 00:30:16.570
Or if both sides is off, then you
could either turn it on or actually

566
00:30:16.570 --> 00:30:20.070
choose the right cable, turn both sides
off and you'll be off and ready to go.

567
00:30:20.070 --> 00:30:23.770
So, Daniel, that will pretty much cover
the idea of interfaces and cables for

568
00:30:23.770 --> 00:30:25.560
us, and
being able to troubleshoot them too.

569
00:30:25.560 --> 00:30:26.930
>> It was great troubleshooting tips, and

570
00:30:26.930 --> 00:30:31.740
it was good food for thought as we look
to the future in our CCENT Series.

571
00:30:31.740 --> 00:30:34.800
Well, Ronnie we are out of time for this
episode so we do thank you for joining us.

572
00:30:34.800 --> 00:30:38.000
We thank you good folks as always for
watching, but signing off,

573
00:30:38.000 --> 00:30:40.100
for ITPROTV I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

574
00:30:40.100 --> 00:30:40.940
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

575
00:30:40.940 --> 00:30:43.162
>> We'll see you next time.

576
00:30:43.162 --> 00:30:49.037
>> [MUSIC]

577
00:30:49.037 --> 00:30:52.179
>> Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use of vlans and configure. The guys describe using vlans on a single switch and on multiple switches.  They also describe how to configure using trunk ports to span vlans across multiple switches.
episodes.title: Configure and Verify VLANs
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.222
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.222 --> 00:00:03.485
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.485 --> 00:00:04.399
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:04.399 --> 00:00:05.876
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:05.876 --> 00:00:10.673
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:10.673 --> 00:00:13.248
>> All right, greetings, everyone and

7
00:00:13.248 --> 00:00:16.740
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.740 --> 00:00:17.910
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

9
00:00:17.910 --> 00:00:18.810
And in today's episode,

10
00:00:18.810 --> 00:00:21.720
well, you guessed it,
we're back with more on our CCENT series.

11
00:00:21.720 --> 00:00:24.430
Joining us in the studio yet again,
our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:24.430 --> 00:00:25.170
Ronnie, welcome back.

13
00:00:25.170 --> 00:00:25.930
How's it going?

14
00:00:25.930 --> 00:00:27.230
>> It is going well, Daniel.

15
00:00:27.230 --> 00:00:30.320
Thank you for having me back on
the show as we continue on, of course,

16
00:00:30.320 --> 00:00:32.450
in our journey right here on CCENT.

17
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:36.630
We are now at the episode inside
of the switching topic here

18
00:00:36.630 --> 00:00:40.060
where we begin to create VLANs.

19
00:00:40.060 --> 00:00:43.000
Now if this is something that
sounds brand new to you,

20
00:00:43.000 --> 00:00:44.770
well, you're going to learn
a little bit about it.

21
00:00:44.770 --> 00:00:47.840
So we have to talk a little
bit of conceptual theory here.

22
00:00:47.840 --> 00:00:48.650
And then, of course,

23
00:00:48.650 --> 00:00:52.280
that means we are also going to show you
how you actually create these things.

24
00:00:52.280 --> 00:00:56.080
And also, of course, talk about why
we also need to create these as well.

25
00:00:56.080 --> 00:01:00.250
Okay, so it's really important for us to
understand, of course, the concept and

26
00:01:00.250 --> 00:01:03.300
the use of VLANs because
they are used everywhere

27
00:01:03.300 --> 00:01:05.940
inside of networking switches today.

28
00:01:05.940 --> 00:01:10.340
And it is one of the reasons why we
actually do want to end up using

29
00:01:10.340 --> 00:01:15.370
switches a lot of times is because we
can now create VLANs, which stands for

30
00:01:15.370 --> 00:01:17.330
virtual local area networks.

31
00:01:17.330 --> 00:01:22.600
So let's get back to a basic idea before
we go into the idea of VLANs here.

32
00:01:22.600 --> 00:01:26.080
Let's take a look at my diagram here for
a moment.

33
00:01:26.080 --> 00:01:31.140
So I've used this before in a previous
episode where we talked about the idea of

34
00:01:31.140 --> 00:01:35.220
domains and collision domains as well and
broadcast domains.

35
00:01:35.220 --> 00:01:40.530
So if we have a hub, remember that for
us the end result of this,

36
00:01:40.530 --> 00:01:46.350
right, is that we have a single broadcast
domain and a single collision domain.

37
00:01:46.350 --> 00:01:47.990
And when something like this happens,
well,

38
00:01:47.990 --> 00:01:50.780
that means one device
everybody hears which is fine.

39
00:01:50.780 --> 00:01:56.190
Two devices communicating simultaneously
will essentially cause a collision, okay?

40
00:01:56.190 --> 00:02:02.927
Well, then we introduced the concept of
switches which don't reduce broadcast.

41
00:02:02.927 --> 00:02:05.550
I'm gonna say them backwards here.

42
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:09.610
Don't reduce broadcast domain or
limit broadcast domains, but

43
00:02:09.610 --> 00:02:13.380
actually do start to
limit collision domains.

44
00:02:13.380 --> 00:02:19.180
By creating more collision domains, we
actually eliminate a lot more collisions.

45
00:02:19.180 --> 00:02:22.400
Sounds strange but
it is the way that it ends up happening.

46
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:24.630
And that's because today's switches,

47
00:02:24.630 --> 00:02:29.100
every single port on a switch
represents its own collision domain.

48
00:02:29.100 --> 00:02:31.710
But the only time you should
end up getting collisions,

49
00:02:31.710 --> 00:02:37.110
the majority of times is when you actually
have two devices off of that single port.

50
00:02:37.110 --> 00:02:39.290
And normally you're not gonna have that.

51
00:02:39.290 --> 00:02:43.578
So just about all collisions have,
kind of been eliminated that way.

52
00:02:43.578 --> 00:02:46.418
But the problem that we have still,
though,

53
00:02:46.418 --> 00:02:49.960
is that now we have this
one big broadcast domain.

54
00:02:49.960 --> 00:02:52.891
So in that sense, it works,
it does exactly what we need to do.

55
00:02:52.891 --> 00:02:58.081
But this also then, of course,
means that if you want to connect people

56
00:02:58.081 --> 00:03:03.361
together in their proper, let's say,
logical management grouping,

57
00:03:03.361 --> 00:03:08.430
it means you also have to assign
individual switches to them.

58

281
00:16:36.040 --> 00:16:39.520
into any switch that I want to and
assign them to the same Vlan.

282
00:16:39.520 --> 00:16:44.054
And that puts them in the same broadcast
domain regardless of what switch that

283
00:16:44.054 --> 00:16:45.830
they're in, okay.

284
00:16:45.830 --> 00:16:49.230
Now once we start getting
beyond that single one, right?

285
00:16:49.230 --> 00:16:54.000
So remember that on a single switch
We're essentially subdividing

286
00:16:55.210 --> 00:16:56.910
out what we're seeing here.

287
00:16:56.910 --> 00:17:05.120
Where it really does become,
Where it's really like this is a grouping.

288
00:17:07.120 --> 00:17:09.900
All right, and even a few more there.

289
00:17:09.900 --> 00:17:13.880
And another one, and
here's another broadcast domain.

290
00:17:13.880 --> 00:17:15.700
That may also be happening.

291
00:17:15.700 --> 00:17:19.050
And here's another one that
can also be happening as well.

292
00:17:19.050 --> 00:17:22.500
So this is us chopping
that single switch up.

293
00:17:22.500 --> 00:17:27.360
When we start going to multiple switches,
now we can

294
00:17:27.360 --> 00:17:33.130
span multiple switches with
a single VLAN if we choose to.

295
00:17:33.130 --> 00:17:38.610
And it still does not have to
be where it is all contiguous.

296
00:17:38.610 --> 00:17:43.110
So let's say that I take this and
I change it to the red one here.

297
00:17:43.110 --> 00:17:48.270
So it may be where, of course,
why would it actually work the same way?

298
00:17:48.270 --> 00:17:53.870
Why would it choose to do the exact same
thing here, yeah, why would it, okay?

299
00:17:53.870 --> 00:17:57.420
So we could do that and
also this one here.

300
00:17:57.420 --> 00:17:59.410
Go across this way.

301
00:17:59.410 --> 00:18:00.560
I'll change all that to red.

302
00:18:02.170 --> 00:18:06.857
My tool is not exactly the most intuitive
tool to be able to use to do this, but

303
00:18:06.857 --> 00:18:08.412
it is nice, I do like it.

304
00:18:08.412 --> 00:18:09.347
>> [CROSSTALK] right?
[LAUGH]

305
00:18:09.347 --> 00:18:10.454
>> So it will actually allow

306
00:18:10.454 --> 00:18:11.090
us to do this.

307
00:18:11.090 --> 00:18:12.690
So remember,
it doesn't have to be that but

308
00:18:12.690 --> 00:18:14.600
now that's kinda the weird thing, right?

309
00:18:14.600 --> 00:18:15.920
It's the opposite, right?

310
00:18:15.920 --> 00:18:19.520
If you only have a single switch,
VLAN's allowed us to subdivide that and

311
00:18:19.520 --> 00:18:23.380
create multiple smaller
broadcast domain-on switches.

312
00:18:23.380 --> 00:18:28.547
And even though that's normally
the venue of what routers do,

313
00:18:28.547 --> 00:18:33.041
VLANs allow us to do same
thing on switches too, okay?

314
00:18:33.041 --> 00:18:36.485
Then, when you start tying
multiple switches together,

315
00:18:36.485 --> 00:18:40.730
they allow us to expand a single
vlan across multiple devices.

316
00:18:40.730 --> 00:18:42.180
Now when we do something like this,

317
00:18:42.180 --> 00:18:45.380
you do have to take in
special consideration here.

318
00:18:45.380 --> 00:18:49.050
There's also gonna be ports
that you have to leave alone so

319
00:18:49.050 --> 00:18:51.420
that those vlans can
communicate with each other or

320
00:18:51.420 --> 00:18:55.340
the same vlan can communicate
with each other across a switch.

321
00:18:55.340 --> 00:19:01.070
And this is where instead,
you end up creating what you call trunks.

322
00:19:03.500 --> 00:19:06.360
At least I think you're
gonna create a trunk here.

323
00:19:06.360 --> 00:19:07.090
At least that's the hope.

324
00:19:09.780 --> 00:19:10.380
Let's see.

325
00:19:10.380 --> 00:19:11.950
Let's make that bigger and thicker.

326
00:19:11.950 --> 00:19:12.841
There we go.

327
00:19:12.841 --> 00:19:16.705
And then we'll do that, and
make it orange at this point.

328
00:19:16.705 --> 00:19:18.650
So you'll link a cable here.

329
00:19:18.650 --> 00:19:21.210
And let me duplicate that table if I can.

330
00:19:26.660 --> 00:19:29.610
And we'll do that as well, okay?

331
00:19:29.610 --> 00:19:32.755
So we'll actually take
two ports like this,

332
00:19:32.755 --> 00:19:37.742
and we'll reconfigure them to become
what we call trunk ports, okay?

333
00:19:37.742 --> 00:19:41.210
So over here on the top,this
idea of trunk ports.

334
00:19:41.210 --> 00:19:47.940
Trunk ports will allow for the idea of
multiple VLANs to be able to use a single

335
00:19:47.940 --> 00:19:52.710
link to go across these switches so
that they can communicate with each other.

336
00:19:52.710 --> 00:19:55.690
In other words,
red ports on this particular switch,

337
00:19:55.690 --> 00:19:59.670
can also communicate well with
the red ports on this switch.

338
00:19:59.670 --> 00:20:01.000
What if I don't use trunks?

339
00:20:01.000 --> 00:20:02.640
What do I have to do?

340
00:20:02.640 --> 00:20:08.335
If I do not use a trunk,
what ends up happening instead is that for

341
00:20:08.335 --> 00:20:14.360
every vlan that is created here,
let me see if I can get back to this.

342
00:20:14.360 --> 00:20:17.206
For every VLAN that's created,

343
00:20:17.206 --> 00:20:22.284
inside of that particular VLAN I
would have to make sure that

344
00:20:22.284 --> 00:20:27.930
I run a single connection in
to every single one of those.

345
00:20:27.930 --> 00:20:31.680
So I'd have to run my own link
inside of that particular VLAN,

346
00:20:31.680 --> 00:20:35.240
and then the same thing with
the yellow one over here,

347
00:20:35.240 --> 00:20:38.420
is that I would also have
to do that over here too.

348
00:20:38.420 --> 00:20:41.410
So if I do not configure
a trunk that allows for

349
00:20:41.410 --> 00:20:44.730
multiple VLANs to pass
over a single connection.

350
00:20:47.860 --> 00:20:49.840
Then I would also have to add these in.

351
00:20:49.840 --> 00:20:52.520
And now all of a sudden I'm losing ports

352
00:20:52.520 --> 00:20:55.610
just to make connections
between those two VLANs.

353
00:20:55.610 --> 00:21:00.530
So instead,
the way to reduce the number of ports that

354
00:21:00.530 --> 00:21:04.680
are just being used to communicate
is to configure these particular

355
00:21:04.680 --> 00:21:09.730
ports over here to allow for
traffic, okay?

356
00:21:09.730 --> 00:21:14.190
From every VLAN to be able to cross over
to this switch and then to this port.

357
00:21:14.190 --> 00:21:17.810
And then get distributed out to
the proper VLAN the way that needs to be.

358
00:21:19.120 --> 00:21:23.840
Now, this brings up to another point
that we also have to realize as well.

359
00:21:23.840 --> 00:21:27.860
Because we are creating
separate broadcast domains, and

360
00:21:27.860 --> 00:21:32.690
even across multiple switches here,
it also means that

361
00:21:32.690 --> 00:21:37.280
there will not be a direct
interaction between VLANs.

362
00:21:37.280 --> 00:21:43.790
Okay, so if you have traffic that
is destined for the red VLAN, even

363
00:21:43.790 --> 00:21:49.480
if they're on the same switch they will
not directly talk to each other, okay?

364
00:21:49.480 --> 00:21:51.060
It just won't happen.

365
00:21:51.060 --> 00:21:54.600
And that's because this is
one broadcast domain and

366
00:21:54.600 --> 00:21:57.530
this is now another broadcast domain.

367
00:21:57.530 --> 00:22:02.500
So Daniel, this brings us all the way back
to that concept of IP addressing again.

368
00:22:02.500 --> 00:22:06.460
If you remember that when we broke up and
we started doing subnetting,

369
00:22:06.460 --> 00:22:10.590
each particular subnet has
a broadcast address in it.

370
00:22:10.590 --> 00:22:15.580
So in theory that means that
this is one network over here,

371
00:22:15.580 --> 00:22:18.150
one of the logical IP networks.

372
00:22:18.150 --> 00:22:22.770
And this actually can represent
another logical IP network as well.

373
00:22:22.770 --> 00:22:26.870
So that way they will not communicate
directly with each other.

374
00:22:26.870 --> 00:22:28.620
Can it be done though?

375
00:22:28.620 --> 00:22:33.140
Yes, you'll normally need a layer
3 device that provides routing.

376
00:22:33.140 --> 00:22:37.820
So even between two ports that
are directly the same here.

377
00:22:37.820 --> 00:22:41.520
Let me move this one over here
just as an example, okay?

378
00:22:41.520 --> 00:22:47.130
Even if this yellow VLAN port over
here was right net to this red port,

379
00:22:47.130 --> 00:22:49.210
they would not directly communicate or

380
00:22:49.210 --> 00:22:54.240
send data to each other, they would have
to go out, get connected to a router.

381
00:22:54.240 --> 00:22:58.400
The router would route them
to the proper VLAN and

382
00:22:58.400 --> 00:23:00.540
then it would come back in instead.

383
00:23:00.540 --> 00:23:03.370
>> Ronnie I tell you,
this concept used to just baffle me.

384
00:23:03.370 --> 00:23:07.110
I would think,
if I'm creating these VLANs, and

385
00:23:07.110 --> 00:23:08.810
now I want them to talk to each other.

386
00:23:08.810 --> 00:23:11.200
Why did I create the VLANs
in the first place?

387
00:23:11.200 --> 00:23:11.960
What's the whole purpose?

388
00:23:11.960 --> 00:23:14.530
It seemed convoluted to have a VLAN.

389
00:23:14.530 --> 00:23:17.965
And then you have to have that go through
a router just to talk to a switchboard

390
00:23:17.965 --> 00:23:20.446
that without the VLANs,
it could normally talked to.

391
00:23:20.446 --> 00:23:20.984
>> Right.

392
00:23:20.984 --> 00:23:22.728
>> But then,
I started to understand network design and

393
00:23:22.728 --> 00:23:23.745
that made a little more sense.

394
00:23:23.745 --> 00:23:24.506
[LAUGH]
>> Right, and

395
00:23:24.506 --> 00:23:25.705
that's the whole goal, right?

396
00:23:25.705 --> 00:23:27.385
Is because you normally need to,

397
00:23:27.385 --> 00:23:30.830
because of the very fact that
at the beginning, right?

398
00:23:30.830 --> 00:23:33.900
We needed to subdivide that 48
port switching that 48 port

399
00:23:33.900 --> 00:23:35.630
switch instead of buying five of them.

400
00:23:35.630 --> 00:23:38.220
>> Right.
>> But now that we have this capability

401
00:23:38.220 --> 00:23:43.800
with these VLAN's, we can logically
configure essentially a switch, and using

402
00:23:43.800 --> 00:23:48.900
a layer three device to help us to route
the traffic in between them very easily.

403
00:23:48.900 --> 00:23:51.111
So it actually allows us to do that.

404
00:23:51.111 --> 00:23:54.474
Now, can we do this also without a router?

405
00:23:54.474 --> 00:23:58.704
Yes, if you have what we
call a multilayer switch, or

406
00:23:58.704 --> 00:24:02.270
also you hear the term layer 3 switch.

407
00:24:02.270 --> 00:24:07.550
That means that the switch itself also has
the ability to do the routing inside it.

408
00:24:07.550 --> 00:24:12.333
It's not a full router, per se, that has
every single feature of routing built into

409
00:24:12.333 --> 00:24:15.600
it, but
it is enough to run a routing protocol.

410
00:24:15.600 --> 00:24:18.460
It's enough to also sit right there so

411
00:24:18.460 --> 00:24:23.010
that it can actually do what we need it
to do, which is the inter-VLAN routing.

412
00:24:23.010 --> 00:24:26.520
And that's probably
the preferred method today.

413
00:24:26.520 --> 00:24:29.758
And the reason why is, that most of
the time, I don't wanna say most of it,

414
00:24:29.758 --> 00:24:34.580
just about every place that you look,
routers, they're really edge

415
00:24:34.580 --> 00:24:38.540
devices between you, of course, and your
internet service provider a lot of times.

416
00:24:38.540 --> 00:24:43.140
But because internet service providers
are also now on metro Ethernet,

417
00:24:43.140 --> 00:24:47.670
even routers are kind of taking a back
seat to the very fact that it's like,

418
00:24:47.670 --> 00:24:49.790
why don't we just connect
you to a layer 3 switch?

419
00:24:49.790 --> 00:24:52.490
And it's just another layer
3 network that's out there.

420
00:24:52.490 --> 00:24:54.880
So even routers are having
to take a back seat.

421
00:24:54.880 --> 00:24:57.010
Now just when I say that, right?

422
00:24:57.010 --> 00:24:59.090
If you need security, putting a router and

423
00:24:59.090 --> 00:25:04.600
a firewall in place is absolutely
100% the best way to go, okay?

424
00:25:04.600 --> 00:25:08.414
But you will see some networks that just
go, no, if it's just an Ethernet cable,

425
00:25:08.414 --> 00:25:08.952
plug it in.

426
00:25:08.952 --> 00:25:12.851
As long as it's on VLAN, you are off and
ready to go, route in between them, and

427
00:25:12.851 --> 00:25:14.110
you can do that.

428
00:25:14.110 --> 00:25:18.833
So if you hear the term layer 3 switch,
okay, or hear the term multilayer switch,

429
00:25:18.833 --> 00:25:22.154
that's probably the most
popular configuration today.

430
00:25:22.154 --> 00:25:26.714
But the other one where you actually do
attach a router, because of the way that

431
00:25:26.714 --> 00:25:31.430
the diagram ends up looking, the topology
is normally called router on a stick.

432
00:25:31.430 --> 00:25:33.870
>> I was about to say, isn't this the
whole router on a stick that we used to

433
00:25:33.870 --> 00:25:34.960
see back in the day all the time?

434
00:25:34.960 --> 00:25:37.173
>> It is, yeah, and
that's because it actually did look like,

435
00:25:37.173 --> 00:25:39.685
because people would draw a straight
line from the link to the router,

436
00:25:39.685 --> 00:25:41.534
it looked like a lollipop
sticking out of a switch.

437
00:25:41.534 --> 00:25:42.056
>> Yeah.

438
00:25:42.056 --> 00:25:43.194
[LAUGH]
>> Is what it would look like.

439
00:25:43.194 --> 00:25:44.062
>> [LAUGH]
>> So yeah,

440
00:25:44.062 --> 00:25:46.402
it's kind of funny cuz I was all like,
if I had called it router on a stick, and

441
00:25:46.402 --> 00:25:47.484
then somebody drew me the picture.

442
00:25:47.484 --> 00:25:49.295
I was like, that makes more sense.

443
00:25:49.295 --> 00:25:50.061
>> Router on a stick.

444
00:25:50.061 --> 00:25:52.348
>> It looks like a router,
and then it's on a stick.

445
00:25:52.348 --> 00:25:54.786
>> [CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, that's pretty much it, so

446
00:25:54.786 --> 00:25:55.576
that's what we had.

447
00:25:55.576 --> 00:25:57.612
Now over on the left-hand side,

448
00:25:57.612 --> 00:26:03.180
you will have trunk ports when you are
creating VLANs between multiple switches.

449
00:26:03.180 --> 00:26:06.910
The other thing that you'll also need
to do is you'll need to configure

450
00:26:06.910 --> 00:26:11.230
what is called either VLAN tagging or
encapsulation, okay?

451
00:26:11.230 --> 00:26:14.921
So today the most popular blend of this,
right,

452
00:26:14.921 --> 00:26:19.888
is what we call,
of course the 802.1q VLAN tagging, okay?

453
00:26:19.888 --> 00:26:24.256
So inside of the configuration though,
you'll call it encapsulation, but

454
00:26:24.256 --> 00:26:26.830
technically, there's no encapsulation.

455
00:26:26.830 --> 00:26:29.430
Then there's Cisco proprietary ISL,

456
00:26:29.430 --> 00:26:33.550
the Inter-Switch Linking type
of encapsulation, as well.

457
00:26:33.550 --> 00:26:37.180
And we'll get into more of this when
we get into the configuration itself.

458
00:26:37.180 --> 00:26:42.187
But these are just two different
ways to accomplish the ability

459
00:26:42.187 --> 00:26:48.300
to differentiate VLANS as they go
across trunk leaks, trunk links.

460
00:26:48.300 --> 00:26:50.250
I don't know where I missed the n,
but I did.

461
00:26:50.250 --> 00:26:53.410
Trunk leaks, so that's what happens, okay?

462
00:26:53.410 --> 00:26:55.630
So we'll actually see
where that's configured.

463
00:26:55.630 --> 00:27:01.300
The other thing that works as a benefit
for you and me are two layer 2 discovery

464
00:27:01.300 --> 00:27:07.120
protocols called cdp and lldp, which
we'll also need to get into, as well.

465
00:27:07.120 --> 00:27:10.870
Cisco Discovery Protocol and
Link Local Discovery Protocol.

466
00:27:10.870 --> 00:27:15.532
These are two very neat protocols
that allow us to find out

467
00:27:15.532 --> 00:27:18.210
a ton of information about our devices.

468
00:27:18.210 --> 00:27:20.402
And it also helps us when
we start to configure and

469
00:27:20.402 --> 00:27:23.408
we start having to troubleshoot,
it's gonna help out, as well.

470
00:27:23.408 --> 00:27:26.652
The last concept that we're
briefly gonna mention, and

471
00:27:26.652 --> 00:27:31.044
then when we get into the lab, we'll
kinda discuss it a little bit more here,

472
00:27:31.044 --> 00:27:33.766
is this term,
what we call native VLAN, okay?

473
00:27:33.766 --> 00:27:40.850
If you're using 802.1q, okay, you will
have something called a native vlan.

474
00:27:40.850 --> 00:27:45.907
Once you establish trunks and
you establish VLANS, every single thing

475
00:27:45.907 --> 00:27:50.551
that passes between these two switches,
it will have a VLAN tag.

476
00:27:50.551 --> 00:27:54.581
Like VLAN10, VLAN20, or VLAN5, 6, and 7.

477
00:27:54.581 --> 00:27:57.970
Whatever it has,
it will have that tag on it,

478
00:27:57.970 --> 00:28:02.175
except that if you're sending
data to the native VLAN.

479
00:28:02.175 --> 00:28:06.296
The native VLAN is essentially
traffic that is untagged.

480
00:28:06.296 --> 00:28:09.830
You might wonder like, why the heck
would I ever send data that's untagged?

481
00:28:09.830 --> 00:28:11.380
Well, that's a good question.

482
00:28:11.380 --> 00:28:16.150
Normally, you don't, but by default,
that's normally our management

483
00:28:16.150 --> 00:28:21.200
traffic is where we send data that's
actually untagged, is in that native VLAN.

484
00:28:21.200 --> 00:28:25.840
We normally do not want to put anything
in the native VLAN in terms of

485
00:28:25.840 --> 00:28:28.740
physical ports to be
assign to those VLANs.

486
00:28:28.740 --> 00:28:32.940
That means that nobody can access anything
else that's actually going through here.

487
00:28:32.940 --> 00:28:34.000
So we normally use this for

488
00:28:34.000 --> 00:28:37.900
management of the switches themselves
if we're doing remote management.

489
00:28:37.900 --> 00:28:40.230
But we'll get into that concept, too.

490
00:28:40.230 --> 00:28:41.570
So at the very beginning,

491
00:28:41.570 --> 00:28:46.250
though, when we start, this is another
thing that kind of gets confusing.

492
00:28:46.250 --> 00:28:49.530
By default, right,
on a single switch, okay?

493
00:28:49.530 --> 00:28:54.630
Without any configuration at all, your
default VLAN1, which is something that

494
00:28:54.630 --> 00:29:00.640
you can't get rid of,
is also by default your native VLAN.

495
00:29:00.640 --> 00:29:02.010
And it should make sense.

496
00:29:02.010 --> 00:29:06.170
And that's because, well,
at the beginning, there's only one VLAN.

497
00:29:06.170 --> 00:29:09.090
Well, which VLAN does it have to be in,
then?

498
00:29:09.090 --> 00:29:12.820
Has to be in the native one that
doesn't have anything tagged.

499
00:29:12.820 --> 00:29:15.940
So most people will never,
well, I say most people.

500
00:29:15.940 --> 00:29:18.068
A lot of companies, if they're small,

501
00:29:18.068 --> 00:29:21.022
they may never even deal with
the idea of needing VLANs.

502
00:29:21.022 --> 00:29:25.082
But as your network continues to grow,
and you do need more broadcast

503
00:29:25.082 --> 00:29:28.582
domains to segment traffic out
the way that you want to, but

504
00:29:28.582 --> 00:29:33.750
you only have a single switch, well,
VLANs will help you to be able to do that.

505
00:29:33.750 --> 00:29:38.570
If you continue to grow, and
now you need for multiple people or

506
00:29:38.570 --> 00:29:44.060
multiple devices to be on that same VLAN
even if they're on multiple switches,

507
00:29:44.060 --> 00:29:48.390
well, then we can also encompass that,
as well, by doing something like this.

508
00:29:48.390 --> 00:29:51.630
And trunking to allow for
this all to happen.

509
00:29:51.630 --> 00:29:55.720
So now that we have some basic
conceptual knowledge down, Daniel, okay?

510
00:29:55.720 --> 00:29:59.505
It means that we are going to be ready to
take a look at how we begin to configure

511
00:29:59.505 --> 00:30:00.284
these things.

512
00:30:00.284 --> 00:30:04.294
And we'll show you how the operate and
how they break in between when we don't

513
00:30:04.294 --> 00:30:08.400
have a layer 3 device setup to handle
the routing in between, as well.

514
00:30:08.400 --> 00:30:10.920
But Daniel, that is for another episode.

515
00:30:10.920 --> 00:30:12.960
So now that we've got
the conceptual knowledge down,

516
00:30:12.960 --> 00:30:14.800
it means we're ready to start configuring.

517
00:30:14.800 --> 00:30:18.670
>> All right, well, great introduction
to VLANS and our switching environments.

518
00:30:18.670 --> 00:30:21.064
Good stuff, definitely join us for
the next episode so

519
00:30:21.064 --> 00:30:22.896
we can see Ronnie put that into practice.

520
00:30:22.896 --> 00:30:26.580
It's gonna be a lot of fun and
a good learning experience for you.

521
00:30:26.580 --> 00:30:27.589
So Ronnie, thanks for joining us today.

522
00:30:27.589 --> 00:30:30.956
And we do thank you for watching, but
looks like we're at that time yet

523
00:30:30.956 --> 00:30:31.880
again to sign off.

524
00:30:31.880 --> 00:30:34.130
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

525
00:30:34.130 --> 00:30:35.060
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

526
00:30:35.060 --> 00:30:35.832
>> See you next time.

527
00:30:35.832 --> 00:30:42.380
[MUSIC]

528
00:30:42.380 --> 00:30:45.180
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe how to configure vlans and assign ports to vlans.  They configure and name vlans.  Once configured, they verified the configuration on the switch, preparing the switch to assign ports to the vlans.
episodes.title: Configure and Verify VLANs Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:02.103
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.103 --> 00:00:06.350
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.350 --> 00:00:08.044
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.044 --> 00:00:12.013
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

5
00:00:12.013 --> 00:00:13.806
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.806 --> 00:00:16.384
welcome back to another
great episode of ITPro TV.

7
00:00:16.384 --> 00:00:18.469
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

8
00:00:18.469 --> 00:00:21.840
in today's episode we're back
with more of CCENT series.

9
00:00:21.840 --> 00:00:25.437
And joining us in the studio, you him and
you love him, is the one Mr. Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:25.437 --> 00:00:27.270
Ronnie, welcome back man, how is it going?

11
00:00:27.270 --> 00:00:28.960
>> it is going well, Daniel, thank you for

12
00:00:28.960 --> 00:00:34.890
having me back on the show as we continue
now, of course, into our CCENT journey and

13
00:00:34.890 --> 00:00:41.020
we are of course talking about
configuring and verifying VLANs now.

14
00:00:41.020 --> 00:00:44.220
Now we already talked a little bit
about the idea of VLANs in terms of

15
00:00:44.220 --> 00:00:45.830
concepts and theories.

16
00:00:45.830 --> 00:00:49.960
Understanding that what it allows us to
do with a single switch is to break that

17
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:53.600
switch up or, as I like to call it,
chop that switch up logically, and

18
00:00:53.600 --> 00:00:57.500
I essentially create smaller switches
out of that particular VLAN.

19
00:00:57.500 --> 00:01:02.423
And then of course, if we actually go
across multiple switches we can make those

20
00:01:02.423 --> 00:01:06.685
VLANs span multiple switches,
thereby actually creating multiple

21
00:01:06.685 --> 00:01:10.750
broadcast domains across
multiple switches themselves.

22
00:01:10.750 --> 00:01:13.801
So, it allows us to do a lot
when we actually think about it,

23
00:01:13.801 --> 00:01:17.707
cuz if not then the single physical
device, especially a switch, is pretty

24
00:01:17.707 --> 00:01:22.510
much the limits of its broadcast domain is
the number of ports that it has available.

25
00:01:22.510 --> 00:01:25.810
So this allows us to be able
to use a switch more wisely or

26
00:01:25.810 --> 00:01:27.720
more conservatively if we need to.

27
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:31.707
Or it allows us to be able to also
deal with scalability, right?

28
00:01:31.707 --> 00:01:35.701
Continue the add in switches and
then continue to add those same VLANs and

29
00:01:35.701 --> 00:01:40.025
as long as we link them together with
trunk links they'll also of course be able

30
00:01:40.025 --> 00:01:43.384
to function as those VLANs
across those multiple switches.

31
00:01:43.384 --> 00:01:48.380
Thereby having multiple broadcast
domains regardless of what particular

32
00:01:48.380 --> 00:01:50.680
switch that that VLAN is on.

33
00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:54.550
If we actually do have them across all
them, they'll extend that way as well.

34
00:01:54.550 --> 00:01:56.970
So that is where we are picking up.

35
00:01:56.970 --> 00:02:01.430
So all we have to do now, Dan,
of course is, we wanna create some VLANs,

36
00:02:01.430 --> 00:02:05.410
we also of course want to
assign ports into the VLAN.

37
00:02:05.410 --> 00:02:10.260
So in this IDM conceptually, even though
we haven't talk in the configuration side,

38
00:02:10.260 --> 00:02:15.205
when we use VLANs, two steps
essentially have to be done here, okay?

39
00:02:15.205 --> 00:02:17.760
One is of course creating
the VLAN itself and

40
00:02:17.760 --> 00:02:21.550
then secondly we have to
assign ports into that VLAN.

41
00:02:21.550 --> 00:02:25.200
Because if we only do one or the other,
it's not really going to work.

42
00:02:25.200 --> 00:02:27.168
So we actually have to do both of them.

43
00:02:27.168 --> 00:02:30.590
Now, we're gonna show you a couple
of different methods to do that.

44
00:02:30.590 --> 00:02:32.501
One actually is gonna be
that two-step method,

45
00:02:32.501 --> 00:02:34.560
because they definitely
are gonna test you on that.

46
00:02:34.560 --> 00:02:39.830
And then the second one rolls everything
up into one big step as well.

47
00:02:39.830 --> 00:02:42.382
And both of them are valid
configurations but

48
00:02:42.382 --> 00:02:46.680
you should feel fairly comfortable with
the way to actually do both of them,

49
00:02:46.680 --> 00:02:49.382
is what you want to be able to know and
do, okay?

50
00:02:49.382 --> 00:02:52.429
So, Daniel, we're gonna open
up our practice labs here, and

51
00:02:52.429 --> 00:02:56.107
I've already got the lab set up for us and
I've turned it on, got it ready and

52
00:02:56.107 --> 00:02:58.197
powered up the way that
it needs to be here.

53
00:02:58.197 --> 00:03:03.428
So once I'm here I'm gonna select this
nycore1 switch that will actually

54
00:03:03.428 --> 00:03:09.090
allow me to connect to multiple devices
that are also around this is well.

55
00:03:09.090 --> 00:03:13.668
Now, when I start off, okay, and
I start to take a look at the switch here,

56
00:03:13.668 --> 00:03:18.031
one the first things that i want to do
is I want to identify where the VLANs

57
00:03:18.031 --> 00:03:22.667
actually are and if there's actually
any already pre-configured here.

58
00:03:22.667 --> 00:03:25.579
So let me go ahead and
type in show, before I do that,

59
00:03:25.579 --> 00:03:28.650
let me press Enter a couple of times here.

60
00:03:28.650 --> 00:03:29.730
At least I think I'm going to.

61
00:03:29.730 --> 00:03:30.770
There we go.

62
00:03:30.770 --> 00:03:34.350
And then get into of course
the privileged exec mode.

63
00:03:34.350 --> 00:03:35.990
Then show VLAN.

64
00:03:38.310 --> 00:03:42.877
And when I do that, it will start
bringing up the VLAN database here.

65
00:03:42.877 --> 00:03:47.103
Okay, now the VLAN database is
actually going to be a file,

66
00:03:47.103 --> 00:03:49.700
it's actually called vlan.dat.

67
00:03:49.700 --> 00:03:53.230
And that file,
when you shut down the actual switch, or

68
00:03:53.230 --> 00:03:58.415
if you reboot the switch, anything that
you configure in this gets written to that

69
00:03:58.415 --> 00:04:03.650
vlan.dat file, and
that vlan.dat file is on the flash, okay?

70
00:04:03.650 --> 00:04:08.790
So I'm emphasizing that again,
vlan.dat is not stored in VRAM,

71
00:04:08.790 --> 00:04:14.190
like where the startup-config is stored,
but is normally stored in flash.

72
00:04:14.190 --> 00:04:18.160
The reason why this is gonna become
important, even now for the exam,

73
00:04:18.160 --> 00:04:22.090
is cuz of course you have
to know where it's stored.

74
00:04:22.090 --> 00:04:25.893
But when you ever have to retask
that particular switch, or

75
00:04:25.893 --> 00:04:28.180
you're selling that switch.

76
00:04:28.180 --> 00:04:31.380
Or you're re-purposing, not re-task,
that's the term I was looking for.

77
00:04:31.380 --> 00:04:33.210
You're re-purposing that switch.

78
00:04:33.210 --> 00:04:35.820
Even if you get it back
to a factory default.

79
00:04:35.820 --> 00:04:39.210
Like you go okay, I'm just gonna
put it back to a factory default.

80
00:04:39.210 --> 00:04:43.850
One of the files that you have
to erase automatically, or

81
00:04:43.850 --> 00:04:48.570
secondarily I should say,
is the vlan.dat file.

82
00:04:48.570 --> 00:04:52.440
If you don't erase it, that means
that they have your VLAN information.

83
00:04:52.440 --> 00:04:55.260
Whoever you sell it to is gonna
also have your VLAN information.

84
00:04:55.260 --> 00:04:59.080
And even though that doesn't sound like
a lot, it's still actually not what is

85
00:04:59.080 --> 00:05:04.990
considered a factory default refresh
without deleting out that vlan.dat.

86
00:05:04.990 --> 00:05:08.760
So initially when you first boot
the switch up, it doesn't start off with

87
00:05:08.760 --> 00:05:12.790
the vlan.dat except for something like
this, which it really only has one VLAN

88
00:05:12.790 --> 00:05:17.770
configured with ports in it,
which is the default VLAN here.

89
00:05:17.770 --> 00:05:21.630
And notice that if you take a look at
the information that we're seeing, right?

90
00:05:21.630 --> 00:05:24.490
VLAN, and it gives us the name,
and this is the default one,

91
00:05:24.490 --> 00:05:28.460
the status right now is active as well.

92
00:05:28.460 --> 00:05:33.558
And then notice that there's also all of
these ports that are listed in here too.

93
00:05:33.558 --> 00:05:37.121
And that's every single port
on this particular switch, and

94
00:05:37.121 --> 00:05:39.485
it's all in that one VLAN at this point.

95
00:05:39.485 --> 00:05:44.162
Now, Daniel, I also end up seeing just
a little bit more information that I

96
00:05:44.162 --> 00:05:49.020
may have actually expected to see,
but I'm not exactly sure here.

97
00:05:49.020 --> 00:05:53.866
Is, notice there's actually these
other additional four VLANs that

98
00:05:53.866 --> 00:05:56.175
we see right here as well, okay?

99
00:05:56.175 --> 00:06:01.194
And when you take a look at it,
it begins with really 1002, right?

100
00:06:01.194 --> 00:06:05.179
And you actually see in the name of it,
which is kind of neat here,

101
00:06:05.179 --> 00:06:07.288
you see where it says FDDI, okay?

102
00:06:07.288 --> 00:06:10.953
Token ring, and then FDDI Inet here, and

103
00:06:10.953 --> 00:06:15.700
then also of course TR net,
whatever that is, okay?

104
00:06:15.700 --> 00:06:18.680
Now when you start seeing
any of this information.

105
00:06:18.680 --> 00:06:21.280
So you might be wondering,
what is this about?

106
00:06:21.280 --> 00:06:23.566
Well let's go back to our
base knowledge again,

107
00:06:23.566 --> 00:06:26.930
I wanna go back to the LSR model just
briefly for a moment here, Daniel.

108
00:06:26.930 --> 00:06:30.153
When we do this right, remember
when we talked about layer 2, okay?

109
00:06:30.153 --> 00:06:34.241
In the OSI model layer 2 doesn't
just mean for you and me,

110
00:06:34.241 --> 00:06:38.130
right, MAC addresses and
stuff like that, okay?

111
00:06:38.130 --> 00:06:40.910
Layer 2 information can
actually be anything.

112
00:06:40.910 --> 00:06:43.630
So it includes that Ethernet which,
actually for us logically,

113
00:06:43.630 --> 00:06:44.658
is the MAC address.

114
00:06:44.658 --> 00:06:49.517
But layer 2 though, Cisco was
actually built during that time and

115
00:06:49.517 --> 00:06:54.052
it said look, I don't wanna
limit myself to TCP/IP, okay?

116
00:06:54.052 --> 00:06:58.873
So, cuz I'm not gonna limit myself to
TCP/IP I'll also VLANs in here that

117
00:06:58.873 --> 00:07:03.695
will support other layer 1 and
then layer 2 technologies, such as FDDI,

118
00:07:03.695 --> 00:07:07.457
such as token ring,
such as all these other ones in there.

119
00:07:07.457 --> 00:07:12.940
And so they actually have their own VLANs
set up for even networks like that, okay?

120
00:07:12.940 --> 00:07:17.679
But the rest of these, right, are pretty
much gonna be, at least at this point,

121
00:07:17.679 --> 00:07:19.860
these are what we call legacy VLANs.

122
00:07:19.860 --> 00:07:22.937
We're really not going to use them for
anything,

123
00:07:22.937 --> 00:07:25.287
is what's gonna happen here, okay?

124
00:07:25.287 --> 00:07:29.181
So that's why you're also seeing this
because they're still around but

125
00:07:29.181 --> 00:07:31.271
nobody really essentially uses this.

126
00:07:31.271 --> 00:07:35.569
So that brings us into his kind
of weird gap here, Daniel,

127
00:07:35.569 --> 00:07:41.360
between VLAN 1 and then VLAN 1,001 here,
okay, is what we have.

128
00:07:41.360 --> 00:07:46.908
And normally if you actually consider
what they call normal range of VLANs,

129
00:07:46.908 --> 00:07:51.773
it actually goes from VLAN 1
all the way through VLAN 1,005.

130
00:07:51.773 --> 00:07:54.974
Even though these last few
here are not gonna be used and

131
00:07:54.974 --> 00:07:59.359
you see that also underneath that
status here, even though it's active,

132
00:07:59.359 --> 00:08:01.953
notice today they are unsupported, okay?

133
00:08:01.953 --> 00:08:06.297
So these aren't gonna be used,
So in all practicality,

134
00:08:06.297 --> 00:08:12.540
1 all the way through 1,001,
we can create those VLAN numbers, okay?

135
00:08:12.540 --> 00:08:13.220
And we can do that.

136
00:08:13.220 --> 00:08:17.280
So we can actually create VLAN,
and then VLAN 2.

137
00:08:17.280 --> 00:08:22.030
We can do that all the way through
VLAN 1,001, and we're perfectly fine.

138
00:08:22.030 --> 00:08:26.479
Once you start hitting 1,002 you might get
some weird message where it's like you're

139
00:08:26.479 --> 00:08:30.620
running TCP/IP, yeah, you're probably
not gonna wanna create that.

140
00:08:30.620 --> 00:08:31.130
But can you?

141
00:08:31.130 --> 00:08:33.100
Yes, if you wanted to, you can do that.

142
00:08:33.100 --> 00:08:36.190
But at this point you're probably
not gonna see that too often, okay?

143
00:08:36.190 --> 00:08:39.150
So it is still there and available for us.

144
00:08:39.150 --> 00:08:43.992
Now there are two special VLANs
that are not listed here as well.

145
00:08:43.992 --> 00:08:49.680
So even though they're actually
there we don't use them.

146
00:08:49.680 --> 00:08:55.167
There is a VLAN zero and
there's a VLAN 4,095 that's there but

147
00:08:55.167 --> 00:08:57.488
those are reserved, okay?

148
00:08:57.488 --> 00:08:59.763
You and are not gonna end
up using them for anything,

149
00:08:59.763 --> 00:09:01.510
those were kind of the default.

150
00:09:01.510 --> 00:09:08.270
So in theory it could support
up to 4,096 VLANs are possible.

151
00:09:08.270 --> 00:09:10.910
You might wonder like, where the heck
are these numbers coming from?

152
00:09:10.910 --> 00:09:15.006
Well, this is 2 to the 16th
power is the idea.

153
00:09:15.006 --> 00:09:17.689
It's actually the, [COUGH] excuse me,

154
00:09:17.689 --> 00:09:22.009
is actually that idea of those
bits that we're talking about.

155
00:09:22.009 --> 00:09:27.275
Actually, I'm lying to you, it's not 16,
4,096 is 12th or something?

156
00:09:27.275 --> 00:09:28.717
So I'm lying to you, it's at the 12th.

157
00:09:28.717 --> 00:09:30.348
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, it's 2 to the 12th power,

158
00:09:30.348 --> 00:09:32.395
that's what actually ends up happening.

159
00:09:32.395 --> 00:09:36.549
So once you get to 512,
I know that that's to the 9th power and

160
00:09:36.549 --> 00:09:42.240
then 1,024 is 12th,
13th power somewhere around there.

161
00:09:42.240 --> 00:09:48.770
But in theory you can create those,
but not all the time, okay?

162
00:09:48.770 --> 00:09:53.840
Once you get past 1,001 you go look,
I need more VLANs at more than likely,

163
00:09:53.840 --> 00:09:58.860
you're hitting this network range of like,
I have to have 1,000 VLANs.

164
00:09:58.860 --> 00:10:01.651
Something is insane here-
>> If you got a 1,000 VLANs,

165
00:10:01.651 --> 00:10:03.621
you have got a large network my friend.

166
00:10:03.621 --> 00:10:06.160
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's weird, right?

167
00:10:06.160 --> 00:10:08.385
Because see at this level we're, so what?

168
00:10:08.385 --> 00:10:12.300
1,000 VLANs and it's not gonna really
make sense to you why that's such a weird

169
00:10:12.300 --> 00:10:18.460
number until you starting chaining
multiple switches together, and

170
00:10:18.460 --> 00:10:22.520
we actually have a protocol that prevents
loops called spanning tree protocol.

171
00:10:22.520 --> 00:10:28.660
Well, one of those switches every
single frame has to pass through.

172
00:10:28.660 --> 00:10:32.090
So on that one switch,
if you had 1,000 VLAN,

173
00:10:32.090 --> 00:10:38.510
then that particular one switch became
the center of that spanning tree protocol.

174
00:10:38.510 --> 00:10:42.140
I mean, that means every single
packet from 1,000 VLANs.

175
00:10:42.140 --> 00:10:45.100
It doesn't matter if it has
to go through 1,500 switches,

176
00:10:45.100 --> 00:10:47.380
it's all got to be
filtered through that one.

177
00:10:47.380 --> 00:10:50.780
So that's why,
when Daniel you're kind of insane,

178
00:10:50.780 --> 00:10:53.170
it's because nobody wants to do that.

179
00:10:53.170 --> 00:10:58.070
But normally for the majority of us
1 through 1,001 technically through

180
00:10:58.070 --> 00:11:00.600
1,005 that's what's
called the normal range.

181
00:11:00.600 --> 00:11:04.820
But then beginning with 1,006
through 4,094 you actually what

182
00:11:04.820 --> 00:11:08.130
is called an extended range of VLANs.

183
00:11:08.130 --> 00:11:09.890
Now can you use those?

184
00:11:09.890 --> 00:11:14.390
Yes, but only when you are in
a multiple switch configuration.

185
00:11:14.390 --> 00:11:17.930
And only when you're actually
running VTP version 3,

186
00:11:17.930 --> 00:11:20.720
which is
Virtual Trunking Protocol Version 3.

187
00:11:20.720 --> 00:11:23.450
So they won't even show up in
the other virtual trunking protocols,

188
00:11:23.450 --> 00:11:25.020
which is version 1 and 2.

189
00:11:25.020 --> 00:11:29.290
Which of course version 1 and 2 are more
popular than version 4, so go figure.

190
00:11:29.290 --> 00:11:31.059
But those are possibilities and

191
00:11:31.059 --> 00:11:34.408
we're not really worried about
the idea of extended VLANs.

192
00:11:34.408 --> 00:11:36.443
So we're gonna stick to the normal ranges,

193
00:11:36.443 --> 00:11:39.330
is what we're gonna stick to
make sure that we understand it.

194
00:11:39.330 --> 00:11:41.530
But that's just kind of the idea

195
00:11:42.540 --> 00:11:45.942
of what we have when you start
seeing some of the information.

196
00:11:45.942 --> 00:11:47.300
All right, so now Daniel,

197

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe how to configure vlans and assign ports to vlans.  The team shows to configure the ports to assign to vlan.  They review the diferent port modes and show how to assign them to existing vlans.  They also show how to assign a port into and create a vlan within the interface configuration prompt. They create a default vlan to "park" our ports into when needed and lastly they configure a voice and data vlan to assign a single interface to both.
episodes.title: Configure and Verify VLANs Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie now work multiple switches.  They describe the benefits of doing so in an existing environment.  The team also shows how to make the switches work together by configuring trunks which allow for multiple vlans to flow over them.  They describe the use of vlan tagging 802.1q for allow trunks to keep the data tagged to a vlan. Lastly, the discuss the Native VLAN, this is the vlan in which the traffic is untagged and normally used for management and not port assignments
episodes.title: Configure Multiple Switches

00:13:57.320 --> 00:14:02.030

00:14:02.030 --> 00:14:05.150

00:14:05.150 --> 00:14:09.130
it's like pouring red paint

00:14:09.130 --> 00:14:13.830

262
00:14:13.830 --> 00:14:17.640

it allows you to work.

00:14:17.640 --> 00:14:19.350

00:14:19.350 --> 00:14:21.438
because that means somebody else

265
00:14:21.438 --> 00:14:24.730

then put another VLAN on, and

00:14:24.730 --> 00:14:27.122

00:14:27.122 --> 00:14:32.930
.1Q is different in this sense is

00:14:32.930 --> 00:14:38.030

00:14:38.030 --> 00:14:41.430

inside of it.

270
00:14:41.430 --> 00:14:48.120

sure that's 16 bits, that's two bytes.

271
00:14:48.120 --> 00:14:51.450

I can't remember which one it actually is.

272
00:14:51.450 --> 00:14:56.836
It actually inserts it in between,
inside of the frame itself,

273
00:14:56.836 --> 00:15:01.823
essentially changing not only
the header in the frame, but

274
00:15:01.823 --> 00:15:04.433

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie now work multiple switches. The guys continue by explaining how to manually configure vlans on all the switches to work over the trunk links and configure VTP, so that VLANs will automatically be configured on additional switches.
episodes.title: Configure Multiple Switches Part 2

My mind has actually disappeared on the

which I can't spell create,

All right, so

Now, the other thing

of course, is that that's pretty much

You can also set up

So any changes made on the VTP server

Is what you'll also end up seeing.

Now there are times that you may

So this one functions standalone.

00:23:41.380 --> 00:23:46.760
Yeah, I think there's gotta be something
with this particular switch here.

439
00:23:46.760 --> 00:23:49.905
That's the only thing I would
actually know at this point.

440
00:23:49.905 --> 00:23:54.045
Do show VLAN brief.

441
00:23:56.830 --> 00:23:57.662
All right, so there we go.

442
00:23:57.662 --> 00:24:02.410
So finally, you now see where I can
configure this particular VLAN on

443
00:24:02.410 --> 00:24:07.180
the one that's also designated as
being the primary VLAN as well, okay?

444
00:24:07.180 --> 00:24:11.450
So we've got that portion of
what we actually need done.

445
00:24:11.450 --> 00:24:14.020
At this point, when we configure this, and

446
00:24:14.020 --> 00:24:16.690
we make sure that everything can be done,
okay?

447
00:24:16.690 --> 00:24:21.280
So once we actually do that, right,
there's still a bit more for

448
00:24:21.280 --> 00:24:24.200
us to go, but we'll have to do
that in another part because I've

449
00:24:24.200 --> 00:24:26.580
run up against the time limit once again,
Daniel.

450
00:24:26.580 --> 00:24:28.070
So it looks like we are coming back for

451
00:24:28.070 --> 00:24:30.840
a part three on this particular lab.
>> Well, Ronnie,

452
00:24:30.840 --> 00:24:32.820
I can respect a man that knows his limits.

453
00:24:32.820 --> 00:24:35.780
And it looks like we've come to yours for
at least this episode anyway.

454
00:24:35.780 --> 00:24:38.828
I know that Ronnie is gonna dazzle us
when we come back for the next show.

455
00:24:38.828 --> 00:24:42.960
So, he likes to find good stopping spots,
which he does so well.

456
00:24:42.960 --> 00:24:46.360
Ronnie, thanks for joining us today,
thanks for helping us get thus far, we got

457
00:24:46.360 --> 00:24:49.760
plenty to chew on and to ruminate about
before we come back to that next part.

458
00:24:49.760 --> 00:24:51.430
But definitely come back and

459
00:24:51.430 --> 00:24:55.390
see Ronnie finish this VTP business up
because it's extremely helpful when

460
00:24:55.390 --> 00:24:58.200
it comes to configuring multiple
switches inside of a domain.

461
00:24:58.200 --> 00:24:59.100
Very good stuff.

462
00:24:59.100 --> 00:25:01.860
Ronnie, thanks again for joining us,
and we do thank you for watching, but

463
00:25:01.860 --> 00:25:02.890
guess what?

464
00:25:02.890 --> 00:25:05.520
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

465
00:25:05.520 --> 00:25:06.140
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

466
00:25:06.140 --> 00:25:08.582
>> And we'll see you next time.

467
00:25:08.582 --> 00:25:14.571
[MUSIC]

468
00:25:14.571 --> 00:25:16.560
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie now work multiple switches.  They describe the benefits of doing so in an existing environment.  They complete the vlan configuration with verification.  Also they create a Native VLAN on this trunk port.
episodes.title: Configure Multiple Switches Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:02.822
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:02.822 --> 00:00:06.155
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,
California [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.155 --> 00:00:08.163
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.163 --> 00:00:11.657
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.657 --> 00:00:13.511
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.511 --> 00:00:16.790
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.790 --> 00:00:19.590
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we are moving on,

8
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:23.560
moving forward and trying to get some
more information with this whole CCENT

9
00:00:23.560 --> 00:00:24.860
series we've been working on.

10
00:00:24.860 --> 00:00:27.550
And joining us back in the studio

00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:29.950

our good man Mr. Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:32.000
Ronnie, we're glad to have you back,

13
00:00:32.000 --> 00:00:33.210
>> It's going great, Daniel.

14
00:00:33.210 --> 00:00:37.080
Thank you for having me back so that I
can complete this lab that we're on.

15
00:00:37.080 --> 00:00:38.160
>> We have faith in you, Ronnie.

16
00:00:38.160 --> 00:00:40.967
>> And it's just one of those things,
I keep talking, and

there's a lot of stuff here
that you do need to practice.

18
00:00:43.858 --> 00:00:46.686
So make sure you go back through
this lab and walk through it,

19
