explain it to yourself as you go through,
just like I'm doing it.

20
00:00:50.070 --> 00:00:52.685
That way it gets into your mind
as you do that as well, okay?

21
00:00:52.685 --> 00:00:54.840
And we're just picking up
where we left off last time.

22
00:00:54.840 --> 00:00:58.940
We had just finished creating,
of course, the idea of using VTP.

23
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:03.404
Where we could show you that you had to
have a server before you could actually

24
00:01:03.404 --> 00:01:06.620
see the VLAN span across
the second switch.

25
00:01:06.620 --> 00:01:09.099
So now we want to go into
that second switch and

26
00:01:09.099 --> 00:01:11.768
we want to hard configure the other side.

27
00:01:11.768 --> 00:01:14.440
We don't wanna leave one side as
being dynamic trunk in protocol and

28
00:01:14.440 --> 00:01:15.720
the other side as being hard set.

29
00:01:15.720 --> 00:01:18.180
So lets go back to NYACCESS1.

30
00:01:18.180 --> 00:01:22.375
And there's not a lot of explanation
that I need to give right here, right?

31
00:01:22.375 --> 00:01:28.713
We're essentially duplicating the effort
that we have already done over on NYCORE1.

32
00:01:28.713 --> 00:01:33.500
So let's go ahead and
just get access into this, okay?

33
00:01:33.500 --> 00:01:36.044
So lets set up the trunking here,
interface.

34
00:01:38.566 --> 00:01:40.272
FA.

35
00:01:40.272 --> 00:01:43.110
Before I do that,
I think this is supposed to be,

36
00:01:43.110 --> 00:01:47.770
now I have to actually find out what
interface I was on, that's the only thing.

37
00:01:47.770 --> 00:01:51.450
And I think I have it typed wrong here,
if I remember correctly.

38
00:01:51.450 --> 00:01:53.976
So let's do, do show.

39
00:01:56.251 --> 00:01:57.227
Interface.

40
00:02:00.500 --> 00:02:01.801
Brief.

41
00:02:01.801 --> 00:02:06.456
IP interface brief, but even in a Switch,
IP interface brief will work for us.

42
00:02:10.068 --> 00:02:14.521
Let me make sure cuz I just looked down on
my notes, I'm like that's not right, okay,

43
00:02:14.521 --> 00:02:16.361
it's gonna be FA0/24, okay?

44
00:02:16.361 --> 00:02:21.016
So that's all I needed to verify cuz
I was about type in FA1/0/ something.

45
00:02:21.016 --> 00:02:24.562
Interface FA0/24,

46
00:02:24.562 --> 00:02:28.958
if I remember correctly here.

47
00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:35.150
Now, we're gonna do
a switchport mode trunk, okay?

48
00:02:35.150 --> 00:02:39.220
So notice that this side, it actually
took it without complaining like hey,

49
00:02:39.220 --> 00:02:41.640
encapsulation and all that stuff here.

50
00:02:41.640 --> 00:02:43.200
It said sure, we can go ahead and

51
00:02:43.200 --> 00:02:46.510
do that, you don't have to
really worry about it, okay?

52
00:02:46.510 --> 00:02:49.260
But we're still gonna hard set it, okay?

53
00:02:49.260 --> 00:02:53.690
Because I don't want there to be
any particular questions about this

54
00:02:53.690 --> 00:02:55.236
if anything fails here.

55
00:02:55.236 --> 00:03:01.901
It's gonna be switchport
trunk encap dot1q.

56
00:03:03.660 --> 00:03:06.701
Switchport, maybe if I can spell it.

57
00:03:06.701 --> 00:03:10.416
>> Switchport, here you go.

58
00:03:10.416 --> 00:03:11.309
[LAUGH]
>> Now,

59
00:03:11.309 --> 00:03:13.561
let me see cuz sometimes
it doesn't have it, okay?

60
00:03:13.561 --> 00:03:17.116
So here this done
a little bit differently,

61
00:03:17.116 --> 00:03:20.679
this switch is saying I only accept dot1q.

62
00:03:20.679 --> 00:03:25.500
So notice the encapsulation
command isn't even in there, okay?

63
00:03:25.500 --> 00:03:28.300
So you will also see that sometimes too.

64
00:03:28.300 --> 00:03:32.380
So whereas on 3750 it says no, I'll do the
encapsulation cuz I know I'll be hooked

65
00:03:32.380 --> 00:03:35.790
into different other switches that
may have it, may not have it.

66
00:03:35.790 --> 00:03:38.190
This one though, we'll only do dot1q, so

67
00:03:38.190 --> 00:03:43.700
even that encapsulation is not set
up here for what we want to do.

68
00:03:43.700 --> 00:03:45.120
So that's fine.

69
00:03:45.120 --> 00:03:47.770
So now that we got switch port mode trunk,
we are fine.

70
00:03:47.770 --> 00:03:48.560
Let's verify.

71
00:03:48.560 --> 00:03:52.790
Do show interface trunk.

72
00:03:52.790 --> 00:03:55.590
Make sure that everything is good.

73
00:03:55.590 --> 00:03:56.215
And there we go.

74
00:03:56.215 --> 00:04:02.550
So on NYACCESS1, FA24, it is trunking,
it is doing the dot1q.

75
00:04:02.550 --> 00:04:04.320
And the difference between this time and

76
00:04:04.320 --> 00:04:09.710
what we did in the first part of
this little mini series here, right?

77
00:04:09.710 --> 00:04:12.610
Is that we saw that the mode actually said

78
00:04:12.610 --> 00:04:16.030
auto at the very beginning when
we showed you this before.

79
00:04:16.030 --> 00:04:18.370
This time it says on, and
that is what you are looking for.

80
00:04:18.370 --> 00:04:19.696
If both sides say it is on,

81
00:04:19.696 --> 00:04:24.020
that means it's hard-set to do
what we want it to do, okay?

82
00:04:24.020 --> 00:04:28.975
Now, once we have this,
I want to now limit this, okay?

83
00:04:28.975 --> 00:04:32.866
Where is says VLANs allowed on the trunk.

84
00:04:32.866 --> 00:04:38.679
I don't have 4094, 4095 trunks here,
4095 trunks, I want to kind

85
00:04:38.679 --> 00:04:44.860
of limit this down to the VLANs that
are existing, or to the ones that I want.

86
00:04:44.860 --> 00:04:48.573
Now, in an environment where there
are many VLANs, you might wonder like,

87
00:04:48.573 --> 00:04:49.977
why do we want to limit this?

88
00:04:49.977 --> 00:04:54.201
It could where you create multiple
redundant trunk links between them, and

89
00:04:54.201 --> 00:04:58.560
what you want to do is you want to
distribute the traffic between them.

90
00:04:58.560 --> 00:05:03.090
You can say, I want VLANs 10 and
30 to go across this trunk link.

91
00:05:03.090 --> 00:05:06.580
I want VLANs 20 and 40 to go
across another trunk link instead.

92
00:05:06.580 --> 00:05:10.860
And that way it's not all kind of getting
bottlenecked in that single trunk.

93
00:05:10.860 --> 00:05:13.810
So you can use it for
your purposes like that as well.

94
00:05:13.810 --> 00:05:15.350
And also for security purposes.

95
00:05:15.350 --> 00:05:18.308
I shouldn't say security, logging,
I think is probably the better.

96
00:05:18.308 --> 00:05:21.523
So it makes it easier for you just to see
those logs instead of going I gotta do

97
00:05:21.523 --> 00:05:25.290
this, and then I gotta filter it down,
then I gotta filter it down here again.

98
00:05:25.290 --> 00:05:28.558
That way you can say okay, on this
interface, okay, here is all the even

99
00:05:28.558 --> 00:05:32.003
number of VLANs on this one, then you
can start limiting down as you need to.

100
00:05:32.003 --> 00:05:34.308
But that's what we wanna do at this point,
right?

101
00:05:34.308 --> 00:05:37.750
It's that we want to make sure that
it's configured this way, okay?

102
00:05:37.750 --> 00:05:42.410
But when you verify, make sure that
this says on, and not or DTP, or

103
00:05:42.410 --> 00:05:44.240
whatever else it might be.

104
00:05:44.240 --> 00:05:46.460
Both sides should be set to on.

105
00:05:46.460 --> 00:05:53.870
So how do we limit this one to only the
links that we want to do, or the VLANs?

106
00:05:53.870 --> 00:05:54.492
Let me click here.

107
00:05:55.977 --> 00:06:02.090
Switchport, trunk, and now I saw
that keyword there which is allowed.

108
00:06:02.090 --> 00:06:04.910
So up here at the top it says allowed,

109
00:06:04.910 --> 00:06:09.820
set allowed VLAN characteristic when
the interface is in trunking mode.

110
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:12.470
So on this one, switchport allowed here.

111
00:06:13.540 --> 00:06:20.620
VLAN, now I have to type in
the VLANSs separated by a comma.

112
00:06:20.620 --> 00:06:24.151
But here is another important syntax,

113
00:06:24.151 --> 00:06:29.187
you have to do comma, so
VLAN 10, comma, VLAN 20.

114
00:06:29.187 --> 00:06:32.931
Notice that there is no space, okay,

115
00:06:32.931 --> 00:06:37.617
in between VLAN 10 and VLAN 20 here, okay?

116
00:06:37.617 --> 00:06:42.376
You wanna make sure that there are no
spaces in between the VLANs, okay?

117
00:06:42.376 --> 00:06:46.183
If you don't, that, again,
is a syntax error, and

118
00:06:46.183 --> 00:06:51.190
in that syntax error, it's not gonna
be forgiven for you on the exam.

119
00:06:51.190 --> 00:06:53.595
It's just gonna say,
you should know better than this.

120
00:06:53.595 --> 00:06:55.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's the ones that kill you,

121
00:06:55.420 --> 00:06:56.680
this one space.

122
00:06:56.680 --> 00:06:58.430
But they expect you to
be able to see that and

123
00:06:58.430 --> 00:07:00.780
the difference when you
do something like this.

124
00:07:00.780 --> 00:07:04.470
So make sure you realize that that's
something that you will end up seeing

125
00:07:04.470 --> 00:07:06.150
as a possibility.

126
00:07:06.150 --> 00:07:07.860
Now, notice it accepts command,

127
00:07:07.860 --> 00:07:11.340
it doesn't give us any other
type of output to worry about.

128
00:07:11.340 --> 00:07:16.170
Now, let's compare the difference

129
00:07:16.170 --> 00:07:21.308
that we see right here when I run the same

130
00:07:21.308 --> 00:07:25.530
do show interface trunk again.

131
00:07:27.410 --> 00:07:30.090
Now, when we compare them, I think I
can actually get them both on screen.

132
00:07:30.090 --> 00:07:30.773
Yeah, cool, I can.
>> Here you go.

133
00:07:30.773 --> 00:07:31.947
>> I was trying to make sure.

134
00:07:31.947 --> 00:07:36.613
So here it is, VLANs allowed on
that trunk that we just created

135
00:07:36.613 --> 00:07:39.520
there before we did the VLAN allowed.

136
00:07:39.520 --> 00:07:44.308
And now, oops, [LAUGH] that shouldn't
be that difficult but darn,

137
00:07:44.308 --> 00:07:46.073
it's what it is, okay?

138
00:07:46.073 --> 00:07:50.500
And now notice the difference,
one has 4095 VLANs going across it.

139
00:07:50.500 --> 00:07:51.212
This one has two.

140
00:07:51.212 --> 00:07:51.871
>> Two.
[LAUGH] Dos.

141
00:07:51.871 --> 00:07:54.688
>> So yeah thought,
it makes it very easy for

142
00:07:54.688 --> 00:07:59.050
you to understand why this is
a good option for you to set.

143
00:07:59.050 --> 00:07:59.890
Now, can you allow for that?

144
00:07:59.890 --> 00:08:03.180
Yeah, notice that it says that a single
trunk can't handle all of this.

145
00:08:03.180 --> 00:08:05.972
But remember, when you're pushing
a high volume of traffic,

146
00:08:05.972 --> 00:08:09.470
it's still gonna end up having bottle
necks in terms of speed, right?

147
00:08:09.470 --> 00:08:13.070
If it's 100 megabit and you're
sending 200 megs, you gotta realize,

148
00:08:13.070 --> 00:08:14.220
it's gonna slow down.

149
00:08:14.220 --> 00:08:14.750
Okay?

150
00:08:14.750 --> 00:08:17.590
But overall, though,
it shouldn't normally for us,

151
00:08:17.590 --> 00:08:19.270
it's not gonna actually be that way.

152
00:08:19.270 --> 00:08:22.190
But you can kinda get the idea
that this is what happens here.

153
00:08:22.190 --> 00:08:22.730
Okay?

154
00:08:22.730 --> 00:08:26.320
So now that we have those
trunks configured here and

155
00:08:26.320 --> 00:08:29.905
the VLAN is essentially
limited in what we need.

156
00:08:29.905 --> 00:08:32.770
We've got everything set
up the way we want to.

157
00:08:32.770 --> 00:08:36.839
It is now time to start assigning
some ports to those VLANs.

158
00:08:36.839 --> 00:08:39.650
Now this is the one where
VTP doesn't help us.

159
00:08:39.650 --> 00:08:40.585
Okay?

160
00:08:40.585 --> 00:08:43.879
So I can't go to NYCORE1 and

161
00:08:43.879 --> 00:08:48.971
assign on NYACCESS1 a port into that VLAN.

162
00:08:48.971 --> 00:08:49.850
Okay?

163
00:08:49.850 --> 00:08:52.030
So I have to do this per switch, so this,

164
00:08:52.030 --> 00:08:55.290
when you can't allow VTP to handle for
you.

165
00:08:55.290 --> 00:08:59.590
So let's go over to
NYCORE1 if I can find it.

166
00:08:59.590 --> 00:09:00.130
There it is.

167
00:09:02.130 --> 00:09:03.455
NYCORE1.

168
00:09:06.122 --> 00:09:12.255
And let's assign some ports to VLANs.

169
00:09:15.751 --> 00:09:19.250
All right.

170
00:09:19.250 --> 00:09:22.240
So we're gonna assign the first.

171
00:09:22.240 --> 00:09:25.646
Yeah.
The first interface here,

172
00:09:25.646 --> 00:09:30.377
Interface fa1/0/1 into vlan 10.

173
00:09:33.566 --> 00:09:39.610
SO I need switchport mode access,
to hard is set as an access port.

174
00:09:39.610 --> 00:09:44.901
And then, switchport Access vlan 10.

175
00:09:46.321 --> 00:09:52.714
Then we're gonna do interface fa1/0/2,

176
00:09:52.714 --> 00:10:00.079
again, switchport mode access and
then switchport.

177
00:10:01.516 --> 00:10:04.929
Switchporrt, two Rs,
>> Switchport.

178
00:10:04.929 --> 00:10:07.360
>> Access, I know.

179
00:10:07.360 --> 00:10:07.860
Access 20.

180
00:10:08.971 --> 00:10:13.740
Make sure I'm doing the right ports here,
don't wanna get those wrong as well.

181
00:10:13.740 --> 00:10:17.810
Okay?
So that should do that for that one.

182
00:10:17.810 --> 00:10:22.300
We also want over on NY access now, okay?

183
00:10:22.300 --> 00:10:23.200
So just verifying.

184
00:10:23.200 --> 00:10:26.740
Now, we actually did have
a comment in our chatroom.

185
00:10:26.740 --> 00:10:31.670
Somebody is probably screaming a little
bit saying, Ronnie, you've done two

186
00:10:31.670 --> 00:10:36.080
of these different episodes now and
you haven't saved a single time.

187
00:10:36.080 --> 00:10:39.740
>> No, you haven't.
>> Yeah, I know, so let's do a save here.

188
00:10:39.740 --> 00:10:46.275
>> [INAUDIBLE] A real world
of hurt at that point.

189
00:10:46.275 --> 00:10:50.550
>> So do copy run start.

190
00:10:50.550 --> 00:10:55.736
Now, that is an abbreviation for
copy running-config

191
00:10:55.736 --> 00:10:59.510
startup-config, but
that's what it will also.

192
00:10:59.510 --> 00:11:00.940
It says it doesn't allow me to do that.

193
00:11:00.940 --> 00:11:02.270
Well, then I'm lying to you, okay?

194
00:11:02.270 --> 00:11:04.236
So apparently,
I have to actually do it out here.

195
00:11:04.236 --> 00:11:10.210
So copy running-config startup-config.

196
00:11:10.210 --> 00:11:11.330
So I wasn't expecting that.

197
00:11:11.330 --> 00:11:13.680
Usually it allows you to do

00:25:00.930 --> 00:25:05.250
switches you also have the same Native
VLAN between those switches as well.

423
00:25:05.250 --> 00:25:08.620
So Daniel, that's pretty much everything
that I needed to show you here.

424
00:25:08.620 --> 00:25:13.783
With that unusual, I say unusual, that
mistake by me of just mistaking that one

425
00:25:13.783 --> 00:25:19.350
entire concept for another one, you know,
I mean go figure, who else would do that?

426
00:25:19.350 --> 00:25:21.462
But, we've already talked
about the other one and

427
00:25:21.462 --> 00:25:23.570
that's what slipped into my mind here.

428
00:25:23.570 --> 00:25:27.314
So overall though Daniel, we actually see
that there's a lot of configuration right

429
00:25:27.314 --> 00:25:30.128
here for you to go through, so
make sure to take the time to do it.

430
00:25:30.128 --> 00:25:33.250
>> That's right, but VTP,
totally worth the effort to get it into,

431
00:25:33.250 --> 00:25:35.880
learn how it works, because it's
going to save you a lot of time and

432
00:25:35.880 --> 00:25:40.120
frustration if you figure out this is
exactly how I can configure all my

433
00:25:40.120 --> 00:25:42.414
switches to make sure they're running and
don't forget the trunking.

434
00:25:42.414 --> 00:25:44.979
It's a wonderful thing, so
Ronnie we do thank you for

435
00:25:44.979 --> 00:25:48.517
showing us how we can make that happen,
even though you had a little gaff.

436
00:25:48.517 --> 00:25:49.528
>> [LAUGH]
>> Not a big deal,

437
00:25:49.528 --> 00:25:50.905
we forgive around here Ronnie,

438
00:25:50.905 --> 00:25:52.316
it's not a huge problem,
>> That's who I am.

439
00:25:52.316 --> 00:25:53.616
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's right,

440
00:25:53.616 --> 00:25:54.939
we accept you man that's right.

441
00:25:54.939 --> 00:25:55.701
>> That's right.
[LAUGH]

442
00:25:55.701 --> 00:25:57.294
>> Ronnie thanks again for dropping by,

443
00:25:57.294 --> 00:25:58.600
always appreciate your time.

444
00:25:58.600 --> 00:26:00.930
And we appreciate you good
folks out there as well, but

445
00:26:00.930 --> 00:26:03.170
we are out of time when it
comes to this show anyway.

446
00:26:03.170 --> 00:26:06.551
But don't worry, we got plenty more in
the series to come, but as for this day we

447
00:26:06.551 --> 00:26:09.500
are gonna sign off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

448
00:26:09.500 --> 00:26:12.329
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong,
>> See you next time.

449
00:26:12.329 --> 00:26:18.273
[MUSIC]

450
00:26:18.273 --> 00:26:21.611
Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie take a look at Layer 2 discovery protocols.
episodes.title: Configure and Verify Layer 2 Protocols
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:04.161
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.161 --> 00:00:07.855
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:07.855 --> 00:00:11.316
>> Well hello, thank you for

4
00:00:11.316 --> 00:00:13.995
choosing ITProTV.

5
00:00:13.995 --> 00:00:16.520
Helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.520 --> 00:00:19.997
I'm your host Zach Memos with
this episode of Cisco CCENT.

7
00:00:19.997 --> 00:00:24.640
And we're gonna be taking a look at
layer 2 protocols with the one and

8
00:00:24.640 --> 00:00:25.930
only Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:25.930 --> 00:00:28.167
Ronnie, great to see you, sir.
>> Thank you for

10
00:00:28.167 --> 00:00:29.930
having me on the show, Zach.

11
00:00:29.930 --> 00:00:34.116
As we continue on in our CCENT journey
together and learning more about it.

12
00:00:34.116 --> 00:00:39.017
Today we are focusing in on some
additional layer 2 protocols that we need

13
00:00:39.017 --> 00:00:42.360
to know about,
as we prepare for that exam.

14
00:00:42.360 --> 00:00:46.543
So today, we're gonna be taking a look at
some that really help in the management

15
00:00:46.543 --> 00:00:49.569
of, well, for us,
switches is what we're going to see.

16
00:00:49.569 --> 00:00:50.332
>> Well, Ronnie,

17
00:00:50.332 --> 00:00:51.755
what are layer two protocols?

18
00:00:51.755 --> 00:00:52.403
What are they?
And

19
00:00:52.403 --> 00:00:55.709
what do they do?
>> Okay, when it comes down to it, for

20
00:00:55.709 --> 00:00:59.396
us, the layer 2 protocols that we're
specifically gonna be addressing

21
00:00:59.396 --> 00:01:01.783
are gonna be what we
call discovery protocols.

22
00:01:01.783 --> 00:01:06.530
The idea of discovery protocols, they work
at layer 2 of the OSI model, which means,

23
00:01:06.530 --> 00:01:09.720
of course,
the data-link layer of the OSI model.

24
00:01:09.720 --> 00:01:13.446
They allow us to discover devices
that are directly connected.

25
00:01:13.446 --> 00:01:16.950
And so
these are very important protocols for us,

26
00:01:16.950 --> 00:01:20.210
because of all that they
really allow us to do.

27
00:01:20.210 --> 00:01:24.571
That allowance of discovery really
helps out when you are faced with

28
00:01:24.571 --> 00:01:29.251
a situation in which you cannot clearly
lay out a nice diagram of things.

29
00:01:29.251 --> 00:01:33.850
And all the sudden, you're still having to
discover what device is connected to what.

30
00:01:33.850 --> 00:01:38.540
So sometimes you will get instances where
you'll see kind of a mess of things,

31
00:01:38.540 --> 00:01:43.316
like a bird's nest of different devices
that are all stacked nicely together.

32
00:01:43.316 --> 00:01:48.040
But so many additional wires that
are out there, that it becomes much more

33
00:01:48.040 --> 00:01:53.350
difficult to be able to figure out
exactly what device is plugged into what.

34
00:01:53.350 --> 00:01:57.784
This type of protocol is really going
to help us to figure that out as well.

35
00:01:57.784 --> 00:01:59.624
So that's why we're jumping into this.

36
00:01:59.624 --> 00:02:03.528
Now, when we start to talk about this,
this is part of the exam objectives and

37
00:02:03.528 --> 00:02:07.250
understanding this, and we wanna
show you all that we can about it.

38
00:02:07.250 --> 00:02:10.835
But there is no official labs
in the practice labs guides for

39
00:02:10.835 --> 00:02:12.277
us to be able to do this.

40
00:02:12.277 --> 00:02:14.997
So let's go ahead and
take a look at my machine, and

41
00:02:14.997 --> 00:02:17.340
this will kind of help us out.
>> Okay.

42
00:02:17.340 --> 00:02:19.181
>> Now, over here on the left hand side,

43
00:02:19.181 --> 00:02:21.601
if you open up of course
your practicelabs.com,

44
00:02:21.601 --> 00:02:23.457
you can chose any lab that you want to.

45
00:02:23.457 --> 00:02:26.528
And here's the diagram that you're
given for every single lab.

46
00:02:26.528 --> 00:02:28.612
And all you're doing is you're
configuring different devices.

47
00:02:28.612 --> 00:02:31.410
You get through all the scenarios
that they're putting you through.

48
00:02:31.410 --> 00:02:33.755
But notice how nicely it's laid out.

49
00:02:33.755 --> 00:02:38.115
Everything is actually directly connected
too, and you see all the labeling,

50
00:02:38.115 --> 00:02:41.560
all the diagrams and
all that stuff when you see that.

51
00:02:41.560 --> 00:02:45.829
But in reality it's not that there's
a room somewhere on this planet in which

52
00:02:45.829 --> 00:02:50.099
every device is actually laid out like
in this triangular pattern that you see

53
00:02:50.099 --> 00:02:50.835
right here.

54
00:02:50.835 --> 00:02:53.715
And a straight cable going
to a Cisco IP phone, and

55
00:02:53.715 --> 00:02:56.810
another cable laid out where
there's a router here.

56
00:02:56.810 --> 00:03:00.025
And then another one laid out over here,
and then a frame relay switch.

57
00:03:00.025 --> 00:03:03.200
And it's not laid out that way.

58
00:03:03.200 --> 00:03:08.183
In all reality, Zach, all these are
probably mounted inside of a rack that you

59
00:03:08.183 --> 00:03:11.519
have, and
they're stacked one on top of the other.

60
00:03:11.519 --> 00:03:15.824
And that cabling that you're
seeing here that's so nicely,

61
00:03:15.824 --> 00:03:20.636
logically laid out for us is not in
that existence, in that pattern.

62
00:03:20.636 --> 00:03:23.544
So even though physically,
it doesn't look like this,

63
00:03:23.544 --> 00:03:25.800
this is how logically it lays out.

64
00:03:25.800 --> 00:03:28.893
When you get hired as
a Cisco professional,

65
00:03:28.893 --> 00:03:34.424
there is gonna be sometimes you inherit
this network of devices that you have.

66
00:03:34.424 --> 00:03:38.710
And now you're asked to make heads or
tails of this.

67
00:03:38.710 --> 00:03:43.337
Well, the only way that you normally can
actually make a nice logical diagram is if

68
00:03:43.337 --> 00:03:46.099
you had put it together yourself,
very easily.

69
00:03:46.099 --> 00:03:49.377
But now you see wires
upon wires upon wires.

70
00:03:49.377 --> 00:03:52.796
And you're not exactly sure
what is connected to what.

71
00:03:52.796 --> 00:03:57.230
And this way what we can do is we
can use something that we call

72
00:03:57.230 --> 00:04:02.110
Cisco Discovery Protocol, or
CDP as it's more commonly known,

73
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:03.812
to allow us to do this.

74
00:04:03.812 --> 00:04:08.370
Now the great thing about this
is that on Cisco devices they

75
00:04:08.370 --> 00:04:11.010
are normally turned on already.

76
00:04:11.010 --> 00:04:14.434
So Cisco has their own
proprietary discovery protocol,

77
00:04:14.434 --> 00:04:16.938
called CDP, Cisco Discovery Protocol.

78
00:04:16.938 --> 00:04:20.200
And just about on every device,
whether it's a router or a switch,

79
00:04:20.200 --> 00:04:24.196
it is turned on, and it is communicating.
>> But that only works on Cisco equipment.

80
00:04:24.196 --> 00:04:25.479
Is that right, Ronnie?
>> It

81
00:04:25.479 --> 00:04:25.979
is.
>> Okay.

82
00:04:25.979 --> 00:04:26.704
>> It's only Cisco

83
00:04:26.704 --> 00:04:28.000
proprietary at this point.
>> Okay.

84
00:04:28.000 --> 00:04:29.924
>> So that means if you don't have

85
00:04:29.924 --> 00:04:31.330
all Cisco equipment,

86
00:04:31.330 --> 00:04:33.782
some devices will not respond.
And

87
00:04:33.782 --> 00:04:36.624
we'll address that in a few moments here.
But at the beginning,

88
00:04:36.624 --> 00:04:40.767
since we're dealing with the idea of Cisco
equipment, we'll stick with that idea for

89
00:04:40.767 --> 00:04:41.540
now.
>> Good.

90
00:04:41.540 --> 00:04:42.973
>> So let's go ahead and

91
00:04:42.973 --> 00:04:47.162
take a look just by default here.
The key to remember, as far as getting

92
00:04:47.162 --> 00:04:51.249
ready for the exam as well, is that this
particular protocol works on layer 2.

93
00:04:51.249 --> 00:04:53.913
Now it's gonna be funny, cuz we're gonna

94
00:04:53.913 --> 00:04:57.837
see some layer 3 information which
kind of violates the rule of

95
00:04:57.837 --> 00:05:01.458
separation that we do in the OSI model.
But it is in there,

96
00:05:01.458 --> 00:05:04.149
it allows us to see a lot.
So let's take this for example.

97
00:05:04.149 --> 00:05:06.878
Now Zach, I briefly showed you a flash on

98
00:05:06.878 --> 00:05:11.412
my screen of the diagram that's laid out.
Now, just now Zach, do you have

99
00:05:11.412 --> 00:05:15.931
the memory of how everything is laid out?
So if I were to say this, Zach, right now,

100
00:05:15.931 --> 00:05:19.918
what devices are connected to NYCORE1?
Just from your memory of that diagram,

101
00:05:19.918 --> 00:05:22.372
what are your chances of
actually recalling those devices

102
00:05:22.372 --> 00:05:24.522
that are connected?
>> I would say slim to

103
00:05:24.522 --> 00:05:25.317
none.
>> [LAUGH]

104
00:05:25.317 --> 00:05:27.234
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, slim to none, right?

105
00:05:27.234 --> 00:05:28.651
And I would say the same thing.

106
00:05:28.651 --> 00:05:29.839
Even though I've looked at that

107
00:05:29.839 --> 00:05:32.176
diagram and I know some of
the devices that are connected to it.

108
00:05:32.176 --> 00:05:33.988
But my memory is not that great

109
00:05:33.988 --> 00:05:34.779
either.
>> Right.

110
00:05:34.779 --> 00:05:36.802
>> So the great thing is those devices

111
00:05:36.802 --> 00:05:41.900
are Cisco devices.
And unless somebody has turned it off from

112
00:05:41.900 --> 00:05:47.365
the default then we should be
able to discover quickly what

113
00:05:47.365 --> 00:05:53.080
devices are directly connected to NYCORE1.
So let's go ahead and

114
00:05:53.080 --> 00:05:54.992
show how you can do this.
>> Excellent.

115
00:05:54.992 --> 00:05:56.580
>> So right here in the NYCORE1,

116
00:05:56.580 --> 00:05:59.278
I've selected that over
here on the left hand side.

117
00:05:59.278 --> 00:06:01.359
That brought me to this router.

118
00:06:01.359 --> 00:06:04.246
I'm going to get access in, I have to type

119
00:06:04.246 --> 00:06:08.589
in their little typing box here.
Get access after the user mode here and

120
00:06:08.589 --> 00:06:13.063
to the privilege exec mode.
From this point I can use a show command.

121
00:06:13.063 --> 00:06:14.832
Let me type in show cdp and

122
00:06:14.832 --> 00:06:19.212
then a question mark so
that we can see some of the things that we

123
00:06:19.212 --> 00:06:21.685
actually want to explore here.
And

124
00:06:21.685 --> 00:06:24.750
we're not gonna explore too
many commands at this point.

125
00:06:24.750 --> 00:06:30.160
But for us, you have CDP entry,
information for a specific neighbor entry.

126
00:06:30.160 --> 00:06:33.542
So if I know of a specific device,
I can do that.

127
00:06:33.542 --> 00:06:37.965
Now the great thing about CDP, though,
is that it works very well as long

128
00:06:37.965 --> 00:06:41.920
as there's a couple of
prerequisites that are made.

129
00:06:41.920 --> 00:06:46.262
One, of course, is the ports that you
are connecting to from this device.

130
00:06:46.262 --> 00:06:47.730
They have to be on.

131
00:06:47.730 --> 00:06:51.443
So if that port is turned off,
it's not gonna send back information.

132
00:06:51.443 --> 00:06:52.486
So it has to be on.

133
00:06:52.486 --> 00:06:54.431
So that's one of prerequisites.

134
00:06:54.431 --> 00:06:59.227
The other one that helps to identify
these devices incredibly well is that you

135
00:06:59.227 --> 00:07:02.280
need to assign a host
name to every device.

136
00:07:02.280 --> 00:07:05.473
In other words, give it a name that you
can identify is pretty much the key.

137
00:07:05.473 --> 00:07:08.408
And we do that using
that host name command.

138
00:07:08.408 --> 00:07:12.070
So on every device inside your network,
make sure that there's a host name.

139
00:07:12.070 --> 00:07:16.189
You do not want the generic name that's
there, because even though it will work,

140
00:07:16.189 --> 00:07:19.785
it would be a lot harder to discover
what devices you are connected too.

141
00:07:19.785 --> 00:07:23.428
The great thing is, in our network
topology and our diagram that we

142
00:07:23.428 --> 00:07:27.348
showed you, all the devices already
have a host name assigned to them.

143
00:07:27.348 --> 00:07:29.189
The other thing that you can also do here.

144
00:07:29.189 --> 00:07:32.512
So when you start seeing it,
is notice as I showed CDP and

145
00:07:32.512 --> 00:07:34.440
then I typed in interface here.

146
00:07:34.440 --> 00:07:38.363
It says, show me the interface status and
the configuration.

147
00:07:38.363 --> 00:07:41.496
There's something else that
we can do with CDP as well.

148
00:07:41.496 --> 00:07:45.700
By default it's enabled for
every single port.

149
00:07:45.700 --> 00:07:49.508
So that means that any device that
connects to this switch on any one

150
00:07:49.508 --> 00:07:51.552
of the ports that's on the switch.

151
00:07:51.552 --> 00:07:55.431
CDP will work with it as long as
the other side is also working with it.

152
00:07:55.431 --> 00:08:02.320
So it's not limited, but can I turn off,
CDP firm, the global switch.

153
00:08:02.320 --> 00:08:05.695
In other words, every port and
just enable it on the port that I want to,

154
00:08:05.695 --> 00:08:06.820
yes.
>> Perfect.

155
00:08:06.820 --> 00:08:08.290
>> So I can actually limit

156
00:08:08.290 --> 00:08:11.160
what I want to go out of it
if I want to as well, okay.

157
00:08:11.160 --> 00:08:13.760
But the one that we're gonna
spend time on right now

158
00:08:13.760 --> 00:08:17.420
is really this third one here
which is show CDP neighbors.

159
00:08:17.420 --> 00:08:22.529
So if I can go in and type show cdp
neighbors, and you don't really have

160
00:08:22.529 --> 00:08:27.560
to type out the whole thing as long
as it's enough to be unambiguous.

161
00:08:27.560 --> 00:08:31.430
But let's go ahead and type out
the whole thing for a good measure here.

162
00:08:31.430 --> 00:08:36.680
When I press Return here,
if CDP is enabled on all of the devices.

163
00:08:36.680 --> 00:08:39.320
Let me go ahead and
zoom in just a little bit more here.

164
00:08:40.510 --> 00:08:42.860
Then we can see this,
I don't want to get too far in.

165
00:08:42.860 --> 00:08:47.300
Let me see if I can zoom up a little bit
so that we can see the whole thing, okay.

166
00:08:47.300 --> 00:08:52.560
So now if you look at the screen down here
at the bottom, you see the information.

167
00:08:52.560 --> 00:08:55.400
It say, Global CDP information and

168
00:08:55.400 --> 00:09:01.470
that means on the entire switch it is
sending CDP packets every 60 seconds.

169
00:09:01.470 --> 00:09:06.950
So it is communicating with other devices
that are also using CDP every minute.

170
00:09:06.950 --> 00:09:10.850
Notice there's also a sending hold
time value of 180 seconds, okay.

171
00:09:11.870 --> 00:09:15.820
Now this idea of the 180 time
hold seconds, what is that about?

172
00:09:15.820 --> 00:09:20.630
If it doesn't hear from a neighbor,
okay, in 180 seconds,

173
00:09:20.630 --> 00:09:25.780
it will drop that connection thinking
that, hey, that connection is gone, okay.

174
00:09:25.780 --> 00:09:28.280
But it will actually wait 180 seconds,

175
00:09:28.280 --> 00:09:33.230
just in case Zach rebooted that router or
rebooted that switch.

176
00:09:33.230 --> 00:09:35.410
It says, eh, it'll come up here.

177
00:09:35.410 --> 00:09:40.360
And it'll actually keep that information
down here at the bottom, for 180 seconds.

178
00:09:40.360 --> 00:09:45.195
Every 60 seconds it's communicating, but
if it doesn't hear from a neighbor in that

179
00:09:45.195 --> 00:09:49.360
180 seconds, then it will kind of get rid
of it and then try and discover it again.

180
00:09:49.360 --> 00:09:53.917
It's also sending CDP version two
advertisements, so what we are getting is,

181
00:09:53.917 --> 00:09:56.260
of course, CDP advertisements.

182
00:09:56.260 --> 00:09:59.330
It's essentially advertising
information back to this router.

183
00:09:59.330 --> 00:10:01.530
And so
what kind of information is showing?

184
00:10:01.530 --> 00:10:03.190
Let's take a look down here at the bottom.

185
00:10:03.190 --> 00:10:07.260
Let me see if I can scroll up
here to help that out, right.

186
00:10:07.260 --> 00:10:09.280
So yeah,
now we can actually see a little bit more.

187
00:10:09.280 --> 00:10:12.750
I wanna try and leave those capability
codes so that we can see this.

188
00:10:12.750 --> 00:10:15.440
Notice over here, Zach,
on the left-hand side.

189
00:10:15.440 --> 00:10:15.940
>> Mm-hm.

190
00:10:16.990 --> 00:10:19.790
I have the device ID.

191
00:10:19.790 --> 00:10:22.440
Now that device ID,
what if I don't set up a host name?

192
00:10:22.440 --> 00:10:26.230
If I do not set up a host name,
you'll end up seeing that it would just

193
00:10:26.230 --> 00:10:30.780
copy that platform information
over here to device ID.

194
00:10:30.780 --> 00:10:33.630

The other thing that you see along with

00:13:37.520 --> 00:13:39.600
Now this is part of that messaging

00:13:39.600 --> 00:13:44.020
the advertisements that you and I are

00:13:44.020 --> 00:13:47.492
Now CDP works based on

00:13:47.492 --> 00:13:51.600
That means every device that's out there
that's using CDP and broadcasts that, and

00:13:51.600 --> 00:13:56.770
as long as those CDP messages are received

254
00:13:56.770 --> 00:13:58.420
it will receive that as well.
>> Yeah,

255
00:13:58.420 --> 00:14:00.020
the broadcast goes out to everybody.
>> Yep,

256
00:14:00.020 --> 00:14:01.470
it goes out to everybody.

00:14:01.470 --> 00:14:03.460

down here at the bottom, I'll notice

So NYACCESS, NYEDGE1,

What I have to do to enable it, cdp run.

Well, you can, but there's really

00:17:37.300 --> 00:17:39.950
We can set all that up, but normally,

00:17:39.950 --> 00:17:44.480

00:17:44.480 --> 00:17:45.880

00:17:45.880 --> 00:17:49.558
What if I want to mix other vendors'

00:17:49.558 --> 00:17:50.228
>> Okay, well,

00:17:50.228 --> 00:17:53.100
if you want to do that, obviously,
CDP is not going to work.

320
00:17:53.100 --> 00:17:56.870
So does that mean that those other
devices cannot be discovered for

00:17:56.870 --> 00:17:58.595

322
00:17:58.595 --> 00:18:02.860
No, the other Layer Two Protocol, that of
course is actually probably the one that

323
00:18:02.860 --> 00:18:08.930
you'll end up running more often
today than not, is what we call LLDP,

324
00:18:08.930 --> 00:18:12.360
which stands for
Link Layer Discovery Protocol.

325
00:18:12.360 --> 00:18:15.810
This is an industry-standard
version of CDP, and

326
00:18:15.810 --> 00:18:19.640
it is used with multiple vendors,
including Cisco.

327
00:18:19.640 --> 00:18:24.340
So Cisco can run both, either CDP or LLDP.

328
00:18:24.340 --> 00:18:27.280
It doesn't matter to Cisco
which one you chose to do.

329
00:18:27.280 --> 00:18:28.147
It of course says,

330
00:18:28.147 --> 00:18:31.740
look, we're not gonna enable the industry
standard when we can enable ours.

331
00:18:31.740 --> 00:18:35.560
So LLDP is not enabled by
default when you do this.

332
00:18:35.560 --> 00:18:38.800
Now, this one requires a little bit
more setup if you choose to do this

333
00:18:38.800 --> 00:18:39.810
one instead.

00:18:39.810 --> 00:18:45.287
So let me see if I can pick

00:18:45.287 --> 00:18:50.004
We'll use NYCORE2 since this is

00:18:57.101 --> 00:19:01.181
Now, the first thing I'm going to

00:19:19.850 --> 00:19:23.820

00:19:23.820 --> 00:19:28.650
On NYCORE2 here,

00:19:28.650 --> 00:19:31.990

00:19:33.340 --> 00:19:34.791
Let me do a question mark if

00:19:34.791 --> 00:19:36.480

00:19:36.480 --> 00:19:41.836
lldp, let's just do that one,

00:19:41.836 --> 00:19:43.810
All right, I've jumped ahead of myself.

00:19:43.810 --> 00:19:47.580
I was looking for LLDP receive,

00:19:47.580 --> 00:19:48.740
But I do see the one that I need,

00:19:48.740 --> 00:19:51.743
which is LLDP enable, which is run.

now lldp run will go ahead and

00:19:58.695 --> 00:20:04.190

And let's go ahead and

And then let's do an lldp run, okay?

00:20:18.290 --> 00:20:23.400
Now, on these two devices, I've turned

00:20:23.400 --> 00:20:25.440
But on all the other devices, I haven't.

00:20:25.440 --> 00:20:30.830
So at this point, we should be able

00:20:30.830 --> 00:20:32.560
Let's do a show lldp.

00:20:33.920 --> 00:20:40.100
Let me go back out to our

00:20:40.100 --> 00:20:42.990
Let's do a question mark to see

00:20:42.990 --> 00:20:46.480
So at this point, it is showing me
just a couple of things, right?

366
00:20:46.480 --> 00:20:51.980
It says the status is active, LLDP
advertisements are sent every 30 seconds.

367
00:20:51.980 --> 00:20:53.625
So notice this one is different, right?

368
00:20:53.625 --> 00:20:56.070
LLDP does it every 30 seconds.

369
00:20:56.070 --> 00:20:59.225
And the hold time is
a 120 seconds instead,

370
00:20:59.225 --> 00:21:04.040
whereas CDP was every 60 seconds,
hold time 180 seconds, okay?

371
00:21:04.040 --> 00:21:09.300
LLDP about half that time, and

00:21:09.300 --> 00:21:12.769
If the other neighbor doesn't respond in

00:21:14.157 --> 00:21:19.655

well, maybe not, it won't let me do that.

398
00:22:23.920 --> 00:22:28.155
So depending on your particular network

00:22:28.155 --> 00:22:30.786

00:22:30.786 --> 00:22:33.666
But if it's a mixed environment,

If it's gonna be a single environment such

00:22:38.341 --> 00:22:40.750
Cisco is the one that's preferred.

00:22:40.750 --> 00:22:43.860
But if you know that you're gonna be

00:22:43.860 --> 00:22:48.000

00:22:48.000 --> 00:22:52.460

00:22:52.460 --> 00:22:55.680
But it is very powerful, especially when

407
00:22:55.680 --> 00:22:57.760
you need to discover it quickly.

408
00:22:57.760 --> 00:23:03.410
The way to do so is using either one of
those two Link Layer Discovery Protocols

409
00:23:03.410 --> 00:23:04.790
that's there.

417
00:23:22.860 --> 00:23:26.940
So you won't see a lot on it, but
you might actually see a question or two.

418
00:23:26.940 --> 00:23:28.360
Make sure you know that acronym.

419
00:23:28.360 --> 00:23:32.710
Make sure you understand what its purpose
is and that it works at layer two.

420
00:23:32.710 --> 00:23:34.724
And the funny thing,
a lot of times, right,

421
00:23:34.724 --> 00:23:38.630
is even though it works at layer two,
there are more commands in show cdp.

422
00:23:38.630 --> 00:23:40.330
And you can do those on your own.

423
00:23:40.330 --> 00:23:44.100
It will show you layer three information,
which technically it's not supposed to,

424
00:23:44.100 --> 00:23:46.400
but it does, on CDP at least.

425
00:23:46.400 --> 00:23:49.600
So just go ahead and see, and
you'll actually see that there's more.

426
00:23:49.600 --> 00:23:54.620
But at least for us, for the CCENT, this
will be plenty for us to get started with.

427
00:23:54.620 --> 00:23:56.140
>> Great job, Ronnie, thank you so much.

428
00:23:56.140 --> 00:23:58.640
And Cisco CCENT is a wonderful series.

429
00:23:58.640 --> 00:24:00.472
Make sure you watch each and
every episode.

430
00:24:00.472 --> 00:24:01.760
You'll be glad you did.

431
00:24:01.760 --> 00:24:04.860
And you'll be in the course library,
where there's thousands of other videos.

432
00:24:04.860 --> 00:24:07.790
And they're there to help you go further,
check those out.

433
00:24:07.790 --> 00:24:09.642
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

434
00:24:09.642 --> 00:24:11.640
ITProTV is binge-worthy.

435
00:24:11.640 --> 00:24:13.900
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

436
00:24:13.900 --> 00:24:16.257
>> And we will see you soon.

437
00:24:16.257 --> 00:24:22.166
[MUSIC]

438
00:24:22.166 --> 00:24:25.419
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce the concept of port-security. They discuss different violation modes and the need for "switchport port-security."
episodes.title: Configure and Verify Port Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:02.730
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.730 --> 00:00:06.264
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.264 --> 00:00:08.282
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.282 --> 00:00:12.857
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, thank you for

5
00:00:12.857 --> 00:00:16.455
choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn everywhere you go.

6
00:00:16.455 --> 00:00:19.625
I'm your host Zach Memos and
we continue on with CISCO CCENT.

7
00:00:19.625 --> 00:00:23.895
We're gonna configure and
verify port security with the one and

8
00:00:23.895 --> 00:00:27.075
only Ronnie Wong.
>> [LAUGH] Thank you Zach for

9
00:00:27.075 --> 00:00:31.838
joining me as we continue on
our journey together in CCENT,

10
00:00:31.838 --> 00:00:36.046
we are here taking a look
of course at port security.

11
00:00:36.046 --> 00:00:41.027
We've already described a lot of the LAN
switching concepts that we've needed to,

12
00:00:41.027 --> 00:00:45.812
but now we need to also take a look at the
idea of implementing some port security.

13
00:00:45.812 --> 00:00:46.553
>> Mm-hm.

14
00:00:46.553 --> 00:00:48.740
>> Switches that are out of the box,

15
00:00:48.740 --> 00:00:53.758
if you remember that when you first hold
them out and you plug a power into it.

16
00:00:53.758 --> 00:00:55.300
You can plug a cable in and

17
00:00:55.300 --> 00:00:57.360
it will work right away.
>> Mm-hm.

18
00:00:57.360 --> 00:00:59.730
>> So that sounds like a good idea okay?

19
00:00:59.730 --> 00:01:02.950
But now let's say that you've
ended up where you've cabled

20
00:01:02.950 --> 00:01:05.060
every single thing inside of that switch.

21
00:01:05.060 --> 00:01:08.410
And they now go to different wall outlets,
right?

22
00:01:08.410 --> 00:01:13.210
Different networking jacks and
the wall outlets that are actually around.

23
00:01:13.210 --> 00:01:16.080
And you have one in a public area,
okay, and

24
00:01:16.080 --> 00:01:20.870
you've now connected that to your switch
through the cabling in your building.

25
00:01:20.870 --> 00:01:24.432
That can actually be bad in one way or
another, okay.

26
00:01:24.432 --> 00:01:28.780
The first bad thing it could be is
that since everything is actually

27
00:01:28.780 --> 00:01:33.672
on by default, okay, it means that
somebody that's not known to you could

28
00:01:33.672 --> 00:01:38.255
simply sit down near that particular
network jack, plug a device in,

29
00:01:38.255 --> 00:01:43.099
the switch will recognize the device and
maybe even give it an IP address.

30
00:01:43.099 --> 00:01:47.904
With all the other configurations that are
on it, allow it possibly also of course,

31
00:01:47.904 --> 00:01:49.811
will access out to the Internet.

32
00:01:49.811 --> 00:01:54.577
So you don't want something like that
to happen where it's simply unplugs or

33
00:01:54.577 --> 00:01:57.157
plugs in and then do something like that.

34
00:01:57.157 --> 00:01:59.816
So we've talked about how
we can kind of counter

35
00:01:59.816 --> 00:02:03.883
act that by putting all of the switch
ports that we aren't using, okay?

36
00:02:03.883 --> 00:02:08.589
Even if they're not plugged in physically
around the building, putting those into

37
00:02:08.589 --> 00:02:12.365
a parking lot VLAN where we say look,
nothing's gonna access us and

38
00:02:12.365 --> 00:02:15.765
we only pull them and
put them into active VLANs as we need to.

39
00:02:15.765 --> 00:02:19.402
We can also implement shutdown on
the ports that we're not using.

40
00:02:19.402 --> 00:02:22.890
And that way we'll manually have
to configure them to turn on and

41
00:02:22.890 --> 00:02:25.532
only enable them when we need to, okay?
>> Mm-hm.

42
00:02:25.532 --> 00:02:27.665
>> The other thing though that can happen

43
00:02:27.665 --> 00:02:29.070
is something like this.

44
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:33.270
Let's take a look at my diagram here and
this will help us out a little bit.

45
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:37.674
So instead of the situation which I just
told you about which is just an unattended

46
00:02:37.674 --> 00:02:40.803
outlet, one that doesn't have
a cable plugged into it.

47
00:02:40.803 --> 00:02:45.397
But let's say it's actually one that
does have something plugged into it such

48
00:02:45.397 --> 00:02:47.610
as this server here, okay?

49
00:02:47.610 --> 00:02:51.834
So when, if you remember
the functioning of the port security or

50
00:02:51.834 --> 00:02:54.240
the switch itself, right?

51
00:02:54.240 --> 00:02:58.700
These ports will begin to
populate as a MAC table here,

52
00:02:58.700 --> 00:03:04.990
a MAC address table based off
the source of the actual device itself.

53
00:03:04.990 --> 00:03:08.126
So it takes a MAC address,
when it begins to communicate,

54
00:03:08.126 --> 00:03:10.700
the switch will learn on this port.

55
00:03:10.700 --> 00:03:12.630
Zero slash one.

56
00:03:12.630 --> 00:03:15.580
Here is what the MAC address should be,
and

57
00:03:15.580 --> 00:03:20.275
it will populate the MAC address table
with the source IP of that packet.

58
00:03:20.275 --> 00:03:22.910
That also means that on
this port down here,

59
00:03:22.910 --> 00:03:26.700
the one with the orange cable that I
have set up, it also means that for

60
00:03:26.700 --> 00:03:30.760
that one it will do the same thing and
populate this one as well.

61
00:03:31.870 --> 00:03:32.630
If I can make it happen.

62
00:03:35.448 --> 00:03:39.647
Too many, not enough.
>> [LAUGH]

63
00:03:39.647 --> 00:03:41.639
>> All right so it will also if this one

64
00:03:41.639 --> 00:03:45.842
actually sends data in it will also
populate that MAC address table too.

65
00:03:45.842 --> 00:03:46.424
>> Mm-hm.

66
00:03:46.424 --> 00:03:48.626
>> Okay so when we do something like this

67
00:03:48.626 --> 00:03:49.270
it works.

68
00:03:49.270 --> 00:03:52.501
Okay, because now these computers
will be able to communicate,

69
00:03:52.501 --> 00:03:53.804
it won't really matter.

70
00:03:53.804 --> 00:03:58.618
The issue though that we might have is,
let's say that this is

71
00:03:58.618 --> 00:04:03.341
one of those places where nobody
is really looking too much or

72
00:04:03.341 --> 00:04:08.619
too carefully, that when somebody
sneaky is doing is that they're

73
00:04:08.619 --> 00:04:14.640
unplugging that one device and
now plugging it in to their computer.

74
00:04:14.640 --> 00:04:16.791
And if they do something like this,

75
00:04:16.791 --> 00:04:21.237
well what can end up happening of course
is that this particular one here,

76
00:04:21.237 --> 00:04:25.267
and I'm gonna change up just one
number here so that we can do this.

77
00:04:25.267 --> 00:04:32.034
You may end up seeing where now,
If I can do it.

78
00:04:36.541 --> 00:04:42.340
Where now that port number may end
up with two different MAC addresses.

79
00:04:42.340 --> 00:04:43.073
And it's works perfectly fine.

80
00:04:43.073 --> 00:04:45.881
The address table will take it,
it's not gonna to complain,

81
00:04:45.881 --> 00:04:47.346
it's not gonna to do anything.

82
00:04:47.346 --> 00:04:52.325
So even though they are plugged into
both of these devices it can do this.

83
00:04:52.325 --> 00:04:55.681
And so now, this attacker
that I've represented in red,

84
00:04:55.681 --> 00:04:59.312
they may have access in by simply
going around to some machine,

85
00:04:59.312 --> 00:05:02.823
unplugging the network cable and
plugging their device in.

86
00:05:02.823 --> 00:05:08.885
So what we can do to prevent that
is that on an individual port,

87
00:05:08.885 --> 00:05:14.630
like this one that the orange
cable is plugged into.

88
00:05:14.630 --> 00:05:17.960
We can implement what
we call port security.

89
00:05:17.960 --> 00:05:22.327
Port security allows us to do some
security based on the MAC address itself.

90
00:05:22.327 --> 00:05:26.060
We can do it in a couple
of different ways, okay?

91
00:05:26.060 --> 00:05:32.025
When we start talking about the idea
of implementation of port security,

92
00:05:32.025 --> 00:05:38.290
I can manually configure this port to
accept only the MAC addresses I type in.

93
00:05:38.290 --> 00:05:41.398
So even if an attacker comes in and
brings their computer to do this and

94
00:05:41.398 --> 00:05:44.090
it says you're not one of
the addresses that were typed in.

95
00:05:44.090 --> 00:05:46.694
You're not going to be able
to use this port, okay?

96
00:05:46.694 --> 00:05:48.491
So that's one way that we can do that.

97
00:05:48.491 --> 00:05:53.538
Another thing that we can also
do instead is to when we plug

98
00:05:53.538 --> 00:05:59.532
a device into that port is that we
can say learn about that address and

99
00:05:59.532 --> 00:06:04.174
make sure that that gets
into the MAC address table.

100
00:06:04.174 --> 00:06:07.497
But then I can limit the number of IP,
or not IP,

101
00:06:07.497 --> 00:06:11.668
MAC addresses that can be stored for
that individual port.

102
00:06:11.668 --> 00:06:14.153
So if I wanted to I could restrict it and

103
00:06:14.153 --> 00:06:17.039
limit it down to one MAC
address if I do that.

104
00:06:17.039 --> 00:06:22.888
So that way, if there's only one available
MAC address on this port, Zach, and

105
00:06:22.888 --> 00:06:28.392
it's already filled with the one with
all fives, if an attacker comes in and

106
00:06:28.392 --> 00:06:33.143
simply unplugs the cable,
it will not be able to make an entry in.

107
00:06:33.143 --> 00:06:34.930
Now I can't delete it.

108
00:06:34.930 --> 00:06:39.805
It will not be able to configure
another device on that port,

109
00:06:39.805 --> 00:06:40.863
okay?
>> Right.

110
00:06:40.863 --> 00:06:43.790
>> So that is possible as well, okay?

111
00:06:43.790 --> 00:06:47.710
The other thing that we can
also of course do here okay

112
00:06:47.710 --> 00:06:52.060
is to just say here is what
we want to make sure of.

113
00:06:52.060 --> 00:06:56.860
Because it can also lose this
configuration quickly if the device

114
00:06:56.860 --> 00:06:57.720
reboots.

115
00:06:57.720 --> 00:06:59.920
It's not necessarily persistent here.

116
00:06:59.920 --> 00:07:02.812
That means every time it reboots right
this MAC address table goes away.

117
00:07:02.812 --> 00:07:09.621
And if it does what if this guy is plugged
in instead while the switch is rebooted?

118
00:07:09.621 --> 00:07:13.807
Well that means that the first address
that gets plugged in is gonna be here, and

119
00:07:13.807 --> 00:07:16.160
now I've implemented port security.

120
00:07:16.160 --> 00:07:19.010
So if I now realize that there's
a cable hanging loose and I try and

121
00:07:19.010 --> 00:07:21.260
plug this guy back again.

122
00:07:21.260 --> 00:07:25.040
Well now there's an issue because now it's
like, we already have a MAC address and

123
00:07:25.040 --> 00:07:26.410
it's stuck there.

124
00:07:26.410 --> 00:07:28.710
So what we can do is tell it, look,

125
00:07:28.710 --> 00:07:32.330
I want this to be persistent
through reboots as well.

126
00:07:32.330 --> 00:07:35.300
So all that's possible
when you start doing this.

127
00:07:35.300 --> 00:07:39.610
So static entry means we type
in the mac address itself.

128
00:07:39.610 --> 00:07:41.187
And then a static is gonna
stay there permanently.

129
00:07:41.187 --> 00:07:44.344
It doesn't matter what happens to
the router, is going to stay there.

130
00:07:44.344 --> 00:07:44.936
>> Mm-hm.

131
00:07:44.936 --> 00:07:46.503
>> But that means I also actually have to

132
00:07:46.503 --> 00:07:48.488
do all that for
all the ports that come online.

133
00:07:48.488 --> 00:07:49.633
>> Boards is right.

134
00:07:49.633 --> 00:07:51.919
>> So if I have a 48 port switch which I

135
00:07:51.919 --> 00:07:56.723
can have and now I'm using all 48 ports,
that's a lot of MAC addresses,

136
00:07:56.723 --> 00:08:00.079
a lot of information that's
typed in this format and

137
00:08:00.079 --> 00:08:02.998
in just letters A through G and
0 through 9.

138
00:08:02.998 --> 00:08:05.959
That's a lot of information that
I don't want to have to type in.

139
00:08:05.959 --> 00:08:07.805
It really is,
I don't want to have to do that.

140
00:08:07.805 --> 00:08:08.972
>> So is there a way to do it so

141
00:08:08.972 --> 00:08:12.690
that you can knock it all out in one shot?
>> Yep, well not in one shot, right?

142
00:08:12.690 --> 00:08:14.250
But there are different ways so, but

143
00:08:14.250 --> 00:08:16.460
just make sure that we understand
that we can statically do it.

144
00:08:16.460 --> 00:08:19.840
And then we can do dynamic and that's
what we're talking about here, okay?

145
00:08:19.840 --> 00:08:21.840
Dynamic is saying learn about it.

146
00:08:21.840 --> 00:08:23.430
And keep it there.

147
00:08:23.430 --> 00:08:26.420
But then we have to restrict the number
of Mac addresses we'll allow for

148
00:08:26.420 --> 00:08:28.690
that port to learn, okay?

149
00:08:28.690 --> 00:08:31.650
But remember that like I
said on a reboot though,

150
00:08:31.650 --> 00:08:34.450
this Mac address table
clears up on a reboot.

151
00:08:34.450 --> 00:08:39.600
So if we end up where a malicious
device is attached to it,

152
00:08:39.600 --> 00:08:42.360
and that get's in the table before and
we've limited it to one.

153
00:08:42.360 --> 00:08:44.980
And now a legitimate device
that plugs in that port

154
00:08:44.980 --> 00:08:46.670
is not gonna be recognized.
>> Dear.

155
00:08:46.670 --> 00:08:48.650
>> So instead, what we can do is say,

156
00:08:48.650 --> 00:08:50.440
look, we'll do it this way,

157
00:08:50.440 --> 00:08:55.210
where it will learn about the first Mac
addresses that are plugged into this port,

158
00:08:55.210 --> 00:08:59.330
but keep that persistent in the Mac
address table between reboots.

159
00:08:59.330 --> 00:09:01.760
And then you don't have to
worry about something like

160
00:09:01.760 --> 00:09:02.520
that.
>> Okay.

161
00:09:02.520 --> 00:09:04.148
>> So we're gonna show you of course

162
00:09:04.148 --> 00:09:05.900
an example of how we do this, okay?

163
00:09:05.900 --> 00:09:07.941
So once we get this all set up,

164
00:09:07.941 --> 00:09:13.103
we also have to decide what happens if
the port security gets violated too.

165
00:09:13.103 --> 00:09:18.730
There is always a full
configuration includes not only.

166
00:09:18.730 --> 00:09:22.680
But also saying what is to happen,
when it actually gets violated.

167
00:09:22.680 --> 00:09:24.560
And that's what we are about to show you.
>> Okay.

168
00:09:24.560 --> 00:09:26.890
>> So we are gonna use NYCORE1,

169
00:09:26.890 --> 00:09:28.570
as we get started here.

170
00:09:28.570 --> 00:09:34.090
To essentially help us to initiate
static port security at the beginning,

171
00:09:34.090 --> 00:09:37.420
and then we will initiate what we
call the dynamic port security.

172
00:09:37.420 --> 00:09:40.420
So using NYCORE1, and I'll zoom in.

173
00:09:42.420 --> 00:09:46.730
We are hopefully getting too wide and
off board here.

174
00:09:46.730 --> 00:09:52.020
And let's go ahead and
get into our privilege exact mode here,

175
00:09:52.020 --> 00:09:58.624
then I'm gonna type in,
show mac address-table.

176
00:10:00.830 --> 00:10:03.490
When I do that it's going to show
the entire address table and

177
00:10:03.490 --> 00:10:06.130
notice that there is a couple of
different entries in here Zack.

178
00:10:06.130 --> 00:10:09.590
One of course are the ones
marked as static, and

179
00:10:09.590 --> 00:10:11.910
then the other ones are marked as dynamic.

180
00:10:11.910 --> 00:10:16.110
When you and I are dealing with this we're
going to be messing around with dynamic

181
00:10:16.110 --> 00:10:17.480
ones is what we're gonna be dealing with.

182
00:10:17.480 --> 00:10:21.340
The static ones you can even see
where it's connected to the CPU.

183
00:10:21.340 --> 00:10:22.850
So you and I can't change this.

184
00:10:22.850 --> 00:10:23.350
Okay?
>> Okay.

185
00:10:23.350 --> 00:10:24.030
>> So that's why we're

186
00:10:24.030 --> 00:10:28.650
gonna be down here and you're also gonna
see an interface attached to them as well.

187
00:10:28.650 --> 00:10:32.073
Okay?
So on this one, the interface that we

188
00:10:32.073 --> 00:10:37.355
are going to be messing around
with is gonna be the Fa1/0/1.

189
00:10:37.355 --> 00:10:41.053
And I'm simply going to
copy this Mac address so

190
00:10:41.053 --> 00:10:47.074
I can statically enter it in for port
security, is what I'm going to do here.

191
00:10:47.074 --> 00:10:50.320
So that is the that one I'm copying for
right now.

192
00:10:50.320 --> 00:10:53.270
Now once I get that port address, now, or

193
00:10:53.270 --> 00:10:59.150
that network Mac address, let me go
into our global configuration mode.

194
00:10:59.150 --> 00:11:05.000
And then we're going to enter
in our port security, okay?

195
00:11:05.000 --> 00:11:07.530
So when we start to enter
in our port security.

196
00:11:07.530 --> 00:11:09.140
I'm gonna make sure that you can see that.

197
00:11:09.140 --> 00:11:14.290
I don't know it bugs me when I
see more than what I need to.

198
00:11:14.290 --> 00:11:17.330
So here,
when we actually get into NYCORE1.

199
00:11:17.330 --> 00:11:20.810
I now need to make sure that I
get in to that interface too.

200
00:11:20.810 --> 00:11:26.149
So interface fastethernet.

201
00:11:26.149 --> 00:11:28.381
It's gonna be 1/0/1.

202
00:11:28.381 --> 00:11:32.985
So now that I'm inside that interface,
I need to make sure that I implement port

203
00:11:32.985 --> 00:11:37.260
security but port security is
only implemented on switchports.

204
00:11:37.260 --> 00:11:40.360
The switchport, access port, excuse me.

205

00:25:19.890 --> 00:25:20.980
>> By disabling that port,

436
00:25:20.980 --> 00:25:25.900
it means I will not let it turn back
on until an administrator comes and

437
00:25:25.900 --> 00:25:27.610
fixes what the issue is.
>> Mm-hm.

438
00:25:27.610 --> 00:25:30.730
>> Okay, so that's the idea of shutdown.

439
00:25:30.730 --> 00:25:34.130
Protect though, it says look.

440
00:25:34.130 --> 00:25:37.310
Let's talk about this for
a moment here, okay?

441
00:25:37.310 --> 00:25:40.520
So what it might do as we
start to do this, right,

442
00:25:40.520 --> 00:25:46.080
is that it will still allow for
what ever Mac address it learned.

443
00:25:46.080 --> 00:25:50.353
Okay, but any thing else,
any other Mac address that comes through,

444
00:25:50.353 --> 00:25:53.430
it just says I'm not going to let it work.

445
00:25:53.430 --> 00:25:56.300
Okay, so you unplug it, and
you plug-in another it goes yeah.

446
00:25:56.300 --> 00:25:58.120
I'm just not going to let you work.

447
00:25:58.120 --> 00:26:00.140
Which is fine, so you can do that.

448
00:26:00.140 --> 00:26:03.380
And that's what protect does instead.
>> Mm-hm.

449
00:26:03.380 --> 00:26:06.790
>> Restrict is almost the same as protect.

450
00:26:06.790 --> 00:26:09.900
And says look,
here is my configure MAC address,

451
00:26:09.900 --> 00:26:13.600
I just learned this, I'm keeping
it through a reboot if I need to.

452
00:26:13.600 --> 00:26:17.280
Perfectly fine, that will work for me.

453
00:26:17.280 --> 00:26:21.250
But, the other thing I'm gonna do is,
I'm gonna send a log message, okay?

454
00:26:21.250 --> 00:26:27.340
I'm gonna log the fact that somebody has
tried to put in another device, okay.

455
00:26:27.340 --> 00:26:30.890
So if there's anything that's
actually between these two,

456
00:26:30.890 --> 00:26:33.930
it's about the idea of logging, okay.

457
00:26:33.930 --> 00:26:38.660
Restrict logs the fact that
a violation has happened,

458
00:26:38.660 --> 00:26:43.120
whereas protect just says look, I'm going
ensure a violation doesn't happen, okay.

459
00:26:43.120 --> 00:26:45.990
Restrict says, I'm going to ensure
a violation doesn't happen, but

460
00:26:45.990 --> 00:26:51.110
I'm also gonna report on the very fact
that it did happen, and it is probably

461
00:26:51.110 --> 00:26:54.680
the MAC address that tried to do this.
>> I'm sure it's not one size fits all,

462
00:26:54.680 --> 00:26:56.700
but the restrict sounds
like the better option.

463
00:26:56.700 --> 00:26:58.360
>> The restrict between the two is

464
00:26:58.360 --> 00:27:00.000
the more secure of the options,

465
00:27:00.000 --> 00:27:02.760
because logging is a very
important part of what we do.

466
00:27:02.760 --> 00:27:05.590
The most secure of course is shut down.

467
00:27:05.590 --> 00:27:09.340
Shut down let's you know an error occurred
and it's going to stop all traffic.

468
00:27:09.340 --> 00:27:12.190
It doesn't matter if you have
the good device plugged back in,

469
00:27:12.190 --> 00:27:15.580
it's not gonna turn back on,
it's gonna say you fix the problem, and

470
00:27:15.580 --> 00:27:18.250
then I'll allow you to
manually turn it back on.

471
00:27:18.250 --> 00:27:21.530
You literally have to go into that
interface once you fix the problem,

472
00:27:21.530 --> 00:27:25.250
you have to issue a shut down,
and then a no shutdown again.

473
00:27:25.250 --> 00:27:29.480
So even if it actually says it's shutdown,
it says line down, protocol down,

474
00:27:29.480 --> 00:27:33.650
you still have to issue the word shutdown,
and then you have to issue no shutdown.

475
00:27:33.650 --> 00:27:35.630
It's like you walking in the room and
flipping the switch off,

476
00:27:35.630 --> 00:27:37.820
and flipping it back on like resetting it.

477
00:27:37.820 --> 00:27:41.520
So that's why shutdown is
by far the most secure.

478
00:27:41.520 --> 00:27:43.750
But that means manually once again, or

479
00:27:43.750 --> 00:27:46.370
administratively, you have to check for
this.

480
00:27:46.370 --> 00:27:49.520
And that means a lot more administrative
effort on your part as well.

481
00:27:49.520 --> 00:27:50.750
But usually that's the default.

482
00:27:50.750 --> 00:27:53.480
That's by far the most secure of them all.
>> All right.

483
00:27:53.480 --> 00:27:55.570
>> But you don't wanna be, if wanna go on,

484
00:27:55.570 --> 00:27:57.650
I just wanna see what's happening here.

485
00:27:57.650 --> 00:27:59.060
Restrict is the better one.

486
00:27:59.060 --> 00:28:01.380
I know it's still protected I'll allow for

487
00:28:01.380 --> 00:28:04.250
the Mac addresses that
are configured on here to work.

488
00:28:04.250 --> 00:28:05.720
But I'm not gonna allow for anything else,

489
00:28:05.720 --> 00:28:09.240
well then choosing these other two
options are also good for you as well.

490
00:28:09.240 --> 00:28:12.780
So protect may be the better one if you
know that your environment is constantly

491
00:28:12.780 --> 00:28:17.310
changing, and people are just swapping
computers in and out and doing all that.

492
00:28:17.310 --> 00:28:18.590
But most of the time, right?

493
00:28:18.590 --> 00:28:21.070
Restrict is probably
the one that let you know

494
00:28:21.070 --> 00:28:23.040
what you want to be able to do.
>> Sure.

495
00:28:23.040 --> 00:28:24.080
>> All right, so

496
00:28:24.080 --> 00:28:27.640
now that we've got this
configured in terms of dynamic,

497
00:28:27.640 --> 00:28:32.020
what we wanna do is show the port
security on the interface as well.

498
00:28:32.020 --> 00:28:39.511
Let's go back out here,
now we're gonna do a show,

499
00:28:39.511 --> 00:28:47.876
port-security Interface
fastethernet 1/0/12.

500
00:28:50.815 --> 00:28:53.690
And notice again,
this one is a little bit different.

501
00:28:53.690 --> 00:28:57.590
It is now secured down,
which is what we're expecting to see, and

502
00:28:57.590 --> 00:28:59.170
that's perfectly fine.

503
00:28:59.170 --> 00:29:02.260
Port Security right now is Disabled.
>> Mm-hm.

504
00:29:02.260 --> 00:29:03.850
>> And the reason why,

505
00:29:03.850 --> 00:29:07.130
right, is that I forgot a command here,
okay?

506
00:29:07.130 --> 00:29:09.700
Remember I told you that if there's a
command that's gonna be forgotten, that's

507
00:29:09.700 --> 00:29:13.320
gonna be the one that I shouldn't forget?
>> Yes.

508
00:29:13.320 --> 00:29:15.534
>> So if I get back in there,

509
00:29:15.534 --> 00:29:19.444
int fa1/0/12, I need the switchport

510
00:29:22.103 --> 00:29:28.150
port-security to essentially turn it on or
to enable it, and

511
00:29:28.150 --> 00:29:33.406
then, I can exit back out and
type in that same thing.

512
00:29:33.406 --> 00:29:40.381
Show port-security interface fa1/0/12.

513
00:29:41.910 --> 00:29:45.184
And now verify Port Security
as now Enabled, and

514
00:29:45.184 --> 00:29:48.360
now it's actually showing,
it should be up.

515
00:29:48.360 --> 00:29:51.680
Showing Secure-up, which is actually
what I do have, that's fine,

516
00:29:51.680 --> 00:29:55.820
cuz I was like Secure down, yeah, it's
down because I didn't have Port Security.

517
00:29:55.820 --> 00:29:58.350
So, that's why I was like that's right,
okay?

518
00:29:58.350 --> 00:30:01.940
So Violation Mode at this point, we
just left, I left it Shutdown cuz that's

519
00:30:01.940 --> 00:30:04.470
the one that the one that I'll
probably choose if I chose any.

520
00:30:04.470 --> 00:30:07.484
And we now have that one MAC address.

521
00:30:07.484 --> 00:30:10.420
Alright, so let us go ahead and
turn this interface off, too.

522
00:30:12.850 --> 00:30:17.140
And this will simulate
a failure of this interface.

523
00:30:17.140 --> 00:30:19.510
So, shutdown.

524
00:30:19.510 --> 00:30:20.500
That's where I wanted to get.

525
00:30:20.500 --> 00:30:23.900
So right at the beginning,
why am I halfway through this already and

526
00:30:23.900 --> 00:30:24.779
I didn't even realize it.

527
00:30:25.910 --> 00:30:30.780
So now that I've shut this down here,
we are seeing some different up downs,

528
00:30:30.780 --> 00:30:31.910
which is perfectly fine.

529
00:30:31.910 --> 00:30:35.000
Let me get back out.

530
00:30:35.000 --> 00:30:37.630
Let's clear the port
security stuff that we have.

531
00:30:37.630 --> 00:30:40.370
So we're gonna do clear port.

532
00:30:40.370 --> 00:30:42.680
So we've set it up, which is fine.

533
00:30:42.680 --> 00:30:47.600
Clear port-security sticky at this point,
telling it to drop whatever it learned

534
00:30:49.990 --> 00:30:53.751
on the interface fa1/0/12.

535
00:30:53.751 --> 00:30:57.150
Go for fast ethernet.

536
00:30:57.150 --> 00:30:59.610
And now I've cleared that out,
which is perfectly fine.

537
00:30:59.610 --> 00:31:04.027
Let's go back into the interface
itself once again.

538
00:31:04.027 --> 00:31:07.658
And now we are going to
manually assign an address,

539
00:31:07.658 --> 00:31:10.454
and see what happens from here, okay?

540
00:31:10.454 --> 00:31:17.257
So switchport port-security MAC-address

541
00:31:17.257 --> 00:31:22.656
0001.0001.0001.

542
00:31:22.656 --> 00:31:27.230
So this way, it's just as clear as
we can actually make it to do that.

543
00:31:29.060 --> 00:31:34.630
All right, now let's do a no shutdown,
and turn this thing back on.

544
00:31:36.480 --> 00:31:40.400
And hopefully get an UPDOWN here in
just a moment or so, there we go.

545
00:31:40.400 --> 00:31:43.570
So that is a state that got changed.

546
00:31:43.570 --> 00:31:44.210
Look at that.

547
00:31:44.210 --> 00:31:45.400
There we go, okay.

548
00:31:45.400 --> 00:31:47.510
We're starting to see
a couple of other things.

549
00:31:47.510 --> 00:31:49.950
Notice that power was detected.

550
00:31:49.950 --> 00:31:51.120
Power device detected.

551
00:31:51.120 --> 00:31:53.150
Power granted here.

552
00:31:53.150 --> 00:31:58.040
And we're seeing that the Line protocol
and updown has actually occurred.

553
00:31:58.040 --> 00:32:00.740
So let's see what happened on this port.

554
00:32:00.740 --> 00:32:03.430
So those are some of the commands
that you're like what the heck is

555
00:32:03.430 --> 00:32:04.510
going on here.

556
00:32:04.510 --> 00:32:13.010
So now we do a show port -security.

557
00:32:13.010 --> 00:32:16.018
And then for interface, fa1/0/12.

558
00:32:20.365 --> 00:32:21.910
And let's see.

559
00:32:21.910 --> 00:32:27.720
Any violation that has happened at this
point is what we are expecting to see.

560
00:32:27.720 --> 00:32:28.370
Okay.

561
00:32:28.370 --> 00:32:33.500
So, so far, it actually is saying
that device was granted here.

562
00:32:33.500 --> 00:32:36.460
We may have to give it
a little bit of time.

563
00:32:36.460 --> 00:32:38.970
Because I was hoping that it
would actually show up yet.

564
00:32:38.970 --> 00:32:42.050
So it may take just a little
bit more time here.

565
00:32:42.050 --> 00:32:46.430
But it should be violating
its port security as well.

566
00:32:46.430 --> 00:32:48.930
Since I did set up my own MAC address, and

567
00:32:48.930 --> 00:32:52.500
whatever this power device
was that came up, it should.

568
00:32:52.500 --> 00:32:53.870
There we go.
That's what I was looking for.

569
00:32:53.870 --> 00:32:55.730
I was like,
it should just be a matter of time.

570
00:32:55.730 --> 00:32:56.930
But it's hard to wait.

571
00:32:56.930 --> 00:33:00.660
It's the impatience that I
have that we are seeing, so

572
00:33:00.660 --> 00:33:02.582
here it is, notice what it says.

573
00:33:02.582 --> 00:33:08.710
ERR disable, and
a notification message of four, okay?

574
00:33:08.710 --> 00:33:12.280
Four right here means an error
has actually occurred,

575
00:33:12.280 --> 00:33:14.250
which not really a good thing.

576
00:33:14.250 --> 00:33:16.395
And you can see,
here is the terminology right?

577
00:33:16.395 --> 00:33:20.160
psecure-violation-error has been detected.

578
00:33:20.160 --> 00:33:24.740
And now on this particular port,
it's been disabled.

579
00:33:24.740 --> 00:33:26.690
It has actually occurred, and you can see,

580
00:33:26.690 --> 00:33:30.520
caused by another MAC address,
has now been configured on this port.

581
00:33:30.520 --> 00:33:32.830
We manually configured
our own MAC address, and

582
00:33:32.830 --> 00:33:35.580
now it tried to learn a new one,
and that's what happened.

583
00:33:35.580 --> 00:33:36.250
All right, Zach.

584
00:33:36.250 --> 00:33:39.520
Now on this one, okay,
there's still a few steps to go, but

585
00:33:39.520 --> 00:33:42.080
I clearly out of time at this point.

586
00:33:42.080 --> 00:33:44.550
So, we'll have to save that for
a part two.

587
00:33:44.550 --> 00:33:46.360
>> Configure and verify port security,

588
00:33:46.360 --> 00:33:49.890
there's gonna be a lot more, so
you want to make sure you see part two,

589
00:33:49.890 --> 00:33:51.090
this has been part one.

590
00:33:51.090 --> 00:33:53.160
Ronnie, anything else you'd like to say?
>> Well,

591
00:33:53.160 --> 00:33:56.270
remember this is a little
bit of an unusual lab right?

592
00:33:56.270 --> 00:33:59.960
You're actually seeing stuff then
that has to involve patience here.

593
00:33:59.960 --> 00:34:02.720
But this concept is one of the more
important ones that you want to make sure

594
00:34:02.720 --> 00:34:05.350
that you get right,
because of the steps that are involved.

595
00:34:05.350 --> 00:34:08.005
Make sure you remember to practice
this over and over again.

596
00:34:08.005 --> 00:34:10.750
CISCO C has some marvelous theories.

597
00:34:10.750 --> 00:34:12.340
Make sure you watch every episode.

598
00:34:12.340 --> 00:34:15.480
You're going to be so glad you did,
and you'll be in the course library,

599
00:34:15.480 --> 00:34:19.080
where there's thousands of other
videos there to help you go further.

600
00:34:19.080 --> 00:34:21.350
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

601
00:34:21.350 --> 00:34:23.430
ITProTV is binge-worthy.

602
00:34:23.430 --> 00:34:24.540
I'm Zach Memos.
>> And

603
00:34:24.540 --> 00:34:25.877
I'm Ronnie Wong.
>> Thanks for watching,

604
00:34:25.877 --> 00:34:26.409
and we'll see you soon.

605
00:34:26.409 --> 00:34:33.536
[MUSIC]

00:34:33.536 --> 00:34:36.530
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

Configuring Verified Port Security,

>> For joining me once again as we take

a look at the CCENT here, and of course,

15
00:00:38.370 --> 00:00:41.793
We've already went through the lab and

00:00:41.793 --> 00:00:42.752
>> Yes.

>> Okay, being able to manually

in the LAN switching topic that

So when you do the configuration,

But let's finish up

23
00:01:04.890 --> 00:01:06.350
as we showed you from part one.

24
00:01:06.350 --> 00:01:08.656
If you haven't been watching part one and
you jumped into part two,

>> But if that happens to be true,

my recommendation-

>> Yeah, make sure you go back-

29

>> And watch in part one.

Cuz you're probably saying,
that's unusual,

31

why would they end an episode like this?

Or have enough fill by this,
cuz this is the part two.

33
00:01:23.206 --> 00:01:27.820
So let's pick up where we left off, okay?

34
00:01:27.820 --> 00:01:29.870
We had just finished
configuring port security and

35
00:01:29.870 --> 00:01:33.040
I was there kind of nervously like
this thing should be working.

36
00:01:33.040 --> 00:01:35.462
But it's just a matter of time and
patience here,

37
00:01:35.462 --> 00:01:37.199
which is never good on air, right?

38
00:01:37.199 --> 00:01:39.137
Dead time when you're like, okay.

39
00:01:39.137 --> 00:01:42.518
Hopefully it works, and
as soon as I was about ready to go,

40
00:01:42.518 --> 00:01:45.419
we're going to have to cut this and
go it happens.

41
00:01:45.419 --> 00:01:47.260
Well, it magically appeared.

42
00:01:47.260 --> 00:01:50.760
So here's some of the information
that we end up seeing, right?

43
00:01:50.760 --> 00:01:55.620
The very fact is that once we violated it,
by a long to learn

44
00:01:55.620 --> 00:02:00.397
of a new MAC address compared
to the one we configured on.

45
00:02:00.397 --> 00:02:03.573
But this is the syslog
messages that we start to get.

46
00:02:03.573 --> 00:02:06.772
ERR_DISABLE is kinda the key here, okay?

47
00:02:06.772 --> 00:02:08.933
Is that we get out from syslog and

48
00:02:08.933 --> 00:02:14.780
what essentially really happens is what
we call a key secure violation, okay?

49
00:02:14.780 --> 00:02:20.500
And that is a clear indication that port
secure, a violation has actually occurred.

50
00:02:20.500 --> 00:02:24.540
Then we get another one that really
does define what that means.

51
00:02:24.540 --> 00:02:28.640
So PSECURE_VIOLATION,
Security violation occurred and

52
00:02:28.640 --> 00:02:31.950
it said it was caused by this MAC address.

53
00:02:31.950 --> 00:02:37.977
And the reason it was caused by the MAC
address right here that you're seeing,

54
00:02:37.977 --> 00:02:44.938
is that I've configured this port
with a MAC address of 0001.0001.0001.

55
00:02:44.938 --> 00:02:47.071
So when we turn the port back on,

56
00:02:47.071 --> 00:02:50.291
this is the MAC address it tried to learn-
>> Right.

57
00:02:50.291 --> 00:02:54.038
>> He was in violation to
the one that I had set, and

58
00:02:54.038 --> 00:02:58.350
from that point when it did

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce basic routing concepts. They explain how a packet uses the layer 2 and layer 3 protocols in networking.  The team demonstrates how the IP address (Layer 3 addresses) do not change but the layer 2 protocols do change as data move from device to device.  They also describe the changing fo the layer 2 protocol at each hop is known as frame rewrite.
episodes.title: Describe Routing Concepts
