00:13:29.000 --> 00:13:33.470
Once the packet is now inside of
that exiting interface's buffer,

227
00:13:34.700 --> 00:13:37.640
this is where a couple
of things happen again.

228
00:13:37.640 --> 00:13:40.920
It now works like the PC does, okay?

229
00:13:40.920 --> 00:13:45.371
It takes a look and says, all right, let
me see if I can find this device again.

230
00:13:45.371 --> 00:13:49.510
Who is 172.16.23.2?

231
00:13:49.510 --> 00:13:51.084
It can actually issue that out.

232
00:13:51.084 --> 00:13:54.620
But before it does it,
it's gonna look in its own ARP cache.

233
00:13:54.620 --> 00:13:56.740
And it finds it in its ARP cache,

234
00:13:56.740 --> 00:14:01.040
this is where we get into what
is called a frame rewrite.

235
00:14:01.040 --> 00:14:06.040
A frame rewrite says, look,
I know that this IP address and

236
00:14:06.040 --> 00:14:08.540
this MAC address matches up.

237
00:14:08.540 --> 00:14:11.490
I know exactly that's what happens here.

238
00:14:11.490 --> 00:14:17.340
So when it does that,
it will then put a new layer two frame on,

239
00:14:17.340 --> 00:14:23.250
this time with the source MAC address as
being this interface right here, okay?

240
00:14:23.250 --> 00:14:27.390
And then the destination MAC address
of being the interface over on SRV01.

241
00:14:28.670 --> 00:14:33.279
If it doesn't match at that point though,
okay, then it will instead go,

242
00:14:33.279 --> 00:14:35.704
look, I don't find it in my ARP table.

243
00:14:35.704 --> 00:14:41.130
Let me go and issue out an ARP, and
it waits for a reply to come back, okay.

244
00:14:41.130 --> 00:14:45.210
In our instance here,
it will actually get one of two things.

245
00:14:45.210 --> 00:14:48.850
If it does an ARP and there's another
router in between, that other router will

246
00:14:48.850 --> 00:14:53.340
go, I'm doing a proxy ARP,
just go ahead and send it on to me and

247
00:14:53.340 --> 00:14:57.570
I'll take care of it, because I believe
I know where that's going, okay.

248
00:14:57.570 --> 00:15:00.560
But if it doesn't match,
right, and it doesn't do that,

249
00:15:00.560 --> 00:15:04.030
well then at that point that's when
you actually start seeing that.

250
00:15:04.030 --> 00:15:09.180
So here on that one, you actually end up
getting forwarded over to a new address

251
00:15:09.180 --> 00:15:11.970
if it gets it, but
if nothing's replying at that point

252
00:15:11.970 --> 00:15:16.070
it will probably drop the packet as
well as timeout after awhile, all right.

253
00:15:16.070 --> 00:15:19.560
So through these two devices,
that's what happens.

254
00:15:19.560 --> 00:15:24.990
Ultimately, the frame then, after actually
rewrites the layered two letters,

255
00:15:24.990 --> 00:15:28.950
to include in the MAC address
of this exiting interface, and

256
00:15:28.950 --> 00:15:33.540
of the receiving interface over here,
it will then send it out.

257
00:15:33.540 --> 00:15:38.890
And now when R01 sends out the frame,
the frame is gonna be received.

258
00:15:38.890 --> 00:15:43.310
And on SRV01 it just has to check
again in that layer two header.

259
00:15:43.310 --> 00:15:47.950
If it matches, then it processes it and
begins to work at layer three here,

260
00:15:47.950 --> 00:15:50.173
looking for the proper IP address.

261
00:15:50.173 --> 00:15:54.426
But if it's not there,
this will actually drop it, and

262
00:15:54.426 --> 00:16:00.774
then also send back an ICMP message along
this path going all the way back to PC01.

263
00:16:00.774 --> 00:16:06.369
So now, if it matches ICMP says,
send an echo reply back.

264
00:16:06.369 --> 00:16:10.110
And the process essentially starts,
and it reverses itself.

265
00:16:10.110 --> 00:16:14.879
And goes through the entire same
process all the way back here to get

266
00:16:14.879 --> 00:16:16.678
all the way back to PC1.

267
00:16:16.678 --> 00:16:19.200
Now just explaining that concept, right?

268
00:16:19.200 --> 00:16:21.840
Again, take it step by step.

269
00:16:21.840 --> 00:16:25.970
And now you start seeing it's a pretty
complicated process to just get it from

270
00:16:25.970 --> 00:16:30.830
this interface to this interface,
across to another interface, and

271
00:16:30.830 --> 00:16:31.990
then into another one.

272
00:16:31.990 --> 00:16:33.880
That's pretty complex.
>> Mm-hm.

273
00:16:33.880 --> 00:16:35.710
>> Every step along the path requires it

274
00:16:35.710 --> 00:16:38.496
to go between really like layer 3 and

275
00:16:38.496 --> 00:16:43.520
layer 2, checking every time to see if
it actually matches when it does, okay?

276
00:16:43.520 --> 00:16:49.110
And it can even change layer 2, but notice

277
00:16:49.110 --> 00:16:52.754
Now this is good in terms of the

00:16:52.754 --> 00:16:56.364

00:16:56.364 --> 00:17:01.119
So I've gone ahead so that we can see

00:17:01.119 --> 00:17:03.649
better here, is I've even set it up and

00:17:03.649 --> 00:17:07.800
added in another router in
between to help us out, okay?

282
00:17:07.800 --> 00:17:10.960
So this is gonna be little
bit more complex, but

283
00:17:10.960 --> 00:17:14.030
it is gonna help you out to be able
to see what happens at the very

284
00:17:14.030 --> 00:17:14.956
beginning.

00:17:14.956 --> 00:17:16.160
mm-hm.

00:17:16.160 --> 00:17:18.140
So let's walk through this now.

00:17:18.140 --> 00:17:22.896
Now using this diagram to help us

288
00:17:22.896 --> 00:17:28.240
So if we start on the left-hand side with

00:17:28.240 --> 00:17:29.135
It doesn't matter which one.

00:17:29.135 --> 00:17:32.030
I made up these MAC addresses and

00:17:36.630 --> 00:17:41.377

Actually, 2, technically, as the 1st one

00:17:46.660 --> 00:17:51.785
So when this guy says,

00:17:51.785 --> 00:17:57.990
192.168.16.10, I need to send a packet,

00:17:57.990 --> 00:18:00.620
And here is the layer 3 header, okay?

00:18:00.620 --> 00:18:02.940
It also is the source MAC address.

00:18:06.268 --> 00:18:10.553
It says,
I need to get over to 172.16.23.2.

00:18:10.553 --> 00:18:13.690

00:18:13.690 --> 00:18:18.090
And then it doesn't know what to

00:18:18.090 --> 00:18:24.067
So let's say, I forgot to

I already told you what

00:18:26.331 --> 00:18:28.180
Well, let's start right there, okay?

00:18:28.180 --> 00:18:32.300
So it does not have a clue

00:18:32.300 --> 00:18:36.877
So this is where it looks it
up in its own ARP table, okay?

307
00:18:36.877 --> 00:18:40.870
And it doesn't find its ARP table,

00:18:40.870 --> 00:18:45.337
In the ARP broadcast,
the only one that will reply will be R1's

00:18:45.337 --> 00:18:49.490
interface right here,

00:18:49.490 --> 00:18:53.197
Default gateway will reply

00:18:53.197 --> 00:18:55.480
you can use my layer 2 address.

00:18:57.430 --> 00:19:04.630
So send it on instead to

00:19:04.630 --> 00:19:07.550
So now we have a layer 2 frame.

00:19:07.550 --> 00:19:11.180
And that layer 2 frame now is

00:19:11.180 --> 00:19:13.910
to go across these devices here.

00:19:13.910 --> 00:19:15.820
Now does the switch do anything?

00:19:15.820 --> 00:19:20.087
The switch doesn't, the switch

00:19:20.087 --> 00:19:21.930

00:19:21.930 --> 00:19:24.938

00:19:28.681 --> 00:19:30.970
The switch also has a MAC

00:19:30.970 --> 00:19:36.261

00:19:36.261 --> 00:19:39.855

00:19:39.855 --> 00:19:41.955

00:19:47.125 --> 00:19:51.632
On Router 1,
it will process the layer 2 header.

00:19:51.632 --> 00:19:56.658
It'll say, look,

00:19:56.658 --> 00:19:58.320
That belongs to me.

00:19:58.320 --> 00:20:01.874

00:20:04.861 --> 00:20:08.460

00:20:08.460 --> 00:20:13.455
So Router 1 now will end up only seeing,

00:20:13.455 --> 00:20:17.310
that belongs to me, so

00:20:17.310 --> 00:20:20.901

00:20:20.901 --> 00:20:26.718
172.16.23.2, well,
that's not my IP address, okay?

00:20:26.718 --> 00:20:30.970
It is not my IP address,
I need to look it up in my routing table.

00:20:30.970 --> 00:20:36.740
If in the routing table, okay,
it is possibility there, okay?

00:20:36.740 --> 00:20:41.310
Then it will go ahead and
forward it to the next exiting interface.

338
00:20:41.310 --> 00:20:43.582
But if it's not in the routing table,

339
00:20:43.582 --> 00:20:47.700
then it will either send it out a default
gateway or it will go ahead and

340
00:20:47.700 --> 00:20:52.252
send back a message saying, I don't

00:20:52.252 --> 00:20:58.211
Well, let's say that Router
1 learns about 172.16.23.

00:20:58.211 --> 00:21:01.600
And it says, yes,

00:21:02.730 --> 00:21:09.400
Well, now Router 1 takes that

00:21:09.400 --> 00:21:14.592
And when it actually says and
it hears from router 2 that

345
00:21:14.592 --> 00:21:21.229
I know where 17216.23 is,
it will rewrite the layer 2 frame.

346
00:21:21.229 --> 00:21:26.286
So this time it will say, all right,
we're sending it out from me instead,

347
00:21:28.372 --> 00:21:30.600
Which is gonna be this interface.

00:21:30.600 --> 00:21:34.230
Notice again that the layer
3 address doesn't change.

00:21:34.230 --> 00:21:41.070
And then I am forwarding this on to Router
2, which has now responded to my proxy.

00:21:41.070 --> 00:21:43.736
Or it's actually responded

00:21:45.609 --> 00:21:48.676
So now in between Router 1 and Router 2,

00:21:48.676 --> 00:21:52.880
when this packet gets put out

00:21:52.880 --> 00:21:57.277

00:21:57.277 --> 00:22:00.190
And it will start the process again, okay?

00:22:00.190 --> 00:22:01.990
It takes a look at layer 2 and says what?

00:22:01.990 --> 00:22:05.470
That layer 2 address matches.

00:22:08.086 --> 00:22:12.300
So let me go ahead and

00:22:13.510 --> 00:22:18.158
Let's check and see, well, no, at layer 3,

00:22:18.158 --> 00:22:23.496

This is where it will go ahead and

00:22:28.310 --> 00:22:33.100

00:22:33.100 --> 00:22:36.120

00:22:47.233 --> 00:22:51.008
It will say, that is my interface,

00:22:53.912 --> 00:22:59.446

So now in the end,

00:23:12.398 --> 00:23:17.336

00:23:18.691 --> 00:23:25.110
And this one is all e's,

00:23:27.616 --> 00:23:28.600
Okay?

00:23:28.600 --> 00:23:32.830
When it ends up arriving, look what

00:23:32.830 --> 00:23:37.100
It will say, hey,
destination MAC address, that is me.

Let me go ahead and process the layer 2

00:23:43.629 --> 00:23:47.493
Now it will take a look at layer 3 and

00:23:47.493 --> 00:23:50.785
That is also my layer 3 header.

00:23:52.288 --> 00:23:54.759
Let me process all of layer 3.

00:23:56.506 --> 00:23:59.060
So it will know exactly who it came from.

00:24:00.352 --> 00:24:04.085
Once we hit past layer 3 in its process,

00:24:04.085 --> 00:24:07.907
It's not gonna forward it on to anyplace

00:24:07.907 --> 00:24:08.983

00:24:20.930 --> 00:24:24.290
So, this process, and

00:24:30.540 --> 00:24:32.570
Remember that when we move

00:24:32.570 --> 00:24:37.530

But the IP address is important,

If it never processes the layer three,

Only up here,

So, that is for

Well, you are now seeing, we are showing

Because it's already now at the

00:25:59.344 --> 00:26:00.520

So, now it's just

448
00:27:24.820 --> 00:27:26.760
So at some point, it stopped processing.

449
00:27:26.760 --> 00:27:29.550
Well, that means either the packet got
dropped, or it doesn't know what to do.

450
00:27:29.550 --> 00:27:33.820
But you actually do see it now, and how
it actually works, all the way through.

451
00:27:33.820 --> 00:27:37.400
So, it's a good conceptual understanding
of how routing can work for you.

452
00:27:37.400 --> 00:27:39.780
And then, we'll dive into it
a little bit deeper next time.

453
00:27:39.780 --> 00:27:40.330
>> Thanks Ronnie,

454
00:27:40.330 --> 00:27:42.210
another great Cisco C Set episode.

455
00:27:42.210 --> 00:27:44.990
And make sure you watch every
single episode that Ronnie's put

456
00:27:44.990 --> 00:27:46.010
together for you.

457
00:27:46.010 --> 00:27:48.450
Cisco C Set, you'll be glad you did.

458
00:27:48.450 --> 00:27:50.380
And you know what?
You'll be in the course library.

459
00:27:50.380 --> 00:27:54.390
There's thousands of other videos there,
that are there to help you go further.

460
00:27:54.390 --> 00:27:55.630
Check those out too.

461
00:27:55.630 --> 00:27:58.060
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

462
00:27:58.060 --> 00:27:59.770
ITProTV is binge worthy.

463
00:27:59.770 --> 00:28:00.560
Thanks for watching.

464
00:28:00.560 --> 00:28:02.170
I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

465
00:28:02.170 --> 00:28:03.610
>> And we will see you again very soon.

466
00:28:03.610 --> 00:28:10.170
[MUSIC].

467
00:28:10.170 --> 00:28:13.992
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce basic routing table and the information it provides.  They explain the different components found in the routing table.  Also, the pair describe the use of Administrative Distance for routing protocols.  Lastly, they demonstrate basic routing using static routes and a dynamic routing protocol.
episodes.title: Describe Routing Tables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.220
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:01.220 --> 00:00:03.195
I'm your host Don Pezet.
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.195 --> 00:00:05.525
>> Coming to you live from San Francisco,

4
00:00:05.525 --> 00:00:06.375
California.

5
00:00:06.375 --> 00:00:08.323
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.323 --> 00:00:13.230
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

7
00:00:13.230 --> 00:00:17.190
choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

8
00:00:17.190 --> 00:00:18.120
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

9
00:00:18.120 --> 00:00:20.370
As we continue on with Cisco CCET,

10
00:00:20.370 --> 00:00:23.800
we're gonna describe routing
tables in this episode.

11
00:00:23.800 --> 00:00:28.030
And the person that's gonna do that for
us, it isn't me, it's Ronnie Wong.

12
00:00:28.030 --> 00:00:29.279
Ronnie, good to see you, sir, thanks for

13
00:00:29.279 --> 00:00:31.427
joining.
>> Well, thank you, Zach, for

14
00:00:31.427 --> 00:00:34.905
having me on the show as we continue
on in our CCET journey together.

15
00:00:34.905 --> 00:00:38.581
We have now talked about some of
the basics of the routing concepts that

16
00:00:38.581 --> 00:00:42.631
you have to fundamentally understand,
the ability to of course get data from

17
00:00:42.631 --> 00:00:45.850
one device over to another
one on a different network.

18
00:00:45.850 --> 00:00:48.162
We've walked through every
step of that process.

19
00:00:48.162 --> 00:00:52.036
So that you understand what ends up
working between layer two and layer three

20
00:00:52.036 --> 00:00:56.480
and how the data moves from device to
device, to get to its endpoint as well.

21
00:00:56.480 --> 00:00:57.545
Now at this point,

22
00:00:57.545 --> 00:01:01.349
it means that we are ready to start
dealing with the idea of routing.

23
00:01:01.349 --> 00:01:06.186
And this is part of that process that we
were also talking about before where we do

24
00:01:06.186 --> 00:01:07.530
a routing lookup.

25
00:01:07.530 --> 00:01:11.450
So let's take a look at something
now as we get started here.

26
00:01:11.450 --> 00:01:15.900
So remember that when we take a look at
the idea of the packet delivery process,

27
00:01:15.900 --> 00:01:20.790
and it gets into the router, well,
what does the router do at that point?

28
00:01:20.790 --> 00:01:24.170
We've talked about a couple of
different things that it can do, okay?

29
00:01:24.170 --> 00:01:26.770
So once layer two is processed,

30
00:01:26.770 --> 00:01:29.200
remember that means it begins
to look at layer three.

31
00:01:29.200 --> 00:01:31.950
And there's two possibilities here, okay?

32
00:01:31.950 --> 00:01:36.260
If the IP address matches what's on
the interface of that router, well,

33
00:01:36.260 --> 00:01:38.930
then it processor just
like everything else.

34
00:01:38.930 --> 00:01:42.460
But there's gonna be more than likely
a chance, especially with a router,

35
00:01:42.460 --> 00:01:46.170
that the destination IP
address is not going to match.

36
00:01:46.170 --> 00:01:49.310
Well, when it doesn't match,
then at that point,

37
00:01:49.310 --> 00:01:52.080
it ends up doing what
we call a route lookup.

38
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:56.010
And that means it goes to the routing
table on the router here, and

39
00:01:56.010 --> 00:01:58.250
tries to find a match.

40
00:01:58.250 --> 00:02:03.460
Now that match is very important because
it actually does tell where that data

41
00:02:03.460 --> 00:02:08.810
is supposed to go, even through
the router, to whatever exiting interface.

42
00:02:08.810 --> 00:02:12.060
So routers, unlike switches,
they don't have 24 ports.

43
00:02:12.060 --> 00:02:14.985
Most of them have relatively few, 2 or 3,

44
00:02:14.985 --> 00:02:18.550
maybe 4 ports if you add an extra card or
slot.

45
00:02:18.550 --> 00:02:21.160
But most of the time,
right, it's not a lot.

46
00:02:21.160 --> 00:02:25.240
So what we have of course then,
is this ability for the routing table

47
00:02:25.240 --> 00:02:30.750
to simply say we are going to switch
you from what interface it came in on,

48
00:02:30.750 --> 00:02:34.580
to the exiting interface of where
it's supposed to go out to.

49
00:02:34.580 --> 00:02:39.540
Okay, so what we are looking at then is we
need to understand how that routing table

50
00:02:39.540 --> 00:02:44.530
actually is structured, and what
information that you and I can find in

51
00:02:44.530 --> 00:02:48.770
that routing table, and why the router
actually uses it the way that it does.

52
00:02:48.770 --> 00:02:52.570
So that's the part of the process that
we are gonna be taking a look at today.

53
00:02:52.570 --> 00:02:57.820
So when we take a look at a routing table
on the router itself, and I'm gonna try

54
00:02:57.820 --> 00:03:02.260
and scroll it down a little bit so that we
can see some of the elements here, okay?

55
00:03:02.260 --> 00:03:03.360
It's broken down, and

56
00:03:03.360 --> 00:03:06.420
I have a list of about seven
different elements that you'll find.

57
00:03:06.420 --> 00:03:10.120
Now they're gonna be very important,
of course, as you get ready for

58
00:03:10.120 --> 00:03:13.484
the exam and as you start working
with routers to understand.

59
00:03:13.484 --> 00:03:16.728
When you do this,
you can simply go to the router and

60
00:03:16.728 --> 00:03:21.035
type in at the privileged exec mode,
not at the config router mode.

61
00:03:21.035 --> 00:03:23.350
You're not doing it at the config router.

62
00:03:23.350 --> 00:03:26.330
But you simply type in, show ip route.

63
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:31.040
And that will show you the entire
routing table for that router okay?

64
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:34.270
And that's important,
the routing table is how

65
00:03:34.270 --> 00:03:38.940
the router makes the decision of how
it gets information from one interface

66
00:03:38.940 --> 00:03:43.440
over to the exiting interface that needs
to, so it can go on to its next hop.

67
00:03:43.440 --> 00:03:45.830
Okay, so when it actually discovers that,

68
00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:51.060
it's because of the information stored
right here in this routing table itself.

69
00:03:51.060 --> 00:03:53.300
Now when you take a look
at the routing table,

70
00:03:53.300 --> 00:03:55.570
there is a lot of information in it.

71
00:03:55.570 --> 00:03:58.580
And for you and me, if we are gonna
be working with Cisco climate,

72
00:03:58.580 --> 00:04:03.770
this should feel second nature to you,
as you start to work with it more and

73
00:04:03.770 --> 00:04:05.380
more, as you do this.

74
00:04:05.380 --> 00:04:08.135
So even at CCNT level,
we are gonna be describing it.

75
00:04:08.135 --> 00:04:10.590
We're gonna be pointing
some of the elements out.

76
00:04:10.590 --> 00:04:12.980
But once you get into the CCNA routing and
switching and

77
00:04:12.980 --> 00:04:16.150
you go on to your CCNP,
it should be second nature for

78
00:04:16.150 --> 00:04:19.410
you to read the information here,
just like you're reading a book.

79
00:04:19.410 --> 00:04:22.110
And literally,
that's what you want it to become.

80
00:04:22.110 --> 00:04:26.700
So for us, we're gonna examine some of
these different elements at this point, to

81
00:04:26.700 --> 00:04:30.530
make sure that you understand what you're
taking a look at when we do this, okay.

82
00:04:30.530 --> 00:04:34.960
Once you type in show ip route,
without any additional modifiers,

83
00:04:34.960 --> 00:04:38.940
or any filters, or anything else here,
you normally will get,

84
00:04:38.940 --> 00:04:41.680
of course, well, essentially a legend.

85
00:04:41.680 --> 00:04:45.550
If you wanna call it something that you'll
recognize, right, the ability to match up

86
00:04:45.550 --> 00:04:52.650
a code that you see with the naming of
what each of these things are about.

87
00:04:52.650 --> 00:04:56.180
So normally that code that you
see here in this code table,

88
00:04:56.180 --> 00:04:58.860
or this legend up here,
matches up to, well,

89
00:04:58.860 --> 00:05:02.010
some of the elements that you'll
see inside of the routing table.

90
00:05:02.010 --> 00:05:06.350
And lot of time, that's gonna be over
here on the far left-hand side, okay?

91
00:05:06.350 --> 00:05:07.572
On the far left-hand side,

92
00:05:07.572 --> 00:05:11.880
you'll actually see some of the different
codes that are actually right here too.

93
00:05:11.880 --> 00:05:12.795
And then you can look up.

94
00:05:12.795 --> 00:05:16.110
So for example, if I take a look
at the letter R right here, okay?

95
00:05:16.110 --> 00:05:20.330
The letter R, well,
I can just go up to into this code table.

96
00:05:20.330 --> 00:05:25.180
Then I can look, and that stands for RIP,
which I know is a routing protocol, okay?

97
00:05:25.180 --> 00:05:28.088
So dynamic routing protocol,
which allows for, well,

98
00:05:28.088 --> 00:05:31.950
the router to actually be able to
learn routes from other routers.

99
00:05:31.950 --> 00:05:37.340
So I know that that is how this particular
route was also learned as well, okay?

100
00:05:37.340 --> 00:05:39.115
So that's what we also end up seeing,

101
00:05:39.115 --> 00:05:41.850
is just something simple as we go through,
okay?

102
00:05:41.850 --> 00:05:46.130
Now, as you start to look and
find some different things as well,

103
00:05:46.130 --> 00:05:50.627
okay, you will actually kinda use this to
help us out over on the left-hand side.

104
00:05:50.627 --> 00:05:53.330
One of the things that we want to
point out that you actually end up

105
00:05:53.330 --> 00:05:54.450
seeing, right?

106
00:05:54.450 --> 00:05:57.250
So we've already talked about this
idea of the codes that are there,

107
00:05:57.250 --> 00:05:59.130
the routing protocol codes.

108
00:05:59.130 --> 00:06:02.280
But let's take a look at this
idea of prefix for a moment.

109
00:06:02.280 --> 00:06:04.550
Prefix is the network prefix.

110
00:06:04.550 --> 00:06:09.000
And instead of saying it's the network
ID number, they use prefix.

111
00:06:09.000 --> 00:06:12.700
Because what the router
looks like is how many bits,

112
00:06:12.700 --> 00:06:16.060
okay, are actually gonna
be the network portion.

113
00:06:16.060 --> 00:06:19.770
The routing table really works by
the most specific networking or

114
00:06:19.770 --> 00:06:21.380
prefix that we have.

115
00:06:21.380 --> 00:06:24.560
So the longer the actual prefix number,

116
00:06:24.560 --> 00:06:27.810
that's what it's gonna go with
usually by default as well.

117
00:06:27.810 --> 00:06:34.284
So for example, this particular
router ended up finding a route for

118
00:06:34.284 --> 00:06:39.210
the 34.0.0.0/24 network here.

119
00:06:39.210 --> 00:06:44.217
Well, the prefix would be 34.0.0.0.

120
00:06:44.217 --> 00:06:46.940
That's what the prefix would be, okay.

121
00:06:46.940 --> 00:06:49.850
That is the network ID, okay.

122
00:06:49.850 --> 00:06:54.250
The other part that you also see
here is right after the slash.

123
00:06:54.250 --> 00:06:58.820
So beginning with the slash and
then the 24, that is gonna represent your

124
00:06:58.820 --> 00:07:03.849
network mask,
telling you that 24 bits of this 32-bit

125
00:07:03.849 --> 00:07:08.278
router ID is gonna be the network
portion for what we're seeing.

126
00:07:08.278 --> 00:07:12.360
And as you scroll down, you'll actually
see some different ones maybe pop up.

127
00:07:12.360 --> 00:07:17.220
So down here, notice next to the letter
L as I go along through here, you'll

128
00:07:17.220 --> 00:07:21.220
actually see that there's one that's
a /32, and there's another /32 down here.

129
00:07:21.220 --> 00:07:25.600
So each one of these actually has a prefix
as well as a network mask too, okay?

130
00:07:26.760 --> 00:07:31.130
In each particular route
that you see listed here,

131
00:07:31.130 --> 00:07:37.870
you'll also not only find that idea of,
of course, the route itself.

132
00:07:37.870 --> 00:07:41.220
But you'll find a couple
of other things too, okay?

133
00:07:41.220 --> 00:07:45.990
So on this one, sometimes you see
the term where it says next hop, okay?

134
00:07:45.990 --> 00:07:50.165
But you'll also end up seeing where it
says, hey, this is how you get there.

135
00:07:50.165 --> 00:07:58.307
So notice that if you wanted to go from
this router to the 34.33.32 network,

136
00:07:58.307 --> 00:08:04.630
it says you are going to
go to 192.168 .12.2, okay?

137
00:08:04.630 --> 00:08:08.614
So there's two possibilities in this
configuration that you have as well.

138
00:08:08.614 --> 00:08:11.872
So you actually say hey,
that's the way it's gonna go and

139
00:08:11.872 --> 00:08:14.344
that's your next top
at that point as well.

140
00:08:14.344 --> 00:08:18.470
So you're seeing the prefix,
you're also seeing the network mask.

141
00:08:18.470 --> 00:08:21.860
You're also seeing the next hop
that is supposed to get you.

142
00:08:21.860 --> 00:08:28.480
Here's the IP address, so that I can
reach 34.33.32 that's gonna happen.

143
00:08:28.480 --> 00:08:29.550
On this router,

144
00:08:29.550 --> 00:08:35.800
you got a GigabitEthernet0/0 to
get there as what you also see.

145
00:08:35.800 --> 00:08:39.210
Now, along with that bit of information,
right?

146
00:08:39.210 --> 00:08:43.148
There's a bit of other stuff that we
have to talk about as well, okay?

147
00:08:43.148 --> 00:08:47.845
Administrative distance and metric,
all of that is inside these square

148
00:08:47.845 --> 00:08:50.777
brackets that you see right here too,
okay?

149
00:08:50.777 --> 00:08:55.449
Now inside the square brackets you'll see,
of course, a bracket with a single number

150
00:08:55.449 --> 00:08:58.979
at the beginning, a slash, and
then another number after that.

151
00:08:58.979 --> 00:09:04.858
The first number that you see listed there
is called the administrative distance.

152
00:09:04.858 --> 00:09:09.814
And the idea of the administrative
distance is a ranking of the routing,

153
00:09:09.814 --> 00:09:11.041
what can I say it?

154
00:09:11.041 --> 00:09:14.490
Routing protocols believability.
>> [LAUGH].

155
00:09:14.490 --> 00:09:16.030
>> That means that there are different

156
00:09:16.030 --> 00:09:18.200
routing protocols that are out there.

157
00:09:18.200 --> 00:09:21.300
You take a look up here at
the top on the codes here right?

158
00:09:21.300 --> 00:09:24.006
Notice there's local,
there's connected, there's static.

159
00:09:24.006 --> 00:09:28.520
There's RIP, mobile, BGP, EIGRP,

160
00:09:28.520 --> 00:09:32.200
notice the code here is where it says D
and we'll talk about that for a moment.

161
00:09:32.200 --> 00:09:36.470
There's also OSPF that's up here,
there's also a bunch of

162
00:09:36.470 --> 00:09:39.840
other types of codes that are up here,
but for us we'll see that

163
00:09:39.840 --> 00:09:42.930
that's kinda what we'll stick to out of
the ones that are a little bit higher.

164
00:09:42.930 --> 00:09:48.160
Inside of the middle list, there is also
another routing protocol called ISIS, and

165
00:09:48.160 --> 00:09:50.890
when you start seeing
that as well down here.

166
00:09:50.890 --> 00:09:54.080
And these are other types of
routing protocols that exist, but

167
00:09:54.080 --> 00:09:58.420
we don't tend to see them too often
in today's networks as well, okay?

168
00:09:58.420 --> 00:10:03.530
So, inside of this, what you have is each
one of those different routing protocols

169
00:10:03.530 --> 00:10:06.640
will have what they call
administrative distance.

170
00:10:06.640 --> 00:10:11.240
Administrative distance is somebody or
the router itself, saying here is

171
00:10:11.240 --> 00:10:15.620
how we are ranking these particular
protocols based on their believability.

172
00:10:15.620 --> 00:10:18.550
On what we believe is
gonna be the best way for

173
00:10:18.550 --> 00:10:20.950
you to get to that destination network.

174
00:10:20.950 --> 00:10:22.980
So that's what you'll end up seeing.

175
00:10:22.980 --> 00:10:25.446
Sometimes you'll see where
those numbers will change.

176
00:10:25.446 --> 00:10:30.404
On this one it looks like I'm only running
a RIP which means the routing protocol

177
00:10:30.404 --> 00:10:33.524
its administrative
distance is gonna be 120.

178
00:10:33.524 --> 00:10:34.996
But there are other ones and

179
00:10:34.996 --> 00:10:39.101
we'll take a look at a table of these
administrative distances in a moment.

180
00:10:39.101 --> 00:10:43.205
But that's the key here is that's how it
decides, if now you get multiple routing

181
00:10:43.205 --> 00:10:47.266
protocols it's gonna make the decision
based on the administrative distance.

182
00:10:47.266 --> 00:10:51.173
And the one that is actually the lowest
administrative distance will end up

183
00:10:51.173 --> 00:10:54.340
getting into the routing table itself,
okay?

184
00:10:54.340 --> 00:11:00.320
The idea of the metric is also dependent
on the idea of the routing protocol too.

185
00:11:00.320 --> 00:11:04.510
Different routing protocols will have
different metrics that their based on.

186
00:11:04.510 --> 00:11:08.570
So for example, the idea of RIP which
is the Routing Information Protocol,

187
00:11:08.570 --> 00:11:12.800
it is based on the number
of hops to the destination.

188
00:11:12.800 --> 00:11:17.760
In other words, how many routes or
how many other routers do I have to hit

189
00:11:17.760 --> 00:11:21.240
before I get to the destination network,
okay?

190
00:11:21.240 --> 00:11:25.030
So that can be true, but there's also
other ones that we see up here, for

191
00:11:25.030 --> 00:11:30.340
example, like this one, the D for EIGRP.

192
00:11:30.340 --> 00:11:35.110
EIGRP stands for
Enhanced Interior Gateway Protocol.

193
00:11:35.110 --> 00:11:40.330
And that is a very sophisticated
protocol that has about bandwidth and

194
00:11:40.330 --> 00:11:45.890
delay as this metric, which means it's
actually a more defined metric for

195
00:11:45.890 --> 00:11:49.560
us, and it has a lower
administrative distance as well.

196
00:11:49.560 --> 00:11:56.420
And then you have OSPPF which actually
falls into clean what RIP and EIGRP, okay?

197
00:11:56.420 --> 00:11:59.190
So, the reason why that's actually
important in terms of administrative

198
00:11:59.190 --> 00:12:02.670
distance, they also have
different metrics, okay?

199
00:12:02.670 --> 00:12:06.500
OSPF is really based on
bandwidth in between, and

200
00:12:06.500 --> 00:12:12.610
then EIGRP is based on bandwidth and
delay, and then

201
00:12:12.610 --> 00:12:17.200
RIP is only based on the number of routers
in between me and the destination, okay?

202
00:12:17.200 --> 00:12:19.307
So, all those are actually different.

203
00:12:19.307 --> 00:12:23.910
So in RIP here, you'll see
an administrative distance of 6.

204
00:12:23.910 --> 00:12:31.366
So that means that there is actually 6
hops between me and network 34.33.32.

205
00:12:31.366 --> 00:12:35.204
So there's six router hops that I
have to go through to get there.

206
00:12:35.204 --> 00:12:37.571
But in the EIGRP it could
be something different.

207
00:12:37.571 --> 00:12:41.603
It could be 34.92, it could be 15,
it could be whenever it might be,

208
00:12:41.603 --> 00:12:42.739
it doesn't matter.

209
00:12:42.739 --> 00:12:47.637
But that's a different way of actually
counting that particular metric to

210
00:12:47.637 --> 00:12:50.870
that destination network as well.

211
00:12:50.870 --> 00:12:54.350
Now there is one last element
here that we want to point out,

212
00:12:54.350 --> 00:12:59.670
which is this idea of the gateway
of last resort is not set, okay?

213
00:12:59.670 --> 00:13:03.910
Now, you can set this and this is
something that you may choose to set up,

214
00:13:03.910 --> 00:13:06.640
it is all dependent
upon your network here.

215
00:13:06.640 --> 00:13:10.941

216
00:13:10.941 --> 00:13:15.166
You and I on our regular computers we
have what we call a default gateway.

217
00:13:15.166 --> 00:13:20.116
And that is so that when my computer
needs to send something somewhere,what it

218
00:13:20.116 --> 00:13:24.997
takes a look at it says, hey, is the
destination IP address on this network?

219
00:13:24.997 --> 00:13:26.577
Or is it on another network?

220
00:13:26.577 --> 00:13:31.608
Or it's on another network,
it knows that it's supposed to send it

221
00:13:31.608 --> 00:13:36.745
to the router interface, or
to the default gateway address, okay?

222
00:13:36.745 --> 00:13:41.305
And the way it does that is because what
the router itself has put a proxy outside,

223
00:13:41.305 --> 00:13:43.331
I am the default gateway to do that.

224
00:13:43.331 --> 00:13:46.340
So here you can set that up for
the router.

00:13:46.340 --> 00:13:48.079

00:13:48.079 --> 00:13:53.484
That means that if now the router receives
a packet, that is not destined for

00:13:53.484 --> 00:13:58.635

here in the routing table itself,

00:13:58.635 --> 00:14:02.098

229
00:14:02.098 --> 00:14:05.149

00:14:05.149 --> 00:14:09.815

00:14:09.815 --> 00:14:12.698

want us to go to is gonna be

00:26:50.549 --> 00:26:57.500
192.168.16.3, okay?

421
00:26:57.500 --> 00:27:00.062
That is gonna be the next hop.

422
00:27:00.062 --> 00:27:04.450
So now I'm trying to put in to
the routing table the 172.16.16 and

423
00:27:04.450 --> 00:27:08.130
here is the next hop as well.

424
00:27:11.070 --> 00:27:15.956
Oops, I misspelled something, so
let me try it one more time here,

425
00:27:15.956 --> 00:27:20.951
ip route, so apparently copying and
pasting is not my best bet here.

426
00:27:23.323 --> 00:27:30.728
.0 and then 192.168.16.3, okay.

427
00:27:30.728 --> 00:27:34.029
So now, if I typed in a do show ip route,

428
00:27:37.508 --> 00:27:40.270
Notice the code changes.

429
00:27:40.270 --> 00:27:45.940
We have an S for static but also now
notice that this changes too, okay?

430
00:27:45.940 --> 00:27:51.470
So inside the administrative distance as
well as the metric ended up changing too.

431
00:27:51.470 --> 00:27:55.220
So this one is telling me hey,
172.16.16 has

432
00:27:55.220 --> 00:28:01.020
an administrative distance of 1,
notice the metric is 0.

433
00:28:01.020 --> 00:28:04.300
Now when we start seeing metrics
of zero saying there's no hop,

434
00:28:04.300 --> 00:28:05.510
where are we sending it?

435
00:28:05.510 --> 00:28:11.040
We're actually telling it to send it out
of this IP address right here, okay?

436
00:28:11.040 --> 00:28:15.136
So this is saying I know exactly where
to go, this is directly connected,

437
00:28:15.136 --> 00:28:19.360
there is no hop in between,
it's just going to send it there, okay?

438
00:28:19.360 --> 00:28:23.420
And so that means that this
particular router, actually,

439
00:28:23.420 --> 00:28:24.960
this is a layer 3 switch.

440
00:28:24.960 --> 00:28:27.758
If you now take a look here,

441
00:28:27.758 --> 00:28:33.610
you can see that we're
starting to get to 172.16.

442
00:28:33.610 --> 00:28:37.423
We have to send it out this interface,
192.168.16.1.

443
00:28:37.423 --> 00:28:41.940
So, this GigabitEthernet0/0,

444
00:28:41.940 --> 00:28:47.740
that is actually statically or
very closely connected to,

445
00:28:47.740 --> 00:28:51.390
well this interface, which means
it's in the same network for us.

446
00:28:51.390 --> 00:28:54.170
We're not taking any hop
to go anywhere else.

447
00:28:54.170 --> 00:28:58.930
All right so should I now be able to ping,

448
00:28:58.930 --> 00:29:04.370
do ping 172.16.16.1, okay?

449
00:29:04.370 --> 00:29:08.510
So there it is, I am now able to
ping that particular address and

450
00:29:08.510 --> 00:29:10.350
we can actually get to it.

451
00:29:10.350 --> 00:29:14.150
Now there's also a problem
though that can happen.

452
00:29:14.150 --> 00:29:19.340
Usually on static routing when you do
this, okay, on this side, it's already

453
00:29:19.340 --> 00:29:22.790
been configured for the other side, but
you have to configure it on both ends.

454
00:29:22.790 --> 00:29:26.468
Because if not,
you'll send data in one way, but

455
00:29:26.468 --> 00:29:32.249
if the other side is not ready to return
traffic or it has to return traffic, and

456
00:29:32.249 --> 00:29:37.788
is not in the routing table over on
the other side which is on NYEDGE1 here,

457
00:29:40.960 --> 00:29:45.370
On NYEDGE1, it would not
normally know how to get it back.

458
00:29:45.370 --> 00:29:48.670
So let me type out shell
iproute not do shell.

459
00:29:51.180 --> 00:29:56.490
So on shellip route,
it has to have a path coming all the way

460
00:29:56.490 --> 00:30:01.340
back to .16.3 network and
notice that it already had

461
00:30:01.340 --> 00:30:04.680
enlisted in here because it
is locally connected to it.

462
00:30:04.680 --> 00:30:09.184
So if this was actually not that way and
you're actually pinging to another network

463
00:30:09.184 --> 00:30:13.234
that was offlist, and it didn't have
it in the routing table to come back,

464
00:30:13.234 --> 00:30:15.314
well then you couldn't do so, okay?

465
00:30:15.314 --> 00:30:19.292
So when you set up static route it has
to be configured on both sides for

466
00:30:19.292 --> 00:30:23.220
you to normally do that and
make sure that ends that problem, okay?

467
00:30:23.220 --> 00:30:27.890
All right, so now Zach, there's a lot for
us to talk about with the routing table,

468
00:30:27.890 --> 00:30:29.930
cuz we still got some things to examine.

469
00:30:29.930 --> 00:30:33.330
And we still need to talk about
the idea of configuring for

470
00:30:33.330 --> 00:30:37.700
dynamic routing protocols but we are at
the end of this particular segment.

471
00:30:37.700 --> 00:30:40.240
So let's go ahead and stop it right now,
and then we'll have a part 2

472
00:30:40.240 --> 00:30:43.077
when we come back.
>> Okay, but may I say, well done, Ronnie.

473
00:30:43.077 --> 00:30:47.010
Describe Routing Tables Part 1,
there will be a Part 2, and

474
00:30:47.010 --> 00:30:49.440
there might even be a Part 3,
you never know.

475
00:30:49.440 --> 00:30:50.480
Anyway, before we move on,

476
00:30:50.480 --> 00:30:53.437
Ronnie, any last words?
>> Well just remember, right,

477
00:30:53.437 --> 00:30:57.920
on static routing, it actually has to be
configured normally on both sides for us.

478
00:30:57.920 --> 00:31:01.170
But on this one, cuz it was directly
connected to the router, it said hey,

479
00:31:01.170 --> 00:31:04.880
as I'm replying back, I know exactly
where to send out cuz it was in

480
00:31:04.880 --> 00:31:07.670
the routing table already so
you don't have to worry about it.

481
00:31:07.670 --> 00:31:10.240
But if you don't find it in
the routing table on the other side,

482
00:31:10.240 --> 00:31:12.325
you have to configure it there too.

483
00:31:12.325 --> 00:31:16.275
So it is very possible you configure on
one side and it doesn't work, make sure

484
00:31:16.275 --> 00:31:18.345
you always configure on both sides.
>> Fantastic and

485
00:31:18.345 --> 00:31:21.195
you'll find out more in
Describe Routing Tables Part 2.

486
00:31:21.195 --> 00:31:24.495
Make sure you see everything inside
the Cisco CSense Series too.

487
00:31:24.495 --> 00:31:27.195
Ronnie has done a great job putting
that all together for you and

488
00:31:27.195 --> 00:31:29.775
it'll help you in the exams and even more.

489
00:31:29.775 --> 00:31:33.015
And by the way it'll be in the course
library too and there's thousands of other

490
00:31:33.015 --> 00:31:36.690
videos there designed to do one thing,
help you go further.

491
00:31:36.690 --> 00:31:40.910
And tell everybody you know about
IT Pro TV, IT Pro TV is binge worthy.

492
00:31:40.910 --> 00:31:43.460
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

493
00:31:43.460 --> 00:31:46.574
>> And we will see you soon.

494
00:31:46.574 --> 00:31:52.633
[MUSIC]

495
00:31:52.633 --> 00:31:55.170
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce basic routing table and the information it provides. They discuss the different components of the routing table in use.  The guys discuss and show how to configure dynamic routing and demonstrate how the router learns from another protocol.
episodes.title: Describe Routing Tables Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.960
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:02.960 --> 00:00:05.279
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:05.279 --> 00:00:06.759
California [CROSSTALK].

4
00:00:06.759 --> 00:00:07.867
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.867 --> 00:00:12.309
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Thank you for

6
00:00:12.309 --> 00:00:17.010
watching ITProTV, empowering
the world through engaging learning.

7
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:21.110
I'm your host Zach Memos,
as we continue on with Cisco CCENT

8
00:00:21.110 --> 00:00:25.250
describe routing tables part two,
make sure you see part one.

9
00:00:25.250 --> 00:00:29.190
And the person to bring us the information
we need is the one and only Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:31.250
Ronnie, great to see you again, sir.
>> Well, thank you for

11
00:00:31.250 --> 00:00:35.740
having me back as we continue on
in our lab here for Cisco CCENT.

12
00:00:35.740 --> 00:00:36.650
And we're in the middle of,

13
00:00:36.650 --> 00:00:39.850
of course, taking a look at
the elements in the routing table.

14
00:00:39.850 --> 00:00:43.740
We've already talked and described about
so many different elements that are there,

15
00:00:43.740 --> 00:00:47.450
and now we're showing you how it
also works as we come through, and

16
00:00:47.450 --> 00:00:50.550
as we're starting to work
with the routers too, okay?

17
00:00:50.550 --> 00:00:55.530
So so far in our lab, we've configured
what, one side of a static route, and

18
00:00:55.530 --> 00:00:58.540
we also, of course,
verified that it is working

19
00:00:58.540 --> 00:01:01.865
by being on a ping now that's
inside of the routing table.

20
00:01:01.865 --> 00:01:05.470
And we still need to configure the other
side, and show you how that also worked.

21
00:01:05.470 --> 00:01:09.160
Then we'll jump into dynamic
routing protocols as well, and

22
00:01:09.160 --> 00:01:11.250
talk about some administrative distance.

23
00:01:11.250 --> 00:01:13.460
So we're ready to pick up from here.
>> Perfect.

24
00:01:13.460 --> 00:01:15.100
>> Let's take a look here, okay?

25
00:01:15.100 --> 00:01:20.030
Right on my machine, we left off exactly
in this place here where we were

26
00:01:20.030 --> 00:01:25.050
just finishing up, we had just
finished pinging the other side.

27
00:01:25.050 --> 00:01:29.320
And now we came to NYWAN1,
and we showed why it

28
00:01:29.320 --> 00:01:32.710
did end up replying even though I said
you have to configure both sides.

29
00:01:32.710 --> 00:01:35.760
It is because that route
is already in there.

30
00:01:35.760 --> 00:01:37.310
Now, this is something
that gets confusing for

31
00:01:37.310 --> 00:01:40.490
most people that are just starting off.

32
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:45.170
Because they're multiple IP addresses on
this device and even on NYEDGE1, right?

33
00:01:45.170 --> 00:01:50.060
Okay, there are actually going to be
multiple IP addresses on this one.

34
00:01:50.060 --> 00:01:56.963
Let me show you what I mean, do show
IP interface, brief, just briefly here.

35
00:01:59.329 --> 00:02:03.150
All right, so, Zack, as you take
a look at this table right here, okay?

36
00:02:03.150 --> 00:02:06.413
Notice that on Gigabit Ethernet 0/0 and

37
00:02:06.413 --> 00:02:10.589
0/1 there's two different IP addresses,
right?

38
00:02:10.589 --> 00:02:14.165
Then go all the way down
to the bottom loop-back 0,

39
00:02:14.165 --> 00:02:17.264
there's 172180/1 as well, okay?

40
00:02:17.264 --> 00:02:22.182
So when I pinged from this
device over to 172.16.16.1,

41
00:02:22.182 --> 00:02:26.058
which IP address does it ping from, okay?
>> Gee,

42
00:02:26.058 --> 00:02:31.150
I probably don't know.
>> Yes well, see, that is the problem.

43
00:02:31.150 --> 00:02:32.410
>> It's hard to figure it out, yeah.

44
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:34.610
>> Most of us do not understand and

45
00:02:34.610 --> 00:02:37.580
do not know which IP
address that goes out from,

46
00:02:37.580 --> 00:02:38.110
right?
>> That is right

47
00:02:38.110 --> 00:02:39.900
>> When you and I send a regular ping

48
00:02:39.900 --> 00:02:42.280
from our machines, and it goes out, and

49
00:02:42.280 --> 00:02:46.020
it hits someplace across the Internet,
and comes back, well we know something.

50
00:02:46.020 --> 00:02:48.670
We only have one IP
address on my machine so

51
00:02:48.670 --> 00:02:51.800
we know the source IP address is mine.
>> Right.

52
00:02:51.800 --> 00:02:52.410
>> But now,

53
00:02:52.410 --> 00:02:54.600
Zach, I'm showing you three.
>> Correct.

54
00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:55.950
>> And so which one is it?

55
00:02:55.950 --> 00:02:59.390
See, that's the problem,
it's that we don't exactly understand

56
00:02:59.390 --> 00:03:00.710
which one it really is.
>> Yeah,

57
00:03:00.710 --> 00:03:01.710
I don't know.
>> But

58
00:03:01.710 --> 00:03:06.430
what essentially ends up happening here,
when we issue out a pig, okay?

59
00:03:06.430 --> 00:03:08.680
A ping, I said pig, I think.
>> [LAUGH]

60
00:03:08.680 --> 00:03:10.110
>> When we issue out a ping-

61
00:03:10.110 --> 00:03:10.900
>> Don't send out a pig.

62
00:03:10.900 --> 00:03:11.940
>> Don't send out a pig,

63
00:03:11.940 --> 00:03:17.470
it's not gonna work.
>> But when we send out a ping, whatever

64
00:03:17.470 --> 00:03:22.560
interface the ping exits from,
okay, goes out of,

65
00:03:22.560 --> 00:03:29.090
that will be the source IP address of
that ping, or any traffic that goes out.

66
00:03:29.090 --> 00:03:32.480
That will be that,
if it originates from the router.

67
00:03:32.480 --> 00:03:38.075
If the router were sending it out,
let's say, to 172.14.0.10, right?

68
00:03:38.075 --> 00:03:40.839
Well, it would send it out as 172.14.0.1,
okay?

69
00:03:40.839 --> 00:03:48.710
So remember that this is about
the source being the router itself.

70
00:03:48.710 --> 00:03:50.810
When we took a look at the network path,
right?

71
00:03:50.810 --> 00:03:55.224
And the data going from one device through
a couple of routers going to other device,

72
00:03:55.224 --> 00:03:59.515
I said that the IP address doesn't change
its source and destination IP address,

73
00:03:59.515 --> 00:04:00.969
layer three is protected.

74
00:04:00.969 --> 00:04:05.604
Well, that's different than what we
see right here because this is now not

75
00:04:05.604 --> 00:04:10.830
originating as traffic goes through the
router, this is now the router originating

76
00:04:10.830 --> 00:04:16.739
the traffic, which is what we started
here when we said ping 172.16.16.0, okay?

77
00:04:16.739 --> 00:04:21.670
So now when we do something like that,
we've got to realize that over on,

78
00:04:21.670 --> 00:04:28.910
when it replied back, that means that
when we sent it from here, right?

79
00:04:28.910 --> 00:04:29.980
It went out.

80
00:04:29.980 --> 00:04:37.328
The route that we had inside
the table that said 172 16,

81
00:04:37.328 --> 00:04:42.095
that it goes out to 172.16.1.

82
00:04:42.095 --> 00:04:47.112
So it went across 172.16.1,
so it went across 172.16,

83
00:04:47.112 --> 00:04:51.054
it went out, excuse me, 192.168.16.1.

84
00:04:52.657 --> 00:04:55.190
On NY1 over here, okay?

85
00:04:56.790 --> 00:05:00.030
It received it right here, and

86
00:05:00.030 --> 00:05:04.110
it knew because it was directly connected,
and it responded here.

87
00:05:04.110 --> 00:05:09.250
Then it sent it back over here, and went
back to, well, as we go up to NYEDGE1,

88
00:05:09.250 --> 00:05:13.050
went back up this device, and it answered.

89
00:05:13.050 --> 00:05:17.037
So everything was good, that's why we
end up getting the successful replies

90
00:05:17.037 --> 00:05:18.020
that we got.

91
00:05:18.020 --> 00:05:18.588
>> Okay.
>> Okay.

92
00:05:18.588 --> 00:05:20.050
All right, so that make sense.

93
00:05:20.050 --> 00:05:24.780
At least, I hope it makes sense to you,
it's really what the hope is, okay?

94
00:05:24.780 --> 00:05:28.079
Now, once we get it, now,

95
00:05:28.079 --> 00:05:33.389
I configure an IP address over on NYEDGE1,

96
00:05:33.389 --> 00:05:38.574
which was 172.14.0.1, okay?

97
00:05:38.574 --> 00:05:42.110
Well, it's in the same configuration.

98
00:05:42.110 --> 00:05:45.014
I've configured it on NYEDGE1, but

99
00:05:45.014 --> 00:05:50.835
notice it's not right here in the router,
in the routing table of NYWAN1.

100
00:05:50.835 --> 00:05:58.211
So now when I ping 172.14.0.1, okay?

101
00:05:58.211 --> 00:06:00.585
Even though I know it's on NYEDGE1,

102
00:06:00.585 --> 00:06:03.860
and we were able to ping
from the other side, right?

103
00:06:05.390 --> 00:06:09.726
We showed you how to ping from
192.168.16.1 all the way through

104
00:06:09.726 --> 00:06:11.360
172.16.16.1.

105
00:06:11.360 --> 00:06:14.480
Well, now notice that I'm
getting these five periods here,

106
00:06:14.480 --> 00:06:18.560
which means it's answering, but
it's not because it's successful.

107
00:06:18.560 --> 00:06:21.490
It's essentially saying, no,
I'm not answering for this.

108
00:06:21.490 --> 00:06:24.960
And that's because it's not
in this routing table here,

109
00:06:24.960 --> 00:06:25.570
okay?
>> Okay.

110
00:06:25.570 --> 00:06:27.290
>> So if it's not in the routing table,

111
00:06:27.290 --> 00:06:28.420
I can not ping it.

112
00:06:28.420 --> 00:06:32.290
And that's why you have to make sure
that you configure it on both ends.

113
00:06:32.290 --> 00:06:32.900
>> On both ends.

114
00:06:32.900 --> 00:06:37.619
>> So if I do the config terminal,

115
00:06:37.619 --> 00:06:44.526
now I can go IP route 172.14.0.0.

116
00:06:44.526 --> 00:06:49.092
And then we'll do a 24 bit
subnet mask in the same way I

117
00:06:49.092 --> 00:06:52.630
configured it in that interface.

118
00:06:52.630 --> 00:06:58.660
Now, I'm gonna tell it
to go across to 16.1,

119
00:06:58.660 --> 00:07:04.272
the next hop, or
next device along that path.

120
00:07:04.272 --> 00:07:09.638
Now, if I issue out a ping, 172.14.0.1,

121
00:07:09.638 --> 00:07:14.530
now notice that we are successful, okay?

122
00:07:14.530 --> 00:07:18.750
So if you get where you get what we
call unidirectional traffic, okay?

123
00:07:18.750 --> 00:07:20.230
That's what we just showed you.
>> Right.

124
00:07:20.230 --> 00:07:21.450
>> It pinged one way, but

125
00:07:21.450 --> 00:07:24.690
I couldn't ping the other way,
back the way I needed to.

126
00:07:24.690 --> 00:07:29.031
It's because I did not set up
the static routing on both ends, okay?

127
00:07:29.031 --> 00:07:34.700
So static routing, make sure you configure
it on both routers if you do this.

128
00:07:34.700 --> 00:07:36.670
It's very important that you do that.

129
00:07:36.670 --> 00:07:40.743
Remember that even though this
is a great way to do routing,

130
00:07:40.743 --> 00:07:44.009
it's only great in certain scenarios,
okay?

131
00:07:44.009 --> 00:07:48.383
The very fact is if you have a network
that really isn't gonna grow much bigger,

132
00:07:48.383 --> 00:07:52.563
okay, static routing is the way to go
because it doesn't generate any extra

133
00:07:52.563 --> 00:07:53.175
traffic.

134
00:07:53.175 --> 00:07:55.941
It's set,
all it has to do is a look up, okay?

135
00:07:55.941 --> 00:08:00.071
It goes okay, there's the list, it says
send it up this interface to that device,

136
00:08:00.071 --> 00:08:01.640
we're ready to go.

137
00:08:01.640 --> 00:08:04.970
So it doesn't have to actually
calculate or do anything, okay?

138
00:08:04.970 --> 00:08:09.453
But it does mean though that every
time there's a change in network, and

139
00:08:09.453 --> 00:08:13.040
it does change,
you have to manually configure it.

140
00:08:13.040 --> 00:08:17.710
So it's a much more hands on type of
configuration, that you're doing, yes.

141
00:08:17.710 --> 00:08:19.700
>> Is dynamic more flexible?

142
00:08:19.700 --> 00:08:20.680
>> It is, okay, and

143
00:08:20.680 --> 00:08:22.790
that's what we wanna talk about as well,
okay?

144
00:08:22.790 --> 00:08:27.960
So if you do know that your network
is gonna continue to grow and

145
00:08:27.960 --> 00:08:31.940
change because you realize
that the future is coming,

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review the need of interVLAN routing as vlans on a single switch cannot directly communicate without a router.  They discuss the configuration must occur on the switch as well as the trunk.  They show how to configure the trunk port on the switch as well as the subinterfaces on the router.
episodes.title: Configure InterVLAN Routing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:06.202
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.202 --> 00:00:08.142
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.142 --> 00:00:12.631
>> You're watching ITPro TV.
>> Hello, again.

4
00:00:12.631 --> 00:00:16.850
Thank you for choosing ITPro TV,
we're helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:20.560
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with Cisco CCENT.

6
00:00:20.560 --> 00:00:23.940
We are going to configure
inter-VLAN routing in this episode,

7
00:00:23.940 --> 00:00:25.090
that's what we're going to do.

8
00:00:25.090 --> 00:00:27.130
And Ronnie Wong is going
to help us do that, Ronnie,

9
00:00:27.130 --> 00:00:30.330
good to see you.
>> Thank you, Zach, for being right here

10
00:00:30.330 --> 00:00:34.048
and for helping me out as we continue
on in our CCENT journey together.

11
00:00:34.048 --> 00:00:36.853
Today, we're gonna be taking
a look at iner-VLAN routing.

12
00:00:36.853 --> 00:00:38.720
Now, I've held off on this,

13
00:00:38.720 --> 00:00:43.450
there are times I wanted to jump into
it during our LAN switching episodes.

14
00:00:43.450 --> 00:00:46.470
But it really doesn't involve LAN
switching as much as it involves of

15
00:00:46.470 --> 00:00:47.700
course routing.

16
00:00:47.700 --> 00:00:50.890
And that is because we need to
be able to route between VLANs.

17
00:00:50.890 --> 00:00:55.230
And what we already talked about was
the idea inside of LAN switching

18
00:00:55.230 --> 00:00:59.430
that if I configure two different
VLANs on that same physical switch.

19
00:00:59.430 --> 00:01:03.860
They cannot directly communicate
well between those two VLANs

20
00:01:03.860 --> 00:01:08.530
without the help of a layer 3
device such as a router, okay?

21
00:01:08.530 --> 00:01:11.480
So today we're gonna show
you that configuration so

22
00:01:11.480 --> 00:01:16.450
that you can allow for the idea of
inter-VLAN routing even between

23
00:01:16.450 --> 00:01:18.800
two VLANs on the same switch as well.

24
00:01:18.800 --> 00:01:21.360
I wanna show you two different
ways to accomplish this.

25
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:22.200
So let's remind

26
00:01:22.200 --> 00:01:23.261
you of what I'm talking about here.
>> Okay.

27
00:01:23.261 --> 00:01:25.641
>> So, we'll take a look on my screen, and

28
00:01:25.641 --> 00:01:28.800
this will help us out a little bit more,
okay?

29
00:01:28.800 --> 00:01:33.190
So remember that when we started off
in LAN switching we took essentially

30
00:01:33.190 --> 00:01:38.218
a single switch and
then we configured multiple VLANs on this.

31
00:01:38.218 --> 00:01:41.480
That's just generic,
we'll be using different VLAN numbers

32
00:01:41.480 --> 00:01:43.700
when we get into
the configuration side of this.

33
00:01:43.700 --> 00:01:48.870
But for us, that means that each one
of these is its own broadcast domain.

34
00:01:48.870 --> 00:01:52.700
Essentially three different
networks on this same switch.

35
00:01:52.700 --> 00:01:57.530
Well, because they're three different
networks, well, I cannot have

36
00:01:57.530 --> 00:02:03.130
one port over here directly communicate
with another port in another VLAN.

37
00:02:03.130 --> 00:02:09.730
For me do so I need to involve
a router to help us to do this, okay?

38
00:02:09.730 --> 00:02:14.590
That router that we have allows us to
do what we call inter-VLAN routing.

39
00:02:14.590 --> 00:02:18.740
Because we are actually sending data
from one network to another network.

40
00:02:18.740 --> 00:02:22.095
So what essentially ends up
happening at this particular point,

41
00:02:22.095 --> 00:02:23.803
once everything is configured.

42
00:02:23.803 --> 00:02:28.950
Is that I can communicate
between VLAN 10 going to VLAN

43
00:02:28.950 --> 00:02:35.522
20 by going across that interface,
getting into the routing table,

44
00:02:35.522 --> 00:02:39.890
and the routing table sending it back out.

45
00:02:39.890 --> 00:02:43.710
And then getting accessed either
to the wireless or into VLAN 20,

46
00:02:43.710 --> 00:02:45.510
whatever it might be, okay?

47
00:02:45.510 --> 00:02:50.290
So all that is actually possible when
we start to do something like this as

48
00:02:50.290 --> 00:02:51.420
well, okay?
>> Okay.

49
00:02:51.420 --> 00:02:54.130
>> Now, it actually does require us to do

50
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:56.600
a couple of things because the router

51
00:02:56.600 --> 00:03:00.370
will actually do something that
we don't want it to do, okay?

52
00:03:00.370 --> 00:03:04.365
Routers by default don't like this idea.

53
00:03:04.365 --> 00:03:08.030
And what it doesn't like about it is that

54
00:03:08.030 --> 00:03:12.420
it has a mechanism that's involved
at the router level up here, okay?

55
00:03:12.420 --> 00:03:17.330
That says, look,
to prevent routing loops, okay?

56
00:03:17.330 --> 00:03:20.430
What will I will do is I will go ahead and

57
00:03:20.430 --> 00:03:24.390
implement this idea that
I will not allow for

58
00:03:24.390 --> 00:03:29.990
data that comes in one interface
to go back out the same interface.

59
00:03:29.990 --> 00:03:33.418
Now, in our LAN switching episodes,
we already talked about this.

60
00:03:33.418 --> 00:03:37.884
That as we send data into one port,
it will forward it out to every

61
00:03:37.884 --> 00:03:42.790
other port on the switch except for
the one it comes in on.

62
00:03:42.790 --> 00:03:48.050
Routers will not actually allow for
us to send data in and

63
00:03:48.050 --> 00:03:52.090
send it back out that same port to do so.

64
00:03:52.090 --> 00:03:56.997
So what we have to do is we have
to actually trick the router by

65
00:03:56.997 --> 00:04:02.603
configuring it to handle well,
more than one VLAN traffic, okay?

66
00:04:02.603 --> 00:04:07.370
So we'll have to actually come up with a
configuration to help us to do that, okay?

67
00:04:07.370 --> 00:04:11.110
And that is what we call creating
sub interfaces on the router, and

68
00:04:11.110 --> 00:04:12.580
we'll show you how to do that in our lab.

69
00:04:13.760 --> 00:04:17.960
The other thing that has to be done of
course is on the switch itself too, okay?

70
00:04:17.960 --> 00:04:21.220
So let me get rid of this drawing cuz
it's kinda defeating my purpose of what

71
00:04:21.220 --> 00:04:22.760
I needed, okay?
>> [LAUGH]

72
00:04:22.760 --> 00:04:24.630
>> Also on the link then,

73
00:04:24.630 --> 00:04:29.300
it has to be able to handle, well,
traffic from more than one VLAN.

74
00:04:29.300 --> 00:04:32.140
So inside of our LAN switching episodes,
we said for

75
00:04:32.140 --> 00:04:35.220
us to be able to send traffic across,
well,

76
00:04:35.220 --> 00:04:40.240
a single link from multiple VLANs,
we have to configure this interface,

77
00:04:40.240 --> 00:04:46.330
Gigabit 0/1 as an example,
as being a trunk interface as well.

78
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:51.124
So in doing what we call the idea of
inter-VLAN routing with a router,

79
00:04:51.124 --> 00:04:55.610
we have to configure this switch
port over here to be a trunk port.

80
00:04:56.920 --> 00:05:02.285
Then on the router, we've got to
configure that interface over here

81
00:05:02.285 --> 00:05:09.250
to essentially be logically sub-divided up
to handle a VLAN for each one of these.

82
00:05:09.250 --> 00:05:13.250
So essentially turning this link
into three virtual links for

83
00:05:13.250 --> 00:05:15.830
us on one link here.

84
00:05:15.830 --> 00:05:21.380
The only limitation that you and I have
as far as the physical configuration goes

85
00:05:21.380 --> 00:05:28.310
is you cannot use a 10 megabit
connection to this trunk, okay?

86
00:05:28.310 --> 00:05:32.170
It's gonna require at least a fast
Ethernet connection, or 100 megabit, or

87
00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:34.580
a gigabit connection to do so.

88
00:05:34.580 --> 00:05:37.460
So do not try this with a slower link.

89
00:05:37.460 --> 00:05:39.810
It must be up here, okay?

90
00:05:39.810 --> 00:05:44.340
We must have either 100 megabit or we
have to have a gigabit connection, okay?

91
00:05:44.340 --> 00:05:48.570
So that's kind of the key in what
we're doing when we start doing this.

92
00:05:48.570 --> 00:05:51.680
The other thing that we're gonna talk
about a little bit later on is when we

93
00:05:51.680 --> 00:05:55.280
don't actually have a router
any more to deal with and

94
00:05:55.280 --> 00:05:56.722
we only have a layer 3 switch.

95
00:05:56.722 --> 00:06:00.477
Well, how do we configure inter-VLAN
routing with a layer 3 switch?

96
00:06:00.477 --> 00:06:02.700
And we'll get to that one as well.

97
00:06:02.700 --> 00:06:06.010
This particular topology that we're doing

98
00:06:06.010 --> 00:06:10.060
right now is also regularly
known as router on a stick.

99
00:06:10.060 --> 00:06:11.097
And you can see why.
>> [LAUGH]

100
00:06:11.097 --> 00:06:12.550
>> It looks like a lollipop.

101
00:06:12.550 --> 00:06:13.976
It does, it looks like a-
>> It's great name.

102
00:06:13.976 --> 00:06:15.753
>> It's actually right on a stick, and

103
00:06:15.753 --> 00:06:18.980
that's why they call this
configuration router on a stick.

104
00:06:18.980 --> 00:06:22.130
So remember that there's two
sides to this configuration.

105
00:06:22.130 --> 00:06:24.920
And the one that you're gonna pay
attention to most is gonna be

106
00:06:24.920 --> 00:06:27.860
right up here on the router configuration.

107
00:06:27.860 --> 00:06:32.030
Configuring this as being a trunk isn't
the hardest thing in the world to do, but

108
00:06:32.030 --> 00:06:36.200
we are gonna limit it to the VLANs
that we want going across it, and

109
00:06:36.200 --> 00:06:40.150
not just opening up to every
single VLAN that we can find out.

110
00:06:40.150 --> 00:06:44.270
But overall though, you'll see its
configuration is relatively simple, okay?

111
00:06:44.270 --> 00:06:48.780
So let's go ahead and do that so that we
can see what's gonna be happening, okay?

112
00:06:48.780 --> 00:06:53.225
So here, we're gonna be using this
lab right here called Configure,

113
00:06:53.225 --> 00:06:58.065
Verify, and
Troubleshoot Inter-VLAN Routing, okay?

114
00:06:58.065 --> 00:07:01.155
So that is the lab that we'll
be using to help us to set

115
00:07:01.155 --> 00:07:02.085
this up.
>> Wonderful.

116
00:07:02.085 --> 00:07:03.385
>> They pre-configure

117
00:07:03.385 --> 00:07:05.375
this in a couple of different ways.

118
00:07:05.375 --> 00:07:09.410
So what we have on the switch
that we'll be using, okay,

119
00:07:09.410 --> 00:07:14.051
already on NYCORE1,
is gonna be three different VLANs, okay?

120
00:07:14.051 --> 00:07:17.115
They've already configured VLAN 16,
17, and 18,

121
00:07:17.115 --> 00:07:20.500
they've already been
configured in the setup.

122
00:07:20.500 --> 00:07:25.140
Because of the way that the switches
work in this basic diagram here, so

123
00:07:25.140 --> 00:07:27.810
let me see if I can pull
up the basic diagram and

124
00:07:27.810 --> 00:07:30.520
I'll kinda take a look at
it a little bit more here.

125
00:07:30.520 --> 00:07:36.350
So in this diagram, because there's
actually two switches in between here and

126
00:07:36.350 --> 00:07:40.370
what we're configuring is really just
right here in-between this router and

127
00:07:40.370 --> 00:07:41.250
this switch.

128
00:07:41.250 --> 00:07:46.119
They've gone ahead and they've configured
a trunk link in-between NYCORE1 and

129
00:07:46.119 --> 00:07:47.390
NYACCESS1.

130
00:07:47.390 --> 00:07:49.630
So it actually does act does one switch,
so

131
00:07:49.630 --> 00:07:53.128
you don't have to worry about
that configuration as well, okay?

132
00:07:53.128 --> 00:07:57.184
Also, the P lab CSO1,
whatever this one is,

133
00:07:57.184 --> 00:08:01.041
is also been configured
with an IP address.

134
00:08:01.041 --> 00:08:04.399
And NYACCESS1 has been
configured with IP address,

135
00:08:04.399 --> 00:08:07.541
they're gonna be in two different VLANs,
okay?

136
00:08:07.541 --> 00:08:10.733
So those IP addresses are gonna be
in different VLANs is what we'll

137
00:08:10.733 --> 00:08:11.790
end up seeing there.

138
00:08:11.790 --> 00:08:17.610
All right, so now that we've got that
settled up here, let's go to NYCORE1 which

139
00:08:17.610 --> 00:08:22.950
is gonna be the switch that we're going
to configure for the trunk link, okay?

140
00:08:22.950 --> 00:08:26.260
So we're configuring now
the trunk between us and

141
00:08:26.260 --> 00:08:30.100
NYEDGE1 which is gonna be our router,
all right?

142
00:08:30.100 --> 00:08:35.302
So on NYCORE1, go ahead and
get accessed in, if I can,

143
00:08:35.302 --> 00:08:41.636
and get out of the user mode into
privileged exec mode, well maybe.

144
00:08:43.795 --> 00:08:47.583
Lemme try it one more time,
get there, okay?

145
00:08:47.583 --> 00:08:50.990
Configure terminal.

146
00:08:53.120 --> 00:08:54.750
Now, I don't know why it keeps going back.

147
00:08:56.360 --> 00:08:59.936
Let's see if I can get to NYCORE1 here.

148
00:08:59.936 --> 00:09:03.690
It keeps kicking me like it's not
going to allow me to do that.

149
00:09:03.690 --> 00:09:04.940
Maybe, let me zoom out.

150
00:09:04.940 --> 00:09:10.340
Sometimes that zooming thing
is not doing what we wanna do.

151
00:09:10.340 --> 00:09:15.060
So hopefully I can keep that on the screen
here without causing much delay, okay?

152
00:09:15.060 --> 00:09:22.252
So that interface between NYCORE1 and
NYEDGE1 is fast ethernet 1/0/1.

153
00:09:22.252 --> 00:09:25.356
So if I go into global configuration mode.

154
00:09:28.397 --> 00:09:31.571
It still kicks me all the way out there.

155
00:09:48.377 --> 00:09:52.615
Okay, finally, [LAUGH] I don't know why,

156
00:09:52.615 --> 00:09:56.867
I was like, it's still not working here.

157
00:09:56.867 --> 00:10:01.905
So I just give it a moment here and
so once we get in there,

158
00:10:01.905 --> 00:10:06.422
now I can do interface fastethernet 1/0/1.

159
00:10:06.422 --> 00:10:13.832
And now, inside of this, we're gonna
start configuring it as a trunk port,

160
00:10:13.832 --> 00:10:20.720
so this is gonna be switchport
trunk encapsulation dot1q, okay?

161
00:10:20.720 --> 00:10:25.050
That is the method of encapsulation or
tagging that we're gonna put onto

162
00:10:25.050 --> 00:10:27.010
this trunk port here.
>> Okay.

163
00:10:27.010 --> 00:10:29.530
>> Then we're going to limit

164
00:10:29.530 --> 00:10:34.240
the VLANs that we're gonna
allow on this trunk port.

165
00:10:34.240 --> 00:10:37.490
The switchport trunk allowed VLANs,

166
00:10:37.490 --> 00:10:42.160
we're gonna get rid of any
previous notion of allowing

167
00:10:42.160 --> 00:10:46.948
everything to go across,
that should be VLAN, sorry.

168
00:10:46.948 --> 00:10:52.505
Switchport trunk allowed vlan,

169
00:10:52.505 --> 00:10:57.800
that should be none, okay?

170
00:10:57.800 --> 00:11:00.066
So, allowed VLAN, none.

171
00:11:00.066 --> 00:11:02.450
And now we'll configure
only the ones that we want.

172
00:11:02.450 --> 00:11:07.446
Switchport trunk

173
00:11:07.446 --> 00:11:12.442
allowed vlans add

174
00:11:12.442 --> 00:11:18.442
16,17,18.

175
00:11:20.640 --> 00:11:23.060
I have to spell switchport correctly.

176
00:11:23.060 --> 00:11:25.443
I tell you, my typing-
>> [LAUGH]

177
00:11:25.443 --> 00:11:26.620
>> It is terrible.

178
00:11:26.620 --> 00:11:34.022
16, 17, 18, all right.

179
00:11:34.022 --> 00:11:39.826
Now we have to actually issue
the command to turn this into the trunk,

180
00:11:39.826 --> 00:11:41.840
the mode, okay?

181
00:11:41.840 --> 00:11:44.711
Now if you try to do the mode
trunk first it's not gonna work,

182
00:11:44.711 --> 00:11:47.471
it's gonna tell you you're
missing the encapsulation,

183
00:11:47.471 --> 00:11:50.800
so that's why we did it in
this particular order, okay?

184
00:11:50.800 --> 00:11:58.010
So now that we've got that set up,
do show interface trunk.

185
00:11:58.010 --> 00:11:59.960
Let's verify a couple of things, okay?

186
00:12:01.310 --> 00:12:03.390
So, here it is.

187
00:12:03.390 --> 00:12:08.590
On our trunking port here,
that we have available

188
00:12:08.590 --> 00:12:13.750
to us, we are seeing,
that's what I'm looking for.

189
00:12:13.750 --> 00:12:18.620
So, All right,

190
00:12:18.620 --> 00:12:22.167
I was looking at these numbers,
I was like, why is this doing that?

191
00:12:22.167 --> 00:12:27.441
But they have switched this at
some point here to Fa0/24 and

192
00:12:27.441 --> 00:12:30.825
we're seeing that it's configured for

193
00:12:30.825 --> 00:12:35.623
this even though the interface is Fa1/0/1,
okay?

194
00:12:35.623 --> 00:12:38.998
So we're gonna just go with it cuz
it actually is working right now.

195
00:12:38.998 --> 00:12:42.856
So somehow there's reporting
from the other side,

196
00:12:42.856 --> 00:12:47.248
which is unusual, but
that's what we're seeing, okay?

197
00:12:47.248 --> 00:12:51.253
So Fa1/0/24,
notice that is only allowing those and

198
00:12:51.253 --> 00:12:55.897
also of course right here, okay,
it is actually allowing just 1 and

199
00:12:55.897 --> 00:12:59.921
16 through 18 and
the same thing here on spanning tree.

200
00:12:59.921 --> 00:13:03.622
So we're gonna leave that as is
cuz I'm not exactly sure but

201
00:13:03.622 --> 00:13:07.918
they've changed it around on
the other end, is what's happening,

202
00:13:07.918 --> 00:13:10.154
is the only thing I can see going on.

203
00:13:10.154 --> 00:13:14.321
So, even though I actually did configure
for one interface it turned it on for

204
00:13:14.321 --> 00:13:14.907
this one.

205
00:13:14.907 --> 00:13:18.628
So there's some magic happening in
the background that we're seeing, which is

206
00:13:18.628 --> 00:13:22.870
unusual, but that's what we're gonna go
with cuz that's how they have it set up.

207
00:13:22.870 --> 00:13:26.630
So now that we've got that set up and
we know that we've now limited this,

208
00:13:26.630 --> 00:13:28.050
the trunk is now set up,

209
00:13:28.050 --> 00:13:31.380
we do not have to worry about
configuring the rest of the switch.

210
00:13:31.380 --> 00:13:32.820
The switch already has VLANs,

211
00:13:32.820 --> 00:13:35.395
it already has interfaces in those VLANs.
>> Okay.

212
00:13:35.395 --> 00:13:36.537
>> So we've already done that in

213
00:13:36.537 --> 00:13:37.450
a previous episode, so

214
00:13:37.450 --> 00:13:39.810
we're not gonna worry about it too much.
>> Perfect.

215
00:13:39.810 --> 00:13:44.784
>> Now if we go to NYEDGE1, though, Okay,

216
00:13:44.784 --> 00:13:49.800
on NYEDGE1, this is the one that's
gonna be a little bit trickier, okay?

217
00:13:49.800 --> 00:13:54.850
So once you have the trunk configured
in the way that you want to, now, we

218
00:13:54.850 --> 00:14:00.550
have to go in and we have to actually be
able to create sub-interfaces on NYEDGE1.

219
00:14:01.610 --> 00:14:03.311
Let's get into our privilege mode and

220
00:14:03.311 --> 00:14:05.977
we're going out into a global
configuration mode as well.

221
00:14:08.216 --> 00:14:12.810
Okay, now inside of our global
configuration mode, okay?

222
00:14:12.810 --> 00:14:16.780
Remember that because of the way that this
is gonna work, where we literally sending

223
00:14:16.780 --> 00:14:22.470
traffic into that same port and then
coming out of that exact same port here.

224
00:14:22.470 --> 00:14:26.840
We've got to convince the router
that that's not going to be true.

225
00:14:26.840 --> 00:14:30.976
The way that we do this is by
creating what we call sub-interfaces.

226
00:14:30.976 --> 00:14:35.190
Sub-interfaces are not
real physical interfaces.

227
00:14:35.190 --> 00:14:38.110
They allow us to take
one physical port and

228
00:14:38.110 --> 00:14:42.330
treat it as if it's multiple ports, okay?

229
00:14:42.330 --> 00:14:43.740
That's what it does.

230
00:14:43.740 --> 00:14:47.640
But it creates it logically so
that the router believes they're actually

231
00:14:47.640 --> 00:14:50.600
different ports,
even though it's the same port.

232
00:14:50.600 --> 00:14:54.870
So if you don't do this right you'll
actually have what we call split horizon.

233
00:14:54.870 --> 00:14:58.450
It actually will stop that
traffic from coming back out,

234
00:14:58.450 --> 00:15:00.410
trying to get to the VLAN
that it needs to go.

235
00:15:00.410 --> 00:15:03.050
But now that a trunk can handle and

236
00:15:03.050 --> 00:15:07.720
send multiple VLANs along this trunk here,
now on the router side,

237
00:15:07.720 --> 00:15:13.040
we have to actually be able to allow for
the router to accept that as well, okay?

00:15:13.040 --> 00:15:15.900
So here is what we

Now we're gonna have to save that for
