00:29:08.478 --> 00:29:13.410
a part two on this particular lab
instead cuz I've run out of time

447
00:29:13.410 --> 00:29:17.693
by talking about router on a stick.
>> Configure inter-VLAN routing with

448
00:29:17.693 --> 00:29:18.801
routing on a stick.

449
00:29:18.801 --> 00:29:21.920
And there'll be more
configuring inter-VLAN routing.

450
00:29:21.920 --> 00:29:22.920
And that will be in part two.

451
00:29:22.920 --> 00:29:24.150
Make sure you see that.

452
00:29:24.150 --> 00:29:25.600
And before we move on, Ronnie,

453
00:29:25.600 --> 00:29:28.190
anything else you'd like to say?
>> Not really, so

454
00:29:28.190 --> 00:29:31.715
this part of the configuration, and
the only other thing I should say,

455
00:29:31.715 --> 00:29:37.120
right, in all reality, you probably will
not see this configuration in a real

456
00:29:37.120 --> 00:29:39.040
production setting, okay?

457
00:29:39.040 --> 00:29:41.190
This is great in a lab setting.

458
00:29:41.190 --> 00:29:46.140
And at one time you had to, but today
you don't tend to see anything like this

459
00:29:46.140 --> 00:29:51.783
necessary because yeah, it's just not as
necessary any more with layer 3 switches.

460
00:29:51.783 --> 00:29:57.215
What we're about to do, though, in layer 3
switches you'll see that much more often.

461
00:29:57.215 --> 00:30:00.360
That's the one you also wanna pay
attention to as well, but they will be

462
00:30:00.360 --> 00:30:04.944
tested both on the exam, so be aware.
>> Important stuff, thanks again, Ronnie.

463
00:30:04.944 --> 00:30:07.758
And see everything inside
of the Cisco CCENT series.

464
00:30:07.758 --> 00:30:09.340
See every episode.

465
00:30:09.340 --> 00:30:12.380
Ronnie's done a great job putting all
this information together for you.

466
00:30:12.380 --> 00:30:14.220
And you'll be in the course library, too.

467
00:30:14.220 --> 00:30:17.754
There's thousands of other videos
there designed to do one thing,

468
00:30:17.754 --> 00:30:18.877
help you go further.

469
00:30:18.877 --> 00:30:21.324
Now tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

470
00:30:21.324 --> 00:30:23.270
ITProTV is binge-worthy.

471
00:30:23.270 --> 00:30:25.640
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

472
00:30:25.640 --> 00:30:26.878
>> And we will see you again soon.

473
00:30:26.878 --> 00:30:34.231
[MUSIC]

474
00:30:34.231 --> 00:30:36.796
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue demonstrating the interVLAN routing using a layer 3 switch.  The team demonstrates the conifguration of Switched Virtual Interfaces (SVI) on a single switch.  They show the configuration on a layer 3 switch and how to verify it's configured properly.
episodes.title: Configure InterVLAN Routing Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.190 --> 00:00:01.542
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.542 --> 00:00:03.293
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.293 --> 00:00:06.758
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.758 --> 00:00:08.675
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.675 --> 00:00:13.437
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

6
00:00:13.437 --> 00:00:16.970
watching ITProTV, empowering
the world with engaging learning.

7
00:00:16.970 --> 00:00:21.100
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue with Cisco CCENT.

8
00:00:21.100 --> 00:00:25.384
This is gonna be configuring
interVLAN routing, part two.

9
00:00:25.384 --> 00:00:27.167
Make sure you see part one, important.

10
00:00:27.167 --> 00:00:31.330
And the person bringing us the information
we need, is the one and only Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:31.330 --> 00:00:34.000
Ronnie, good to see you again, sir.
>> Thank you for having me on the show,

12
00:00:34.000 --> 00:00:37.750
Zach, as we continue on with
our CCENT journey together.

13
00:00:37.750 --> 00:00:42.918
We are now again in, as Zach said,
a part two of interVLAN routing.

14
00:00:42.918 --> 00:00:45.460
We've already configured
router on a stick, so

15
00:00:45.460 --> 00:00:49.242
that you know that when you actually
do have multiple VLANs on a switch and

16
00:00:49.242 --> 00:00:53.272
you need to do routing in between them,
you're gonna need a layer 3 device,

17
00:00:53.272 --> 00:00:55.930
which is normally gonna be a router.

18
00:00:55.930 --> 00:00:59.920
Routers today, though, we don't tend to
do a lot of interVLAN routing on that

19
00:00:59.920 --> 00:01:02.283
configuration that we
call router on a stick.

20
00:01:02.283 --> 00:01:06.876
Most of it has kind of gone away
because we've introduced a newer

21
00:01:06.876 --> 00:01:10.220
device that we call a layer 3 switch.

22
00:01:10.220 --> 00:01:14.628
Now a layer 3 switch has both of
the abilities of a layer 2 switch,

23
00:01:14.628 --> 00:01:18.662
as well as some of the routing
components on a router, okay.

24
00:01:18.662 --> 00:01:20.450
So it doesn't do a full router's job.

25
00:01:20.450 --> 00:01:25.669
Some of it can do some of it, but
is not really designed to be full router.

26
00:01:25.669 --> 00:01:27.400
But at the same time, though,

27
00:01:27.400 --> 00:01:31.410
it can handle most of the basic
functions that routers can do.

28
00:01:31.410 --> 00:01:35.150
So it gives us this chance,
instead of needing a third device or

29
00:01:35.150 --> 00:01:40.130
another device like an external device
to handle that traffic in between VLANs.

30
00:01:40.130 --> 00:01:42.260
It says it can do it internally.

31
00:01:42.260 --> 00:01:46.210
But you and I have to actually be able
to understand how to set that up and

32
00:01:46.210 --> 00:01:46.790
make it work.

33
00:01:46.790 --> 00:01:51.250
Because if there's a configuration to
do this, that's actually more common,

34
00:01:51.250 --> 00:01:55.750
it's gonna be this one instead of
the idea of the router on a stick.

35
00:01:55.750 --> 00:01:58.700
So when we start to do
something like this,

36
00:01:58.700 --> 00:02:02.760
there's gonna be something that we
can't do yet which is unusual, okay?

37
00:02:02.760 --> 00:02:06.670
So let me see if I can bring up the,
where did the lab go?

38
00:02:06.670 --> 00:02:07.770
There I go, okay?

39
00:02:07.770 --> 00:02:10.770
I bring up the lab here for
a moment to help us out.

40
00:02:10.770 --> 00:02:13.738
And that is starting to look
a little bit diminutive here.

41
00:02:13.738 --> 00:02:14.593
Once again,

42
00:02:14.593 --> 00:02:17.584
let me put this back up here for a moment.
>> There you

43
00:02:17.584 --> 00:02:20.144
go.
>> All right, now I can actually kind of

44
00:02:20.144 --> 00:02:23.922
do a couple things here just so
that we can see this, okay?

45
00:02:23.922 --> 00:02:28.111
So on NYCORE1 here, let's just do a show,

46
00:02:28.111 --> 00:02:35.140
enter show ip interface brief,
cuz I just need to check something out.

47
00:02:35.140 --> 00:02:40.159
Do show ip interface brief.

48
00:02:43.043 --> 00:02:47.302
So notice all of the ports that are on
here that we have available to us.

49
00:02:47.302 --> 00:02:51.333
And even though you see where it says
IP Address assigned, let's take for

50
00:02:51.333 --> 00:02:52.057
an example.

51
00:02:52.057 --> 00:02:54.762
I'm just trying to pull one that I know
I'm not gonna mess something up on here.

52
00:02:54.762 --> 00:02:59.650
So let's just do like, FA1/0/9 here, okay?

53
00:02:59.650 --> 00:03:06.100
So if I wanted to configure that interface
with an IP address, let's do this.

54
00:03:06.100 --> 00:03:12.204
We'll kinda go interface,
fa for FastEthernet, 1/0/9.

55
00:03:15.181 --> 00:03:21.853
Usually we would just type in ip address,
and then we'll do 192.168.9.1,

56
00:03:21.853 --> 00:03:27.105
just as an example,
24 bit subnet mask, and I press Enter.

57
00:03:27.105 --> 00:03:31.046
And now notice it says hey,
I can't do this.

58
00:03:31.046 --> 00:03:35.265
I'm not allowing you to put
an IP address on an interface.

59
00:03:35.265 --> 00:03:37.895
So that now kind of, you're like, well, so

60
00:03:37.895 --> 00:03:43.650
how do we do interVLAN routing if each
VLAN is its own broadcast domain?

61
00:03:43.650 --> 00:03:48.810
I need to set up a default gateway, but
I can't do it on one of those interfaces.

62
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:51.380
So how does this end up working for us?
>> Yeah.

63
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:53.924
>> Well, we have to actually create what

64
00:03:53.924 --> 00:03:57.500
we call an SVI,
a Switched Virtual Interface.

65
00:03:57.500 --> 00:04:01.920
Now this is the same as us doing, like
when we took a look at router on a stick,

66
00:04:01.920 --> 00:04:07.600
doing the subinterfaces up on the router
on that one physical interface.

67
00:04:07.600 --> 00:04:10.650
But inside of the switch we're
actually going to be subdividing, or

68
00:04:10.650 --> 00:04:16.320
creating that switch virtual interface
by using VLANs is what we're gonna do,

69
00:04:16.320 --> 00:04:18.730
interface VLANs is what
we're gonna do here.

70
00:04:18.730 --> 00:04:23.930
And on those, we can go ahead and
also assign IP addresses to them.

71
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:27.020
But there has to be a key command for
us to do so.

72
00:04:27.020 --> 00:04:28.720
Now before we do this, I went ahead and

73
00:04:28.720 --> 00:04:32.782
typed in kind of the basic configuration
of what it is that we're going to because

74
00:04:32.782 --> 00:04:38.030
it's not as much as when we
did the router on stick, okay?

75
00:04:38.030 --> 00:04:43.080
So on that layer 3 switch, and
ours is 3750 is what we have available.

76
00:04:43.080 --> 00:04:45.734
Let's say we want to set up
these three different VLANs,

77
00:04:45.734 --> 00:04:47.959
we already know how to
configure VLANs on them.

78
00:04:47.959 --> 00:04:50.286
We know how to assign
interfaces to those VLANs,

79
00:04:50.286 --> 00:04:54.350
so I'm not gonna worry about that
cuz you already know how to do that.

80
00:04:54.350 --> 00:04:58.280
Then there has to also of
course be something that you

81
00:04:58.280 --> 00:05:01.030
gotta make sure you that you do, okay?

82
00:05:01.030 --> 00:05:06.473
This is the key, One right here, okay?

83
00:05:06.473 --> 00:05:09.410
You notice it says IP routing, okay?

84
00:05:09.410 --> 00:05:10.500
Without that,

85
00:05:10.500 --> 00:05:16.050
you can't assign IP addresses on the
interfaces in the way that you want to.

86
00:05:16.050 --> 00:05:21.410
You have to be able to turn on IP
routing for that switch to do so, okay?

87
00:05:21.410 --> 00:05:23.260
Now, will it allow you to do
it on virtual interfaces?

88
00:05:23.260 --> 00:05:28.035
Yes, but in terms of that working as a
router, which is what we need it to do for

89
00:05:28.035 --> 00:05:31.970
interVLAN routing,
you have to type in ip routing.

90
00:05:31.970 --> 00:05:34.230
Now it doesn't matter if it's first or
if it's last.

91
00:05:34.230 --> 00:05:38.260
In our lab configuration, the way that I
have it set up, they set it up as last.

92
00:05:38.260 --> 00:05:42.871
I always type it in first because I
know that if I don't, I'll forget it.

93
00:05:42.871 --> 00:05:44.066
So that's what I always do.

94
00:05:44.066 --> 00:05:47.990
But notice that once we do that,
we just create our virtual interfaces.

95
00:05:47.990 --> 00:05:51.660
Interface VLAN 10,
we type in an IP address and

96
00:05:51.660 --> 00:05:53.530
we make sure that they're turned on.

97
00:05:53.530 --> 00:05:57.650
Now if you remember, I said that by
default, out of the box when Cisco sends

98
00:05:57.650 --> 00:06:02.770
us the switch, when we buy a switch,
right, every interface is on by default.

99
00:06:02.770 --> 00:06:06.030
That's every physical
interface is on by default.

100
00:06:06.030 --> 00:06:09.790
Virtual interfaces, though,
are off by default.

101
00:06:09.790 --> 00:06:12.560
So you make sure that you
enter in a no shutdown command

102
00:06:12.560 --> 00:06:14.500
after creating each one of these.

103
00:06:14.500 --> 00:06:18.030
The other thing is at the very end here,
that I also went ahead and

104
00:06:18.030 --> 00:06:20.710
put in is this, too.

105
00:06:20.710 --> 00:06:22.870
I was hoping it was actually
gonna be the marker here,

106
00:06:22.870 --> 00:06:25.300
but apparently I chose the wrong one,
okay?

107
00:06:26.570 --> 00:06:27.941
It's this one right here.

108
00:06:27.941 --> 00:06:32.202
Okay, so that one, too,
is actually gonna be important,

109
00:06:32.202 --> 00:06:36.090
which is a default gateway or
a default route.

110
00:06:36.090 --> 00:06:40.440
This is saying, look, as long as we're
routing in between VLANs, that's fine, but

111
00:06:40.440 --> 00:06:43.630
what if I get traffic and
it's destined for some place else?

112
00:06:43.630 --> 00:06:48.319
This is instead telling it
to route to 0.0.0.0.0.0,

113
00:06:48.319 --> 00:06:51.899
that's actually gonna be
a default route for us,

114
00:06:51.899 --> 00:06:55.498
that says send it on to 192.168.1.1.

115
00:06:55.498 --> 00:07:00.133
Okay, so we always wanna put that in there
if we're expecting to route out to another

116
00:07:00.133 --> 00:07:02.877
network besides the VLANs
that are on the switch,

117
00:07:02.877 --> 00:07:03.760
okay?
>> Okay.

118
00:07:03.760 --> 00:07:04.590
>> So that's also

119
00:07:04.590 --> 00:07:05.813
a part of the configuration.

120
00:07:05.813 --> 00:07:10.670
So we're gonna see that when we get
into what are configuration is.

121
00:07:10.670 --> 00:07:14.032
So now that we are ready,
we gonna take NYCORE1, and

122
00:07:14.032 --> 00:07:18.690
I've already turned off the router
on the stick configuration here.

123
00:07:18.690 --> 00:07:22.270
Okay, so to verify that, let me bring up.

124
00:07:22.270 --> 00:07:25.120
Now let's see,
where is that other device here?

125
00:07:25.120 --> 00:07:26.490
Where is that practice device?

126
00:07:26.490 --> 00:07:28.181
Let me see where it is.

127
00:07:28.181 --> 00:07:29.390
There it is, okay.

128
00:07:29.390 --> 00:07:32.150
So here is that machine that
we're actually on here.

129
00:07:33.190 --> 00:07:38.210
So let's do acls here, and
I'm gonna ping 192.168.17.10,

130
00:07:38.210 --> 00:07:42.468
which should be the end
line access switch.

131
00:07:42.468 --> 00:07:45.510
It's the one that is directly
connected to you right now.

132
00:07:45.510 --> 00:07:48.640
But it is on VLAN 17, okay.

133
00:07:48.640 --> 00:07:53.330
So I've turned off that and I simply
went up, of course, to the router.

134
00:07:53.330 --> 00:07:56.290
And actually, did I go the router or
did I go to the switch here?

135
00:07:56.290 --> 00:07:57.530
I went up to the router.

136
00:07:57.530 --> 00:07:58.880
I can't remember which one I did.

137
00:07:58.880 --> 00:08:02.035
I just didn't shut down on that interface.
>> Okay.

138
00:08:02.035 --> 00:08:03.763
>> So it's not accepting any traffic.

139
00:08:03.763 --> 00:08:06.921
So that way you know it's not on
the router on the stick doing any of

140
00:08:06.921 --> 00:08:09.573
the interVLAN routing that
we're about to do, okay?

141
00:08:09.573 --> 00:08:13.193
So this device is now showing you
that it's not happening that way.

142
00:08:13.193 --> 00:08:18.120
So now on NYCORE1, let's go ahead and
start creating then,

143
00:08:18.120 --> 00:08:22.311
our virtual interfaces that we need to,
all right?

144
00:08:22.311 --> 00:08:31.060
So the first one is gonna
be interface vlan 16, okay?

145
00:08:31.060 --> 00:08:34.050
All right,
you can pick whatever number you want to.

146
00:08:34.050 --> 00:08:38.878
For me, logically, it just makes sense,
so it's the same thing,

147
00:08:38.878 --> 00:08:42.366
okay, ip address 192.168.16.1.

148
00:08:44.131 --> 00:08:49.444
And these will essentially become,
The default

149
00:08:49.444 --> 00:08:53.520
gateway for that particular VLAN.

150
00:08:55.420 --> 00:09:00.446
And interface vlan 17, and
notice I really don't have to do a lot,

151
00:09:00.446 --> 00:09:04.695
I'm just configuring the virtual
interface itself, and

152
00:09:04.695 --> 00:09:09.305
an IP address on that virtual interface,
and do a no shutdown.

153
00:09:14.177 --> 00:09:17.410
And vlan oops, I don't need vlan 10.

154
00:09:17.410 --> 00:09:21.565
I need interface, do a no,

155
00:09:21.565 --> 00:09:25.542
interface vlan 10, and

156
00:09:25.542 --> 00:09:30.242
then interface vlan 18, and

157
00:09:30.242 --> 00:09:36.587
ip address 192.168.18.1,

158
00:09:40.565 --> 00:09:41.658
And a no shutdown.

159
00:09:45.826 --> 00:09:49.540
All right, so believe it or not,
that's kind of the major configuration.

160
00:09:49.540 --> 00:09:51.030
Now that didn't take too long, right?

161
00:09:51.030 --> 00:09:53.820
We didn't have to do any
fancy word encapsulation.

162
00:09:53.820 --> 00:09:55.066
We don't have to do all that stuff.

163
00:09:55.066 --> 00:09:59.002
The switch is already able to see that
we're using that switched virtual

164
00:09:59.002 --> 00:10:01.790
interface, which is the interface vlans.

165
00:10:01.790 --> 00:10:04.510
They're not real,
they're virtual interfaces.

166
00:10:04.510 --> 00:10:07.600
I can put an IP address on them,
I've now turned them on.

167
00:10:07.600 --> 00:10:12.585
Now when I do something like that,
right, I told you that there's one

168
00:10:12.585 --> 00:10:17.064
command that we also have to do
to make sure that this also done,

169
00:10:17.064 --> 00:10:20.044
which is going to be from here ip routing.

170
00:10:20.044 --> 00:10:24.972
Okay, ip routing will again turn on
the routing component inside of this layer

171
00:10:24.972 --> 00:10:26.610
3 switch for us.

172
00:10:26.610 --> 00:10:33.392
Now I can type in do show,
ip interface brief,

173
00:10:33.392 --> 00:10:39.168
and this is us just verifying that
we did all the proper configuration.

174
00:10:39.168 --> 00:10:42.910
And so here, look at that.

175
00:10:42.910 --> 00:10:45.660
I messed up at some point here, okay?

176
00:10:45.660 --> 00:10:50.410
So that's where you can see it's like,
my gosh, he skipped vlan 17.

177
00:10:50.410 --> 00:10:51.600
You have the wrong numbers here.

178
00:10:51.600 --> 00:10:53.150
So that means that I need to go back and

179
00:10:53.150 --> 00:10:56.730
I need to add that change in
there to essentially help us out.

180
00:10:56.730 --> 00:11:01.027
Because it if not,
it's not gonna work at all.

181
00:11:01.027 --> 00:11:08.252
So now,
Iet me get back into interface vlan 16,

182
00:11:08.252 --> 00:11:13.069
and simply type in a new address,

183
00:11:13.069 --> 00:11:18.931
16.1, so that should override it.

184
00:11:18.931 --> 00:11:23.373
And then interface vlan 17, and

185
00:11:23.373 --> 00:11:29.352
then IP address 192.168.17.1.

186
00:11:31.715 --> 00:11:35.626
Two and no shutdown,

187
00:11:35.626 --> 00:11:40.845
do show ip interface brief.

188
00:11:44.356 --> 00:11:48.044
And in a moment here, let's verify
that I have all the proper VLANs, and

189
00:11:48.044 --> 00:11:49.990
notice that they're all up.

190
00:11:49.990 --> 00:11:51.290
Cuz I've actually turned them up,

191
00:11:51.290 --> 00:11:54.360
to make sure that they were actually
working the way that we want to.

192
00:11:54.360 --> 00:11:57.901
Wonderful, okay, so
as long as I've done that, and

193
00:11:57.901 --> 00:12:02.790
I also need to verify that I have
IP routing turned on, too, okay?

194
00:12:02.790 --> 00:12:04.810
So this one, though,
doesn't show up as easily.

195
00:12:04.810 --> 00:12:09.102
So I'm gonna do a show,

196
00:12:09.102 --> 00:12:14.040
do show running-config,

here do show running-config.

00:12:22.895 --> 00:12:25.100

00:12:25.100 --> 00:12:27.010
I knew it was right here near the top.

If it's not, it's not going to work.

00:12:31.193 --> 00:12:36.168
All right, so now that we've got
everything turned on the way we want to,

203
00:12:36.168 --> 00:12:37.942
let's go to NYACCESS1.

204
00:12:37.942 --> 00:12:42.320
And let's begin our pinging

205
00:12:42.320 --> 00:12:48.605
So on NYACCESS1,
I am going to ping 192.168.16.10.

206
00:12:48.605 --> 00:12:50.771
That should be that PC that we have.

207
00:12:50.771 --> 00:12:53.424
We're actually pinging from this switch,
and

208
00:12:53.424 --> 00:12:56.550
we'll see here in a moment
if it accepts it.

209
00:12:56.550 --> 00:12:57.718
I have to get out of this, of course.

210
00:13:00.662 --> 00:13:04.957
Now I can ping 192.168.16.10.

211
00:13:04.957 --> 00:13:09.948
So notice that actually successfully
verified what we wanted it to be able

212
00:13:09.948 --> 00:13:11.326
to do.
>> Wonderful.

213
00:13:11.326 --> 00:13:11.965
>> Okay,

214
00:13:11.965 --> 00:13:17.607
then let's take a look at our
routing table on NYCORE1 again,

215
00:13:17.607 --> 00:13:21.768
to verify that we can get
access to all of them.

216
00:13:21.768 --> 00:13:22.511
Let me get out of that there.

217
00:13:25.233 --> 00:13:26.745
Do show ip route.

218
00:13:31.861 --> 00:13:36.161
So I wanna verify that I have
a network for 16, which I do, and

219
00:13:36.161 --> 00:13:39.690
17, which is perfectly fine, and 18.

220
00:13:39.690 --> 00:13:44.241
So the great thing is we can verify that
we can see, well, all of those routes

221
00:13:44.241 --> 00:13:46.564
are where they need to be.
>> Yep.

222
00:13:46.564 --> 00:13:47.712
>> Now, let's go ahead and

223
00:13:47.712 --> 00:13:50.009
do some other things here
to check on our status and

224
00:13:50.009 --> 00:13:52.930
be able to troubleshoot
a couple of things, right?

225
00:13:52.930 --> 00:13:55.910
It is not a routing table,
we know it's not gonna be there.

226
00:13:55.910 --> 00:14:00.360
If you saw what I saw when I
did the show IP interface brief

227
00:14:00.360 --> 00:14:03.920
where the vlan didn't exist
is not gonna work for us.

228
00:14:03.920 --> 00:14:05.730
Make sure that those are configured.

229
00:14:05.730 --> 00:14:10.250
If you didn't do a no shutdown

00:14:10.250 --> 00:14:12.980
it's not going to work for
you either, okay?

231
00:14:12.980 --> 00:14:17.560
If you're missing the IP routing command,
it's not gonna work for you.

232
00:14:17.560 --> 00:14:21.440
So you can see that there's a lot
of little tiny things that can just

234
00:14:24.570 --> 00:14:28.860
And it's just fat fingering it, like I did

00:14:28.860 --> 00:14:31.660
if it's just because you
forgot to implement something,

it's pretty hefty here, okay.

237
00:14:34.300 --> 00:14:41.065
So let's go to a show interface status,
at this point.

238
00:14:44.967 --> 00:14:49.443
The other thing that the interface
status helps us to show,

239
00:14:49.443 --> 00:14:52.586
right, is such as fast Ethernet 0/1.

240
00:14:52.586 --> 00:14:56.491
Notice it also has

00:14:56.491 --> 00:14:59.971
So if you are expecting, hopefully,

00:14:59.971 --> 00:15:05.316
Fa0/1 to be in Vlan 16,
well, you're good, okay?

243
00:15:05.316 --> 00:15:07.697
But it is supposed to be Vlan 17.

244
00:15:07.697 --> 00:15:10.531
Well, then that means that you
need to actually need to check on

245
00:15:10.531 --> 00:15:11.976
the configuration of whether or

246
00:15:11.976 --> 00:15:15.080
not this interface was assigned

247
00:15:15.080 --> 00:15:17.273
So those are actually gonna be key for

248
00:15:17.273 --> 00:15:18.456
So NYACCESS1,

249
00:15:18.456 --> 00:15:23.700
this the one I believe is actually

See if it allows us to do this.

00:15:58.773 --> 00:16:03.119

259
00:16:03.119 --> 00:16:04.716
So that's actually good.

And then one more show interfaces trunk.

00:16:14.337 --> 00:16:18.719
Verifying that only those interfaces

263
00:16:21.170 --> 00:16:23.481
Though all that's actually possible

264
00:16:23.481 --> 00:16:26.176
Now take a look at this from each device,

266

If there's something out of order and

For me, it's usually a typo error, okay?

00:16:37.190 --> 00:16:42.852
Some way, somehow I just misconfigured

269
00:16:42.852 --> 00:16:45.320
even though I think they're
identically the same.

270
00:16:45.320 --> 00:16:50.580
So check out your typo errors, not

00:16:50.580 --> 00:16:54.210

272
00:16:54.210 --> 00:16:55.640
Those are fairly simple things,

273

but it is something that can stop
the entire process from working.

274
00:16:59.918 --> 00:17:03.150
So now, Zach,
through both of the part one and

00:17:03.150 --> 00:17:06.020

279

So Zach, that's a good place for

00:17:19.750 --> 00:17:24.380

>> Great job,

282

Ronnie, and configure interVLAN routing
parts one and two, see them both.

283

And before we move on, I'm gonna ask
Ronnie if he has any last words.

00:17:33.010 --> 00:17:34.170
>> Well, just again,

00:17:34.170 --> 00:17:36.600
a great reminder at this point, right?

You gotta practice, that's pretty much it.

It should be a part of your common,
everyday activity to do them, and

to understand what it

And to work with them to the point where

And you don't have to worry about

00:17:59.111 --> 00:18:00.810
you simply just know.

00:18:00.810 --> 00:18:03.350
Now, speed is important.

295
00:18:03.350 --> 00:18:05.410
I don't know how else to tell you that.

296
00:18:05.410 --> 00:18:08.200
You've got to get faster at doing this.

297
00:18:08.200 --> 00:18:12.240
Start typing it slow, but try and

00:18:12.240 --> 00:18:15.860
even if you get errors in
doing it in terms of typos.

299
00:18:15.860 --> 00:18:17.790
It just makes you type it in again.

300
00:18:17.790 --> 00:18:22.580
So try it, just continue to move faster,
make sure your mind understands what it is

301

Know those show commands.

303

Do not always depend on show

304

Make sure you take a look at all of those

Because those are also gonna be for

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure static routing with IPv4.  The guys show how to create a static route and show how the destination side has to be configured with a static route back or using a default route. They also show the routing table to verify that static routes are in the routing lookup table.  Lastly, the team configures a floating static route to recover from a routing failure.
episodes.title: Configure Static Routing IPv4

192.168.23 over here,

48
00:02:42.510 --> 00:02:43.923
As well as one more, okay?

49
00:02:43.923 --> 00:02:46.425
Just off to the right hand side of NYEDGE,

So, for example, I wanna be able to

Whenever you see this kind of

75
00:04:11.900 --> 00:04:17.170
In that serial connection,
usually it is a point to point connection,

76
00:04:17.170 --> 00:04:19.190

77
00:04:19.190 --> 00:04:24.550

78
00:04:24.550 --> 00:04:27.554
And that's why you see the /30, okay?

79
00:04:27.554 --> 00:04:32.461
The /30 means the first 32 bits

81
00:04:37.527 --> 00:04:41.850
I can use for the actual host

82
00:04:41.850 --> 00:04:45.420
So we only have really two addresses that
we can use, and that's gonna be the very

83
00:04:45.420 --> 00:04:49.990

then the next one that's available.

84
00:04:49.990 --> 00:04:52.676
We can't use the other two
there cuz if you take two bits,

85
00:04:52.676 --> 00:04:55.195
well that gives you four
possible combinations here.

86
00:04:55.195 --> 00:04:58.230
So you can't use the network ID,
you can't use the broadcast ID, so

87
00:04:58.230 --> 00:05:00.980
that leaves us those two

88
00:05:00.980 --> 00:05:05.060
So every single one I picked .1 and
.2 just to keep it simple for

94
00:05:22.110 --> 00:05:27.684

95
00:05:27.684 --> 00:05:31.777

96
00:05:31.777 --> 00:05:34.770

00:05:34.770 --> 00:05:40.060

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure static routing with IPv6.  The guys show how to create a static route and show how the destination side has to be configured with a static route back or using a default route. They also show the routing table to verify that static routes are in the routing lookup table.

:1, I'm gonna always forget that,

okay,

that allows us to do that very same thing.

242

Ping.

244

So let's see if we're missing anything is

245

A, and then 1.

Looks like we're actually
having some issues, okay?

So what in the world would

248

249
00:16:40.085 --> 00:16:44.750

A, A, there we go.

252

Wait, I did the wrong one there.

Let me go back to NYEDGE, okay?

254

So it is not successful at this point.

255

So if it's not successful,

256

what can I do to help me to figure out

257
00:17:03.520 --> 00:17:07.480
Well, it's at this point we can kind

258
00:17:07.480 --> 00:17:12.380
If I start off, lets do it this way,
okay, actually we can do it from here.

259
00:17:12.380 --> 00:17:14.610
What if I issued a trace route?

260

2001:0a:a::1 and

let's see what happens.

Notice that it actually does look like
that it got to a certain point and

263
00:17:34.674 --> 00:17:36.560
then it just kind of quit for us.

264
00:17:36.560 --> 00:17:41.470
But where it looks like it went to,
though, is it actually hit this router.

265
00:17:41.470 --> 00:17:43.270
So at this particular router,

266
00:17:43.270 --> 00:17:47.450
going that direction, that is where we
would have to begin to troubleshoot and

267

figure out why it's actually
kind of breaking where it did.

268
00:17:52.050 --> 00:17:53.140
So it did hit this router so

269
00:17:53.140 --> 00:17:57.930
whatever the next hop was, which is
gonna be up here at NYEDGE1, okay?

270
00:17:58.960 --> 00:18:02.144
So now we'll actually get to see and

271

So here, I may have to do like

272

Now if it doesn't let you out you

the number 6 a lot of times.

And that normally helps break you

275

Sometimes you just have to wait for

So we're just gonna let it
do its thing right now and

277
00:18:25.290 --> 00:18:27.900
we'll hopefully end up

278
00:18:27.900 --> 00:18:33.201
But let's check out NYEDGE1 here,

279
00:18:33.201 --> 00:18:36.282
do show ipv6 route.

280
00:18:37.580 --> 00:18:42.290
Okay, so let's take a look and
see what we're missing, okay?

281
00:18:42.290 --> 00:18:47.830
I told it to go out of a:3, but
look at what I'm missing here.

282
00:18:50.060 --> 00:18:54.210
I am actually not seeing what,
an a:3, okay,

283
00:18:54.210 --> 00:18:57.600
at all, so
this one is actually showing me that hey,

284
00:18:57.600 --> 00:19:02.210
I don't have a path to go back and

285
00:19:02.210 --> 00:19:11.200
So on NYEDGE1 then, I should now be
able to configure IPv6 route, okay?

286
00:19:11.200 --> 00:19:12.590
Now were gonna have two choices, right,

287

either a default gateway, okay,
or a gateway of last resort.

288
00:19:16.280 --> 00:19:20.090
Or the idea of actually setting it up
the way that we are going to do it,

289
00:19:20.090 --> 00:19:21.070
which is right here.

290
00:19:21.070 --> 00:19:23.092
Let's give it just a direct
path back instead.

291
00:19:28.594 --> 00:19:35.180
That's gonna be a3Network/64.

292
00:19:35.180 --> 00:19:39.463
And this time I need to
send from there to NYWAN1.

293
00:19:39.463 --> 00:19:43.027
Which is gonna be

294
00:19:43.027 --> 00:19:47.612
2000a:1:: I

295
00:19:47.612 --> 00:19:51.947
gotta remember 2.

296
00:19:51.947 --> 00:19:54.306
I never remember those addresses here.

297

So apparently I set up
the wrong IP address.

298

How's that, let's do a1.

There we go.

300

So I just had those numbers
backward apparently.

301

That's right.
[LAUGH]

302

I was like, why is that working?

303
00:20:12.250 --> 00:20:14.280
2 and 2, that doesn't work here.

304
00:20:14.280 --> 00:20:16.340
So now we've got another address.

305
00:20:16.340 --> 00:20:20.670
Let's see if the other side has
now finished its thing, okay?

306
00:20:20.670 --> 00:20:22.037
So, look at that.

307
00:20:22.037 --> 00:20:26.005
It actually did end up finding it after,
probably when we set up that route

308
00:20:26.005 --> 00:20:29.400
everything actually finally went through.
>> Wow.

309
00:20:29.400 --> 00:20:30.710
>> Let's see here and

310
00:20:30.710 --> 00:20:34.840
see what we can do now, all right?

311
00:20:34.840 --> 00:20:38.010
Now, there we go okay?

312
00:20:38.010 --> 00:20:40.760
So it was some time in that,
right, when it was determining it,

313
00:20:40.760 --> 00:20:43.550
when we set up the proper
routing in between but

314
00:20:43.550 --> 00:20:47.180
once again it shows you the limitations
of static routing, okay?

315
00:20:47.180 --> 00:20:52.070
So even though you might think of IPv6
as scary cuz it changes everything,

316
00:20:52.070 --> 00:20:52.780
it really doesn't.

317
00:20:52.780 --> 00:20:56.999
It's the same logic that
we were using with IPv4.

318
00:20:56.999 --> 00:21:01.100
The numbering looks a little bit
different, it is a little bit stranger to

319
00:21:01.100 --> 00:21:04.720
have to deal with but
it's still the same functionality.

320
00:21:04.720 --> 00:21:07.104
It still helps us to do what
we need to as well, and

321
00:21:07.104 --> 00:21:11.198
just making sure those configurations that
we correct are gonna be a big part of it.

322
00:21:11.198 --> 00:21:14.774
But realize that that's pretty
much all what we end up dealing

323
00:21:14.774 --> 00:21:17.500
with in static routing
the majority of times.

324
00:21:17.500 --> 00:21:21.924
So get used to also typing in IPv6, right?
>> Right.

325
00:21:21.924 --> 00:21:23.490
>> And doing that as well.

326
00:21:23.490 --> 00:21:30.090
So show ipv6 interface
brief is another one, okay?

327
00:21:30.090 --> 00:21:34.820
If you need to see the configuration
of the interfaces on that.

328
00:21:34.820 --> 00:21:40.537
Remember that it also creates its own link
local address on that interface as well.

329
00:21:40.537 --> 00:21:47.729
And then if you need to verify your IPv6
routes don't forget show ipv6 route and

330
00:21:47.729 --> 00:21:52.190
that will also bring up
the routing table for you.

331
00:21:52.190 --> 00:21:55.975
It's not as lengthy as what
we expect to see IPv4 but

332
00:21:55.975 --> 00:21:58.890
it is actually doing the same job.

333
00:21:58.890 --> 00:22:02.071
So overall, Zach,
that's actually a good place,

334
00:22:02.071 --> 00:22:07.060
we've kinda of done just about everything
that we need to understand at this point

335
00:22:07.060 --> 00:22:11.168
in using static routing in IPv6.
>> [INAUDIBLE] static routing IPv6,

336
00:22:11.168 --> 00:22:12.608
great episode, right?

337
00:22:12.608 --> 00:22:13.560
Did a wonderful job.

338
00:22:13.560 --> 00:22:14.704
And before we move along,

339
00:22:14.704 --> 00:22:17.680
anything else you'd like to say?
>> Well once again practice

340
00:22:17.680 --> 00:22:18.890
is the key, right?

341
00:22:18.890 --> 00:22:22.880
So at this point you need to
begin practicing if you haven't.

342
00:22:22.880 --> 00:22:23.554
>> Practice, practice.

343
00:22:23.554 --> 00:22:26.110
>> And it needs to be daily as well.

344
00:22:26.110 --> 00:22:29.850
Don't forget,
speed is important at this point, right?

345
00:22:29.850 --> 00:22:33.370
You don't need to be going backwards and
slowing down.

346
00:22:33.370 --> 00:22:36.010
I know that that sounds strange, but

347
00:22:36.010 --> 00:22:40.400
as you make mistakes,
you need to configure the work quicker.

348
00:22:40.400 --> 00:22:43.524
And even if you have to do abbreviations,
by now, though,

349
00:22:43.524 --> 00:22:47.397
hopefully you've already memorized
the most basic commands fully, and

350
00:22:47.397 --> 00:22:51.098
now you can start using those
abbreviations to help you to get faster.

351
00:22:51.098 --> 00:22:55.920
But don't just use abbreviations and not
know what the full command actually means.

352
00:22:55.920 --> 00:23:01.374
So continue to work as quickly as you can
and understand it's functionality as well,

353
00:23:01.374 --> 00:23:05.780
but speed is a key as well as of
course accuracy is tantamount.

354
00:23:05.780 --> 00:23:09.770
But if you don't have both of them,
you will not get through the exam.

355
00:23:09.770 --> 00:23:13.270
So make sure both, that you're practicing,
build that muscle memory, and

356
00:23:13.270 --> 00:23:16.110
it's gonna help you get through the exam.
>> Great advice, Ronnie.

357
00:23:16.110 --> 00:23:18.363
Cisco CCENT's a wonderful series.

358
00:23:18.363 --> 00:23:21.060
Make sure you watch every episode,
you'll be glad you did.

359
00:23:21.060 --> 00:23:22.780
And you'll be in the course library, too.

360

There's thousands of other videos

361
00:23:26.090 --> 00:23:27.400
help you go further.

362

And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

363

ITProTV is binge-worthy.

364

Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure RIP for IPv4.
episodes.title: Configure RIPv2 for IPv4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.134 --> 00:00:02.458
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.458 --> 00:00:08.352
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.352 --> 00:00:11.878
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:11.878 --> 00:00:13.232
>> Hello and thank you for

5
00:00:13.232 --> 00:00:16.730
watching ITPro.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.730 --> 00:00:20.510
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with Cisco CCENT.

7
00:00:20.510 --> 00:00:26.480
This particular episode is we're gonna
configure RIP version two for IPv4.

8
00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:28.256
Wow, that sounds cool.

9
00:00:28.256 --> 00:00:31.520
And the person doing that for
us is the one and only Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:31.520 --> 00:00:33.910
Ronnie, great to have you here, sir.
>> Thank you for

11
00:00:33.910 --> 00:00:38.860
having me back on the show as we continue
on here in our journey through CCENT.

12
00:00:38.860 --> 00:00:42.930
Now we are jumping in to
dynamic routing protocols.

13
00:00:42.930 --> 00:00:46.440
If you've been watching it in the order
in which we've been presenting it,

14
00:00:46.440 --> 00:00:48.670
in terms of what you see on the website.

15
00:00:48.670 --> 00:00:51.920
We've gone through static routing,
which is what we need do.

16
00:00:51.920 --> 00:00:53.190
We showed you how to configure it, and

17
00:00:53.190 --> 00:00:54.970
we've done a little bit
more configuration.

18
00:00:54.970 --> 00:00:58.251
We even showed you a basic
idea of configuring RIP,

19
00:00:58.251 --> 00:01:00.553
as well dynamic routing protocol.

20
00:01:00.553 --> 00:01:04.645
But now we're gonna jump in and we're
gonna talk about some of the details that

21
00:01:04.645 --> 00:01:08.480
you need to know about RIP as you get
ready for the CCENT exam as well.

22
00:01:08.480 --> 00:01:13.404
So RIP was actually one of the dynamic
routing protocols that they got rid of in

23
00:01:13.404 --> 00:01:15.692
a previous iteration of this exam.

24
00:01:15.692 --> 00:01:19.913
But they've brought it back because it's
good protocol to begin to learn about

25
00:01:19.913 --> 00:01:21.840
dynamic routing protocols.

26
00:01:21.840 --> 00:01:25.840
And it's a good one to see how the routers
actually do function and how they work.

27
00:01:25.840 --> 00:01:29.779
Without having really having to bring
up a lot of extra stuff right here

28
00:01:29.779 --> 00:01:33.200
at the entry level of
working with Cisco equipment.

29
00:01:33.200 --> 00:01:35.890
So that is what we're going to
be taking a look at, of course,

30
00:01:35.890 --> 00:01:39.950
is really the idea of what it
takes to run RIP version 2.

31
00:01:39.950 --> 00:01:43.030
And some of the different things that
are a little bit quirky about it

32
00:01:43.030 --> 00:01:45.050
that you need to know about as well.

33
00:01:45.050 --> 00:01:47.195
Now before we get started in there,

34
00:01:47.195 --> 00:01:51.774
we wanna make sure that we round out
some fundamental knowledge as well about

35
00:01:51.774 --> 00:01:54.867
the idea of dynamic routing protocols too,
okay?

36
00:01:54.867 --> 00:01:58.498
So let's go ahead and take a look
at my diagram here on the computer,

37
00:01:58.498 --> 00:02:01.580
and this will help us out
at the beginning, okay?

38
00:02:01.580 --> 00:02:05.800
So I've got a lab topology here, I've
got five routers that are set up just so

39
00:02:05.800 --> 00:02:07.410
that we can see this.

40
00:02:07.410 --> 00:02:10.043
But when it comes down to
dynamic of writing protocols,

41
00:02:10.043 --> 00:02:13.470
remember that in static you and
I have to configure all of it.

42
00:02:13.470 --> 00:02:15.969
But in the idea of dynamic
routing protocols,

43
00:02:15.969 --> 00:02:20.270
the term dynamic means it adjusts for
us and it actually does it automatically.

44
00:02:20.270 --> 00:02:21.730
>> More flexible.

45
00:02:21.730 --> 00:02:23.257
>> Yeah more flexible, and

46
00:02:23.257 --> 00:02:26.220
actually the idea of having it learn for
us.

47
00:02:26.220 --> 00:02:29.963
So I don't have to tell it about every
route that I might want to be able

48
00:02:29.963 --> 00:02:30.553
to get to.

49
00:02:30.553 --> 00:02:35.550
It can learn and it can pass that other
information on to other routers as well.

50
00:02:35.550 --> 00:02:39.170
Now when it comes down to dynamic routing
protocols, there's generically two types.

51
00:02:39.170 --> 00:02:44.590
There's what we call distance vector and
then there's also link state.

52
00:02:44.590 --> 00:02:47.925
Now depending on who you talk to,
you may hear three types, okay?

53
00:02:47.925 --> 00:02:51.702
So you may hear distance vector and
then you hear the term hybrid sometimes,

54
00:02:51.702 --> 00:02:53.541
then you hear the term Link-State.

55
00:02:53.541 --> 00:02:55.577
But when it comes down to it,
Cisco itself,

56
00:02:55.577 --> 00:02:57.901
which developed the one
that people call hybrid.

57
00:02:57.901 --> 00:03:02.886
They like the terminology, but they admit
that it's really not a super hybrid as

58
00:03:02.886 --> 00:03:08.130
much as it is in what's called an Advanced
Distance Vector protocol as well, okay?

59
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:12.300
So when we start talking about this,
let's differentiate those to help us out.

60
00:03:12.300 --> 00:03:17.140
In distance vector protocol,
let's explain that term just for

61
00:03:17.140 --> 00:03:19.150
a moment to help us out, okay?

62
00:03:19.150 --> 00:03:22.570
So when we break apart the term
distance vector, okay?

63
00:03:22.570 --> 00:03:27.512
What you get a sense of is this routing
protocol itself is based on an algorithm.

64
00:03:27.512 --> 00:03:32.127
And an algorithm is just a simple series
of ways that it calculates whatever it

65
00:03:32.127 --> 00:03:33.160
wants to.

66
00:03:33.160 --> 00:03:37.490
It doesn't matter for you and I what
the mathematics actually is in doing it,

67
00:03:37.490 --> 00:03:39.460
but there's technical terms for it.

68
00:03:39.460 --> 00:03:42.135
But overall though at this point,
distance vector.

69
00:03:42.135 --> 00:03:46.839
Distance means that it is about
the number of hops from the source,

70
00:03:46.839 --> 00:03:50.640
from where you are, to the destination.

71
00:03:50.640 --> 00:03:53.560
So that's the idea of distance,
that's what it's gonna count.

72
00:03:53.560 --> 00:03:57.108
The other thing it is also
about is the term vector.

73
00:03:57.108 --> 00:04:03.280
Vector is giving us a direction to go in
to arrive at the destination network.

74
00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:08.410
So in dynamic routing protocols,
if it's a distance vector protocol,

75
00:04:08.410 --> 00:04:11.950
that means it bases itself off
of the number of routers or

76
00:04:11.950 --> 00:04:17.200
hops that you have to go through to
get to its ultimate destination, okay?

77
00:04:17.200 --> 00:04:19.560
So that's what it's talking about there,
okay?

78
00:04:19.560 --> 00:04:23.840
So when you start taking a look at it
here, there's really four different ones.

79
00:04:23.840 --> 00:04:26.560
And one of them I've put in here just for
the sake of completeness,

80
00:04:26.560 --> 00:04:29.400
but I will talk about these
two in particular cuz

81
00:04:29.400 --> 00:04:32.010
we're actually spending
our time in RIP version 2.

82
00:04:32.010 --> 00:04:36.690
But let's just describe them briefly
here and make sure that we understand.

83
00:04:36.690 --> 00:04:42.850
In terms of distance vector, let's start
at the beginning here, which is IGRP.

84
00:04:42.850 --> 00:04:47.500
So Cisco developed their own distance
vector protocol at the very beginning.

85
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:52.540
And it worked, but it didn't work
very well is what it came down to.

86
00:04:52.540 --> 00:04:57.110
So then in the industry standard
sources and other places.

87
00:04:57.110 --> 00:05:01.530
They came up with, well, RIP here,
which is Routing Information Protocol.

88
00:05:01.530 --> 00:05:03.610
And this worked a little bit better,

89
00:05:03.610 --> 00:05:07.870
because of the way that it did its metric
it actually did work a little bit better.

90
00:05:07.870 --> 00:05:12.996
The first version of RIP was developed
around the idea of classful routing, okay?

91
00:05:12.996 --> 00:05:17.309
So when you take a look at
that idea of RIP version 1,

92
00:05:17.309 --> 00:05:19.880
this is for classful routing.

93
00:05:19.880 --> 00:05:22.020
Now remember what that actually means.

94
00:05:22.020 --> 00:05:24.440
If we go back into our
networking fundamental.

95
00:05:24.440 --> 00:05:29.147
Classful routing really only looked
at the first octet to decide how it

96
00:05:29.147 --> 00:05:31.830
would route information.

97
00:05:31.830 --> 00:05:34.140
So it was based on
the idea of those classes,

98
00:05:34.140 --> 00:05:37.780
class A, class B, and class C addresses.

99
00:05:37.780 --> 00:05:39.739
That is as far as it went.

100
00:05:39.739 --> 00:05:42.650
It didn't care about
the subnet mask at all.

101
00:05:42.650 --> 00:05:46.590
It just said look, we're only
looking at the first octet there.

102
00:05:46.590 --> 00:05:48.970
And based on the binary
that it knows about.

103
00:05:48.970 --> 00:05:52.160
Class A for example,
it begins all of them,

104
00:05:52.160 --> 00:05:55.530
if you turn those addresses into binary,
it begins with a 0.

105
00:05:55.530 --> 00:06:00.740
Class B begins with a 10 in binary and
then class C is a 110.

106
00:06:00.740 --> 00:06:05.600
So that's all it cared about, and
RIP version 1 was actually out there and

107
00:06:05.600 --> 00:06:07.960
it actually did work in that sense.

108
00:06:07.960 --> 00:06:10.240
But if you tried to do
any type of subnetting,

109
00:06:10.240 --> 00:06:13.367
where you start changing the subnet masks,
it didn't care.

110
00:06:13.367 --> 00:06:15.810
It didn't even look for it, okay?

111
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:20.553
So when subnetting got popular then,
well RIP version 2 came along and

112
00:06:20.553 --> 00:06:23.888
gave us the idea here of
also being able to do this.

113
00:06:23.888 --> 00:06:27.857
But it actually did what we called
auto-summarization as well,

114
00:06:27.857 --> 00:06:30.463
and then it also did classless too, okay?

115
00:06:30.463 --> 00:06:34.962
So it could support it, but
it wasn't normally on by default, okay?

116
00:06:34.962 --> 00:06:38.960
So RIP version 2 allowed
us now to play around and

117
00:06:38.960 --> 00:06:41.690
take into account the subnet mask as well.

118
00:06:41.690 --> 00:06:44.660
So it could summarize up to the class.

119
00:06:44.660 --> 00:06:50.060
So even if you took a classful
address like 192.168.1,

120
00:06:50.060 --> 00:06:56.944

mask and used a 26-bit subnet mask.

121
00:06:56.944 --> 00:06:59.690
You'd be able to take all of
those smaller networks and

122
00:06:59.690 --> 00:07:03.255

network that it needed to be.

123
00:07:03.255 --> 00:07:04.315
So it did that, but

124
00:07:04.315 --> 00:07:08.370
it did it automatically as well,

125
00:07:08.370 --> 00:07:12.892

00:07:12.892 --> 00:07:15.231

00:07:15.231 --> 00:07:18.860

00:07:23.110 --> 00:07:25.770

00:18:25.090 --> 00:18:28.510
then we'll get to router 3 here in
a moment that's behind my head, okay?

322
00:18:28.510 --> 00:18:33.500
But when it begins here with router 1 and
we turn RIP on,

323
00:18:33.500 --> 00:18:38.310
it will automatically learn about the
networks that it is directly connected to.

324
00:18:38.310 --> 00:18:41.352
So what it puts into its routing
table right away, right,

325
00:18:41.352 --> 00:18:42.727
is the network over here.

326
00:18:42.727 --> 00:18:47.744
That's off of g0/0, 192.168.16.1.

327
00:18:47.744 --> 00:18:51.501
It enters it in because it is
directly connected as well and

328
00:18:51.501 --> 00:18:53.503
doesn't have to go anywhere.

329
00:18:53.503 --> 00:18:57.140
Its metric is gonna be a 0, and
it actually says it's off this interface,

330
00:18:57.140 --> 00:18:59.660
which is the one here to the left.

331
00:18:59.660 --> 00:19:02.060
Notice the second one that it knows about.

332
00:19:02.060 --> 00:19:02.840
It's the same way.

333
00:19:02.840 --> 00:19:04.921
It says, hey, that 12 network, right?

334
00:19:04.921 --> 00:19:09.057
192.168.12.1, or the 12 network,

335
00:19:09.057 --> 00:19:14.610
is off of the one to the right over here,
which is g0/1, okay?

336
00:19:14.610 --> 00:19:18.130
Now when that is actually true,
it enters that in.

337
00:19:18.130 --> 00:19:20.460
Now the problem that we have is simple.

338
00:19:20.460 --> 00:19:26.446
Now we have to get the information about

339
00:19:26.446 --> 00:19:28.407
Now how does that actually end up working,

00:19:31.120 --> 00:19:36.447
So we want to actually be able to learn

342
00:19:36.447 --> 00:19:41.614

00:19:41.614 --> 00:19:44.579
And also the 200.200.200 network,

00:19:44.579 --> 00:19:48.320
I wanna learn about that

345
00:19:48.320 --> 00:19:54.900
So if I have RIP turned on, this is what
will also begin to happen, too, okay?

346
00:19:54.900 --> 00:19:57.030
So now we have to go over to router 3,

347
00:19:57.030 --> 00:19:59.530
cuz you kinda get the idea
router 2 is the same thing.

348
00:19:59.530 --> 00:20:03.190
It knows about the networks that
it's directly connected to, and so

349
00:20:03.190 --> 00:20:04.081
does router 3.

350
00:20:04.081 --> 00:20:08.290
Well, let's start here with router
3 to kind of help us along, okay?

351
00:20:08.290 --> 00:20:11.350
So, when we start doing this,
over here on router 3,

352
00:20:11.350 --> 00:20:15.300
we kind of have to take a look at
the network behind my head here, okay?

353
00:20:15.300 --> 00:20:20.130
I just put X's to give us space
to be a place holder, right?

354
00:20:20.130 --> 00:20:22.920
So router 3 knows about
these two networks.

355
00:20:22.920 --> 00:20:27.600
Well, what begins to happen here, right,
between these routers is once we turn on

356
00:20:27.600 --> 00:20:31.960
RIP, they being to communicate with
each other about what they know about.

357
00:20:31.960 --> 00:20:35.620
So let's say router 3 says, hey,
I've got these networks, and

00:20:35.620 --> 00:20:39.460
now it actually hears

359
00:20:39.460 --> 00:20:43.748
Router 2 says, hey, I have
information that I can share as well.

360
00:20:43.748 --> 00:20:47.281
So router 3 and
router 2 begin to update, okay?

361
00:20:47.281 --> 00:20:50.121
So when it does that, notice down here,

362
00:20:50.121 --> 00:20:53.560
full routing table
updates every 30 seconds.

363
00:20:53.560 --> 00:20:57.034
So now router 2 sends a copy
over to router 3, okay,

364
00:20:57.034 --> 00:21:01.020
of its entire routing table,

365
00:21:01.020 --> 00:21:08.321
So, from router 2 it
learns about 172.16.23.0.

366
00:21:08.321 --> 00:21:16.222
172.16.23.0/24, if I can
actually type it out there, okay?

367
00:21:16.222 --> 00:21:19.430
Now, once we take a look at that,

368
00:21:19.430 --> 00:21:24.110
right, it is now saying, all right,

369
00:21:24.110 --> 00:21:29.040
With that routing table now being
reported, router 3 here says,

370
00:21:29.040 --> 00:21:33.370
hey, I am one hop away from router 2.

371
00:21:33.370 --> 00:21:39.000
So its metric, then,
it'll actually be a 1, okay?

372
00:21:39.000 --> 00:21:43.870
So there it is, router 1 got its update
from router 2, which is one hop away.

373
00:21:43.870 --> 00:21:46.870
Here's the one hop, and
it updated its table.

374
00:21:46.870 --> 00:21:51.020
Now the other side, though,
it'd do the same thing, okay?

375
00:21:51.020 --> 00:21:58.880
So it will again go 192.168.12.0 as well.

376
00:21:58.880 --> 00:22:04.010
And the same process here, it learned
it from router 2's update, oops.

377
00:22:05.110 --> 00:22:08.650
So it will also be one hop away as well,
okay?

378
00:22:09.800 --> 00:22:12.820
Now on or about the same time,
depending on it.

379
00:22:12.820 --> 00:22:16.729
Now I can't do it simultaneously here,
which is the problem, right?

380
00:22:16.729 --> 00:22:20.575
So router 2 and router 3 could
have updated simultaneously here,

381
00:22:20.575 --> 00:22:23.630
okay, is what could have happened.

382
00:22:23.630 --> 00:22:25.480
Now, but let's just take it in order here.

383
00:22:25.480 --> 00:22:27.290
Let's just say that they're
a little bit off, right?

384
00:22:27.290 --> 00:22:31.830
So router 2 got its update just
a little bit later from router 3.

385
00:22:31.830 --> 00:22:36.925
So now router 2 wants to know

386
00:22:36.925 --> 00:22:44.877
So it can actually do 200.200.200 here,

387
00:22:44.877 --> 00:22:47.003
.0/24.

00:22:47.003 --> 00:22:49.730
Let me see if I can extend

389
00:22:51.140 --> 00:22:55.670
And this time it is actually one hop away,
but

00:22:55.670 --> 00:23:00.650
it learned it from out of that interface,
which is over here on the right-hand side.

391
00:23:00.650 --> 00:23:02.330
Ooh, I need to stretch that one

392
00:23:04.740 --> 00:23:06.460
So it'll learn this one.

393
00:23:06.460 --> 00:23:11.390
Now, router 2 says, look,

394
00:23:11.390 --> 00:23:14.730
So now it could have been that router

395
00:23:14.730 --> 00:23:16.836
Started receiving updates as well.

396
00:23:16.836 --> 00:23:20.720
So let's say that router 1 by this
time had also sent its update.

397
00:23:20.720 --> 00:23:23.711
It compares, and it knows,
and router 2 says, well,

398
00:23:23.711 --> 00:23:28.184
I'm missing the route that I'm not
connected to, which 192.168.16.

399
00:23:30.738 --> 00:23:36.870
192.168.16.0/24.

400
00:23:36.870 --> 00:23:38.370
And that is one hop away.

401
00:23:39.670 --> 00:23:42.780
And now we have that routing
table that's filled up.

402
00:23:44.100 --> 00:23:48.830
Router 2 now sends its routing table over,
and it matches,

403
00:23:48.830 --> 00:23:52.470
and it compares, and it sees that it has
two routes that are the same, right?

404
00:23:52.470 --> 00:23:55.140
The 12 and the 16,
they're already in here.

405
00:23:55.140 --> 00:23:59.915
When it compares and it goes,
all right, so I need the 172, oops.

406
00:23:59.915 --> 00:24:04.671
172.16.

407
00:24:04.671 --> 00:24:11.250
23.0/24, and this metric,
it learned it from Router 2 here.

408
00:24:14.289 --> 00:24:15.970
Make sure I'm doing that right, yep.

409
00:24:15.970 --> 00:24:18.960
It learned it from Router 2,
which is one hop away, and

00:24:18.960 --> 00:24:21.780
it learned it off of that interface too.

411
00:24:21.780 --> 00:24:28.195
Now, we have one more though,
which is this 200.200.200.0 network.

412
00:24:28.195 --> 00:24:35.437
So Router 1 learns about that as well,

00:24:35.437 --> 00:24:39.520
that's what I heard from
Router 2 that it did.

00:24:40.520 --> 00:24:42.790
Now here's where it gets interesting,

415
00:24:42.790 --> 00:24:47.330
The metric though is not a one hop

416
00:24:47.330 --> 00:24:49.810
But look at what Router 2 said to it.

417
00:24:49.810 --> 00:24:55.612
It said that, I am one hop away, so

00:24:55.612 --> 00:24:58.860

419
00:24:58.860 --> 00:25:03.248
The update that I got from Router 2, and

00:25:03.248 --> 00:25:08.280
I am one hop away from Router 2,
so I must be two

421
00:25:08.280 --> 00:25:14.762
hops away from the 200.200.200.0 network.

422
00:25:14.762 --> 00:25:18.910
So now you see where
the routing table gets updated.

423
00:25:18.910 --> 00:25:22.030
And when it does this, and
everything is actually fine and stable and

424
00:25:22.030 --> 00:25:23.730

425
00:25:23.730 --> 00:25:27.620
Every 30 seconds it will exchange
this at some point in time, right?

426
00:25:27.620 --> 00:25:31.780
Each one of them, they don't have to
always be synchronized up in that way.

427
00:25:31.780 --> 00:25:35.710
But as they start learning about it,
this is what will end up happening.

428
00:25:35.710 --> 00:25:40.448
Now when every single router in
your administrative system, now,

429
00:25:40.448 --> 00:25:45.267
your AS, your administrative system here,
when they are all having

430
00:25:45.267 --> 00:25:50.023
the same identical routing table,
you are what we call converged.

431
00:25:50.023 --> 00:25:52.438
Or you're in that state of convergence.

432
00:25:52.438 --> 00:25:57.820
Which means that the entirety of those
routing tables are essentially matching.

433
00:25:57.820 --> 00:26:00.940
I can get to every other
network that I need to get to

434
00:26:00.940 --> 00:26:03.900

435
00:26:03.900 --> 00:26:07.640
If something changes, the nice thing

436
00:26:07.640 --> 00:26:11.160

But with distance vector protocols though,

Which essentially are routing loops and

441

So we'll be addressing some

00:26:30.360 --> 00:26:33.670
But just kind of get at least into

You now understand a little bit more

00:29:57.208 --> 00:29:58.911
have available to you.

516
00:29:58.911 --> 00:30:02.861
So now we're only going to be sending
out the other two interfaces that we're

517
00:30:02.861 --> 00:30:04.501
connected to in our network, or

518
00:30:04.501 --> 00:30:07.143
the singular interface
that we're connected to.

519
00:30:07.143 --> 00:30:09.628
And then we're not sending
it out the other one, okay?

520
00:30:09.628 --> 00:30:12.375
So Passive Interfaces
they are a part of it and

521
00:30:12.375 --> 00:30:15.423
don't forget it is called
out on the exam as well.

522
00:30:15.423 --> 00:30:20.520
So remember that you're gonna configure
that inside of the router RIP, okay?

523
00:30:20.520 --> 00:30:22.876
And then in their passive-interface.

524
00:30:22.876 --> 00:30:25.953
And then in the interface itself and
that's what will do it.

525
00:30:25.953 --> 00:30:30.768
You can verify that you did
configure it right here in this

526
00:30:30.768 --> 00:30:33.085
show IP protocols, okay?

527
00:30:33.085 --> 00:30:38.013
So that is a big part of what
we also end up doing too, okay?

528
00:30:38.013 --> 00:30:41.996
So now that we have that ready to go,
okay?

529
00:30:41.996 --> 00:30:45.365
There are still a few concepts
we haven't gotten to yet.

530
00:30:45.365 --> 00:30:48.423
So we'll need a little bit of
explanation for that as well,

531
00:30:48.423 --> 00:30:51.419
which is now we're gonna deal
with the idea of timers, and

532
00:30:51.419 --> 00:30:54.440
why they are also important to and
also the rest of our lab.

533
00:30:54.440 --> 00:30:57.133
So, Zach, this is a good place for
us to end this episode.

534
00:30:57.133 --> 00:30:59.119
>> So here's a bunch of numbers, ready?

535
00:30:59.119 --> 00:31:02.292
Okay, you've configured RIP version 2 for
IPv4.

536
00:31:02.292 --> 00:31:04.668
This is part two,
there will be a part three.

537
00:31:04.668 --> 00:31:06.538
Make sure you see all of those things.

538
00:31:06.538 --> 00:31:08.860
And by the way, Ronnie, anything else
you'd like to say before we move on?

539
00:31:08.860 --> 00:31:10.868
>> Well, once again, practice is key.

540
00:31:10.868 --> 00:31:14.502
And at this point here,
this is a bunch of new concepts, right?

541
00:31:14.502 --> 00:31:16.701
If you haven't been working
with routing protocols,

542
00:31:16.701 --> 00:31:18.335
there's a lot of information to learn.

543
00:31:18.335 --> 00:31:21.832
So go through, make sure you
understand the updating concept and

544
00:31:21.832 --> 00:31:23.365
what we're talking about.

545
00:31:23.365 --> 00:31:27.211
And then you actually see
the configuration is relatively simple,

546
00:31:27.211 --> 00:31:29.310
there's not really complex at all.

547
00:31:29.310 --> 00:31:32.010
Because doing it in background,
cuz it runs an algorithm,

548
00:31:32.010 --> 00:31:35.359
that's another good thing about me
not having run static routes as well.

549
00:31:35.359 --> 00:31:39.217
But just remember, go through this lab,
configure it to that point where

550
00:31:39.217 --> 00:31:43.386
you're working fast and quickly through
it, is what you want to be able to do and

551
00:31:43.386 --> 00:31:46.580
that's what will help you also
as you get ready for the exam.

552
00:31:46.580 --> 00:31:48.047
>> Fantastic, thank you, Ronnie.

553
00:31:48.047 --> 00:31:51.909
And make sure you watch every
single episode of Cisco CCent.

554
00:31:51.909 --> 00:31:55.338
You'll be glad you did, it will help you
and you'll be in the course library too.

555
00:31:55.338 --> 00:31:58.713
So there's thousands of other
videos there to help you go for it.

556
00:31:58.713 --> 00:32:01.278
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
would you?

557
00:32:01.278 --> 00:32:03.171
ITProTV is binge worthy.

558
00:32:03.171 --> 00:32:03.910
Thanks for watching.

559
00:32:03.910 --> 00:32:04.820
I'm Zach Memos.
>> And

I'm Ronnie Wong.

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host, Don.

4

Hello, and thank you for choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn everywhere you go.

6
00:00:16.991 --> 00:00:20.729
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
with this episode of Cisco CCent.

7
00:00:20.729 --> 00:00:23.394
Right now, believe it or not,

8
00:00:23.394 --> 00:00:28.863
we're gonna configure RIP version 2 for
IPv4, part three.

9
00:00:28.863 --> 00:00:31.420
[LAUGH] That's a lot of numbers, and

10
00:00:31.420 --> 00:00:34.780
the person bringing us all the information
we need is the one and only Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:34.780 --> 00:00:36.130
Ronnie, good to see you sir.

12
00:00:36.130 --> 00:00:37.580
Thank you for having me back on the show,

13
00:00:37.580 --> 00:00:41.970
as we continue on in the lab that we
kinda started just in the last episode.

14
00:00:41.970 --> 00:00:46.820
We started talking about dynamic routing
protocols just a couple episodes ago, and

15
00:00:46.820 --> 00:00:47.750
now we're carrying through and

16
00:00:47.750 --> 00:00:51.500
we're setting up, of course,
RIP version two in our CCent journey.

17
00:00:51.500 --> 00:00:55.980
Remember that every day, you should be
practicing how to begin configuring and

18
00:00:55.980 --> 00:00:57.890
working with your routers and switches.

19
00:00:57.890 --> 00:00:59.750
And remember,
if you don't have the physical ones,

20
00:00:59.750 --> 00:01:02.110
you do have access to practicelabs.com.

21
00:01:02.110 --> 00:01:05.640
Our lab partner that provides
you access to real equipment, so

22
00:01:05.640 --> 00:01:08.270
you're not using a simulator,
you're not using an emulator.

23
00:01:08.270 --> 00:01:12.440
You're using the real equipment, and
that does actually help you out, okay?

24
00:01:12.440 --> 00:01:13.910
So let's go ahead, and

25
00:01:13.910 --> 00:01:17.810
we are now continuing to kind of see
some of the stuff that we need to do.

26
00:01:17.810 --> 00:01:23.905
So, when we ended the previous episode,
we had just configured passive interfaces.

27
00:01:23.905 --> 00:01:26.740
Right.
And remember that idea means that normally

28
00:01:26.740 --> 00:01:31.170
for us, if we have an interface,

29
00:01:31.170 --> 00:01:34.060
somewhere that is not going to
be connected to another router.

30
00:01:34.060 --> 00:01:35.970
Let's say it is facing our own land, and

31
00:01:35.970 --> 00:01:39.560
we don't have another router internally,
then I don't need to send routing updates.

32
00:01:39.560 --> 00:01:42.245
I don't need to be receiving
any routing updates.

33
00:01:42.245 --> 00:01:45.740
Turning it as a passive interface,
so don't go ahead and do that.

34
00:01:45.740 --> 00:01:47.270
Don't send those updates out.

35
00:01:47.270 --> 00:01:48.700
Don't participate in it.

36
00:01:48.700 --> 00:01:49.650
So we're not worried about it.

37
00:01:49.650 --> 00:01:52.230
But it will still work inside a Rip.

38
00:01:52.230 --> 00:01:52.790
Okay?

39
00:01:52.790 --> 00:01:55.110
So we're not doing that.

40
00:01:55.110 --> 00:01:58.850
Now, we need to talk about something
we've been floating around here.

41
00:01:58.850 --> 00:02:02.530
I've pointed it out here a couple of times
trying to hold back the explanation,

42
00:02:02.530 --> 00:02:05.900
because we also see some information,

43
00:02:05.900 --> 00:02:10.300
specifically right here under
the show IP protocols, right?

44
00:02:10.300 --> 00:02:14.110
Which is the idea of these timers
that we've been hinting around.

45
00:02:15.170 --> 00:02:21.820
In the routing updates that tend to happen
for what you and I are looking at okay?

46
00:02:21.820 --> 00:02:27.140
Remember that every router really
does send updates every 30 seconds,

47
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:30.650
and the great thing is you can see
when a router is actually doing that.

48
00:02:30.650 --> 00:02:33.560
So let's run that command again.

49
00:02:33.560 --> 00:02:37.730
Oops, let me see if I can stay
with the proper router here, and

50
00:02:37.730 --> 00:02:40.060
get access to it, so there we go.

51
00:02:40.060 --> 00:02:44.470
I'll try to do that right here,
and I'll zoom in.

52
00:02:46.840 --> 00:02:53.470
So let's do a show IP protocols for
a moment.

53
00:02:53.470 --> 00:02:57.560
And now you can see that the next
one is due in 21 seconds.

54
00:02:57.560 --> 00:02:59.160
Okay.
So when we start seeing that,

55
00:02:59.160 --> 00:03:01.860
the updates is actually being sent,
if there's updates,

56
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:03.913
it's actually doing it every 30 seconds.

57
00:03:03.913 --> 00:03:09.016
So whatever this one is, ideally what
should happen is between this one and

58
00:03:09.016 --> 00:03:11.790
NYEDGE1, It would be identical.

59
00:03:11.790 --> 00:03:16.020
In other words, when this one says 21
seconds, EDGE2 would also say 21 seconds.

60
00:03:16.020 --> 00:03:19.440
But if you did that,
things would start to happen as well,

61
00:03:19.440 --> 00:03:22.580
because you might have collisions,
you might have some different things

62
00:03:22.580 --> 00:03:24.340
that happen as they're sending and
receiving data.

63
00:03:24.340 --> 00:03:26.920
But you tend to actually have
everything kinda slowed down,

64
00:03:26.920 --> 00:03:29.590
when stuff like that does happen as well.

65
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:33.690
But because they are a little bit
off sync too, you can also have

66
00:03:33.690 --> 00:03:37.020
issues like what we described,
that cause routing loops as well.

67
00:03:37.020 --> 00:03:38.850
So if we actually take a look,

68
00:03:38.850 --> 00:03:41.820
right, let's make sure we
understand these numbers, okay.

69
00:03:41.820 --> 00:03:45.240
The very first one, like we said here,
is probably the key number.

70
00:03:45.240 --> 00:03:49.600
Every 30 seconds, okay, is when we
send out the entire routing table.

71
00:03:49.600 --> 00:03:52.830
Not a partial update, but
the entire routing table.

72
00:03:52.830 --> 00:03:57.100
But now notice that it doesn't
get rid of it immediately, okay.

73
00:03:57.100 --> 00:04:02.530
So what we're also seeing is, after about
three minutes here, okay, after about

74
00:04:02.530 --> 00:04:07.430
three minutes, it is going to say look,
if I don't hear a routing update, I'm not

75
00:04:07.430 --> 00:04:12.280
gonna just dump it out of the table, but
let's say in three minutes time, okay?

76
00:04:12.280 --> 00:04:15.470
Then I'll consider it invalid.

77
00:04:15.470 --> 00:04:17.300
Hm.
And invalid just means I'm not

78
00:04:17.300 --> 00:04:20.120
gonna consider it as
actually being a good route.

79
00:04:20.120 --> 00:04:23.840
I'm just going to kind of say,
something may be wrong with this, and

80
00:04:23.840 --> 00:04:24.670
not do anything.

81
00:04:24.670 --> 00:04:25.510
Okay.

82
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:30.780
Then it has a hold down time of
another about three minutes as well.

83
00:04:30.780 --> 00:04:34.610
Hold down time is saying look, let me hold
on this, just in case it's just a glitch.

84
00:04:34.610 --> 00:04:38.343
Routers are rebooting or something,
and we don't wanna get rid of it, but

85
00:04:38.343 --> 00:04:42.074
if I do that, we'll have to learn
the entire routing table over again, but

86
00:04:42.074 --> 00:04:44.640
after essentially six
minutes here all together.

87
00:04:44.640 --> 00:04:49.840
So it could be upwards to what,
almost six, seven, eight, nine, ten,

88
00:04:49.840 --> 00:04:55.600
maybe almost 12 minutes, before
everything actually gets back into place.

89
00:04:55.600 --> 00:04:58.170
So it's a very slow updating process.

90
00:04:58.170 --> 00:04:59.995
It's a very slow thing that can happen.

91
00:04:59.995 --> 00:05:00.530
Mm-hm.

92
00:05:00.530 --> 00:05:03.680
If we don't have things working
the way that we want to.

93
00:05:03.680 --> 00:05:05.680
And if one of those gets upset,

94
00:05:05.680 --> 00:05:10.020
in terms of the timing of things,
that's when routing loops can happen.

95
00:05:10.020 --> 00:05:12.110
So when you set up for

96
00:05:12.110 --> 00:05:17.650
the idea here of your timers,
usually the best practice is this.

97
00:05:17.650 --> 00:05:20.570
You can adjust these timers, okay?

98
00:05:20.570 --> 00:05:24.450
But you should normally only adjust
them if you have a need to adjust them.

99
00:05:24.450 --> 00:05:27.970
In other words, if somebody can tell you,
here's a good reason to adjust them.

100
00:05:27.970 --> 00:05:31.300
It is taking too long for
a route to time out.

101
00:05:31.300 --> 00:05:33.380
Adjust them, that's way too long.

102
00:05:33.380 --> 00:05:34.110
I don't want that.

103
00:05:34.110 --> 00:05:35.340
I want it to pick up immediately.

104
00:05:35.340 --> 00:05:36.090
I want to do this.

105
00:05:37.890 --> 00:05:42.090
Just take that time,
make sure she does what you want it to do.

106
00:05:42.090 --> 00:05:43.680
That's what has to happened.

107
00:05:43.680 --> 00:05:48.440
Now if you do that,
make sure you also take a look and

108
00:05:48.440 --> 00:05:50.718
verify for
anything like loops that can happen.

109
00:05:50.718 --> 00:05:52.998
If that starts to happen,
what it means is,

110
00:05:52.998 --> 00:05:55.790
you need to adjust them to be the same.

111
00:05:55.790 --> 00:06:00.680
So whatever is inside your administrative
domain, your autonomous system,

112
00:06:00.680 --> 00:06:04.620
I said administrative system
in an earlier segment here.

113
00:06:04.620 --> 00:06:07.530
But it's the autonomous, I don't know
why I can't keep that word in my head

114
00:06:07.530 --> 00:06:10.350
in your own autonomous
system at that point.

115
00:06:10.350 --> 00:06:14.580
If you do something like that, well, just
make sure you set them all the same, okay?

116
00:06:14.580 --> 00:06:17.100
So here, we're gonna show you
how to adjust those timers,

117
00:06:17.100 --> 00:06:21.020
if I can actually keep
the router on my screen here.

118
00:06:21.020 --> 00:06:23.570
I may show you that instead, okay?

119
00:06:23.570 --> 00:06:28.440
So let's go ahead and set up some of
the adjustments on the timers here.

120
00:06:28.440 --> 00:06:31.870
Now this is a little bit of
a strange configuration for

121
00:06:31.870 --> 00:06:33.510
us to be playing with here.

122
00:06:33.510 --> 00:06:35.100
So let me show you what I mean by that.

123
00:06:35.100 --> 00:06:39.230
Now we're gonna get into, of course,
our global configuration mode.

124
00:06:39.230 --> 00:06:42.830
And let's run our global configuration
mode back into router rip.

125
00:06:42.830 --> 00:06:46.960
And now I'm inside, of course,
of the rip configuration, the router here.

126
00:06:46.960 --> 00:06:52.790
Once I do this, we're gonna actually
set timers, and then, the term basic.

127
00:06:52.790 --> 00:06:54.990
There's no advanced system.

128
00:06:54.990 --> 00:06:57.520
Let me see if I can show you that,
I'll just set up timers.

129
00:06:57.520 --> 00:06:59.810
And now notice it says, incomplete.

130
00:06:59.810 --> 00:07:02.680
That's the only option that we have.

131
00:07:02.680 --> 00:07:06.770
So it has to be timers basic, and now,

132
00:07:06.770 --> 00:07:09.510
this is where it begins to get
a little bit more unusual.

133
00:07:10.750 --> 00:07:15.170
So the first thing that it says is, what's
your interval for your updates in between.

134
00:07:15.170 --> 00:07:19.128
Well if 30 seconds is too long, if you go
wow, no, I need that update a lot quicker

135
00:07:19.128 --> 00:07:21.790
than that, let's set this for
half of that, which is 15.

136
00:07:21.790 --> 00:07:25.120
Now, I'm going to do
another question mark here,

137
00:07:25.120 --> 00:07:27.720
because it doesn't tell
you what you should do.

138
00:07:27.720 --> 00:07:29.440
Right?
No actually I don't need to do that.

139
00:07:29.440 --> 00:07:30.438
I need to do the whole thing.

140
00:07:30.438 --> 00:07:33.320
I forgot,
this thing doesn't allow me to add in.

141
00:07:33.320 --> 00:07:35.811
It just says timer, basic.

142
00:07:35.811 --> 00:07:38.780
This is gonna be annoying here,
I can feel it.

143
00:07:40.330 --> 00:07:44.210
15, and now notice that once we
do something like that as well,

144
00:07:44.210 --> 00:07:46.330
it says that there's
an incomplete command.

145
00:07:46.330 --> 00:07:47.630
So let's do timer.

146
00:07:48.730 --> 00:07:50.918
So this is why it's annoying.

147
00:07:50.918 --> 00:07:55.688
Timer, basic, 15, and
then a question mark again,

148
00:07:55.688 --> 00:07:59.405
and let's see, what are we looking for?

149
00:07:59.405 --> 00:08:00.949
Well, I'm lying to you.

150
00:08:00.949 --> 00:08:05.155
It actually is saying,
incomplete is what it's saying.

151
00:08:05.155 --> 00:08:08.231
So it's just going to make me
type them all in at one time.

152
00:08:08.231 --> 00:08:13.689
So timer basic, and
then I can do 15, oops.

153
00:08:13.689 --> 00:08:19.111
Then I can do 90, which, I'm cutting
that idea of that invalid time in half.

154
00:08:19.111 --> 00:08:23.058
And then that other 180 in half for
the whole downtime.

155
00:08:23.058 --> 00:08:28.052
And then lastly, we're gonna cut the 240
in half for that time that it waits

156
00:08:28.052 --> 00:08:32.605
until it actually flushes it out
the table here, that's what we want.

157
00:08:32.605 --> 00:08:33.940
And now it accepts the whole thing.

158
00:08:33.940 --> 00:08:36.900
So it didn't like the very fact that
I only did piecemeal at a time.

159
00:08:36.900 --> 00:08:39.543
>> Mm-hm.
>> It actually made me type in the whole

160
00:08:39.543 --> 00:08:40.066
thing.

161
00:08:40.066 --> 00:08:41.529
That is what we end up seeing here.

162
00:08:41.529 --> 00:08:45.972
But yeah, you're not gonna know what
that is unless you walk through

163
00:08:45.972 --> 00:08:49.355
that procedure here of making
sure that you do this.

164
00:08:49.355 --> 00:08:53.346
And the great thing is this step
is actually in your lab and

165
00:08:53.346 --> 00:08:56.938
it corresponds directly
to these numbers up here.

166
00:08:56.938 --> 00:09:03.060
30 seconds we cut down to 15,
invalid after 90 seconds instead of 180.

167
00:09:03.060 --> 00:09:06.729
Hold down, we again change 180 to 90, and

168
00:09:06.729 --> 00:09:10.683
then the flush time here
to 120 seconds as well.

169
00:09:10.683 --> 00:09:14.700
So that's what we just set up for
this particular router.

170
00:09:14.700 --> 00:09:17.804
All right, now, if we go to NYEDGE2,

171
00:09:17.804 --> 00:09:22.226
which is the other router that
we are working with here,

172
00:09:22.226 --> 00:09:26.760
let's see if I can zoom back out and
get a little bit more.

173
00:09:26.760 --> 00:09:28.188
There we go, okay.

174
00:09:28.188 --> 00:09:34.155
On NYEDGE2, Make sure we can get in here.

175
00:09:34.155 --> 00:09:38.825
What we want to see is, how does this
affect the routing table over here?

176
00:09:38.825 --> 00:09:44.157
So let's go ahead and
do that, show ip route.

177
00:09:44.157 --> 00:09:47.170
And we're gonna specifically look for
RIP routes here.

178
