But that's the term that they have.

407
00:23:43.590 --> 00:23:45.670
But now both of them
are actually showing up,

408
00:23:45.670 --> 00:23:49.680
which is what we want them to
actually be doing as well, okay?

409
00:23:49.680 --> 00:23:53.271
So now we're taking care
of discontiguous networks.

410
00:23:53.271 --> 00:23:58.105
My recommendation period, okay, and
you don't have to do it this way,

411
00:23:58.105 --> 00:24:02.007
is that when you configure a RIP for
anything and I mean it.

412
00:24:02.007 --> 00:24:06.460
I always choose Rip version two,
so router Rip version two.

413
00:24:06.460 --> 00:24:11.080
And then I always type in no auto-summary,
okay, automatically.

414
00:24:11.080 --> 00:24:15.380
Because I don't want Rip saying
that I'll summarize for you.

415
00:24:15.380 --> 00:24:19.080
If I want to summarize, then I will
manually create the summary and

416
00:24:19.080 --> 00:24:21.120
enter it in there as well, okay?

417
00:24:21.120 --> 00:24:23.960
So that is something that
I always just do because

418
00:24:23.960 --> 00:24:26.560
that's what you'll want to do as well,
okay?

419
00:24:26.560 --> 00:24:30.630
All right, now there is a few minutes left
which actually is just perfect enough time

420
00:24:30.630 --> 00:24:34.160
to finish up what we need
to in regards to Rip, okay?

421
00:24:34.160 --> 00:24:36.590
>> Okay.
>> So let's go ahead and do this.

422
00:24:36.590 --> 00:24:38.400
Now let's go back over to NYEDGE1.

423
00:24:40.510 --> 00:24:44.360
And remember that n,
when we take a look at this routing table,

424
00:24:44.360 --> 00:24:48.690
notice it says,
a gateway of last resort here, okay?

425
00:24:48.690 --> 00:24:50.540
That is not set.

426
00:24:50.540 --> 00:24:54.030
The gateway of last resort
is not set up for us.

427
00:24:54.030 --> 00:24:58.332
And now what we want to do is we wanna
begin setting up, of course, well,

428
00:24:58.332 --> 00:25:01.270
the idea here of that
gateway of last resort or

429
00:25:01.270 --> 00:25:04.100
a default route is what we want here.

430
00:25:04.100 --> 00:25:07.810
Now when we do so,
there's two ways we can do this.

431
00:25:07.810 --> 00:25:10.250
We can manually go in and
we can set it up statically,

432
00:25:10.250 --> 00:25:12.060
which is what we'll have to do here.

433
00:25:12.060 --> 00:25:15.321
But I also wanna set it up for
NYEDGE2, the other router.

434
00:25:15.321 --> 00:25:18.680
So I could go all the way over
to NYEDGE2 and set it up again.

435
00:25:18.680 --> 00:25:22.169
And then if I had another one that was
out there, router three, router four,

436
00:25:22.169 --> 00:25:24.330
each one I'd have to go in and
set this thing up.

437
00:25:24.330 --> 00:25:27.040
The great thing is you and I know how
to create a default route now, so

438
00:25:27.040 --> 00:25:28.350
it doesn't really matter.

439
00:25:28.350 --> 00:25:32.153
But that's a lot of effort, and it's a lot
of what we call administrative effort.

440
00:25:32.153 --> 00:25:34.880
If I have to do that for five,
six, seven, maybe ten routers,

441
00:25:34.880 --> 00:25:36.641
that's a lot of configuration, okay?

442
00:25:36.641 --> 00:25:37.404
>> That's a lot of time.

443
00:25:37.404 --> 00:25:42.650
>> But we can get the default
route set up here and

444
00:25:42.650 --> 00:25:49.014
then have it essentially
redistributed through Rip.

445
00:25:49.014 --> 00:25:56.270
Okay, so let's verify on NYEDGE2
again just for a moment.

446
00:25:56.270 --> 00:25:57.620
Let me see, okay?

447
00:25:57.620 --> 00:25:59.760
Just wanna verify on NYEDGE2.

448
00:25:59.760 --> 00:26:04.240
Notice that the gateway of last resort
is also not set before us, okay?

449
00:26:04.240 --> 00:26:11.364
So now if I go back to NYEDGE1,
We can now zoom in.

450
00:26:11.364 --> 00:26:14.152
And for us,
we're beginning to configure [INAUDIBLE].

451
00:26:14.152 --> 00:26:17.766
I'm gonna set up a static
default route here first.

452
00:26:17.766 --> 00:26:22.652
So I'm gonna do our configure terminal,
and once I get in here,

453
00:26:22.652 --> 00:26:27.087
we're going to go into the interface
at this point here and

454
00:26:27.087 --> 00:26:30.452
we're gonna turn on the interface, okay?

455
00:26:30.452 --> 00:26:37.532
So interface gigabits which

456
00:26:37.532 --> 00:26:44.612
is gonna be gigabitethernet

457
00:26:44.612 --> 00:26:49.216
0.1, oops.

458
00:26:49.216 --> 00:26:56.673
Interface let's just do abbreviation
here to make it a little bit faster.

459
00:26:56.673 --> 00:27:02.349
Give it a 0/1 ip address 172.15.0.1

460
00:27:02.349 --> 00:27:07.087
with a 24 bit subnet mask here, right?

461
00:27:07.087 --> 00:27:12.568
Now we're gonna make sure
it's on by a no shutdown.

462
00:27:12.568 --> 00:27:15.619
And now on NYEDGE1,
what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna say,

463
00:27:15.619 --> 00:27:18.857
hey, all of the routes that
are not found in my routing table,

464
00:27:18.857 --> 00:27:22.530
send it out this interface
that I've just turned on.

465
00:27:22.530 --> 00:27:23.410
So let's do it.

466
00:27:24.750 --> 00:27:26.442
Now I can do ip route and

467
00:27:26.442 --> 00:27:31.173
we did this during our static
routing configurations as well.

468
00:27:31.173 --> 00:27:34.509
Remember that 0.0.0 and
these 8 zeros in a row?

469
00:27:34.509 --> 00:27:39.189
This is typical in how you actually
create a default route as well.

470
00:27:39.189 --> 00:27:42.367
Then 172.15.0.1.

471
00:27:46.708 --> 00:27:49.030
It's supposed to be 0.2, sorry.

472
00:27:49.030 --> 00:27:52.340
See that's what happens when I
don't look at the notes here.

473
00:27:52.340 --> 00:27:53.220
I am lying to you.

474
00:27:55.600 --> 00:27:57.740
That should be the other router,
there we go.

475
00:27:57.740 --> 00:27:59.970
Okay, so I can't do it to myself, okay?

476
00:27:59.970 --> 00:28:04.477
So now I'm setting up, it's gonna go to
whatever that next hop router actually is.

477
00:28:04.477 --> 00:28:06.396
I don't even know what it is,
so that's fine.

478
00:28:06.396 --> 00:28:10.828
So let's check it out, do show ip route.

479
00:28:14.378 --> 00:28:15.980
And now let's take a look
at the information.

480
00:28:17.530 --> 00:28:20.790
All right, now look and
you'll see a couple of changes.

481
00:28:20.790 --> 00:28:23.397
The first two are pretty much right here,
okay?

482
00:28:23.397 --> 00:28:27.198
So notice gateway of last resort has
now been set for the default route.

483
00:28:27.198 --> 00:28:30.680
And also notice an s and a asterisk, okay?

484
00:28:30.680 --> 00:28:35.080
The s asterisk means it's a candidate
route, but it's statically configured.

485
00:28:35.080 --> 00:28:37.820
Now what is the candidate route about,
okay?

486
00:28:37.820 --> 00:28:42.127
It is actually giving us this ability
to take a look at it and say, hey,

487
00:28:42.127 --> 00:28:45.497
do we want to consider that
as being the default route.

488
00:28:45.497 --> 00:28:47.994
So you can actually have
another one if you choose to,

489
00:28:47.994 --> 00:28:50.005
ut that's what that star is about, okay?

490
00:28:50.005 --> 00:28:55.570
Is that is a possible candidate route for
us to become that default route?

491
00:28:55.570 --> 00:28:57.190
So there it is.

492
00:28:57.190 --> 00:29:02.220
Now that I've got this configured and
ready to go, okay, the problem that

493
00:29:02.220 --> 00:29:10.000
I have is, well, Rip doesn't actually
advertise static routes for me, okay?

494
00:29:10.000 --> 00:29:14.140
So if I want this static route right here

495
00:29:14.140 --> 00:29:18.170
to get sent into Rip, and
then to be distributed over to NYEDGE2,

496
00:29:18.170 --> 00:29:23.760
I have to actually be able to
redistribute this command, okay?

497
00:29:23.760 --> 00:29:25.860
Or this particular interface here.

498
00:29:25.860 --> 00:29:31.260
So remember that this is called a default
type of route that we just did, right?

499
00:29:31.260 --> 00:29:34.216
So let's go into router rip here.

500
00:29:38.459 --> 00:29:43.515
Router rip and once I'm in here,
okay, I want to go ahead and

501
00:29:43.515 --> 00:29:48.671
what I want to do, right,
is I want to actually say that this is

502
00:29:48.671 --> 00:29:53.847
gonna be where default information
originates from, okay?

503
00:29:53.847 --> 00:29:59.126
So on this particular router, so

504
00:29:59.126 --> 00:30:04.217
I type in default-information

505
00:30:04.217 --> 00:30:09.501
originate, right here, okay?

506
00:30:09.501 --> 00:30:10.323
So remember,

507
00:30:10.323 --> 00:30:15.140
static routes they don't automatically
get advertised by Rip itself.

508
00:30:15.140 --> 00:30:19.040
This is the configuration that says,
any default information,

509
00:30:19.040 --> 00:30:23.565
that I have now set here, this is where
it's gonna originate from into Rip.

510
00:30:23.565 --> 00:30:24.710
>> Mm-hm.

511
00:30:24.710 --> 00:30:28.830
>> All right, so that's all we
have to do at that point, okay?

512
00:30:28.830 --> 00:30:33.600
So now that the routing tables, right,
they're exchanging the full routing table.

513
00:30:33.600 --> 00:30:35.310
>> Right.
>> That includes now

514
00:30:35.310 --> 00:30:38.690
this default information
orginate which includes what?

515
00:30:38.690 --> 00:30:43.720
Well, the default information, which for
us is, well, right here, okay?

516
00:30:43.720 --> 00:30:46.440
That is default information for us.

517
00:30:46.440 --> 00:30:51.440
So if we go to NYEDGE2, I'm just gonna go

518
00:30:51.440 --> 00:30:55.670
into this mode here show ip route.

519
00:30:55.670 --> 00:31:00.880
Now this may take a few seconds, so
let's see what happens here as we do so.

520
00:31:00.880 --> 00:31:04.290
Good, it didn't actually take any
time at all, which is even better.

521
00:31:04.290 --> 00:31:08.970
Now you can see where, Zach, you and

522
00:31:08.970 --> 00:31:15.450
I did not configure this
0.0.0 network at all, okay?

523
00:31:15.450 --> 00:31:20.110
It learned it from Rip and
it also has the asterisk,

524
00:31:20.110 --> 00:31:26.050
and then we take a look at the asterisk,
it is a candidate default route.

525
00:31:26.050 --> 00:31:31.020
So it's saying, hey, I learned about this
information because the other router

526
00:31:31.020 --> 00:31:35.430
that running it said this is where
the decode information originates from.

527
00:31:35.430 --> 00:31:38.320
So this is a possible
candidate default route.

528
00:31:38.320 --> 00:31:43.410
And when I put that into route, notice
what it also did which was set my gateway

529
00:31:43.410 --> 00:31:49.250
and last resort at this point to go
back to wherever it actually wanted to.

530
00:31:49.250 --> 00:31:54.300
So now it is actually part of
the Rip configuration to do so.

531
00:31:54.300 --> 00:31:57.720
This is what we call some
type of route redistribution.

532
00:31:57.720 --> 00:31:59.890
>> Okay.
>> This one just happens to be a default

533
00:31:59.890 --> 00:32:00.990
route redistribution.

534
00:32:00.990 --> 00:32:05.030
For those of you that wanna learn
more about route redistribution,

535
00:32:05.030 --> 00:32:09.210
make sure you continue to go
on to your CCNA routing and

536
00:32:09.210 --> 00:32:14.330
switching as well as the CCNP routing and
switching shows too.

537
00:32:14.330 --> 00:32:18.650
All that will give you more information on
the idea of actually redistributing other

538
00:32:18.650 --> 00:32:22.710
routing protocols as well as connecting
routes and different routes as well.

539
00:32:22.710 --> 00:32:25.930
But just remember that this is a part
of what we're actually doing, okay?

540
00:32:25.930 --> 00:32:28.010
So everything is now set up.

541
00:32:28.010 --> 00:32:33.600
You've now seen kinda the basics of
the Rip version two configuration.

542
00:32:33.600 --> 00:32:36.720
And we've gone through all those exam
objectives to make sure that we've covered

543
00:32:36.720 --> 00:32:40.610
every single one so
that we could actually show you all of it.

544
00:32:40.610 --> 00:32:43.385
The great thing is,
it's built into your lab right here,

545
00:32:43.385 --> 00:32:45.430
under practice labs, our partner.

546
00:32:45.430 --> 00:32:47.370
So you'll be able to see how
much you can configure each and

547
00:32:47.370 --> 00:32:52.300
every step of those exam objectives for
you as well, okay?

548
00:32:52.300 --> 00:32:55.650
So more practice is kinda
the key here at this point.

549
00:32:55.650 --> 00:32:59.770
So just keep on practicing and, Zach,
that will end our episode for us here.

550
00:32:59.770 --> 00:33:01.190
>> Another fantastic job, Ronnie.

551
00:33:01.190 --> 00:33:02.170
Thank you so very much.

552
00:33:02.170 --> 00:33:03.500
You did such a great job.

553
00:33:03.500 --> 00:33:07.288
Configure Rip version two for
ipv4, this was part three,

554
00:33:07.288 --> 00:33:10.160
make sure you see part one and part two.

555
00:33:10.160 --> 00:33:15.320
And before we leave and say bye bye,
I think he wants to say something again.

556
00:33:15.320 --> 00:33:19.240
>> All right, so just kinda remember,
practice, practice, practice is the key.

557
00:33:20.320 --> 00:33:23.570
Getting the concepts down is very
important in terms of the elements that we

558
00:33:23.570 --> 00:33:24.560
talked about.

559
00:33:24.560 --> 00:33:27.780
But practice is the only way for
you to see how it happens.

560
00:33:27.780 --> 00:33:32.040
So make sure you're in a router or
a switch every day from this point on and

561
00:33:32.040 --> 00:33:35.730
that you are trying to get faster
at the configurations, okay?

562
00:33:35.730 --> 00:33:38.880
So that is the only way to build
the muscle memory that you'll need for

563
00:33:38.880 --> 00:33:39.820
the exam.

564
00:33:39.820 --> 00:33:43.440
And that is a point I
cannot emphasize any less.

565
00:33:43.440 --> 00:33:46.270
You have to actually be in
it daily at this point.

566
00:33:46.270 --> 00:33:51.090
And it has to become part of that,
where it's a natural thing for

567
00:33:51.090 --> 00:33:54.710
you and it's not like, I can't believe
I've got to get into the router.

568
00:33:54.710 --> 00:33:58.400
You've got to be excited about cuz
that's the way you're gonna learn more.

569
00:33:58.400 --> 00:33:59.990
>> Great advice,
thank you so much, Ronnie.

570
00:33:59.990 --> 00:34:03.700
And make sure you see every
single episode of Cisco CCENT.

571
00:34:03.700 --> 00:34:05.795
It will help you, it really, really will.

572
00:34:05.795 --> 00:34:09.676
And you'll be inside the course library
where there's thousands of other videos,

573
00:34:09.676 --> 00:34:11.982
and they're all designed
to help you go further.

574
00:34:11.982 --> 00:34:13.864
Tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

575
00:34:13.864 --> 00:34:15.768
ITProTV is bingeworthty.

576
00:34:15.768 --> 00:34:16.603
Thanks for watching.

577
00:34:16.603 --> 00:34:17.351
I'm Zach Memos.

578
00:34:17.351 --> 00:34:18.189
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

579
00:34:18.189 --> 00:34:21.280

00:34:21.280 --> 00:34:27.355

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce the concept of DNS.  The team describe the DNS lookup process.  They show how the process can work for each individual device but it requires configuration on every device that uses it.  They also describe the use of a DNS Server and how to can serve other devices too.
episodes.title: Describe and Configure DNS on a Router
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.592
Welcome to IT Pro TV, I'm your host

2

San Fransisco, CA.

4

5

00:00:16.930 --> 00:00:19.720
I'm your host Zach Memos for
this episode of Cisco Ccent,

8
00:00:19.720 --> 00:00:23.980
where we describe and
configure DNS on a router.

9
00:00:23.980 --> 00:00:25.310
That sounds exciting to me.

10
00:00:25.310 --> 00:00:27.610
And the person who's gonna do it for
us, not me.

11
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:28.310
No, no, no.

13
00:00:29.740 --> 00:00:33.546
Ronnie, good to see you sir.
>> Nice to be back here Zack as we

14
00:00:33.546 --> 00:00:34.487
continue on.

15
00:00:34.487 --> 00:00:39.112
And of course, getting ready for that
CCENT exam and we're in our journey and

16
00:00:39.112 --> 00:00:41.320
we're heading into another topic or

17
00:00:41.320 --> 00:00:45.610
another domain where we're talking
about infrastructure services.

18
00:00:45.610 --> 00:00:48.700
And that is really one of
the topics that we're covering.

19
00:00:48.700 --> 00:00:53.510
Which of course, is using what we
call DNS or domain name system.

20
00:00:53.510 --> 00:00:54.910
Or depending on when you learn about it,

21
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:58.948
it may have actually kind of
transitioned into domain name service.

22
00:00:58.948 --> 00:01:00.970
Both of those still end up working so

23
00:01:00.970 --> 00:01:06.130
you may see both of them as you continue
on your preparations of different things.

24
00:01:06.130 --> 00:01:10.750
But overall though, let's make sure that
we understand what DNS actually is because

25
00:01:10.750 --> 00:01:17.080
we're gonna see that we rely upon it
entirely today in our networking.

26
00:01:17.080 --> 00:01:20.010
But we're gonna rely on it
even more into the future.

27
00:01:20.010 --> 00:01:25.698
And the reason why is the transition over
to IVP6, you're gonna find out something.

28
00:01:25.698 --> 00:01:30.380
Even though you might remember
a few IP addresses like right now,

29
00:01:30.380 --> 00:01:33.625
I know just about all of
the infrastructure devices right here at

30
00:01:33.625 --> 00:01:36.625
ITPro.TV by their IP addresses.

31
00:01:36.625 --> 00:01:39.135
And the reason why is that with Nate and

32
00:01:39.135 --> 00:01:42.755
myself, we configured all
of those devices manually.

33
00:01:42.755 --> 00:01:44.755
So I typed them in over and
over again, and

34
00:01:44.755 --> 00:01:47.895
I know what those IP addresses
are without having to think about them.

35
00:01:47.895 --> 00:01:52.655
But we've taken a look at IPV6, and
those addresses are not as easy for

36
00:01:52.655 --> 00:01:56.520
me to memorize anymore
because they're actually,

37
00:01:56.520 --> 00:01:59.190
at least from my perspective,
a bit longer.

38
00:01:59.190 --> 00:02:04.300
So the reason why I'm actually emphasizing
that, is because what is easier for us to

39
00:02:04.300 --> 00:02:11.430
memorize is of course gonna be using names
that then can be resolved to IP address.

40
00:02:11.430 --> 00:02:15.070
And they realize that in the earliest
days of internet as well and

41
00:02:15.070 --> 00:02:18.750
that's what end up happening too is
that people aren't gonna remember

42
00:02:18.750 --> 00:02:21.480
every single IP address
on the entire planet.

43
00:02:21.480 --> 00:02:24.800
But they will remember what
names that are unique, and

44
00:02:24.800 --> 00:02:27.130
gives you that ability to do so, okay?

45
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:30.825
So that's what we're talking about today,
is we wanna understand that functionality.

46
00:02:30.825 --> 00:02:34.355
You wanna be able to describe at
least what that actually means and

47
00:02:34.355 --> 00:02:36.470
the way that it ends up working.

48
00:02:36.470 --> 00:02:39.720
And then of course,

00:29:23.854 --> 00:29:27.300
watch it again because there was
a lot of valuable information here.

492
00:29:27.300 --> 00:29:30.119
And Ronnie, before we go on,
anything else you'd like to say?

493
00:29:30.119 --> 00:29:31.348
>> Well, no, right now,

494
00:29:31.348 --> 00:29:34.950
remember that these are,
once again, foundational things.

495
00:29:34.950 --> 00:29:40.010
So if you've gotten through this episode,
and hopefully you have an understanding,

496
00:29:40.010 --> 00:29:42.300
but what we want you to
take some time as well.

497
00:29:42.300 --> 00:29:44.047
Make sure that you
understand this process.

498

There's not a ton that
you have to understand.

499
00:29:46.670 --> 00:29:49.350
But at the same time,
this is gonna be more cognizant and

500

something that you have
to keep on the radar.

501
00:29:51.526 --> 00:29:54.020
Because you're gonna be
depending on it more and more.

502
00:29:54.020 --> 00:29:57.360
So slow down, make sure you
understand the concepts here too.

503
00:29:57.360 --> 00:30:00.590
And don't forget practice every
day on entering in router and

504

swtich configurations.
>> Practice, practice, practice.

505

And also,

506

make sure you watch every episode of Cisco
CCENT that Ronnie's put together for you.

507
00:30:07.500 --> 00:30:10.760
He's put a lot of work into it, he's
done a great job, and it will help you.

508

And you'll be in the course library,

And there's thousands

510

And they're designed to do one thing,

And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

ITProTV is bingeworthy.

Thanks for watching.

514

>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue to configure DNS using a router as the DNS server.  They also discuss the more common usage of hosts tables for routers too.  The guys demontrate how to configure a router as a DNS server and show how it can work.  Lastly, they describe the more common usage of hosts-tables instead.
episodes.title: Describe and Configure DNS on a Router Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

Don Pezet.

3

My name is Zach Memos, and I'm your

Describe and
Configure DNS on a Router, Part Two.

good to see you.
>> Thank you for

on taking a look more at some DNS

configurations that we have to deal with.

12
00:00:37.600 --> 00:00:40.946
Now, of course,
as we started talking about this, right?

13
00:00:40.946 --> 00:00:45.698
Now we're not configuring a DNS server
like a Windows server DNS server,

14
00:00:45.698 --> 00:00:49.720
we're going to configure
a router to work as DNS for us.

15
00:00:49.720 --> 00:00:54.059
But remember that when we do this,
that the way that the interpretation was,

16
00:00:54.059 --> 00:00:55.945
at least from the lab designers.

17
00:00:55.945 --> 00:01:00.689
Is the very fact that they wanted
us to configure a full service DNS

18
00:01:00.689 --> 00:01:02.900
server on that router.

19
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:05.140
And I just have to kind of warn you again,
and

20

we'll see if we can take a look at this.

21

Because I've got to remember,

22

to see if we can take a look at

23

But we're going to be using, of course,
practice labs to help us out, okay?

24
00:01:16.826 --> 00:01:20.977
So the lab that we're doing
is going to be configure and

25
00:01:20.977 --> 00:01:26.380
verify DHCP and DNS as an introduction
here is what we're seeing.

26
00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:30.485
So this is what we'll actually
be taking a look at as well, so

27
00:01:30.485 --> 00:01:34.916
you can make sure that you follow

28
00:01:34.916 --> 00:01:38.423
We're going to configure
that DNS server on NYEDGE1,

29
00:01:38.423 --> 00:01:41.410
is where we're going to be configuring.

30
00:01:41.410 --> 00:01:45.782
This is one of those 2911 routers that

31
00:01:45.782 --> 00:01:46.961

32

And that's what we're going
to be setting up, and

33

then we'll be using our PC over here,
okay?

34
00:01:52.700 --> 00:01:56.430
On the right hand side, to test out and
verify that DNS is going to work.

35
00:01:56.430 --> 00:01:59.948
We've still got a little bit of
configuration here that we'll have to do

36
00:01:59.948 --> 00:02:03.480
on this one too, but right now
everything is set up for static IPs.

37
00:02:03.480 --> 00:02:05.579
You can see that DHCP is not enabled,

38

39

We'll enable this and show you how

40
00:02:12.856 --> 00:02:15.300
everything has to be manually configured.

41
00:02:15.300 --> 00:02:21.626
So on NYEDGE1, let's go ahead and

42
00:02:21.626 --> 00:02:25.310
and let me zoom in a bit so
that we can see it.

43
00:02:25.310 --> 00:02:27.671
So remember that in this
box here I get to type, but

44
00:02:27.671 --> 00:02:30.180
I don't get to use some of the nice,
cool features.

45
00:02:30.180 --> 00:02:33.975
Such as the up arrow to bring back
the history of what I've just typed in.

46
00:02:33.975 --> 00:02:36.221
So everything will be manually typed in,

47
00:02:36.221 --> 00:02:39.684
which means you are going to get
an eyeful, right, once again,

48
00:02:39.684 --> 00:02:42.494
of my incredible typos.
>> [LAUGH]

49
00:02:42.494 --> 00:02:43.929
>> In that path.

50
00:02:43.929 --> 00:02:47.047
We're just getting access
into privilege exec mode and

51
00:02:47.047 --> 00:02:50.290
now into the global
configuration mode as well.

52
00:02:50.290 --> 00:02:55.172
And once we're here, here's the setting
that we need to pay attention to, okay?

53
00:02:55.172 --> 00:03:00.870
So I'm going to do ip dns server, okay?

54
00:03:00.870 --> 00:03:05.608
Now when it accepts that command,
that is now turning on the full

55
00:03:05.608 --> 00:03:10.095
DNS server capabilities that
this router can do and handle.

56
00:03:10.095 --> 00:03:15.150
Traditionally, though,
we don't run DNS on a router itself.

57
00:03:15.150 --> 00:03:18.767
Because it is handling like all of
the traffic normally going in and

58
00:03:18.767 --> 00:03:20.327
out of our network, right?

59
00:03:20.327 --> 00:03:23.613
Between us and the Internet
a lot of times, between us and

60
00:03:23.613 --> 00:03:29.010
other networks that are out there, it's
actually handling quite a bit of traffic.

61
00:03:29.010 --> 00:03:30.101
So can you do it?

62
00:03:30.101 --> 00:03:33.160
Yes, okay, theoretically, you can do it.

63
00:03:33.160 --> 00:03:35.141
Now once we've turned the service on,

64
00:03:35.141 --> 00:03:37.732
it doesn't mean that it's
fully configured yet.

65
00:03:37.732 --> 00:03:41.761
I now need to make this
the primary DNS server for

66
00:03:41.761 --> 00:03:44.800
my network if I'm going to do this.

67
00:03:44.800 --> 00:03:48.045
So the way that that works is IP DNS.

68
00:03:48.045 --> 00:03:50.098
And then I'm going to
do a question mark so

69
00:03:50.098 --> 00:03:53.640
that we can see what other
options we have available, okay?

70
00:03:53.640 --> 00:03:58.423
So the first one that we are going to do,
okay, or the second command, right?

71
00:03:58.423 --> 00:04:02.078
We already enabled the DNS
server by doing, ip dns server,

72
00:04:02.078 --> 00:04:05.010
which is the one that
we see right up here.

73
00:04:05.010 --> 00:04:11.984
And now, we're going to configure
the primary DNS server for

74
00:04:11.984 --> 00:04:18.433
our router here, ip dns primary,
and now when I do this?

75
00:04:18.433 --> 00:04:22.420
Well, what am I actually, what is
this going to be a primary for, okay?

76
00:04:22.420 --> 00:04:27.305
Well, this is actually going to be the,
what we call the, why can't I remember it?

77
00:04:27.305 --> 00:04:32.830
Startup authority, sheesh, the names of
stuff that I can't remember here, okay?

78
00:04:32.830 --> 00:04:38.295
So primary, this is going to be for

79
00:04:38.295 --> 00:04:43.387
practice-labs.com, okay?

80
00:04:43.387 --> 00:04:49.030
Now, we're going to create a record here
by doing soa, for start of authority.

81
00:04:49.030 --> 00:04:52.224
Which means it's going to be
responsible for this entire zone here.

82
00:04:52.224 --> 00:04:56.380
And then, we're going to tell it
the server to look it up to, okay?

83
00:04:56.380 --> 00:05:02.155
And I think this one they've actually
just made up as a name here,

84
00:05:02.155 --> 00:05:08.678
ns1-practice-labs, here if I
spelt practice right, .com, okay?

85
00:05:08.678 --> 00:05:13.342
So our start of authority is ns1,
whatever that may be here,

86
00:05:13.342 --> 00:05:17.480
but it is actually going to be for
this entire network.

87
00:05:18.570 --> 00:05:22.710
All right, so now,
it says I have something else, I forgot,

88
00:05:22.710 --> 00:05:25.752
I need another server up here,
so that was my fault.

89
00:05:25.752 --> 00:05:28.480
There's one more that they
also added in here at the end.

90
00:05:28.480 --> 00:05:33.648
Which that's what I get for my notes
not looking down at the next line here.

91
00:05:33.648 --> 00:05:37.661
There's also another server out there, so

92
00:05:37.661 --> 00:05:43.532
the secondary server,
which is mb1-practice-labs.com.

93
00:05:43.532 --> 00:05:47.365
So it requires two as we see it.

94
00:05:47.365 --> 00:05:50.821
Now, this is something we haven't seen yet
before, Zach, so this is a good place for

95
00:05:50.821 --> 00:05:52.075
me to point this out.
>> Okay.

96
00:05:52.075 --> 00:05:53.575
>> Notice the prompt has

97
00:05:53.575 --> 00:05:58.081
changed just a little bit when we
started to do this here, okay?

98
00:05:58.081 --> 00:05:58.730
>> Yeah.

99
00:05:58.730 --> 00:06:00.600
>> Now you don't see it because of the way

100
00:06:00.600 --> 00:06:04.536
that this box down at the bottom, where
it says type command for NYEDGE1 here.

101
00:06:04.536 --> 00:06:08.260
You don't see it, but if we were
typing directly into that router.

102
00:06:08.260 --> 00:06:12.266
Once it gets to the length that
it can show on the screen,

103
00:06:12.266 --> 00:06:18.006
what it does is it changes and adds in
this character right after the pound sign.

104
00:06:18.006 --> 00:06:18.847
The reason for

105
00:06:18.847 --> 00:06:24.030
that is it's telling you that the line is
too long to be displayed on the screen.

106
00:06:24.030 --> 00:06:28.124
So it is passing
the beginning of the line,

107
00:06:28.124 --> 00:06:32.463
essentially behind
the prompt that you see.

108
00:06:32.463 --> 00:06:35.301
So notice how it actually
looks like ce-labs, but

109
00:06:35.301 --> 00:06:37.220
it really is all the way to the end.

110
00:06:37.220 --> 00:06:41.277
And if I had access to that before I hit
Enter, I could actually use my right and

111
00:06:41.277 --> 00:06:44.471
left arrows to scroll all the way
back to the beginning line.

112
00:06:44.471 --> 00:06:47.533
And then use the right arrow to
scroll all the way over to the end of

113
00:06:47.533 --> 00:06:48.810
the line as well.

114
00:06:48.810 --> 00:06:53.598
So when you see something like that,
okay, it's not because it's wrong, but

115
00:06:53.598 --> 00:06:57.043
it's just because the line
was too long to be displayed.

116
00:06:57.043 --> 00:06:59.883
So that's something else that
you do end up seeing, so

117
00:06:59.883 --> 00:07:02.677
it's something that we haven't seen yet
in our lab.

118
00:07:02.677 --> 00:07:05.660
So I wanted to make sure that
we pointed that out, too, okay.

119
00:07:05.660 --> 00:07:09.102
So now that I've got that in there,
we now have created,

120
00:07:09.102 --> 00:07:13.565
at least at the beginning here,
the configuration that we need, right?

121
00:07:13.565 --> 00:07:17.195
We've turned on the service,

00:07:17.195 --> 00:07:21.520

123
00:07:21.520 --> 00:07:25.293
And at this point,

124
00:07:25.293 --> 00:07:28.519
Now, because of the way that

125
00:07:28.519 --> 00:07:32.240
it's not set up to do a lot

126
00:07:32.240 --> 00:07:35.358
We also have to set up,
essentially, the host table, okay?

127
00:07:35.358 --> 00:07:39.030
Which is what it looks up as
a primary database to help us.

128
00:07:39.030 --> 00:07:43.242
So the way that this works is,
ip host, and

129
00:07:43.242 --> 00:07:49.562
then we're going to actually just
use some generic terms here,

130
00:07:49.562 --> 00:07:54.144
ciscoserver 192.168.16.10.

131
00:07:54.144 --> 00:07:57.713
Now in all reality right now, that 16.10,

132
00:07:57.713 --> 00:08:03.557
that is actually the IP to This machine
that we we're working with for testing.

133
00:08:03.557 --> 00:08:06.260
But I can set up any name I want to.

134
00:08:06.260 --> 00:08:11.020
If I ping that name, in theory,
this is the address it will go to, and

135
00:08:11.020 --> 00:08:13.020
it will respond for that.

136
00:08:13.020 --> 00:08:15.530
So it can actually allow us to do that.

137
00:08:15.530 --> 00:08:19.550
Now, normally, this is by far one of
the most important records that we have.

138
00:08:19.550 --> 00:08:24.600
It's usually the only one in the list of
databases records that we've talked about,

139
00:08:24.600 --> 00:08:26.100
right here, okay?

140
00:08:26.100 --> 00:08:28.300
So in this type of list here,

141
00:08:28.300 --> 00:08:32.515
it's the only one that matches
up to a name to the IP address.

142
00:08:32.515 --> 00:08:35.834
The rest of them will tell you
what the name of it is, right?

143
00:08:35.834 --> 00:08:41.302
And even a CNAME is just an alias that
links up to the A record as well, okay?

144
00:08:41.302 --> 00:08:44.437
And NS,
it actually tells you the name of that.

145
00:08:44.437 --> 00:08:48.072
But it all ends up looking up
to this A record at some point.

146
00:08:48.072 --> 00:08:53.035
Or if you're actually looking at IPv6,
they call it a quad A-record, okay?

147
00:08:53.035 --> 00:08:57.901
So that is by far the most important
record that we can actually set up,

148
00:08:57.901 --> 00:08:59.560
is right there, okay?

149
00:08:59.560 --> 00:09:07.899
We're gonna do one more
name here as an example.

150
00:09:07.899 --> 00:09:13.347
So ip host, and
then ns1_practice-labs.com,

151
00:09:13.347 --> 00:09:16.577
192.168.16.1.

152
00:09:18.078 --> 00:09:21.709
Okay, now in this one, right,

153
00:09:21.709 --> 00:09:26.965
practicens1practise-labs.com, okay?

154
00:09:26.965 --> 00:09:32.006
The 16.1 is actually to
this router itself, okay?

155
00:09:32.006 --> 00:09:37.820
So this router,
its IP address is 192.168.16.1.

156
00:09:37.820 --> 00:09:42.298
So right here, when we set up
the primary DNS, practice-labs.com, and

157
00:09:42.298 --> 00:09:46.710
we pointed the start of authority
to being essentially itself, right?

158
00:09:46.710 --> 00:09:49.370
Didn't need to do that,
whatever I did there.

159
00:09:49.370 --> 00:09:54.580
So it's pointing to itself, it's gonna
look up in it's own host table here, and

160
00:09:54.580 --> 00:09:58.070
it's gonna say, all right,
that 16.1, which is me.

161
00:09:58.070 --> 00:10:02.460
So it has the ability to look in this
host table and answer record, or

162
00:10:02.460 --> 00:10:06.350
answer a query request,
that we have for us, okay?

163
00:10:06.350 --> 00:10:10.090
So when we do that, right,
then it's pretty much done.

164
00:10:10.090 --> 00:10:14.570
Now, this is our DNS server, and it should
work like a DNS server for our network,

165
00:10:14.570 --> 00:10:19.580
where I can now go to the other machine,
the practice lab's workstation

166
00:10:19.580 --> 00:10:25.110
that we have, and point it to this guy,
and it should work as our DNS server.

167
00:10:25.110 --> 00:10:29.700
Now, let me talk about, traditionally,
the way that we normally use DNS

168
00:10:29.700 --> 00:10:35.070
on our router instead, Zach, cuz that's
actually probably a lot more common, okay?

169
00:10:35.070 --> 00:10:43.500
So on a router, if we just had
actually left off IP DNS server, okay?

170
00:10:43.500 --> 00:10:48.250
And as well as the IP DNS Primary,
and the rest of that stuff,

171
00:10:48.250 --> 00:10:53.780
we could still enter in this, and

172
00:10:53.780 --> 00:10:59.220
this, and create the host table
that I was talking about.

173
00:10:59.220 --> 00:11:05.460
This will allow me from router or
NYEDGE here, NYEDGE1, to be able

174
00:11:05.460 --> 00:11:10.145
to do something like ping Cisco server,
and it would look it up here, okay?

175
00:11:10.145 --> 00:11:14.150
And I can ping ns1.practicelabs.com,
and in theory,

176
00:11:14.150 --> 00:11:17.120
it would actually look it up here,
and do the same thing, okay?

177
00:11:17.120 --> 00:11:19.600
So I can actually do both of them.

178
00:11:19.600 --> 00:11:23.580
But when I do the IP DNS server,
and then the primary,

179
00:11:23.580 --> 00:11:27.310
I'm setting this up to be
the primary DNA server.

180
00:11:27.310 --> 00:11:29.490
And once I do that, right,
it will handle it on,

181
00:11:29.490 --> 00:11:33.750
and it should be able to distribute that
out, and other machines can use this, too.

182
00:11:33.750 --> 00:11:38.750
Now, I don't know, because I haven't
run this one before on this lab here,

183
00:11:38.750 --> 00:11:42.880
but I wanna see if I can check out
the CPU utilization just briefly.

184
00:11:42.880 --> 00:11:47.213
So this is just me adding in a step that's
not gonna be in your practice lab steps

185
00:11:47.213 --> 00:11:48.010
here, okay?

186
00:11:48.010 --> 00:11:53.607
So if I do a show processes cpu, okay?

187
00:11:53.607 --> 00:11:58.380
So I wanna see if this particular
utilization is hot, okay?

188
00:11:58.380 --> 00:11:59.370
But it's not so far.

189
00:11:59.370 --> 00:12:03.590
So I can see that right now,

other devices by name from that router.

00:25:27.670 --> 00:25:32.320
And that's just setting up the IP host and
then the name and the IP address.

415
00:25:32.320 --> 00:25:36.050
And that gives you that ability on
that router and not for anything else.

416
00:25:36.050 --> 00:25:38.310
And you do that for
all the other routers, too.

417
00:25:38.310 --> 00:25:41.570
That way, you don't have to go,
what was the IP address to router two?

418
00:25:41.570 --> 00:25:43.210
I don't remember.

419
00:25:43.210 --> 00:25:46.450
All you have to do is type in ping
router two, and then you're off and

420
00:25:46.450 --> 00:25:47.770
ready to go, okay?

421
00:25:47.770 --> 00:25:50.250
So, Zach,
that's actually our demonstration and

422
00:25:50.250 --> 00:25:53.530
our idea here of understanding
DNS configuration for

423
00:25:53.530 --> 00:25:54.890
a router.
>> Describe and

424
00:25:54.890 --> 00:25:56.680
configure DNS on a router Part Two.

425
00:25:56.680 --> 00:26:00.420
Make sure you see Part One, and Ronnie
has something else he'd like to say.

426
00:26:00.420 --> 00:26:01.970
>> All right, once again,

427
00:26:01.970 --> 00:26:05.240
don't forget practice is the key here.

428
00:26:05.240 --> 00:26:11.050
This one is, again, a little bit of
a shorter lab demonstration for us.

429
00:26:11.050 --> 00:26:14.010
But at the same time,
it's still valuable information.

430
00:26:14.010 --> 00:26:15.840
Make sure you do learn about it.

431
00:26:15.840 --> 00:26:17.862
If you're already comfortable
with the idea of DNS,

432
00:26:17.862 --> 00:26:22.000
you can kind of move on from here and
not worry too much.

433
00:26:22.000 --> 00:26:26.390
But at the same time this may be easy
points for you, so review the concepts and

434
00:26:26.390 --> 00:26:29.010
make sure you get them down.
>> Great advice and Ronnie has done

435
00:26:29.010 --> 00:26:33.840
a great job with Cisco CCENT the entire
series, make sure you see every episode.

436
00:26:33.840 --> 00:26:37.310
And you will be in the course library
where there will be other videos that

437
00:26:37.310 --> 00:26:40.350
are available for
you to help you go further.

438
00:26:40.350 --> 00:26:42.345
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

439
00:26:42.345 --> 00:26:44.510
ITProTV is binge worthy.

440
00:26:44.510 --> 00:26:46.610
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

441
00:26:46.610 --> 00:26:49.073
>> And we'll see you again soon.

442
00:26:49.073 --> 00:26:55.105
[MUSIC]

443
00:26:55.105 --> 00:26:58.249
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe the use of DHCP server as the replacement for static configurations.  Though, according to the team, a mix of static and dynamic configuration are important, they emphasize the use of DHCP as a service.  The guys discuss the process for DHCP and options that can be configured for DHCP clients.
episodes.title: Configure DHCP on a Router
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:03.050
Welcome to IT ProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.050 --> 00:00:05.994
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,
California-

3
00:00:05.994 --> 00:00:07.042
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.042 --> 00:00:08.333
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.333 --> 00:00:12.170
>> You're watching IT ProTV.

6
00:00:12.170 --> 00:00:14.528
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

7
00:00:14.528 --> 00:00:17.280
empowering the world
with engaging learning.

8
00:00:17.280 --> 00:00:20.360
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with Cisco CCENT.

9
00:00:20.360 --> 00:00:24.640
We're gonna configure DHCP on a router.

10
00:00:24.640 --> 00:00:27.215
Yes, we are, and
Ronnie Wong is the man to do it.

11
00:00:27.215 --> 00:00:28.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ronnie, good to see you again.

12
00:00:28.810 --> 00:00:32.880
>> Thank you, Zach, for helping us as we
continue on our CCENT journey together.

13
00:00:32.880 --> 00:00:33.890
We are now, of course,

14
00:00:33.890 --> 00:00:38.150
in the realm of taking a look at
infrastructure services, as well.

15
00:00:38.150 --> 00:00:42.330
Which now means, of course, learning
about some of the different servers.

16
00:00:42.330 --> 00:00:44.770
That you would also find in networking.

17
00:00:44.770 --> 00:00:47.820
And we're starting to see something that
we might not have guessed before where

18
00:00:48.850 --> 00:00:52.180
Cisco routers can actually do
a lot more than just routing, but

19
00:00:52.180 --> 00:00:56.640
it doesn't necessarily mean their always
the best thing to do for other things.

20
00:00:56.640 --> 00:00:58.330
We saw in a previous episode.

21
00:00:58.330 --> 00:01:03.965
Where we could turn the Cisco router
to configure it to become a DNS server,

22
00:01:03.965 --> 00:01:05.410
[INAUDIBLE] say DHCP.

23
00:01:05.410 --> 00:01:10.117
But it can do that too, so that's why
we're talking about this, okay, so

24
00:01:10.117 --> 00:01:14.376
we can actually run DNS as a service
on a network, using the router,

25
00:01:14.376 --> 00:01:18.229
we can also then turn around and
run what we call DHCP, okay.

26
00:01:18.229 --> 00:01:24.540
DHCP stands for Dynamic Host
Configuration Protocol server.

27
00:01:24.540 --> 00:01:26.460
Now, when we think about that, right,

28
00:01:26.460 --> 00:01:29.970
as we break that terminology
down a little bit here.

29
00:01:29.970 --> 00:01:33.510
Let me go ahead and
do that right up here, okay?

30
00:01:33.510 --> 00:01:37.100
So, on my screen I will talk
about it word by word here,

31
00:01:37.100 --> 00:01:39.690
so that we get this down by now.

32
00:01:39.690 --> 00:01:43.995
Host configuration protocol.

33
00:01:43.995 --> 00:01:47.520
All right, so much for

34
00:01:47.520 --> 00:01:51.770
my ability to kind of be
consistent at my typing here.

35
00:01:51.770 --> 00:01:53.154
DHCP.
>> I think you are good,

36
00:01:53.154 --> 00:01:54.787
just to be honest with you [LAUGH].

37
00:01:54.787 --> 00:01:55.706
>> Yeah.

38
00:01:55.706 --> 00:01:57.560
DHCP, okay.

39
00:01:57.560 --> 00:01:59.846
So, when we start to break that down,
okay,

40
00:01:59.846 --> 00:02:02.745
let's talk about this idea
of dynamic at the beginning.

41
00:02:02.745 --> 00:02:06.549
Well, for us, every host machine
that you and I are on, a device

42
00:02:06.549 --> 00:02:11.414
that's represented in our network usually
a host means an IP address as well, but

43
00:02:11.414 --> 00:02:14.640
the very fact is it's
a device on our network.

44
00:02:14.640 --> 00:02:18.325
Well, when we talk about
a dynamic configuration for that.

45
00:02:18.325 --> 00:02:19.135
We're saying that you and

46
00:02:19.135 --> 00:02:24.905
I don't have to mainly touch that
machine to get some configuration on it.

47
00:02:24.905 --> 00:02:26.575
>> Right.
>> So, it means it's dynamic,

48
00:02:26.575 --> 00:02:27.905
which means it's automatic.

49
00:02:27.905 --> 00:02:33.015
It will take individual host and
provide a configuration for it.

50
00:02:33.015 --> 00:02:37.220
Now, the key here, though, is what
type of configuration is it providing?

51
00:02:37.220 --> 00:02:40.540
Is gonna provide what normally at
least for what we need, right?

52
00:02:40.540 --> 00:02:45.995
A uniform configuration across
multiple devices that we need, okay?

53
00:02:45.995 --> 00:02:46.850
>> Uh-huh.
>> So, you and

54
00:02:46.850 --> 00:02:49.920
I don't have to manage whether,
or not it's done.

55
00:02:49.920 --> 00:02:55.440
It normally will do it as long as not
only do we have server to provide that,

56
00:02:55.440 --> 00:02:59.550
but we also have, of course,
clients then ready to listen, and

57
00:02:59.550 --> 00:03:01.660
ready to do that as well, okay?

58
00:03:01.660 --> 00:03:05.830
So, we're gonna talk about in a couple of
different instances here at the beginning,

59
00:03:05.830 --> 00:03:09.470
so that we understand the nature of DHCP,
okay?

60
00:03:09.470 --> 00:03:14.690
So, in DHCP, what normally ends
up happening is this, okay?

61
00:03:14.690 --> 00:03:19.970
A computer,
such as PC1@ITPro.TV when we first plug

62
00:03:19.970 --> 00:03:25.870
that in to a network cable, if we leave it
at its default, if it's a Windows machine

63
00:03:25.870 --> 00:03:30.870
it is actually going to send out
a message out onto the network.

64
00:03:30.870 --> 00:03:36.500
And that initial message is simple,
it's called a DHCP discover packet, okay.

65
00:03:36.500 --> 00:03:38.670
That DHCP discover packet.

66
00:03:38.670 --> 00:03:42.415
It is broadcast out to the entire network.

67
00:03:42.415 --> 00:03:43.040
>> Mm-hm.

68
00:03:43.040 --> 00:03:47.310
>> Now, the DNS server doesn't care,
so it's gonna drop that packet.

69
00:03:47.310 --> 00:03:51.850
But a DHCP server says,
hey, I just heard that, and

70
00:03:51.850 --> 00:03:56.400
somebody is asking for,
well, DHCP information.

71
00:03:56.400 --> 00:03:59.700
And normally, the information that it's
really asking for at the beginning.

72
00:03:59.700 --> 00:04:04.130
Is an IP address, a subnet mask,
and a default gateway.

73
00:04:04.130 --> 00:04:08.620
It can also ask for other things too,
like an DNS Server if we want to.

74
00:04:08.620 --> 00:04:10.450
And we can even configure it for

75
00:04:10.450 --> 00:04:16.760
additional information that we can pass
out to whoever is asking for it, okay?

76
00:04:16.760 --> 00:04:21.550
So, when we do that,
the DHCP server, okay?

77
00:04:21.550 --> 00:04:25.510
It will go ahead and figure that out,
that it's heard this message, and

78
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:29.860
it will send out what is
called a DHCP Offer, okay?

79
00:04:29.860 --> 00:04:35.410
Now, that DHCP Offer essentially has the
basic information that I told you about,

80
00:04:35.410 --> 00:04:38.450
and it communicates it back,
but it does it in a broadcast.

81
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:42.430
So, everything at this point
is a complete broadcast.

82
00:04:42.430 --> 00:04:46.460
Now, once we have that broadcast,
this guy goes, I don't need that, okay?

83
00:04:46.460 --> 00:04:47.760
So, it drops it.

84
00:04:47.760 --> 00:04:53.760
But PC1 says, hey, I need that offer,
and it will take that information and

85
00:04:53.760 --> 00:04:57.800
automatically configure that
information back to us, okay?

86
00:04:57.800 --> 00:05:00.570
Now, once it does that and it takes it,

87
00:05:00.570 --> 00:05:06.200
it will send back as a broadcast again,
a DHCP request.

88
00:05:06.200 --> 00:05:10.660
Now, it's kind of weird that a request
would come after an offer, but

89
00:05:10.660 --> 00:05:15.400
the idea of the request at this
point is to tell the DHCP server,

90
00:05:15.400 --> 00:05:19.030
please don't assign this
information to anybody else.

91
00:05:19.030 --> 00:05:23.930
So, I have now a unique address that
will work in this network, so please,

92
00:05:23.930 --> 00:05:27.440
don't assign my IP address
to anybody else, okay?

93
00:05:27.440 --> 00:05:29.430
Now, when all that's done, right?

94
00:05:29.430 --> 00:05:34.080
During that offer, as well,
it will normally have a time limit on it.

95
00:05:34.080 --> 00:05:36.860
So, by default, like with Windows servers,

96
00:05:36.860 --> 00:05:40.410
DHCP servers,
it's usually an eight day default, okay?

97
00:05:40.410 --> 00:05:43.610
So, it's a, here's the information for
eight days, you can lease.

98
00:05:43.610 --> 00:05:47.090
This IP address, and
this information for eight days here.

99
00:05:47.090 --> 00:05:50.940
And now the DHC, or the PC says,
yes, let me go ahead and do that.

100
00:05:50.940 --> 00:05:56.458
And it will make an entry in its own
database there, of those IP addresses.

101
00:05:56.458 --> 00:06:00.810
And then, sends back a final
acknowledgment that I've got you down, or

102
00:06:00.810 --> 00:06:02.490
that eight day lease.

103
00:06:02.490 --> 00:06:05.510
PC one will now begin to accept it.

104
00:06:05.510 --> 00:06:07.690
And work it and
do whatever else it needs to.

105
00:06:07.690 --> 00:06:08.310
Okay?

106
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:12.350
Now, all that is actually set up
when we start to do this right away.

107
00:06:12.350 --> 00:06:12.950
Okay?

108
00:06:12.950 --> 00:06:16.890
So, the key here is to understand
that the process is done.

109
00:06:16.890 --> 00:06:19.720
There's a neat little acronym
that's actually created here.

110
00:06:19.720 --> 00:06:20.450
Okay?

111
00:06:20.450 --> 00:06:24.765
To remember the process of DHCP,
you just have to remember, DORA.

112
00:06:24.765 --> 00:06:28.870
D-O-R-A.

113
00:06:28.870 --> 00:06:29.410
Okay?

114
00:06:29.410 --> 00:06:32.890
So, that will help you to remember
that process that it doesn't.

115
00:06:32.890 --> 00:06:35.690
All of these at this point
is done in a broadcast.

116
00:06:35.690 --> 00:06:39.489
When you actually start
seeing this information.

117
00:06:39.489 --> 00:06:43.570
Now, initially, okay, when you start
doing this it works very well.

118
00:06:43.570 --> 00:06:46.810
Okay, so that means all you and
I have to do, if we were responsible for

119
00:06:48.320 --> 00:06:52.630
setting up 50 workstations, and
we had everything ready to go.

120
00:06:52.630 --> 00:06:56.720
We just plug it into the network,
if my DHCP server's configured,

121
00:06:56.720 --> 00:07:01.690
I don't have to walk around and
assign IP addresses, Subnet mask, default

122
00:07:01.690 --> 00:07:06.290
gateways to every individual machine, DNS
Servers, it will do it all for us, okay?

123
00:07:06.290 --> 00:07:09.120
So, let's take a look at
that just briefly here.

124
00:07:09.120 --> 00:07:11.250
And I'll go all the way
over to our machine.

125
00:07:11.250 --> 00:07:12.830
Which is now not connected anymore.

126
00:07:12.830 --> 00:07:15.580
Let me see if I can
actually make it connect.

127
00:07:15.580 --> 00:07:20.190
There we go, so we are now connecting
back to that machine for a moment.

128
00:07:20.190 --> 00:07:22.680
Let me minimize this if I can.

129
00:07:22.680 --> 00:07:29.280
And then, if I can I will zoom in here
to help us out just a little bit.

130
00:07:29.280 --> 00:07:33.300
Apparently I have to actually zoom
out again, so I can get to that menu,

131
00:07:33.300 --> 00:07:35.250
that taskbar down at the bottom.

132
00:07:35.250 --> 00:07:39.180
So, I'm gonna right click on the network
adapter and go to open network and

133
00:07:39.180 --> 00:07:40.210
sharing center.

134
00:07:40.210 --> 00:07:43.170
I know that's a little bit small,
but I'm gonna zoom in now.

135
00:07:43.170 --> 00:07:44.110
So, that we can see it.

136
00:07:45.340 --> 00:07:50.124
Then on the Lab_Nic, I'm not gonna
touch the one that says do not change.

137
00:07:52.502 --> 00:07:59.192
Then I'm gonna select Properties here,
and it's right here, okay?

138
00:07:59.192 --> 00:08:02.510
Under Internet Protocol Version 4.

139
00:08:02.510 --> 00:08:04.553
On the Microsoft world.

140
00:08:04.553 --> 00:08:07.784
Even though they don't call
it DHCP on the client side,

141
00:08:07.784 --> 00:08:11.730
this machine is ready to accept
that type of connection.

142
00:08:11.730 --> 00:08:15.250
They call it obtaining an IP
address automatically.

143
00:08:15.250 --> 00:08:17.800
So if I set it this way and

144
00:08:17.800 --> 00:08:22.820
I obtain an IP address automatically, and
then the second option will also appear.

145
00:08:22.820 --> 00:08:26.840
So I if do this notice all
the information disappears from here and

146
00:08:26.840 --> 00:08:29.590
then if I do this,
it also disappears from here.

147
00:08:29.590 --> 00:08:36.260
That's because it is now ready to make
a DHCP discover message that's put

148
00:08:36.260 --> 00:08:41.780
out into the wire to get an IP address to
come back and do what we need to do, okay?

149
00:08:41.780 --> 00:08:43.190
So all that is possible.

150
00:08:43.190 --> 00:08:46.810
So this side is what initiates
that discover message and

151
00:08:46.810 --> 00:08:50.480
enters the DHCP server,
it is now responding and

152
00:08:50.480 --> 00:08:53.770
doing everything but I'd have to hit
OK first, we're not gonna do that yet.

153
00:08:53.770 --> 00:08:57.090
So at this point,
that's what happens over here.

154
00:08:57.090 --> 00:08:57.940
The issue that you and

155
00:08:57.940 --> 00:09:03.440
I have right now is that we don't
have a DHCP server set up, okay?

156
00:09:03.440 --> 00:09:08.490
So when something like that ends up
happening then, this machine itself will

157
00:09:08.490 --> 00:09:16.010
end up getting an IP address that begins
with 169.254.whatever.whatever, okay?

158
00:09:16.010 --> 00:09:19.270
And that is called an APIPA address.

159
00:09:19.270 --> 00:09:22.880
Now if I click on that lab nick again,

160
00:09:22.880 --> 00:09:28.340
select Properties and Internet Protocol
version 4 and Properties again.

161
00:09:30.469 --> 00:09:34.320
There's something else that's strange,
so I'm not saving the changes here.

162
00:09:34.320 --> 00:09:37.930
But notice as soon as I hit Obtain
an IP Address Automatically,

163
00:09:37.930 --> 00:09:41.020
an Alternate Configuration tab came up,
okay?

164
00:09:42.160 --> 00:09:47.029
And that Alternate Configuration tab,
you'll see if I can zoom

165
00:09:47.029 --> 00:09:51.642
in here notice what it says,
Automatic private IP address.

166
00:09:51.642 --> 00:09:57.016
A-P-I-P-A, APIPA, so
that's what it actually end up doing,

167
00:09:57.016 --> 00:10:02.204
and that begins with 169.254
which means that even though

168
00:10:02.204 --> 00:10:07.219
this client which is what this
is cuz it's not a server itself.

169
00:10:07.219 --> 00:10:10.425
It is saying, I need an IP
address from a DHCP server and

170
00:10:10.425 --> 00:10:15.010
the information that comes along with it,
well, I'm not finding one.

171
00:10:15.010 --> 00:10:19.872
So it will automatically
assign itself its own private

172
00:10:19.872 --> 00:10:24.530
IP address in that range, 169.254, okay?

173
00:10:24.530 --> 00:10:27.650
And that's what it will
allow you to be able to do.

174
00:10:27.650 --> 00:10:31.120
Now even though technically that means all
the machines that don't get an answer from

175
00:10:31.120 --> 00:10:35.340
a DHCP server, they'll still be networked
together inside of that network,

176
00:10:35.340 --> 00:10:39.080
but it's not useful for
anything in today's world, okay?

177
00:10:39.080 --> 00:10:43.095
So the only thing that we actually do with
it is if we see that address beginning

178
00:10:43.095 --> 00:10:44.520
with 169.254,

179
00:10:44.520 --> 00:10:49.370
the APIPA address, it normally means we
need to check one of two things, okay?

180
00:10:49.370 --> 00:10:53.160
I need to check whether or
not my machine is configured or

181
00:10:53.160 --> 00:10:56.630
what I needed to do which is,
of course, to listen for DHCP or

182
00:10:56.630 --> 00:10:59.820
two is there something
wrong with the DHCP server?

183
00:10:59.820 --> 00:11:03.030
And that's usually the two that
we have to be able to do, okay?

184
00:11:03.030 --> 00:11:07.000
So that's kind of the beginning point
of what we're talking about in getting

185
00:11:07.000 --> 00:11:08.090
set up here.

186
00:11:08.090 --> 00:11:11.070
So now that you understand that there
is something that needs to be set up on

187
00:11:11.070 --> 00:11:12.190
both ends.

188
00:11:12.190 --> 00:11:17.220
One side has to be willing to be
turned on and start the DHTP process.

189
00:11:17.220 --> 00:11:22.610
The other side has to be answering
the DHTP process that started as well.

190
00:11:22.610 --> 00:11:26.170
So that is what we are actually
going to take a look at as well.

191
00:11:26.170 --> 00:11:29.030
Now, we're also gonna end up
doing something else too.

192
00:11:29.030 --> 00:11:34.060
We're gonna talk about another procedure
that's gonna work with that process but

The other thing that you may find out,

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue to configure DHCP clients and even an DHCP relay.  The discuss the way to configure a router interface as a DHCP client for an IP address on its interface.  Also they configure how to use DHCP on a different broadcast domain.
episodes.title: Configure DHCP on a Router Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie talk about synchronizing router clocks. They show how to manually configure a router's clock.  Even so, the team also shows that this doesn't make it synchronize for accuracy as much as to demonstrate how it can be controlled.
episodes.title: Configure and Verify NTP

1

>> We are, of course,

taking a look at the topic
of infrastructure services

15

that we're dealing with.

And today we're gonna be configuring and

which is the network time protocol.

18

And this particular element of what

And it becomes even more important as

The reason why,
especially on Cisco devices,

As you put them into their particular

be that even from the factory, right?

25

The time was set a little bit differently.

26
00:01:16.630 --> 00:01:18.420
Now, when I talk about
a little bit differently,

Zach, it may not even be a whole second,

It may even just be off, let's say,

a thousandths of a second, okay, maybe
two or three thousandths of a second.

30
00:01:29.498 --> 00:01:32.580
Some of them may be off by even

31

And it doesn't sound like much,

32

in their productivity as they're

33

That time can continue to actually start

34

slippage or something like that,

35

And the nature and
the problem with something like that,

36
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:54.750
is when it comes down to
auditing of some sort.

And actually trying to put a timestamp

38

Well, now that those

41

So by themselves,
if left to their own devices,

42

whatever their time slippage is
as they continue to function,

43
00:02:17.690 --> 00:02:21.360
it'll probably begin to happen more,
and more, and more over time.

44

So that is a problem,

45
00:02:22.750 --> 00:02:26.640
especially because the very fact is
in today's networks, we wanna keep

46
00:02:26.640 --> 00:02:30.110
a consistent time with those devices.
>> So

47

that we're not actually off when we go and

Which one's accurate then, okay?

49

Is it the one that's off
by a hundredth of a second?

50
00:02:37.652 --> 00:02:41.070
Is it one that's off by a thousandth
of a second, but compared to what?

51
00:02:41.070 --> 00:02:43.680
Okay, that's what we need to know about,
you know?

52
00:02:43.680 --> 00:02:47.210
Normally, as long as they're all
consistent, we don't really care that much

53
00:02:47.210 --> 00:02:50.380
in terms of the hundredth or
the thousandths of a second.

54
00:02:50.380 --> 00:02:53.100
But it does begin to add up,
like I said, over time and

55
00:02:53.100 --> 00:02:54.940
that's where the problem comes in.

56

So it is actually a very important
part of our networking of what we do

57

58

So it is key for what we talked about,

60

Well, is it actually

64

It's possible,
in my extreme case, probably not.

65

But let's just kind of go with it, right.

66
00:03:28.760 --> 00:03:30.950
Is it actually referring
to the same event, or

67

68
00:03:33.080 --> 00:03:37.020
Well you and I would never really know if

69

So in that sense, that's when we
actually start to have to try and

figure out what we can do.

So the overall goal of course then,

our time across all of our Cisco devices.
>> So this might be a little bit

rhetorical but you can time sync

00:03:54.300 --> 00:03:55.710
And that's what we're
going into right now.

75
00:03:55.710 --> 00:03:56.320
>> That is true,

76

and that's what our goal is.

77

Right, is to make sure that
we understand first of all,

78

how these clocks work just a little bit,
okay?

79
00:04:03.700 --> 00:04:07.215
And then we wanna show you how
you configure them to actually

80

work together as well.

81
00:04:08.630 --> 00:04:13.192
So, in our set up for us creating
what we call of course, not creating,

82
00:04:13.192 --> 00:04:18.770
building up to the fact that we're gonna
be issuing NTP network time protocol.

83
00:04:18.770 --> 00:04:20.924
Actually makes us less responsible for
it and

84
00:04:20.924 --> 00:04:23.142
allows machines to
become more responsible.

85
00:04:23.142 --> 00:04:25.626
And the reason why is that, you and I,

86
00:04:25.626 --> 00:04:30.060
we might be able to adjust it
to some point where it's close.

87
00:04:30.060 --> 00:04:34.173
But NTP, the network time protocol, can
adjust it to where it's actually off just

88
00:04:34.173 --> 00:04:36.720
within, like I said
a milliseconds a lot of times.

89
00:04:36.720 --> 00:04:41.360
And so that might be a better option for

90

So that is where we

91

So let's take a look here,

Now, I'm gonna use this router and

the one that says configuring and

Now, in this lab, they don't have us doing

Officially in the lab setting itself,
NY WAN is turned off and this is a default

configuration, there is nothing

So this one is just like you

99

and everything is up.

100

But I wanted to show us some of the basic
things that we have to understand as we

00:05:25.413 --> 00:05:28.868
start syncing up the time and
getting everything ready, okay?

102
00:05:28.868 --> 00:05:31.988
So I do wanna tell you something,
that there is a manual way for

103
00:05:31.988 --> 00:05:34.510
us to begin at least some synchronization.

104
00:05:34.510 --> 00:05:37.644
Okay, but at the same time as you
start adding in more and more devices,

105
00:05:37.644 --> 00:05:38.697
when you do that right?

You're gonna actually start seeing that
time skew, that time slippage that we're

talking about that becomes a little
bit harder to actually do here.

00:05:46.360 --> 00:05:50.840
So let's go ahead and at least show

109
00:05:50.840 --> 00:05:54.020
Now when we start to pull
up a Cisco router and

110

Let me go ahead and
get access into the privilege exec mode,

let me type in show clock here.

And right now let me zoom in so

that we can see that a little

You can see that it is actually set
in couple of different parts of

00:06:13.090 --> 00:06:14.760
what we're seeing as the output, right?

00:06:14.760 --> 00:06:20.133
Now notice that after
the show clock command,

I get an asterisk, and
then I get 17:26:41.939, right.

00:06:28.810 --> 00:06:33.480
That's a tenth of a second right there,

00:06:33.480 --> 00:06:37.450
This is thousandths of a second so

122
00:06:39.760 --> 00:06:42.721
What are the chances, Zach, if I manually
configure another one to try and

That I'm gonna be able to, now,

Probably, not exactly great.

>> Yeah, not exactly great, right?

But just to show you, right?

00:06:55.890 --> 00:06:59.400
So you're seeing that, we're gonna come

00:06:59.400 --> 00:07:02.770
But the other part is UTC, okay?

131
00:07:02.770 --> 00:07:08.430
Now, UTC, essentially, actually,
I shouldn't say essentially,

00:07:08.430 --> 00:07:14.020
technically right, it is actually what
is called coordinated universal time.

133
00:07:14.020 --> 00:07:15.108
Okay, now you might think,

134
00:07:15.108 --> 00:07:18.950
well shouldn't that be cut then,
coordinated universal time.

135
00:07:18.950 --> 00:07:22.870
Well a couple of things happened here,
that we ended up with UTC which is not

136
00:07:22.870 --> 00:07:25.000
gonna make much sense Zach, right?
>> Right.

137
00:07:25.000 --> 00:07:25.600
>> So

138
00:07:25.600 --> 00:07:28.970
let me explain this, you've probably
seen UTC everywhere in networking,

139
00:07:28.970 --> 00:07:30.820
it's just all over the place, okay.

140
00:07:30.820 --> 00:07:35.770
But the reason why we ended up with UTC
is that the English, the British, okay?

141
00:07:35.770 --> 00:07:42.508
They came up with the true name of it
called, Coordinated Universal Time, okay?

142
00:07:42.508 --> 00:07:45.901
Now on and
about same general time period, and

143
00:07:45.901 --> 00:07:49.124
this happens more often
then we realize it.

144
00:07:49.124 --> 00:07:56.180
Another nation also came up with
a way to designate this idea.

145
00:07:56.180 --> 00:07:56.970
But independently.

146
00:07:56.970 --> 00:08:00.102
So they weren't working on it but
they designated independently and

147
00:08:00.102 --> 00:08:01.470
it was France, okay?

148
00:08:01.470 --> 00:08:02.530
And France said,

149
00:08:02.530 --> 00:08:06.120
however the French say stuff like
this cuz I don't know exactly how.

150
00:08:06.120 --> 00:08:10.500
But their acronym turned out to to be TUC,
so

151
00:08:10.500 --> 00:08:16.160
I'm assuming something like time universal
coordinate, whatever it might be, okay?

152
00:08:16.160 --> 00:08:17.950
So they came up with that.

153
00:08:17.950 --> 00:08:22.900
Well, because of the very fact that they
could not actually agree to who actually

154
00:08:22.900 --> 00:08:30.870
should own or should claim provenance to
what this coordinated universal time is.

155
00:08:30.870 --> 00:08:34.170
They compromised and
said, we'll just do this.

156
00:08:34.170 --> 00:08:35.790
It won't be either one of us.

157
00:08:35.790 --> 00:08:38.560
So they actually decided on UTC.

158
00:08:38.560 --> 00:08:42.430
So instead of CUT or TUC, they said,

159
00:08:42.430 --> 00:08:44.840
let's just turn this whole thing around.
>> So UTC.

160
00:08:44.840 --> 00:08:45.870
>> UTC and

161
00:08:45.870 --> 00:08:47.170
there's not really an acronym for it.

162
00:08:47.170 --> 00:08:50.290
We all think that it actually stands for
universal time coordinate.

163
00:08:50.290 --> 00:08:51.310
>> Right, that's what I was gonna say.

164
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:52.120
>> But technically it's not.

165
00:08:52.120 --> 00:08:55.747
It's actually just the compromise
between those two organizations.

166
00:08:55.747 --> 00:08:56.966
So more trivial facts for

167
00:08:56.966 --> 00:08:59.649
people to not really care about.
>> That's

168
00:08:59.649 --> 00:09:00.690
cool.
>> But

169
00:09:00.690 --> 00:09:02.630
something that actually stuck
in my mind as well, okay?

170
00:09:02.630 --> 00:09:05.230
And then of course you
have the day of the week.

171
00:09:05.230 --> 00:09:11.060
And the month, the day and the four
digit year for what we see it, okay?

172
00:09:11.060 --> 00:09:13.400
Now, let's go back to this asterisk
right here at the beginning,

173
00:09:13.400 --> 00:09:16.260
because that's actually more
important than we think, okay?

174
00:09:16.260 --> 00:09:21.360
The asterisk is actually
not saying that it is

175
00:09:21.360 --> 00:09:25.480
exactly what the universal, this UTC is.

176
00:09:25.480 --> 00:09:27.800
Okay?
It's not really saying that saying, but

177
00:09:27.800 --> 00:09:30.430
Ronnie, it says UTC right there.

178
00:09:30.430 --> 00:09:35.450
What it's actually saying
with this asterisk though,

179
00:09:35.450 --> 00:09:39.291
is that,
it is saying that I am guessing and

180
00:09:39.291 --> 00:09:44.755
I alone am saying that this
is 172641939 UTC time.

181
00:09:44.755 --> 00:09:46.740
So that means that it hasn't
confirmed it with anybody.

182
00:09:46.740 --> 00:09:48.020
It hasn't actually done that.

183
00:09:48.020 --> 00:09:52.320
It is saying that according to what
I know right now from the factory,

184
00:09:52.320 --> 00:09:54.110
that this is what it should be.

185
00:09:54.110 --> 00:09:56.410
Universal coordinated time, okay?

186
00:09:56.410 --> 00:09:58.200
And it should be this.

187
00:09:58.200 --> 00:10:01.270
So that's what we have when we
start seeing something like that.

188
00:10:01.270 --> 00:10:05.060
So it's not authoritative and
it cannot be guaranteed that this is

189
00:10:05.060 --> 00:10:07.997
accurate at this point whenever
you see that asterisk, okay?

190
00:10:09.010 --> 00:10:11.400
So just because you see
that it shows you a clock,

191
00:10:11.400 --> 00:10:12.940
it doesn't mean that it's accurate.

192
00:10:12.940 --> 00:10:14.570
So what is this about?

193
00:10:14.570 --> 00:10:20.080
A router has two particular pieces of time
that it actually coordinates off of, okay?

194
00:10:20.080 --> 00:10:23.250
One is a hardware clock inside of it.

195
00:10:23.250 --> 00:10:27.420
Sometimes as you read the information
that you find on the internet about this,

196
00:10:27.420 --> 00:10:35.850
you actually end up learning that, you
read the term Calendar, instead of Clock.

197
00:10:35.850 --> 00:10:38.850
So, it just depends on
the age of the device itself.

198
00:10:38.850 --> 00:10:42.250
The viewers might be referring to
the Calendar Technically what they're

199
00:10:42.250 --> 00:10:46.130
referring is the hardware clock that
was built in at the Cisco factory

200
00:10:46.130 --> 00:10:49.660
when they designed it, okay,
and that keeps a track of time.

201
00:10:49.660 --> 00:10:51.060
Now why is that important?

202
00:10:51.060 --> 00:10:54.620
Because with that time itself and
the way that keeps track of it,

203
00:10:54.620 --> 00:10:58.510
there's a battery backup which
means that even between reboots,

204
00:10:58.510 --> 00:11:00.840
it keeps the time and actually does that.

205
00:11:00.840 --> 00:11:03.960
And the great thing is, we've seen this
happen, even in our own computers.

206
00:11:03.960 --> 00:11:06.990
When we shut down the computer, let's
say we shut down a computer for a week.

207
00:11:06.990 --> 00:11:09.020
Today that would be unheard of, of course.

208
00:11:09.020 --> 00:11:11.570
But when I first started,
shutting down a computer for

209
00:11:11.570 --> 00:11:12.860
a week was not exactly unheard of.

210
00:11:12.860 --> 00:11:16.119
Now not in a business setting but at home,
we used to shut down the computer and

211
00:11:16.119 --> 00:11:17.936
just turned it on when we needed it, okay?

212
00:11:17.936 --> 00:11:19.649
And then it would come back up and
the right time would be there and

213
00:11:19.649 --> 00:11:20.230
we'd be like, wow.

214
00:11:20.230 --> 00:11:21.070
That was pretty cool.

215
00:11:21.070 --> 00:11:24.320
It was off, Power off, and
it still is able to keep time.

At the time source, once again,

442
00:24:44.805 --> 00:24:45.383

a lot of understanding
that you have to have too.

So what we're gonna do though, and

what officially is called
out on the exam itself,

So once we get all that set up,

And then all of our devices will be

So Zach, we definitely need to do that and

So this would be great for another part,

wonderful episode and they're will be

this is one of the harder elements to

But you do need to at least understand

00:26:47.830 --> 00:26:48.440
you saw that.

You saw that process and
the way that it is and

Because right now we're getting
