episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with the clock synchronization by show how to setup an ntp server and ntp client. They describe the configure details that used to setup the router as an ntp master, and as an ntp client.  Lastly, they demonstrate how to verify it's use.
episodes.title: Configure and Verify NTP Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.432
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host, Don.

2
00:00:02.432 --> 00:00:06.115
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:06.115 --> 00:00:10.342
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.342 --> 00:00:13.399
>> Hello, thank you for watching ITProTV,

5
00:00:13.399 --> 00:00:16.026
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.026 --> 00:00:20.020
I'm Zach Memos, your host for
this episode, Cysco C set.

7
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:24.100
We're gonna configure and verify NTP part
two, part two, make sure you see part one.

8
00:00:24.100 --> 00:00:28.206
And the person that's bringing all
the information we need is the one and

9
00:00:28.206 --> 00:00:29.340
only Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:29.340 --> 00:00:32.008
Ronnie good to see you again sir.
>> Well, Zach thank you again for

11
00:00:32.008 --> 00:00:34.246
having me on the show as we
continue on in our part two

12
00:00:34.246 --> 00:00:34.881
here on NTP.
>> Right.

13
00:00:34.881 --> 00:00:36.845
>> Most of the time people are probably

14
00:00:36.845 --> 00:00:38.220
going, are you joking,

15
00:00:38.220 --> 00:00:39.983
it was just setting up a clock.
>> [LAUGH]

16
00:00:39.983 --> 00:00:41.188
>> What does it really matter

17
00:00:41.188 --> 00:00:42.780
that there's more than one part.

18
00:00:42.780 --> 00:00:45.462
And, well, its because we showed
you in the first part here, right.

19
00:00:45.462 --> 00:00:47.838
How to manually configure that clock so

20
00:00:47.838 --> 00:00:51.582
that we could get it at least
synced up between the hardware and

21
00:00:51.582 --> 00:00:53.500
the software clock.
>> Right.

22
00:00:53.500 --> 00:00:54.727
>> But, that's how you'd have to do that,

23
00:00:54.727 --> 00:00:55.473
if you wanted to, okay.

24
00:00:55.473 --> 00:01:00.550
But it doesn't mean that they
function together with other devices.

25
00:01:00.550 --> 00:01:03.896
But those particular concepts
that we showed you about, and

26
00:01:03.896 --> 00:01:07.315
configurations that we showed
you are key elements, right.

27
00:01:07.315 --> 00:01:09.900
If you need to do this on your own.

28
00:01:09.900 --> 00:01:11.361
So make sure that you look at them and

29
00:01:11.361 --> 00:01:13.474
understand that there is
a manual configuration.

30
00:01:13.474 --> 00:01:18.569
But the problem that we have is one that
I kept describing thru-out that part 1

31
00:01:18.569 --> 00:01:24.420
series is that the manual configuration by
someone like me or you as well as a human.

32
00:01:24.420 --> 00:01:29.042
Well, we can't account very easily for
the idea of time drift or

33
00:01:29.042 --> 00:01:31.193
technically clock drift of.

34
00:01:31.193 --> 00:01:35.066
I always wanting to say something else,
I call it time slippage but

35
00:01:35.066 --> 00:01:38.670
I think the technical term is clock drift,
all right.

36
00:01:38.670 --> 00:01:39.980
And that's the idea, right?

37
00:01:39.980 --> 00:01:42.665
If I go to one router and
I configure it, and

38
00:01:42.665 --> 00:01:47.488
I set up everything like I did in Part 1
where all of the set that way I want to.

39
00:01:47.488 --> 00:01:50.968
By the time I switch on over to
another router and then try and

40
00:01:50.968 --> 00:01:55.296
compare that and try and configure out
it again has already drifted time.

41
00:01:55.296 --> 00:01:59.667
And if I set the exact same time again I'm
probably off by seconds, at least for me,

42
00:01:59.667 --> 00:02:02.970
if not minutes the way that I talk and
I configure things.

43
00:02:02.970 --> 00:02:05.544
But overall though that's
what you want to avoid.

44
00:02:05.544 --> 00:02:07.908
So with humans just doing it,

45
00:02:07.908 --> 00:02:13.550
we'll probably get be off in terms
of time settings that we do.

46
00:02:13.550 --> 00:02:17.460
Just because of the human nature that we
are in moving from one device to another.

47
00:02:17.460 --> 00:02:21.733
Forgetting one element, not remembering
that we set this, not doing that,

48
00:02:21.733 --> 00:02:24.060
having to go back and change it.

49
00:02:24.060 --> 00:02:26.889
Trying to configure it,
it can cause some errors, okay,

50
00:02:26.889 --> 00:02:29.333
after a while,
especially if you need accuracy.

51
00:02:29.333 --> 00:02:32.063
So what we want to talk about
then is how we do we deal

52
00:02:32.063 --> 00:02:36.270
with this idea of some of these
micro-details, like we showed you.

53
00:02:36.270 --> 00:02:37.955
And when you type in Show Clock, right,

54
00:02:37.955 --> 00:02:40.347
it shows probably out to the ten
thousandths of a second.

55
00:02:40.347 --> 00:02:44.040
You and I can't configure
that exactly very easily.

56
00:02:44.040 --> 00:02:44.829
And even then,

57
00:02:44.829 --> 00:02:49.396
even if we could, that means that there's
still a 10,000 seconds that may be off.

58
00:02:49.396 --> 00:02:55.170
Which can add up over time and after
a while it can add up into seconds too.

59
00:02:55.170 --> 00:02:57.059
So just kinda realize that
all of that is possible.

60
00:02:57.059 --> 00:03:02.144
So what we want is a system,
okay, or something that allows

61
00:03:02.144 --> 00:03:07.950
us to have essentially the idea
of a regular time update, okay?

62
00:03:07.950 --> 00:03:11.911
In other words it actually is regular or
repeatable in what it does,

63
00:03:11.911 --> 00:03:13.307
in terms of the update.

64
00:03:13.307 --> 00:03:18.250
It's not like me, did I configure that
one, or did I not configure that one?

65
00:03:18.250 --> 00:03:19.680
Did it work?
Did it not work?

66
00:03:19.680 --> 00:03:20.675
What happened here?

67
00:03:20.675 --> 00:03:21.880
What went on, okay?

68
00:03:21.880 --> 00:03:23.605
So I want something that is regular.

69
00:03:23.605 --> 00:03:27.385
I also want the idea of something that
is periodic, okay, as well, okay?

70
00:03:27.385 --> 00:03:29.948
Now repeatable, and
consistent, the regularity is,

71
00:03:29.948 --> 00:03:31.592
of course the idea of consistency.

72
00:03:31.592 --> 00:03:34.370
The idea of being periodic is repeatable.

73
00:03:34.370 --> 00:03:38.083
And then the ability to
synchronize between those devices,

74
00:03:38.083 --> 00:03:42.610
without me having to interact too
much with the devices, as well, okay.

75
00:03:42.610 --> 00:03:46.350
And the way that we do that is
through what we call NTP, or

76
00:03:46.350 --> 00:03:48.980
Network Time Protocol, okay.

77
00:03:48.980 --> 00:03:52.235
NTP allows us to handle
the synchronization.

78
00:03:52.235 --> 00:03:55.014
And actually,
even better than just the idea of

79
00:03:55.014 --> 00:03:58.760
synchronizing between just
devices in the network.

80
00:03:58.760 --> 00:04:02.985
It can allow us to also handle the time
synchronizations across networks that

81
00:04:02.985 --> 00:04:04.419
don't account for time.

82
00:04:04.419 --> 00:04:07.830
And you might be saying,
well what networks would that be?

83
00:04:07.830 --> 00:04:09.780
That'd be essentially the entire Internet.

84
00:04:09.780 --> 00:04:13.976
The Internet doesn't care about
the way that your log messages appear,

85
00:04:13.976 --> 00:04:16.960
if they're accurate or not, but you do.

86
00:04:16.960 --> 00:04:20.154
And when we actually
want to sync up something

87
00:04:20.154 --> 00:04:24.364
with another device outside
of our own networks, as well.

88
00:04:24.364 --> 00:04:26.192
It can cause some drift as well,

89
00:04:26.192 --> 00:04:30.530
because those are particular
different networks that we go across.

90
00:04:30.530 --> 00:04:34.886
So, in that sense, right, if it goes from
one that worked us really fast to another

91
00:04:34.886 --> 00:04:38.333
network that's fairly slow to
another network that's, okay.

92
00:04:38.333 --> 00:04:41.760
And fast again, and then back to you,
if that happens, right?

93
00:04:41.760 --> 00:04:46.124
What that means that your time reporting
through those networks, it can change,

94
00:04:46.124 --> 00:04:48.034
it can be variable, it can do that.

95
00:04:48.034 --> 00:04:52.826
So what if you are synchronizing to clock
out there on the Internet somewhere for

96
00:04:52.826 --> 00:04:55.560
your router even for your own desktop.

97
00:04:55.560 --> 00:04:58.137
Well, how does it know to keep it
consistent and how does it do that?

98
00:04:58.137 --> 00:05:01.230
And that's usually because
of the way that NTP works.

99
00:05:01.230 --> 00:05:04.157
It can synchronize even though
the networks are variable,

100
00:05:04.157 --> 00:05:05.747
in the way that they relay time.

101
00:05:05.747 --> 00:05:10.270
So if you're running a Windows machine,
okay, as a Windows desktop.

102
00:05:10.270 --> 00:05:14.934
You've seen the ability, if your network
allows you to synchronize your own machine

103
00:05:14.934 --> 00:05:16.886
to a time clock out on the Internet.

104
00:05:16.886 --> 00:05:21.704
Okay, you've seen that, and
actually usually it says time.Windows.com.

105
00:05:21.704 --> 00:05:23.464
A kindment, a kindment,

106
00:05:23.464 --> 00:05:28.730
a common [LAUGH] time synchronization
clock that's out on the Internet.

107
00:05:28.730 --> 00:05:30.780
Well, that's not directly
connected to your network,

108
00:05:30.780 --> 00:05:31.982
it's somewhere on this planet.

109
00:05:31.982 --> 00:05:34.544
I don't know exactly where
it's on this planet but

110
00:05:34.544 --> 00:05:38.012
it has to go across multiple hops
before it gets to you and comes back.

111
00:05:38.012 --> 00:05:41.370
So that's something that you've
got to be able to account for.

112
00:05:41.370 --> 00:05:43.616
And that's something that NTP accounts for
us,

113
00:05:43.616 --> 00:05:45.822
so that we don't have to worry about it,
okay?

114
00:05:45.822 --> 00:05:47.254
So how does it do it, and

115
00:05:47.254 --> 00:05:51.830
why do we actually tend to get our time
synchronization from the Internet.

116
00:05:51.830 --> 00:05:54.935
And why is that actually better
than Ronnie just kind of guessing.

117
00:05:54.935 --> 00:05:58.871
And going that's what I heard on the radio
today it was closed that time, okay.

118
00:05:58.871 --> 00:05:59.500
>> [LAUGH].

119
00:05:59.500 --> 00:06:00.945
>> Well, the reason why is,

120
00:06:00.945 --> 00:06:05.241
let's go ahead and take a look at my
screen and this should help us out, okay.

121
00:06:05.241 --> 00:06:08.618
So out on the internet, okay,
and actually out on the world and

122
00:06:08.618 --> 00:06:11.310
in the governments and the worlds, okay.

123
00:06:11.310 --> 00:06:12.634
There's what we call of

124
00:06:12.634 --> 00:06:14.954
course NTP stratums that can help us out.

125
00:06:14.954 --> 00:06:16.293
>> Stratums?
>> Stratums.

126
00:06:16.293 --> 00:06:16.880
>> Okay.

127
00:06:16.880 --> 00:06:18.583
>> Yeah, each one of course a stratosphere

128
00:06:18.583 --> 00:06:20.393
of some sort if you want
to call it that way.

129
00:06:20.393 --> 00:06:21.010
>> Okay.

130
00:06:21.010 --> 00:06:22.635
>> A layer of things.

131
00:06:22.635 --> 00:06:27.738
Now for us, we as networks and
devices will never sync up

132
00:06:27.738 --> 00:06:34.560
to kind of the ultimate stratum,
itself, which is stratum zero.

133
00:06:34.560 --> 00:06:37.814
Stratum zeros are actually the atomic
time clocks that exist, and

134
00:06:37.814 --> 00:06:40.734
usually held in government
facilities somewhere, okay.

135
00:06:40.734 --> 00:06:45.171
You and I are never gonna actually have
our machine essentially sync up exactly to

136
00:06:45.171 --> 00:06:46.894
that particular time clock.
>> Okay.

137
00:06:46.894 --> 00:06:49.250
>> And so, can you?

138
00:06:49.250 --> 00:06:51.252
Well, it depends, it really does depend.

139
00:06:51.252 --> 00:06:56.164
So in the United States you do have a link
that says, here it is actually synced

140
00:06:56.164 --> 00:06:59.660
to the atomic time clock of
the US Navy and what it does.

141
00:06:59.660 --> 00:07:04.465
Which you can do, but it doesn't work that
way through NTP, NTP uses stratum share.

142
00:07:04.465 --> 00:07:08.314
The other things of course that
are also in this synchronization

143
00:07:08.314 --> 00:07:11.960
layer is the GPS satellites that
are out there on the planet.

144
00:07:12.960 --> 00:07:14.562
Well, what does this actually
mean as stratum zero?

145
00:07:14.562 --> 00:07:17.801
That means between all these devices and

146
00:07:17.801 --> 00:07:22.380
stratum zero there is very little,
if any delays at all.

147
00:07:22.380 --> 00:07:26.468
In other words, all of those
clocks on every GPS satellite and

148
00:07:26.468 --> 00:07:28.285
on the atomic time clocks.

149
00:07:28.285 --> 00:07:33.404
If there's any sort of time
drift at all it is negligible,

150
00:07:33.404 --> 00:07:37.920
it doesn't affect anything that we do.

151
00:07:37.920 --> 00:07:40.076
So that is something that happens.

152
00:07:40.076 --> 00:07:41.349
Now what happens,

153
00:07:41.349 --> 00:07:46.540
of course then is that around the world
with NTP there's also other stratum.

154
00:07:46.540 --> 00:07:50.546
There's actually stratums one through 16,
okay.

155
00:07:50.546 --> 00:07:55.315
Now, I set this up in this way to
allow us to realize something, okay.

156
00:07:55.315 --> 00:07:59.290
Every stratum essentially
depends on the stratum above it.

157
00:07:59.290 --> 00:08:03.040
So stratum 1-16 is probably
actually on equal layers

00:21:08.745 --> 00:21:11.715
>> So this clock is wrong obviously.

385
00:21:11.715 --> 00:21:15.035
And that's what we want, cuz we want to
see if it actually does synchronize up

386
00:21:15.035 --> 00:21:17.165
when we get everything here, okay?

387
00:21:17.165 --> 00:21:18.745
So noticing that is key.

388
00:21:18.745 --> 00:21:23.060
All right, once we are here,
let's go back in, and now,

389
00:21:23.060 --> 00:21:25.930
we're ready to configure this for
an NTP client.

390
00:21:27.706 --> 00:21:30.358
So when we do this idea of the NTP client,

391
00:21:30.358 --> 00:21:34.740
this is where the language gets
a little bit muddled here, right?

392
00:21:34.740 --> 00:21:37.420
Cuz it gets a little bit
backward in this set.

393
00:21:37.420 --> 00:21:42.910
So this is where on the client,
you have to set up ntp server,

394
00:21:42.910 --> 00:21:46.940
and then point it to
the correct IP address.

395
00:21:49.903 --> 00:21:53.093
And now, as we pointed it
to the correct IP address,

396
00:21:53.093 --> 00:21:56.470
we've also enabled NTP at the same time.

397
00:21:56.470 --> 00:22:01.360
Now, if I show clock here, let's see.

398
00:22:01.360 --> 00:22:03.170
And look at that, Zach.

399
00:22:03.170 --> 00:22:08.480
So right before, right,
we had done the NYCORE1.

400
00:22:08.480 --> 00:22:11.242
We did the show clock, and
it was showing as 1993,

401
00:22:11.242 --> 00:22:12.320
right?
>> Yes.

402
00:22:12.320 --> 00:22:14.790
>> Okay, now that I've just run that same

403
00:22:14.790 --> 00:22:19.675
exact command, It is now

404
00:22:19.675 --> 00:22:24.110
actually happening, and it has a-
>> But it has an asterisk, so

405
00:22:24.110 --> 00:22:26.780
what is that telling us, Ronnie?
>> Well, that right now, is telling

406
00:22:26.780 --> 00:22:29.740
us that it is not it's own time server.
>> Okay.

407
00:22:29.740 --> 00:22:31.180
>> It's saying that, hey, I got this

408
00:22:31.180 --> 00:22:33.390
authoritatively from somewhere else.
>> Okay.

409
00:22:33.390 --> 00:22:35.320
>> So somebody else is giving me this

410
00:22:35.320 --> 00:22:37.905
particular information.
>> That's what the asterisk means?

411
00:22:37.905 --> 00:22:39.187
So yeah, add this one, right,

412
00:22:39.187 --> 00:22:40.970
because it can't be authoritative.
>> Right.

413
00:22:40.970 --> 00:22:42.177
>> Because I'm saying I'm not

414
00:22:42.177 --> 00:22:43.620
the authority of my own time.

415
00:22:43.620 --> 00:22:45.400
I'm getting it from someone else.

416
00:22:45.400 --> 00:22:47.390
And so, it's going to do that as well.

417
00:22:47.390 --> 00:22:55.660
So now,
if I type in show NTP associations,

418
00:22:57.970 --> 00:23:01.246
we can now see where it did connect to.

419
00:23:01.246 --> 00:23:06.260
Well, the NTP server, and
the other one actually does

420
00:23:06.260 --> 00:23:11.880
even tell us even this address, it is
now considered a system peer as well.

421
00:23:11.880 --> 00:23:17.220
The reference clock based off of it is
actually the local clock, which is fine.

422
00:23:17.220 --> 00:23:21.940
But then, you start seeing there's the
stratum, when it actually happened here,

423
00:23:21.940 --> 00:23:24.750
how often it's being polled, the reach.

424
00:23:24.750 --> 00:23:30.560
The delay right now is about 1.2 seconds,
and offset, and the dispersion time.

425
00:23:30.560 --> 00:23:34.180
You name it, there's a lot of
technical details back here for us.

426
00:23:34.180 --> 00:23:37.592
But our key in understanding whether or
not it's happened,

427
00:23:37.592 --> 00:23:40.330
of course, right,
is that when we ran that show clock,

428
00:23:40.330 --> 00:23:44.670
did we get the information that
we are expecting to see, okay?

429
00:23:44.670 --> 00:23:47.710
And if we did, that's good, and
then we can do the other one.

430
00:23:47.710 --> 00:23:53.010
All right, so now,
lets do the show clock detail.

431
00:23:56.240 --> 00:23:59.420
Now notice, this is different now, okay?

432
00:23:59.420 --> 00:24:03.175
So, when we took a look at the details,
notice that now,

433
00:24:03.175 --> 00:24:08.330
it is actually going to say, look,
it did find it now being authoritative.

434
00:24:08.330 --> 00:24:09.287
>> Right [CROSSTALK].

435
00:24:09.287 --> 00:24:12.350
>> Because the time source is NTP.

436
00:24:12.350 --> 00:24:13.540
So, I was, yeah.

437
00:24:13.540 --> 00:24:19.080
So, in this sense here, even though at
the beginning, it got it, the information.

438
00:24:19.080 --> 00:24:22.090
It still wasn't sure yet but
now when we ran it again,

439
00:24:22.090 --> 00:24:25.350
after just a few seconds later,
it actually was able to match up and

440
00:24:25.350 --> 00:24:29.870
go nope, we believe that this is now
the authoritative time that we're getting,

441
00:24:29.870 --> 00:24:32.810
and that we now have
the time source as NTP.

442
00:24:32.810 --> 00:24:36.210
So show clock detail will
actually show us whether or

443
00:24:36.210 --> 00:24:40.340
not we're actually really using NTP or
not, along with all the information here.

444
00:24:40.340 --> 00:24:43.110
So these show commands
are very valuable to us.

445
00:24:43.110 --> 00:24:48.150
So Zach, this allows us now to,
once we've had that master set up,

446
00:24:48.150 --> 00:24:53.970
we now can go to all the other
routers that we want to use, that

447
00:24:53.970 --> 00:25:00.390
server is being the master time clock,
it really comes down to one command, okay?

448
00:25:00.390 --> 00:25:04.450
Which is NTP server and
the IP address of that server.

449
00:25:04.450 --> 00:25:09.110
Once that's done, then those machines
will begin to establish that association,

450
00:25:09.110 --> 00:25:11.870
that synchronization and
it will work and we can verify that.

451
00:25:11.870 --> 00:25:13.100
>> And that's what I was gonna ask you.

452
00:25:13.100 --> 00:25:15.840
Are we setting all the routers
all at once at one time, or

453
00:25:15.840 --> 00:25:17.290
just one router at a time?
>> Yeah,

454
00:25:17.290 --> 00:25:19.810
right now we can only set one
router at a time with this.

455
00:25:19.810 --> 00:25:22.310
So we still need to go ahead and
do that, okay?

456
00:25:22.310 --> 00:25:24.880
But besides that though,
I don't have to go in and

457
00:25:24.880 --> 00:25:26.670
reset every single clock anymore.

458
00:25:26.670 --> 00:25:29.950
I don't have to worry about
changing the timezone.

459
00:25:29.950 --> 00:25:32.410
I don't have to worry about
any of that other stuff here.

460
00:25:32.410 --> 00:25:36.560
Now, I just point it to the one that we
did set up, and the one we did tell was

461
00:25:36.560 --> 00:25:40.480
the master, and once that's done,
then it is ready to go, okay?

462
00:25:40.480 --> 00:25:45.660
So that for us, actually does set up,
and configure, verify NTP for us.

463
00:25:45.660 --> 00:25:46.840
And you know,

464
00:25:46.840 --> 00:25:48.490
you'll be able to do that on your own now.
>> Fantastic.

465
00:25:48.490 --> 00:25:52.880
Configure and verify NTP part two,
make sure you see part one.

466
00:25:52.880 --> 00:25:55.530
Ronnie, I know you want to say
something else before we move on.

467
00:25:55.530 --> 00:25:57.910
>> Well, this is again conceptually

468
00:25:57.910 --> 00:26:02.450
a little bit harder to remember, and it's
because of just a couple of things here.

469
00:26:02.450 --> 00:26:06.624
Let me see if I can zoom back, I have one
more that I wanted to show you too, okay?

470
00:26:07.820 --> 00:26:09.610
The hard thing is to remember here.

471
00:26:09.610 --> 00:26:13.040
And I made this slide and then I
remembered it right when we finished here.

472
00:26:13.040 --> 00:26:16.960
The NTP client is the one that has
to command, which is weird, right?

473
00:26:16.960 --> 00:26:18.330
NTP server on it.

474
00:26:18.330 --> 00:26:19.560
It doesn't seem like it, right,

475
00:26:19.560 --> 00:26:24.610
because the NTP server is where we'd
think that we'd type in NTP server.

476
00:26:24.610 --> 00:26:27.690
But this is the one where
we type in ntp master.

477
00:26:27.690 --> 00:26:32.210
That's usually if anything, that is
confusing for people in a troubleshooting

478
00:26:32.210 --> 00:26:36.640
issue, is that they don't remember
which particular command goes where.

479
00:26:36.640 --> 00:26:40.630
But just remember the server,
it only has ntp master on it.

480
00:26:40.630 --> 00:26:45.070
And then every other client
has the word ntp server on it.

481
00:26:45.070 --> 00:26:46.730
Strange but true.

482
00:26:46.730 --> 00:26:50.610
It's a little bit, at least in my mind,
mentally kind of switched up.

483
00:26:50.610 --> 00:26:53.300
Because I can see why people
would get this confused.

484
00:26:53.300 --> 00:26:54.620
But that is the way that it is.

485
00:26:54.620 --> 00:26:57.620
So make sure you remember that
as you go through it, okay?

486
00:26:57.620 --> 00:27:00.140
Now the last thing that I also wanna say.

487
00:27:00.140 --> 00:27:02.310
Can you set up the NTP master as a client?

488
00:27:02.310 --> 00:27:03.000
Yes.

489
00:27:03.000 --> 00:27:06.650
You can actually get this server to become
a client of one of these stratum devices

490
00:27:06.650 --> 00:27:09.150
up here and have that all set up.

491
00:27:09.150 --> 00:27:11.590
And then once you do that,
then it can also pass it out too.

492
00:27:11.590 --> 00:27:14.840
But we did it a little bit differently,
where we set up the NTP master and

493
00:27:14.840 --> 00:27:17.670
we told it hey,
you're gonna report as stratum one,

494
00:27:17.670 --> 00:27:21.190
which is fine, and
it can also go out and do that as well.

495
00:27:21.190 --> 00:27:26.330
But that's for more advanced set
than what we're doing here today.

496
00:27:26.330 --> 00:27:28.930
But just remember these commands and
where they'll also go,

497
00:27:28.930 --> 00:27:30.440
and that will help you
in the troubleshooting.

498
00:27:30.440 --> 00:27:34.625
And don't forget, practice everyday in
whatever configurations you can do,

499
00:27:34.625 --> 00:27:37.205
that's gonna be very helpful
to you as you get to the exam.

500
00:27:37.205 --> 00:27:38.505
>> Fantastic Ronnie, well done.

501
00:27:38.505 --> 00:27:43.155
Cisco's CCENT is a fabulous series,
make sure you watch every episode.

502
00:27:43.155 --> 00:27:45.025
Ronnie's worked very
hard to put together for

503
00:27:45.025 --> 00:27:48.615
you all the information you're gonna
need that will help you go further.

504
00:27:48.615 --> 00:27:50.935
And by the way, you'll be in
that course library, won't you?

505
00:27:50.935 --> 00:27:53.185
And there's thousands of
other videos there, and

506
00:27:53.185 --> 00:27:54.955
they're designed to help you go further.

507
00:27:54.955 --> 00:27:56.225
Check those out too.

508
00:27:56.225 --> 00:27:58.440
And tell everybody you
know about ITPro.TV.

509
00:27:58.440 --> 00:28:01.920
ITProTV is binge worthy, thanks for
watching I'm Zach Memos.

510
00:28:01.920 --> 00:28:02.630
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

511
00:28:02.630 --> 00:28:03.960
>> And we will see you again soon.

512
00:28:03.960 --> 00:28:10.620
[MUSIC]

513
00:28:10.620 --> 00:28:13.290
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss the use of ACLs: Standard Access Control Lists, Extended Access Controls and mention Named lists too.  They describe the configuration and logic of the configuration and operation of ACLs.  They begin configuring Standard ACLs.
episodes.title: Configure Standard Access Lists
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:02.775
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.775 --> 00:00:06.163
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.163 --> 00:00:08.263
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.263 --> 00:00:12.010
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.010 --> 00:00:16.561
>> Hello, thank you for choosing ITPRO.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.561 --> 00:00:19.527
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with Cisco CCENT.

7
00:00:19.527 --> 00:00:24.346
In this particular episode, we're
gonna configure standard access lists.

8
00:00:24.346 --> 00:00:25.690
What is that all about?

9
00:00:25.690 --> 00:00:27.024
Well, Ronnie Wong is here to tell us.

10
00:00:27.024 --> 00:00:28.470
Ronnie, good to see you, sir.

11
00:00:28.470 --> 00:00:29.061
>> Thank you for

12
00:00:29.061 --> 00:00:32.613
having me back on the show as we continue
on our CCENT journey together, Zach.

13
00:00:32.613 --> 00:00:37.110
We are now at that part where we're taking
a look at really one of the next to last,

14
00:00:37.110 --> 00:00:41.700
the penultimate topic, which,
of course, is infrastructure services.

15
00:00:41.700 --> 00:00:44.539
And now we're getting to that
point of where we're talking

16
00:00:44.539 --> 00:00:46.427
about standard access control lists.

17
00:00:46.427 --> 00:00:48.340
Now it's exactly like it sounds.

18
00:00:48.340 --> 00:00:52.321
When we talk about this, an access
control list talks about, of course,

19
00:00:52.321 --> 00:00:54.841
then the idea of controlling access,
right?

20
00:00:54.841 --> 00:00:59.375
So there's a part, and when you actually
just think about the title of what we're

21
00:00:59.375 --> 00:01:03.317
talking about here, right,
is that we're going to either restrict or

22
00:01:03.317 --> 00:01:06.420
we're going to deny
access into our network.

23
00:01:06.420 --> 00:01:10.320
So that's where we're actually starting
off when we think about this, okay?

24
00:01:10.320 --> 00:01:15.690
So in the idea of what we're talking
about, in a network, by itself,

25
00:01:15.690 --> 00:01:18.490
we've gotta realize that our network's
gonna continue to grow and change.

26
00:01:18.490 --> 00:01:21.890
And that means we need to control
access to certain parts of our network.

27
00:01:21.890 --> 00:01:25.607
An access control list is one of the
primary tools that we're going to use to

28
00:01:25.607 --> 00:01:26.264
help us out.

29
00:01:26.264 --> 00:01:30.446
So let's take a look at my diagram here,
and this will help us to at least

30
00:01:30.446 --> 00:01:34.210
get a visualization of something
that we need to understand.

31
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:36.729
>> Okay.
>> So I don't wanna say it's the most

32
00:01:36.729 --> 00:01:42.262
typical example of a secured network, but
it's a good example of a secured network.

33
00:01:42.262 --> 00:01:44.059
And this diagram helps us out,

34
00:01:44.059 --> 00:01:47.931
because we're gonna see a couple
of things in this diagram here too

35
00:01:47.931 --> 00:01:52.580
that you may also encounter in the future
as you get ready for the exam.

36
00:01:52.580 --> 00:01:56.040
Pay attention to, of course,
the symbols that are actually used, right?

37
00:01:56.040 --> 00:02:00.242
So notice the symbol on the router, and
this one is the symbol for firewall.

38
00:02:00.242 --> 00:02:03.557
I tried to make it a different color
than what the actual outline would be so

39
00:02:03.557 --> 00:02:07.120
that we could see it a little bit better,
and even the switch.

40
00:02:07.120 --> 00:02:11.740
All those are components that make up
the infrastructure of our network.

41
00:02:11.740 --> 00:02:14.700
And when we start to take a look
at the idea of the infrastructure,

42
00:02:14.700 --> 00:02:18.670
of the network and we're security minded
about it, this actually does provide,

43
00:02:18.670 --> 00:02:21.270
well, some different layers of security.

44
00:02:21.270 --> 00:02:25.730
The idea of having a single entry
point as far as from the Internet,

45
00:02:25.730 --> 00:02:29.550
into our network,
we may have a perimeter type of router

46
00:02:29.550 --> 00:02:33.020
that we can also just limit
access if we choose to.

47
00:02:33.020 --> 00:02:35.590
So we're not troubleshooting
many different connections.

48
00:02:35.590 --> 00:02:39.380
We're actually just troubleshooting one
connection going out and coming in.

49
00:02:39.380 --> 00:02:42.049
>> Okay.
>> In our firewall, well, this allows us

50
00:02:42.049 --> 00:02:46.718
separation from with inside of our network
as well by using a hardware device.

51
00:02:46.718 --> 00:02:52.080
And like the firewall says, it really
does initially, at least, by default.

52
00:02:52.080 --> 00:02:56.800
It prevents all access that wants
to get inside of our network

53
00:02:56.800 --> 00:02:58.520
to not actually be allowed.

54
00:02:58.520 --> 00:03:01.980
And then you and I open up what
we want to allow to come in.

55
00:03:01.980 --> 00:03:03.877
So in this firewall here,

56
00:03:03.877 --> 00:03:08.374
you're gonna hear terms like
the idea of untrusted network.

57
00:03:08.374 --> 00:03:11.971
And you're gonna hear terms like trusted
network, and that's what a firewall does.

58
00:03:11.971 --> 00:03:17.215
It actually helps us to define boundaries
not in terms of a perimeter boundaries so

59
00:03:17.215 --> 00:03:20.570
much, between the Internet and my network.

60
00:03:20.570 --> 00:03:25.920
But security boundaries, such as what
is considered untrusted versus trusted.

61
00:03:25.920 --> 00:03:29.480
So, for example,
from the perimeter router and

62
00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:33.642
the Internet all the way to this interface
right here on the firewall itself.

63
00:03:33.642 --> 00:03:37.880
Well, that is gonna be considered,
let's say, our untrusted side.

64
00:03:37.880 --> 00:03:39.478
So we don't have much control over here.

65
00:03:39.478 --> 00:03:42.727
We have some,
because we have this perimeter firewall,

66
00:03:42.727 --> 00:03:44.970
but we don't have a lot of that.

67
00:03:44.970 --> 00:03:48.285
But then at this firewall,
we can actually automatically,

68
00:03:48.285 --> 00:03:53.310
by just plugging in this device,
the untrusted port that we're configuring,

69
00:03:53.310 --> 00:03:56.940
we can go ahead and say, look,
all data that's coming in by default,

70
00:03:56.940 --> 00:04:02.100
okay, in other words, originating from
outside, it's gonna be blocked here.

71
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:05.430
Then, from that point, on the firewall,
and the way that we can do it,

72
00:04:05.430 --> 00:04:08.650
we can route it either to
an internal trusted network.

73
00:04:08.650 --> 00:04:11.460
Or we may even route it
out to other places,

74
00:04:11.460 --> 00:04:15.840
like a DMZ, which stands for
demilitarized zone.

75
00:04:15.840 --> 00:04:19.982
And this allows us to be able to put out
into the world things like web search,

76
00:04:19.982 --> 00:04:23.440
where everybody on the Internet
can get access to it.

77
00:04:23.440 --> 00:04:24.100
And also,

78
00:04:24.100 --> 00:04:28.030
even internally we can get access to
our own web servers if we need to.

79
00:04:28.030 --> 00:04:32.244
But even if this is compromised,
our internal network is not.

80
00:04:32.244 --> 00:04:33.530
The same thing with email.

81
00:04:33.530 --> 00:04:38.020
We may also put our email servers
out here in this DMZ as well.

82
00:04:38.020 --> 00:04:41.512
Because what we want to do is we
want people that are traveling for

83
00:04:41.512 --> 00:04:45.404
our company or working remotely for
our company to get access to email.

84
00:04:45.404 --> 00:04:50.334
But we don't want them having to go all
the way through internally where they're

85
00:04:50.334 --> 00:04:53.780
gonna be exposed inside,
and then get access in.

86
00:04:53.780 --> 00:04:55.156
We may put that in here, too.

87
00:04:55.156 --> 00:04:55.818
>> Mm-hm.

88
00:04:55.818 --> 00:04:59.527
>> So a firewall can help us to route,
once again, either to a DMZ, or

89
00:04:59.527 --> 00:05:03.100
maybe even inside of the internal network,
itself.

90
00:05:03.100 --> 00:05:05.309
From there, we have an internal router.

91
00:05:05.309 --> 00:05:08.403
An internal router can actually be
used in a couple of different ways.

92
00:05:08.403 --> 00:05:11.641
Here I've got it to set
to two different VLANs.

93

00:08:00.791 --> 00:08:06.930

00:08:06.930 --> 00:08:10.920

The number's gonna be between 1 and

Well, then it actually did

Well, beginning with 200 or

Well, with TCP/IP, we got configure

>> Because that's the identifier for

So here, I just picked number

So then, the next thing that you have to

So is it something you're

00:11:25.200 --> 00:11:28.110

Now the source IP address can be a single

00:11:32.450 --> 00:11:37.220
Usually it has one IP address, right,
or it could be an entire network, okay?

00:11:37.220 --> 00:11:39.590
So you can actually do either one.

206
00:11:39.590 --> 00:11:43.550
Now the hard part for you and me,
this is something we haven't come to yet,

207
00:11:43.550 --> 00:11:48.980
which we'll need to discuss briefly,
is what we call a wildcard mask.

208
00:11:48.980 --> 00:11:52.789
Now we've talked about what
a subnet mask is, okay?

209
00:11:52.789 --> 00:11:57.446
A subnet mask helps us to separate
out which part is the network ID,

210
00:11:57.446 --> 00:12:00.023
okay, and which part is the node ID,

211
00:12:00.023 --> 00:12:05.200
which part individually identifies
that computer within that network.

212
00:12:05.200 --> 00:12:08.550
So that subnet mask helps us to do that.

213
00:12:08.550 --> 00:12:13.260
A wildcard mask is all
about matching bits, okay?

214
00:12:13.260 --> 00:12:14.964
So it's all about that idea.

215
00:12:14.964 --> 00:12:19.802
And what that means instead of
using ones to help us to identify

216
00:12:19.802 --> 00:12:24.734
what bits end up matching,
what we do is we instead use zeroes to

217
00:12:24.734 --> 00:12:29.040
tell us what bits end up matching instead,
okay?

218
00:12:29.040 --> 00:12:34.025
So we essentially, a lot of people you'll
hear it called an inverse subnet mask.

219
00:12:35.420 --> 00:12:37.790
You'll see it written that
way a lot of times, but

220
00:12:37.790 --> 00:12:41.440
it doesn't have to follow
the same rules as a subnet mask.

221
00:12:41.440 --> 00:12:45.140
For example, a subnet mask normally,
there'd have to be that continuous

222
00:12:45.140 --> 00:12:49.350
string of ones from the left-hand side,
the most significant bit,

223
00:12:49.350 --> 00:12:52.640
toward the right-hand side,
the least significant bit.

224
00:12:52.640 --> 00:12:55.091
And wherever that last bit
is on the right-hand side,

225
00:12:55.091 --> 00:12:56.916
that's gonna be your network portion.

226
00:12:56.916 --> 00:12:59.877
So out of 32 bits,
if you choose 24 of them for

227
00:12:59.877 --> 00:13:04.286
your network ID in terms of subnet mask,
that means the first 24 bits or

228
00:13:04.286 --> 00:13:07.162
the first 3 octets
are gonna be your network.

229
00:13:07.162 --> 00:13:10.800
In a wildcard mask,
you don't have to do that at all.

230
00:13:10.800 --> 00:13:13.650
You just have to choose which ones
are gonna represent zeros and

231
00:13:13.650 --> 00:13:16.033
which ones are gonna represent
ones if you chose to.

232
00:13:16.033 --> 00:13:20.930
Now that's a little bit more confusing as
we get into CCNA routing and switching.

233
00:13:20.930 --> 00:13:25.630
We'll see where we would choose to use
a wildcard mask instead, especially when

234
00:13:25.630 --> 00:13:29.670
we're doing this, to help us to filter out
different things and to help us to make

235
00:13:29.670 --> 00:13:33.190
sure that we understand that it's
not the same as inverse subnet mask.

236
00:13:33.190 --> 00:13:36.482
So even if you read it some place on the
Internet, and it's like, they just call it

237
00:13:36.482 --> 00:13:39.372
inverse subnet mask, that's because
it's how it's commonly used.

238
00:13:39.372 --> 00:13:41.280
But we'll show you in CCNA routing and

239
00:13:41.280 --> 00:13:44.500
switching that you don't have
to follow the same rules.

00:13:44.500 --> 00:13:47.060
So we'll actually show

So notice I actually did that.

And that means the first three octets have

But notice on this one, this 255 here,

00:14:26.900 --> 00:14:30.610
So that's fine for what we want to,

00:14:30.610 --> 00:14:33.379
Now you can also write this a different
way if you wanted to make sure

00:14:33.379 --> 00:14:34.774

You wanna make sure there is only that

00:14:38.723 --> 00:14:41.030

00:14:41.030 --> 00:14:46.001
Is that you could do access
list here 1 deny and

00:14:46.001 --> 00:14:50.844
host as an alias for
a 32 bit wildcard mask,

258
00:14:50.844 --> 00:14:57.988
a 0.0.0.0 saying that, sure,
everything matches here.

00:14:57.988 --> 00:15:01.510
192.168.16.10 match all 32 bits instead.

00:15:01.510 --> 00:15:04.508
So you can do it either
way as you do that.

00:15:04.508 --> 00:15:09.339
The only other thing you have to add
in at the end here, is access-list 1,

262
00:15:09.339 --> 00:15:10.755
and then permit any.

Any is also another way to be an alias for

The reason why we need that is

00:15:22.838 --> 00:15:27.400

an implicit deny statement that

00:15:32.280 --> 00:15:35.420
So you and I don't see it,

00:15:35.420 --> 00:15:39.884
So that means that if it doesn't match

The second part of an access

Now when we start taking a look at that,

But essentially there's two steps to this,

00:16:25.500 --> 00:16:30.079
The access list we have to configure, but

The second part of it is to

00:16:33.950 --> 00:16:36.740

00:16:36.740 --> 00:16:41.724
So before we create an access list, but

313
00:18:25.000 --> 00:18:28.961
once I'm in the global configuration mode
here, this is where we're gonna spend just

314
00:18:28.961 --> 00:18:32.234
a little bit of time and taking a look
at what we're typing here, okay?

315
00:18:32.234 --> 00:18:36.491
So we are going to permit
the entire network,

316
00:18:36.491 --> 00:18:45.130
192.168.16 network is what we're
actually going to be permitting here.

317
00:18:45.130 --> 00:18:48.340
So the way that I would do that
is I type in access-list and

318
00:18:48.340 --> 00:18:51.115
we'll just use the number 1 right now.

319
00:18:51.115 --> 00:18:52.500
>> Mm-hm.

320
00:18:52.500 --> 00:18:55.300
>> And then from that point, let's go
ahead and so some question marks so

321
00:18:55.300 --> 00:18:56.810
that we can take a look.

322
00:18:56.810 --> 00:19:02.110
Notice I have the ability to permit or
deny or even add in a comment.

323
00:19:02.110 --> 00:19:05.271
Now in a production network we're adding
in comments is really good because if not,

324
00:19:05.271 --> 00:19:06.918
you're gonna see all
these access lists and

325
00:19:06.918 --> 00:19:08.536
you're not gonna know what they're for.

326
00:19:08.536 --> 00:19:11.445
So adding in a remark is
actually a good thing but for

327
00:19:11.445 --> 00:19:15.480
right now we're just gonna
do access-list 1 permit.

328
00:19:15.480 --> 00:19:20.856
So now I have to type it in again,
access-list 1 permit.

329
00:19:20.856 --> 00:19:21.630
All right, so

330
00:19:21.630 --> 00:19:25.535
now notice that I have to actually be
able to put after this permit here.

331
00:19:25.535 --> 00:19:27.754
>> Right.
>> Either to the host name or

332
00:19:27.754 --> 00:19:33.330
the IP address, and it even gives
me of course the aliases, right?

333
00:19:33.330 --> 00:19:34.830
Any means, any single source.

334
00:19:34.830 --> 00:19:36.074
>> Right.
>> And then of course

335
00:19:36.074 --> 00:19:38.940
host is actually a single
IP address as well.

336
00:19:38.940 --> 00:19:46.929
So instead what we are going to do
of course is access-list 1 permit.

337
00:19:46.929 --> 00:19:51.511
And this time we're going to type
in the entire network address,

338
00:19:51.511 --> 00:19:55.024
which is going to be 192.168.16.0.

339
00:19:55.024 --> 00:19:57.617
>> Right.
>> And this time I wanna make sure that I

340
00:19:57.617 --> 00:20:01.950
match the 192, which is going to be 0 168,
which is gonna be a 0.

341
00:20:01.950 --> 00:20:07.240
And then .16, and now I don't care
what's actually in the last octet,

342
00:20:07.240 --> 00:20:09.410
which means the entire network.

343
00:20:09.410 --> 00:20:14.880
Now there's one more time I'm going
to press the question mark here and

344
00:20:14.880 --> 00:20:18.675
show you that there's also
a log that you can see, okay?

345
00:20:18.675 --> 00:20:19.640
>> Mm-hm.
>> So on NY edge,

346
00:20:19.640 --> 00:20:22.840
notice it actually gives
me this logging here.

347
00:20:22.840 --> 00:20:27.480
Now the reason why logging is
important is if I am doing let's say,

348
00:20:27.480 --> 00:20:30.340
initially especially testing here, okay?

349
00:20:30.340 --> 00:20:34.920
I want to log at the beginning whether or
not this access list is effective.

350
00:20:34.920 --> 00:20:39.642
If it's effective, there'll be matches
that will show up when we actually do

351
00:20:39.642 --> 00:20:41.590
run a show access list command.

352
00:20:41.590 --> 00:20:44.100
And then I want to make
sure that it's logged.

353
00:20:44.100 --> 00:20:48.880
You do have to be careful because if
you do this and you select log here,

354
00:20:48.880 --> 00:20:52.580
it will send it to the place where it
normally sends it, which is the buffer.

355
00:20:52.580 --> 00:20:55.750
Which is a small area
memory on that device, and

356
00:20:55.750 --> 00:20:57.960
that buffer of course can get filled up.

357
00:20:57.960 --> 00:21:01.280
And that means the earliest logs of

358
00:21:01.280 --> 00:21:03.770
then whatever the logs that

00:21:03.770 --> 00:21:09.890
So usually for us it's not so much that we
mind about the earliest stuff being gone.

360
00:21:09.890 --> 00:21:14.220
But the problem that we have is if we're
trying to save it for historical data,

361
00:21:14.220 --> 00:21:17.670
there's no real use for it, but
this way you can at least tell.

362
00:21:17.670 --> 00:21:21.490
Now you may see on certain other devices,
as you do this,

363
00:21:21.490 --> 00:21:24.445
you may see also an issue here for

00:21:24.445 --> 00:21:28.995
If you're using smart log it's because

365
00:21:28.995 --> 00:21:32.840
also running on your network as well,

366
00:21:32.840 --> 00:21:36.634
So if you're running NetFlow that actually

367
00:21:36.634 --> 00:21:39.260
to send that to a smart log instead.

368
00:21:39.260 --> 00:21:43.732
But on mine, on NYEDGE1 here,
it only allows me to do that one.

369
00:21:43.732 --> 00:21:46.410
Let me me copy this thing over here.

370
00:21:46.410 --> 00:21:49.120
And we're not gonna worry about logging,
am I?

371
00:21:49.120 --> 00:21:53.025
Nope, at this point,
we're not gonna worry about logging, okay?

372
00:21:53.025 --> 00:21:57.865
So once we have that set up at this
point here, let's go ahead and

373
00:21:57.865 --> 00:22:03.455
type in a do show access-list here.

374
00:22:03.455 --> 00:22:06.725
And I'll go ahead and
show you something, okay?

375
00:22:06.725 --> 00:22:10.490
Here is a verification that you've
set up the access control list.

376
00:22:10.490 --> 00:22:14.880
Notice now, under Standard IP access list,
there's the 1.

377
00:22:14.880 --> 00:22:20.100
And we've just configured this one, and
it begins by giving us an entry number.

378
00:22:20.100 --> 00:22:23.820
So you have an access control lesson, ACL.

379
00:22:23.820 --> 00:22:28.300
And then each one of these that you
see that also has a number besides it,

380
00:22:28.300 --> 00:22:32.310
that's called an ACE, or
an access control entry.

381
00:22:32.310 --> 00:22:34.581
>> Okay.
>> It's not that it's so much that,

382
00:22:34.581 --> 00:22:37.280
technically that's
the correct way to do it.

383
00:22:37.280 --> 00:22:40.127
And you probably won't get something
like that on the exam like,"what's

384
00:22:40.127 --> 00:22:41.337
the difference between these?

385
00:22:41.337 --> 00:22:45.680
But remember that the greater,
the more encapsulating unit, right?

386
00:22:45.680 --> 00:22:49.350
Is that you and I just set up this
access control right here, okay?

387
00:22:49.350 --> 00:22:50.990
And then it begins with this, and

388
00:22:50.990 --> 00:22:56.046
so each access control list, there can
be multiple entries that we have, okay?

389
00:22:56.046 --> 00:22:57.990
And here it's saying
what we're gonna do is,

390
00:22:57.990 --> 00:22:59.430
we're gonna take the one
that you just typed in.

391
00:22:59.430 --> 00:23:04.370
We're gonna assign a number of 10
to this entry to permit this,and

392
00:23:04.370 --> 00:23:06.340
here is the wildcard bits.

393
00:23:06.340 --> 00:23:10.300
And you may be wondering why 10,
why not actually assign it as 1?

394
00:23:10.300 --> 00:23:11.704
>> Mm-hm.
>> Well 1 is the lowest number

395
00:23:11.704 --> 00:23:12.930
that we can have.

396
00:23:12.930 --> 00:23:17.170
But Zach, what if I actually
instead said I look at this now.

397
00:23:17.170 --> 00:23:20.630
I don't need to change this access control
list because it's there, but I need to

398
00:23:20.630 --> 00:23:24.260
add something else in here and I believe

399
00:23:25.370 --> 00:23:29.670
Well now I have the ability then,
to go back in and change this.

400
00:23:29.670 --> 00:23:34.507
And I can do that by adding in a 9 or
an 8 or 7, 6 all the way down to a 1, so

401
00:23:34.507 --> 00:23:36.396
that gives me that ability.

402
00:23:36.396 --> 00:23:39.239
>> Right.
>> And if we don't specify what that entry

403
00:23:39.239 --> 00:23:42.699
number is,
the next one will be a 20 and then 30.

404
00:23:42.699 --> 00:23:45.180
And then that way we can
put things in between,

405
00:23:45.180 --> 00:23:48.116
as we realize we gotta insert
it somewhere in between.

406
00:23:48.116 --> 00:23:51.947
So it actually puts spaces in there for
us or holding places.

407
00:23:51.947 --> 00:23:54.862
That we can now add in
some entries in between.

408
00:23:54.862 --> 00:23:58.905
So that's what you end up seeing in
terms of that number as well, all right?

409
00:23:58.905 --> 00:24:00.170
But we're gonna leave this one alone.

410
00:24:00.170 --> 00:24:04.210
And you can also see where
that access control list or

411
00:24:04.210 --> 00:24:06.380
another one that's out there, okay?

412
00:24:06.380 --> 00:24:10.870
One that they've named instead,
Standard IP list, called NAT.

413
00:24:10.870 --> 00:24:12.710
Notice this is no longer a number.

414
00:24:12.710 --> 00:24:15.590
This is what's called
a named access control list.

415
00:24:15.590 --> 00:24:18.520
And this one has about the same
thing that what we did.

416
00:24:18.520 --> 00:24:23.440
And this is the way that they identify
the traffic that will end up running

417
00:24:23.440 --> 00:24:28.218
through network address translation to get
translated out to the Internet as well.

418
00:24:28.218 --> 00:24:31.090
So here is an example, and
they've already to set this up for you.

419
00:24:31.090 --> 00:24:34.384
That's why you're seeing that entry
right in there for right now, okay?

420
00:24:34.384 --> 00:24:36.340
All right, so
let's create another one here.

421
00:24:36.340 --> 00:24:40.610
And this time,
we're gonna do a deny as well, okay?

422
00:24:40.610 --> 00:24:43.312
But we're gonna create
an access control list 10.

423
00:24:43.312 --> 00:24:50.480
So it's gonna be access-list 10,
and this time we're gonna deny.

424
00:24:50.480 --> 00:24:55.570
Now I'm only gonna deny one address,
which is gonna be 192.168.16.10.

425
00:24:55.570 --> 00:24:57.607
So I have two ways where I can do that.

426
00:24:57.607 --> 00:25:02.405
If I want the entire thing,
I can do 192.168.16.10 and

427
00:25:02.405 --> 00:25:07.080
then for the entirety of the address,
it would be right here.

428
00:25:07.080 --> 00:25:11.230
Notice all four are 0s,
saying match every single bit.

429
00:25:11.230 --> 00:25:13.530
>> Right.
>> But the equivalent of that,

430
00:25:13.530 --> 00:25:14.930
if I do not want to type it out and

431
00:25:14.930 --> 00:25:20.270
probably the more standard practices of
this is instead gonna be using an alias.

432
00:25:20.270 --> 00:25:25.146
Just say, hey, I wanna deny this host,
192.168.16.10, and

433
00:25:25.146 --> 00:25:27.475
why would I choose to do that, Zach?

434
00:25:27.475 --> 00:25:31.502
The reason why I would choose to do it,
is if I can't remember, the 0s,

435
00:25:31.502 --> 00:25:35.180
do I need to do the first three 0s and
then 255, or whatever?

436
00:25:35.180 --> 00:25:37.720
If I know that it's only
supposed to be one IP address,

437
00:25:37.720 --> 00:25:41.520
I do host instead right here as an alias.

438
00:25:41.520 --> 00:25:45.190
And that automatically sets
the wildcard bits to all 32 bits

439
00:25:45.190 --> 00:25:47.530
as being the wildcard bit itself, okay?

440
00:25:47.530 --> 00:25:50.660
>> Makes sense.
>> All right, so now we'll go ahead and

441
00:25:50.660 --> 00:25:54.775
add that one in there, and then let's
take a look at the access list now.

442
00:25:54.775 --> 00:26:00.660
Show access-lists.

443
00:26:00.660 --> 00:26:05.390
And now you can see where there's two
different access lists listed, okay,

444
00:26:05.390 --> 00:26:07.320
that we have just configured.

445
00:26:07.320 --> 00:26:10.770
Notice that one is,

446
00:26:10.770 --> 00:26:14.700
of course, access list one,
which we permitted the entire ten network.

447
00:26:14.700 --> 00:26:23.830
But notice this one right here were we
have now denied one IP address instead.

448
00:26:23.830 --> 00:26:26.990
So when you start taking a look
at this access control list and

449
00:26:26.990 --> 00:26:30.760
you start seeing it, now we have to
talk about the processing order.

450
00:26:30.760 --> 00:26:36.480
So as traffic now is coming to the router,
the way that these are processed,

451
00:26:36.480 --> 00:26:39.325
because they're not exactly
in line with each other.

452
00:26:39.325 --> 00:26:41.510
One's not an entry of the other one here,
right?

453
00:26:41.510 --> 00:26:44.180
We have access list 1,
we have access list 10.

454
00:26:44.180 --> 00:26:46.260
Well, which one gets processed first,
okay?

455
00:26:46.260 --> 00:26:47.880
And that's kinda the key here.

456
00:26:47.880 --> 00:26:52.560
The key in what gets processed first is
the way that it appears in this list.

457
00:26:52.560 --> 00:26:55.580
So in this list as well,
okay, as you see it,

458
00:26:55.580 --> 00:26:59.700
access list 1 will get processed first.

459
00:26:59.700 --> 00:27:03.030
So now anything coming in with
192.168 16.16, 16.17, 16.18,

460
00:27:03.030 --> 00:27:09.130
that will get processed first,
and will hit this

461
00:27:09.130 --> 00:27:14.990
access control list, and be permitted to
go through, or leave, or whatever, okay?

462
00:27:14.990 --> 00:27:18.587
Then, if it actually happens to,
let's say it doesn't match 10.

463
00:27:18.587 --> 00:27:21.292
Let's say it's actually from 16.10.

464
00:27:21.292 --> 00:27:25.851
Well, now as it hits the router, it we'll
take a look at this, and it'll go, hey,

465
00:27:25.851 --> 00:27:29.060
it matches this, so
there's a problem already.

466
00:27:29.060 --> 00:27:32.760
It will automatically process it as this,
okay?

467
00:27:32.760 --> 00:27:34.590
Well, if that happens,

468
00:27:34.590 --> 00:27:40.439
it will never hit the second item because
it only processes what it has to match.

469
00:27:40.439 --> 00:27:45.784
Well, 192.168.16.10,
it is essentially at this point

470
00:27:45.784 --> 00:27:52.530
a subset of what this entirety that we've
actually put here, the entire network.

471
00:27:52.530 --> 00:27:56.460
So if it matches this,
it doesn't ever process the second one.

472
00:27:56.460 --> 00:28:03.620
So at some point, what would be better
is if this came before this, okay?

473
00:28:03.620 --> 00:28:05.950
So how do we actually ensure that?

474
00:28:05.950 --> 00:28:10.520
The best practice in training
access control list as we do this.

475
00:28:10.520 --> 00:28:14.070
Even within a single access control list
and the entries that we put in there

476
00:28:14.070 --> 00:28:18.060
is that the most specific items
that we can actually list here.

477
00:28:18.060 --> 00:28:23.370
Such as denying a single IP address
versus a range of IP addresses,

478
00:28:23.370 --> 00:28:25.540
what we would do is we'd put
the one that actually says,

479
00:28:25.540 --> 00:28:29.820
let me deny the most specific one,
which is gonna be the host instead.

480
00:28:29.820 --> 00:28:32.690
So deny that one first and
then allow the other one.

481
00:28:32.690 --> 00:28:37.405
So this, in this order, list number 10
should actually appear before list number

482
00:28:37.405 --> 00:28:40.620
1, and that's the way that it
would actually be processed here.

483
00:28:40.620 --> 00:28:44.609
So there is a bit of different things
that can actually happen when you do

484
00:28:44.609 --> 00:28:46.682
something like this as well, okay?

485
00:28:46.682 --> 00:28:51.482
Now the other thing that we also have to
be able to do here is remember what I

486
00:28:51.482 --> 00:28:56.044
said, that at the end of each of these,
even though we don't see it,

487
00:28:56.044 --> 00:28:59.608
there is what's called
an implicit deny statement.

488
00:28:59.608 --> 00:29:06.333
So even though this says 10 and it permits
192.168.16.0, at the very end of this,

489
00:29:06.333 --> 00:29:11.581
whenever we finish whatever other things
that we add in in terms of entries,

490
00:29:11.581 --> 00:29:17.670
right, after this, you'll actually
see that there's gonna be deny all.

491
00:29:17.670 --> 00:29:21.150
So if you understand that, that's fine,

492
00:29:21.150 --> 00:29:25.310
as long as there's a permit statement
in there somewhere, it will work.

493
00:29:25.310 --> 00:29:29.750
But if you create an access control
list and you forget that, right?

494
00:29:29.750 --> 00:29:32.110
And you're saying, hey,
I have permitted everything or

495
00:29:32.110 --> 00:29:35.110
I permitted what thought I should've
permitted, well, that's fine.

496
00:29:35.110 --> 00:29:36.107
That should get through.

497
00:29:36.107 --> 00:29:39.457
But you're wondering why everything
else is not getting through,

498
00:29:39.457 --> 00:29:42.347
it's because you forgot that
there's an implicit deny.

499
00:29:42.347 --> 00:29:46.151
But let me go back to this
diagram here for a moment, and

500
00:29:46.151 --> 00:29:50.400
let's take a look at something
right here too, okay?

501
00:29:50.400 --> 00:29:55.660
So let me unhide this for
a moment and do this, okay?

502
00:29:55.660 --> 00:30:01.320
So for example, right now in what we've
just done, if we take a look at access

503
00:30:01.320 --> 00:30:06.050
list 10, let's say that we've denied this,
which is exactly what we did here.

504
00:30:06.050 --> 00:30:09.770
But remember that at the end of that,
there's actually a deny any statement.

505
00:30:09.770 --> 00:30:12.670
Even though we don't see it,
it's right here.

506
00:30:12.670 --> 00:30:15.670
So if we do something like this, okay?

507
00:30:15.670 --> 00:30:21.640
So, Zach, even though I'm only,
according to what I typed in,

508
00:30:21.640 --> 00:30:26.370
I'm denying only 192.196.8.16.10,
if something else goes into the router

509
00:30:26.370 --> 00:30:31.110
that's 16.16 or 17, or 18, or 19, it then
doesn't match this first statement but

510
00:30:31.110 --> 00:30:33.730
eventually it will match
the second statement.

511
00:30:33.730 --> 00:30:35.930
And if it does that,
that means it blocks everything.

512
00:30:35.930 --> 00:30:36.710
>> Right, right.

513
00:30:36.710 --> 00:30:40.610
>> It blocks everything, and that's
something we have to be careful about.

514
00:30:40.610 --> 00:30:43.130
There has to be at least
one permit statement for

515
00:30:43.130 --> 00:30:45.310
that to actually end up working for us.

516
00:30:45.310 --> 00:30:48.480
Now let's take a look at
this other side here, okay?

517
00:30:48.480 --> 00:30:53.890
If I truly only want to block
a single address here, okay?

518
00:30:53.890 --> 00:30:58.521
So taking the same thing here,
this is what we would also have to do.

519
00:30:58.521 --> 00:31:03.055
So not only do we have the same deny
statement that we had over on the other

520
00:31:03.055 --> 00:31:07.820
side, but I would explicitly need
an allow statement here, okay?

521
00:31:07.820 --> 00:31:12.791
So I would add in a second statement
that allows me to do this,

522
00:31:12.791 --> 00:31:16.311
where it says access-list 1 permit any.

523
00:31:16.311 --> 00:31:20.415
And that means as long as
it matches 16.10, deny it.

524
00:31:20.415 --> 00:31:25.545
But if 16.16, 16.17,
16.18, it comes through,

525
00:31:25.545 --> 00:31:29.710
it won't match entry 10,
it'll match entry 20.

526
00:31:29.710 --> 00:31:31.240
So it will be allowed to go through.

527
00:31:31.240 --> 00:31:34.320
If it doesn't match any of that,
deny, okay?

528
00:31:34.320 --> 00:31:35.850
So it is this process and

529
00:31:35.850 --> 00:31:39.160
this order of process that we
also have to worry about too.

530
00:31:39.160 --> 00:31:43.060
So that is at least the beginning of
some of the things that we have to

531
00:31:43.060 --> 00:31:45.520
kind of understand as we get set up for
this.

532
00:31:45.520 --> 00:31:47.610
Now Zach, we're by no means done.

533
00:31:47.610 --> 00:31:50.612
But at least for this episode,
we're running out of time.

534
00:31:50.612 --> 00:31:53.324
So we probably need to come back and
when we do,

535
00:31:53.324 --> 00:31:57.863
we'll also talk about this idea of
applying the access list onto the router.

536
00:31:57.863 --> 00:32:02.074
And I’ll also talk about directionality,
as well as in the inbound and

537
00:32:02.074 --> 00:32:03.010
outbound too.

538
00:32:03.010 --> 00:32:06.360
So there’s a lot more configuration to go,
but I’m just out of time for this episode.

539
00:32:06.360 --> 00:32:09.240
>> Wait for the part the two of
configure standard access lists.

540
00:32:09.240 --> 00:32:10.423
You've seen part one.

541
00:32:10.423 --> 00:32:13.802
And before we move on, I know, Ronnie,
I know you wanna say something else.

542
00:32:13.802 --> 00:32:14.930
I can tell.

543
00:32:14.930 --> 00:32:16.120
>> Well, remember,

544
00:32:16.120 --> 00:32:19.280
I'm not gonna tell you that this is the
easiest concept to get right away, okay?

545
00:32:19.280 --> 00:32:21.510
Especially if this is
the first time you've seen it.

546
00:32:21.510 --> 00:32:25.450
Make sure you go back and
you practice the steps and you understand.

547
00:32:25.450 --> 00:32:27.899
Go line by line like I did here,
and explain,

548
00:32:27.899 --> 00:32:31.321
and make sure it makes sense to
you as you go through and do this.

549
00:32:31.321 --> 00:32:33.890
There's a lot of rules dealing
with access control lists.

550
00:32:33.890 --> 00:32:36.895
And at the end of the series,
well, hopefully, if I remember,

551
00:32:36.895 --> 00:32:40.756
we'll review some of those rules as well
that will help you to get this settled in.

552
00:32:40.756 --> 00:32:42.468
But we still got a lot of configuration.

553
00:32:42.468 --> 00:32:44.390
You gotta remember that
we're only halfway through.

554
00:32:44.390 --> 00:32:47.730
Because we've configured an access list,
we just haven't applied it anywhere.

555
00:32:47.730 --> 00:32:51.115
And that's the second part of
getting access control lists down.

556
00:32:51.115 --> 00:32:52.540
But we'll do that in our next episode.

557
00:32:52.540 --> 00:32:56.570
>> Awesome, great advice, great show and
make sure you see everything.

558
00:32:56.570 --> 00:33:01.040
All the episodes inside the Cisco CCent
series that Ronnie's put together for you.

559
00:33:01.040 --> 00:33:02.490
You will be very glad you did.

560
00:33:02.490 --> 00:33:03.161
And by the way,

561
00:33:03.161 --> 00:33:06.429
it'll be in the course library where
there's thousands of other videos.

562
00:33:06.429 --> 00:33:08.258
And they are there to help you go further.

563
00:33:08.258 --> 00:33:09.654
So check those out too.

564
00:33:09.654 --> 00:33:11.699
Tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

565
00:33:11.699 --> 00:33:13.800
ITProTV is bingeworthy.

566
00:33:13.800 --> 00:33:14.480
Thanks for watching.

567
00:33:14.480 --> 00:33:15.168
I'm Zach Memos.

568
00:33:15.168 --> 00:33:15.906
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

569
00:33:15.906 --> 00:33:17.887
>> And we will see you again soon.

570
00:33:17.887 --> 00:33:24.414
[MUSIC]

571
00:33:24.414 --> 00:33:27.646
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie continue with configuring access lists.  They continue with applying an ACL to an interface.  They remind that both: creating an ACL and applying to an interface is essential to the ACL operation.  They create an extended ACL to show it's flexibiity and review the importance of the placement of ACLs.
episodes.title: Configure Standard Access Lists Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.189 --> 00:00:01.726
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.726 --> 00:00:06.319
I'm your host.
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.319 --> 00:00:08.139
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.139 --> 00:00:11.964
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.964 --> 00:00:16.520
>> Hello, and welcome to ITProTV,
helping you learn everywhere you go.

6
00:00:16.520 --> 00:00:20.911
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with Cisco CCENT.

7
00:00:20.911 --> 00:00:25.290
This is gonna be part two of
Configure Standard Access Lists.

8
00:00:25.290 --> 00:00:29.327
And once again, Ronnie Wong has said, I'm
gonna drop by and help you out with that.

9
00:00:29.327 --> 00:00:30.380
>> [LAUGH]
>> So here he is, Ronnie.

10
00:00:30.380 --> 00:00:31.590
Ronnie, good to see you.

11
00:00:31.590 --> 00:00:32.280
>> Thank you, Zach.

12
00:00:32.280 --> 00:00:35.370
As we continue on in our
CCENT journey once again,

13
00:00:35.370 --> 00:00:38.070
remember that we were
in the middle of a lab.

14
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:41.440
We are configuring, of course,
a standard access control list.

15
00:00:41.440 --> 00:00:43.517
Now we're not only gonna be doing that,

16
00:00:43.517 --> 00:00:47.184
we're also gonna end up configuring
an extended access control list,

17
00:00:47.184 --> 00:00:50.993
as well as even a named one so that you
can see and compare the differences.

18
00:00:50.993 --> 00:00:54.458
But according to Cisco's CCENT and
their own exam objectives,

19
00:00:54.458 --> 00:00:58.448
that they're only really focusing in
on standard access control lists.

20
00:00:58.448 --> 00:01:03.450
But like everything else, those exam
objectives are subject to change.

21
00:01:03.450 --> 00:01:07.507
And I can pretty much tell you that you're
probably gonna see a mix of all three

22
00:01:07.507 --> 00:01:08.080
on there.

23
00:01:08.080 --> 00:01:11.038
So even though they say they're really
only focusing on standard access

24
00:01:11.038 --> 00:01:13.702
control lists, some of the details
that you'll be asked about,

25
00:01:13.702 --> 00:01:16.090
that's probably what you'll end up seeing.

26
00:01:16.090 --> 00:01:20.715
But the ability to distinguish this
from an extended one versus a named one

27
00:01:20.715 --> 00:01:22.512
is also gonna be key for you.

28
00:01:22.512 --> 00:01:25.580
But we'll make sure that you can actually
see the difference between those two.

29
00:01:25.580 --> 00:01:28.935
>> Fantastic.
>> So in our first episode in this little

30
00:01:28.935 --> 00:01:33.560
miniseries that we've taken on here, we
ahead in and we configured access control

31
00:01:33.560 --> 00:01:36.210
lists on a router, and
we also talked about some of the details.

32
00:01:36.210 --> 00:01:39.230
So let's go back here, and
we'll take a look again.

33
00:01:39.230 --> 00:01:43.490
And let me zoom in so that we can
see it just a little bit better,

34
00:01:43.490 --> 00:01:47.280
as well as we just trying
to get down there.

35
00:01:47.280 --> 00:01:51.792
So we had just shown the access
control list itself, and

36
00:01:51.792 --> 00:01:57.367
here was our last configurations
that we manually typed in, right?

37
00:01:57.367 --> 00:02:00.880
We see two standard access control
list where we had configured them.

38
00:02:00.880 --> 00:02:05.744
And we also, of course, talked about
this idea of the processing order that

39
00:02:05.744 --> 00:02:08.558
you have to be aware of and
an implicit deny.

40
00:02:08.558 --> 00:02:13.388
I would make sure that I go back in, along
with whatever other study materials that

41
00:02:13.388 --> 00:02:18.358
you're looking at, understand that idea,
especially with the implicit deny that

42
00:02:18.358 --> 00:02:21.523
it's not gonna show up even
with show access-list.

43
00:02:21.523 --> 00:02:23.020
You're not gonna see it.

44
00:02:23.020 --> 00:02:29.390
But if you don't see an explicit entry,
it means it's implicitly denied.

45
00:02:29.390 --> 00:02:33.680
So don't think that if you see
an entry that just says permit

46
00:02:33.680 --> 00:02:35.840
that that that's all that there is.

47
00:02:35.840 --> 00:02:39.700
If everything else besides what's in that
permit statement is still getting denied,

48
00:02:39.700 --> 00:02:42.570
it means you have to add
in at least one more

49
00:02:42.570 --> 00:02:46.590
entry in there to ensure that other
things can also get through, okay?

50
00:02:46.590 --> 00:02:50.170
So make sure you do that, and
that's where we've kind of left off.

51
00:02:50.170 --> 00:02:53.620
Now the other part of,
of course, getting to

52
00:02:53.620 --> 00:02:58.840
an access control list to work is
applying it to an interface, okay?

53
00:02:58.840 --> 00:03:02.670
So creating the access control list
really does nothing except for,

54
00:03:02.670 --> 00:03:06.018
say, here's the logic that's in place.

55
00:03:06.018 --> 00:03:10.500
Now we have to take that logic, and
we now have to apply it to a router, and

56
00:03:10.500 --> 00:03:15.380
specifically to an interface and
give direction to it as well.

57
00:03:15.380 --> 00:03:21.150
So at this particular point, as we do so,
we're gonna use that same diagram,

58
00:03:21.150 --> 00:03:25.260
and I'll try to simplify it a little
bit more here, to talk about this

59
00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:30.200
idea of where the access list should
go when you start to do this.

60
00:03:30.200 --> 00:03:35.090
So if I wanted to control what
it actually was doing, so

61
00:03:35.090 --> 00:03:38.720
we're gonna use access
list ten as our example.

62
00:03:38.720 --> 00:03:39.910
And in access list ten,

63
00:03:39.910 --> 00:03:44.940
I wanna make sure that I'm telling you
right, we are denying one IP address.

64
00:03:44.940 --> 00:03:49.510
So that's the one IP address that
we're denying, which is fine, 16.10.

65
00:03:49.510 --> 00:03:54.000
So if we come over here,
here's 16.10, and I want to

66
00:03:54.000 --> 00:03:59.190
deny its ability to do one thing.

67
00:03:59.190 --> 00:04:03.105
According to the directions in your
lab guide, you're denying access to

68
00:04:03.105 --> 00:04:08.196
practice-labs.com, www.practice-labs.com.

69
00:04:08.196 --> 00:04:13.130
So once we've created that
access list on this router,

70
00:04:13.130 --> 00:04:18.160
I also am going to need to apply
this on an interface as well.

71
00:04:18.160 --> 00:04:21.710
So there's two different ways
that this can be done, okay?

72
00:04:21.710 --> 00:04:25.197
So of course, we need to
actually do inbound or outbound.

73
00:04:25.197 --> 00:04:28.890
And let's talk about this idea of
I change this to inbound, okay?

74
00:04:28.890 --> 00:04:32.903
If you change an access list and
then you put it on an interface,

75
00:04:32.903 --> 00:04:36.109
you're going to select that interface,
right?

76
00:04:36.109 --> 00:04:40.408
You're gonna go into your global config,
do an interface gigabit ethernet 0/0.

77
00:04:40.408 --> 00:04:49.560
Then you can type in ip acess-group
the number of the access, which is 10.

78
00:04:49.560 --> 00:04:51.150
And you're gonna say inbound.

79
00:04:51.150 --> 00:04:52.750
Now, what does that mean?

80
00:04:52.750 --> 00:05:00.024
Well, remember that access-group is how we
group this list to the interface, okay?

81
00:05:00.024 --> 00:05:01.850
So that's what we're saying
here in that access-group.

82
00:05:01.850 --> 00:05:06.425
We're saying group that access
list 10 to this interface.

83
00:05:06.425 --> 00:05:11.378
And we're monitoring for
whether it's inbound or outbound here.

84
00:05:11.378 --> 00:05:15.860
So we've put in the word in,
like I have right here, okay?

85
00:05:15.860 --> 00:05:18.050
What does that really mean?

86
00:05:18.050 --> 00:05:20.130
That is about the traffic.

87
00:05:20.130 --> 00:05:23.980
And what that means is
coming into the interface.

88
00:05:23.980 --> 00:05:28.366
Now whenever we talk about
directionality for a router's interface,

89
00:05:28.366 --> 00:05:32.530
it's always from outside
coming into the router, okay?

90
00:05:32.530 --> 00:05:37.430
So that is kind of where the terminology
kinda gets a little bit strict.

91
00:05:37.430 --> 00:05:42.080
So in other words, for us,
in this diagram, okay, when we do that and

92
00:05:42.080 --> 00:05:47.066
we apply access-group 10 in,
we're saying as it comes into

93
00:05:47.066 --> 00:05:51.640
gigabit ethernet 0/0, okay,

94
00:05:51.640 --> 00:05:57.090
as it does that, this is where
that access list 10 will apply.

95
00:05:57.090 --> 00:06:01.396
So in access list 10,
if we go back here, okay,

96
00:06:01.396 --> 00:06:05.930
we'll see that that's
exactly what happens.

97
00:06:05.930 --> 00:06:11.294
Is that at that particular interface,
then, it should go ahead and

98
00:06:11.294 --> 00:06:16.202
block that from getting access in,
which is perfectly fine.

99
00:06:16.202 --> 00:06:21.864
That effectively right now does
do what we need it to do, okay?

100
00:06:21.864 --> 00:06:26.730
That will prevent it from
getting to practice-labs.com.

101
00:06:26.730 --> 00:06:28.832
Now, there can be a problem though, okay?

102
00:06:28.832 --> 00:06:33.020
So Zach, let me kind of do little bit
of an ad lib here just for a moment.

103
00:06:34.020 --> 00:06:38.876
Let's say, though,
that there is a partner group for us.

104
00:06:38.876 --> 00:06:44.179
We'll call it ourpartner.com.

105
00:06:44.179 --> 00:06:47.584
And let's say that for
some reason or the other,

106
00:06:47.584 --> 00:06:50.525
they're off of this interface instead.

107
00:06:50.525 --> 00:06:54.290
>> Mm-hm.

108
00:06:54.290 --> 00:07:02.960
>> So this interface, let's just do
this one, And let's change it here.

109
00:07:03.970 --> 00:07:08.370
Now if I do that and we change that up,

110
00:07:08.370 --> 00:07:13.690
if I have the access-group here for
10 going inbound,

111
00:07:13.690 --> 00:07:18.910
okay, and my specific requirement,
okay, was essentially to block,

112
00:07:21.861 --> 00:07:25.588
Me from getting there, right,

113
00:07:25.588 --> 00:07:32.290
now its only requirement was
to protect me and there.

114
00:07:32.290 --> 00:07:35.998
Of course, why would it actually allow me
to choose both of them at the same time?

115
00:07:35.998 --> 00:07:40.480
That'd be silly, so
that was my only requirement here.

116
00:07:40.480 --> 00:07:42.770
And apparently I even chose
two different colors there.

117
00:07:42.770 --> 00:07:43.410
I can see it now.

118
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:44.090
That's amazing.

119
00:07:45.410 --> 00:07:47.610
That is really amazing.

120
00:07:47.610 --> 00:07:50.130
All right, let me group that together.

121
00:07:50.130 --> 00:07:52.470
All right, I'm gonna leave it,
cuz now I'm done.

122
00:07:52.470 --> 00:07:55.060
So that's my only requirement.

123
00:07:55.060 --> 00:08:00.632
Is there an issue if I go ahead and
add that to this interface?

124
00:08:00.632 --> 00:08:03.817
Well, yeah.
Because that only blocks it there, but

125
00:08:03.817 --> 00:08:05.385
if you think about it,

126
00:08:05.385 --> 00:08:11.420
it also effectively blocks it from going
away to our partner as well, right?

127
00:08:11.420 --> 00:08:13.730
Because I blocked it at this interface.

128
00:08:13.730 --> 00:08:15.300
>> Right, you blocked it at the interface.

129
00:08:15.300 --> 00:08:16.860
>> Well,
if I blocked it at that interface,

130
00:08:16.860 --> 00:08:20.460
it's gonna block it from getting
everywhere besides, what?

131
00:08:20.460 --> 00:08:22.890
The one place that I needed it,

132
00:08:22.890 --> 00:08:27.730
which is the only requirement was
to block it from practice-labs.com.

133
00:08:27.730 --> 00:08:30.070
Now, so what do I do then?

134
00:08:30.070 --> 00:08:31.540
How do I do this?

135
00:08:31.540 --> 00:08:35.390
Well, what I need to do then is to maybe
find something that is actually a little

136
00:08:35.390 --> 00:08:40.150
bit more specific, and I can do this of
course with the directionality as well.

137
00:08:40.150 --> 00:08:43.822
So instead, I might move and

138
00:08:43.822 --> 00:08:48.111
configure g or gigabyte 0/1.

139
00:08:48.111 --> 00:08:54.980
And I might say not going inbound because
inbound will be from practicelabs.com.

140
00:08:54.980 --> 00:09:01.310
But instead just say, look, I want to
block it coming outbound instead, okay?

141
00:09:02.380 --> 00:09:07.150
So, if I block it out-bound,
in this theory, in theory at least,

142
00:09:07.150 --> 00:09:10.390
right, it would actually
go through the router.

143
00:09:10.390 --> 00:09:16.661
And then at g0/1, it would also
run across the access-group 10,

144
00:09:16.661 --> 00:09:21.270
it would match up to 192.168.16.10.

145
00:09:21.270 --> 00:09:25.040
And it would actually be denied out.

146
00:09:25.040 --> 00:09:29.050
So in other words, it would block
it from leaving the interface.

147
00:09:29.050 --> 00:09:33.524
So maybe that's a better syntax
to actually use either going

148
00:09:33.524 --> 00:09:36.190
into the interface is inbound.

149
00:09:36.190 --> 00:09:41.420
And then outbound or out at the end
is leaving in the interface, okay?

150
00:09:41.420 --> 00:09:45.250
So I might chose instead to do that, okay?

151
00:09:45.250 --> 00:09:50.160
And that would effectively block me
from getting access to Practicelabs.com.

152
00:09:50.160 --> 00:09:53.590
But notice it would also allow me do what,
to go through and

153
00:09:53.590 --> 00:09:55.550
get access to ourpartner.com.

154
00:09:55.550 --> 00:09:59.863
And that's exactly what I need,
I need to able to get access here but

155
00:09:59.863 --> 00:10:01.560
not to here, okay?

156
00:10:01.560 --> 00:10:06.590
So I could actually choose either way, but
this is where it comes with experience and

157
00:10:06.590 --> 00:10:07.880
with practice.

158
00:10:07.880 --> 00:10:12.260
It's nothing that you learn immediately or
right away until you practice it and

159
00:10:12.260 --> 00:10:16.740
until you see it, of where would be
the most effective place to put it.

160
00:10:16.740 --> 00:10:22.000
But there is a, I don't know what to
call it, it's not even a rule of thumb.

161
00:10:22.000 --> 00:10:25.961
There is essentially Cisco best practices.

162
00:10:25.961 --> 00:10:28.886
And that means they're not
written down anywhere,

163
00:10:28.886 --> 00:10:33.820
there's no documentation that absolutely
says it has to be this way, okay?

164
00:10:33.820 --> 00:10:38.780
But in theory, the way that Cisco
seems to provide it here, right?

165
00:10:38.780 --> 00:10:42.730
Is that if we create
a standard access list,

166
00:10:42.730 --> 00:10:46.160
not an extended access list,
but a standard access list.

167
00:10:53.690 --> 00:10:54.426
The closest that we can put it
to the destination network,okay?

168
00:10:54.426 --> 00:10:57.792
In other words, the closest that we can
put that access list to the destination

169
00:10:57.792 --> 00:11:00.530
network that is the place that
standard access list should be.

170
00:11:00.530 --> 00:11:05.680
>> Because it allows for
this type of connection to still go on

171
00:11:05.680 --> 00:11:11.090
while blocking that specific connection
because only based on the source.

172
00:11:11.090 --> 00:11:14.540
So that means that there is
a canvas to this as well as that.

173
00:11:14.540 --> 00:11:17.730
If I create an extended access control
list, which we haven't talked about,

174
00:11:17.730 --> 00:11:19.740
but we'll mention it right now.

175
00:11:19.740 --> 00:11:24.206
Extended access control lists,
take into account those source and

176
00:11:24.206 --> 00:11:26.644
destination, as well as protocol.

177
00:11:26.644 --> 00:11:31.760
Well that one, we wanna put it as
close to the source as possible.

178
00:11:31.760 --> 00:11:36.626
Because, at that point, we can filter
out either the source address, or, and

179
00:11:36.626 --> 00:11:38.596
the destination, right then.

180
00:11:38.596 --> 00:11:42.130
Before it actually has to go
through the router any further.

181
00:11:42.130 --> 00:11:44.300
So that's what you want to do there.

182
00:11:44.300 --> 00:11:49.770
So extend it as close to the source as
possible but add the idea of standard

183
00:11:49.770 --> 00:11:55.970
ones, we want it as far away, or closer
to the destination, as possible as well.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie show how to configure a Named Access list.  The team remind us that though emphasis is on Standard ACLs, it is not the only ACLs to be configured.  They demonstrate how to configure it and that it has the same functionality as previously configured lists too.
episodes.title: Configure Standard Access Lists Part 3

Empowering the world with engaging

And now you're probably wondering

Not so much that as much as

just configuring standard

control lists as well as named

So in this episode we are going to be,

So we're using the same lab topology.

remember the difference here when

28

In a standard access control list
