IP address okay,
that's all we're concerned about, okay?

30

It doesn't take into account

We're only concerned about that,

lists are much more flexible in the very

35

even port number, depending on how

36

we're talking about.
>> Mm-hm.

37

>> But the great thing is,

that's kinda one of the big differences.

39

The other thing of course,

40

In a standard access control list,

1 through 99, and then beginning with

00:02:17.581 --> 00:02:21.209
it's 100 through 199,

00:02:21.209 --> 00:02:24.621
I wanna make sure I'm telling you about,
yes, no, yeah, it's 100 or

101 through 199,
I don't know why I forget that number, but

45
00:02:27.708 --> 00:02:30.540
it's something that you can look up and
verify.

46
00:02:30.540 --> 00:02:33.731
So just remember that that's
what you're normally seeing, so

47
00:02:33.731 --> 00:02:36.523
those are kind of the numbers
that we're dealing with.

48
00:02:36.523 --> 00:02:41.240
So anytime, actually a very good kind of
easy exam kind of points that you might

get is, how do you know this is
an extended access control list, or

50
00:02:45.242 --> 00:02:48.890
how do you know this is
a standard access control list?

51
00:02:48.890 --> 00:02:50.660
Well you can just look at the numbers.

52
00:02:50.660 --> 00:02:53.200
That's probably actually a good point or
two,

53

and it's actually real easy cuz

54
00:02:56.380 --> 00:02:59.450
So imagine just getting a question right

55
00:02:59.450 --> 00:03:03.610
between 1 in 99 and then 101 through 199,

56
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:07.500
that would be cool if I

57
00:03:07.500 --> 00:03:11.290
And you can, you can get points

58
00:03:11.290 --> 00:03:12.100
>> That is cool.

59
00:03:12.100 --> 00:03:15.240
>> So now when we start here, okay, we're

60

gonna set up this particular scenario, and
this is why it's actually so flexible.

61
00:03:20.150 --> 00:03:23.270
So, remember that I just said
that it really doesn't matter,

00:03:23.270 --> 00:03:27.750
okay, that as we took a look at this

00:03:27.750 --> 00:03:32.160
right, I wanted to block access

But what if I didn't wanna

00:03:34.930 --> 00:03:36.550
Well, I couldn't do that

controller.
>> No.

67
00:03:37.660 --> 00:03:39.140
>> Except by placement, okay.

68
00:03:39.140 --> 00:03:42.850
Only by placement have I actually moved it
from one interface to another, did I have

00:03:42.850 --> 00:03:48.400
that hope of doing so, but even in RSS

70

But with extended access control list,
here's what I can set up.

71

Once again, we're going to our global
configuration mode which is fine,

72
00:03:58.131 --> 00:04:01.824
access-list 110,
I just chose this number here.

73
00:04:01.824 --> 00:04:04.886
Then we're gonna permit and then,

I select the protocol first,
so what am I permitting?

75
00:04:09.630 --> 00:04:13.570
TCP is probably one of the more common
ones that you see, you can also do UDP but

76
00:04:13.570 --> 00:04:17.300
you wanna everything,
it's usually gonna be IP,

77
00:04:17.300 --> 00:04:20.090
IP is everything cuz it's TCPIP, okay?

78
00:04:20.090 --> 00:04:24.260
So you can actually permit everything,
but here, we're just saying TCP and

79
00:04:24.260 --> 00:04:27.400
now the source address, okay?

80
00:04:27.400 --> 00:04:31.832
Notice as the host which is an alias for
this one IP,

81
00:04:31.832 --> 00:04:38.845
192.168.16.10, the destination I have any,
which is a match for

82
00:04:38.845 --> 00:04:43.809
anything that it wants to go to
as long as it equals to FTP.

83
00:04:43.809 --> 00:04:45.567
So this allows me to say, hey,

84
00:04:45.567 --> 00:04:49.897
I want to actually make sure that if I
connect any place that I'm gonna do it,

85
00:04:49.897 --> 00:04:52.214
as long as it's equal to FTP.
>> Mm-hm.

86
00:04:52.214 --> 00:04:54.830
>> Okay, so that one protocol.

87
00:04:54.830 --> 00:04:58.400
Now FTP doesn't function only by itself.

88
00:04:58.400 --> 00:05:02.600
FTP is one of these rare occasions where

89
00:05:02.600 --> 00:05:06.594
actually there's two port numbers for
FTP, 20 and 21, okay?

90
00:05:06.594 --> 00:05:09.907
So the second line is
essentially the same thing, but

91
00:05:09.907 --> 00:05:13.370
this line allows us to

92
00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:18.220
That's exactly the same but notice there

93
00:05:18.220 --> 00:05:22.420
Now you can actually enter in the port

94
00:05:22.420 --> 00:05:25.160
21 here is technically what it is.

95
00:05:25.160 --> 00:05:26.900
But a lot of times if you take a look and

96
00:05:26.900 --> 00:05:30.820
you do the question mark,
at the end list, it will list,

97
00:05:30.820 --> 00:05:35.320
usually of course, the protocol and
not necessarily the port number.

98
00:05:35.320 --> 00:05:37.280
So you'll actually see that too.

99
00:05:37.280 --> 00:05:40.540
Okay, now the other thing
behind this stuff,okay.

100
00:05:40.540 --> 00:05:44.620
Is that if I go anywhere,
I want to only connect on FTP, but

101
00:05:44.620 --> 00:05:50.120
my third line in this
actually says deny ICMP.

102
00:05:50.120 --> 00:05:55.389
Okay, which means prevent the Internet
control messaging protocol.

103
00:05:55.389 --> 00:06:00.171
For you and me, that's actually quit a bit

104
00:06:00.171 --> 00:06:04.651
to do is just trying to deny ping, what
we're denying everything in ICNP instead.

105
00:06:04.651 --> 00:06:09.231
So notice this Zach in one
access control list I'm actually

106
00:06:09.231 --> 00:06:12.790
not only limiting or restricting, okay?

107
00:06:12.790 --> 00:06:16.530
That one IP address permitting
it to go out on FTP but

108
00:06:16.530 --> 00:06:19.990
then on that same access control
list I'm actually saying.

109
00:06:19.990 --> 00:06:22.920
But if you try and
connect, if 192.168.16.10,

110
00:06:22.920 --> 00:06:28.590
try to connect using ping or
anything an ICNP, deny, okay?

111
00:06:28.590 --> 00:06:31.245
So that is how specific it actually is.

112
00:06:31.245 --> 00:06:36.457
Now, it even allows me to do it to a
specific host, so here in this third line,

113
00:06:36.457 --> 00:06:41.436
notice I'm actually saying,
as long as 192.168.16.10 is

114
00:06:41.436 --> 00:06:46.430
trying to go to 172.15.0.10 using ping,
okay, then deny.

115
00:06:46.430 --> 00:06:48.100
But what about every other thing?

116
00:06:48.100 --> 00:06:51.530
Well, that is where
the fourth line comes in.

117
00:06:51.530 --> 00:06:57.170
Even at the end of extended access control
lists, there is that implicit Deny all.

118
00:06:57.170 --> 00:07:01.150
Okay, essentially, for us here, deny any
to any is what we're actually saying here,

119
00:07:01.150 --> 00:07:05.250
and now you can see that here
on access-list 110 permit,

120
00:07:05.250 --> 00:07:10.160
and I say ip which means
every other protocol

121
00:07:10.160 --> 00:07:15.710
that's actually represented from
any place going to any place.

122
00:07:15.710 --> 00:07:19.060
And that says hey,
allow any other traffic to go through.

123
00:07:19.060 --> 00:07:22.040
But here's what I'm
restricting at this point.

124
00:07:22.040 --> 00:07:26.720
If I do not put this fourth statement in
here, that is automatically gonna say,

125
00:07:26.720 --> 00:07:28.910
deny everything else.

126
00:07:28.910 --> 00:07:33.000
Which, at this point,
means only connect on FTP.

127
00:07:33.000 --> 00:07:36.700
We do the same thing,
we still have to apply it to an interface.

128
00:07:36.700 --> 00:07:40.000
So here we're doing the same thing,
and this time we're gonna apply that

129
00:07:40.000 --> 00:07:44.770
best practice where we take an extended
access control list, and we apply it as

130
00:07:44.770 --> 00:07:49.340
close to the source as possible, where the
best practice with standard access control

131
00:07:49.340 --> 00:07:53.240
lists is to apply it as close
to the destination as possible.

132
00:07:53.240 --> 00:07:57.367
But remember, that doesn't always apply
just like we showed you in our previous

133
00:07:57.367 --> 00:07:58.890
configuration here, okay?

134
00:07:58.890 --> 00:08:02.540
So this is what we'll be setting
up in our lab as we do so,

135
00:08:02.540 --> 00:08:03.264
okay?
>> Okay.

136
00:08:03.264 --> 00:08:06.557
All right, so
we're gonna go over NYEDGE1 here, and

137
00:08:06.557 --> 00:08:09.320
we are going to start right here again.

138
00:08:09.320 --> 00:08:13.590
And the only thing that I've actually done
a little bit differently is I've removed

139
00:08:13.590 --> 00:08:18.750
the last access list from
that interface that we did

140
00:08:18.750 --> 00:08:20.510
from the previous lab that we were doing.

141
00:08:20.510 --> 00:08:25.210
Okay, so no IP access-group 10,
I've removed it off the interface.

142
00:08:25.210 --> 00:08:28.190
The list is still there, so
I'm not getting rid of the list.

143
00:08:28.190 --> 00:08:30.520
I've just removed it off that interface,
and

144
00:08:30.520 --> 00:08:34.110
now we're ready to configure this
extended access control list.

145
00:08:34.110 --> 00:08:35.990
So let's go ahead and get access in.

146
00:08:35.990 --> 00:08:40.720
And we'll get into, of course,
the global configuration mode.

147
00:08:43.850 --> 00:08:45.146
Unless I'm in here,

00:08:45.146 --> 00:08:49.114
now we can begin configuring this
extended access control list.

149
00:08:49.114 --> 00:08:54.060
So access-list, and
we'll do the same thing here.

150
00:08:54.060 --> 00:08:57.110
Let's go ahead and do a question mark,
cuz I didn't show you this and

151
00:08:57.110 --> 00:08:59.740
this is how you can see what
the number are and verify.

152
00:08:59.740 --> 00:09:01.599
So I was wrong when I said
a little bit earlier it was 101.

153
00:09:01.599 --> 00:09:04.380
Notice it shows me right away.

154
00:09:04.380 --> 00:09:08.270
Okay, 1 through 99 and 100 through 99,

155
00:09:08.270 --> 00:09:12.010
it is either the extended or
the standard here.

156
00:09:12.010 --> 00:09:15.960
So I chose 110 just as a little bit

157
00:09:15.960 --> 00:09:20.850
110, I know that that's right there inside

158
00:09:20.850 --> 00:09:23.710
But you could see some of the other
ones that have been set up there from

00:09:23.710 --> 00:09:25.330
ages past, right?

00:09:25.330 --> 00:09:27.290
So notice even DECnet is listed here.

161
00:09:27.290 --> 00:09:31.690
Again, the network that's actually no
longer something that we end up using.

162
00:09:31.690 --> 00:09:33.680
And then there's even other
ranges that are out there, but

163
00:09:33.680 --> 00:09:37.390
for us,
we're really gonna stick right here, okay?

164
00:09:37.390 --> 00:09:41.720
Now, there is an extension list
when they actually went beyond 100.

165
00:09:41.720 --> 00:09:45.710
Notice that if you go up
to 1300 through 1999 here,

166
00:09:45.710 --> 00:09:47.860
that is an expanded range for extended.

167
00:09:47.860 --> 00:09:52.421
So they added in an extra 699, too, and

00:09:52.421 --> 00:10:00.300
then 2000 through 2699 is
the extended range for extended ones.

169
00:10:00.300 --> 00:10:02.650
I'm sure somebody out there is using it.

170
00:10:02.650 --> 00:10:04.420
I'm not gonna use it, okay?

171
00:10:04.420 --> 00:10:06.350
So I'm not gonna worry about it.

172
00:10:06.350 --> 00:10:10.398
All right, so
let's do access-list 110, okay?

173
00:10:10.398 --> 00:10:14.595
Now that I have access to
access-list 110 at this point,

174
00:10:14.595 --> 00:10:20.410
I of course now need to decide whether
I'm permitting or denying it, okay?

175
00:10:20.410 --> 00:10:23.010
So let's go ahead and take a look.

176
00:10:23.010 --> 00:10:24.490
Just got to spell access right.

177
00:10:24.490 --> 00:10:25.209
How is that?

178
00:10:25.209 --> 00:10:28.159
Access-list 110.

179
00:10:28.159 --> 00:10:30.520
And we'll just hit this along the way.

180
00:10:30.520 --> 00:10:31.590
Now, this is a good practice.

181
00:10:31.590 --> 00:10:35.500
I know it seems long and extraneous as I'm
explaining it, but it's good practice for

182
00:10:35.500 --> 00:10:38.020
you to do this so
that you know what the options are.

183
00:10:38.020 --> 00:10:39.590
And it doesn't hurt for you to go back and

184
00:10:39.590 --> 00:10:41.950

options as you do this.

185
00:10:41.950 --> 00:10:47.365
So at this point,
we are going to permit access-list 110,

186
00:10:47.365 --> 00:10:51.290
and we are going to permit at this point.

187
00:10:51.290 --> 00:10:55.670
Then we actually have to
choose a protocol, okay?

188
00:10:55.670 --> 00:11:00.410
Now notice that there are a bunch of
different protocols that we can choose.

189
00:11:00.410 --> 00:11:04.060
Now some of these are routing protocols

190
00:11:04.060 --> 00:11:06.800
We're interested in traffic primarily.

191
00:11:06.800 --> 00:11:12.600
For us, it's usually TCP or
UDP or IP up here.

192
00:11:12.600 --> 00:11:17.330
And in a moment,
we'll also configure ICMP as well.

193
00:11:17.330 --> 00:11:19.040
So that's another possibility.

194
00:11:19.040 --> 00:11:22.010
But those are normally the ones that we're
actually going to be dealing with at

195
00:11:22.010 --> 00:11:22.980
this point.

196
00:11:22.980 --> 00:11:31.180
So we instead are gonna do access-list
permit, copy that down here.

197
00:11:31.180 --> 00:11:34.395
This time we're gonna do TCP,

198
00:11:36.502 --> 00:11:40.298
Then I'm going to choose host,
192.168.16.10.

199
00:11:40.298 --> 00:11:42.660
All right, so
now what I need here, of course,

200
00:11:42.660 --> 00:11:44.982
is gonna be the destination address,
right?

201
00:11:44.982 --> 00:11:49.320
So I wanna actually allow it to go any
place, which is perfectly fine, so

202
00:11:49.320 --> 00:11:52.130
I can use that alias instead,
which is any.

203
00:11:52.130 --> 00:11:55.590
Now of course, at the very end,
I need this unusual word here.

204
00:11:55.590 --> 00:11:59.530
Let me go ahead and do a question mark so
that we can see what happened, okay?

205
00:11:59.530 --> 00:12:02.730
So after we actually
select the destination,

206
00:12:02.730 --> 00:12:08.750
notice I have an EQ match only
packets on a given port number.

207
00:12:08.750 --> 00:12:10.374
That is what I'm
specifically trying to do.

208
00:12:10.374 --> 00:12:12.420
I don't wanna allow all TCP.

209
00:12:12.420 --> 00:12:16.850
I only really want to allow FTP
which is a TCP protocol, right,

210
00:12:16.850 --> 00:12:18.820
it's one of the subprotocols under there.

211
00:12:18.820 --> 00:12:20.327
I want to be able to do that.

212
00:12:20.327 --> 00:12:23.182
So I'm gonna choose EQ right here instead.

213
00:12:23.182 --> 00:12:29.810
Let me copy that and kinda paste that
back in here and make that work.

214
00:12:31.360 --> 00:12:35.180
Then this is where we get
a list of protocols, okay?

215
00:12:35.180 --> 00:12:39.230
So notice now, if I go ahead and
fill this all out,

216
00:12:39.230 --> 00:12:43.175
you can see where it doesn't seem to
list a bunch of port numbers over here.

217
00:12:43.175 --> 00:12:46.438
And you can see, there's the one that
we're talking about, which is 21 and 22.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie conclude the ACL configuration by taking a named access list and apply it to a virtual interface.  They show how applying the an ACL is different on a virtual interface and how to verify it's working.

joining me in this little
epic mini marathon that we

14
00:00:35.740 --> 00:00:36.875
are doing.
>> It's epic.

15
00:00:36.875 --> 00:00:39.425
The idea of different access list, right?

16
00:00:39.425 --> 00:00:43.315
I just got lazy in the naming
convention here, but it is about,

17
00:00:43.315 --> 00:00:45.215
of course, access control list.

18
00:00:45.215 --> 00:00:48.675
And officially on the exam, I know you've
probably heard me say it if you've been

19
00:00:48.675 --> 00:00:52.315
watching the series through over and
over again, but they really do only

20
00:00:52.315 --> 00:00:57.175
emphasize standard access control lists,
at least on the exam objectives.

21
00:00:57.175 --> 00:01:02.790
But I can't tell you, that they only
limit themselves to showing you that.

22
00:01:02.790 --> 00:01:04.180
So instead we're showing
you the whole gamut.

23
00:01:04.180 --> 00:01:07.500
Now, we're not explaining
everything in the utmost detail.

24
00:01:07.500 --> 00:01:08.900
We're showing you bits and pieces of it.

25
00:01:08.900 --> 00:01:12.381
And we spend a little bit more time,
of course, on the standard one and

26
00:01:12.381 --> 00:01:13.449

27
00:01:13.449 --> 00:01:16.490
Here we are now going into
named access control lists.

28
00:01:16.490 --> 00:01:18.110
Now, we're starting to see more and

29
00:01:18.110 --> 00:01:20.840
more popularity with the named
access control list.

30
00:01:20.840 --> 00:01:24.110
And the reason why is that
there is a lot less redundancy

31
00:01:24.110 --> 00:01:26.480
when working with the named
access controller list, but

32
00:01:26.480 --> 00:01:29.840
also we're not limited by numbers anymore,
right.

33
00:01:29.840 --> 00:01:32.530
So, inside that number group, right,
standard access controller list,

34
00:01:32.530 --> 00:01:35.900
we have 1 through 99,
okay essentially is what we have.

35
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:39.830
And then once you do that,
then you can jump up to 1300 through 1999,

36
00:01:39.830 --> 00:01:42.900
so another 700 or 699 in it, okay.

37
00:01:42.900 --> 00:01:45.890
And then with the extended
access controller list,

38
00:01:45.890 --> 00:01:48.380
you go from 100 through 199.

39
00:01:48.380 --> 00:01:53.560
And then you jump up there from 2000,
I think, to 2699.

40
00:01:53.560 --> 00:01:57.770
So they've actually kind of added
in additional ones that they have

41
00:01:57.770 --> 00:01:59.040
out there, okay.

42
00:01:59.040 --> 00:02:01.600
So on these,
you do still see a lot of them.

43
00:02:01.600 --> 00:02:04.030
That's because that was
their limitation and

44
00:02:04.030 --> 00:02:09.520
what they had to do in the earliest
days of the IOS and how they did this.

45
00:02:09.520 --> 00:02:12.510
Now there's a problem with them though,
too, okay.

46
00:02:12.510 --> 00:02:16.050
In these types of numbered access control
lists that we have, as you started

47
00:02:16.050 --> 00:02:19.840
building them for your routers and for
your networks, they got pretty long.

48
00:02:19.840 --> 00:02:22.880
And there's also something else
that was problematic, as well.

49
00:02:22.880 --> 00:02:28.240
It wasn't easy to remove a single entry
in those lists or to reconfigure them.

50
00:02:28.240 --> 00:02:30.970
It was a lot more difficult
to reconfigure them.

51
00:02:30.970 --> 00:02:34.890
A lot of times, if you had this, you had
to actually show like every single one,

52
00:02:34.890 --> 00:02:38.940
by doing a show access list,
getting every single one out of there, and

53
00:02:38.940 --> 00:02:41.690
then you could modify what you wanted, and

54
00:02:41.690 --> 00:02:45.350
then you'd have to paste the whole
thing back into the router to do so.

55
00:02:45.350 --> 00:02:48.250

00:29:15.680 --> 00:29:18.030
you're gonna be very happy that you did.

508
00:29:18.030 --> 00:29:20.930
And by the way, you'll be in the course
library where there's thousands of other

509
00:29:20.930 --> 00:29:23.470
videos that are there
to help you go further.

510
00:29:23.470 --> 00:29:24.619
Check those out, too.

511
00:29:24.619 --> 00:29:27.560
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

512
00:29:27.560 --> 00:29:29.470
ITProTV is binge worthy.

513
00:29:29.470 --> 00:29:30.150
Thanks for watching.

514
00:29:30.150 --> 00:29:31.882
I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

515
00:29:31.882 --> 00:29:34.122
>> And we will see you again very soon.

516
00:29:34.122 --> 00:29:40.188
[MUSIC]

517
00:29:40.188 --> 00:29:44.546
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie introduce the concept of NAT--Network Address Translation.  They describe the different ways to implement it and begin to configure Static NAT.
episodes.title: Configure NAT
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:05.810
Welcome to ITPRO.TV I'm
your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:05.810 --> 00:00:08.179
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.179 --> 00:00:12.945
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.
>> Hello and thank you for

4
00:00:12.945 --> 00:00:16.010
choosing ITPRO.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:16.010 --> 00:00:20.770
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with Cisco CCENT.

6
00:00:20.770 --> 00:00:24.040
This particular episode,
we're going to configure NAT.

7
00:00:24.040 --> 00:00:24.880
What's that?

8
00:00:24.880 --> 00:00:26.360
Well, let's find out, shall we?

9
00:00:26.360 --> 00:00:27.750
And Ronnie Wong is here to tell us.

10
00:00:27.750 --> 00:00:30.080
Ronnie, good to see you, sir.
>> Thank you, Zach, for

11
00:00:30.080 --> 00:00:34.200
letting me back on the show as we continue
on in our CCENT journey together.

12
00:00:34.200 --> 00:00:37.150
We are now at that point where
we're gonna be configuring NAT,

13
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:40.370
which is Network Address Translation.

14
00:00:40.370 --> 00:00:44.220
Now, this is the technology,
we spoke about this during our networking

15
00:00:44.220 --> 00:00:48.430
fundamentals, where we talked about,
there's three basic technologies

16
00:00:48.430 --> 00:00:53.660
that really help slow down the depletion
of IP version four addressing

17
00:00:53.660 --> 00:00:56.860
from really just disappearing
quicker than they needed it to.

18
00:00:56.860 --> 00:00:59.770
And the reason why this is
important is because without it

19
00:00:59.770 --> 00:01:01.928
today in the way that networking works,

20
00:01:01.928 --> 00:01:07.890
it actually will not allow you to connect
out to network directly anymore, since we

21
00:01:07.890 --> 00:01:13.352
use a combination of what we call private
IP addresses and public IP addresses.

22
00:01:13.352 --> 00:01:18.050
So NAT, Network Address Translation,
is one of those three technologies that

23
00:01:18.050 --> 00:01:24.330
really did help us to slow down the actual
depletion of those IP version four.

24
00:01:24.330 --> 00:01:30.240
That, along with variable link subnet
masking, is also what we also did here,

25
00:01:30.240 --> 00:01:33.540
too, and of course,
the use of private IP addresses.

26
00:01:33.540 --> 00:01:37.796
So along with the idea of network address
translations that allow us to take,

27
00:01:37.796 --> 00:01:42.760
well at least practically,
take private IP addresses and

28
00:01:42.760 --> 00:01:45.890
translate them into public IP addresses.

29
00:01:45.890 --> 00:01:50.640
Using the router to help us to do that,
it actually allows us to again,

30
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:53.374
be able to get access to
the internet today, is what it does.

31
00:01:53.374 --> 00:01:56.091
>> So we wouldn't use NAT or IPv6?.

32
00:01:56.091 --> 00:01:58.397
>> Yes, there is a NAT if you need it, but

33
00:01:58.397 --> 00:02:02.160
most of the time in IPv6,
you're not gonna need it any more.

34
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:06.110
So today, what ends up happening
is that if you choose to

35
00:02:06.110 --> 00:02:09.170
I think you can still do it but
it's probably not recommended.

36
00:02:09.170 --> 00:02:12.760
So there's probably a configuration for
it but the way that we tend to work with

37
00:02:12.760 --> 00:02:15.740
addresses especially in this
environment and IP version six,

38
00:02:15.740 --> 00:02:20.000
you're probably not gonna need
to ever visit that at all.

39
00:02:20.000 --> 00:02:25.680
So one of the ideas behind IPv6 is you can
drop NAT and it doesn't bother it all.

40
00:02:25.680 --> 00:02:28.970
But since we're still in IPv4 and
we're preparing for

41
00:02:28.970 --> 00:02:30.890
our CCENT exam-
>> Right on.

42
00:02:30.890 --> 00:02:32.600
>> We wanna make sure that we understand,

43
00:02:32.600 --> 00:02:36.090
of course, the concept of
network address translation.

44
00:02:36.090 --> 00:02:40.500
And of course, the idea here of that
there's several different things that we

45
00:02:40.500 --> 00:02:43.230
have to get done and
the configuration of it.

46
00:02:43.230 --> 00:02:47.940
So let me start by explaining
the idea of what NAT does for

47
00:02:47.940 --> 00:02:50.810
us, which is using three
different methods.

48
00:02:50.810 --> 00:02:54.650
And it again, happened along in
the development of the technology,

49
00:02:54.650 --> 00:02:56.250
is what happened.

50
00:02:56.250 --> 00:03:02.430
So when we start to talk about it, there's
three main differences that we can do.

51
00:03:02.430 --> 00:03:05.910
One is what we call a static
NAT translation, and

52
00:03:05.910 --> 00:03:08.740
that is a direct one to one translation.

53
00:03:08.740 --> 00:03:11.910
That means if I have
a single private IP address,

54
00:03:11.910 --> 00:03:16.620
I can translate it into a single
public IP address in practicality.

55
00:03:16.620 --> 00:03:18.820
Now do I have to always use public and
private?

56
00:03:18.820 --> 00:03:21.650
No, you can actually translate
private to private or

57
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:23.620
public to public if you choose to.

58
00:03:23.620 --> 00:03:24.670
It depends on what you need, but

59
00:03:24.670 --> 00:03:29.140
the most practical example is private
IP address to public IP address.

60
00:03:29.140 --> 00:03:31.060
So static NAT is available.

61
00:03:31.060 --> 00:03:34.250
So hold off, we’ll talk about
why we would choose to do that.

62
00:03:34.250 --> 00:03:37.750
Then, there is also what’s
called dynamic NAT.

63
00:03:37.750 --> 00:03:42.667
Dynamic NAT allows me to take all of
the addresses inside of my network that

64
00:03:42.667 --> 00:03:43.947
I have available.

65
00:03:43.947 --> 00:03:48.905
So let's say, for an example, I have a
class C local area network, and if I do so

66
00:03:48.905 --> 00:03:51.370
I have 254 addresses.

67
00:03:51.370 --> 00:03:57.303
But from the ISP, let's say I only
got four public IP addresses or so.

68
00:03:57.303 --> 00:03:59.892
If I only got four public IP addresses,

69
00:03:59.892 --> 00:04:04.057
I can't get a translation to
every single one of those 254.

70
00:04:04.057 --> 00:04:08.791
But what I can create is a pool of
those four public IP addresses, and

71
00:04:08.791 --> 00:04:14.920
then have up to four connections going
out through that router at any one time.

72
00:04:14.920 --> 00:04:18.840
If a fifth one comes along though,
one of those four has to drop.

73
00:04:18.840 --> 00:04:22.570
If it doesn't,
then they aren't gonna get a connection.

74
00:04:22.570 --> 00:04:26.394
But normally, and the most prevalent
one that is used today is what we call,

75
00:04:26.394 --> 00:04:31.270
it's called NAT overload,
it is technically Cisco, the way that we

76
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:35.760
call it, but you'll hear it more commonly
called PAT or Port Address Translation.

77
00:04:36.810 --> 00:04:40.230
When we start doing something
like Port Address Translation,

78
00:04:40.230 --> 00:04:45.050
this allows me to take all the addresses
that I need internally and it attaches

79
00:04:45.050 --> 00:04:51.500
a port number to them, and then I can
overload a single public IP address.

80
00:04:51.500 --> 00:04:56.872
So if I have 254 nodes,
they can exit out of my router interface.

81
00:04:56.872 --> 00:05:02.390
And to the Internet, It just appears as
one IP address, is what is ends up doing.

82
00:05:02.390 --> 00:05:07.296
So all of that is possible and
in today's world, if I know that my local

83
00:05:07.296 --> 00:05:11.789
area network is running a private
IP address scheme of any sort,

84
00:05:11.789 --> 00:05:15.034
whether that's anything
in the ten network,

85
00:05:15.034 --> 00:05:21.382
anything in the 172.16 all the way
through 17231, or 192168 network.

86
00:05:21.382 --> 00:05:25.347
Any of those, if that's the way
my network prefix begins,

87
00:05:25.347 --> 00:05:30.104
then I know that somewhere before me,
before I get out to the Internet,

88
00:05:30.104 --> 00:05:33.147
that I'm actually going to get translated.

89
00:05:33.147 --> 00:05:36.830
I'm gonna have that Network Address
Translation ending up working.

90
00:05:36.830 --> 00:05:41.210
So usually at least at the CCENT level,
at CCENT level,

91
00:05:41.210 --> 00:05:46.510
if there's anything on the basic
configuration side that stops end to end

92
00:05:46.510 --> 00:05:51.500
connection or connectivity for you and me,
especially we go out across the internet,

93
00:05:51.500 --> 00:05:55.470
it's going to be because
we didn't configure NAT.

94
00:05:55.470 --> 00:05:59.420
The great thing is, more than likely you
and I are probably not gonna have to

95
00:05:59.420 --> 00:06:02.400
configure it but we do need to
understand how it's configured.

96
00:06:02.400 --> 00:06:05.360
We need to understand the translation
of it because most of the time,

97
00:06:05.360 --> 00:06:06.660
that's gonna be one of the primary things.

98
00:06:06.660 --> 00:06:10.283
But in a lab setting, if you tried
to build this up and go, brother,

99
00:06:10.283 --> 00:06:14.559
I know that this is how these routers
are connected together, and I can do this.

100
00:06:14.559 --> 00:06:18.573
But if I try and reach another network
that I'm not directly connected to, well,

101
00:06:18.573 --> 00:06:19.911
I'm gonna also need NAT and

102
00:06:19.911 --> 00:06:23.370
routing to also be implemented to
make sure that that ends up working.

103
00:06:23.370 --> 00:06:26.860
So for us on the Internet,
it is impossible for

104
00:06:26.860 --> 00:06:31.230
us to actually be able to put a private
IP address out on the Internet.

105
00:06:31.230 --> 00:06:32.095
It's just impossible.

106
00:06:32.095 --> 00:06:37.797
And if an ISP gets found out that they
let a private IP address on the Internet,

107
00:06:37.797 --> 00:06:40.270
it's gonna be a bad day for them.

108
00:06:40.270 --> 00:06:44.840
So usually they tell us like, you know,
use whatever private IP addresses, but

109
00:06:44.840 --> 00:06:50.000
make sure you turn on NAT on your
particular perimeter router, and

110
00:06:50.000 --> 00:06:51.590
let that end up happening.

111
00:06:51.590 --> 00:06:52.980
So the great thing is today though,

112
00:06:52.980 --> 00:06:57.600
we've got a lab that we're gonna end up
using, and I've got a couple of diagrams

113
00:06:57.600 --> 00:07:02.580
that's gonna help support the concept
of what we end up seeing here too.

114
00:07:02.580 --> 00:07:06.660
Now depending on which NAT that we do,
and we're gonna

115
00:07:06.660 --> 00:07:09.778
do a sample of all three of them,
is what we're going to do here, Zack.

116
00:07:09.778 --> 00:07:13.440
But we're gonna start off with of course,
static NAT.

117
00:07:13.440 --> 00:07:14.890
And you're gonna see that NAT,

118
00:07:14.890 --> 00:07:19.050
just like access control lists,
there's a couple of parts to them.

119
00:07:19.050 --> 00:07:21.040
So if you remember the idea
of access control lists,

120
00:07:21.040 --> 00:07:25.480
we can configure the access control lists
but that doesn't make it do anything.

121
00:07:25.480 --> 00:07:28.760
I then have to apply
that to an interface and

122
00:07:28.760 --> 00:07:31.080
then also I have to apply
directionality to that.

123
00:07:31.080 --> 00:07:35.345
But once I apply it to an interface,
then that is what allows that particular

124
00:07:35.345 --> 00:07:42.620
address access control list to
actually get applied and work.

125
00:07:42.620 --> 00:07:45.720
In Network Address Translation
you have to decide two things.

126
00:07:45.720 --> 00:07:50.020
You have to decide what the NAT is
going to be and how to configure it.

127
00:07:50.020 --> 00:07:51.260
So that's first.

128
00:07:51.260 --> 00:07:57.094
And then, you have to be able to
state which way the NAT is working.

129
00:07:57.094 --> 00:08:00.815
So let's take a look at the diagram,
and this will help us out, and

130
00:08:00.815 --> 00:08:02.814
then we'll do the configuration.

131
00:08:02.814 --> 00:08:06.063
So up at the top of the screen
I have Static NAT here.

132
00:08:06.063 --> 00:08:08.435
And we're gonna be using
some of these addresses so

133
00:08:08.435 --> 00:08:10.156
I tried to keep them fairly similar.

134
00:08:10.156 --> 00:08:12.862
So let's take, for an example,

135
00:08:12.862 --> 00:08:17.830
we're gonna actually have 192.168.16.10.

136
00:08:17.830 --> 00:08:23.380
And I need to get to this,
172.15.0.10 over here.

137
00:08:23.380 --> 00:08:27.930
Or practice-labs.com,
www.practice-labs.com.

138
00:08:27.930 --> 00:08:32.770
Now, when I do so, on one interface
it's gonna be 192.168.16.1,

139
00:08:32.770 --> 00:08:35.630
which is gonna be gigabyte 0/0.

140
00:08:35.630 --> 00:08:39.150
And then of course, 172.14.

141
00:08:39.150 --> 00:08:43.240
Do not be fooled by this address here.

142
00:08:43.240 --> 00:08:44.797
You may go, hey, wait a minute,

143
00:08:44.797 --> 00:08:48.316
that's a private IP address cuz I
remember something in the 172 range.

144
00:08:48.316 --> 00:08:53.708
But this is not 172.16 going
all the way through 172.31.

145
00:08:53.708 --> 00:08:59.640
This is 172.14, so technically this
is going to be a public IP address.

146
00:08:59.640 --> 00:09:03.560
Now we're using it as just an example
inside of our lab here, but

147
00:09:03.560 --> 00:09:04.850
that's what you'll end up seeing.

148
00:09:05.900 --> 00:09:10.530
So the first thing that we want to do
is that on the interface here, and

149
00:09:10.530 --> 00:09:13.705
we're configuring it right here
at the beginning because that way

150
00:09:13.705 --> 00:09:17.210
we'll make sure that we have it for
all of our configurations regardless

151
00:09:17.210 --> 00:09:21.100
of whether we are doing a static,
dynamic or Port Address Translation.

152
00:09:21.100 --> 00:09:27.210
You have to decide which side is gonna
be considered the end side address and

153
00:09:27.210 --> 00:09:31.140
which side is also gonna be considered
the outside address as well.

154
00:09:31.140 --> 00:09:33.240
Now when you take a look
at something like that,

155
00:09:33.240 --> 00:09:37.600
that doesn't really sound like,
okay, so what's the big deal?

156
00:09:37.600 --> 00:09:39.220
I know what my internal address is.

157
00:09:39.220 --> 00:09:41.570
I know what my external address is.

158
00:09:41.570 --> 00:09:46.400
But it is a big deal because when we end
up showing the translations, like I have

159
00:09:46.400 --> 00:09:52.420
down here in the second group of this one
command here, do show IP NAT translations.

160
00:09:52.420 --> 00:09:56.270
I just kind of abbreviated a little bit.

161
00:09:56.270 --> 00:10:02.000
Notice that the table that it shows up,
the terminology is terrible.

162
00:10:02.000 --> 00:10:04.990
There's an inside global address.

163
00:10:04.990 --> 00:10:07.720
There's an inside local address.

164
00:10:07.720 --> 00:10:09.710
There's an outside local address.

165
00:10:09.710 --> 00:10:10.750
What the heck is that?

166
00:10:10.750 --> 00:10:13.550
What's an outside,
what are these terms about?

167
00:10:13.550 --> 00:10:17.560
Well, that's why it's important that, at
least for the way that the router works,

168
00:10:17.560 --> 00:10:21.680
that what we're defining is
what side is actually what.

169
00:10:21.680 --> 00:10:28.540
So here I'm saying that gigabit ethernet
0/0, this is gonna be my IP NAT inside.

170
00:10:28.540 --> 00:10:32.300
We would just going to the interface
itself and we configure that.

171
00:10:32.300 --> 00:10:35.340
So this is what I would do if I'm
actually trying to configure this and

172
00:10:35.340 --> 00:10:36.790
make sure that I get it right.

173
00:10:36.790 --> 00:10:39.406
Even on the exam, you're gonna
be given a dry erase marker and

174
00:10:39.406 --> 00:10:40.980
probably laminated sheet of paper.

175
00:10:40.980 --> 00:10:46.360
I would just draw a simple router,
a circle, put you know, just a plus sign.

176
00:10:46.360 --> 00:10:48.820
That way you kinda
remember it's the router.

177
00:10:48.820 --> 00:10:52.030
Then draw a little line off one side and

178
00:10:52.030 --> 00:10:54.360
label whatever the interface
is that they're telling you.

179
00:10:54.360 --> 00:10:56.650
Then the other side label
whatever interface it is.

180
00:10:56.650 --> 00:11:00.860
Then make a decision, which side is
inside and which side is outside?

181
00:11:00.860 --> 00:11:03.330
So that's what you want to
make sure that you get.

182
00:11:03.330 --> 00:11:05.730
Then you put the network
on what's the inside.

183
00:11:05.730 --> 00:11:09.710
So usually that's gonna be a
representation of the local area network.

184
00:11:09.710 --> 00:11:12.220
And then on the other side is gonna
be a representation of course,

185
00:11:12.220 --> 00:11:14.090
on what is outside.

186
00:11:14.090 --> 00:11:17.660
So now by taking a look
at the term inside and

187
00:11:17.660 --> 00:11:22.160
outside, now Zack, when you take a look
at how we do the show IP NAT trans,

188
00:11:22.160 --> 00:11:24.040
notice that they're really
just grouping it and

189
00:11:24.040 --> 00:11:27.170
what they're doing is they're making
the dividing line right here.

190
00:11:27.170 --> 00:11:30.742
So the information is inside global and
inside local.

191
00:11:30.742 --> 00:11:31.533
Now what the heck, again, does that mean?

192
00:11:31.533 --> 00:11:38.190
Well, what they are telling you on
the inside local address as you do this,

193
00:11:38.190 --> 00:11:45.280
is they're saying, from the standpoint of
this router, taking a look at the inside.

194
00:11:46.450 --> 00:11:52.306
I know something, the address
that I'm seeing is 192.168.16.10.

195
00:11:52.306 --> 00:11:56.140
So that's the address that I
know that I'm seeing here.

196
00:11:56.140 --> 00:12:00.747
Then, when it takes this packet and
is sending it towards it's destination, so

197
00:12:00.747 --> 00:12:03.469
here it is,
here's my packet of information.

198
00:12:03.469 --> 00:12:08.081
I'm setting it towards
the destination which is 172.15.0.10.

199
00:12:08.081 --> 00:12:11.526
Well, according to this side,
the inside here,

200
00:12:11.526 --> 00:12:16.640
this interface when it looks at it,
it says where is it going?

201
00:12:16.640 --> 00:12:20.980
Well, what it's gonna do is say hey,
it needs to go out of that interface,

202
00:12:20.980 --> 00:12:24.720
which is the global side of things,
which is outside of network.

203
00:12:24.720 --> 00:12:28.860
But there it gets translated
into 172.14.0.1, and

204
00:12:28.860 --> 00:12:31.780
this is where it places
a port number on it too.

205
00:12:31.780 --> 00:12:34.030
Now, the initial one it doesn't.

206
00:12:34.030 --> 00:12:36.870
On the initial one, it just says,
hey look, here it is.

207
00:12:36.870 --> 00:12:41.010
We're just going to make sure that
we can do that connection there, and

208
00:12:41.010 --> 00:12:42.540
that's what it does.

209
00:12:42.540 --> 00:12:47.010
When it gets translated,
then you get this list that says hey,

210
00:12:47.010 --> 00:12:49.330
I know what the protocol is you're using.

211
00:12:49.330 --> 00:12:51.940
And now, let me make sure that I can

212

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure dynamic NAT.  The describe how to configure it on the router and verify it's working.  They also discuss when to use it in comparison to static routing.

So the very fact that we have
something like this, and

372

So this is where we have to again

377

378

379

So, I'm gonna use this scroll and

381

382

So in our show run, that is correct,

383

384

And then our access list,

385

We're permitting everything,

386

Now, ip nat pool 172.14, 172.14, and

that's the range here.

389
00:22:25.390 --> 00:22:27.960
So, I am missing something here.

00:22:33.660 --> 00:22:35.230
Okay, that is the key,

Well there is clearly something

Remember what I said has to exist, right?

397

>> Okay,

We also created that pool, right?

Ip nat inside source list,

403
00:23:06.324 --> 00:23:09.524
Well if I scroll through

408

So now, let's check it out here.

00:23:27.760 --> 00:23:30.160
So now inside of global configuration,

411

ip nat inside source.

412
00:23:36.070 --> 00:23:38.310
Oops, I forgot to scroll.

413

My apologies there.

414
00:23:39.650 --> 00:23:44.646
Inside source lists here, I'm referring

415

to list 100, and then on the outside,

416
00:23:49.501 --> 00:23:56.037
it's gonna be pool called mydynamicpool,
all right?

417
00:23:56.037 --> 00:24:03.537
So now, as I exit out of here,
I do a show running-config.

418
00:24:03.537 --> 00:24:07.483
And now let's take

420

Now look at it.

421

422
00:24:15.695 --> 00:24:21.660
So remember the three elements,

423

I now have what binds
the access control list and

424

the pool together also

425

So at this point,

And now see if we can get through.

427

Okay, now we can't get through this time.

We may have to kind of try

429

And now there you go, look at that Zach.

430

>> You made it ping.

431

>> Okay, so I now get pings

432
00:24:47.603 --> 00:24:50.944
So here, oops.

433

Show ip nat translations, and

434

now we're starting to get those addresses.

435

Now it's very difficult for

436

>> Here you said translations,

>> Yep, here it said translations.

So it's very difficult though for

But the next one that we would
have if we had multiple devices,

let me show you what

442

So I forgot that should

443
00:25:24.796 --> 00:25:29.950
But if IP nat pull is actually done,
I actually built up my own lab and

444
00:25:29.950 --> 00:25:31.370
my own environment instead.

445
00:25:32.820 --> 00:25:36.210
And now you'll actually see a couple of
different things as I scroll through here.

446
00:25:36.210 --> 00:25:39.280
Notice that you're seeing
different IP addresses.

447
00:25:39.280 --> 00:25:44.358
So there you're actually seeing
where it translated 14.0.1,

448
00:25:44.358 --> 00:25:50.760
and now notice on this one 0.2, and
then down here at the bottom, 0.3 as well.

449
00:25:50.760 --> 00:25:54.840
Now you're also seeing some unusual
things once we get to this point

450
00:25:54.840 --> 00:25:57.110
in the dynamic translation as well.

451
00:25:57.110 --> 00:26:02.800
Notice these numbers with a colon after
them too, these numbers as well, okay?

452
00:26:02.800 --> 00:26:05.990
So they're actually kinda skipping
around and you're starting to see stuff,

453
00:26:05.990 --> 00:26:08.970
but the reason why is that
when we issue pings, right?

454
00:26:08.970 --> 00:26:13.350
They all are individual in their
connection going through, okay?

455
00:26:13.350 --> 00:26:15.870
And if they're individual in
their connection going through,

456
00:26:15.870 --> 00:26:17.880
they have to return that same way.

457
00:26:17.880 --> 00:26:22.110
So this is how they distinguish
even between individual pings

458
00:26:22.110 --> 00:26:23.960
which pings are coming back.

459
00:26:23.960 --> 00:26:25.220
>> Okay.
>> So that's why

460
00:26:25.220 --> 00:26:27.922
those numbers are different
in what we're seeing, okay?

461
00:26:27.922 --> 00:26:30.140
>> Mm-hm, mm-hm.
>> So, the great thing is though Zach,

462
00:26:30.140 --> 00:26:33.670
is that we now have the idea
of Dynamic NAT set up for us.

463
00:26:33.670 --> 00:26:34.450
>> Right.
>> We even showed

464
00:26:34.450 --> 00:26:37.660
you a bit of troubleshooting I
also showed you what was missing.

465
00:26:37.660 --> 00:26:39.530
>> Right.
>> And that could be another type of

466
00:26:39.530 --> 00:26:40.910
question that you might see.

467
00:26:40.910 --> 00:26:43.980
Like, why isn't the translation working?

468
00:26:43.980 --> 00:26:45.570
Well, especially with Dynamic, right?

469
00:26:45.570 --> 00:26:48.040
Those three elements have to be involved,
okay?

470
00:26:48.040 --> 00:26:51.520
So Zach, this is a great place for
us to end this episode, but we still have,

471
00:26:51.520 --> 00:26:54.360
of course,
port address translation to go, so

472
00:26:54.360 --> 00:26:56.760
we need to do that in
a third episode instead.

473
00:26:56.760 --> 00:26:58.020
>> Wonderful job, as usual, Ronnie.

474

Configure nat, part one and
two, and soon, part three.

475

Make sure you see that and see everything
inside the Cisco CSense series.

You’ll be very glad did.

477

It’s going to help you too, by the way.

And you’ll be in the course library.

485

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure the most commonly use form of NAT: NAT overload or PAT--both are used to describe the same thing.  Here they configure this by using an access-list and a nat statement to combine it with interface and the overload keyword.
episodes.title: Configure NAT Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:02.607
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.607 --> 00:00:06.647
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.647 --> 00:00:08.249
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.249 --> 00:00:13.118
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

5
00:00:13.118 --> 00:00:15.968
watching ITPRO.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.968 --> 00:00:20.507
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with Cisco CCENT,

7
00:00:20.507 --> 00:00:25.350
this is Configure NAT Part 3,
because you demanded it.

8
00:00:25.350 --> 00:00:28.007
And the person bringing us all
the information we need is the one and

9
00:00:28.007 --> 00:00:30.344
only Ronnie Wong, Ronnie,
great to see you again, sir.

10
00:00:30.344 --> 00:00:31.337
>> Well, Zach, once again,

11
00:00:31.337 --> 00:00:32.640
thank you for having me on the show.

12
00:00:32.640 --> 00:00:36.835
As we continue on, taking a little bit of
a deeper dive into configuring NAT here.

13
00:00:36.835 --> 00:00:40.689
Because, well, there is a lot of
information that you have to know not only

14
00:00:40.689 --> 00:00:42.474
for preparing for the CCENT exam.

15
00:00:42.474 --> 00:00:46.747
But also because if there is anything for
you to configure and have to troubleshoot.

16
00:00:46.747 --> 00:00:50.770
And that is one of the easiest
ones to just forget something.

17
00:00:50.770 --> 00:00:55.182
Because there are more moving parts to it,
more configuration that you have to make.

18
00:00:55.182 --> 00:00:58.974
But the great thing is, since we've
configured at least those interfaces that

19
00:00:58.974 --> 00:01:00.628
we've done in parts 1 and 2.
>> Yes.

20
00:01:00.628 --> 00:01:01.642
>> We haven't had to touch them,

21
00:01:01.642 --> 00:01:02.805
which is good.
>> Mm-hm.

22
00:01:02.805 --> 00:01:03.638
>> But remember,

23
00:01:03.638 --> 00:01:06.890
make sure you verify those
when you get onto the exam.

24
00:01:06.890 --> 00:01:09.452
Make sure those are actually
correctly verified, and

25
00:01:09.452 --> 00:01:12.077
then the different components
that we've done so far.

26
00:01:12.077 --> 00:01:15.790
So, Zach, we've already gone over,
of course, static NAT translations.

27
00:01:15.790 --> 00:01:19.273
We've talked about, of course,
using dynamic NAT translations.

28
00:01:19.273 --> 00:01:22.857
Static being one to one, NAT being a many
to many translation, or a many to few,

29
00:01:22.857 --> 00:01:24.650
whatever you want to call it.

30
00:01:24.650 --> 00:01:26.528
It allows us to do that, but

31
00:01:26.528 --> 00:01:31.289
the problem that we have still is
the existence of the issue, right?

32
00:01:31.289 --> 00:01:34.181
Is that regardless of which
of those two that we did,

33
00:01:34.181 --> 00:01:37.750
if more people inside need to be
able to connect to the Internet.

34
00:01:37.750 --> 00:01:40.740
Or need to be able to
have a public IP address,

35
00:01:40.740 --> 00:01:43.673
we still need to request
more IP addresses.

36
00:01:43.673 --> 00:01:47.082
So in both dynamic NAT
as well as static NAT,

37
00:01:47.082 --> 00:01:51.890
that would still have to happen,
so the technology changed.

38
00:01:51.890 --> 00:01:54.515
NAT itself, network address translation,

39
00:01:54.515 --> 00:01:57.629
added in what they called
port address translation.

40
00:01:57.629 --> 00:02:02.101
Technically, NAT overload in the CISCO
community is what you also tend to hear,

41
00:02:02.101 --> 00:02:04.029
and what does that actually mean?

42
00:02:04.029 --> 00:02:08.762
Well, that means we can overload
a single IP address, but

43
00:02:08.762 --> 00:02:14.090
with more than one connection in
both the dynamic and the static.

44
00:02:14.090 --> 00:02:15.915
It really is a one-to-one translation.

45
00:02:15.915 --> 00:02:18.629
So even though with the dynamic,
I might have three or four,

46
00:02:18.629 --> 00:02:19.970
that allows me three or four.

47
00:02:19.970 --> 00:02:24.832
But it's really still one private IP
address to any one of those three or

48
00:02:24.832 --> 00:02:27.193
four public IP addresses, okay?

49
00:02:27.193 --> 00:02:29.598
So but it's just dynamically handling it,
right?

50
00:02:29.598 --> 00:02:32.341
So it doesn't have to be
the same three at any one time.

51
00:02:32.341 --> 00:02:38.710
But when we move on to the idea of port
address translation, or NAT overload.

52
00:02:38.710 --> 00:02:43.669
This allows me to take that entire pool
of class C addresses that I was talking

53
00:02:43.669 --> 00:02:46.623
about that's within my local area network.

54
00:02:46.623 --> 00:02:51.257
And then I can run them through the router
and when it gets translated out,

55
00:02:51.257 --> 00:02:55.490
it can get translated into
a single public IP address.

56
00:02:55.490 --> 00:03:00.589
Now technically,
the way that this ends up working

57
00:03:00.589 --> 00:03:05.332
is that we can actually have,
theoretically,

58
00:03:05.332 --> 00:03:09.968
one through 65,535 port connections.

59
00:03:09.968 --> 00:03:14.956
Now when I start saying that,
that means I can have up to 65,000

60
00:03:14.956 --> 00:03:20.800
additional IP addresses connecting in,
well, not exactly, okay?

61
00:03:20.800 --> 00:03:24.816
When you make a connection, let's take,
for example, to a web server, okay?

62
00:03:24.816 --> 00:03:30.052
That means your IP address is getting
translated, but when we're using ports,

63
00:03:30.052 --> 00:03:34.350
it could use, let's say, 4 or
5, or 20 of those ports.

64
00:03:34.350 --> 00:03:35.882
So when you start doing that, and

65
00:03:35.882 --> 00:03:39.353
then a single machine has multiple
applications that are connecting out.

66
00:03:39.353 --> 00:03:44.267
A single machine might actually
take up to 100, or maybe even,

67
00:03:44.267 --> 00:03:47.870
let's say, low end, 50, or 20 or so.

68
00:03:47.870 --> 00:03:52.838
All the way up to, let's say, 150, maybe
even 200 ports, and now, all of a sudden,

69
00:03:52.838 --> 00:03:55.405
you start doing that with 254 connections.

70
00:03:55.405 --> 00:03:59.336
And some of the computers,
of course, depending on who you are,

71
00:03:59.336 --> 00:04:02.490
you might actually take
up even more of those.

72
00:04:02.490 --> 00:04:05.400
So the realistic IP addresses
in terms of numbers,

73
00:04:05.400 --> 00:04:07.438
it starts going down very rapidly.

74
00:04:07.438 --> 00:04:12.061
When you realize that your own single
internal IP address could take up hundreds

75
00:04:12.061 --> 00:04:14.496
of those port numbers very quickly.
>> Mm-hm.

76
00:04:14.496 --> 00:04:15.434
>> So all of a sudden,

77
00:04:15.434 --> 00:04:18.960
it's not 65,000 additional addresses,
if you think about it,

78
00:04:18.960 --> 00:04:22.070
it's actually 65,000
different connections.

79
00:04:22.070 --> 00:04:24.861
That is what we are talking
about at any one time, and

80
00:04:24.861 --> 00:04:27.468
your machine is not just
making one connection.

81
00:04:27.468 --> 00:04:31.500
You might be connected to a web server,
you might connected to an email server.

82
00:04:31.500 --> 00:04:35.731
You might be connected to a remote
storage, like Dropbox, or OneDrive, or

83
00:04:35.731 --> 00:04:36.667
whatever it is.

84
00:04:36.667 --> 00:04:40.083
All those could take multiple
connections to make and there it is,

85
00:04:40.083 --> 00:04:43.460
you're just sitting there on
your Internet connection.

86
00:04:43.460 --> 00:04:46.710

is actually key as well.

310
00:19:16.210 --> 00:19:20.900
Okay, but in the static one if anything
that was probably the easiest to

311
00:19:20.900 --> 00:19:24.220
actually remember because you're
only doing one IP address.

312
00:19:24.220 --> 00:19:26.272
But you're actually
taking a look at it and

313
00:19:26.272 --> 00:19:28.723
you're going to make that
translation manually so

314
00:19:28.723 --> 00:19:32.324
that's probably the one that will kinda
be easier for you to work through.

315
00:19:32.324 --> 00:19:35.107
Take a look at these commands
that will help show and

316
00:19:35.107 --> 00:19:39.183
clear out the table for you, and you'll
see as they come back through if you

317
00:19:39.183 --> 00:19:42.614
are actually getting the information
it's gonna be working,

318
00:19:42.614 --> 00:19:46.240
so nat is a very prevalent
technology in today's networks.

319
00:19:46.240 --> 00:19:50.510
As we move to IP version six, you'll
probably see it disappear more and more.

320
00:19:50.510 --> 00:19:54.750
But at this point, Zach, we've configured
dynamic, we've configured static,

321
00:19:54.750 --> 00:19:57.660
we've configured port address
translation or net overload.

322
00:19:57.660 --> 00:20:01.160
Everything is done at this point
in terms of configuring nat but

323
00:20:01.160 --> 00:20:05.210
it doesn't mean that there's all that
there is to this but at least for the CCNT

324
00:20:05.210 --> 00:20:10.240
here, that's enough to get you started and
to get you prepared as we move on to

325
00:20:10.240 --> 00:20:14.220
the CCNA routing and switching exam two.
>> Very well done, Ronnie.

326
00:20:14.220 --> 00:20:17.390
And that's configure nats Part one,
two, and three.

327
00:20:17.390 --> 00:20:18.220
I may say that again.

328
00:20:18.220 --> 00:20:21.420
Configure nat part one,
two, and three, not gnats.

329
00:20:21.420 --> 00:20:22.520
Forgive me for that.

330
00:20:22.520 --> 00:20:24.616
Before we move on,
Ronnie anything else you'd like to say?

331
00:20:24.616 --> 00:20:27.160
Well once again, practice is the key.

332
00:20:27.160 --> 00:20:30.530
So because this topic is
a little bit more detailed and

333
00:20:30.530 --> 00:20:34.760
all the configurations that we have
to do cuz it is a lot of setup.

334
00:20:34.760 --> 00:20:39.290
Make sure you do not move on from
this topic until you understand

335
00:20:39.290 --> 00:20:41.760
the elements of it that we've
talked about here, okay?

336
00:20:41.760 --> 00:20:44.360
And the only way to do
that is by practicing,

337
00:20:44.360 --> 00:20:47.640
by configuring, getting it wrong,
troubleshooting.

338
00:20:47.640 --> 00:20:51.960
And then, reconfiguring it again, and
then going, this is where I messed up.

339
00:20:51.960 --> 00:20:54.460
And once you get that down,
it will be much easier for

340
00:20:54.460 --> 00:20:57.620
you learning from those
mistakes is a valuable part

341
00:20:57.620 --> 00:21:00.660
of what will help you out as
you get ready for the exam.

342
00:21:00.660 --> 00:21:03.010
But even if it takes you
a little bit extra time and

343
00:21:03.010 --> 00:21:06.270
you've already got everything planned out,
make sure you take the time to do this

344
00:21:06.270 --> 00:21:10.280
along with those axis control lists that
we talked about in previous episodes.

345
00:21:10.280 --> 00:21:15.000
These are two of the more unfamiliar
concepts that you'll run into.

346
00:21:15.000 --> 00:21:18.690
As well as the ones that have a much
more difficult configuration.

347
00:21:18.690 --> 00:21:20.260
Pay attention to them as well.

348
00:21:20.260 --> 00:21:24.910
Great advice Ronnie, and a great job
with Cisco CCENT, wonderful series.

349
00:21:24.910 --> 00:21:27.290
Watch every episode,
you'll be glad you did.

350
00:21:27.290 --> 00:21:30.900
And you'll be in the course library where
there's a whole bunch of other videos and

351
00:21:30.900 --> 00:21:34.150
they're there to help you go further,
check those out too.

352
00:21:34.150 --> 00:21:35.940
And tell everybody you
know about IT Pro TV.

353
00:21:35.940 --> 00:21:38.420
You know IT Pro TV is binge worthy.

354
00:21:38.420 --> 00:21:40.690
Thanks for watching, I'm Zack Memos.
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

355
00:21:40.690 --> 00:21:43.194
>> And we will see you again soon.

356
00:21:43.194 --> 00:21:49.303
[MUSIC]

357
00:21:49.303 --> 00:21:52.403
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie configure basic monitoring using syslog commands.  They discuss the use of the buffer and a syslog server. The team setup the syslog server and configure the router to send logs to it.
episodes.title: Implement Device Monitoring
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.280
Welcome to ITPRO TV.

2
00:00:01.280 --> 00:00:07.059
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]
>> Coming at you live from San Fransisco

3
00:00:07.059 --> 00:00:11.622
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:11.622 --> 00:00:13.942
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITPRO TV.

5
00:00:13.942 --> 00:00:16.430
Helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.430 --> 00:00:17.690
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

7
00:00:17.690 --> 00:00:19.479
As we continue on with Cisco CCENT.

8
00:00:19.479 --> 00:00:23.310
We're gonna be implementing device
monitoring in this episode.

9
00:00:23.310 --> 00:00:25.730
And the one and only Ronnie Wong
is here to do that for us.

10
00:00:25.730 --> 00:00:27.270
Ronnie, good to see you sir.

11
00:00:27.270 --> 00:00:31.440
>> Well Zach thank you for helping me
as we continue on our journey here

12
00:00:31.440 --> 00:00:34.750
through getting prepared for
our CISCO CCENT exam.

13
00:00:34.750 --> 00:00:39.630
We're in our final topic where we are now
talking about infrastructure maintenance.

14
00:00:39.630 --> 00:00:42.560
And we're gonna begin of course well
with taking a look at the idea of

15
00:00:42.560 --> 00:00:45.100
device monitoring and

16
00:00:45.100 --> 00:00:49.330
making sure that we can implement the
things that we can do in device monitor.

17
00:00:49.330 --> 00:00:53.720
Now when we start talking about
the idea of monitoring these devices.

18
00:00:53.720 --> 00:00:55.670
Are we really just talking about the,

19
00:00:55.670 --> 00:00:57.960
looking at what the command
line looks like?

20
00:00:57.960 --> 00:01:02.010
Well not exactly because a lot of
times it doesn't really show anything.

21
00:01:02.010 --> 00:01:04.040
Let me show you what I'm talking about.

22
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:07.430
So right here we're gonna take
a look at our practice lab just for

23
00:01:07.430 --> 00:01:10.605
a moment and
make sure I can get access in.

24
00:01:10.605 --> 00:01:14.260
Let me zoom in,
well there is really not a lot to show.

25
00:01:14.260 --> 00:01:16.660
So if I leave this alone.

26
00:01:16.660 --> 00:01:18.060
Long enough here.

27
00:01:18.060 --> 00:01:19.980
Believe it or
not it will just stay this way.

28
00:01:19.980 --> 00:01:22.690
And there's not a lot that
looks like it's going on.

29
00:01:22.690 --> 00:01:26.770
But if this device is connected to
a network, there are things going on.

30
00:01:26.770 --> 00:01:28.160
If it's a router it's routing traffic.

31
00:01:28.160 --> 00:01:30.610
Because the switch is
actually switching traffic.

32
00:01:30.610 --> 00:01:35.470
But we also see every once in a while
messages will of course pop forward.

33
00:01:35.470 --> 00:01:38.790
So let me see if I can do something here.

34
00:01:38.790 --> 00:01:41.200
If I go into configuration terminal.

35
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:44.648
Well now notice it's starting to actually
send some information back and forth.

36
00:01:44.648 --> 00:01:47.537
And if I exit out of that, sometimes you
also get a message that pulls up, and

37
00:01:47.537 --> 00:01:48.045
there we go.

38
00:01:48.045 --> 00:01:50.290
That's what I was hoping to see, okay?

39
00:01:50.290 --> 00:01:53.300
So I configured from the console,
by the console.

40
00:01:53.300 --> 00:01:56.010
Well these are the messages that
we're talking about here, okay?

41
00:01:56.010 --> 00:01:59.608
Because they indicate what is
actually happening on that device.

42
00:01:59.608 --> 00:02:01.584
Whether it's a router or switch,

43
00:02:01.584 --> 00:02:04.659
this is the stuff that we're
actually having to see.

44
00:02:04.659 --> 00:02:08.611
And a lot of times this is actually good
information that we need to review and

45
00:02:08.611 --> 00:02:10.820
that we might need to take a look at.

46
00:02:10.820 --> 00:02:12.370
>> So this is real time, right?

47
00:02:12.370 --> 00:02:14.590
We're not looking at history or
can we look at history?

48
00:02:14.590 --> 00:02:17.500
>> Well, you can and that's what
we're also talking about as well.

49
00:02:17.500 --> 00:02:23.010
The idea of doing real time analysis,
in terms of what we're doing.

50
00:02:23.010 --> 00:02:29.030
It can be helpful but the problem is it's
only helpful for that moment in time.

51
00:02:29.030 --> 00:02:32.750
So as long as you catch
it while it's happening,

52
00:02:32.750 --> 00:02:36.930
it can save you some time when you're
trying to do troubleshooting, when you're

53
00:02:36.930 --> 00:02:41.620
trying to take a look here at the idea
of maintenance and trying to do things.

54
00:02:41.620 --> 00:02:43.450
But the reality is,

55
00:02:43.450 --> 00:02:47.370
what we wanna see is something that's
a little bit more over a historical time.

56
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:51.660
In other words, after a period of time,
after a series of events is what we want.

57
00:02:51.660 --> 00:02:53.940
Because then we can spot trending.

58
00:02:53.940 --> 00:02:57.150
We can spot, a lot of times,
how long something has been happening or

59
00:02:57.150 --> 00:03:00.400
occurring, and
how often something has been occurring.

60
00:03:00.400 --> 00:03:03.525
But if we only look at it in real time,
it means we can't spot any of that.

61
00:03:03.525 --> 00:03:04.120
>> Mm-hm.

62
00:03:04.120 --> 00:03:07.530
>> So the messages that we're seeing
right here, okay for example,

63
00:03:07.530 --> 00:03:09.320
such as this message, Zach.

64
00:03:09.320 --> 00:03:12.330
>> Yep.
>> Is technically what we call a syslog

65
00:03:12.330 --> 00:03:13.010
message.

66
00:03:13.010 --> 00:03:15.360
>> Okay.
>> S-Y-S-L-O-G, okay?

67
00:03:15.360 --> 00:03:18.090
Those are the messages that
we are generally seeing.

68
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:21.070
Now by default on the Cisco devices,

69
00:03:21.070 --> 00:03:24.570
it ends up getting reported
in two places here, okay?

70
00:03:24.570 --> 00:03:26.890
One is a historical buffer, okay?

71
00:03:26.890 --> 00:03:30.750
In other words, there's a buffer which
is just a small amount of RAM that is

72
00:03:30.750 --> 00:03:31.950
on the router or the switch.

73
00:03:31.950 --> 00:03:36.650
It says here's how much space I'm
setting aside for syslog messages.

74
00:03:36.650 --> 00:03:39.433
When it does so it allows you then
to pull up those messages and

75
00:03:39.433 --> 00:03:40.810
to be able to see them as well.

76
00:03:40.810 --> 00:03:45.240
But the other place is what we're
seeing right here on the screen.

77
00:03:45.240 --> 00:03:48.640
So, this is what is
called a Console Access.

78
00:03:48.640 --> 00:03:51.975
So, notice where it says configured
from console, by a console.

79
00:03:51.975 --> 00:03:56.400
And that was just me entering
in information from the console.

80
00:03:56.400 --> 00:03:59.420
And the console is reporting it back out.

81
00:03:59.420 --> 00:04:04.260
So by default syslog messages end up
going to the buffer on a device and

82
00:04:04.260 --> 00:04:07.010
also end up reporting out to the console.

83
00:04:07.010 --> 00:04:12.698
Now when that buffer fills up one of
the earliest syslog messages, of course

84
00:04:12.698 --> 00:04:18.320
you empty that out to make room for the
new syslog messages that may be appearing.

85
00:04:18.320 --> 00:04:22.510
So these buffers,
it really does just depend on each device,

86
00:04:22.510 --> 00:04:27.190
how big that they are, and how many lines
of information that they can store.

87
00:04:27.190 --> 00:04:31.220
Now sometimes when you actually do hear
about the idea of the buffer size,

88
00:04:31.220 --> 00:04:33.920
I don't know if I can actually
show the buffer size here.

89
00:04:33.920 --> 00:04:35.740
Let me see if I can actually do that.

90
00:04:38.340 --> 00:04:43.180
I gotta remember if, because not every
single machine actually does this.

91
00:04:43.180 --> 00:04:44.960
Let me see if I can get that here, okay.

92
00:04:44.960 --> 00:04:49.640
All right, so I was trying to look for,
if there was actually just kind of

93
00:04:49.640 --> 00:04:55.430
the generic in terms of just a single
buffer size that I can find here.

94
00:04:55.430 --> 00:04:59.250
But I'm actually starting to see a little,
I wonder these buffer pulls.

95
00:04:59.250 --> 00:05:01.670
Let me see if I scroll
up here a little bit.

96
00:05:01.670 --> 00:05:05.920
This might be part of what we see there.

97
00:05:05.920 --> 00:05:10.750
A little bit of the free list 345 and
free which means in free memory.

98
00:05:10.750 --> 00:05:14.870
And then I'm not seeing
exactly what I was looking for

99
00:05:14.870 --> 00:05:16.380
but I was hoping to see something.

100
00:05:16.380 --> 00:05:17.910
I don't know, normal buffers.

101
00:05:17.910 --> 00:05:19.050
There we go, okay.

102
00:05:19.050 --> 00:05:21.103
So there is some information.

103
00:05:21.103 --> 00:05:25.314
So in terms of bytes of information,
right now it says 1676 and

104
00:05:25.314 --> 00:05:28.500
notice that the total
is about double that.

105
00:05:28.500 --> 00:05:30.990
And that's actually part
of the permanent buffer.

106
00:05:30.990 --> 00:05:35.170
If you take a look at that and
round up, that's about four megs,

107
00:05:35.170 --> 00:05:39.190
maybe, in size or 4,000 kilobits.

108
00:05:39.190 --> 00:05:42.400
Whatever it might be, I don't remember
the exact size that it's reported in.

109
00:05:42.400 --> 00:05:45.930
So if it was bytes,
it would be about four kilobytes, right.

110
00:05:45.930 --> 00:05:47.321
3000, yeah.

111
00:05:47.321 --> 00:05:50.710
3840 kilobytes, so as we see this.

112
00:05:50.710 --> 00:05:52.870
>> Is there a maximum amount
that it would reach and

113
00:05:52.870 --> 00:05:55.413
at that point it would just
start regenerating itself?

114
00:05:55.413 --> 00:05:58.660
>> No, the neat thing is just
as you asked, there you go.

115
00:05:58.660 --> 00:05:59.912
So right here.

116
00:05:59.912 --> 00:06:04.190
You're actually seeing that there is a
maximum number that we can reach here now.

117
00:06:04.190 --> 00:06:07.810
What happens is that it doesn't
regenerate but it freeze it up, right?

118
00:06:07.810 --> 00:06:12.613
So once it gets to that point, it will
continue to free up older things that get

119
00:06:12.613 --> 00:06:13.280
>> It will erase it.

120
00:06:13.280 --> 00:06:15.440
>> Right, and then give you that space.

121
00:06:15.440 --> 00:06:16.510
But there you go.

122
00:06:16.510 --> 00:06:21.150
And it doesn't sound like
a big amount of space, right?

123
00:06:21.150 --> 00:06:25.289
4k is what we're talking,
4000 kilobytes is the size, and

124
00:06:25.289 --> 00:06:28.159
you might be saying
that's not a lot of room.

125
00:06:28.159 --> 00:06:32.487
There's files that I generate that
are larger than 4k just by generating them

126
00:06:32.487 --> 00:06:33.349
a lot of times.

127
00:06:33.349 --> 00:06:35.507
So 4k doesn't sound like a lot but

128
00:06:35.507 --> 00:06:40.900
when you take a look at the information
that we're normally storing.

129
00:06:40.900 --> 00:06:45.200
So for instance, each one of these,
a line like this.

130
00:06:45.200 --> 00:06:49.000
Well, that may not take up
an entire kilobyte itself.

131
00:06:49.000 --> 00:06:50.350
>> Right.
>> So it's not that it's but

132
00:06:50.350 --> 00:06:53.100
so you can actually store a lot.

133
00:06:53.100 --> 00:06:55.690
So, for example,
I think that if you were you to take like

134
00:06:55.690 --> 00:07:00.432
the Encyclopedia Britannica and turn it
into text which is all this is, right?

135
00:07:00.432 --> 00:07:03.147
Essentially letters and
numbers and different characters.

136
00:07:03.147 --> 00:07:07.063
And [INAUDIBLE] I think it's less than 10
megabytes if you would just take out all

137
00:07:07.063 --> 00:07:10.011
the pictures and everything and
just store the text itself.

138
00:07:10.011 --> 00:07:12.081
It's something that's relatively small.

139
00:07:12.081 --> 00:07:19.230
So a 4 kilobyte buffer size doesn't
sound huge but it's normally enough.

140
00:07:19.230 --> 00:07:23.116
Now people always ask can you change the
buffer size, yes we're actually gonna be

141
00:07:23.116 --> 00:07:26.399
changing the buffer size for logging,
to expand it out a little bit.

142
00:07:26.399 --> 00:07:31.650
But before you decide hey let's change
this and max it all up here, and do that.

143
00:07:31.650 --> 00:07:35.990
Remember that any time you're taking away
the idea of actually increasing the buffer

144
00:07:35.990 --> 00:07:37.130
size somewhere.

145
00:07:37.130 --> 00:07:40.835
You're also gonna be taking away
memory from some other place too.

146
00:07:40.835 --> 00:07:41.430
>> Mm-hm.
>> So

147
00:07:41.430 --> 00:07:45.230
it will reduce maybe and then the amount
of memory used for something else.

148
00:07:45.230 --> 00:07:49.964
So there is no magical way to continue to
add in something without taking away from

149
00:07:49.964 --> 00:07:51.019
some place else.

150
00:07:51.019 --> 00:07:53.833
So that's what we wanna make
sure that we get across as well.

151
00:07:53.833 --> 00:07:55.883
So the buffer size is adjustable.

152
00:07:55.883 --> 00:07:58.209
It does allow us to do this, and

153
00:07:58.209 --> 00:08:03.318
we are saving it right now on this
particular N Y edge router, okay?

154
00:08:03.318 --> 00:08:07.312
So, it's a good thing to actually have
because we know that can be recorded out,

155
00:08:07.312 --> 00:08:08.810
it can be doing this.

156
00:08:08.810 --> 00:08:13.360
Now, the issue though, okay, as we start
doing it, we're only on this one, right?

157
00:08:13.360 --> 00:08:17.490
Only storing and that's perfectly fine but
Zach what happens now.

158
00:08:18.670 --> 00:08:24.254
When I actually start to let's say,
have multiple routers on my network,

159
00:08:24.254 --> 00:08:28.610
okay, well now, if I were to do this
that means I'd have to go round and

160
00:08:28.610 --> 00:08:31.530
check every single one
of these routers for

161
00:08:31.530 --> 00:08:34.850
their buffer messages and
stuff like that, that sounds like

162
00:08:34.850 --> 00:08:37.340
a management nightmare to me, right,
>> It sounds like a management

163
00:08:37.340 --> 00:08:38.090
nightmare, yes.

164
00:08:38.090 --> 00:08:38.770
>> Because why?

165
00:08:38.770 --> 00:08:41.950
You're having to go round to every
single one of those routers and then now

166
00:08:41.950 --> 00:08:45.420
you're having to see what the messages
are, you're having to pull up the console,

167
00:08:45.420 --> 00:08:50.160
you're having to do that, is it,
are all the devices actually in some

168
00:08:50.160 --> 00:08:54.560
type of distress or something, you are
having to find all that information out,

169
00:08:54.560 --> 00:08:58.800
okay because we are storing them only
on their own individual buffers.

170
00:08:58.800 --> 00:09:03.520
So instead,
what might be more practical idea is,

171
00:09:03.520 --> 00:09:08.356
instead of actually just using the buffer
is to instead have all of our messages

172
00:09:08.356 --> 00:09:17.050
really set let's say down through here,
so that when we do so,

173
00:09:18.360 --> 00:09:24.100
it all ends up getting stored in a single
location that we call syslog server.

174
00:09:24.100 --> 00:09:28.240
And now, all of our devices can
actually send it to a managed and
