00:22:33.220 --> 00:22:36.620
Notification, Information,
and Debugging, okay?

403
00:22:36.620 --> 00:22:39.331
So make sure you understand that.

404
00:22:39.331 --> 00:22:41.375
Now for you and me though, okay?

405
00:22:41.375 --> 00:22:44.310
As we start to do that we will kind
of talk about something else here.

406
00:22:44.310 --> 00:22:48.120
But just kind of remember that this is
the order that you want to remember.

407
00:22:48.120 --> 00:22:51.500
So from the top to the bottom,
the top one is gonna be the most severe.

408
00:22:51.500 --> 00:22:53.550
>> Right.
>> You also have a pneumonic.

409
00:22:53.550 --> 00:22:56.170
Now this idea of a pneumonic for

410
00:22:56.170 --> 00:23:00.190
what we want to do is this is how
we describe what has happened.

411
00:23:00.190 --> 00:23:04.150
So an UPDOWN here tells me that
something happened on that interface.

412
00:23:04.150 --> 00:23:06.970
What I did,
is I Issue to shutdown a no shutdown.

413
00:23:06.970 --> 00:23:09.310
And when I did that,
it actually had an UPDOWN signal.

414
00:23:09.310 --> 00:23:12.260
And then the description here tells
you that something else happened.

415
00:23:12.260 --> 00:23:14.780
Notice it says changed the state to down.

416
00:23:14.780 --> 00:23:19.050
So this is probably when I issued a
shutdown, so I could grab this command and

417
00:23:19.050 --> 00:23:20.390
do this.

418
00:23:20.390 --> 00:23:23.380
So that's the way that we normally
describe it as an UPDOWN, okay?

419
00:23:23.380 --> 00:23:26.650
So if you want to refer to it anyway,
especially

420
00:23:26.650 --> 00:23:30.530
when somebody is asking you if you call in
support and you go, hey, I have an UPDOWN.

421
00:23:30.530 --> 00:23:33.150
Well, the timestamp is not gonna
be important to somebody on

422
00:23:33.150 --> 00:23:34.460
technical support.

423
00:23:34.460 --> 00:23:37.240
But the idea of the UPDOWN is,
and the idea of, hey,

424
00:23:37.240 --> 00:23:41.990
I'm getting a severity level of 0,
well that might be a 2.

425
00:23:41.990 --> 00:23:45.582
Whatever it might be, that's something
that you want to understand, okay?

426
00:23:45.582 --> 00:23:50.346
But usually it helps us to at least
manually debug now as we start seeing

427
00:23:50.346 --> 00:23:52.385
information coming across.

428
00:23:52.385 --> 00:23:53.463
All right.

429
00:23:53.463 --> 00:23:54.820
Do I need to memorize this?

430
00:23:54.820 --> 00:23:57.527
Yes, but in the severity, okay.

431
00:23:57.527 --> 00:23:59.966
So is there an easy way and
the funny thing is,

432
00:23:59.966 --> 00:24:02.460
I'm into this idea of a mnemonic, right?

433
00:24:02.460 --> 00:24:05.323
>> Okay.
>> So here's what I learned from a world

434
00:24:05.323 --> 00:24:11.170
famous Cisco teacher, Todd Lammle and
I was, okay, this is cool.

435
00:24:11.170 --> 00:24:15.590
So here this is the easiest way I know
to memorize it cuz he was the one that

436
00:24:15.590 --> 00:24:16.468
told me about it, okay.

437
00:24:16.468 --> 00:24:20.480
He said there is the easiest way for
you to memorize syslogs and severity logs.

438
00:24:20.480 --> 00:24:26.120
Every Awesome Cisco Engineer Will
Need Information Daily, okay?.

439
00:24:26.120 --> 00:24:27.793
So notice E,

440
00:24:27.793 --> 00:24:36.950
Every Awesome Cisco Engineer Will
Need Information Daily, okay?

441
00:24:36.950 --> 00:24:41.870
So if you can remember that pneumonic,
hopefully that will give a leg up,

442
00:24:41.870 --> 00:24:44.690
in remembering the severity levels here.

443
00:24:44.690 --> 00:24:47.340
And just associate,
I will write in severity level, and

444
00:24:47.340 --> 00:24:48.620
write in not only these.

445
00:24:48.620 --> 00:24:50.710
But write these and copy it down,

446
00:24:50.710 --> 00:24:53.130
make sure you understand what
you are seeing it, okay?

447
00:24:53.130 --> 00:24:56.405
So there's a lot of good information
when you start to take a look at

448
00:24:56.405 --> 00:24:59.340
what's actually happening
as you start doing this.

449
00:24:59.340 --> 00:25:00.020
>> Very well done sir.

450
00:25:00.020 --> 00:25:04.800
>> So, this is important because I am,
again, I can't

451
00:25:04.800 --> 00:25:08.850
guarantee you that you'll absolutely
see something like that on the exam.

452
00:25:08.850 --> 00:25:15.320
But I wouldn't put it past Cisco to say
we need to know if our professionals

453
00:25:15.320 --> 00:25:20.650
are really able to take a look at
the data that they're given and

454
00:25:20.650 --> 00:25:24.460
determine something like,
is this device still functional or not?

455
00:25:24.460 --> 00:25:29.690
Well, I know at least at this point,
right, if it is probably a one or

456
00:25:29.690 --> 00:25:35.640
a zero, maybe a one is still okay,
but zero means it's not functioning.

457
00:25:35.640 --> 00:25:38.610
Notice that even a one it says
immediate action is needed,

458
00:25:38.610 --> 00:25:41.020
and that means something
is about to go wrong.

459
00:25:41.020 --> 00:25:45.740
Critical is saying, I am seeing all
the indications of imminent failure.

460
00:25:45.740 --> 00:25:49.500
If you don't do something about it,
it's gonna become unusable, okay?

461
00:25:49.500 --> 00:25:51.030
So, just realize that you'll see that, but

462
00:25:51.030 --> 00:25:54.600
most of the time, when we
are normally seeing, of course then,

463
00:25:54.600 --> 00:25:57.980
especially in the messages like what we
are doing, notice this UPDOWN, right?

464
00:25:57.980 --> 00:25:59.200
I shut down that port.

465
00:25:59.200 --> 00:26:05.430
It's only a severity level which is
a notification here of five means normal.

466
00:26:05.430 --> 00:26:09.320
That's significant, that's what we are
normally looking for is between five and

467
00:26:09.320 --> 00:26:10.030
six, right?

468
00:26:10.030 --> 00:26:16.710
Where it says normal, normal those
are good five and six are good too.

469
00:26:16.710 --> 00:26:18.340
Seven is always good as well,

470
00:26:18.340 --> 00:26:22.270
but it also may indicate you need to
turn off debugging if you are done.

471
00:26:22.270 --> 00:26:25.680
Because debugging messages can overwhelm
a router if you're not careful.

472
00:26:27.040 --> 00:26:30.120
But once you get beyond that four warning,

473
00:26:30.120 --> 00:26:36.000
hopefully the actual description here,
the adjective that they're using warning,

474
00:26:36.000 --> 00:26:39.400
error, critical,
immediate action is needed.

475
00:26:39.400 --> 00:26:42.030
Okay, hopefully that tells
you something like yeah,

476
00:26:42.030 --> 00:26:44.012
something else needs to
be done at this point.

477
00:26:44.012 --> 00:26:45.469
>> [LAUGH]
>> And you gotta take care of it.

478
00:26:45.469 --> 00:26:48.440
Yeah, at least that's what
you hope ends up, okay?

479
00:26:48.440 --> 00:26:53.300
So the Cisco console, it doesn't tend
to show us in red letters, okay?

480
00:26:53.300 --> 00:26:56.440
And it doesn't have an alert,
like a beeping that continues to go off.

481
00:26:56.440 --> 00:27:01.180
It may go up in flames before it actually
does any other beeping that too.

482
00:27:01.180 --> 00:27:03.960
But just realize that that's
why we keep trackers.

483
00:27:03.960 --> 00:27:07.460
So, the more messages that we get, instead
of sitting right here on the router and

484
00:27:07.460 --> 00:27:13.440
trying to console into it, we would be
monitoring our own syslog server, instead.

485
00:27:13.440 --> 00:27:14.830
And this is where we would do that.

486
00:27:14.830 --> 00:27:19.000
So, of all the other routers and switches,
they will actually come in here, and

487
00:27:19.000 --> 00:27:21.640
then if we had that
ability with this tool.

488
00:27:21.640 --> 00:27:26.820
We could even see multiple logging
messages indicating from whom,

489
00:27:26.820 --> 00:27:30.940
which will actually be like
16.2.3.4 whatever might be.

490
00:27:30.940 --> 00:27:33.448
And we could even see the time and
date stamps.

491
00:27:33.448 --> 00:27:36.690
And those are matching up and
correct, are not you-name-it.

492
00:27:36.690 --> 00:27:39.950
And then of course take a look at the
logging messages themselves, whether or

493
00:27:39.950 --> 00:27:42.190
not they are working
the way that they need to.

494
00:27:42.190 --> 00:27:46.155
So that or at least what we wanna
demonstrate in terms of just monitoring,

495
00:27:46.155 --> 00:27:51.110
remember that the command is really
simple, logging, and then the IP address

496
00:27:51.110 --> 00:27:57.210
or even the word host and the IP address

497
00:27:57.210 --> 00:28:01.950
And then on the other end we just need to
verify that we have a syslog server which

498
00:28:01.950 --> 00:28:08.100
is indicated at least by this tab, not so
much the TFTP 32 which is part of it,

499
00:28:08.100 --> 00:28:13.240
but is a basic syslog server here and
these can be very sophisticated too, okay?

500
00:28:13.240 --> 00:28:15.230
So Zack,
that's actually a demonstrating for

501
00:28:15.230 --> 00:28:17.080
us in terms of the monitoring
that we're doing.

502
00:28:17.080 --> 00:28:20.810
But there's still a few other types of
infrastructure maintenance things that we

503
00:28:20.810 --> 00:28:23.440
have to but that'll be for
different episodes.

504
00:28:23.440 --> 00:28:24.300
>> Well done, sir.

505
00:28:24.300 --> 00:28:27.750
Implement device monitoring,
great episode as usual, Ronnie.

506
00:28:27.750 --> 00:28:29.640
And before we move on to anything else.

507
00:28:29.640 --> 00:28:33.590
>> Well, once again we're starting to see
where we're winding down a few things.

508
00:28:33.590 --> 00:28:37.250
The commands are no longer as
technically challenging anymore.

509
00:28:37.250 --> 00:28:38.690
But they are essential and

510
00:28:38.690 --> 00:28:42.010
they are actually gonna be things that
you're gonna need to be able to do.

511
00:28:42.010 --> 00:28:45.540
Because now we're talking about
trying to maintain these devices,

512
00:28:45.540 --> 00:28:50.600
the only way you and I can do that is
by having good, solid information, and

513
00:28:50.600 --> 00:28:53.785
making sure that we're getting all that
stuff set up the way that we want to.

514
00:28:53.785 --> 00:28:58.700
So, look over this,
this shouldn't be at this

515
00:28:58.700 --> 00:29:03.460
point a topic that scares you,
you should see where, my gosh,

00:29:03.460 --> 00:29:07.380
it really is just that simple,
one keyboard and an IP address?

517
00:29:07.380 --> 00:29:12.050
Yes and then the other side,
just turn on the TFTP server and

yes, that's pretty much about it.

519

And it will start working as long as

520

>> And you will be working fine as long

Cisco CCENT.

Great series Ronnie has put together for

ITProTV is binge worthy.

00:29:34.679 --> 00:29:36.259
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review basic device management.  They discuss the need for backing up a router or switch's configurations using tftp.  They demonstrate how to do this from the Cisco CLI.  Also, they review the use and configuratiion of Layer 2 discovery protocols.
episodes.title: Configure Device Management

Especially if there's a lot

So we're going of course demonstrate

I know how to backup our, well,

The great thing is, regardless of

And the reason why as I knew that

And it's more important for

Now, let's go ahead and

It goes through, let me hit the spacebar

So there's a few, there's not a lot

Now there is something that is different,

00:05:57.259 --> 00:06:00.950

00:06:04.351 --> 00:06:08.610

Ronnie, before we move on,

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie review some of the basic device hardening configuration. The team walks through basic configuration setting up the device for use in a network.
episodes.title: Implement Initial Device Hardening

WEBVTT

>> Hello and

We're gonna be implementing
initial device hardening.

Yes, we are.

And the person doing that for

>> Thank you Zach, for

Remember that we are now in our fifth

We're taking a look at
the infrastructure in maintenance and

today we get to talk

Now the great thing is,

as we began in the networking
fundamentals we did cover this topic.

But we covered it in brief portions of it.

20

We've talked about some of

But we wanna do a little bit of review,

23

For you taking the skills that
you've learned during this show and

then applying it into real life.

25

So that is what we're also doing as well,
and we need to talk about this idea of

device hardening.
>> Mm-hm.

27
00:01:11.523 --> 00:01:13.059
>> One of the issues that you're hearing

about today,

usually when you're reading about it.

Of course on the Internet, on blogs and
different tech sites that's out there,

31
00:01:20.959 --> 00:01:23.714
is that the devices that
people are buying, right?

32
00:01:23.714 --> 00:01:26.675
Is that they buy it,
put it right out of the box and

they just put it into production.

34
00:01:29.180 --> 00:01:30.270
But they don't reconfigure it.

35

They don't do anything.

36

And that means that the device, whatever

37

it also gets carried into your
production network as well.

38

And Cisco usually, it does a good

it's because policies have changed

40

But to give you an example of

true productivity right out of the box.

00:01:54.908 --> 00:01:56.421
And I mentioned this over and

over again during the entire

45

All of the ports are on by default,

46

So you don't have to implement a password,

47

A switch will work just as

So does that sound like bad?

No, you're saying, hey,
that's great for productivity, but

it is bad, because if you now
have one of those switches,

52
00:02:25.200 --> 00:02:28.680
which there are a lot of ports on,
you have a lot of empty ports.

53
00:02:28.680 --> 00:02:32.220
It also means that there is a chance then,
that somebody

54

else could come along that's a little

56

And they would be on and they would

57

So just by you not having some type of

58
00:02:47.570 --> 00:02:51.230
you may want to consider and
you may want to take a look at, okay?

59

The other part, though, is like routers.

60

Routers implement a little bit more

you have to do some basic configuration.

62
00:03:00.310 --> 00:03:03.660
So if you don't know what that

63
00:03:03.660 --> 00:03:05.960
And I'm not telling you that's
a true security measure, but

64
00:03:05.960 --> 00:03:08.660
it's a security measure just by default.

65
00:03:08.660 --> 00:03:10.412
But if you don't how to configure it,
you'll not gonna be able to use it.

66

But secondly, the other part is,
even if you configure it, the force,

67
00:03:15.231 --> 00:03:18.470
the physical force on
routers are normally off.

68
00:03:18.470 --> 00:03:21.030
In other words,
they're shutdown by default.

69
00:03:21.030 --> 00:03:24.670
And then you have to turn them on by
issuing a no shutdown command to be able

70
00:03:24.670 --> 00:03:26.475
to have traffic flow through them.

71

Well today, we're not only
talking about things like that,

which we've covered before

73
00:03:32.535 --> 00:03:36.959
But we also wanna make sure that
we review some of the additional

00:03:36.959 --> 00:03:39.547
things that we can do, as of course,

75
00:03:39.547 --> 00:03:44.481
a Cisco professional to well properly
secure devices as well, okay?

76

So today, instead of just using the labs,

because there is no official practice labs

78

What we actually are gonna do is were

So let's take a look at my screen here and

80

So I am consoled into a real
router at this point and

if you were watching this show at the very

00:04:07.928 --> 00:04:10.285
It's a Cisco 3845 router.

00:04:10.285 --> 00:04:14.258
I've kinda cleared off the config,
so that we can start clean and

84

fresh with this one.
>> Mm-hm.

85

>> As we start off here.

86

But if I were to put that into

what are some of the things that I'd want
to configure just for basic hardening?

Now, we're not doing

89

When you start talking about that,
you're going and you're turning off

different protocols that you may not use

And that's something

and there's plenty of

But in this one, we're just doing the

00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:43.779
the exam.

95
00:04:43.779 --> 00:04:44.953
>> Initial hardening,

96
00:04:44.953 --> 00:04:45.768
okay?

97
00:04:45.768 --> 00:04:46.317
>> So Zach,

98

let's talk about this
idea of getting access

>> Okay.

100
00:04:50.800 --> 00:04:51.540
>> So right now,

there's nothing actually on this router.

So normally when you first start it up,
okay and

it finishes its boot up process,

Usually it'll ask you, do you wanna

And it'll give you a chance

So if you do that you just

then you'll have a pretty

ready to be put into basic use,

And they even do a little bit

But I choose the word no instead and when

00:05:21.849 --> 00:05:26.470

We wanted to actually be right here.

Notice the host name

So let's go ahead and start some

00:05:37.760 --> 00:05:42.960
Because if I try to get access in from

oops, if I can type it in here, enable.

00:05:45.840 --> 00:05:49.430
Well, notice that it didn't require

I just type in enable the command that

Now, in the most basic authentication

Now, when we start doing that, right?

Basical authentication is saying,

So we can set something like that up,

So the password that I want is a password

enable to bring you into

it's gonna require a password instead,

00:06:38.280 --> 00:06:41.080
So the way that we do that

00:06:45.940 --> 00:06:46.690
And there we go.

00:06:46.690 --> 00:06:48.988
So now I have a password set for me.

And what I wanna do here

00:06:59.670 --> 00:07:02.403
If I spelled everything right, I'm okay.

142

And then we'll press Enter.

143

So I just saved my initial configuration

did here was implement some

00:07:12.980 --> 00:07:18.220
So if I exit out of this and it kicks

00:07:18.220 --> 00:07:20.940
Now when I come back here,

147
00:07:20.940 --> 00:07:26.050
I type in enable, well,

00:07:26.050 --> 00:07:29.680
So then I just type in my password and
we're just gonna use Cisco here.

149
00:07:29.680 --> 00:07:30.800
And there we go.

150
00:07:30.800 --> 00:07:34.940
So that's basic, basic,
basic authentication.

151
00:07:34.940 --> 00:07:40.190
Now, the problem with that though is, what
that means that if I tell Zach one time,

152
00:07:40.190 --> 00:07:43.330
Zach here's the password to

153
00:07:43.330 --> 00:07:47.073
Well, Zack may not even know, but he goes
around he starts talking about, hey,

154
00:07:47.073 --> 00:07:50.337
I know what the password is to
the router that Ronnie's configuring.

155
00:07:50.337 --> 00:07:54.496
Well, Zach may have an unintentionally
I hope, not intentionally,

156
00:07:54.496 --> 00:07:57.210
passed that password to somebody else.

157
00:07:57.210 --> 00:08:00.574
And I can just say Zach was the only
one that knew the password.

158
00:08:00.574 --> 00:08:03.436
Well Zach can say,
I knew what the password was but

159
00:08:03.436 --> 00:08:05.080
I didn't touch the router.

160
00:08:05.080 --> 00:08:08.401
And Zach may honestly have
never touched that router, but

161
00:08:08.401 --> 00:08:10.926
somebody is still gaining access in, why?

162
00:08:10.926 --> 00:08:15.676
Because Zach or myself we just happened to
share the password and that gets in, okay?

163
00:08:15.676 --> 00:08:18.560
So that's a problem that
we might end up having.

164
00:08:18.560 --> 00:08:20.340
So how can we stop that?

165
00:08:20.340 --> 00:08:24.581
Well, what we want to do is we want
to implement what we call local

166
00:08:24.581 --> 00:08:25.850
authentication.

167
00:08:25.850 --> 00:08:29.794
Now, this is just on that one word, right?

168
00:08:29.794 --> 00:08:32.469
Enable and
you saw me where I said enable and

169
00:08:32.469 --> 00:08:35.603
then password, and
then we could do that, okay?

170
00:08:35.603 --> 00:08:41.616
But what if I wanted this to actually be

171
00:08:41.616 --> 00:08:44.712
So, that username and
password believe it or not,

172
00:08:44.712 --> 00:08:47.313
is considered advanced authentication.

173
00:08:47.313 --> 00:08:49.253
It doesn't sound advanced today.
>> No.

174
00:08:49.253 --> 00:08:50.719
>> But when they first implemented it,

175
00:08:50.719 --> 00:08:53.450
it was actually advanced
authentication at that point.

176
00:08:53.450 --> 00:08:56.940
So, and technically in the Cisco realm,
they called it

177
00:08:56.940 --> 00:09:00.920
the New Model Authentication,
is what they ended up calling it.

178
00:09:00.920 --> 00:09:04.540
So now, let's say that what
we want to do is we wanna

179
00:09:04.540 --> 00:09:07.990
actually do a new model password instead,
okay?

180
00:09:07.990 --> 00:09:11.370
So the way that we do that is
now back on the router itself.

181
00:09:11.370 --> 00:09:17.255
I want to create just a simple
username and password database.

182
00:09:17.255 --> 00:09:20.160
That's the easiest way to describe it,
it's just a simple username and

183
00:09:20.160 --> 00:09:21.217
password database here.

184
00:09:21.217 --> 00:09:26.320
So if I do this, I just type in username,
and I'll just do Ronnie for right now.

185
00:09:26.320 --> 00:09:29.870
And then with the password, we're just
gonna stick to Cisco cuz it makes it easy.

186
00:09:29.870 --> 00:09:31.860
Now, you in real production,
you shouldn't do that,

187
00:09:31.860 --> 00:09:34.940
shouldn't use a simple password,
should be using something more complex,

188
00:09:34.940 --> 00:09:38.010
but that is the example,
we'll just do this.

189
00:09:38.010 --> 00:09:39.150
I can do that.

190
00:09:39.150 --> 00:09:42.800
I can also go to username,
and then we'll do Zach.

191
00:09:44.020 --> 00:09:45.890
And then whatever password
that I want to set for Zach,

192
00:09:45.890 --> 00:09:47.060
I'm just gonna do the same thing here.

193
00:09:47.060 --> 00:09:48.660
And that's perfectly fine.

194
00:09:49.970 --> 00:09:53.462
Now that I have that,

maybe two things, let me make sure.

421
00:22:22.140 --> 00:22:24.250
Actually, yeah,
a couple of last things here.

422
00:22:24.250 --> 00:22:27.780
And then, we'll do a few things
as we go on through, okay?

423
00:22:27.780 --> 00:22:31.060
So the next thing that we're
talking about right now,

424
00:22:31.060 --> 00:22:34.860
is we also want to configure a banner.

425
00:22:34.860 --> 00:22:37.260
Now, what the heck is a banner about?

426
00:22:37.260 --> 00:22:38.950
Well, let me go ahead and get out.

427
00:22:38.950 --> 00:22:43.920
Let's do a copy, copy run start here,

428
00:22:43.920 --> 00:22:49.010
which is an abbreviation for copy running
dash config space start up dash config.

429
00:22:49.010 --> 00:22:52.142
So once I get to this point here,
and let me change that,

430
00:22:52.142 --> 00:22:56.620
we'll leave it at switch right now, so
that's actually kind of funny, okay?

431
00:22:56.620 --> 00:23:02.278
So normally, when you get here, okay,
as you log in either from the console but

432
00:23:02.278 --> 00:23:06.838
usually from a Telnet session or
a SSH section coming in, well,

433
00:23:06.838 --> 00:23:12.520
you wanna make sure that people that
are connecting in are given a message.

434
00:23:12.520 --> 00:23:16.470
And the reason why is that you want to
ensure that there is some legality to

435
00:23:16.470 --> 00:23:20.350
this, that if they make
an unauthorized connection,

436
00:23:20.350 --> 00:23:25.320
that it tells them right away that
they were not welcomed to be here.

437
00:23:25.320 --> 00:23:29.500
So these particular banner messages
that we can create allow someone,

438
00:23:29.500 --> 00:23:33.870
if they accidentally connect,
that it tells them they shouldn't connect.

439
00:23:33.870 --> 00:23:37.460
We can even have it actually something
that's actually different if we wanted to,

440
00:23:37.460 --> 00:23:38.610
which is we can create, also,

441
00:23:38.610 --> 00:23:42.300
a different banner instead of just
a message that pops up for them.

442
00:23:42.300 --> 00:23:43.820
We can create a different
type of banner where,

443
00:23:43.820 --> 00:23:47.630
if Zach logs in, it gives a message like,

444
00:23:47.630 --> 00:23:50.706
So that way, he actually has a message
from whoever actually is administrating it

445
00:23:50.706 --> 00:23:51.695
if he wanted to, as well.

446
00:23:51.695 --> 00:23:54.810
But there's a couple of different types
of banners that we can create, and

447
00:23:54.810 --> 00:23:56.550
that's what we need to do, okay?

448
00:23:56.550 --> 00:23:58.537
So I'm gonna log in as myself now.

449
00:24:05.018 --> 00:24:05.981
And then gain access.

450
00:24:05.981 --> 00:24:07.331
And let me go back to the router here.

451
00:24:09.460 --> 00:24:11.800
Oops, I gotta get into
global configuration mode.

452
00:24:11.800 --> 00:24:13.107
I always forget that.

453
00:24:13.107 --> 00:24:15.875
hostname R1.

454
00:24:15.875 --> 00:24:18.979
Let's just do something like
that just very easily, okay?

455
00:24:18.979 --> 00:24:23.007
All right, so when we talk about
creating this type of banner,

456
00:24:23.007 --> 00:24:27.910
we're specifically caught out on
the exam to create a login banner.

00:24:27.910 --> 00:24:34.026
Now a login banner normally shows up
right before the authentication prompt.

458
00:24:34.026 --> 00:24:36.743
For you and me, that is right here, okay?

459
00:24:36.743 --> 00:24:39.400
So right before that
authentication prompt.

460
00:24:39.400 --> 00:24:44.350
There's another banner that we can

00:24:44.350 --> 00:24:49.720
implement called an MOTD,
or a Message of the Day.

462
00:24:49.720 --> 00:24:51.710
Which shows to everybody, okay?

463
00:24:51.710 --> 00:24:54.260
Regardless of whether or
not they're at a login or not.

464
00:24:54.260 --> 00:24:58.630
When it comes up as a connect in it says,
here is a message that you should read.

465
00:24:58.630 --> 00:25:01.670
Essentially both of those at this point,
right?

466
00:25:01.670 --> 00:25:06.100
Usually on the log-in banners,
it may be informational, instructional for

467
00:25:06.100 --> 00:25:08.110
someone like Zach that I'm working with.

468
00:25:08.110 --> 00:25:10.934
Or in Mesh, it'd be just a warning, okay?

469
00:25:10.934 --> 00:25:13.121
So either one can actually be that way.

470
00:25:13.121 --> 00:25:17.932
So we are going to configure this to help
us out on just creating just creating

471
00:25:17.932 --> 00:25:19.680
just a login banner first.

472
00:25:19.680 --> 00:25:23.717
So when we do something like this, let's
get into our global configuration mode,

473
00:25:23.717 --> 00:25:24.417
which I am in.

474
00:25:24.417 --> 00:25:26.740
Then it's fairly simple,
I type in the word banner.

475
00:25:27.870 --> 00:25:31.210
And now I did a question mark so
that you can see a couple of things, okay?

476
00:25:31.210 --> 00:25:34.740
The one that we're gonna do is right here,
set login banner.

477
00:25:34.740 --> 00:25:36.680
Notice that there's a few of them.

478
00:25:36.680 --> 00:25:40.798
The Message of the Day, this is the one

479
00:25:40.798 --> 00:25:44.400
of whether or not there's a login
that's presented them, to or not.

480
00:25:44.400 --> 00:25:46.490
So you'll see if you can
figure both of them,

481
00:25:46.490 --> 00:25:50.120
the Message of the Day will
proceed the log inbound.

482
00:25:50.120 --> 00:25:55.944
There's also the ability to do what we
call an exact process banner as well,

483
00:25:55.944 --> 00:25:56.495
okay.

484
00:25:56.495 --> 00:25:59.240
And this also is another one that
is out there and available to you.

485
00:25:59.240 --> 00:26:03.120
Displayed right before the user
sees the exec privilege mode.

486
00:26:03.120 --> 00:26:06.250
So when you actually
finally do authenticate,

487
00:26:06.250 --> 00:26:09.400
you actually get another banner if you
actually wanna configure all of that.

488
00:26:09.400 --> 00:26:15.620
And then there's even an incoming banner

489
00:26:15.620 --> 00:26:17.000
Now if you choose something like this,

490
00:26:17.000 --> 00:26:21.550
this is gonna be if you enable something
like what's called reverse telnet.

491
00:26:21.550 --> 00:26:25.150
We're not getting into that, so we're not
gonna worry about it for right now, okay.

492
00:26:25.150 --> 00:26:29.480
But for us, usually it's the two,
it's the MOTD and the login banner.

493
00:26:29.480 --> 00:26:31.090
So we'll just see.

494
00:26:31.090 --> 00:26:32.413
I actually have us doing both.

495
00:26:32.413 --> 00:26:33.629
So we'll go and configure both.

496
00:26:33.629 --> 00:26:36.035
But let's do one at a time here.

497
00:26:36.035 --> 00:26:39.589
All right, so let's say that we wanna set
a message for people that try to log in.

498
00:26:41.020 --> 00:26:45.190
So the way that we do that is once we
get here, we start typing in banner, and

499
00:26:45.190 --> 00:26:46.600
then login.

500
00:26:46.600 --> 00:26:50.820
And now I'm gonna hit the question mark so
that you can see something, okay?

501
00:26:50.820 --> 00:26:55.570
Now, notice that after banner login,
it says LINE, all in capital letters here.

502
00:26:55.570 --> 00:26:58.570
And this is where it gets tricky if
you haven't done this before, okay?

503
00:26:58.570 --> 00:27:02.798
Banner text and notice the way that
they're trying to show an example.

504
00:27:02.798 --> 00:27:08.200
If they used the letter C,
then you type that in right here, okay?

505
00:27:08.200 --> 00:27:10.508
Right where I had the question mark.

506
00:27:10.508 --> 00:27:14.578
Then you type in whatever you want to and
at the end of the message,

507
00:27:14.578 --> 00:27:16.990
you type in the letter C again.

508
00:27:16.990 --> 00:27:19.190
The problem with the letter C is simple.

509
00:27:19.190 --> 00:27:22.050
You might use the letter
C inside of your message.

510
00:27:22.050 --> 00:27:26.530
Which means if you do that,
if you use a C, somewhere along the line,

511
00:27:26.530 --> 00:27:28.970
it's gonna say you ended the message,
okay?

512
00:27:28.970 --> 00:27:29.850
So don't do that.

513
00:27:29.850 --> 00:27:34.770
Usually, the one that I like to
use is Shift, no, not Shift.

514
00:27:34.770 --> 00:27:37.050
Yeah, yeah, Shift and the number 6.

515
00:27:37.050 --> 00:27:39.980
I keep looking down like,
that's not right, no, but it is.

516
00:27:39.980 --> 00:27:42.750
Shift and number 6,
which is the little caret mark.

517
00:27:42.750 --> 00:27:46.610
That's the one that I like to use,
when I do something like this cuz

518
00:27:46.610 --> 00:27:50.400
I don't know when I would ever use that
inside of a message, but you can, okay.

519
00:27:50.400 --> 00:27:53.210
So let's show you the idea.

520
00:27:53.210 --> 00:27:55.210
So banner login.

521
00:27:55.210 --> 00:28:01.640
And now I'm going to do the Shift and
the caret symbol.

522
00:28:01.640 --> 00:28:03.590
I'm gonna press Enter and now look.

523
00:28:03.590 --> 00:28:06.220
Now enter the text message that we want.

524
00:28:06.220 --> 00:28:11.335
So it's right here I want to actually

525
00:28:11.335 --> 00:28:15.297
say authorized users only.

526
00:28:15.297 --> 00:28:20.970
All right, so if I am done with that,
and I say it's the end of the message,

527
00:28:20.970 --> 00:28:25.470
I can do a Shift and
the number 6 again, and press Enter.

528
00:28:25.470 --> 00:28:27.820
And you're saying that's it,
is that all that there is?

529
00:28:27.820 --> 00:28:29.070
Yep, sure.

530
00:28:29.070 --> 00:28:32.120
Let's get back out here,
and let's exit of this.

531
00:28:32.120 --> 00:28:36.340
So I'm all the way back out to the user
mode, and now notice, look at that.

532
00:28:36.340 --> 00:28:38.190
There's the banner.
>> There it is.

533
00:28:38.190 --> 00:28:39.740
>> It's actually right there, so

534
00:28:39.740 --> 00:28:43.470
every time it brings this up,
that's what puts in place here.

535
00:28:43.470 --> 00:28:48.070
So you might be wondering like, why are
you actually stating something like this?

536
00:28:48.070 --> 00:28:51.970
Because what's happened in the past Zach,
at some point, right?

537
00:28:51.970 --> 00:28:56.160
Is that people have actually seen these
messages, like the Message of the Day.

538
00:28:56.160 --> 00:28:58.785
Normally it says,
welcome to the ITProTV network.

539
00:28:58.785 --> 00:29:00.670
So once you actually issue
that kind of welcome,

540
00:29:00.670 --> 00:29:03.160
it's like you putting a welcome mat out.
>> I think so.

541
00:29:03.160 --> 00:29:04.790
>> And hackers go,

542
00:29:04.790 --> 00:29:07.360
well you welcomed me to
come into this network.

543
00:29:07.360 --> 00:29:10.110
So he didn't say, how I could come in.

544
00:29:10.110 --> 00:29:12.048
But that's what you don't want to do.

545
00:29:12.048 --> 00:29:16.210
So you wanna make sure that these messages
are usually very direct and to the point,

546
00:29:16.210 --> 00:29:19.805
that if you're not supposed to be here,
you're not supposed to be here.

547
00:29:19.805 --> 00:29:24.270
So it's not something that you'll
actually end up seeing but

548
00:29:24.270 --> 00:29:26.820
people will actually look at you and go,
did you have all the warnings in place?

549
00:29:26.820 --> 00:29:29.540
Yes we had all the warnings in place,
right.

550
00:29:29.540 --> 00:29:32.198
And now let me get back in here.

551
00:29:32.198 --> 00:29:33.742
And let's do another one here.

552
00:29:38.641 --> 00:29:42.920
And so let's do the Message
of the Day banner, MOTD.

553
00:29:44.290 --> 00:29:47.900
And once again I'm going to do
the Shift and the number 6 here,

554
00:29:47.900 --> 00:29:50.970
cuz I know I'm not gonna use that
inside of that message here.

555
00:29:50.970 --> 00:29:54.425
So now what I want to do is I want to
actually put in something a little bit

00:29:54.425 --> 00:29:55.136
more direct.

557
00:29:55.136 --> 00:30:03.490
Unauthorized access is strictly-
>> Prohibited.

558
00:30:03.490 --> 00:30:05.873
>> Yep, prohibited.

559
00:30:05.873 --> 00:30:09.370
If I could spell prohibit, pro-hib-it.

560
00:30:11.530 --> 00:30:13.020
Yeah.

561
00:30:13.020 --> 00:30:14.986
And then a Shift and the number 6 here,

562
00:30:14.986 --> 00:30:17.587
okay?
>> Yep, into the caret.

563
00:30:17.587 --> 00:30:19.435
>> Yep, I'm gonna go ahead and

564
00:30:19.435 --> 00:30:21.570
get back out here.

565
00:30:21.570 --> 00:30:26.830
And now as we see this, you can see now,

00:30:26.830 --> 00:30:30.420
notice that right above the login banner,

00:30:30.420 --> 00:30:33.800
there's the Message of the Day as well,
unauthorized access zone.

568
00:30:33.800 --> 00:30:37.440
Now, believe it or not, once you actually
create this right, you can actually create

00:30:37.440 --> 00:30:39.940
it where it's fancy and

00:30:39.940 --> 00:30:44.620
There are people that create these

571
00:30:44.620 --> 00:30:45.940
They really are.

572
00:30:45.940 --> 00:30:49.830
But this banner though, you can even have
it where it actually has little numbers

00:30:49.830 --> 00:30:55.440
like I could actually make a banner and

00:30:55.440 --> 00:30:58.270
And it will actually bring him

00:30:58.270 --> 00:31:00.840

00:31:00.840 --> 00:31:04.600
And I can have something for like two

577
00:31:04.600 --> 00:31:06.130
So I can create a whole menu if I

00:31:06.130 --> 00:31:07.110
wanted to.
>> Wow.

579
00:31:07.110 --> 00:31:08.500
>> Using this banner message if I chose

580
00:31:08.500 --> 00:31:09.730
to do something like this.

581
00:31:09.730 --> 00:31:13.430
So it is very possible that we
can actually create that, and

582
00:31:13.430 --> 00:31:15.080

583
00:31:15.080 --> 00:31:19.120
All right, Zach, there's still a few

00:31:19.120 --> 00:31:23.590

So this looks like a good place for

00:31:29.280 --> 00:31:32.420
Implementing initial device hardening

You can't stop it.

It's gonna happen.

Make sure you see parts one and two.

00:31:36.480 --> 00:31:37.680
And Ronnie, before we move on,

right, but at the same time, they're very

00:31:44.810 --> 00:31:47.922
The banner,
I'd make sure that I pay attention to.

00:31:47.922 --> 00:31:51.305
But all of the other things that we've
already done this before inside of

596
00:31:51.305 --> 00:31:52.290
our series.

597
00:31:52.290 --> 00:31:54.710
So it's a simple review at this point.

598

But it's something that you

this will not cause me any issues

The only new concept
that we've put in here so

So make sure you focus in on that

To help you go furthest.

That means that even as

00:14:30.760 --> 00:14:33.290

00:14:53.320 --> 00:14:55.260

00:14:58.890 --> 00:14:59.835

know those particular settings

We're not gonna really emphasize

So practice, practice, practice every

So that you get everything that

Review everything as well, and

636

Cisco CCENT is a terrific series.

Ronnie's done a great job

ITProTV is binge-worthy.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take an opportunity to work through the logic of tackling exam questions about subnetting.  They review the questions, answers and logic after each question

Okay, so we are trying to show you

So, if you spotted it right away,
kudos to you and you're doing a great job.

90
00:05:23.100 --> 00:05:26.510
If you're needing a hint or
a practice, do it the way that I did.

91
00:05:26.510 --> 00:05:30.530
Once you get those numbers above 128,
start counting at 128.

92
00:05:30.530 --> 00:05:35.220
If you realize that the network interval
here is gonna be 8, count by 8 from 128.

93
00:05:35.220 --> 00:05:38.840
If it's going to be 16,
count by 16 from 128 if you need to.

94
00:05:38.840 --> 00:05:43.430
But I like using those high numbers
because most of us kind of don't do that,

95
00:05:43.430 --> 00:05:46.030
start in the middle of something and
try and figure it out.

96
00:05:46.030 --> 00:05:50.620
All right,
let's move on to number 8 here, okay?

97
00:05:50.620 --> 00:05:53.410
So, as we start to take
a look here at number 8,

98
00:05:53.410 --> 00:05:55.410
which of the following are NetworkIDs?

99
00:05:57.040 --> 00:06:00.670
So let's make sure that we understand
the concept of NetworkIDs and

100
00:06:00.670 --> 00:06:03.718
make sure you read the question clearly,
okay?

101
00:06:03.718 --> 00:06:06.670
There's three ways that they can get
you even on a question like this.

102
00:06:06.670 --> 00:06:09.880
They might ask you about, which of
the following is a network host, right?

103
00:06:09.880 --> 00:06:12.550
So remember that that's actually
individual devices within the subnet.

104
00:06:12.550 --> 00:06:15.280
They can ask you about
the broadcasts as well and

105
00:06:15.280 --> 00:06:18.090
they can ask you about the idea of IDs.

106
00:06:18.090 --> 00:06:23.370
The NetworkID, if you remember correctly,
or the network number itself, right?

107
00:06:23.370 --> 00:06:26.800
Is the one where all of the host bits that

108
00:06:26.800 --> 00:06:32.400
are available in my subnet,
that they're all zeros.

109
00:06:32.400 --> 00:06:35.610
But the problem that you have is that you
only have a minute per question to be able

110
00:06:35.610 --> 00:06:36.681
to do something like this.

111
00:06:36.681 --> 00:06:40.720
If you only have a minute per question
to do this, you can't take the time to

112
00:06:40.720 --> 00:06:45.500
essentially change all
of these into binary and

113
00:06:45.500 --> 00:06:47.535
then go, okay,
which portion is the host portion?

114
00:06:47.535 --> 00:06:51.510
But, you have to be able to kind of
spot a couple of different things.

115
00:06:51.510 --> 00:06:56.389
The first thing, of course, is take a look
at the subnet mask that you have, okay?

116
00:06:56.389 --> 00:07:01.742
So, I'm going to go ahead and go,
hey, I know what the subnet mask is,

117
00:07:01.742 --> 00:07:04.887
its 255.255.255.192.

118
00:07:04.887 --> 00:07:06.618
Well, how do I know it's 192?

119
00:07:06.618 --> 00:07:11.447
Because the first three gives me 24
bits and then if I do slash 25, well,

120
00:07:11.447 --> 00:07:17.050
that's going to be a 128, then I'm gonna
do a slash 26, that's gonna be 192.

121
00:07:17.050 --> 00:07:22.930
So now I have my network interval at
that point which is gonna be 64, right?

122
00:07:22.930 --> 00:07:26.690
So if I do 64 at this point,
let me go ahead and take a look.

123
00:07:26.690 --> 00:07:29.270
Look at that, they gave me 128.

124
00:07:29.270 --> 00:07:35.560
Well, what is the next network up from
128 that is actually an interval of 64?

125
00:07:35.560 --> 00:07:38.110
Well, that would be 192.

126
00:07:38.110 --> 00:07:41.570
So I know which one it's not going to be.

127
00:07:41.570 --> 00:07:43.970
It's not gonna be b here, okay?

128
00:07:43.970 --> 00:07:46.020
Well, what about this 0 here?

129
00:07:46.020 --> 00:07:50.190
Well, that is possibly a NetworkID, okay?

130
00:07:50.190 --> 00:07:54.070
So it is very possible that
that is a NetworkID, as well.

131
00:07:54.070 --> 00:07:57.580
And this one is also a possibility, too.

132
00:07:57.580 --> 00:08:00.090
Now, the problem that I have with the 64,
right?

133
00:08:00.090 --> 00:08:05.585
128 and the next network is 192, well,
I have to go a little bit further.

134
00:08:05.585 --> 00:08:10.270
Well, what is 64 up from 192?

135
00:08:10.270 --> 00:08:11.585
Well, I hate to say it.

136
00:08:11.585 --> 00:08:16.760
From 192 to get to 224,
that's only 32 instead.

137
00:08:16.760 --> 00:08:21.068
So, at this point, what you'd have to
actually be able to understand and

138
00:08:21.068 --> 00:08:25.640
do here is to realize that it's
gonna be these two as well, okay?

139
00:08:25.640 --> 00:08:29.360
So with this /26 it makes sense here,
okay?

140
00:08:29.360 --> 00:08:30.160
But now with the /23, well,

141
00:08:30.160 --> 00:08:35.900
that's one more that actually gets
into the Class B network here.

142
00:08:35.900 --> 00:08:39.429
It gives me one Class B network but
with 512 hosts.

143
00:08:39.429 --> 00:08:45.479
And so, the range for
this one goes from 172.16.1.0,

144
00:08:45.479 --> 00:08:50.101
all the way through 172.16.2.254.

145
00:08:50.101 --> 00:08:54.920
So, make sure you review that as you
start to continue to study, as well.

146
00:08:54.920 --> 00:08:59.500
And so, don't be tripped up by saying, hey
look, I recognize that there is a pattern.

147
00:08:59.500 --> 00:09:01.820
Well, we already recognized those numbers,

148
00:09:01.820 --> 00:09:05.480
make sure you also pay attention
to the subnet mask itself or

149
00:09:05.480 --> 00:09:10.240
you're gonna get thrown off by that,
the speed and accuracy is the key.

150
00:09:10.240 --> 00:09:14.230
All right, now,
let's take a look at 9, here, okay?

151
00:09:14.230 --> 00:09:17.020
Which of the following
is a valid subnet mask?

152
00:09:17.020 --> 00:09:19.460
And now I have it listed as choose 2.

153
00:09:19.460 --> 00:09:21.600
Most of the time,
especially on Cisco exams,

154
00:09:21.600 --> 00:09:25.870
and even on CompTIA exams, they're not
gonna try and make you guess a ton of them

155
00:09:25.870 --> 00:09:27.540
because they realize they have
a limited number of time.

156
00:09:27.540 --> 00:09:30.780
So they're gonna say, tell me which of
the two are actually gonna be valid.

157
00:09:30.780 --> 00:09:33.530
Well, this is where you have
to be able to distinguish

158
00:09:33.530 --> 00:09:35.770
whether it's a subnet mask or not.

159
00:09:35.770 --> 00:09:40.910
Remember that the easiest to do that is
that a subnet mask in binary term, right?

160
00:09:40.910 --> 00:09:45.920
Is always a contiguous string of zeros
from the left hand, the farthest or

161
00:09:45.920 --> 00:09:49.770
the most significant bit all
the way to the right hand side,

162
00:09:49.770 --> 00:09:51.622
the least significant bit.

163
00:09:51.622 --> 00:09:56.000
And if that is actually what is happening
when you're taking look at this, right?

164
00:09:56.000 --> 00:09:58.220
That means that there
cannot be any drops at all.

165
00:09:58.220 --> 00:10:00.127
No zeroes in between that.

166
00:10:00.127 --> 00:10:03.967
So if I were to take a look
at this first one here, well,

167
00:10:03.967 --> 00:10:09.142
that starts off with eight bits in a row
but, then this is actually is six bits and

168
00:10:09.142 --> 00:10:13.020
two zeroes and
this is eight bits in a row again.

169
00:10:13.020 --> 00:10:16.410
Well, that one absolutely
has eliminated itself.

170
00:10:16.410 --> 00:10:20.930
I know this one just because it's a Class
C default, which is perfectly fine.

171
00:10:20.930 --> 00:10:23.690
Now, it looks like b, c, and d,

172
00:10:23.690 --> 00:10:28.660
well, they're all contiguous strings,
is what we actually have here, too, okay?

173
00:10:28.660 --> 00:10:33.780
So this third octet here is five ones and
three zeroes in the third octet.

174
00:10:33.780 --> 00:10:37.250
And this one doesn't
have any of them at all.

175
00:10:37.250 --> 00:10:41.510
So now it comes down to
the term valid subnet mask.

176
00:10:41.510 --> 00:10:46.290
Well, technically, this is not
a valid subnet mask or a subnet.

177
00:10:46.290 --> 00:10:50.568
This is what we call a host subnet mask,
is what this one is called.

178
00:10:50.568 --> 00:10:54.760
So we wanna pick two of them,
what we would do is actually find

179
00:10:54.760 --> 00:10:58.260
those two that are actually
valid in this point, okay?

180
00:10:58.260 --> 00:11:00.150
So the last one, is it a subnet mask?

181
00:11:00.150 --> 00:11:02.750
Yes, but is it a valid one for a network?

182
00:11:02.750 --> 00:11:05.180
Probably not, okay?

183
00:11:05.180 --> 00:11:09.080
So that now leads us to
the final one that we have.

184
00:11:09.080 --> 00:11:14.040
So the key here, of course, is to be quick
and to, again, be accurate about this.

185
00:11:14.040 --> 00:11:16.220
Which of the following mask corresponds,

186
00:11:16.220 --> 00:11:19.750
at least I hope I spell that right,
to a /22?

187
00:11:19.750 --> 00:11:24.040
Well, that means that what
you're taking a look at here is,

188
00:11:24.040 --> 00:11:27.700
well, which one is it that actually
shows me 22 bits in a row?

189
00:11:28.720 --> 00:11:31.580
You might be able to take
the time to write out 22 ones

190
00:11:31.580 --> 00:11:33.680
in terms of binary in a row.

191
00:11:33.680 --> 00:11:37.360
And then, just look at that last
octet that you need to, and

192
00:11:37.360 --> 00:11:40.750
figure out what that number would
convert to to help you out.

193
00:11:40.750 --> 00:11:44.280
So, if you start off with something like
that, you'd have to actually go, wait,

194
00:11:44.280 --> 00:11:47.090
that's 24 bits,
I know that went from a Class C.

195
00:11:47.090 --> 00:11:49.880
So, that one's out of the question,
that one doesn't actually do that.

196
00:11:49.880 --> 00:11:52.250
So, eliminate that one from your mind,
okay?

197
00:11:52.250 --> 00:11:53.760
Well, what about this one?

198
00:11:53.760 --> 00:11:57.400
Okay, if I do something like this one,
first 16, and

199
00:11:57.400 --> 00:12:02.280
then I start realizing that
this window is 240 here.

200
00:12:02.280 --> 00:12:06.150
Well, that would actually be four one so
that's 16 plus 4, that's 20.

201
00:12:06.150 --> 00:12:07.250
So I can eliminate d.

202
00:12:07.250 --> 00:12:10.600
So that leaves me with b and c here, okay?

203
00:12:10.600 --> 00:12:12.490
So from this point,
this is what you'll have to do.

204
00:12:12.490 --> 00:12:16.960
You'll have to make a decision on which
one you think is the most likely guess.

205
00:12:16.960 --> 00:12:18.934
Now the other way that you can do that,

206
00:12:18.934 --> 00:12:23.332
instead of doing the whole thing is just
concentrate on the third octet here, okay?

207
00:12:23.332 --> 00:12:26.359
So this is from you doing
the binary math in the head and

208
00:12:26.359 --> 00:12:28.456
realizing what's happening here.

209
00:12:28.456 --> 00:12:36.500
A 252 is going to be, well,
six ones and two zeros.

210
00:12:36.500 --> 00:12:40.725
And then the 248 is going to
be five ones and three zeros.

211
00:12:40.725 --> 00:12:45.420
Well, if I take a look at that and
I realize something like that, well,

212
00:12:45.420 --> 00:12:51.480
that means 16 and 16 plus 6,
that sounds like 22 to me.

213
00:12:51.480 --> 00:12:54.470
And that is a /22, okay?

214
00:12:54.470 --> 00:12:57.760
So, that is something
else that you can also do

215
00:12:57.760 --> 00:13:01.020
to help you out to be able to do this,
okay?

216
00:13:01.020 --> 00:13:07.440
Now, that kind of ends our little bit of
subnetting review for what you have, okay?

217
00:13:07.440 --> 00:13:09.790
But do not stop with this review and

218
00:13:09.790 --> 00:13:12.950
think I've got this subnetting
thing licked here, okay?

219
00:13:12.950 --> 00:13:17.310
What you want to do is you want to
create your own questions if you can.

220
00:13:17.310 --> 00:13:20.390
Make sure you understand the binary,
and the conversions, and

221
00:13:20.390 --> 00:13:22.020
the idea of subnetting.

222
00:13:22.020 --> 00:13:26.200
Your goal is to take like all ten
of those questions that we have and

223
00:13:26.200 --> 00:13:29.130
be able to answer each one in a minute or
less.

224
00:13:29.130 --> 00:13:32.570
Now, obviously, I didn't do that

225
00:13:32.570 --> 00:13:35.390
because I was trying to explain to you
the logic and how I would attack it

226
00:13:35.390 --> 00:13:39.630
on the exam if I didn't know how
to spot them very quickly, okay?

227
00:13:39.630 --> 00:13:41.850
So, use the simple
methods that you do know.

228
00:13:41.850 --> 00:13:44.310
Eliminate the answers that
are wrong right away.

229
00:13:44.310 --> 00:13:47.525
And just focus in on
the ones that may be right.

230
00:13:47.525 --> 00:13:50.280
So don't take a lot of
time trying to figure out

231
00:13:50.280 --> 00:13:52.830
whether every single
one is actually right.

232
00:13:52.830 --> 00:13:55.410
If they only ask you for two,
remember that means you can eliminate two.

233
00:13:55.410 --> 00:13:58.390
So try and eliminate those two right away.

234
00:13:58.390 --> 00:14:00.330
If it takes you a little bit longer,
that's fine.

235
00:14:00.330 --> 00:14:05.060
But where it should take you the longest
time is during your preparation and

236
00:14:05.060 --> 00:14:08.630
looking at these questions as well and
looking at different question that you can

237
00:14:08.630 --> 00:14:12.220
find and
even creating your own questions, too.

238
00:14:12.220 --> 00:14:16.410
And that way, you'll be better up on the
practice and being able to identify that.

239
00:14:16.410 --> 00:14:18.960
The more that you can see
these numbers and see this,

240
00:14:18.960 --> 00:14:21.390
it will help you out as you get ready for
the exam.

241
00:14:22.570 --> 00:14:27.080
So make sure you are practicing subnetting
at this point on a daily basis and

242
00:14:27.080 --> 00:14:31.310
do not let that go all the way
through your time of study together.

243
00:14:31.310 --> 00:14:34.840
And that way you'll engrain and you'll
start seeing the patterns in your head,

244
00:14:34.840 --> 00:14:38.700
and you'll be able to tackle problems
like this very easily without

245
00:14:38.700 --> 00:14:42.380
very little thought of you having
to write the binary at all.

246
00:14:42.380 --> 00:14:44.530
But if you have to do it now,
this is the best time to do it.

247
00:14:44.530 --> 00:14:46.930
On the exam,
you're going to waste a lot of time and

248
00:14:46.930 --> 00:14:48.820
you don't have time to waste there.

249
00:14:48.820 --> 00:14:52.360
So, do take some time and

250
00:14:52.360 --> 00:14:55.520
And also, of course,
